name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on China's market economy status (2016/2667(SDR)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the question of granting market economy status to China is one of unprecedented political significance for the European Union, given its wide-ranging implications. Not only will it affect EU trade, but deriving from it, jobs and growth as well. Obviously the EU must comply with its obligations under WTO law, but it must also balance the legitimate concerns of European producers, consumers, and users, while acknowledging China’s position as a strategic trading partner. Clearly the EU is under high pressure from its industries and civil society to take a decision on this matter. On the Council side, we will examine the full potential impact of our decision in order to give the question a solid and well-founded answer. This is why the Council very much welcomes the work being carried out by the European Commission, in particular the open public consultation of stakeholders and a full impact assessment. In addition, it is important not to lose sight of the potential effects of the EU’s decision in this matter, beyond the trade aspects of our relations with China. Yes, the Council is very much aware of the alarming situation of the EU steel industry, which is facing a serious crisis as a result of global overcapacity, in particular in China. Now, as you will know, the Council has not yet taken any position, for the very reason that the right to initiate legislation belongs to the Commission. In other words, the Council looks forward to the results of the Commission’s impact assessment and stands ready to work with the European Parliament and the Commission in the best interests of EU industry and European citizens. In the meantime, the Council has restarted discussions on the Commission’s 2013 proposal on modernising the EU’s trade defence instruments (TDIs). Although it is not for me to prejudge the outcome of the ongoing work, let me underline that this might be the moment to reflect on how to improve our trade defence mechanisms with a view to better tackling unfair trade practices and to ensuring a global level playing field for EU companies. In the same context, the recent release by the Commission of its communication on steel has been a welcome initiative to examine how to strengthen our defences against unfair competition and cheap imports.  In closing, and considering the importance of the subject, the Foreign Affairs Council, in trade formation, will discuss the Commission’s communication from a trade angle this coming Friday May 13, including new Commission ideas on how to modernise the EU’s trade defence instruments and in particular in the light of the economic damage caused by overcapacity in third-country markets.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is very clear that the issue of market economy status for China, as well as the overcapacity issue in the steel sector, are two of the most important trade issues facing us. The Commission is treating them as an utmost priority. While the EU-China relationship is of the utmost importance, it is undeniable that China is not a market economy by any standards. We know that is not the question here. We are working very hard to find a solution, but that is not easy. Clearly our trade defence instruments need to be efficient and effective, independently of the expiry of certain provisions of China’s WTO Accession Protocol. Let me tell you where we are. The three options we are considering are, firstly, we do nothing. This would mean no change in legislation, an option that we consider would pose a high legal risk, given that the European Union’s and other countries’ methodology for China is based on the very elements of the Protocol which expires in December this year.  Secondly, we remove China from the list of non—market economies and apply the standard dumping calculation methodology. This is usually called granting market economy status to China. Our analysis of this option so far and the feedback from many stakeholders show that it would involve a very high cost in terms of potential job losses in the European Union, as the Union would not be able to allow fully for the distortions existing in the Chinese economy and would therefore no longer be able to provide the necessary protection against unfair trading practices. Even without the current climate of overcapacity, any such move would be untenable. Thirdly, we change the anti-dumping methodology by introducing a new approach which would maintain a strong trade defence system in the EU, while giving effect to the expiry of certain provisions of the China Accession Protocol. This approach would help ensure that the dumping margins calculated would, for the most part, reflect the ongoing distortions in the Chinese economy more accurately. The EU would thus be following the example of the United States. The Commission’s public consultation ended on 28 April and generated almost 5 300 sponsors, as well as some 150 additional submissions delivered by citizens, industrial associations and other stakeholders in the form of letters, position papers, emails, etc. In addition, almost 300 stakeholders attended a Commission conference on 13 March, which was followed by a consultation with the social partners on 15 April. The economic study carried out by external economic experts is also being finalised. The additional work on the study aims to enlarge upon the results and provide more information about the impact of the options at both Member State and sectoral level.  The input received and the feedback from all of these sources is being compared and analysed at present, and the findings will be reflected in the impact assessment. Given the massive interest and the volume of representations received, it takes time to draw conclusions. Once the impact assessment has been finished, as it will be in the coming weeks, the College is planning to discuss the matter again before the summer recess. We are also in close contact with our non-European Union G7 partners on the issue, bearing in mind of course that the specific features of each legal system differ. Irrespective of the legal interpretation of Section 15 of China’s Protocol of Accession to the World Trade Organisation, let me reassure you that the Commission’s overriding aim is to ensure that the EU will continue to have a trade defence system that will remain strong and effective in the face of unfair trading practices – practices which, as we see, are especially frequent when there is massive overcapacity , not only in the steel sector, but in many other sectors as well.  It is becoming more urgent than ever for the modernisation package to be adopted. Parliament has done its job, but unfortunately the Council has been unable to take matters forward. As you know, the Commission is making every effort to help the Member States to break the deadlock. The adoption of the modernisation package has also been mentioned in the connection with the steel communication.  I know that I can count on the European Parliament’s determination to continue playing its role in finding a solution in the best interest of the European Union.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The strategic partnership with China is important to us, and whether China is not a market economy today or not, and whether China has market economy status today or not, we see that today many tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, steel workers are taking care of their jobs, and then we realise that we urgently need to do something to further strengthen our trade defence instruments.  This is not the first time today: we had the situation in the footwear sector a few years ago, then two years ago we had the situation in the solar sector, and now we have the situation on the steel markets. In other words, we now know that China does not have market economy status today, and yet we are not in a position to react quickly, appropriately and effectively. That is why, dear representative of the Council, you are right that the Commission has the right of initiative. But the Council has no right to block it and you have been blocking the much-needed reform of trade defence instruments in the Council for years, which is now falling on our feet again. Please finally break this blockade in the Council!

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to make it very clear that the Group of The Party of European Socialists and Democrats is currently opposed to China being given market economy status. And this for a simple reason: today China, despite the progress made, is not a market economy. Let us not take refuge behind technicality. What is at stake is the future of European industry and millions of jobs. We have a duty to listen to the well-founded concerns of those workers who fear for their jobs.  Chinese industries have been dumping in the steel sector for years, but all manufacturing could be affected by unfair competition. Faced with this risk, in the name of the precautionary principle, we have a duty to stop. The recognition of market economy status would in fact be an irreversible choice, and there can be no compromise solutions or mitigation measures in relation to this. There are only two possibilities: either China fully meets the five criteria that define the market economy (and I challenge anyone to say that the conditions are there today) or China cannot be granted this status. This does not mean, in any way, denying the friendship between China and the European Union, which is and will remain strong, but today a risky decision would contribute to the suicide of European industry. We do not want to be jointly responsible for an historic mistake. For these reasons, my group has called for this Parliament to debate this issue today and to vote tomorrow on a resolution sending a peremptory message: the ES MES to China cannot be recognised.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, a Commission proposal on how to deal with the expiry part of China’s accession protocol to the WTO is imminent. The ECR Group believes that certain fundamental principles should be considered within this process and these should go hand in hand with the Commission’s impact assessment with industry, with some 5 000 responses, and it is vital that the results of these are taken into account ahead of any proposals being made.  Firstly, and undoubtedly, the case that Chinese contravention of world trade rules has led to the dramatic decline of our own industries, most notably steel in the UK, in recent months. Nevertheless, we expect the EU to lead the way on global trading rules and if we want China to play by the rules we have to do so ourselves. We therefore need to ensure the full compatibility of EU law with the EU’s obligations arising from its WTO commitments, as well as the legal consequences of changes to China’s accession protocol. We also need to determine the full legal meaning of those sections of the protocol which will remain after 11 December 2016 so that we know how to proceed in our relationship with China.  That being said, we must also consider the practical consequences as well as the legal ones. The positive and negative medium and long-term effects for industry, Member States’ economies, and societal impacts need to be known ahead of any decision that is taken. We cannot do this blindly. And in order to deal with any of these negative repercussions in the future, it is critically important that we retain full ability to take timely, necessary and effective measures to tackle anti-competitive market prices by EU trading partners. These market-distorting actions result in injury to EU industry and having tools to combat them guarantees that the EU companies can continue to operate on a global level playing field. The clock is ticking towards the December deadline and we await the Commission’s proposal to ensure future trade is fair.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, today’s debate on how to shape the rules-based trade system and how one of our main trade partners, China, can be held to its commitment to fair trade practice is key for Europe. We need to ensure EU policies are in place after the protocol of China’s WTO accession, which was agreed to 15 years ago, expires. Our Group feels strongly about not leaving this to the WTO courts to decide. Not only do we need solid EU trade defence instruments in general, but specifically the EU needs to be able to apply anti-dumping measures in cases of dumping of goods by China beyond the end of this year.  Our Group wants a thorough assessment of the legal consequences of the expiration of the protocol, as well as a long-term legal, economic and political impact assessment. We look forward to seeing the results of the outcome of the public consultation and the Commission’s impact assessment. We need EU measures to be WTO compliant. It is the only credible way to underline the importance that we adhere to global trade based on rules that apply equally to all. This debate is not, contrary to what the name may suggest, a debate on whether or not China’s economy operates according to free trade and fair competition laws and principles. We share the concerns about state interference, the creation of overcapacity, the lack of transparency and the existence of reliable indicators that can predictably verify whether prices are the result of supply and demand or whether they are kept artificially low.  What we do know is that wages and environmental standards are lower in China than they are in the EU. In fact, importers in Europe benefit from this aspect of globalisation, and it can also lead to lower prices for consumers. So it is key to look at all sides of this debate, both the short-term implications and the long-term, and particularly also to liaise with our trading partners and key allies in making the right decisions in this complex but impactful file.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Chinese government has made overcapacity a priority. In the coal and steel sectors, 1.8 to 5 million people are estimated to lose their jobs. Cynicism of the market economy: the price of steel is rising again. Nevertheless, it is precisely here that there is great concern for jobs, including in many Member States of our European Union. And outside, the steelworkers are protesting. The problems arose from management errors as a result of the fall in demand in China, from weaker economic growth, to which the EU economy had become accustomed and which was often used by local companies as the engine of European economic growth. The Chinese market has long compensated for the EU's lack of industrial policy plans and investments, which have now become apparent after years of prolonged and unresolved economic crisis. However, the debate on market economy status and the choice of weapons in a trade war is misleading and does not provide a solution for jobs. The EU and China must learn and regulate common existence. We need a corrective approach on both sides and constructive solutions based on and within the framework of the WTO. I therefore call on the Commission not only to negotiate with China on investment protection, but to negotiate an agreement for fair trade and against price, social and environmental dumping, in the interests of jobs here and there. Incidentally, this could have happened a long time ago if the Council had developed the instrument of trade defence measures. Waiting for Godot as a principle of action does not help.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Madam Minister, I would like to thank the I believe that we all agree that, on the one hand, we are talking about hundreds of thousands of jobs in European industry, and that we are talking about fair international trade and the need to fight against dumping properly. We want and need a modern, innovative, sustainable and competitive European industry. That is why, as has been said, we must answer this question in a solid and good way. I believe that there are two principles that are at the heart of this. Firstly, we comply with WTO law, we comply with the rules, we do not discriminate – not even against China. Secondly, we are ensuring that we have and retain effective defence instruments against dumping.  I agree with the basic course, because you, Commissioner, have set out for the Commission. The legal analysis, the economic logic and also the political needs lead to the same consequence: we must reform our anti-dumping directive in a WTO-compatible manner; we need to improve defence instruments against dumping, i.e. TDI; we must continue to be able to apply non-standard methodology on a case-by-case basis, as the US does, while allowing Chinese companies or industries to prove that they are operating in a market economy. If we do that, we can meet the two objectives, WTO compatibility and the defence of European interests.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate of recent months has served to make us understand how Europe can become hostage to a legal dilemma, to the point of forgetting the essential foundations of any trade relationship: mutual respect and mutual interest. China is not a market economy, everyone recognises it, perhaps even China itself. We do not want to establish what the WTO rules say. We do not want to cling to more or less bold interpretations of the Accession Protocol. We want to address the Commission and demand that it assume its responsibilities, first and for all that of guaranteeing respect for and application of the Treaties, which stipulate that the Union promotes economic growth and employment, and in relations with the rest of the world defends the general interest of Europe. Now, in these months of obstinate and opaque silence on the part of the Commission, we have not been content to wait. We have organised dozens of meetings, we have listened, we have launched a public counter-consultation. And what we have heard is an unequivocal cry of alarm, a dramatic request for help from entire industrial sectors – some even outside this building today – who fear the tsunami of Chinese competition without any brakes. And certainly no one feels reassured by the Commission's incredible statements of limited and limited impact.  This is an indictment: you are not defending the general interest, but a sterile zero-sum equation between jobs lost and jobs created, which in fact only defends liberal and mercantilist interests. We do not want Europe to be held hostage to a legal trap. We want the WTO to be a place of recomposition of each other's interests: that of Europe opening up more to China and that of China to open up more to Europe. We must have the courage not to recognise China's status as a market economy until it sings the five criteria laid down by the European Union, while respecting fair and balanced relations. There is no excuse for China. There is no other way for Europe.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in opening the discussion, I wanted to remind you that the virtual total free trade with China has devastated French and European industry. These ridiculous border protections are imposed on Europeans by promising that they will benefit by focusing on high value-added products. You were wrong again. The European countries have paid for this huge mistake for you by the loss of a large part of their industry and by enormous social suffering. Quite predictably, huge wage differences and very unequal social, health and environmental regulations have worked, industries have left entire regions to the Chinese skies, workers have been laid off by the millions and have often never found work. You promised the Europeans that the Chinese would settle for the low end and that we would develop the industry of the future. The Chinese are selling us televisions, phones, internet networks, and so on. It is a huge field of ruins that your irresponsible policy has left on our soil. Today, China is no longer able to grow as fast and has colossal production overcapacity in many sectors. If you grant China market economy status, you will once again profess a huge lie since China has chosen to be highly interventionist in its economy. Even worse, World Trade Organization rules will no longer allow us to protect ourselves from products sold at broken prices by a Chinese industry in chronic overproduction. Do you want to trigger another catastrophe or will you stop rendering the Member States of the European Union powerless? There is another way that this absolute free trade brings ruins and conflicts: it is a reasonable protection at the borders, it is intelligent protectionism that allows countries to develop their industry, their jobs, their wealth. Do you remember the Havana Charter? This beautiful objective of a world where trade would not, at best, be a game of dupes, at worst, a game of massacre, and where the balance of trade balances would allow a truly fair trade. I see this as the path we should take.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Of course, China is not a market economy, but none of the Countries of the European Union is a market economy – all governments are interfering in the market in a much larger way than in China. I wanted to ask you if you are aware that the Chinese are also buying things from us, and if we buy cheaper steel, then mercedes will become cheaper and the Chinese will be able to buy more of them, but also Europeans will be able to buy more of these Mercedes? I am amazed that none of the socialists here in the room care about the interests of the ordinary grey man, they all care only about the interests of the big industry, here just steel. I ask Miss Le Pen or Mr Bütikofer whether, if the Chinese promised to give us any amount of steel for free for ten years, should we take it or not? After all, it is beneficial if they gave for free, yes or no? More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our decision on the trade relationship with China will affect hundreds of thousands of European citizens, strategic industrial sectors – the steel industry, above all – but also the future of our relationship with China, which is the strategic partner of the European Union. Automatic recognition of China's market economy status is not a viable option, which is why we call on the European Commission to identify viable trade defence instruments that can be applied to ensure the protection of the steel industry, other industrial sectors against unfair competition and dumping. We believe that dialogue with China and other WTO partners will lead to the identification of the best solutions in the mutual interest of the two strategic partners, Europe and China. However, we owe it to the citizens to secure the future of workers in the European industry, in the steel industry and for vulnerable European companies.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister, we have asked for this debate decisively because we believe it is essential for Parliament to express its opinion on such an important issue as the representative of all European citizens. This is not a battle against China, which we recognise as a major trading and political partner and certainly not as an enemy. Ours, on the contrary, is a battle for fair and sustainable global trade.  The European Union is trying to set up a trade strategy that has the ambition to define rules and standards globally. But if the partners do not comply with these rules, all trade policy collapses. China, regardless of its formal status, is not a market economy and our businesses, if we legislators do not act, would be successfully offered unequal weapons. What we want is not protectionist measures, but a fair and competitive system. That is why we are asking the Commission: firstly, that there should be no automatic recognition of market economy status; secondly, that there should be a legislative proposal aimed at maintaining the effectiveness of anti-dumping measures in a manner compatible with WTO rules; thirdly, that there should be formal coordination with other trading partners. This debate is intended to demonstrate the spirit of constructive cooperation that animates us, in the conviction that only by addressing issues transparently can the best solutions be found.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the International trade is always associated with job losses because competition is getting tougher. And if, like Mrs Le Pen, we demand 'we need intelligent protectionism', it only means postponing structural change and artificially suppressing the productivity of an economy. I believe that if the Chinese are doing intelligent protectionism in importing cars, then we are the ones who suffer. I am always sceptical about dumping, because I think that is always a way of protecting yourself from foreign competition.  However, it has to be said that there is also a form of cut throat competition. Mr Korwin-Mikke said that if we can produce steel for free, that is good for consumers. Of course! But if our own industry then perishes because state-owned enterprises can, of course, collect an infinite amount of losses, then that means that we are destroying a competitive steel industry and that we are then at the mercy of the Chinese. In this respect, we must take care to prevent cut throat competition. Market economy status can only be conferd if state-owned enterprises are really involved in the competitive process.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: – Mr President, china's market economy is a big issue. We know this history. The promise made 15 years ago with China's membership of the WTO now obliges us to reflect on this issue. It's a rule-based deal. Common rules are needed and the WTO has tried to maintain them. However, it is also a question of those rules and values, the EU is a community of values. We must also take care of this side. When considering China and the criteria for market economy, China currently meets one of these five criteria. Of course, it is a big question how they could meet these remaining criteria. So China is not a market economy country, that is clear. It is also a question of how we can act together against the dumping of China. Our steel industry has suffered as a result in Europe. However, here too it should be borne in mind that dumped duties currently account for less than 2% of Chinese imports into the EU. What is needed at the moment is a clear impact assessment of the Commission's direction – that is what we expect – and on that basis this decision can be taken. Personally, I believe that there are currently no conditions for granting market economy status, because the facts speak against it.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my clear opposition to the recognition of China's market economy status, stressing that this is a strategic debate for the future and the Union's trade policy. Not only does China not meet the requirements for the recognition of market economy status, but this is about thinking about the future of the EU's trade policy: do we want it to serve to raise labour standards and rights, or do we want it to be the vehicle for a downward competition on labour rights?  It is not just a question of defending European jobs, it is a question of defending the quality of work. It is not a question of protectionism, it is a question of protecting labour rights. It is also a question of protecting one of the strategic axes, that of the European industry. It is estimated that the recognition of the ES MES to China would result in a reduction in GDP of between 1 and 2 %, mainly affecting countries with manufacturing output. For the Italian steel industry, this would be a devastating choice.  We therefore call on the Commission to act multilaterally for a review of anti-dumping and a reform of the WTO, while at the same time denying China the status of a market economy today.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, China is obviously a trading and political partner. We must treat this country with respect and intelligence. The problem is that today in Europe there is no trade diplomacy. We have a common trade policy, but when it comes to trade diplomacy with China, we have 28 states that act separately from each other. When we mobilised the European Parliament on the issue of Chinese dumping on photovoltaic panels, what did we see? First, that Europe did not have the commercial defence tools sufficiently relevant and robust to protect the competitive European photovoltaic panel industry. But we also found that, all of a sudden, because China does not speak to Europe - it speaks to the 28 European leaders - Europe has broken down.  We have seen France let go because of the threats to wine, and Greece, because of the threats of investment in the port of Piraeus. China has divided Europe by threatening every state. Germany preferred to sell its machine tools that produced Chinese photovoltaic panels rather than impose anti-dumping rules. We are still seeing it with the steel industry - one of the most affected countries, the United Kingdom, with a Prime Minister who is still hesitant to do anti-dumping - because we are afraid of China. Therefore, we cannot give China market economy status once we have not seriously strengthened our collective capacity to do anti-dumping, as well as our collective ability to have an industrial policy, to have trade diplomacy and to weigh in at 28 with China and, in some cases, against China. That is the order of the day: today, to give China market economy status would be to politically kill Europe, it would be to return to the nation-states that will weigh nothing and it would be extremely counterproductive from an economic and social point of view.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, we are having this debate because of the effect of Chinese dumping on the steel industry in particular. I am very proud to say that I worked for 20 years in the steel industry. I started off way back when there was such a thing as British Steel, a company that started in Wolverhampton, and I had a very good long career in the steel trade. During that time, I have seen the British steel trade decline, and although it is still fighting hard and is technologically far more advanced than it ever was, it is still up against it.  I share the frustrations of the protesters outside. This is a time when the politicians really need to be helping our industry and our people. I represent the West Midlands of England, an area that grew to be great through the steel trade, through the manufacture and production of steel. That is how we became a world—famous area, and I am very proud of that as well. But now we are a shadow of what we once were. Yes, some of it is to do with appallingly bad British Government decisions over the years – no one to blame but ourselves. Some of it is due to the application of crazy directives about green taxation and carbon emissions, which has caused damage to us. But now we have aggressive dumping by China, which is distorting the market. This is not about free trade. It is a hostile act to destroy our steel industry.  If we allow this aggressive dumping, we will lose a vital part of our manufacturing base. We will lose a vital part of our tradition and our history – certainly in the UK – and it is strategically vital that we keep an operational steel industry. So, first and foremost, I would ask the British Government to act on this – to have some guts for once and stand up for British manufacturing. But even then, I would urge the people here, just once, to do one thing to help manufacturing and not give China market economy status.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the debate that confirms that Europe does not exist. Now let's not make fun of it. I would like to see this debate attended by any of the workers, craftsmen, fishermen, farmers massacred by the crazy policies of this Europe and a Commission that imposes restrictive laws on our farms.  As far as the environment is concerned, they go around the world and say that we must not pollute, and rightly so, and then there are some who think that they are making agreements with those who do not comply with any legislation in environmental terms, in union terms, in terms of health, in terms of wages. There is someone who wants to place some goods in China and therefore wants to slaughter the steel, ceramics, textile, paper and glass sectors. It's surreal. Someone can stand up here this morning and say that it is the sun that revolves around the Earth and we will certainly find someone in the European Commission who brings us a regulation that explains to the 500 million Europeans that it is the sun that revolves around the Earth. It's bullshit. It's the Earth circling the sun. China is not a market economy. If there is any European Commissioner or member of the European Parliament who is paid by european citizens to do the interests of others go to work elsewhere, go and work in China, but first step in front of an Italian or European factory, which will close if such madness is approved. On the other hand, from a Europe that is unable to defend its borders, which gives EUR 6 billion to Turkey under the blackmail of the invasion of immigrants, which continues to quarrel with Russia – which, yes, would be a trading partner, other than Turkey and China – I do not expect anything. I hope that this Europe will die as soon as possible and that another more serious, more democratic, freer and more modern Europe will be reborn as soon as possible. (The speaker refused to answer a blue card question)

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: – Mr President, our main job as Members is to defend the interests of our citizens, our companies and our workers. Fifteen years have passed since the beginning of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO and we have seen no will on its part to make the reforms necessary to meet the five criteria defined by the Union. That is precisely why we must refuse to give market economy status to China. This concession would have very negative consequences for Europe and would prevent us from continuing to fight unfair competition. We must protect our companies and our workers from all types of dumping, whether fiscal, social or environmental. If we are to be respected at the international level, we have to send a clear message: we will not open our markets to those States that do not respect principles of reciprocity or balance in economic relations.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, this debate is not really about China, but about whether Europe collectively has the political will to defend its manufacturing industry. As the UK steel industry – and EU industry in general – struggles to remain competitive in the face of a tsunami of subsidised imports, the Council, as others have said, has sat on its hands and failed to tackle the reform of trade defence instruments. Unfortunately, I have to acknowledge that my own country is one of those who have been failing to push for urgent reform. But I want to stress in this debate that reform of TDI alone would not allow us to grant MES to China. Chinese prices are not generally reliable, and they do not respond to market forces. We need a non-standard methodology like the analogue country one if we are to deal with China. I asked the Council to unblock TDI reform as soon as possible and the Commission to present a proposal which takes fully into account the potential repercussions on EU jobs and the future of EU industry. Socialists in this House will not accept a proposal which weakens our manufacturing sector and puts thousands of jobs at risk.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say very clearly that China is not a market economy. There is no market economy where the state intervenes heavily to drug a world market in relation to real costs. There are two fundamental points, Mr President, because we can never accept that. We have fought so hard for workers' rights, environmental rights, essential rights in this Europe that may or may not like us, but there is, perhaps it must be changed but it should not be closed, I would like to say this. But a step like this is crucial for my country, but I also believe for Europe. It is not possible to imagine that, with the money of the community of a country, we can attack a sector at world level such as the steel industry, which is clear that the cost of ore is higher than the product, the finished steel. Faced with these facts, I believe that no one, not even the one who has the most interests, perhaps with a one-sector export to China, can decide to vote in favour of recognition.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, I would like to start by saying that this debate is political, it is not legal. It is political because it will have an extremely heavy impact on our European economy.  Secondly, I am very happy with the unanimity. There is total unanimity in our Chamber. I hope that the Commission and the Council will hear it and take note of it. We all consider, on any bench, that, of course, China is not a market economy and that from then on, things are simple. We must not give it market economy status. It is no more complicated than that, and I hope you hear it.  At the same time, we must act in four directions. Firstly, Europe must finally have strong, defensive trade instruments. That is not the case today. Secondly, it must finally have a common industrial strategy and a common investment strategy, particularly in all areas of the future. Thirdly, Europe, on this issue, must speak with one voice. There will, of course, be blackmail by China on the Member States.  I'm telling you, let's stay united. United, we will be strong, divided, Europe will lose.  Finally, this debate is not only a debate for experts and diplomats, it is a debate for all European citizens. I therefore hope that European democracy will take up this issue.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For 15 years, China has been undergoing a remarkable development: a reform of a planned economy towards a market economy. However, is it a genuine market economy that we are talking about? I say no. There is a lot missing. Macroeconomic management of the planned economy continues, state-owned corporations are privileged, and intellectual property is not adequately protected in China. This gives China an artificial competitive advantage. I am personally concerned and concerned. I come from Linz, the heart of Austrian steel production. And when I now think of the fact that China alone exported 134 million tonnes of steel worldwide in 2015 – thank fully, only 7.5 million to the Union – and China has 400 million tonnes of overcapacity, I am very concerned about that. This also means that we must take clear protective measures here in Europe. As long as this distortion of competition is caused by illegal measures, Europe must clearly protect the domestic economy and industry through anti-dumping measures. This is about our European economy, but it is also about millions of jobs in Europe.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, nothing in this discussion is anti-China. We need to have a good relationship with them, but we need to decide the rules by which this relationship in trade and economic issues is played. China today has a massive overcapacity in many things we produce, from steel to chemicals. It is an economy that functions on the idea of flooding our markets with their subsidised production. Whether we like it or not, free trade is on the defence. People are waking up to the fact that ideological free trade has a massive cost on society and on workers. Granting China market economy status is yet another step in this direction. We cannot subject our companies to the oncoming onslaught of Chinese export without any means of defence, and we will not. We believe that there is sufficient room in the remaining provisions of Article 15 of China’s WTO protocol to warrant a China-specific methodology, and we ask the Commission to include this in its proposal.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Union must show pragmatism with regard to the provisions of China's Protocol of Accession to the World Trade Organisation, which expires in December this year. We all know that our main objective is to preserve the interests of European companies and jobs in Europe, without jeopardising the basic WTO rules and our strategic relations with China.  As I said before, the real question here is not to grant or not grant market economy status to China. We must be clear: the expiry of the provisions of the Protocol relates only to the way in which anti-dumping measures are calculated. The correct answer must be not automatic recognition or economic confrontation, but the urgent unblocking of the modernisation of trade defence instruments (TDIs). I call on the Council and the European Commission to take responsibility and allow for the urgent adoption of a new set of trade defence instruments.  I end by highlighting the importance of the results of the impact study launched by the European Commission, which is the only credible assessment of the consequences. One more thing: time, not China, is now our main adversary, and the Council's response, which was the place of the problem, is essential.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – Shortly after our previous debate in February, the European Chamber of Commerce in China published a report on overcapacity in the People's Republic of China. The report concludes that the very role of the Chinese government in the economy is part of the problem, and that is rather mildly expressed. This is yet another proof of the fact that China is not a market economy. It is all the more reason to make informed decisions about china's market economy status quickly. European industry must be protected and remain protected from unfair competition. That is what I expect, and that is what our citizens expect, from the Council, the Commission and this Parliament.  Shortly before this debate I received news from a well-known, a Dutch employee. He's at home at the moment, he used to work in the steel industry. It is the faces and the threat of unemployment that must surely lead us in this debate on market economy status for China. Fair trade and fair competition? Unfortunately, that is not the case here.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that there is no point in reiterating concepts that we have already heard. I think it would be more useful to understand what the effects and consequences would be if we were to grant China market economy status. I believe that there would immediately be a reduction in the trade defences of the countries of Europe, particularly Italy, and I believe that this could be indicated at an estimated percentage of 30 %.  What are the consequences of this 30 % reduction? There is an economic impact, but above all employment and employment, so we are mainly concerned about our workers, about our industrial system, which would result in the loss of thousands and thousands and thousands of jobs.  I believe that it is important to reflect above all on these two concepts, because our task is, in any case, to suggest solutions. The solutions must be those that Parliament must immediately propose, over and above the 'yes' or 'no' vote - to the recognition of China's market economy status. At the same time, however, we are also fulfilling the condition that a legislative procedure should be put in place which will in any case implement trade defence and therefore new anti-dumping defence formulae against China's products.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, we had to take a decision on the granting to China of market economy status in December and this Parliament does not yet know what will be proposed to us. The Socialists are advocating strong but on a balanced and fair basis between the European Union and China, and the reality is that we do not compete on an equal footing. China does not respect WTO rules. It is not a market economy and practices social, environmental and price dumping. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to behave as such and meet the required criteria and requirements. That is why my group opposes the automatic granting of market economy status.  Look, Commissioner, I am very concerned that the public consultation launched by the Commission seems aimed at granting and that the proposed protective measures are insufficient. Chinese prices do not reflect costs and therefore cannot be applied to the standard methodology.  The European Union needs renewed, powerful, effective and rapid trade defence instruments to implement and I therefore ask the Council to unlock the situation now. Innovative sectors such as steel, such as textiles, such as ceramics, which employ millions of people, are at risk and I believe that the European Union cannot afford to lose one more job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This is a rather dizzying debate that, from December this year, we will find it more difficult to impose high safeguard tariffs on China, at least if we are to respect global trade regulations. You would think that this is something new, but no, it is something we committed ourselves to back in 2001, fifteen years ago.  The central question in this debate, which has yet again been asked, is why the Commission has not dealt with this before. It is not five to noon, it is five past twelve, and we have not yet seen a Commission proposal on how to resolve this. How will the Commission even have time to get a proposal in place if they were to propose anything now? Although this has been known for 15 years, we have to accept that the status quo is not an option.  If we change the rules, of course, those who are currently protected by safeguard duties will have a tougher time. But if we do nothing at all then there will also be consequences. Then we will have a very large trade conflict, and it is the Commission's responsibility to ensure a solution. But for 15 years you have been sitting on your hands, and that is the problem.  How will the Commission ensure that, on the one hand, the WTO regulations are complied with and, on the other hand, that we do not have a trade conflict with China? How are you going to do this?

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has One thing is clear: the European Union needs a strong, sharp sword against dumping and against abuse of subsidies in the interests of industrial work and jobs here in Europe. How do you approach that? Two things are quite clear, and the first responsibility lies with the Council: how can it be that the Council has been blocking the modernisation of trade defence instruments since April 2014? We need fast, flexible and sharp trade defence instruments. If we had them, we would not have some problems with the Chinese state at the moment. So please: the Trade Council must finally put an end to the blockade on 13 May! Secondly, the Commission must indeed put forward a proposal for alternative calculation methods after 11 December with regard to China. They have known this for 15 years! There is still nothing on the table. We must also be clear within the framework of the WTO, have alternative calculation options, so that we do not allow free tickets for dumping products in Europe after 11 December. The responsibility lies with the Commission and the Council.

name: Franck PROUST
text: Mr President, it is now impossible to grant China market economy status, and no one says otherwise. What for? Because this country does not meet the criteria that we have set. To grant it this status is to discredit all the rules that we apply. To grant it is to endanger our companies, which are subject to unfair competition in certain sectors. Some, moreover, even put forward the figure of three million jobs at stake. To grant this status is to finally question the necessary solidarity on this issue with the United States and Japan, which are with us the main customers of China.  Our approach to China must be diplomatic, technical, but above all pragmatic. Revising our trade defence instruments by removing, among other things, the lesser tariff or introducing an additional tax on chinese dumping products to create a support fund for our companies, these are realistic proposals to deal with the predictable retaliatory measures on the Chinese side.  I want to protect our European market while being in favour of free competition, but on the condition that everyone plays with the same rules.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, I welcome the presence of the Dutch Presidency because the Netherlands, along with a dozen other countries, is one of those Member States which, with rare consistency, have been blocking the issue of the modernisation of trade defence instruments for the past two years. This has just been said by our colleague Bernd Lange. That is the problem: at a time when European industry is going through a decisive and critical phase, and our workers are being put at risk, you have a dozen countries in the Council that refuse to move forward on this issue, even though the European Parliament is unanimous, because it is not just China's market economy status. Frankly, when we listen to the debate, there is no discussion: China is obviously not a market economy. The question is whether or not Europe has the ambition to protect itself and defend itself, whether or not Europe wants to be the idiot of the global village or whether, like, for example, the United States, it is ready, at some point, to take drastic measures. We have seen this on the photovoltaic file, we have done an investigation that has lasted 18 months where other continents or other countries are able to implement a 200% tax in two months. And that is really where the question lies: do the Commission and the Council want, yes or no, to listen to Parliament's message for an ambitious Europe that defends itself and protects both its workers and its consumers?

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make two comments to the Commission. The first comment concerns the protection of the market. We must not defend ourselves against the market, we must defend ourselves in the market. I do not want to spoil my entrepreneurs by convincing them that it is not necessary to have good products and it is enough to have a state that protects them. I want them to continue, in Italy and Europe, to be the leaders of world manufacturing. That is why I want to defend them in a market that defends itself against China, because it does not respect this fundamental rule. Secondly, I have heard someone here say, somewhat naively, that it is a good thing to buy products at low prices from China. Well, this is a typical statement of those who unfortunately live more in here than outside, in reality. Because those who enter our market at low prices will destroy our industry and then raise prices. This means predatory dumping. It means you won't have the choice anymore. Then we need less naivety, less theory and more defence of true excellence, of a strong and sustainable development model such as that of Europe.  That is why I say 'no' to the recognition of China's market economy status.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for her work on the Parliament, as the citizens' chamber in the EU, acts and decides this week. We urgently expect the Commission and the Council to act now. It is high time that the decision on market economy status with China was taken. Industry in Europe expects clarity. I have 15 000 steelworkers in my constituency, a few hundred have come to Strasbourg today to express their concern about the existence of an entire industry. It is high time that these people were also told where things are going after December 2016. I believe that there must be a third way between doing nothing by the end of the year and automatically awarding market economy status. As Bernd Lange said, we need equivalent instruments to protect ourselves against unfair trade practices. It is time for the Council to unblock this package now. Friday is the first opportunity to do so. And we also need immediate measures. The Commission should conclude an agreement with China on the management of these overcapacity. So: Council and Commission - please act, the people of Europe are waiting for you!

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: – Mr President, any status of free economic market with any country must be based on respect for bilaterality, fair trade and also on preserving the interests of the parties. China is the opposite of a fair and free market with the European area, as Chinese products – dumping of these Chinese products – go against the interests of the industrial and steel sectors of the European area and endanger hundreds of jobs, such as the Basque steelmakers of Sestao or Zumárraga in Spain and elsewhere in Europe. That is why the European Parliament and the European Commission must urgently take anti-dumping precautionary measures in defence of European steelmaking, and these measures are, inter alia, to set a minimum selling price of the coil tonne, to determine a border adjustment for steel, to establish green tariffs on import steel or to reward steel produced through scrap recycling.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Mr President, this debate shows whether, however, some doubted that Europe has no industrial policy, Europe has no strategy to defend its industry and the millions of jobs associated with it. The only roadmap is to organize an increased competition and, in this game, the Chinese will give us a good beating, alas. Because if your only objective is price policy, we will never be competitive with China. Everything there is much cheaper, including commissioners and ministers.  Your role - our role - is to defend the interests of European citizens, not just the consumer. Outside, there are hundreds of workers worried about their future who demand to be listened to and heard. They're worried about their future. You cannot decide for them without them, because to recognize China as a market economy is to allow everything you prohibit from the Member States. Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, which side are you on? Who will benefit from this crime? In any case, obviously, not in the world of work.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, just to underline one aspect, I am very much in favour of fair competition and liberal trade. But what we are facing today is none of that. We are facing trade in sensitive commodities with a country which, as the Commissioner has rightly pointed out, is not a market economy.  I think that what you can see today in the European Parliament is complete unity – complete unity, but also an expectation that, for once, we will act. We will act on the industrial policy and we will act on trade policy instruments, both in this particular case and in future, in general. It is a matter of fact that even in the past, when we were not facing a situation like that, it took 10 months to come to anti-dumping measures at much lower rates, while the US would come to them at a much higher rate in a much shorter period of time. So we have two dimensions here. Please address it.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the "China's market economy status" is the title of this debate. But let us be honest: we are dealing specifically with problems such as the incredible price dumping in the steel sector. Stop quoting the rules of the world market and global competition. What China is doing has nothing to do with competition and a market economy. It is a pure distortion of competition, it is state subsidy of the worst kind. I am not elected as a Member of the Chinese Parliament – no, I am fighting for Europe and our citizens! I have just spoken outside to workers in the Saarland steel industry – fathers, mothers, young apprentices who are concerned about their jobs, their income and their future. It is precisely these concerns that I hear, I take seriously and I represent here.  I say very clearly to the Commission and the Council: stop this unspeakable price dumping! Let us not allow ourselves to be demonstrated by the Chinese, let us speed up the dumping process and allow us to impose genuine, effective punitive tariffs, not 10%, but 200%! Figuratively speaking, none of us would play against a football team that flouts all the rules of the game and grossly flaws. This must apply on the world market.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, China is not a market economy, yet the European Commission seems to want to recognise it as such and, if it does, we will no longer be able to defend ourselves against its unfair commercial practices and we will be overlaused by its products.  What are we talking about? We are talking about a potential invasion of Chinese products worth EUR 145 billion, we are talking about job losses for 3.5 million people in Europe, of which about 400 thousand are in Italy alone. We are talking about a fall in GDP from 1 % to 2 %. The sectors most affected will be steel, ceramics, technology and textiles, but in the future also chemistry and advanced machinery. For Italy, as for many other countries of the European Union, it would really be the final blow. Mr President, when we talk about China, we are talking about an economy that produces 80 % of its energy from coal, that uses 40 different types of business subsidies and that practises without hesitation unfair competition aimed at destroying European industries and slaughtering our workers. So to say 'no MES China', today is our duty.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you started in your debate by saying 'China is not a market economy' and everyone here in Hemicicle has said the same thing. The problem is that it is not enough to say that it is not a market economy, but we have to act.  I think it was a big mistake. I come from the textile industry and, since 2005, I have asked the Commission, at that time, to have measures to protect European industry. We are at an intersection of three major powers: China, the United States and Russia. TTIP is just as dangerous, because America has "Buy America". We don't have Buy Europe. China has subsidy, we don't have subsidy.  The issue that is now being asked, and is crucial to our future, is: "what measures are we now taking to protect the industry?". Because now, when we speak, the European Union market is being invaded by products from China, without giving it new market economy status. The mistake must be remedied and the Council and the Commission have a historic obligation to find measures to protect European industry. Otherwise, the 22 million unemployed will not be able to find jobs in our country.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, pending the results of public hearings and the legal studies being carried out on China's status in the WTO (which I hope will be fully edested by recognising the reality, which is that China is not today a market economy), I would like to encourage the Commission to arbitrate faster mechanisms to solve the problems we have today with dumping Chinese steel. And I want a unanimous response from the Member States. Because no one can save themselves alone. In the Basque Country, two floors have already closed: Zumárraga and Sestao. And there are hundreds of jobs at stake, as in many other European regions. I also call on European steel companies more responsibility and commitment to society based on investment and innovation to gain competitiveness through the circular economy and sustainability. These are the keys to a determined commitment to its strategic role and its permanence in the European economic fabric.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, China is a huge global economy and that is why it makes sense to be a trading partner of the European Union. However, this relationship must be based on the basis of the protection of the commercial interests of the countries of the European Union. Chinese products have flooded European markets at all levels, from the most expensive to the cheapest, which is why they pose many risks and threats to the economies of the states. My country, Greece, has become a victim of this situation. Chinese products dominate Greek markets, with the result that their respective industries and crafts are forced to either close or move to other countries, and this entails the loss of many thousands of jobs and the creation of a social problem. On the other hand, Chinese products are of questionable quality and often dangerous to the health of consumers. That is why European Union legislation should protect the financial interests of the Member States.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I was happy to hear the report from the Commissioner, but also from you, where it is said that China is an important partner for us, but it is not a market economy country. Probably even by the end of this year it will not be able to meet the necessary conditions.  There is also a consensus among experts that large sectors in China are connected to the state to such an extent that it is impossible to talk about the state economy. Moreover, the over-production that China produces is also related to the low social and environmental standard of products. I am afraid that the various debates on the various legal options for how to proceed after the expiry of the relevant wto agreement at the end of 2016 are simply incomprehensible to voters and representatives of the European industry. I can't imagine that, contrary to reality, we will grant China market economy status. I think that would be a big trap to get ourselves into by doing our own thing. Then we would also find it very difficult to find effective safeguards that the EU could put in place against dumping.  Colleagues, these are indeed two things - a market economy that we cannot admit, but even then we must use all the possibilities to counter dumping from China.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, China claims that the WTO Access Protocol would ensure automatic recognition of market economy status after 15 years of entry into the wto, an interpretation that is totally unacceptable. Recognition of China's market economy status must remain conditional first and foremost on compliance with the five criteria.  In any case, whatever decision the European Union takes, we need to think about a Plan B, which includes equivalent trade defence measures that can combat unfair competition practices, ensuring a level playing field between companies from third countries and European companies. These instruments play a crucial role in protecting key sectors of European manufacturing industry that make a fundamental contribution to growth and innovation and employment in the Member States.  It is therefore essential for the European Union to maintain trade protection mechanisms by first applying the principle of reciprocity in the Union's trade policy in order to ensure fair competition and ensure uniform conditions.  At present, the conditions for recognition of China's market economy status do not exist. The Commission is therefore making proposals to protect Europe's interests, identifying a third way, capable of finding a solution that satisfies both sides.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Marias, it is not enough to register, as you ask. The Rules of Procedure are clear: catch-the-eye is for Members who attend the debate, and here are officials who mark attendance during the debate. However, I give you the floor for one minute.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I may be the only one or one of the few Members in the Chamber from the time the sitting begins until it is over all days, throughout the debate. This cannot be denied.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would ask you to go into the substance, because our services know exactly when you entered the Chamber. You have the floor on the subject of the ESA to China.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, because you are referring to me, I am personally answering you. Ask your services to do their job better. I've been here all along and I'm a participant, that can't be denied, and I have to answer you. That's why I sent you this note. Also, at the level of political groups, you have given the floor to only one of the ECR group. I'm telling you this because you mentioned me personally. Now, if I have the floor, I'll talk about the substance.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would ask you to come into the matter if you wish to speak on the substance of the debate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, for some time now the German and other European multinationals, in order to reduce labour costs, have gone through the outsourcing process, transferring part of their production to China. As a result, unemployment in Europe has risen sharply, and the European Union has been closing its eyes to the massive violations of labour rights in China, as well as the practices of Chinese dumping. Now China has grown into the world's second most powerful economy. It aspires to achieve a new division of labour and redistribution of spheres of influence and exploitation around the world. In this context, the debate on the status of the economy is linked to whether anti-dumping duties could continue to be imposed on Chinese products to protect the European steel industry and workers demonstrating outside Parliament. However, before the debate progresses on whether China is a market economy or not, consideration should be given to whether it is necessary to stop the 'Chineseisation' of the European economy, as European companies wish to emulate Chinese and break up labour rights.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing my great satisfaction that, at last, in this plenary session, Parliament will adopt a formal position on a subject of strategic importance, after months in which this House has been guiltily prevented from having this House cast a vote. The decision we have to take is not whether Or not China is a market economy: everyone knows that it is not, either formally or substantially. The decision to be taken is whether or not to relocate our production system. If this question is legitimate for an entrepreneur, this doubt is not granted to the institutions, which must govern and guide the future of Europe. Our institutions must be able to look into the eyes of those small and large entrepreneurs who open their businesses every day, who compete in the global market with quality and innovation and who guarantee high jobs and standards against artificially subsidised foreign companies.  Important decisions await us in the coming months, but no deadline can condition strategic choices for the future of Europe.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President,  I have taken good note of all the interventions. I think that this debate today has highlighted the fact that, despite the technical complexity of this file, the European Union is strongly committed to ensuring that our industry competes on a level playing field. For this to happen, we need to act on the causes of unfair trade, but also on its symptoms. Our trade defence instruments must be efficient and effective, independently of the expiry of certain provisions of Chinese accession and protocol to the WTO. So this object requires action by Member States in the Council to ensure that the modernisation of our trade defence instruments moves forward quickly. In the meantime, the Commission is continuing the impact assessment so that we take account of the views of all those affected, as many of you have mentioned. It is imperative that work is complete in order to enable the Commission to make a decision that will reflect all of our interests.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is clearly a complicated file. On the one hand, we entered into agreements with the accession of China to the WTO 15 years ago and we cannot just ignore our obligations. On the other hand, China is by no means a market economy, as the Commissioner and many MEPs have rightly stated, and yes, we need to protect European industry and European workers against unfair trade practices. In other words, we will need to balance our international obligations and our strategic commercial interests, the interests of our producers, consumers and users. The Council has full confidence that the Commissioner, the Commission, will act accordingly.  Mr Caspary, and others also, stated that the Council should have the necessary political will and unity to overcome the blockade. Let me assure you that the Dutch Presidency is doing everything to do so and let me also underline once more that our ultimate objective is the very same as that of the Members of this House: strong and effective trade defence systems in order to tackle unfair trade practices and thus ensure a global level playing field.  That is why, as I stated earlier today, the Foreign Affairs Council will discuss the Commission’s communication, as well as other proposals and ideas, this Friday, 13 May. I am convinced that the exchanges today are a very good basis for further work between our institutions, and again you can rest assured that the Council will take into consideration the legitimate interests and concerns of European consumers and producers.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be notified at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, May 12, 2016, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have co-signed and of course approved this joint resolution which stresses that China is not a market economy and therefore calls on the Commission to oppose and oppose any unilateral decision to grant China market economy status.  The resolution also calls on the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed by the industrial sector, trade unions and other EU stakeholders about the impact on employment, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth in the Union.  Similarly, Parliament believes that until China is eligible for market economy status, the EU should use a non-standard method for dumping investigations. Finally, MEPs stress the imminent need for a general reform of the EUROPEAN Union's trade defence instruments in order to ensure that the EU industry has a level playing field with China and other trading partners.  This joint resolution is an important first step, but we must now ensure that political pressure on the Commission and the Council is maintained and intensified. The same goes for thousands of jobs in the European Union

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. China's accession to market economy status would be a real dumping permit for Chinese industrialists, allowing them to launch major trade offensives in many sectors. Supported and subsidized by the Chinese government, these industrialists could even afford to sell at a loss for a few years to eliminate in our countries their French and European competitors. In France in France, recent studies put the number of jobs that would then be destroyed between 180,000 and 360,000.  Yet, as we have seen, relocations to China have resulted in the loss of millions of jobs in France and Europe in strategic sectors such as steel or in other more local ones such as textiles in my region. The European Union is not there to protect and develop jobs but to destroy it. China must be denied this status in the name of economic patriotism!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – The representatives of the People's Republic of China take the view that their country should be automatically granted market economy status as of 11 December 2016, 15 years after the signing of the accession agreement to the World Trade Organisation (WT'O). This would create enormous problems for European industry and tens of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises. For example, already highly subsidised Chinese cheap steel is flooding the European internal market and leading to massive job losses in Europe. According to expert estimates, a total of 1.3 million jobs are available in the steel industry and related supply industries. But sectors such as bicycle production, with 600 medium-sized companies and 70 000 employees, are also affected. The European Commission is currently analysing feedback from the public consultation on the recognition of China's market economy status. Discussions with the G7 are to take place before the summer recess. An effective trade defence system against unfair trade practices is also in the pipeline. However, automatic recognition of China's market economy status, which is not necessary at all on the part of the EU, would make anti-dumping instruments much more difficult to apply and market distortions would be difficult to penalise. The negative impact on employment, growth and innovation, especially in key European industries, would be massive.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – Let me place this debate in its genuine framework, which is none other than the Commission's intention to deepen the liberalisation of trade between the EU and China. To this end, a public consultation is commissioned that does not allow interested parties to express themselves in depth; the deadlines for avoiding debate are accelerated and sesewn studies are commissioned, which will once again ignore the employment effects and productive structure of the intensification of foreign trade. We will not fall into the trap of those who use the threat of non-recognition of China as a market economy as a weapon to demand privatization and boost the penetration of their own transnationals. But we also do not believe it is acceptable to eliminate recourse to anti-dumping measures whose disappearance will drive a serious deterioration in global industry conditions. Any further progress in international trade integration cannot be made as if the market were an institution independent of its social construction; it requires, on the contrary, full recognition of international standards on labour and the environment. Otherwise, it will be the popular classes that are at the cost of the biggest profits of multinationals.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – The Commission's latest report on China's market economy status continued to reveal shortcomings in a number of important areas. There is a lack of transparency, the State is interfering significantly in the economy and is detrimental to foreign businesses, it is not adequately protecting intellectual property, and we have not even mentioned the lack of guarantees on workers' rights and the environment at the time. Therefore, although China has taken significant steps towards market economy, the conditions for equal competition are still not ensured. Consequently, measures to exclude dumping in China and to protect the European market are not only justified but also necessary.  The situation is particularly serious for the steel industry, where unequal competition can destroy European businesses. I made sure of this myself when I was informed a few weeks ago at the Danube IronWorks in Dunaújváros. It is particularly important to involve trade unions and industry representatives in further negotiations. In this area, it is particularly true that the Member States are powerless alone, only through joint action by the European Union can jobs be protected and the proper functioning of the market guaranteed. Parliament must therefore also take a strong and unambiguous position on this matter.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. "Not all industries are beeping bitstreams. In my country, Finland, metal processing has been a major employer and export industry. Unfortunately, numerous steel companies across Europe have had to lay off workers. The Chinese have taken orders and jobs.  Now Beijing has interpreted the WTO agreement as automatically granting market economy position after 15 years. This is a hasty interpretation. It is clear that China is not a market economy country. The laws of supply and demand do not guide the country's economy. A one-party system. Censorship. Political courts. Prisoners of opinion. An unknown number of death sentences. These human rights violations should first be eradicated by the Chinese from their system.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The observation is clear: China is not a market economy. It does not meet the criteria set by the European Union and that is why I refuse to consider that this grant can be automatic. Such a decision would have a catastrophic impact on businesses and employment in many sectors already facing the pressure of Chinese dumping in Europe.  At a time when we are looking to revive growth, we must fight against unfair competition. Therefore, I would like to reiterate the urgency of modernizing our trade defence instruments without weakening them. They need to be made more efficient, faster and more accessible to SMEs. The issue of China's economic status should not be reduced to mere legal considerations: it will have major economic and social consequences.  Many sectors have already mobilised and the European Commission must listen to them. Europe must not be isolated in its choices on the international stage and must discuss with its partners who are facing the same issue, such as the United States and Japan.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
