text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Under World Trade Organisation rules, countries that join the organisation can be considered "non-free market economies" for 15 years after accession. For products from countries without such status, it is possible to impose higher than normal duties in order to protect the internal market from dumping and unfair competition. For China, the transition period expires on December 11, 2016. However, 15 years after joining the WTO, China has still not implemented the reforms necessary for it to be considered a free market economy. The 5 EU criteria in this area, such as respect for m.in or an economy independent of state influence, have not been met. Therefore, the European Parliament's position of not agreeing to the automatic granting of market economy status seems as appropriate as possible. This is particularly important because otherwise the interests of European companies and hundreds of thousands of jobs could be seriously threatened. Indeed, granting market economy status to China will make it impossible to defend the market against low-cost products sold at dumped prices. Before the final decision, the European Union should first assess the impact of this decision on jobs and industry and then adopt appropriate regulations to allow for a level playing field and protection for the most vulnerable sectors such as chemical, metallurgical and related industries. Otherwise, we risk uncontrollably flooding our market with Chinese products.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on economic growth and youth employment (2016/2702(SDR)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the good news is that, according to the spring economic forecast issued by the Commission last week, economic recovery in Europe continues. It is true that the picture is not always just a rosy one and we do face a difficult global environment. The growth rate remains modest at a projected 1.8% in the EU this year and there are significant differences between Member States. But things are slowly getting better. The employment situation is also slowly improving but, again, with significant differences among Member States.  In this context, I am happy to note – and I will focus my intervention on this specific point – that unemployment of young people has dropped slightly recently. The gradual improvement in the economic situation over the past two years has translated into a somewhat better situation regarding youth unemployment. While remaining at overall high levels, it has been declining since the year 2013. In 2015 and early this year, 2016, youth unemployment continued to fall and at a faster rate than overall unemployment. Let me be clear though, because we should not hide the fact that the overall level of youth unemployment still remains very worrying, and I would like to underline once more that the situation differs significantly among the Member States. What did we do and what is still to be done to address this? It is not necessary to remind you that three years ago the Council adopted a recommendation on establishing the Youth Guarantee. This recommendation has been, without any doubt, a cornerstone of European policy measures on youth employment. Funds from the Youth Employment Initiative have been front—loaded and the Member States are implementing the Guarantee through their Youth Guarantee implementation plans.  Obviously implementing is just one thing. Taking stock of what has been done and, above all, what is still to be done is another thing. Three years after the adoption of the Youth Guarantee, the Employment Committee has been tasked with monitoring the implementation of the Guarantee and for that purpose a framework for indicators has been developed.  Earlier this year, in March, the Council approved recommendations from the Employment Committee and I am convinced that they are of great importance for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee after 2016. In this respect, we look forward to the review of the Commission which should be presented by the end of this year. The same goes for the announced new skills agenda which should contribute to the achievement of the EU’s targets of cutting the early school-leaving rate to below 10% and getting more young people into higher education or equivalent vocational education. Let me also remind you that the new EURES Regulation should enter into force in the coming days and I sincerely hope that the modernised EURES network can also substantially contribute to the fight against the unemployment of young people. We are fully aware of the fact that Parliament expressed its concerns in the recent past about the slow implementation of the Youth Guarantee. Funding was increased and we tried to speed things up, although it should be clear to all of us that, first of all, Member States are the ones that have to implement structural reforms.  As you all know, youth employment has always been a central subject in the country—specific recommendations, and will continue to be so. We need more job creation and we also need to exploit the full potential of the exchange of best practices among the EU Member States, and also beyond the Union. Let me also underscore that the social partners have a very important role to play within this context.  With specific measures like the Youth Guarantee and, above all, with the ongoing structural reforms in the Member States, we should be able to take advantage of the improving economic situation and, thus, to make further progress in the reduction of youth unemployment.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, since its first day in office, a key goal of this Commission has been to boost economic growth through a combination of funding tools such as the investment plan and structural funds, policy reforms in the framework of the European Semester, new initiatives to unleash the potential of the internal market such as the digital single market or the energy union , and, finally, policy guidance. Our objective is that this will help to tackle the high level of unemployment we are still faced with, and notably youth unemployment.  There are now encouraging signs which I should first mention, as was also just mentioned. Approximately 4.3 million young people in the European Union were unemployed in March 2016. This is down from a peak of 5.7 million in December 2012, or, simply put, a drop of nearly 25%. These are positive developments, reflecting a return to growth, decisive action from the Member States and the support given by the EU. However, while the youth unemployment rate has decreased from a peak of 23.9% in February 2013 to 19.1% in March 2016, it is still too high in various Member States. There are peaks of more than 35% in several countries. Moreover – and more alarmingly – in 2015, 12% of young people aged between 15 and 24 were not in employment, education or training, with peaks of around 20% in Bulgaria and Italy. Wasting the potential of young people, who are usually better trained, is something we cannot afford. Against this background, President Juncker made it clear that we need to channel funding towards projects that can help get the younger generation back to work in decent jobs, further complementing the efforts already undertaken with the Youth Guarantee Scheme, the implementation of which must be accelerated and progressively broadened. As you may know, the Youth Guarantee is a political commitment that all young people under 25 get an offer – within four months of leaving education or becoming unemployed – for employment, a traineeship, an apprenticeship or continued education. Delivery on the objectives of a Youth Guarantee require strategic reforms to achieve more successful transitions from school to the labour market. Progress has been carefully monitored within the European Semester and has resulted in country-specific recommendations where appropriate. Notably, in 2015, country—specific recommendations for Bulgaria, Spain, Italy, Portugal and Romania specifically pointed to the need for action on youth employment.  The Commission has mobilised a range of instruments to support implementation. Policy support and mutual learning help Member States put in place the right infrastructure and measures. The Youth Guarantee’s implementation is still in an early stage, and additional efforts are needed to accelerate and broaden its implementation. While progress has been facilitated so far by an unprecedented political backing and support from EU financial instruments, a key challenge is to ensure sustainable implementation. This requires fundamental structural reforms in most Member States in order to create the necessary conditions to help young generations enter the labour market. The Commission will continue to monitor the Youth Guarantee. In order to take stock of the success achieved and lessons learned from the Youth Guarantee, let me inform you that the report on its implementation and the operation of the Youth Employment Initiative is due by the end of 2016. This will also address the quality and framework of traineeship implementation. It will include a qualitative assessment of the actions and the use of the funding devoted to supporting young people.  The forthcoming Skills Agenda is complementary to the Youth Guarantee. Indeed, we need to make sure that everybody – not only the young – has the skills needed to keep pace with a fast-changing labour market. Europe’s economic success is, to a very large extent, based on the skills of our people. Our future competitiveness and growth depend on skills, and the pace of change in the labour market makes this especially challenging. The digital revolution continues to reshape jobs. The new Skills Agenda will focus on skills as an elevator to the employability of all people. It will also focus on creating the right environment for all skills to drive competitiveness and fair and balanced growth. Moreover, it will set out actions for a reinforced engagement with businesses for a shared commitment to deliver skills to Europe. However, we should not forget that the main responsibility for defining their employment and social policies and for pursuing structural reforms lies, of course, with the Member States. The Commission is working closely with them to support and complement their actions.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I welcome the fact that the EPP Group has insisted on linking this debate on youth employment to the issue of growth, because the subjects of employment and growth are really linked.  Make no mistake, the first of the precarious situation for young people, in particular, is unemployment. A young person without a job or training does not find a place in society. He cannot take his autonomy, he has no housing, no car, sometimes even, no driver's license. This means that an unemployed young person can quickly find himself marginalized and, also, that work is a real factor of social integration.  Today, in Europe, growth is still low, very low in some Member States, and the entry of young people into the labour market has become very difficult. The subject is very serious. Almost 20% of young Europeans are now looking for a job. So what opportunities can we offer our youth? How can we encourage her to undertake, to innovate in Europe, rather than to push her to pursue a career on other continents? How can we not feed the sense of betrayal that sometimes pushes her into the arms of populists? It is these questions that Europe must answer, and it is not through subsidies, supported jobs or emergency measures that we will provide lasting answers.  Young people have ideas, talent, energy. They want to prove what they are worth. They do not expect their politicians to give them alms, but to create the conditions for a return to growth and job creation. The Commission published its economic forecasts last week, but it has clearly shown the differences and differences that exist from one Member State to another. So some Member States have already made a number of reforms. Ireland, Portugal and Italy are in this situation and have seen the unemployment rate fall.  I would also like to highlight the good figures of Spain, where new elections are being prepared and where the courageous reform efforts undertaken are beginning to bear fruit. Unfortunately, this is not the case in all Member States. This is not the case in France despite the repeated assertions of François Hollande and Commissioner Pierre Moscovici, whose optimism seems very gullible. The "everything is better in France" speech does not stand up to serious scrutiny for a minute.  The fight against youth unemployment the first and foremost approach to labour market flexibility, better training for young people, better adapted to the labour market, lower taxation for businesses and, above all, real structural reforms to lift the brakes that are blocking our economy.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, we know very well there is no future for the European Union if the European Union is not able to provide a future for its young people. Yes, of course the European Union can create a lot of good jobs for young people in the activities of the future, in the energy transition, in the digital revolution, in health and in creative industries. We have a young generation with a lot of potential for creativity and innovation. Yes, we have made some progress on reducing youth unemployment, but the youth unemployment rate remains too high – above 20%. Moreover, we have huge divergences: 45% in Spain, 30% in Portugal. We have not mentioned Greece – which is above 50% – in Italy it is also very high, as it is in Slovakia and Croatia. So something is badly wrong in the way the European Union is working and this has huge implications, not only in social and economic terms, but also in political terms, as we can see. So my plea is to adapt all the tools we have to go to the heart of the problem: very high employment and also very deep divergences. This means to reshape the way we are using the Youth Initiative, the structural funds and the investment plan, which should tackle economic and social cohesion. But more than that, in the eurozone, we need to have a fiscal capacity to deal with these divergences.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the key challenge we face is to help Member States create the right environment for businesses to grow and create new jobs. They can only do this if the market allows for it, if they can find qualified workers, if labour markets are sufficiently flexible and if they are not over burdened with regulation. I welcome the recent agreement on the IIA on better law—making. Legislation which is simpler and easier to understand and implement will help Member States create an environment that will encourage companies to hire and manage staff, while protecting basic workers’ rights.  Europe’s strength lies in its diversity, and we must use this diversity to learn from one another. There is no one-size-fits-all template. Many Member States, including my own, have already put in place successful structural reforms. This has enabled Britain to attract investment, to grow its economy and to create more and better jobs. Our employment rate is now over 74%, while the unemployed claimant count is at its lowest for 40 years. There have been over two million apprenticeships giving people the chance to learn skills and get on in life. Ultimately, Europe’s greatest need is for growth – growth that will allow our businesses, especially SMEs, to thrive, to create new jobs and to provide a good future for all of Europe’s young people.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I want to concentrate on the Youth Guarantee, which is our flagship project, and I want to ask the Commissioner – or, even more importantly, I want to ask the Council – what progress has been made by Member States on the Youth Guarantee? We voted in this Parliament for increased pre-financing for the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI). How much has been spent? The deadline is this year. Is it likely that some – even a significant amount – of that money may come back unspent? What are we doing to ensure that this does not happen and the Youth Guarantee delivers? One of the issues I have come across is that it can be challenging to incentivise young people to access the Youth Guarantee. There are different reasons for this and often it is because they know – and the authorities know – that it is only for a few months. It is not sustainable. Many of these young people are already very disillusioned. So what are we doing to reach them? What are we doing to incentivise them? Crucially, we have to understand that this includes the demand side as well as the supply side. One final, and very important, issue I want to raise is about my own country, Ireland, and the fact that the vast majority of young people with disabilities cannot access the Youth Guarantee Scheme. Only those on the live register can access the Youth Guarantee Scheme and most young people with disabilities are not on the live register. So we have a situation in which European moneys are being used to exclude young people with disabilities in the context of employment opportunities. This runs counter to our anti-discrimination legislation and our commitments under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Werner KUHN
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Harkin, you spoke about youth guarantees. In this respect, I wanted to say that we have made EUR 1 billion available in the budget to combat youth unemployment. There are countries in Europe where workers and trainees are sought – in Germany, for example. And we have a programme to bring Portuguese, Spanish and Greek young people there. Is this not an interim solution where a perspective for young people is possible, until we have improved the economic power in the countries, so to speak?

name: Marian HARKIN
text: blue-card answer. –Mr Kuhn, I hear what you are saying, and we have the EURES programme, which is there of course to incentivise young people to move from one Member State to another to access a job. But equally, we have to understand that for many young people – at least for some – they want to access employment in their own Member State as well. So I think we need to find a balance.  In our committee we talk about fair mobility, and that means that young people have a choice. Yes, the EURES programme is important, but it is just one part of what we need to do.

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has What you are announcing here sounds between whistles in the dark forest and fine-coloured. We have put in place a lot of programmes to end this misery. The effect is shameful, almost non-existent. We are still on the way to losing an entire generation, and an entire generation is losing faith in Europe. I believe it is appropriate to do more now on the part of the Commission and the Council. Firstly, the funds must be increased. Even according to renowned studies, they are by no means sufficient to eliminate youth unemployment. Secondly, we must create qualified training. What we are creating with precariousness, with precarious jobs, with short-term employment, with part-time work and with traineeships is not really a useful qualification for young people, from which they can then live permanently. Thirdly, we need to drastically reduce pre-financing and co-financing conditions in the case of EU funding. Fourthly, yes, we can do better, Mr Kuhn, to promote cooperation between the Member States in the use of vacant training places in prosperous countries, to improve the quality of vocational schools and to set up training centres in the countries with weak vocational training. All this is urgently needed. But it will be of no use if we do not at the same time focus economically on creating good, sustainable work from which people can live independently. This requires a European programme for the future of the Member States and the European level, so that we can finally create new work. We simply need to put an end to austerity and finally ensure that we move forward and that we do not continue to be broken. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – My question is: what is the way forward for Europe? Choose Realpolitik or respect the values and principles on which this Union is based?

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The answer is quite simple: realpolitik starts with people's problems. And the values of the European Union are very well invested if we actually keep an eye on them and do not constantly violate them through austerity and austerity.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, when I open the newspaper in Germany, I could very easily get the impression that everything is fine now: that the crisis is over, that European economies are recovering and that everyone should live happily ever after. But when I look at the situation of young people – for example, in Spain or in Greece – I am on the contrary very easily convinced that this picture is utterly wrong. Alarmingly high levels of youth unemployment still, millions of young people without prospects. In fact, the situation is still so very bad that even the Pope mentioned the problem of youth unemployment in his speech last weekend.  At the same time, we have European heads of state who seem to be getting used to this situation, who accept this situation as the new normal in the European Union, and especially as long as the wrong image prevails – not only in the media, but sometimes even in Commission documents – that the crisis is actually over, that austerity has worked and that we will simply have to get on with it now.  All these things are wrong. The crisis is not yet over, austerity has not – and will not – solve the huge problem of youth unemployment in the European Union and we will have to be the ones to fight for political change, for bringing back hope to young people in Europe. The first change should be the realisation that without massive public investment the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee – as good as they could be and as good as they are – will not show the desired effect. Let us not accept that half of Europe’s youth has no prospects, accepting this as the new normal. Let us do something about it. More investment would be a first step. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned that there are differences between the countries in youth unemployment. You mentioned Spain and Greece, for example. Could you perhaps specify what could be the reason? Are there differences, for example, in digital skills, in the type of education, or other things that could be concrete reasons for that?

name: Terry REINTKE
text: blue-card answer. – Well, very obviously we see that in countries where the overall unemployment rate is very high, youth unemployment is also very high, and countries like Spain and Greece have been disproportionately hit by the crisis. But yes, I would agree with you that it is also a question of the educational systems, and indeed digital skills are key in order to overcome this. But this cannot be the only answer that we have. At the same time, we also need to invest in the economy to create good work and to create good jobs, because if there are no jobs, young people – even with the best digital skills – will not have the possibility to get into employment.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, youth unemployment is the scourge that is most severe lying about the future of Europe. Without a job, the young man of the Union loses hope for the future. And not the first year attempts are being made by various programmes, millions of euros, to reduce youth unemployment. If the statistics for several years, when youth unemployment is far from falling but remain stable, it should be noted that all measures to reduce unemployment are inadequate and more declarative. Monetary incentives for employers are too small, the commitment period is too short. The money spent on retraining does not produce the result that we want. I believe that very different solutions should be taken and should not only cover unemployment problems. For a young person, nothing less than work is important for housing. Let us build and allow young people to dispose of it on preferential terms. Housing and work for a young, child-raising family should be the most important task for every State of the European Union and every municipality. Another incentive for young people is to create legislation so that young people can do preferential treatment for their family business throughout the European Union. Thus, lower labour taxation, reduced taxes and tax rates for employers and young people under the age of 30 could at least partially address youth unemployment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, young people are undoubtedly the best guarantee for the future of their country. But when they are forced to migrate because of the intervention of external factors that lead to its destruction, then the future is dark. The malicious interventionist policies of Europe's powerful in the countries of Africa and the Middle East have forced the reluctant relocation of millions of young people to the countries of the Union. And now what is being planned and pursued is their technical training and their work to complete the aspirations of Germany and the other powerful. However, you have not taken into account that people from different cultures can coexist with problems but not assimilate, especially when migrating to the countries responsible for their vomiting. Instead of helping young people from the Member States of the Union and achieving economic growth, you are creating imported terrorists. So stop this policy while it is time. Educate young people and don't just develop their skills. Give them work, not employment. Motivate them to create a better future of their own, not exhortations and causes to destroy yours.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – Our economy is growing, but still too slow, which means that young people in many regions are still too much out of the way. It's got to be different. The key to the credibility of the European integration project lies with young people. A good job gives young people self-worth and hope. The EU can and must make a difference here. This can be done, among other things, by increasing intra-European labour mobility. In my region of West Flanders, for example, companies are crying out for qualified staff. Less than 40 kilometres away in northern France, an army of young people is out of work. You can't do this. By making these young people more mobile, we can offer them opportunities across borders. We need to make them physically familiar with the labour market of other Member States, for example by focusing erasmus+ more on work. At the same time, vacancies must be exchanged digitally, efficiently and up-to-date with up-to-date information through projects such as EURES. My second spearhead is the further development of the youth guarantee scheme. We should not only focus on activation, but should focus more on the transition from education to the labour market. The Flemish approach to bringing together the areas of well-being, education, work and entrepreneurship is bearing fruit and can be taken up by the EU as a proven method. My generation will need strong skills to fill the many jobs that will be created by Europe's ageing population. I can summarize the solution simply: valoriseer the competencies, digitize the information and make the labour market more mobile.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, youth unemployment as a whole seems to have disappeared from the European agenda and, to some of it, from the national agenda. Youth unemployment means financial losses – not only today, but also in the long term. I am thinking here of the long-term loss of chewing power, but also, for example, of old-age poverty. The Commission, including Mrs Thyssen, is talking about the figures nicely: there would be huge progress, the programmes would bear fruit. But the reality is quite different – in Germany, too, by the way, Mr Kuhn. When you see who is in work and what these are very often for jobs in which young people are, it is precarious employment or unpaid internships. And no one includes young people who are unemployed after graduation and in unpaid internships. What Europe really needs is for those who have money to invest this money in the real economy and create jobs, and for them to pay taxes too! This is also the way to finance these measures. More needs to be done, we need better coordination, and the means to combat youth unemployment must not be scaled back, they must be strengthened!

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The catastrophic labour market situation in some countries is still a consequence of the unresolved euro crisis. The Eurogroup deplores the extent to which the over-indebtedness of private borrowers has become a burden on banks in some Member States, thereby weighing on the economy. The analysis is correct, the problem is the solution that has been mentioned. In order to rebuild the ailing banking system in southern Europe, a great deal of money is needed, which southern Europe does not have. The solution for the Eurogroup and the Commission is therefore to create new national insolvency rules and to raise the necessary funds from Northern Europe through the Banking Union and the Deposit Guarantee Funds. We see here that an inflexible monetary system leads to economic distortions that require complex new transfer mechanisms, as well as the youth initiative. Democratic control will be lost, and who knows who will govern Portugal, Spain, Italy or Austria in two years' time and what policies will be made. We need orderly bankruptcies of banks and states and a reorganisation of ailing structures, but we also need a monetary solution that will not create such problems in the future. By this I mean flexible exchange rates, ownership and subsidiarity.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, yesterday we celebrated Europe Day and talked about the future of Europe. The future of Europe is today's young people. That's a fact and can't be changed by anyone. What are we doing with them? Well, here we deal with growth with jobs. The problems of youth unemployment are different depending on the areas of Europe. In some it is an intolerable unemployment rate for an extended period of time; in others it is the quality of work; in others it may be the remuneration of work. But they all lead to the same solution. The solution is that it is a European crisis and it has to have a European approach. And for that, if we talk about growth, because growth must allow education to be financed, not just training; finance very particularly vocational training and vocational training mobility at European level; preferably launch investments in areas, not countries, in areas of large youth unemployment exchanges and, of course, strengthen mobility. We don't have to look any further. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I fully agree with what you have said. But I want to ask you: do you not think that, in order to create new jobs and a sustainable economy and, obviously, places for young people, we should have another innovation and research policy? Don't you think young people are innovative and would need support in this area?

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: "blue card" response. – Of course, dear colleague, that is, everything helps. One of the aspects in which I wanted to summarize this is that of vocational training, education and investment empowerment – social investments also count – and of course, a focus on research and a priority approach to future areas will undoubtedly help. But we must not forget young people who cannot access for thousands of reasons and are as valuable to Europe as those who cannot access high education.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, for too many years the European institutions have been selling the same policy packages and deregulation as the remedy for all evils in Europe, including the problem of youth unemployment.  You have just come here to speak today and continue to present internships. But internships, Commissioner, are not jobs - it is something else, but it is not employment.  These policies have often been imposed on Member States through financial blackmail, financial pressure and threat, but the problem continues to worsen and growth is a mirage. And it is not only unemployment, it is also precariousness and it is wages of misery. None of this, none of these measures, Commissioner, has improved the economy and the European Commission is multiplying in pious statements, each more hypocritical than the previous one. The recipe remains the same and does not solve the problems.  Commissioner, no one expects anything from the Commission anymore, but at least let the Member States choose some of their options, because perhaps doing the opposite of what the Commission recommends is even the solution for growth and creating jobs. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (presented pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President, and also to the Congresswoman, for taking my question. You said that the position of the Commission and other institutions is the same year after year. I do think there is a new element here, and I ask you, what do you see as potential in this? In particular, there are about as many taxes going to tax havens in Europe as half of the European Union's budget. Shouldn't we be holding this rather than playing old records all the time? Thank you very much!

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Dear Colleague, if I understand your question, I agree with the comment you make. But tell me, then, what is the concrete part of the Commission to deal directly with tax havens.  I have not yet seen anything and, in fact, to control, or rather eliminate tax havens, it would be half way for us to consolidate public accounts at European level.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the Union's objective for young people is certainly not to keep them stable, permanent and entitled to work - this, after all, in writing answered a question from the Jrc - but how, by exploiting their unemployment, they will become cheap employable, with hunger wages, flexible work, unpaid apprenticeships, without the right to social security. The main aim is to further permanently squeeze the general level of wages and rights, sacrifice in capitalist profits. Characteristic is the third Greek memorandum, a quartet of SYRIZA governments with the support of all parties other than the KKE, and the already agreed fourth Greek memorandum in yesterday's Eurogroup. The new barbaric pension cuts will also be heavily paid for by young people, who are effectively excluded from the right to a pension, with elusive age limits, as they wander only between unemployment and temporary employment, while being asked to pay unbearable insurance contributions. Don't let them become the new slaves of the 21st century! With massive action to strengthen the struggle to overthrow the politics of the capital of the European Union and its parties.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – In the Europe 2020 strategy, which we adopted with a view to improving the economic situation in the European Union, we have also taken a series of measures to help young Europeans find their jobs, to apprenticeship, or to continue their education. In my country, in Slovenia, employers do not hire new job seekers because they do not have work experience. But I wonder how they will gain this work experience, if they have no chance of getting involved in the work process at all. Of course, we have also taken a few steps forward at European Union level, and the unemployment rate has fallen, but of course that is not enough. We therefore need to accelerate all initiatives to integrate young people into the labour market, the Youth Employment Initiative and to approach the implementation of the programmes more systemically. We must provide employment in the long term, not just for the duration of the programmes. Quality traineeships are very important, apprenticeships, all of which will make it easier to transition into the labour market.  Although mobility within the European Union seems excellent, we do see that this is not really the case. That is why, on the one hand, we are facing too much labour and, on the other hand, there is too little of it. In line with all these measures that we are already ingly, we must, of course, also support greater mobility.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union is experiencing a profound crisis of confidence. Day by day, we debate threats and the perception that the answers are not up to the challenges. At the political level, we are in a negative spiral and this is exploited by populism and nationalism.  The time has therefore come to fight without hesitation for this peace and prosperity project, which has made the European Union the region of the globe with the highest average quality of life and greater sustainability for the planet. There are many fights to fight, but one of the most important is the fight for this generation: a skilled, cosmopolitan, innovative and entrepreneurial generation that has to have opportunities to rescue the future — its future and the future of the European project. And if this crisis is a crisis of confidence, the answer, Commissioner, must be credible.  Youth qualification, exchange and entrepreneurial training programmes must be endowed with the necessary resources.  It's not about expense. This is an investment in our most reproductive capital — in human capital, in the hope, in the European renaissance, a more urgent rebirth than ever before.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Madam President, youth unemployment is a shameful wound for Europe. On average, one in four young people is unemployed, and in some countries it is one in two young people - with the exception of Member States, such as Germany, the Netherlands and Austria, that have made learning the bridge between general education and working life. We also note that students who have enjoyed mobility in a country other than the one where they live are better protected from the risk of unemployment, hence the idea of encouraging apprentices to move, by giving them access to Erasmus scholarships in the same way as students. The difficulty is that 28 countries give rise to 28 different learning statuses. To identify and measure barriers to the mobility of apprentices, it is necessary to experiment. This is the purpose of the pilot project that we will be implementing next September. I would like, Commissioner, to thank you very sincerely for the support and assistance that your services have given us. I just want to express the wish, at a time of simplification, that you should put the experimentation away from the cumbersome usual procedures which can kill the most promising intentions in the bud. Confidence and pragmatism to facilitate experimentation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today the wishes of the Commission and the dominant circles of the Union for economic growth and employment of young people are repeated, through the same failed policies of harsh austerity and a memorandum. Cyprus, despite the celebrations of the "success story" of the memorandums and austerity policies, is yet another tragic example of this failure. The right-wing government in Cyprus and the troika with the memorial policies led to 28.2% of youth unemployment. The number of workers has fallen by 30,000 in the last three years, with thousands of young people migrating abroad or not returning home after their studies. Cyprus has the highest growth rate of the long-term unemployed in the Union, even after the supposed exit from the memorandum. The country did not take fifth place in the European Union in part-time employment rates, with salaries of 500 euros and 94.3% of employees stating that the contract they signed was not their choice. Neoliberal austerity policies have failed. We urgently need public investment in social development and the creation of new safe and decent jobs.  The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – The representative who spoke above pointed out the unfortunate situation in Cyprus, where youth unemployment has increased, even though in many other European countries it is slowly falling. I would like to ask the speaker whether you have tried everything possible, for example with regard to the Youth Guarantee, so that it also helps to achieve youth unemployment in Cyprus. Indeed, there is a risk that the appropriations for the Youth Guarantee will even not be used. Why don't you make this a national project?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". Thanks for the question. Policies were imposed in Cyprus through the Memorandum. First an unacceptable haircut of deposits was imposed which led to a disintegration of the economy of Cyprus. Since no programmes are being used, there are no public expenditure, even with this notorious "Juncker plan" in Cyprus and Greece and other countries, because the condition - which is wrong - is that there should also be private investment. Therefore, without support from the European Union with programmes, without public investment, jobs cannot be created.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, there are some positive signs, but the reality remains stark: more than one in five young people are unemployed - one in five young people with no prospect and no future. This is a generation that we are sacrificing. We cannot accept it and must rise to this challenge. Tools exist, such as the Youth Employment Initiative, which is to continue and be funded until at least 2020. We must fight against school exclusion and failure. Every young person who comes out of school without qualifications and without certification is a Mozart who is murdered. We need to put in place a real European learning system, just like Erasmus, but for vocational learning. These are systems that work and work. We must implement them and, finally, if we are to meet this challenge, we must put the issue of the fight against youth unemployment at the top of the European social dialogue. This issue deserves it.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for my part, I would like to make a simple comment: we need the Youth Employment Initiative to be refinanced for the coming years. This is an essential instrument, as has already been pointed out by the Commission and by many experts with whom I have had the opportunity to discuss it. It provides liquidity to europe's regions with the highest rates of youth unemployment to launch youth guarantee programmes, which are gradually becoming a driving force for improving public and private structures dealing with the matching of labour supply and labour and employment services in general, a sector in need of investment and reform in many countries. Finally, I would like to stress the central role played by the European Social Fund in the fight against youth unemployment. Having suffered a heavy cut during the last negotiations on the multiannual financial framework, we now have the opportunity to remedy this error, within the review exercise that we are about to begin with.  I am convinced that the European Parliament will exercise its prerogatives strongly on this issue.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, the European economic recovery is still fragile and slow and has proved insufficient to break definitively with the terrible numbers of youth unemployment. We have seen the degradation of an entire generation, with serious consequences in the near future, putting pressure on the sustainability of our social security systems. Almost 20% of young Europeans on unemployment is still too worrying for us to lower our arms. As a native of the Azores, an outermost region, I would remind you that the young people from these regions, also Europeans, continue to struggle with unemployment levels that exceed 50 %. We need other policies in these regions. In order to sustainably break this cycle of youth unemployment, we must promote forms of cooperation between governments, companies, educational institutions and social partners, so that national education and training systems can be adapted, adapting skills to the needs of the labour market and promoting targeted and sustained development of our businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises , which are key to generating growth.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Youth Guarantee programme is the great European disappointment. Firstly, because you financed it insufficiently and, secondly, because the Member States, those that are implementing it, are wasting it on programmes that do not help combat youth unemployment. But here we have two problems: one, job creation and, the other, quality of employment. Youth unemployment is always twice the average of general unemployment and that means we have to grow twice as high to absorb all youth unemployment, and for that you have to change the economic policy of the European Union. There's got to be more investment. If there is no economic growth, there will be no job creation and there will continue to be rising youth unemployment. Secondly, the quality of employment has to do with the structural reforms that have also been promoted under the European Semester. Young people today work in positions that have nothing to do with their training; quite a few are charging 20% less than the average wages charged by the general population; they live on totally involuntary partial contracts. We need to change, change to grow more and change to decently integrate a new generation of young people into our labor markets; otherwise they will unplug from the European Union, and that is what we have to avoid.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: PPE). Madam President, since I come from Greece, a country where the youth unemployment rate is 50%, I can tell you that youth unemployment is only addressed by implementing an integrated policy. Firstly, there is a need to link universities better with the labour market and to strengthen technical education. Secondly, a stable fiscal and fiscal framework is needed for significant investment in the private sector of the economy. In addition, it needs funding for small and medium-sized enterprises, which together constitute the largest collective employer. Thirdly, a correction is needed with regard to the composition of public expenditure in order to save money on investment in infrastructure and development projects without increasing public expenditure. Fourthly, the older people, the people of my generation, must stop sending the crisis bill to the younger ones, protecting our own rights and privileges at the expense of their own perspective.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this debate is an opportunity to remind people of the importance of the fight for youth employment and, on this project, much remains to be done. In this Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, we had put in place the Youth Guarantee. Some say: "But it is not used. What is that six billion? Where are they?" I am telling you that in a number of countries where this matter has been taken seriously, considerable efforts have been made, and we can see how much they need to be extended today. The youth guarantee is almost a structural reform, it is the establishment of a totally innovative mechanism for many countries. So, of course, we have to adapt the ways of doing things to accompany young people, and that is not done in a day.  At a time when the Commission is so looking for proposals that are useful both to serve the interests of Europeans and to show the power of the initiatives it can carry, it is time to revive this proposal for a youth guarantee, to give it a significant amount - we propose the twenty billion as they had been identified by the ILO - , to be concerned about the quality of the work that is being offered to young people and also to be concerned about whether to extend the period during which young people can benefit from such a guarantee, which is a means of putting them on the foot in the stirrup, which is our duty.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Colleagues, as we have heard, have positive figures here, because unemployment in general in the euro area and especially throughout the European Union is decreasing. But that doesn't mean we don't see the risks. Because every young unemployed person is a missed chance and there is a risk of frustration. The European Union is aware of this, which is why we are also talking here today about the need to continue our efforts to improve the quality of education, to support young people in their start in the labour market. The European Union is creating programmes, financial instruments for this, and I call on the European Commission to make these instruments, whether Erasmus plus or Youth Guarantee, more flexible and administratively simpler. These instruments are proving to work, but their potential is much higher for both student mobility and teacher mobility, and we are not using this huge potential that the European Union has sufficiently.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, in this debate everyone has pointed out as the main factor and cause of the high number of unemployed, unemployed young people, the economic and financial crisis that Europe is going through. In fact, and unfortunately, all over Europe there are more than 20 million young people who still have no job opportunity. If it is a reality that the "Youth Guarantee" programme has allowed in several countries - and Portugal was an example of this - to reduce a share of youth unemployment, giving opportunities to young people and also allowing companies to invest in human capital, if this was a reality, which is the fact that, at the end of this programme, it is urgent to plan the next phase. Commissioner, I would like to call here for future youth employment programmes to be prepared, with concrete measures to improve the transition to the labour market, and to prepare programmes with concrete measures to facilitate the creation of start-ups and technological projects. Commissioner, that genuine programmes be created to concretely support entrepreneurship. There is a whole generation of young people who yearn for answers and for Europe to give them these opportunities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential for the European Union to promote sustainable, inclusive and sustainable economic growth that finds an effective and natural outlet in creating the conditions for promoting youth employment. At a difficult and complex economic time for the production system, the development of networks between the training and entrepreneurial system is strategic for the development of skills consistent with innovation processes. Training planning in synergy with production must be facilitated through the development of specific sectoral poles organized according to a logic of networking, education and work able to promote dynamic and continuous training. It is sad to say this, but young Europeans do not find the conditions for the enhancement of their wealth of knowledge and their capacity for innovation.  If Europe is to be credible, it must first recover the enthusiasm of its young people by implementing policies geared to their needs and creating the conditions for them to have the skills they need to establish themselves on the labour market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, mercelian austerity has skyrocketed the unemployment rate in Europe. In particular, at the moment in Europe the long-term unemployed exceed 12 million people, while the youth unemployment rate exceeds 20% in some Member States of the Union. Of course, in countries such as Greece, which is now the champion of unemployment in Europe because of the memorandums, youth unemployment reaches 48.9% as a result of the violent fiscal adjustment imposed by the troika on Greece. At the same time, as part of the European Union's objective of recovering the 'social triple A' and boosting growth for 2016, only EUR 19 billion is expected to be given to the European Union. Euro. Of course, this figure is not enough to reduce the unemployment and poverty rates in the countries of the European South. On the contrary, the European Union should take immediate steps to introduce the European minimum wage, the European minimum wage and the European unemployment benefit in order to combat poverty in Europe and huge youth unemployment.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, we are discussing the economic situation without associating it with the real situation of European societies. From a demographic point of view, Europe is in a much worse place than it is economically, as it is the most ageing continent on the planet. This is because the wrong economic and social policies are being followed, with the result that there is insufficient support for families with minor children, while high youth unemployment is certainly more than double that of the general population. In the long term, we are caught in a vicious circle, since the innovation from which we expect economic growth and job creation to come presupposes the existence of a sufficient number of young people with new ideas. Decisive interventions by the European Union and the Member States are needed collectively and coordinated, otherwise Europe's long-term perspective is social and economic collapse.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The Youth Guarantee is therefore a wonderful instrument, which will, of course, work when the Member States have adapted both their tax and financial legislation in appropriate ways, which will be stimulating for both young people and, of course, employers. And that is, in fact, the direction in which we need to go if we are to achieve sustainable jobs, if we are to reduce the number of over-employment, which, unfortunately, is also increasing throughout Europe and putting young people at a disadvantage, especially planning for their future and, of course, housing conditions.  I think that when we talk about young people, we also need to link this to the attitude towards the circular economy – the circular economy and, of course, to the system of adequate education, which must be of good quality and therefore respond to the needs of the market.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, youth unemployment in the Republic of Croatia from which I come is 43%. This has prompted me to spend and organise a large number of youth meetings, conferences, roundtables over the past two years. My goal was to hear how they see and feel our policies for young people, whether they feel a guarantee for young people in their daily lives and whether it has helped them.  What they told me was a little devastating. There are a small number of those who really felt these measures, and those who did say the following: we went to additional education through Erasmus, we trained professionally thanks to the youth guarantee, and in the end we are still out of work and looking for our future somewhere outside the Republic of Croatia and Europe.  What we have to do is listen to them more because they have good ideas about what measures and activities to implement and we need to stop asking young people to adapt to our measures and adapt these measures to the needs of young people.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Thank you, Madam President, and special thanks for giving us all the opportunity to talk. Commissioner, I appreciated what you said and the fact that you were with us today. I would have preferred it to be the Commissioner in charge of the internal market.  For growth and jobs for young people we need a skills-rich Europe. We need economic development and a reindustrialisation strategy to create quality jobs. I am pleased that today we are suddenly debating two extremely important topics. The trade defence measures discussed at the first point today can create new job facilities for young people. There is a need for an educational policy, a vocational education, geared towards the needs of the local economy. We need a new policy to support innovation and research, where young people can excel, but we also need a new vision of fiscal policy for start-ups, for poor jobs, where investors need support for job creation. Otherwise, we will witness helplessly how the economic situation and the lives of young people are deteriorating. We need to educate young people to prefer work over social assistance, and we want incentives for investors.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – First of all, I would like to express my satisfaction that this debate has occurred. Mainly because we can highlight such sweeter problems about reducing youth unemployment in recent years, when it has really shook by almost a million. I am also pleased that the Commission has approached the mid-term review of the functioning of the guarantee scheme, which will, on the basis of new indicators, which will certainly contribute or have an impact on improving the functioning of this scheme in the second half of the financial perspective.  However, I am not particularly pleased with the discussions, with all the discussions I have heard here. We cannot build the future of young people and, rather, their employability simply on fire-fighting, through regulation, by creating new jobs for states and communities. We need to equip them above all with the appropriate competences that the economy will then be able to adopt, and that is what we will do most for young people.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, I had initially prepared a one-minute classical intervention but, hearing certain speeches, I could not resist.  The Council blames the Commission, the Commission blames the Member States, and we, unfortunately, in the European Parliament, are not well enough heard. Colleagues, we are talking about seven million unemployed young people. Seven million, in the context where we need workers in the digital market.  I refuse to make my generation a new generation lost. The poor management of European funds, as is the case in Romania, currently under the current government, must not become a reason for the decrease in budget allocations for young people. The Youth Guarantee must be continued and the Commission must ensure that it is implemented – to ensure, not to monitor. Young Europeans, young people in my country, Romania, have confidence in Europe and have legitimate expectations that we can solve them. To do this, it takes everyone, because they are our young people. We need further investment in education, in developing new skills, in the new digital economy. We need solutions now, at European level.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, unfortunately, despite the increase in employment rates across Europe, young people still experience difficulties in getting access to the labour market. Approximately 20% of young people under the age of 24 are currently not in education, employment or training – some of them for a long time. Today, young people represent the group most exposed to social exclusion in Europe; their long-term disengagement from the labour market could have severe consequences both for them and for the economy and society as a whole. We cannot stand idle when faced with this enormous challenge; we must make sure that our education systems adequately prepare them for professional life and offer them vocational support connected to the needs of the labour market, and that innovation and youth entrepreneurship are given the emphasis they deserve.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, the economic crisis has left us behind a more unequal society, with more poverty, less protected and with more precariousness in our labour markets. We only have to see the different impact it has had on disposable income between Germany and Spain: in the crisis years it has increased by 20% in Germany and decreased by 20% in Spain. Above all, this poverty and exclusion, which has caused many people today to disconnect from the European institutions and support Eurosceptic or Europhobic forces. We have promoted some programs: the Youth Guarantee, the Youth Employment Initiative; but these are programmes, it is not a complete policy in the face of a phenomenon that now haunts the whole of Europe. That is why it is necessary to have a policy of economic growth, sustainable, inclusive growth, which is a real pact between States; a true pact between classes and a pact between generations. Because a society without a future is doomed to failure.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting debate. I see that there is one point we all agree on. We must not have a lost generation. Making sure young people get a foot in the labour market remains therefore one of our highest priorities. This is first and foremost important for the young, to allow them to realise themselves through work, to have a decent wage that allows them to rent or buy accommodation and/or to start a family, that takes care of their professional development, but it is also important for society at large.  Young people tend to be better educated and computer literate. We need them to support productivity and growth in Europe. Delivering on the objectives of the Youth Guarantee requires strategic reforms to achieve more successful transitions from school to the labour market. It is a complex programme that requires time and effort in the Member States, but these efforts are starting to pay off. Progress has been carefully monitored within the European Semester, including those country-specific recommendations where appropriate.  In reply to some questions: to Marian Harkin: the majority of the Member States concerned have effectively used advance payment and today more than one million young people have benefited from the scheme directly. However a few Member States might not be in a position to have used up to 50% of the advance payment by 23 May. In that case, they will have to pay back the advance but they will not lose the money as that will stay in the Youth Employment Initiative envelope allocated to their regions. In reply to Ms Pervenche Berès: at the end of the budgetary conciliation last year the three institutions agreed to assign to the Commission the task of assessing the progress made in the execution of the Youth Employment Initiative this year and, taking into account the available budgetary margins, of considering whether additional funding should be proposed after 2016. This assessment is ongoing and while a few Member States might be obliged to pay back the increased advance payments they received one year ago, the results obtained so far deserve to be taken into consideration in the final decisions. On the calls for more growth and programmes, let me remind you that the Youth Employment Initiative is only a part of the solution. There are, for example, specific programmes for small and medium enterprises and there is also the investment plan. Moreover, the Commission has mobilised a range of instruments to support implementation, for example policy support, mutual learning between Member States, outreach campaigns. The Commission will report in October on the progress of the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me take this opportunity to signal once again our full commitment to addressing youth unemployment and let me stress once more that the Council, obviously in close cooperation with the Commission, will pursue its efforts to address the challenges and closely monitor the progress made. Let us not forget the importance of structural reforms in the Member States. The Council, the Commission, and Parliament will not be able to provide the Member States with the one and only silver bullet. It is up to the Member States to act swiftly and in time.  Ms Marian Harkin asked for concrete numbers and the Commissioner has already replied. She also asked whether the Youth Guarantee could have been implemented faster; the answer is yes. It has taken time for Youth Guarantee measures to be put in place, and therefore a complete evaluation is not yet possible, but we are getting there, slowly but surely. What struck me most in this debate were the words of Ms Rodrigues. Europe has no future if we cannot offer a future to our youth. I could not agree more, and therefore this is an important debate. I also agree with Ms McIntyre, who said that we need to create the right environment for businesses to grow so that they can hire young Europeans entering the labour market. But, as I have just said, this is not so much a matter of European funding programmes, it is first and foremost a task for Member States.  They need to implement the right structural policies in order to foster growth and jobs, and we need to keep using the European Semester and country-specific recommendations to push the Member States in the right direction and make them act accordingly.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: As you say, this is an important debate and I am happy that so many visitors – young and old – are in the Chamber to listen to the debate, which is now closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Over the last few years, we have been discussing a lot of discussions in the EU and in the Member States on how to combat youth unemployment, or at least how to reduce its negative consequences. Youth unemployment in developed, safe and educated Europe itself is quite bizarre– data show that young people have never lived better in history than now if we look at affordable nutrition, education, the level of protection of human rights and freedoms, the ability to travel for scientific and work purposes, not only in the European Union, but also around the world, without mentioning the opportunities offered by the Internet. So, does the Commission not think that, so far, we have not been too active or sufficiently active in the EU debate on the problems of today's youth and, above all, unemployment? In my opinion, too little attention has been paid to the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people so far, and in particular to the promotion of innovative entrepreneurship, for which is our younger generation best prepared? Does the Commission not think that it would be worthwhile for the EU to launch a large-scale initiative that actively engages young people , both young entrepreneurs and those who want to become them, to work together to find concrete tools to enable the younger generation and unlock its potential to create jobs not only for ourselves but also for others? Such an initiative could be one of the initiatives supported by the European Fund for Strategic Investments as a real investment in the future?

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – Youth unemployment in the EU has fallen by 25% in recent years, which is a major achievement, but further efforts are needed. On the one hand, there are significant differences between Member States and, on the other hand, the use of existing financial instruments can be improved. The complexity of the problem is that you have to think about short-term and long-term solutions at the same time.  Young people who have just graduated would need a job immediately, but significant spending on education and further training may not come later. The current €6 billion framework for the Youth Guarantee programme is a useful initiative and, on the basis of existing experience, could be increased after a periodic review. In my opinion, it is necessary to ensure that young people trained in the EU make use of their knowledge here and, if possible, fill jobs appropriate to their qualifications.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – Since the end of 2013, economic and labour data in the European Union indicate a certain recovery. This is a slow and uneven recovery between countries and with even excessively high records in terms of unemployment and poverty.  The Council and the Commission are striving to shift an optimistic view on the results achieved, insisting that this proves that economic measures, structural reforms and austerity have worked.  The reality is very different for the social majority that is now in worse condition than ten years ago and without prospects for the future.  The Youth Guarantee, for example, has not produced the expected results and needs reforms that improve its funding, implementation and ensure its use by States and young people themselves.  It is necessary, as a consequence, to change the Union's economic policies, which have been a failure in economic, social and political terms. If we are to preserve the future of the European project, we must promote progressive structural reforms, starting with a large public investment programme that encourages demand, generates sustainable growth and creates quality jobs, especially with an eye on young people.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – Since the end of 2013, economic and labour data in the European Union indicate a certain recovery. This is a slow and uneven recovery between countries and with even excessively high records in terms of unemployment and poverty. The Council and the Commission are striving to shift an optimistic view on the results achieved, insisting that this proves that economic measures, structural reforms and austerity have worked. The reality is very different for the social majority that is now in worse condition than ten years ago and without prospects for the future. The Youth Guarantee, for example, has not produced the expected results and needs reforms that improve its funding, implementation and ensure its use by States and young people themselves. It is therefore necessary to change the Union's economic policies, which have proved to be a failure in economic, social and political terms and to promote progressive structural reforms, starting with a large public investment programme, which incentivizes demand, generating sustainable growth that creates quality employment, especially with an eye on young people, if we are to preserve the future of the European project.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. – Since the end of 2013, economic and labour data in the European Union indicate a certain recovery. This is a slow and uneven recovery between countries and with even excessively high records in terms of unemployment and poverty. The Council and the Commission are striving to shift an optimistic view on the results achieved, insisting that this proves that economic measures, structural reforms and austerity have worked. The reality is very different for the social majority that is now in worse condition than ten years ago and without prospects for the future. The Youth Guarantee, for example, has not produced the expected results and needs reforms that improve its funding, implementation and ensure its use by States and young people themselves. It is therefore necessary to change the Union's economic policies, which have proved to be a failure in economic, social and political terms and to promote progressive structural reforms, starting with a large public investment programme, which incentivizes demand, generating sustainable growth that creates quality employment, especially with an eye on young people, if we are to preserve the future of the European project.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The link between economic growth and tackling high levels of unemployment is undeniable. But in order to involve the young in the working market, we cannot rely entirely on European youth employment programmes and state programmes. Career prospects are driven by a stable and prosperous economy on the one hand, as well as an increase in the qualifications and mobility of Europeans on the other. The European economy is growing at around 2% a year, but according to the European Commission's recent economic forecast, unemployment will fall by only half. This means that we need to change our economic model, creating new opportunities for young people to be involved. Encouraging young entrepreneurs and providing traineeships and apprenticeships are at the heart of this new model, which not only boosts employment but also boosts the economy. It is also important to encourage the construction of the skills sought by the business – in the next four years a high qualification of another 16 million will be required. Jobs. And for these staff to be available anywhere in Europe, we also need to improve professional mobility. The legal prerequisites for the free movement of labour are present, but now it is also time to overcome practical and administrative obstacles, creating a truly transparent labour market.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – More than 20 million people are unemployed in the EU, 22.8% of whom are young. Some Member States have a very high youth unemployment rate, notably Greece (57.7 %), Spain (54 %), Italy (43 %), Cyprus (36 %) and Portugal (34.8 %). 8.3 million young people under the age of 25 do not engage in an activity, 19% of children are at risk of poverty, 8% of people are victims of severe material deprivation, 15% of children leave school without completing secondary education, 24.2% of people are at risk of poverty, poor workers account for one third of working-age adults at risk of poverty and the number of homeless people in the EU reaches 410 000 , by night.  This is a picture of a catastrophic combination of EU austerity policies and neoliberal structural reforms that has contributed decisively to unprecedented levels of investment in the economy, while purchasing power and domestic demand have decreased and income inequality and poverty have increased, as is very dramatic in the countries under the troika.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: In accordance with Rule 152(2) and in agreement with the political groups, I propose the following change to Wednesday’s agenda concerning the debate on the oral question to the Council and Commission on the follow-up to Parliament’s resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. The proposal is to postpone this until the June I part-session in order to enable the Council to be appropriately represented: its representatives have to leave earlier tomorrow evening. Are there any objections? No? Then our agenda is amended accordingly.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I notice that 25 pages of amendments were put forward by Herr Giegold last night but they were only put forward in German. Is that perhaps a precursor to the vote that is taking place in the United Kingdom on 23 June? Or are you now perhaps getting into hand to take English, with regards to a language, with regards to proceedings in its place?

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr Carver, I am told that all the amendments were tabled last week and they have all been translated, so I do not see the point of your argument, except for making some comment on the upcoming vote in the UK in more than a month.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation is concerned with protection against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. This proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against subsidised imports originating in non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since June 2009.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation to codify the defence regulation against imports that are subsidized by third countries.  Indeed, this codification does not call into question the substance of this regulation, which tends to protect States from unfair trade practices, but seeks, in the interests of transparency, to consolidate the various acts that will be incorporated into the new text.  The aim here is to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the "subsidy agreement" and the countervailing measures concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The agreement put in place a series of detailed measures to counter imports that are subsidized by third countries.  I have therefore supported this report which protects Member States' economies from unfair trade practices through the introduction of a new regulation detailing clearer rules.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it is a simple codification of existing texts, without any amendment on the substance.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
