text: In writing. This report aims to protect Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It is part of protectionism against unfair practices. So I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The legislation is a proposal to codify Council Regulation EC No. 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community. It gathers amendments into one single document. However, it also aims to transpose into EU law the provisions of the World Trade Organisation Subsidies Agreement to ensure proper and transparent application of the anti-subsidy rules. I considered it appropriate to abstain on this measure. Although it is a legislative act, it does not alter the law. It will make no practical difference to industries impacted by subsidised imports.  There is no reason to oppose it; if such measures were to come before the British Parliament I might well support them. However, it should be the UK that implements WTO rules in the UK, and not the European Union.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This text proposes to codify the Council's 11 June 2009 regulation on defence against imports that are subsidized by third countries. This new regulation before us is therefore intended to transpose into EU legislation the countervailing measures agreed in the WTO framework in order to ensure a transparent application of the anti-subsidy rules: for example, it is a question of defining the conditions for granting a subsidy, or the principles governing the applicability of countervailing duties that can be imposed precisely in order to compensate for any subsidy granted.  This text should therefore protect Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. Finally, this is the outline of European protectionism, which is more necessary than ever against unfair practices that penalise our companies, especially against their Chinese competitors; I therefore voted in favour of this text. It should be remembered, however, that by a judgment of 2 February 2012, the Luxembourg Court of Justice forced the European Union to reverse the only protectionist measures it has ever taken, namely anti-dumping taxes on shoes from China and Vietnam.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this proposal, which is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without any change in substance.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Hautala report on the proposal for a regulation of parliament and of the Council on the protection against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. This is a technical measure which merely codifies existing texts, favouring and simplifying the way in which existing legislation is accessed. I therefore agreed with the aim of the report and decided to vote in favour.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. It proposes the codification of the regulation on protection against subsidized products, imported from third countries.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on defence against imports that are subsidized by non-EU countries must in fact proceed with the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 597/2009. This proposed regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it; it fully preserves the substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself. Thus, the regulation should allow the provisions of the "subsidy agreement" and the countervailing measures agreed under the World Trade Organization (WTO) to be transposed into EU legislation in order to ensure transparent application of anti-subsidy rules.  This text is on the right track because it seeks to protect the economies of Member States from subsidised imports from third countries and thus contributes to protectionism against the unfair practices we call for. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Hautala report is to some degree acceptable, it does not represent a real step forward in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy legislation. I believe, however, that stronger action is needed, as I have been saying for years, to make EU legislation more restrictive and to effectively oppose dumping cases that cause serious damage to our businesses. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial changes thereof.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the regulation on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union, since after considering this proposal, the Consultative Working Party decided by common agreement that the proposal merely aims to codify existing texts without changing their substance. In the European context, the Commission attaches great importance to making EU law simpler and clearer in order to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens who can gain new opportunities and benefit from the specific rights conferred on them. This objective will not be achieved if many provisions, which have been amended and often substantially amended several times, remain scattered in various acts, and therefore some of them should be sought in the original act and others in subsequent amending acts. Therefore, in order to find the rules in force at a given moment, research work needs to be carried out in comparing the various pieces of legislation. For this reason, in order for the law to be clear and transparent, it is important to codify the rules that have been frequently amended.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union's internal market must be protected against external dumping, because it helps to preserve and create jobs. It is therefore appropriate to explain in sufficient detail the cases in which aid should be presumed to exist, the principles on which it should be considered countervailable (in particular in the case of the granting of targeted aid) and the criteria for calculating the amount of countervailable subsidy. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ I supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against subsidised imports from countries that are not members of the European Union. The Consultative Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, after examining the proposal for a Council regulation for codification, decided by mutual agreement that the corroditionation of the second paragraph of Article 9(2) of Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 should be published.  In the current paragraph, the term "producer" shall be deleted and the new paragraph shall read: "For the purposes of this paragraph, one shall be deemed to control the other when the former is in a legal or actual position to restrict or guide the latter." It is a codification of existing texts and not substantive changes, so I had no reservations about supporting the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 597/2009 of the Council of 11 June 2009 on defence against imports that are subject to subsidies from third countries. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries, thus contributing to protectionism against unfair practices. I voted for it as I did in the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this codification because I believe that it allows a more orderly organisation of the legal framework governing the defence against subsidised imports from non-EU countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In the interests of transparency, this report aims to codify Council Regulation 597/2009 of 11 June 2009, relating to defence against imports that are subsidized by third countries. This regulation sets out the conditions for the existence of a subsidy as well as the principles governing the calculation of countervailing duties applied to imported products subject to subsidies. Because this text protects the economies of the European Union from certain unfair practices of third countries, I voted in favour of this proposed regulation. However, let us not be fooled, this regulation will not put an end to the unfair international competition that our companies are experiencing, particularly that which exists in the European Union.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for protection against subsidised imports from non-Eu countries is intended to codify Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 of 11 June 2009. This proposal does not make changes in the content of acts, but only changes in form so that they are more accessible to citizens. It is important that the citizen is given a favourable framework to make use of the rights conferred on him by these acts. This requires greater clarity and transparency of the legal provisions so that these acts become accessible and serve the interests of citizens. I was in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to codify legislation in order to better understand the provisions by citizens and to ensure the premises for citizen involvement.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 In both Hautala reports, we are faced with a mere codification of anti-dumping regulations, in this case Regulation (EC) No 597/2009. On the substance, however, it is a question of correcting a passage in the text which in no way represents a substantial change, as the Committee on Legal Affairs itself has stated. There are many other substantive and substantial interventions that the anti-dumping legislation should receive and certainly not just interventions such as today's. On the contrary, the Lega Nord has been fighting for years for anti-dumping and anti-subsidy rules to be updated in a more restrictive sense.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation which brings together all the provisions relating to defence against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union, making European legislation in this area clearer and more transparent. Public subsidies granted by the country of origin of the imported product or by an intermediate country from which the product is exported to the EU distort competition because they allow the selling price of products placed on the market to be lowered and are a serious detriment to European companies. European legislation on the protection against subsidised non-EU imports provides a precise definition of subsidy and contains provisions for calculating the benefit conferred on the beneficiary, for ascertaining the damage and opening the proceedings, for the adoption of provisional measures and definitive countervailing duties. In order to ensure the correct application of these measures in defence of subsidies, it requires the active participation of Member States which have to notify the Commission of trade in imports of products subject to investigation or subject to measures. The Commission, for its part, may request Member States to provide information to monitor the effectiveness of the measures in force.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a technical vote, taken as part of the codification process. This process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In the current case, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Regulation on Protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community made since 2009. As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the codification procedure should be applied to this Regulation on Protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the EU. No changes will be made to the substance of the Regulation but the existing texts will be put together into a single new act.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries as this is merely a codification of the changes that have taken place recently.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as the European Commission's proposal is simply codifying existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the codification report of the text of a proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against imports subsidised by non-EU countries. As this is a technical process of consolidating and codifying different versions and amendments that the text has undergone since 2009 and does not concern its substance, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 It was easy to vote in favour of this report as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. I therefore agreed with the aim of simplifying existing legislation on 'unfair' competition in imports from non-EU countries.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of a people’s Europe, we attach great importance to simplifying and clarifying the law of the European Union so as to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens, thus giving them new opportunities and the chance to make use of the specific rights it gives them. This aim cannot be achieved so long as numerous provisions that have been amended several times, often quite substantially, remain scattered, so that they must be sought partly in the original instrument and partly in later amending ones. Considerable research work, comparing many different instruments, is thus needed to identify the current rules.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the Citizens' Europe, it is imperative to simplify and clarify EU law, making it more accessible and easier for citizens to understand, which allows for new opportunities and possibilities to benefit from the rights of the Union recognised to it. This objective is not attainable as long as there is a dispersion of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially. To this end, I support this Report codified Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on defence against imports which are subsidised by non-Member States of the European Community, with the aim of simplifying and clarifying EU law.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 European trade policy must be protected from subsidised imports for goods from third countries. I therefore welcome the proposal to establish a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at safeguarding trade in the States of the European Union. This Regulation lays down Community rules concerning the imposition of a countervailing duty, the purpose of which is to rebalance the market for subsidies granted, directly or indirectly, for the manufacture, production, export or transport of any product from a third country whose placing on the EU market causes injury to competitors. I voted in favour of the proposal, which is a codification of existing texts, which does not require substantial changes, as established by the Advisory Group which examined its compliance with EU legislation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the scope of the report to eliminate the trade-distorting effects of injurious subsidisation and to restore effective competition. It is necessary to provide for the possibility for the Commission to request Member States to supply, subject to confidentiality rules, information to be used for monitoring price undertakings and verifying the level of effectiveness of the measures in force.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against subsidised imports originating in non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since June 2009.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This European Parliament resolution is important for clarifying certain aspects of imports from subsidised companies to non-EU countries. I believe that it is necessary to establish clear indicative values in order to determine whether subsidised imports are prejudicial to European industries; values that take into account the conditions of both non-member countries and the European market. Furthermore, I believe that improving the system of countervailing duties and provisional duties can help to establish objective rules on subsidies and injury. Finally, I support the introduction of a provision on the circumvention of compensatory measures, which is currently taking place not only within the EU, but also outside the Eu ropean Union. By voting in favour, I therefore intend to support the proposal for a regulation on these significant aspects, the improvement of which would enable the Union market to function transparently and competitively.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Commission was required to present to Parliament and the Council several feasibility studies on extending the obligation to label the origin of certain categories of food. They do not contain any legal proposal, as such a proposal, according to the Commission, would have to increase the cost to industry and consumers are not willing to bear the additional costs.  I support the principle of mandatory labelling of the country of origin of food where this is practical and is based on the needs of consumers. I therefore do not share the Commission's conclusions. The Commission's analysis is useful, but the conclusion does not address important aspects, i.e. the profits from better informed consumers. Mandatory indications already exist for many products, i.e. meat, eggs, fruit, vegetables, fish, honey, oil, wine and alcoholic beverages.  The commission's call for it to put forward a proposal for a mandatory designation, which will be limited to milk and lightly processed dairy products such as cheese and cream, as well as slightly processed meats (i.e. bacon and sausages), should be accepted if there is evidence of consumer interest in such information. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on improving the EU's defence tools against imports that are subsidized by non-EU countries. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, this text aims to codify the 11 June 2009 regulation on defence against imports that are subsidized by third countries. The proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself.  The proposed regulation aims to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the "subsidies and countervailing measures agreement" concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) to ensure transparent enforcement of anti-subsidy rules. To the extent that this text protects the economies of Member States from subsidised imports from third countries and is part of protectionism against unfair practices, I voted in favour.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it only attempts to codify the legislation regulating the framework of defence against imports subsidised by non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. In order to simplify and give clarity to EU law, and to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, research and comparison of the numerous acts is required in order to determine the provisions in force. In this regard, the purpose of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 of 11 June 2009 on the defence against subsidised imports originating in non-EU countries. The proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and therefore merely regroups them by making only the formal amendments that the coding operation itself requires

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal in question on protection against subsidised imports from countries which are not members of the European Union is merely a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their content and substance.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because I am convinced that we need more restrictive anti-dumping and anti-subsidy rules.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it only attempts to codify the legislation regulating the framework of defence against imports subsidised by non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's efforts to simplify and make EU legislation more transparent. The aim is to make them clearer and more accessible to citizens, thus further expanding the possibilities for exercising the rights granted to them. However, in order for the legislation to be clear and transparent, codification of acts which have been amended several times is necessary. I therefore accept the opinion of the Working Party of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on codification of protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries and vote in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report after finding that this is a proposal which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this resolution as it aims to provide an increased legal basis for taking action in regard to protecting EU markets and producers. It is of great importance that the EU has the ability to protect EU workers and businesses from unfair business practices used by countries outside of the European Union. This is not only a matter of economics but also a matter of responsibility and trust and the EU needs to have a high degree of flexibility in regard to market protection to preserve both fair market practices and the trust of our citizens.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution on the agreement reached with the Council on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. This regulation is in fact part of the need for clarity and transparency of the law and aims to transpose into European Union legislation the provisions of the Agreement on Subsidies and Compensatory Measures within the framework of the World Trade Organisation, so as to ensure transparent application of these provisions. The Regulation therefore lays down the conditions governing the existence of a subsidy, the principles governing the applicability of compensatory duties and the criteria for calculating subsidies liable to compensatory measures.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, as I believe that EU action in this area is justified and necessary. What countries like China present to us in sectors such as steel production on the world market has nothing to do with free, fair competition. I therefore also raise my voice for hundreds of thousands of steelworkers in Germany and their families: reasonable punitive tariffs against global price dumping can help to preserve their jobs!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Subsidised imports from non-EU countries are infrinling the Union's competitiveness. Our producers within the industries are permanently affected and disadvantaged by these subsidised goods. With regard to the protection of the internal European market, I support the proposal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. It proposes the codification of the regulation on protection against subsidized products, imported from third countries.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it is necessary for Member States to supervise and report to the Commission on imports of products under examination or measures and on the amount of duties levied under EU law in order to ensure the correct application of the measures. In addition, it is important to allow the Commission to ask Member States to communicate it, subject to confidentiality rules, in order to be able to use this information to monitor price commitments and verify the effectiveness of the measures in force. This report is also necessary to ensure fair competition in the internal market and consumer protection.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation. It is necessary to explain when a subsidy is to be deemed to exist, according to which principles it is to be countervailable, and according to which criteria the amount of the countervailable subsidy is to be calculated.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal for a regulation on the protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union. The proposed regulation sets out in detail the conditions determining the existence of a subsidy, the principles governing the applicability of countervailing duties that may be imposed to offset any subsidy granted directly or indirectly, for the manufacture, production, export or transport of any product whose release for free circulation in the EU causes injury, and the criteria applicable to the calculation of the amount of the countervailing subsidy. This would transpose the provisions of the subsidies and countervailing measures concluded within the World Trade Organization into EU law.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council to protect against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, as this does not prejudice the substance of the proposal, but is mainly about technical amendments. Codified acts do not change in content, but they are simplified and become clearer and more accessible to citizens.  In this context, I support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated process for the swift adoption of codified acts, and for Commission staff to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments. In addition, I believe it is important to enable citizens to access their rights without difficulty and to ensure their certainty.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It encourages protectionism against unfair practices. So I voted for it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is a straightforward codification of an existing text on protection against imports of subsidised products from non-EU countries. Since there was no change in the factual content, I had no problem supporting the text with it. The proposed regulation aims to introduce into EU law the provisions of subsidy and countervailing measures concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organisation in order to ensure the proper and transparent application of anti-subsidy rules. The Regulation lays down clear conditions determining the existence of the subsidy, the principles governing the applicability of countervailing duties or the criteria applicable to the calculation of the amount of the compensatory subsidy.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the "subsidies and countervailing measures agreement" concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), in order to ensure transparent application of anti-subsidy rules.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report on protection against subsidised imports from third countries. This is a codification of the existing act without any substantive changes. For the sake of clarity and clarity, it is therefore necessary to codify the Regulation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report on defence against subsidised imports from non-EU countries. This Regulation lays down Community rules on the imposition of a countervailing duty with the aim of promoting a fairer and more viable market. With regard to the proposal under consideration, the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission calls for the existing texts to be codifying. In view of what has been mentioned, I support the text as proposed by the rapporteur.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on defence against imports, which are subsidised by non-EU countries. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify the defence regulation against imports that are subsidized by third countries. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It therefore protects them from unfair practices.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is a simple codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance. In addition, it protects Member States' economies from unfair trade practices.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The objectives of the report are to protect domestic productions from competition from third countries, with an emphasis on transparency. The aim is to update a 2009 EU regulation that defends imports subsidised by third countries. The proposed amendments are simply formal. The new regulation is now a continuation of the "subsidy agreement" signed under the WTO (World Trade Organization). This agreement provides for transparent enforcement of anti-subsidy rules and establishes countervailing measures to protect states from imported products that could cause them economic harm. This text is protectionist in nature and defends the economies of the Member States, a rarity. I am very much in favour of it, I logically voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report is only a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since June 2009, so I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report deals with the codification of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the defence against subsidised imports originating in countries not members of the European Union. The Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission examined the European Commission's proposal and concluded that this is a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial amendment thereof. Committed to improving the way the EU legislates and en getting EU legislation to serve citizens and businesses more appropriately.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal only puts in a clearer document the rules already in force, which are also based on agreements within the Framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). I also agree with the principle that it is justifiable to impose a compensatory duty on commodities that are favoured by subsidies abroad.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The application of the provisions of protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries greatly protects the Union's economic interests and contributes to the maintenance and creation of jobs.  Over time, the provisions have changed several times. Such a thing has led to various provisions being scattered under different acts, making it very difficult to find the rules in force. An advisory group consisting of the legal services of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament proposed a clearer codification of the text without substantive amendments.  I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries relating to the codification of the text. I consider it very important to simplify and better codify the text, so that it is more accessible to all citizens of the Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The new regulation aims to transpose into EU law the provisions on subsidies and countervailing measures that were concluded and codified within the Framework of the World Trade Organisation in order to ensure the correct and transparent application of anti-subsidy rules. The Regulation lays down the detailed conditions under which the existence of the facts of the subsidisation is identified, as well as the principles governing the applicability of countervailing duties which could be imposed to offset the direct or indirect grant of subsidies for the manufacture, manufacture, export or transport of any product the release for free circulation in the European Union of which causes damage and the criteria applicable to the calculation of the subsidy countervailing amounts. In itself, the regulation does not bring anything new in legal terms, but it combines the existing rules. It was therefore logical to support the new codification.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against imports subsidised by non-EU countries, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation. This text consists of a codification of Regulation (EC) No. 597/2009 of 11 June 2009 relating to defence against publicly subsidized imports. This regulation transposes the World Trade Organization's agreement on subsidies and countervailing measures. Very detailed, it defines, among other things: the criteria for defining a subsidy, the application of compensatory measures, etc. We can only support this regulation which relatively protects European productions from market distortions caused by public subsidies.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the proposal for a regulation on protection against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. The Commission attaches great importance to the simplification and clear formulation of EU legislation, so that it becomes clearer and more accessible to citizens, giving them new opportunities to enforce the rights enshrined in the legislation. It is therefore necessary to codify the provisions that have undergone various changes if the legislation is to be simple, clear and transparent. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is only to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution on the codification of the existing legislation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency. The text before us aims to codify Regulation (EC) 597/2009 on the defence of Europe against subsidised imports from non-Eu countries. It is this regulation that sets out the European rules establishing countervailing duties whose aim is to compensate for any subsidy granted, directly or indirectly, to the manufacture, production, export or transport of any product, from a third country, whose marketing on the EU market is causing harm to competitors. But it also gives the Commission the power to amend, suspend or repeal compensatory measures or to provide for the full or partial exemption from countervailing duties. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The validation of this report must follow through on a regulation to determine criteria for imports receiving subsidies from third countries. This concern for transparency is part of a process of protection against this kind of importation. It is a defence against unfair practices. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 of 11 June 2009 on the defence against imports which are subsidised by non-Member States of the European Community. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this codification as it provides clearer rules on the protection of European enterprises against unfair business practices and does not unduly change the substance of the existing regulations.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the proposal of the European Parliament and the Council on the defence of imports which are subsidised by non-EU countries. This regulation aims to codify existing texts (regulation (EC) 597/2009) without changing their contents, but by making the few formal amendments prescribed by the very act of codification and simplification. The Council's original 2009 regulation on this subject has undergone many significant changes. Therefore, in accordance with the commission's instructions on the importance of codification in 1987, the inter-institutional agreement in 1994 on the rapid procedure of codified acts, and, in order to clarify EU law to make it more accessible to our fellow Europeans, it is essential to establish a clear regulation which would replace the many others already in place. In addition to codifying existing texts, one of the objectives of this proposal is to include in EU law the rules contained in the "subsidies agreement" approved at the WTO. The conditions for a subsidy are detailed, as are the principles governing the imposition of countervailing duties and how to calculate them.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The 1994 Anti-Dumping Agreement contains detailed rules concerning in particular the calculation of dumping, the procedures for initiating and conducting investigations, including the determination and handling of facts, the imposition of provisional measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the disclosure of information concerning anti-dumping investigations. In order to ensure the proper application of its rules, terminology should be introduced into Union law. Taking into account the failure of multilateral negotiations to date and pending the outcome of the referral to the WTO Anti-Dumping Committee, Union legislation should contain provisions to address procedures, including the assembly of goods in the Union or a third country, aimed at circumventing anti-dumping measures. The negative consequence of the dispersion of many provisions in several legal acts is the search for and subsequent comparativeisation of legal acts in order to identify a positive right. I therefore consider it necessary to highlight the need for codification providing legal certainty in finding the law applicable at a particular point in time to protect dumped imports from countries which are not members of the Union, taking into account, of course, the standard procedures for the adoption of Union acts. I therefore fully support this proposal to codify the regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries that are not members of the European Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the EU because this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council the adoption of a regulation on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union. In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the Commission's proposal, as amended in accordance with the recommendations of the Advisory Working Party. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the subsidy agreement and countervailing measures agreed under the World Trade Organization to ensure transparent enforcement of anti-subsidy rules. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It is part of protectionism against unfair practices and can therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Under Article 103 of the Regulation of the European Parliament, a regulation of the existing regulatory framework for the defence of imports which are subsidised by non-EU countries is codified.  In the case of an codification, the amendments cannot substantiate a modification at the substantive level, and should therefore be confined only to the pure and simple compilation of existing texts. In this regard, I am voting in favour of this resolution, because I believe it is advantageous that the regulation of this matter is not dispersed and that it is only contained in a legislative legislation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It also participates in protectionism against unfair practices. That's why I voted FOR.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that contains a codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance regarding protection against subsidised imports from countries that are not members of the European Union.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that protection against subsidised imports from countries that are not members of the European Union is absolutely necessary for the sustainable development of the European community and for ensuring fair market competition. In this respect, the report voted on today reiterates the rules adopted in 2009, the latter being grouped together, a change in form necessary for the coding operation. Last but not least, I am in favour of the provisions of this report because I believe that its most important role is to protect and encourage domestic production and, therefore, the economic development of the Member States.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because this report is a mere codification of the existing legal texts without any substantive changes. Furthermore, the report seems to me to be very clear and clear, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It is essential to adequately protect the Community market and prevent possible injury to EU industry. It is therefore necessary to address all existing errors and legal loopholes in order to ensure that trade defence measures against imports from third countries are applied smoothly and effectively. The codified version of this legislation will provide sufficient protection against the negative effects of subsidies, better enforcement of policy objectives and contribute to the benefits of EU regulation. Legal trade defence instruments will help to eliminate distortions on the domestic and international market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the European Commission's proposal to Parliament and the Council, given that for the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal concerns only the codification of existing texts without making any substantial changes, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – International trade is key to building a worldwide economic network and enabling emerging economies to improve their situation. Nevertheless international trade must be controlled and regulated to not allow unfair advantages for some individuals or businesses over others. I support the proposal concerning the amendments to ensure the appropriate and transparent application of the anti-subsidy and anti-dumping rules to guarantee fair competition between EU firms and their non EU competitors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Council Regulation (EC) No. 597/2009 of 11 October 2015 On June 30, 2009, on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, it shall specify in detail the conditions determining the existence of aid, the principles governing the applicability of countervailing duties charged for equalisation of any subsidy, granted directly or indirectly, for the production, manufacture, export or transport of any product whose release into the EU causes infringement, as well as the criteria applicable to the calculation of the amount of countervailing subsidies. Given that the European Commission adopted a rule on 1 April 1987 that all acts should be codified after at least ten amendments, and that the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 decided on an accelerated method of codification work, I consider that codification of this act is necessary to contribute to its correct application and at the same time to the greater legal certainty of the stakeholders to which the legal acts relate.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of a first-reading position, taking on a Commission proposal tailored to the recommendations of the European Parliament, Council and Commission legal services advisory group. An advisory group consisting of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has considered the proposal for a Council regulation on codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 597/2009 as of 11 June 2009 on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, and agreed that a correction to the second sub-paragraph of Article 9(2) of the ECT should be published. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 597/2009 The word 'manufacturer' should be deleted in the existing text of that subdia. As a result of this necessary correction, the text of the sub-item in question would be as follows: 'For the meaning of this paragraph, one shall be deemed to control one another where the first is legally or operationally able to restrict or manage the other.' Accordingly, the Advisory Working Group unanimously concluded on the basis of the study of the proposal that the proposal constitutes a direct codification of existing texts without substantive changes and therefore, I support such a proposal from the Commission.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 of 11 June 2009 on defence against imports which are subsidised by non-EU countries, by means of a new Regulation replacing the various acts contained therein. Regulations aimed at protecting 'EU industries', by establishing a procedure to enable such protection to be applied in the legal framework. It points to measures that take into account situations of tax evasion and the influence it has on the products that are imported. It lays down provisions for the protection of state and commercial secrets.   This proposal makes formal amendments to the text, integrating a set of amendments introduced to legislation since 2009, and there have been no substantial amendments amending the fund of the Regulation.  Although this is a coding process, we do not review ourselves in a set of references and expressions that are updated, such as 'EU industries' pointing to a sense of EU federalisation, disregarding the diversity, development profile and unique characteristics of industries within each Member State, reasons that motivated our abstention.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU market is the largest single market in the world where consumers and investors enjoy many benefits of free movement of people, goods, services and money. In the application of subsidised import instruments from third countries, WTO rules must be strictly respected and otherwise illegal and unjustified measures are implemented that adversely affect free and fair trade as one of the cornerstones of the EU. I supported Mep Hautal's report, as it is essential that export opportunities are made flowable with a reasonable restriction of market access. Emphasis should be placed on the application of a balanced and moderate approach and strict standards that go beyond the EU's WTO commitments. The continuation of the modernisation project is of great importance in order to improve the current EU trade defence system for the benefit of all stakeholders. I also welcome the continuation of education and further development of bilateral contacts with industries.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 From my point of view, it is very important that every EU citizen has access to information on the activities and outputs of the various EU institutions. In order to ensure clearer and better access to data, individual legislative acts need to be codified. For this reason, I support the implementation of the codification of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against imports of subsidised products from countries which are not members of the European Union. Codification makes it easier to find the documents you need and helps prevent misunderstandings, such as searching for a valid version of a document that has already been modified several times. I believe that a more user-friendly system for searching FOR EU documents will lead to a better understanding by EU citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which refers to an outright codification of existing defence texts against imports that are subject to subsidies from non-EU countries. The aim here is to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the subsidy agreement and the countervailing measures reached in the negotiations within the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the simplification and clarification of EU law which makes it more easy and correct to interpret by European citizens, this proposal codifies Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009, as considered relevant by the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. In this respect, the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament gave its assent to the recommendation of the Advisory Group composed of the services of the three institutions and, since the proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of the texts, without substantive amendments, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, it is only the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution since it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because, in view of the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council (COM (2014)0667) and on the basis of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0256/2015), it is considered that, in the opinion of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance, and therefore instructs its President to pass on Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the national parliaments.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is clear that subsidised exports are a brake on free competition and a killer of innovation. By declaring free competition as a fundamental value of the European Union, we cannot accept distortions of competition. The draft resolution under consideration gives a sufficiently detailed overview of this issue. It is true that I believe that it pays far too little attention to the challenges faced by less developed EU Member States in relation to third-country subsidised exports to the EU. Nevertheless, I am voting in favour and I call on my colleagues to support this report, while bearing in mind that the less developed EU Member States face specific problems with third countries' subsidised exports to the EU and pay a very high social and economic price for it. I call on the Commission to take these aspects more into account when considering specific measures to combat subsidised exports from third countries.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the Citizens' Europe, great importance is given to simplification and clarification of European law.  For this reason, in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the legal provisions, normative acts which are frequently changed have been codified.  To that extent, I was in favour of the adoption of this report which codified Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 of 11 June 2009 on the defence against imports which are subsidised by non-EU countries. The new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against imports that are subsidised by non-EU countries. The text supports the Commission's proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission. The proposal is a codification of existing texts, without altering their substance. The proposed regulation aims to transpose into EU legislation the provisions of the "subsidies and countervailing measures agreement" concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) to ensure transparent enforcement of anti-subsidy rules. It also clarifies the definitions of the various legal terms.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. The report gives the opinion of Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs on a proposal for a regulation, which focuses on defence against subsidised imports from non-EU countries. The report proposes an amendment to the existing texts, but retains their substance. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. It proposes the codification of the regulation on protection against subsidized products, imported from third countries.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against subsidised imports originating in non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since June 2009.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. Since the new regulation replaces the various regulations it incorporates, preserving their substance and making only the formal amendments necessary for the codification work, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the Commission's proposal was subject to a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance, I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation on protection against subsidised imports from non-Union countries, as this is mainly a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing the substance of the text. The objective of this Regulation is to bring into European law provisions concerning subsidies and countervailing measures resulting from the Agreement with the World Trade Organisation (WTO). This should ensure the proper and transparent application of the anti-subsidy rules. In its entirety, the Regulation lays down detailed conditions defining the existence of subsidies and principles governing the application of countervailing obligations which may be imposed as a countervailing measure against direct or indirect subsidies. This measure mainly concerns the production, extraction, export or transport of any goods whose free circulation in the EU could be detrimental to the Union market and also the criteria used to calculate the volume of countervailable subsidies. I believe that it is important for the current shape of the world economy that economic exchange takes place on the basis of clear conditions. I am therefore glad that the EU is adjusting its legislation to comply with WTO agreements.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 External economic relations significantly affect not only the performance of the EU economy, but also the external balance or imbalances of the EU. Subsidised imports can cause material injury, in particular to industries within the EU. It is therefore necessary to adopt commitments and measures which, on the one hand, do not distort competition and, on the other hand, reflect the current market conditions of the Union.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 The proposal concerns only codification of existing texts without substantive changes. On the basis of consideration of the proposal for a Council regulation on codification of The Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, 597/2009 as of 11 June 2009 on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, the Advisory Working Group agreed that a correction to the second sub-paragraph of Article 9(2) of the ECT should be published. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 597/2009 The proposal is that the word 'manufacturer' be deleted in the existing text of that subdiain. I agree with this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, as the content of the Regulation will essentially remain the same and a quality change will achieve a more clearly worded Regulation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes.  On the basis of consideration of the proposal for a Council regulation on codification of The Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, 597/2009 as of 11 June 2009 on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, the Advisory Working Group agreed that a correction to the second sub-paragraph of Article 9(2) of the ECT should be published. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 597/2009 The word 'manufacturer' should be deleted in the existing text of that subdia. I agree with this codification proposal because I believe it is a quality change aimed at a more clearly worded Regulation. The content of the Regulation essentially remains the same.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union. The report does not bring about any substantive changes, but is just a codification of the existing text.  In that way, there was a correction of the second paragraph of Article 9, deleting the term "producer". The Consultative Group also unanimously concluded that this amendment was not of a substantive nature, but only a codification of the existing text.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a report that is part of the process of codifying European legislation, incorporating all the amendments made from time to time and updating the legislation. We voted in favour of the report because it is a purely procedural vote.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report attempts only to codify the legislation regulating the framework of defence against imports subsidised by non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which adopted an amendment to the codified Council Regulation on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community. The amendment follows a proposal from an advisory working group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which proposes the deletion of a word from the Regulation. Since the necessary correction does not substantially amend the existing text, I saw no impediment to the adoption of the report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The unprecedented development of international trade in recent decades has generated an abundance of goods on world markets. This is in favour of consumers, who thus have a wide range of products that they can purchase. However, commercial activity must be carried out within a certain regulatory framework, which gives all agents involved equal conditions to promote their products in certain foreign markets. The European Union is an integrated market that operates on the principles of the free market, but has set itself a priority to protect trade agents in the Member States from unfair competition from third-country agents. Thus, when a number of commercial agents in third countries receive subsidies from that State, they acquire an unnatural advantage over European ones. In these circumstances, the European institutions can and must impose a number of compensatory measures, by means of common customs duties, to balance the situation. This text makes insignificant changes to existing European regulations in the field that provide the necessary protection to Member States. I therefore support its adoption in this form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Considering that, in the opinion of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without any modification of their substance, the European Parliament has validated the text.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of codifying the proposal for a regulation on the protection against subsidised imports from countries that are not members of the European Union, as it will render the regulation clearer and therefore more accessible to citizens. This regulation is aimed at protecting our internal market from harmful market practices, by ensuring that the EU law integrates and applies the anti-subsidy rules agreed upon with the WTO in a correct and transparent way. In other words, these rules clarify under what conditions subsidies are justified and when they are harmful to our market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against subsidised imports from non-EU countries, as this proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The European Commission attaches great importance to simplifying and explaining Union law to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens and to give citizens the opportunity to exercise their specific rights it has been given to them. However, this objective cannot be achieved while many provisions have been amended several times and assigned to different acts and must be sought partly in the original and partly in the amending acts. That is why I consider it extremely important to codify rules that have been changed frequently.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ i supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against subsidised imports from countries that are not members of the European Union (codified text). According to the Consultative Group of Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is only a codification of existing texts without any substantive changes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. It proposes the codification of the regulation on protection against subsidized products, imported from third countries.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify the Council's 11 June 2009 regulation on defence against imports that are subsidized by third countries. The proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it; it fully preserves the substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries. It is part of intelligent protectionism against unfair practices. I voted for this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. It proposes the codification of the regulation on protection against subsidized products, imported from third countries.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this codification-technical report as the new regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; it fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission found that the Commission's proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial modification. That is why this Parliament approves the Commission's proposal adapted to the recommendations of the advisory group. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because the proposal is a simplified codification of existing legislation, without its content being adapted.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is based so only on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Regulation (EC) 597/2009 has been amended several times and in substantial respects. For the sake of clarity and clarity, it is appropriate to codify that Regulation. As this report is a mere codification of the existing legal texts without any substantive changes, I have given my assent.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against subsidised imports from non-European Union countries (codified text). Indeed, if the EU were to promote free trade – and not to promote and protect the interests of powerful industries with the best relations with political leaders – it would be enough to respect two rates: 1. All trade tariffs and tariffs have been abolished. 2. Whoever wants to trade is entitled without any restriction to do so across any border to any extent. So why a set of rules on the prevention of subsidised imports that does not serve the interests of consumers and citizens, but only those of those in power and their symbionts in large-scale industry?

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s trade defence instruments need to be reformed, and the Commission and Parliament have done their part. It is now up to national governments in the Council of Ministers to do their part.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I followed the recommendation of the Advisory Group of the competent legal services by voting in favour of this legislative resolution of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union.  The report on the proposal for a regulation provides for a set of measures which will set countervailing duties on certain subsidised import products which have suffered material injury or threaten to cause injury to the Union industry. I believe that the report credibly claris the intentions of adopting the regulation and propose appropriate solutions.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation concerns protection against dumped imports from countries outside the European Union. Since the proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since November 2009.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation to codify the defence regulation against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries.  Indeed, this codification does not call into question the substance of this regulation, which tends to protect States from unfair trade practices, but seeks, in the interests of transparency, to consolidate the various acts that will be incorporated into the new text. The aim here is to transpose into EU legislation the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994. The agreement put in place a series of detailed measures to counter dumping by non-EU countries.  I have therefore supported this text which protects Member States' economies from unfair trade practices through the introduction of a new regulation detailing clearer anti-dumping rules.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it is a simple codification of existing texts, without any substantive amendment.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report aims to protect Member States' economies from dumped imports from third countries. It is part of protectionism against unfair practices: I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The legislation is a proposal to codify Council Regulation EC No. 597/2009 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Community. It gathers amendments into one single document. However, it also aims to transpose into EU law the provisions of the World Trade Organisation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994 to ensure proper and transparent application of the anti-dumping rules. I considered it appropriate to abstain on this measure. Although it is a legislative act, it does not alter the law. It will make no practical difference to industries impacted by subsidised imports.  There is no reason to oppose it; if such measures were to come before the British Parliament I might well support them. However, it should be the UK that implements WTO rules in the UK, and not the European Union.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the single system of Regulations of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union. Since the Advisory Working Party, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, considers that the proposal in question contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment, the report proposes that the European Parliament adopt the Commission's report. As the protection against dumping from third countries protects the interests of EU operators and since the current text is merely a ingingering of existing rules, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This is the Council's 30 November 2009 regulation on defence against imports resulting from dumping by third countries. I voted in favour of this text because it should protect our businesses from unfair business practices: it is time, in fact, for the Eurocrats to renounce their dogma of the free movement of goods, capital and people.  This is finally the outline of a European protectionism which we are hearing but which is always rejected or contradicted by other provisions. In this regard, it should be remembered that, in a judgment of 2 February 2012, the Luxembourg Court of Justice forced the European Union to reverse the only truly protectionist measures it has ever taken, namely anti-dumping taxes on shoes from China and Vietnam. These measures adopted by the European Parliament were therefore renounced in one of its rare moments of lucidity. And so the European Union bent over to the neo-liberal injunctions of the WTO.  We therefore remain vigilant about the implementation of these new provisions.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this proposal, which is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without any change in substance.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the Hautala report today on the proposal for a regulation of parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries outside the European Union. This is a technical measure which merely codifies the existing texts.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. The text proposes the codification of the dumping protection regulation in products imported from third countries.

name: Dominique BILDE
