text: In writing. This report on defence against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries must in fact proceed with the codification of Regulation (EC) 1225/2009. The proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it; it fully preserves the substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself. Thus, the proposed regulation aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994 into EU law. This text is on the right track because it seeks to protect the economies of the Member States from imports that are dumped from third countries and thus contributes to protectionism against the unfair practices that we call for. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I share some of the support, I believe that the text we are voting on does not make any decisive changes to the anti-dumping and anti-subsidy legislation. I am convinced that substantial action is needed, which I have been fighting for for years, to make EU legislation less tolerant of dumping cases that cause enormous damage to our businesses. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial changes thereof.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union, as the Consultative Working Party decided by consensus that the proposal merely aims to codify existing texts without changing their substance. The purpose of this Regulation is to ensure that the export price and the normal value are compared correctly. In addition, factors which may affect prices and price comparisons should be listed, as well as appropriate rules on how and when adjustments should be made, and provide for double adjustments. It should also be provided that the average prices used for comparison, although individual export prices can also be compared with the average normal value, if they vary according to the buyer, region or period. A product is considered to be dumped if its export price to the EU is lower than the comparable price of the like product in the ordinary course of trade in the exporting country.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union's internal market must be protected against external dumping, because it helps to preserve and create jobs. It is therefore appropriate to explain in sufficient detail the cases in which aid should be presumed to exist, the principles on which it should be considered countervailable (in particular in the case of the granting of targeted aid) and the criteria for calculating the amount of countervailable subsidy. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ as with the point on protection against subsidised imports from third countries, I also voted in favour of the legislative resolution on protection against dumped imports from non-European Union countries. In this case, too, it is a codification of the existing text and does not provide for substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 1225/2009 of the Council of 30 November 2009 relating to defence against imports that are dumped by third countries. This text protects Member States' economies from subsidised imports from third countries, thus contributing to protectionism against unfair practices. I voted for it as I did in the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this codification because I believe that it allows for a more orderly organisation of the legal framework governing protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In the interests of transparency, this report aims to codify Council Regulation 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on defence against imports that are dumped by third countries. This regulation will transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade into EU law.  This regulation defines the calculation of dumping margins, taxation and collection of anti-dumping duties. Although this regulation does not put an end to the unfair international competition that our companies face, particularly in the European Union, I voted for this text which has the merit of tackling social and environmental dumping, particularly in emerging countries.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for protection against dumped imports from non-Eu countries is intended to codify Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November. This proposal does not make changes in the content of acts, but only changes in form so that they are more accessible to citizens. It is important that the citizen is given a favourable framework to make use of the rights conferred on him by these acts. It becomes necessary to codify legislation in order for citizens to understand the provisions more deeply and to ensure the prerequisites for citizen involvement. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that there is a need for greater clarity and transparency of the legal provisions so that these acts become accessible and serve the interests of citizens.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 In both Hautala reports, we are faced with a mere codification of anti-dumping regulations, in this case Regulation (EC) No 597/2009. On the substance, however, it is a question of correcting a passage in the text which in no way represents a substantial change, as the Committee on Legal Affairs itself has stated. There are many other substantive and substantial interventions that the anti-dumping legislation should receive and certainly not just interventions such as today's. On the contrary, the Lega Nord has been fighting for years for anti-dumping and anti-subsidy rules to be updated in a more restrictive sense.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today of the proposal for a regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries outside the European Union because it puts an end to a matter that appeared fragmented. Dumping on products imported into the EU poses serious competition problems for our companies, which have to compete with products that are priced lower than those charged in third country markets or even below the cost of production. The aim is to acquire foreign market shares or to drive out competition. The European anti-dumping legislation contains provisions for the determination of dumping and the determination of injury suffered, the initiation of the investigation procedure, the conduct of the investigation, the provisional measures to be taken, the imposition of definitive duties, the duration and review of the measure adopted. The new Regulation, drawn up on the basis of the consolidation of Council Regulation No 1225/2009 and its amending act, replaces the various regulations it incorporates and makes only the formal amendments necessary for the codification work.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a technical vote, taken as part of the codification process. This process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In the current case, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Regulation on Protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Community made since 2009. As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The report approves the codification procedure for the Regulation on Protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the EU and I voted in favour of it because the submitted proposal does not aim to make any changes to the substance of the texts.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation concerns protection against dumped imports from countries outside the European Union. During its examination of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 imposing additional customs duties on imports of certain products originating in the United States of America, the Advisory Group concluded by common accord that the proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification. I voted in favour of codification.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as the European Commission's proposal is simply codifying existing texts, without modifying their substance.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the codification report of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against dumped imports by non-EU countries is not a substantive debate on the text but an attempt to consolidate and codify it. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The simple aim of this report is to form an efficient codification of the existing regulation on defence against subsidised imports from countries outside the European Union. Given that this proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, and with the aim of simplifying the legislation as much as possible, it was easy for me to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of a people’s Europe, we attach great importance to simplifying and clarifying the law of the European Union so as to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens, thus giving them new opportunities and the chance to make use of the specific rights it gives them. This aim cannot be achieved so long as numerous provisions that have been amended several times, often quite substantially, remain scattered, so that they must be sought partly in the original instrument and partly in later amending ones. Considerable research work, comparing many different instruments, is thus needed to identify the current rules.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Hautala Report which officially codifies the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the defence against dumped imports from non-EU countries, and does not present any substantive amendments to the proposal, with a pure and simple codification. Simplification and clarification of EU law is a central EU objective to make it more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. The dispersion of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially (which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it) leads to the codification of the rules, for the sake of legal clarity and transparency.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure fair competition for products sold on the European Union market by EU manufacturers, the Union may impose anti-dumping measures on imports. The purpose of the Report of the European Parliament and of the Council is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 imposing additional customs duties on imports of certain products originating in the United States of America. I voted in favour of the proposal, which basically represents a codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is established that a product is to be considered as being dumped if its export price to the European Union is less than a comparable price for a like product, in the ordinary course of trade, as established for the exporting country. Procedures to eliminate dumping and injury are needed to enable a level playing field of European businesses so as to do away with anti-competitive behaviour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since November 2009.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The regulation aims to transpose into EU law the provisions on subsidies and countervailing measures (Subsidy Agreement) concluded within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The Regulation lays down the detailed conditions determining the existence of subsidies, the rules governing the application of countervailing duties which may be imposed to offset any subsidies granted, directly or indirectly, for the manufacture, production, export or import of any product for which release for free circulation in the EU causes injury, and the criteria to be used in calculating the countervailable subsidy amount. The regulation aims to transpose into EU law the anti-dumping provisions contained in the Agreement on the Application of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report deals with the codification of the defence regulation against imports that are subsidized by non-EU countries. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law without any change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation because it is not a problem. Indeed, it is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance. This regulation therefore aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994 into EU law.  It sets out detailed rules, in particular the calculation of the dumping margin, the procedures for opening and conducting the investigation, including the establishment and handling of the facts, the establishment of interim measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994 into EU law. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the codified regulation of 30 November 2009 would replace the various acts relating to the defence against imports which are dumped by third countries. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself. To the extent that this text protects the economies of the Member States from imports that are dumped by third countries, I voted in favour.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it only attempts to codify the legislation regulating the framework of defence against dumped imports from non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. In order to reduce the large number of provisions that have undergone various modifications, often essential, and scattered between the original legislative act and subsequent acts of amendment, this proposal aims to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the defence against dumped imports by non-Member States of the European Community. The new Regulation will replace those which are the subject of the coding operation. The advisory group found, by common agreement, that the proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. I and the Center Party are in favour of free trade and increased openness from the EU to the rest of the world. However, this must be based on a level playing field in the market. This report provides for stronger protection against dumped products. Product dumping is harmful both to the EU economy and to greater functioning free trade in the world. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which is to adopt the position of the advisory group.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the defence report against dumped imports from non-EU countries because the proposal under this is effectively based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendment.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this text protects Member States' economies from dumped imports from third countries.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal on protection by dumped imports from countries which are not members of the European Union is merely a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their content and substance.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because I believe more restrictive anti-dumping and anti-subsidy rules are needed.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it only attempts to codify the legislation regulating the framework of defence against dumped imports from non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's efforts to simplify and make EU legislation more transparent. The aim is to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens, thus further expanding the possibilities for exercising the rights granted to them. However, in order for the legislation to be clear and transparent, codification of acts which have been amended several times is necessary. I therefore accept the opinion of the Working Party of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the codification of protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries and vote in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is a proposal which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes. However, it is important to be vigilant about illegal and especially harmful trade practices for European industry and which can seriously affect the competitiveness of our industry and its ability to create quality jobs.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution on the agreement with the Council on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against imports subject to social dumping by non-EU countries. The regulation aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade within the framework of European Union law, which provides, among other things, for specific rules for the calculation of dumping margins, the imposition of provisional measures and the disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries, as I believe that EU action in this area is justified and necessary. What countries like China present to us in sectors such as steel production on the world market has nothing to do with free, fair competition. I therefore also raise my voice for hundreds of thousands of steelworkers in Germany and their families: reasonable punitive tariffs against global price dumping can help to preserve their jobs!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Dumping prices from non-EU countries pose a threat to the Single Market and free trade. By protecting domestic prices, we also protect domestic producers. In addition, the European internal market itself must also be protected so as not to be subject to the consequences of price dumping and to lose its competitiveness.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. The text proposes the codification of the dumping protection regulation in products imported from third countries.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposed regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union. The proposed regulation aims to transpose into EU law the anti-dumping rules contained in the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994. This would protect the economic assets of the EU against certain international dumped imports.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries, as I consider it an obligation of the European Union to provide its citizens with easy access to legal order acts. The scattering of provisions in various acts leads to the need for the swift adoption of codified acts to make the provisions clearer and more certain. I believe that codification of this Regulation will contribute to the certainty of rights and reduce the need for research activities when seeking the rules in force. Codified acts do not change in content, but they are simplified and become clearer and more accessible to citizens.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text protects Member States' economies from dumped imports from third countries. It highlights a certain protectionism against unfair practices. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the report concerned the simple codification of an existing text without amendments in content, I am glad that we have adopted it in Parliament by a clear majority. The aim of the Regulation is to transpose into EU legislation the anti-dumping rules contained in the Agreement on the Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 1994. It contains detailed rules concerning, in particular, the calculation of loss-making exports, the procedures for initiating and conducting investigations, including the collection and processing of information, the imposition of provisional measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures, as well as the publication of information relating to anti-dumping investigations.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which codifies the anti-dumping rules contained in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1994 in European Union (EU) law. For example, it sets out detailed rules such as the calculation of the dumping margin, the imposition of interim measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures, and the disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report on protection against dumping imports from third countries. This is a mere codification of the existing legal texts without any changes in content. For the sake of clarity and clarity, it is therefore necessary to codify that Regulation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The European market has already been protected from dumped imports by a number of regulations, but let us all admit that there are doubts as to its effectiveness. The report is eligible as it sets out a single system of Regulations of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumping from non-EU countries, protecting the interests of EU entrepreneurs slightly more through transparency. The EU always walks into the same trap: first the "smart" do not listen to the warnings, and then they try to solve something with fierce regulation, with little success.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of defending against dumped imports from non-EU countries. As you know, there is dumping when a company sells a product at a lower price when it comes to exporting than it does in the home market. Therefore, in order to ensure fair competition on products sold on the EU market, the EU can impose anti-dumping measures on imports. As with the proposal previously adopted, the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission calls for the existing texts to be codifying. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on defence against imports which are dumped by non-EU countries. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify the defence regulation against imports that are dumped by third countries.  The Regulation sets out rules relating in particular to the calculation of the dumping margin, the procedures for opening and conducting the investigation, including the establishment and handling of the facts, the establishment of interim measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations. It protects Member States' economies from imports that are dumped by third countries.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is a simple codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance. In addition, it protects Member States' economies from unfair practices.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of. The text aims to defend Member States from imports that are dumped by third countries. It sets up a detailed set of rules that are part of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade under EU law. They range from the taxation and collection of anti-dumping duties, to the calculation of the dumping margin, to the procedures for opening and closing investigations in this context. The text is honest and realistic in being protectionist.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report is only a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since November 2009, so I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. I approve this report, which is limited to the simple codification of the Regulation, without substantial amendments, concerning the defence against dumped imports by non-EU countries.  I consider that this text, which contains more specific rules for the calculation, imposition of provisional measures and other anti-dumping measures, improves the quality of investigations and their effectiveness.  For the reasons set out above and because of the importance of simplification and clarity of EU law, so that it is thus more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I am voting in favour of the adoption of the citizen.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The proposal only adds to a clearer document the rules already in force, which are also based on agreements under the International General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). I also agree with the principle that it is justifiable to impose a compensatory duty on dumped exports.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report refers to a proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries. In accordance with Council Regulation 1225/09, anti-dumping duties may be introduced on any goods with a dumped price imported from third countries, the release of which causes damage or threatens to cause damage, with a view to protecting the common market and producers in the European Union.  Having studied the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation No 2013, 1225/2009, the Advisory Working Group unanimously concluded that the proposal was limited to the direct codification of existing legislative texts.  This proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without significant changes and adopts a position at first reading, so I supported the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the new regulation is to transpose into EU law the anti-dumping provisions contained in the text of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade adopted in 1994, in particular Article 6 of its Agreement on Implementation. The Regulation therefore contains detailed rules, in particular as regards the calculation of the existence of dumping, the implementation of the investigation procedures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the relevant information to the public in the context of anti-dumping investigations. As in the case of today's previous vote, this regulation, as such, does not bring anything new in legal terms, because it only brings together the rules that currently exist. I therefore support the new codification becoming part of EU law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on defence against dumped imports by non-EU countries, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this proposed regulation. This regulation codifies EC Regulation 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on defence against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries. It essentially makes formal changes. This regulation transposes Title VI of the World Trade Organization's General Tariff Agreement (1994). It defines, among other things, how the dumping margin is calculated, the applicable interim measures, the conditions of taxation and the calculation of possible anti-dumping duties, the conduct of investigations and the conditions of confidentiality applicable to them. We can only support this regulation, which contributes to the fight against unfair competition.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries.  The purpose of the Report of the European Parliament and of the Council is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 imposing additional customs duties on imports of certain products originating in the United States of America. The proposal is therefore limited to a mere codification of existing texts without any substantial changes.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims only to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on the codification of the existing legislation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 on defence against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries. It is this regulation that enables the EU to combat dumping by taking safeguard measures. But it also gives the Commission every power to amend, suspend or repeal these safeguards. Opposed on the merits to this commission takeover, I vote against this technical report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The validation of the report must follow through on a regulation to determine criteria for dumped imports by third countries. Specific rules are detailed in the proposed regulation. This concern for transparency is part of a process of protection against this kind of importation. It is a defence against unfair practices.  As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the defence against dumped imports from non-Member States of the European Community. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this codification of existing regulations which serves to create a level playing field for enterprises in the European Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I have decided to join the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against imports which are dumped by non-EU countries. The regulation proposed here aims to codify in a single document the anti-dumping rules included in Article 5 of the tariff agreement signed in 1994. Specific rules on the margin of calculation for dumping are detailed and investigation procedures are detailed.  It should therefore be remembered that this regulation will replace and retain all the substance of the various existing instruments that are incorporated into it. I attach an important importance to the simplification of laws so that the European citizen has more transparent and pragmatic access to EU law and that he can have the opportunity to make use of the rights conferred on him by this Parliament.  In order to achieve this goal, I believe that, as is the case here, several instruments relating to the same basic act will have to be codified, in order to prevent various provisions that have been substantially amended on several occasions from being scattered between the basic act and subsequent acts.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The aim of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures is to avoid the negative effects of unfair trading practices, including subsidised imports. In figuring out the existence of a subsidy, it must be demonstrated that a subsidy has been granted by a government or public authority in the territory of a country or that there has been some form of income or price support within the meaning of Article XVI of GATT 1994 and thus the recipient undertaking has benefited from it. It is necessary to draw up detailed guidance on the factors on the basis of which it will be possible to assess whether the subsidised imports have caused or are likely to cause material injury. In proving that the volumes and prices of imports are the cause of the injury suffered by the Union industry, attention should be paid to the impact of other factors, in particular the prevailing market conditions in the Union. A decision shall be taken only if all parties have been given an opportunity to comment. In this investigation, attention should be paid to the need to eliminate the impact of injurious subsidies and to restore effective competition. The present proposal therefore primarily follows the codification of the Regulation on protection against subsidised imports from countries which are not members of the European Union. The new regulation replaces a number of legal acts forming the subject of codification. The proposal fully preserves the content of codified legal acts and is limited solely to their unification into a single legal act, while formal amendments do not go beyond the codification purpose. The proposal put forward has my support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the EU because this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council a regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union. In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the Commission's proposal, as amended in accordance with the recommendations of the Advisory Working Party. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade into EU law. The Regulation sets out detailed rules, in particular the calculation of the dumping margin, the procedures for opening and conducting the investigation, including the establishment and handling of the facts, the establishment of interim measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and the disclosure of information relating to anti-dumping investigations. It protects Member States' economies from imports that are dumped by third countries. It is part of protectionism against unfair practices, so it can be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 103 of the Regulation of the European Parliament, the codification is carried out by means of a regulation of the existing regulatory framework for the defence against imports which are dumped by non-MEMBER COUNTRIES of the European Union.  This is a purely technical issue, given that the amendments cannot substantiate modification at the substantive level, and should therefore be confined only to the pure and simple compilation of existing texts. In this regard, I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution, because I believe it is advantageous that the regulation of this matter is not dispersed and that it is part of a single legislative body.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text protects Member States' economies from dumped imports from third countries. It reinforces protectionism against unfair practices, which is why I voted FOR.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that contains a codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance regarding the protection against dumped imports from countries that are not members of the European Union.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – As this was a technical vote, not involving any changes to the substance of the Regulation, I voted in favour. The codification process is triggered when a Regulation or Directive has been amended by other legal acts 10 or more times. In simple terms, codification brings together all versions and amendments to the Protection Regulation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report does not contain any substantive changes, only existing legal texts have been codified. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Mrs Hautala's proposal, I have decided to vote in favour because the proposal is simply about codifying existing texts and does not make any major changes to them. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Council Regulation (EC) No. 1225/2009 since 30 November 2009 on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries has been amended several times in the past period. According to a Commission decision adopted in 1987, a rule was established that after a dozen amendments to a particular act, the same must be codified, i.e. the original text in the new edition must be textually purified of all outdated formulations that have since been amended, in order to avoid any confusion and involuntary application of outdated rules. Since it is an act containing anti-dumping rules, it explains the procedure for initiating and conducting an investigation in the event of dumping, regulates the imposition of provisional measures, the imposition and collection of anti-dumping duties, I consider the proposed codification necessary because in addition to contributing to greater legal certainty of the stakeholders concerned, it also contributes to the correct application of this act.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. —Having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts, and in particular its point 4, an advisory working group consisting of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission met on 13 November 2014 to consider, inter alia, that proposal submitted by the Commission. At this meeting, the Advisory Working Group, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, examined the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 1999/2013. 1225/2009 as of 30 November 2009 on the protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries and unanimously concluded that the proposal was limited to the direct codification of existing legislative texts, without substantive changes. I support the opinion of the advisory working group and adopt the position at first reading.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the defence against dumped imports from non-Member States of the European Community. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the previous content and merely make formal amendments.  This regulation concerns the protection of industries from the import of dumped products produced in non-EU countries. The aim is to protect the 'Union industries' by establishing a procedure for implementing such protection in the legal sphere. It lays down provisions for the protection of state and commercial secrets. Export prices and dumping margins are defined.    Although this is a coding process, we do not review ourselves in a set of references and expressions that are updated, such as 'EU industries', which point to a sense of eu federalisation, disregarding the diversity, development profile and unique characteristics of industries within each Member State, reasons that motivated our abstention.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Anti-dumping duties are one of the basic trade policy mechanisms of the European Union with the aim of protecting markets and domestic producers from lower price imports of products. The European Commission, in cooperation with Member States, should continue its efforts to collect data in the form of indicators or ranges in order to give a better picture of the current situation. Many problems arising in previous years remain unresolved, in particular the widespread use of safeguards and the questionable way in which third countries use the instrument. Transparency of the criteria should be continued, as the opposite would be contrary to the EU's open markets strategy and access to the fair trade market. Trade defence measures imposed by third countries, as well as ongoing investigations, have a significant impact on EU exports. I therefore support Mep Hautal's report, as efforts to promote the high standards applied by the EU when using these instruments should be insisted on. Mediation and technical support and advice to EU exporters should also be stepped up, in particular when faced with potential abuse of trade defence instruments by third countries.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 From my point of view, it is very important that every EU citizen has access to information on the activities and outputs of the various EU institutions. In order to ensure clearer and better access to data, individual legislative acts need to be codified. For this reason, I support the codification of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries which are not members of the European Union. Codification makes it easier to find the documents you need and helps prevent misunderstandings, such as searching for a valid version of a document that has already been modified several times. I believe that a more user-friendly system for searching FOR EU documents will lead to a better understanding by EU citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which refers to an outright codification of existing defence texts against dumped imports by non-EU countries. Indeed, the aim here is to transpose into European Union law the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade signed in 1994 when the World Trade Organisation (WTO) was created.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering important a simplification and clarification of EU law, enabling the most easy and correct interpretation by European citizens, this proposal codifies Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009, as considered relevant by the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Since the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament deliberated on the opinion of the Advisory Group composed of the services of the three institutions, further maintaining that the proposal is to be computed in the pure and simple codification of the texts, without substantive amendments, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, it is only the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution since it is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation because, in view of the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council (COM (2014)0667) and on the basis of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0256/2015), it is considered that, in the opinion of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance, and therefore instructs its President to pass on Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the national parliaments.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Dumping is clear, it is clear that dumping is a brake on free competition and a killer of innovation. By declaring free competition as a fundamental value of the European Union, we cannot accept distortions of competition. The draft resolution under consideration gives a sufficiently detailed overview of this issue. It is true that I believe that it pays far too little attention to the challenges faced by the less developed EU Member States. Nevertheless, I am voting in favour and I call on my colleagues to support this report, while bearing in mind that the less developed EU Member States face specific problems with the dumping imposed by third countries and pay a very high socio-economic price for it. I call on the Commission to take these aspects more into account when considering specific measures to combat dumping from third countries.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report by Heidi Hautala of the Committee on Legal Affairs is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the defence against dumped imports from non-EU countries.  This new regulation will replace several acts, now integrated into the same text, fully preserving the content of the previous acts, with the formal changes required by the codification process itself. As this report aims to provide more security, transparency and legislative simplification, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on defence against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries. The text supports the Commission's proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission. The proposal is a codification of existing texts, without altering their substance. The proposed regulation aims to transpose the anti-dumping rules contained in the agreement on the implementation of Article VI of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade into EU law.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report welcomes the legal examination of the proposal to impose additional customs duties on imports of certain products from the United States. This proposal does not change the Union's policy but continues along the lines already mapped out with regard to dumped exports. As has already happened on other occasions, I have expressed my position on anti-dumping policies.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. The text proposes the codification of the dumping protection regulation in products imported from third countries.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report establishing defence mechanisms against imports that are dumped by non-EU countries because of their purely technical nature, as this is a codification of the different versions and amendments introduced to the regulation since November 2009.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the Subject of the Commission's proposal was only a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries that are not members of the Union, as this is mainly a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing the substance of the text. The aim of this arrangement is to bring into European law provisions relating to anti-dumping rules resulting from the Agreement on implementation of Article VI of the General Tariff and Trade Treaty 1994 (the 'GATT Treaty'). The proposed Regulation contains detailed rules, in particular with regard to dumping, the procedures for initiation and conduct of investigations. This includes the conditions for obtaining and processing factual evidence, introducing the burden of provisional measures, applying and collecting anti-dumping duties, but also the duration and review of anti-dumping measures and making publicly available information concerning anti-dumping investigations. I believe that it is important for the current shape of the world economy that economic exchange takes place on the basis of clear conditions. I am therefore glad that the EU is adjusting its legislation to comply with international agreements.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is necessary to protect the Union's internal market from the unfair commercial practice of dumped imports from non-EU countries and not only to adopt anti-dumping measures that are in line with fair trade, competition, but are also in the interest of EU producers.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. The Advisory Working Group, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, met on 13 November 2014 to discuss this proposal submitted by the Commission. Advisory Working Group, having studied the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries, unanimously concluded that the proposal was limited to the direct codification of existing legislative texts, thus excluding substantive changes. I agree with this codification proposal, as this quality change will result in a more clearly worded Regulation and the content of the Regulation will essentially remain the same.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The Advisory Working Group, composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, met on 13 November 2014 to discuss this proposal submitted by the Commission. Advisory Working Group, having studied the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries, unanimously concluded that the proposal was limited to the direct codification of existing legislative texts, without substantive changes. I agree with this codification proposal because I believe it is a quality change aimed at a more clearly worded Regulation. The content of the Regulation essentially remains the same.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries that are not members of the European Union. The report does not bring about any substantive changes, but is just a codification of the existing text. This is also noted by the Consultative Group, which consists of the legal services of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a report that is part of the process of codifying European legislation, incorporating all the amendments made from time to time and updating the legislation. We voted in favour of the report because it is a purely procedural vote.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 This report only attempts to codify the legislation regulating the defence framework against dumped imports from non-EU countries, without changing the existing regime, which needs to be significantly improved.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the EU. In the opinion of the Advisory Working Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal simply consolidated the existing texts without substantially a change in the existing texts. As existing texts are not amended, I can support the proposal, which has been amended in line with the recommendations of the Working Party.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Importing enables European consumers to benefit from products they would not have had access to if they had relied solely on domestic production. In this respect, the existence on the European market of products from third countries around the world is a significant advantage. However, in situations where certain products of this type are made at very low (dumping) prices, which jeopardise the development of similar European sectors (and cannot compete with these low prices), jeopardising the jobs of workers in the Member States, measures are required to balance the situation by introducing proportionate customs duties. The current document brings up to date the existing European regulations, sufficient to maintain a balanced situation at Union level, without changes in substance. I therefore support the adoption of this report in its current form.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Considering that, in the opinion of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without any change in substance, Parliament has approved, by a large majority, the text in question.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal aims at codifying the regulation on the protection against dumped imports from countries that are not members of the European Union. I voted in favour of this, as it will simplify the regulation and make it easier for citizens to understand and make use of. The objective of this regulation was to shield our internal market from harmful dumping measures, by ensuring that the EU law integrates and applies the WTO 1994 Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported the report by MeP Heidi Hautala because it concerns those matters that are important for European producers and farmers. There is no doubt that we should try to protect the Union market from the dumped imports of these products, which are exported at dumped prices by non-EU countries. Our priority should be the protection of producers in our Member States. In this way, we will avoid unfair competition in international trade and strengthen our economy and protect jobs in the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to codify the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries. This proposal, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. I believe that the new proposal will ensure the correct and transparent application of the rules of the 1994 Anti-Dumping Agreement. However, this proposal will fully convey the content of codifying acts and will bring them together into a single act, only with those formal amendments necessary for codification.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-Member Countries of the European Union (codified text). At the meeting, the Consultative Group examined the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 of 30 November 2009 on the protection against dumped imports from non-European Community countries and unanimously concluded that the proposal contained only a codification of the existing text without any substantive changes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. The text proposes the codification of the dumping protection regulation in products imported from third countries.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the purpose of this proposal is to codify the Council's 30 November 2009 regulation on defence against imports dumped by third countries. The proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it; it fully preserves the substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself. It protects Member States' economies from imports that are dumped by third countries. It is part of intelligent protectionism against unfair practices. I voted FOR this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as this is a technical text on procedures. The text proposes the codification of the dumping protection regulation in products imported from third countries.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this codification—technical report as the new regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it; it fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and hence does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission found that the Commission's proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without any substantial modification. That is why this Parliament approves the Commission's proposal adapted to the recommendations of the advisory group. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative motion. The original Council Regulation to protect European markets from dumped products has been substantially amended and reworded, to ensure maximum clarity and understanding, as well as ease of reference. It needed to be streamlined and given increased clarity which I feel that this has achieved. The recent scandal over the potential dumping of Chinese steel in the European market showed how important these rules are. By streamlining them we improve our trade defences to make sure that European manufacturers are not unfairly undercut by their competitors. The legislative report also added clarity to the guidance on definitions within the text; in the fight to protect European, and by extension the British market from unfairly subsidised manufacturing this kind of clarity is vital. The recent case of Tata Steel proves that the European market needs to be defended against dumped products from outside of the European Union. I feel that in this vote we took the correct course to achieve that.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because the proposal is a simplified codification of existing legislation, without its content being adapted.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is based so only on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Regulation (EC) 1225/2009 has been amended several times and in substantial respects. For the sake of clarity and clarity, it is appropriate to codify that Regulation. As this report is a mere codification of the existing legal texts without any substantive changes, I have given my assent.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-Eu Union countries (codified text). If the EU were really concerned with promoting free trade and not with the promotion and protection of the interests of powerful industries with the best relations with political leaders, two rates would suffice: 1. All trade tariffs and tariffs have been abolished. 2. Whoever wants to trade is entitled without any restriction to do so across any border to any extent. So why a set of rules on the prevention of dumped imports that does not serve the interests of consumers and citizens, but only those of those in power and their symbionts in large-scale industry?

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Manufacturing industries across Europe and in the UK, like the steel and ceramic sectors, are open to unfair competition from goods being sold at under their production value, and being dumped onto the European market. European action is needed in order to protect these industries. European institutions have done their part and now governments must act, for the sake of all European citizens, including my own constituents in the UK.  As a supporter of the Alternative Trade Mandate, I have advocated that global trade must put people and the planet ahead of profit. As the EU moves to reform its trade policy, and engage with international players, it is indeed better placed than any other international player to achieve that goal. My colleagues and I will continue to work towards an EU policy of truly fair and sustainable trade.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed draft resolution of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, with Mrs Hautala as rapporteur. The approved text shall take into account the opinion of the Advisory Committee on codification and not on the substance of the amendment of the text.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from non-Member Countries of the European Union.  I agree with the report that, for the sake of clarity and rationality, the text of the previous regulation needs to be codified because of a number of amendments. In the event that imports cause or are likely to cause EU injury to industry, the competent authorities need an effective legal basis for the imposition of safeguard measures.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: Madam President, I am opposed to this text because it is part of this logic of intrusion of the European Union into the natural resources of a number of countries and it turns out that, in the case of Liberia, the situation is all the more unacceptable since 50% of the local population lives from fishing. However, we have authorized the capture of 3,500 tonnes of tuna, which will be taken in this way by the opportunities that local fishermen had to live on.  I believe that this is a totally leonine agreement that will turn to the detriment of the local people.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent  This agreement will not only allow European union fishermen to fish legally in Liberia's fishing zone, but will generally provide a stepping stone to development in EU-West Africa economic relations, and clearly that will help to combat illegal catches more effectively, especially in the case of tuna. That is why I voted in favour. Although the fisheries sector accounts for around 12% of Liberia's agricultural GDP and only 3% of total GDP, the agreement could undoubtedly also provide at least indirect support for the development of this area in Liberia. It is likely that in a country located on the Atlantic itself, the fisheries sector could clearly play a much greater role than it currently has. Support.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, the reason we are discussing hoovering up somebody else’s fish is because of the ecological calamity created in EU waters by the common fisheries policy, but I would invite the Chamber to ponder the common fisheries policy as a symbol of a wider problem, a token or symptom, of a wider problem in Europe, and it is the way in which we have elevated the goal of closer integration over any practical concerns.  So despite the hoovering up of fish stocks, we have retained this obsession with the principle of a common resource to which all Members have equal access, even though that discourages conservation. In the same way we are maintaining the euro, despite the immiseration of many of the people who have to use the euro. We are maintaining the principle of Schengen despite the obvious migratory problems that it creates, because everything is sacrificed to the dogma of ever-closer union.  It is worth noting that despite the obvious disaster that has afflicted British fisheries, the common fisheries policy formed no part of the recent renegotiation. That, in a way, is all you need to know if you think the EU may one day be reformed.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I voted against this issue – of course I voted against this issue. We see the debacle and the environmental and economic disaster that the common fisheries policy has brought across the European Union, and now we wish to export our bad practice to the west coast of Africa, or even further. We have seen what other fishery agreements have done to other countries on the west coast of Africa. This is no way to be helping developing countries across the third world. We see EUR 600 000 a year being given to just 34 fishing ships to take 6 500 tonnes of Liberian fish.  What effect is that having on fishing communities across Liberia? I hope it is not, but I fear that it is having the same effect as has happened across many parts of West Africa where we have seen fishermen not just seeing their stocks being hoovered up, but actually being killed by European Union fishing boats ploughing them out of the water. It is an absolute disgrace and a humanitarian disaster.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is invited to give its recommendation to approve or reject the EU-Liberia fisheries agreement. The agreement covers a quota of almost 6 500 tonnes. Part of the EU's contribution is for the sustainable development of the area. The terms of the agreement allow for greater transparency, so as to foster a culture of sustainable development. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this fisheries agreement, as EU vessels will be able to catch 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year for a trade-off of EUR 3.25 million over five years. The financial contribution shall be divided equally by an amount for access to fishery resources and an amount intended to support Liberia's fisheries policy. In addition, other elements of the reform are also included, such as the exclusivity clause, a human rights clause, and the principle that more favourable conditions should not apply to any country practicing deep-sea fishing than those applied to the EU. With regard to transparency, a key element is included in promoting sustainable fisheries: a provision similar, albeit less detailed, to that included in the last agreement with Mauritania, which requires the publication of any agreement (whether public or private) allowing access to ships flying foreign flags into Liberian waters.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the first fisheries agreement with Liberia by the European Union. Despite our strong commitment to a fisheries policy based on responsible management of local fisheries resources, we believe that a small share of exploitation responsible for certain fishery resources is possible to maintain the jobs in the sector. This agreement is the first to be made with that country, which implies that for the first time vessels fishing in those waters will be subject to and accountable to an agreement with the local authorities. The development of such agreements in such a way as to respect the full sovereignty of countries as well as to take into account the care of marine resources is fundamental to the sustainability of fisheries in general. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement to establish a partnership between the European Union and Liberia in the area of sustainable fishing.  This fisheries agreement is the first between the two parties. In particular, it will allow the movement of European Union fishing vessels in Liberian waters and concerns 28 seiner tuna boats (16 Spanish and 12 French) and 6 surface longliners (Spanish). As part of the agreement, a joint commission to monitor the results and properly enforce the rules of the agreement will be set up, which is a step in the right direction.   Although shark catches do not yet appear to have been resolved, I support this agreement, which is part of the development of Liberia, a country facing civil wars and the Ebola crisis. Moreover, this agreement benefits both the EU and Liberia, which does not have the means to combat illegal fishing.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Liberia. Sinn Féin generally does not support Fisheries Partnership Agreements as here, when they are at the expense of developing countries and for the benefit of larger operators of the external fleets. For these reasons I abstained on the vote.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Partnership Agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which states that if the EU shows inaction, then it will allow the emergence of private agreements that cannot guarantee the sustainable development of fisheries. The Liberian authorities undertake not to provide more favourable conditions than those granted under this Agreement to other foreign fleets active in the fisheries sector in Liberia. The meeting of the Joint Committee, i.e. between the European Commission and Liberia, will also be convened at least once a year, reviewing the implementation of the Agreement and the Protocol and, if necessary, regulating programming and financial contribution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to enable, organise and monitor the access of European Union fishing vessels to Liberian waters.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement between the European Union and Liberia on fisheries suffers from the same problems as many other such arrangements. It is exploitative and elitist at the expense of ordinary people in Liberia. Consequently, I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this very first fisheries agreement with Liberia. I welcome the adoption of this agreement which is very favourable for both sides: it offers the opportunity for the European fleet to fish in Liberian waters while supporting the Liberian government in its fight against illegal fishing, a major priority of the European Union. Funds from the European Union can contribute to better implementation by the authorities of fisheries regulation and better management of fisheries resources.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and a Protocol on its implementation. Its aim is to achieve sustainable management of fisheries resources and ecosystems. This new agreement concerns only tuna. For a total of EUR 3,25 million, the commission will be charged eur 3,25 million. Eu vessels will be able to catch 6 500 tonnes of tuna each year over a five-year period. The financial contribution shall be divided into equal shares, the amount of one part shall be paid for access to fishery resources and the amount of the other part shall be allocated to the development of the fisheries policy of the Republic of Liberia. In Liberia, the contribution of small-scale fishing to food security is crucial, but limited due to the lack of infrastructures: Liberia is a net importer of fish for home use, especially small pelagic fish. This should be considered a priority for the sector under EU support, including support for the participatory management plan for small pelagic species in Liberia.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement, which allows EUROPEAN Fishing Vessels to enter Liberian waters for five years; in return, the EU will have to pay sums, the amount of which will decrease each year, with the share of shipowners in the payment of these allowances having to increase over time.  Although the case of incidental shark catches is not settled by the agreement, it is beneficial to both sides, accompanying the recent development of the Liberian economy after Ebola and several years of civil wars; the agreement obliges shipowners to board three qualified Liberian sailors per ship. Moreover, this agreement responds to the lack of resources that obstruct Liberia's fight against illegal fishing.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In recent years, the European Union has signed a number of Fisheries Partnership Agreements (APP) and protocols with "third countries". Through the APP, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone (EEZ).  This sustainable fisheries partnership agreement, which I have approved, is the first agreement to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, whose coastline stretches 570 km along the Atlantic Ocean. It will increase the fight against illegal fishing and disseminate the CFP's objective of sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. 2012 Fishing is a key sector of Liberia's economy, a country with more than 500 kilometres of coastline, a vast EEZ rich in valuable fish species including tuna. 3% of Liberia's GDP and 12% of its agricultural GDP depend on the exploitation of these resources, which provide the Liberian population with 65% of animal protein. The outbreak of the last civil war has hit the sector hard, leading to an increase in illegal, unregulated and undeclared fishing. In particular, foreign fishing vessels have severely compromised Liberian fish stocks by their activities, damaging not only the marine ecosystem but also the potential sources of income of indigenous fishermen.
