The Wałęsa report, which I supported with my vote, approves the conclusion of the new Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and Liberia. This is an important agreement which, in exchange for funding to Liberia in the areas of scientific research, small-scale fishing and the monitoring and fight against illegal fishing, will guarantee the European ocean fleet access to the Liberian EEZ and its fisheries resources, scrupulously following the principles of sustainable fisheries and aquaculture management.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries.  There are timely improvements for Liberia in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This EU-Liberia sustainable fisheries partnership agreement should allow EU fishing vessels to enter Liberia's waters. A new agreement was signed on 5 June 2015 for a period of 5 years. This is the first fisheries agreement with Liberia. It concerns 28 seiner tuna (16 Spanish and 12 French) and 6 surface longliners (Spanish). In return, Liberia will receive EU funds of EUR 715,000 in the first year; 650,000 euros in the second, third and fourth years; EUR 585,000 in the fifth year, based on a reference tonnage of 6,500 tonnes, and sector policy is half of these sums. EU participation will gradually decrease as shipowners' participation increases.  In addition, it was decided that shipowners should endeavour to ship three qualified Liberian sailors per vessel and, overall, 20% of the sailors on board must be of ACP origin. Overall, this agreement seems fair, especially as the country emerges from a period of civil war and the aftermath of the Ebola epidemic, and this will lead to a genuine co-development agreement. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU-Liberia Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries is well structured and does not present any critical issues. That is why I wanted to support you with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained from voting on the report. It is the first agreement that the EU concludes with Liberia and it concerns only tuna. Tuna poaching is a major problem. The West Africa Regional Fisheries Program estimates that developing countries lose $10-23 billion each year due to illegal fishing. The agreement is needed to curb illegal fishing, and the aim of this, as well as all eu fisheries agreements, is to exploit seas outside the territory of the EU in order to benefit its own fishing industry, including in this case. Both labour law and the environment must be taken into account and, in this case, the report does not meet both requirements. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting on the report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The adoption of international fisheries agreements is always good news. They are a key element for the sector in many Member States. This agreement provides that EU vessels can fish for 6 500 tonnes of tuna per year in exchange for a financial contribution aimed in part at promoting sustainable fishing and improving food security in Liberia and, in part, access to fishery resources by Community vessels. It also welcomes the incorporation of a new human rights clause in Liberia. It is vital for the future of the sector to renew fisheries agreements and find new alternatives in other waters; of course, in line with the sustainability of the activity within the framework of the principles of the reformed common fisheries policy and its external dimension. For all this, I have cast my vote in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation because in recent years the European Union (EU) has signed several fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries. Under fisheries partnership agreements, the EU provides financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing opportunities for various fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. Since 2014, following the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, these agreements have been referred to as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements. This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first agreement concluded between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which owns 570 km of the Atlantic coast. 246 152 km² Liberia's exclusive economic zone contains bottom and pelagic stocks, including tuna and related species. The EU and Liberia cooperate in multilateral agreements. In addition, in 2008 Liberia's food and agriculture policy and strategy adopted appropriate provisions based on best international practice in the optional 1995 regulation. Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) responsible for the Fisheries Code (CCRF). The Liberian authorities are working closely with the EU to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. The conclusion of a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership with Liberia would therefore help the EU to achieve its objectives of combating IUU fishing and to promote the objective of the Common Fisheries Policy for the sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the resolution on the conclusion of the Partnership and Sustainable Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which is the first such one between the parties. Liberia has 570 km of coastline with the Atlantic Ocean, and its fisheries sector generates 3% of gross domestic product and can contribute to the country's further development. Liberia's tuna-rich fishing zone and similar species comprise 246 152 km2.  The conclusion of the agreement strengthens the cooperation of the European Union and Liberia, or cooperation between the EU and West Africa, where important tuna fishing zones are located. By partnering with sustainable fishing and the smart exploitation of fish resources, the conclusion of an agreement is therefore in favour of both of its signatories.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Cooperation between the European Union and Liberia in the fisheries sector is now part of the wider framework of multilateral agreements or in the field of action of organisations operating at regional level. I therefore welcome the conclusion of a first bilateral agreement between the EU and Liberia aimed at promoting the development of increasingly sophisticated and sustainable fishing practices and, at the same time, aimed at combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, in line with the EU's overall fisheries strategy. The Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries (APPS) and its protocol will strengthen cooperation between the EU and Liberia in combating this phenomenon, allowing for increased capacity to control fish stocks, greater protection of marine ecosystems and a more responsible use of marine resources. The protocol implementing the agreement grants access to the Liberian fishing zone by Europe within a more transparent and regulated framework, from which both parties will benefit. The partnership will contribute to the development of liberia's fisheries sector through the promotion of scientific cooperation and the strengthening of infrastructure, encouraging employment between local coastal communities and the country's economic recovery.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this first EU-Liberia Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement, which will strengthen cooperation and contribute to Liberia's recovery after extremely difficult years of conflict and civil war.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report provides for the possibility for EU fishing vessels (28 tuna and 6 longliners) to work in Liberia's territorial waters under a well-defined quota over 5 years and with a degressive financial consideration as the financial participation of shipowners rises. The agreement also provides that the money raised will be used to support small-scale fishing and the fight against illegal fishing, which Liberia cannot pay on its own. For all these reasons, I voted for this report

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This report concerned a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Liberia. Sinn Féin generally does not support Fisheries Partnership Agreements as here, when they are at the expense of developing countries and for the benefit of larger operators of the external fleets. For these reasons I abstained on the vote.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that this EU-Liberia Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries allows European fleets access to the fisheries resources of Liberia's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and, at the same time, allows local fishermen to maintain a share of the fisheries that will enable them to live and develop in the future.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This agreement should allow EUROPEAN Fishing Vessels to access Liberian waters. In return for 715,000 euros in the first year, 650,000 euros in the second, third and fourth year and 585,000 euros in the fifth year, the twenty-eight seiner tuna (including twelve French) and the six surface longliners will be able to fish up to 6,500 tons per year. After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement supports this recovery. So I voted for this agreement, which is good for both sides.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Liberia lays the foundations for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the rational exploitation of fisheries resources in the Liberian fisheries area. There are a number of fisheries partnership agreements signed by the Union and third countries whereby the EU provides technical and financial assistance in exchange for fishing rights on a variety of fish stocks in a particular economic area of the partner country. The main purpose of this agreement is to provide fishing opportunities for Union vessels in Liberia's fishing zone, taking into account environmental standards, conservation and good management of fish stocks. Financial support from the Union for the development of sectoral policy in the fisheries sector will also be provided. I was in favour of this partnership agreement because it promotes a partnership framework that strengthens ties between the Union and Liberia, favouring the development of sustainable fisheries policies.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new agreement only covers tuna. For a total of EUR 3.25 million over five years, EU vessels can fish a total of 6 500 tonnes of tuna per year. Financial contributions should be shared equally between an amount intended for access to fishery resources and an amount intended to support Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy. Other elements of the reform are also included, such as the 'exclusivity' clause, a human rights clause and a principle where no other country practising deep-sea fishing can enjoy more favourable conditions than the EU. Although the Italian interest at stake is relative (the Italian fleet that fishes in the ocean is relatively small and aimed at countries other than this one), I am voting in favour.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague's report, which highlights the benefits of this agreement for the European Union and Liberia. Indeed, this is the first agreement between the European Union and Liberia that will allow the union's ships to fish in Liberian waters in exchange for a financial consideration to finance access to water and the development of the sustainable fishing sector in Liberia. This tuna agreement provides fishing opportunities for 28 seiner tuna and 6 surface longliners. The sectoral support available under the protocol will assist Liberia in its national fisheries strategy, including in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the partnership agreement with Liberia because it is consistent with both the objectives of the common fisheries policy and the principles of sustainable fisheries management. The agreement strengthens cooperation between the EU and Liberia, and more generally with West Africa, where important tuna fishing grounds are located. The agreement promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and for the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in liberia's fishing zone. Another very positive aspect is that this agreement assists the EU in its global fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated (IUU) fishing by supporting the improvement of the monitoring, control and surveillance of the liberian fisheries sector and exclusive economic zones.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Liberia. Sinn Féin generally does not support Fisheries Partnership Agreements as here, when they are at the expense of developing countries and for the benefit of larger operators of the external fleets. For these reasons I abstained on the vote.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report and thereby gave my consent for the conclusion of the sustainable fisheries agreement between the European Union and Liberia. The aim of the agreement is to increase our cooperation with Liberia in the area of fisheries. It outlines similar goals to those of the European common fisheries policy and includes measures to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Through this agreement the European Union will also gain fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which allows European vessels to fish in Liberian waters. In particular, I have put forward a provision on transparency, which is a key element in the promotion of sustainable fishing, which requires the publication of any agreement (public or private) allowing access to Liberian waters by vessels flying foreign flags.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the conclusion of a partnership agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries with Liberia would clearly help the EU to achieve its objectives of combating TDP fishing and to extend the objective of the Common Fisheries Policy (CSP) for sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementing protocol. This recommendation focuses on the cooperation effort between the two parties in the fisheries sector and is a positive step towards further cooperation. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in my opinion, in the formation of a partnership agreement between the European Union and Liberia for sustainable fisheries, it lays a solid foundation for genuinely promoting sustainable and economically viable fisheries management. It was an important vote for me because I believe that this report plans the objective of using these resources not only with due attention to our ecosystem, but also with a view to the future, in order to generate prosperity and allow the exploitation of this resource by future generations as well. Having therefore verified that, under the agreement, there are common objectives between Liberia and the Union, and above all how they agree with the objectives set by the common fisheries policy, I could only vote in favour. I will always agree with agreements that will allow the growth and development not only of Europe but also of third countries, especially when these are both in the interests of both sides and, as in this case, with respect for a resource that is fundamental to me.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years the European Union (EU) has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements (FPAs) and protocols with ‘third countries’. Through the FPAs, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country’s exclusive economic zone (EEZ). Since 2014, with the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) these agreements are called sustainable fisheries partnership agreements (SFPAs). This sustainable fisheries partnership agreement is the first to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which has a 570 km coastline along the Atlantic Ocean. The EEZ of 246 152 km² is home to demersal and pelagic fish resources including the tuna and tuna-like species

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefiting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the first sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the Eu ropean Union and Liberia, as such cooperation would help to achieve the EU's objectives in the fight against illegal fishing and to disseminate standards relating to the sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities. The promotion of the partnership framework for the development of sustainable fisheries and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in liberia's fishing zone is an interest shared by the European Union and Liberia. Cooperation between the European Union and Liberia more generally also strengthens the cooperation of West Africa in tuna fishing areas.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This report should be placed within a framework of a number of Fisheries Partnership Agreements (FPAs) and Protocols with ‘third countries’. Through these agreements the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country’s Exclusive Economic Zone. It is important that the overall objectives of such agreements includes sustainable exploitation and not merely exploitation.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The sustainable fisheries agreement with Liberia has a five-year duration and authorises European vessels, mainly Spanish and French, to fish in the waters of Liberia's exclusive economic zone. In return, the EU will pay the African country a total financial contribution of 3.2 million euros: 715 thousand in the first year, 650 thousand in the second, third and fourth years and 585 thousand in the fifth year. The fisheries sector accounts for 3% of Liberia's GDP and makes up a large part of the livelihood of more than half of the population living along the coast. The agreement shows that great progress is being made with regard to relations with Liberia, and serious problems remain in the African country, the fight against poverty and extreme hunger, humanitarian aid and development cooperation cannot cease to operate. Today, poverty and hunger are issues on which the spotlight of international agencies, governments and NGOs is on. From a European point of view, I believe that the fisheries agreements with Liberia represent a step forward, although I hope for a regional fisheries agreement that includes all the African countries concerned. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as the first fisheries agreement with Liberia by the European Union. Despite our strong commitment to a fisheries policy based on responsible management of local fisheries resources, we believe that a small share of exploitation responsible for certain fishery resources is possible to maintain the jobs in the sector. This agreement is the first to be made with that country, which implies that for the first time vessels fishing in those waters will be subject to and accountable to an agreement with the local authorities. The development of such agreements in such a way as to respect the full sovereignty of countries as well as to take into account the care of marine resources is fundamental to the sustainability of fisheries in general. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution to support the conclusion of the first Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Liberia already presented by the Council. I believe that this is a step forward in the partnership agreements for sustainable fisheries, which will give the EU access to fisheries in Liberia's exclusive economic zone and to Liberia technical and financial support, with a view to the joint objectives of combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, and sustainable management of fishery resources and ecosystems.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the European Union has signed a number of financial and technical assistance agreements for the purpose of fishing rights of a wide range of fish stocks. I voted for cooperation between the European Union and Liberia. EU vessels can fish 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year for a total contribution of EUR 3.25 million over a five-year period.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The European Union has concluded several fisheries partnership agreements with third countries in recent years. Through fisheries partnership agreements, the EU provides financial and technical support for fishing rights for fish stocks within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries.  In 2013, the Commission carried out a preliminary assessment of the possibility of a fisheries partnership agreement with Liberia. The report noted that the EU tuna sector is interested in fishing in Liberia. The European Commission held three rounds of negotiations with the Government of Liberia on the conclusion of the first Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and implementation protocol. On 5 June 2015, the Parties corked a new agreement and protocol valid for 5 years. The EU and Liberia cooperate through multilateral agreements and fisheries organisations. Furthermore, the Liberian authorities are working closely with the UNION to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The aim of the Liberian national fisheries authority is to promote sustainably managed and economically viable fisheries, a policy that is in line with EU fisheries policy. I supported the report on the above.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This agreement is the first sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Liberia, which has a 570 km long coastline along the Atlantic Ocean. The exclusive economic zone of 246,152 km² is a habitat for many species of bottom and pelagic fish. In 2013, the Commission carried out an ex ante evaluation of a possible sustainable fisheries partnership agreement with Liberia. The document concludes that the EU tuna fishing sector has a lively interest in fishing in Liberia and that the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement would help improve monitoring, control and surveillance and contribute to improving fisheries management in the region.  For the sake of the above arguments, I expressed my support for the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 5 June 2015, the European Union signed with the Republic of Liberia the first partnership agreement for sustainable fisheries, with its implementation protocol. Today, the European Parliament is giving the final green light to the conclusion of this agreement, which promotes a strategic framework between the European Union and Liberia in the fisheries sector and which allows the development of a sustainable fisheries policy that is capable of ensuring the responsible and economically viable exploitation of fishery resources in liberia's fishing zone, where important tuna fishing grounds are located. This is a first step which has the broader objective of extending the European fisheries cooperation policy with the countries of West Africa and thus allowing European fishing vessels and fishing vessels access to new areas on the basis of precise rules shared also with our partners, in return for support for the local community. The partnership agreement also has the merit of providing for close and more effective cooperation with the Liberian authorities in the fight against illegal fishing, one of the battles undertaken by the European Union in recent years, both inside and outside its borders.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative report provides an overview of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement. According to the rapporteur, the protocol will have a positive impact on Spanish and French fishing vessels. It believes that the positive effect of sectoral support measures on the local economy and coastal communities will prove to be long-term and must therefore be carefully assessed by the Commission when the protocol expires. As such, the rapporteur recommends involving the European Parliament in the implementation and monitoring of the multi-year sector support programme. As I believe that sustainable fishing must be defended and developed at the international level through clear, effective and ambitious partnership agreements, I supported this report.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a serious achievement that the EU concludes a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia in West Africa. This is the first agreement of its kind between the two parties. The active protection of stocks of Atlantic tuna and other fish species opens a new chapter in the environmental protection of the country with an exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km2.  I am particularly pleased that the European Union is contributing significantly to the reduction of irregular, unreported fishing in Liberian waters and to make liberians aware of the different techniques of sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Hungary, as a country with an expert in freshwater fishing and aquaculture, can play a major role in boosting freshwater fish farming and aquaculture in Liberia. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because it is beneficial for both the Union and Liberia. The agreement provides for access to Liberian territorial waters by 34 European vessels with an annual fee for 5 years. It took effect on 9 December 2015 and still needed the approval of the European Parliament. On the one hand, the European fleet needs access to new fishing areas, especially in order to be able to track the migration of certain fish species, notably tuna. On the other hand, in Liberia, more than half of the population lives in coastal areas and depends on fishing. However, the country reports that boats flying Asian but also European flags are illegally fishing in its waters. The EU will pay an annual fee of around 650,000 euros on average to Liberia. Almost half of this amount will be allocated to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (INN) fishing. Finally, I stress the sustainability of fishing, which will not put Liberia's fish reserves at risk and provide the country with long-term income.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text deals with the fisheries agreement that was signed on 5 June 2015 with Liberia, for a period of 5 years. It concerns twenty-eight tuna seiners, including sixteen Spanish and twelve French, as well as six Spanish surface longliners. Half of the funds committed under the agreement include support for small-scale fishing, the fight against illegal fishing, surveillance and control. It should be noted that European financial participation will gradually decrease, as shipowners pay ever higher counterparties. After the civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement is contributing to this development, while remaining beneficial to both sides. In addition, Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. I have therefore supported this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this report because I am convinced that a clearer framework of agreements and regulations is needed, especially in action outside the EU's borders. We must avoid unnecessary misunderstandings and create legal loopholes for the protection of our fishing vessels and for the transport of fish. More importantly, however, by better fisheries management in the region, we indirectly protect EU fishery resources, as well as avoid market disturbances due to economic fluctuations and other damage, overcrowding, etc. , i.e. in the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Voted against the recommendation as the intended Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol will result in strict control and supervision by the EU monitoring mechanisms of Liberia's exclusive economic zone, which marks a direct EU involvement in a third country's most important area of national sovereignty.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a serious achievement that the EU concludes a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia in West Africa. This is the first agreement of its kind between the two parties. The active protection of stocks of Atlantic tuna and other fish species opens a new chapter in the environmental protection of the country with an exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km2.  I am particularly pleased that the European Union is contributing significantly to the reduction of irregular, unreported fishing in Liberian waters and to make liberians aware of the different techniques of sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Hungary, as a country with an expert in freshwater fishing and aquaculture, can play a major role in boosting freshwater fish farming and aquaculture in Liberia. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's distant fishing fleets have been targeting their tropical tuna fishing activities in the Gulf of Guinea since the 1950s and currently obtain around 10 % of their total tuna catch volume in the Atlantic Ocean. These catches consist mainly of jayado (70 %), yellowfin tuna (25 %) and golet tuna (5%). This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which has a coastline of 570 km along the Atlantic Ocean.  I voted in favour because the agreement is consistent with the objectives of the common fisheries policy, sustainable management of fishing and aquaculture activities, and is a source of high benefit for both parties.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: after periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, the Liberian economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement supports this development. This agreement is beneficial to both parties.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the EU and Liberia, the objectives of which meet the needs of the EU's common fisheries policy. The report focuss on the development of international cooperation for the management of shared stocks and the implementation of fisheries monitoring, control and surveillance mechanisms, all of which are objectives designed to increase the certainty and security of rights for EU vessels. The agreement is an important milestone, because it strengthens cooperation between the EU and Liberia, and more generally with West Africa, where important tuna fishing grounds are located, bringing mutual benefits to both sides.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it has positive potential for people and the environment.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement in question in the sustainable fisheries sector between the European Union and Liberia follows the conclusion by the European Union of a number of similar agreements with third countries. In future, the European Union and Liberia must cooperate even more intensively in the fight against illegal fishing, because the civil war in the country has created a huge area for illegal activities and unregulated fishing, which can negatively affect fish stocks and health. The European Union must continue the global fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing by supporting improved monitoring, control and surveillance of the fisheries sector and the exclusive economic zone.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the report which does not adversely affect the Italian economy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation as the intended Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol will result in strict control and supervision by THE EU monitoring mechanisms of Liberia's exclusive economic zone, which marks a direct EU involvement in the third country's most important area of national sovereignty.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this new agreement and protocol. Failure to act by the EU would allow the emergence of private agreements which would not guarantee sustainable fisheries. The Liberian authorities undertake not to give more favourable conditions than those accorded under this agreement to other foreign fleets operating in the Liberian fishing zone. These conditions relate to the conservation, development and management of resources, financial arrangements, fees and rights relating to the issuing of fishing authorisations. In this regard, we particularly welcome the fact that Liberia renders public any agreement authorising foreign fleets to fish in the waters under its jurisdiction. The protocol takes into account the priorities of the reformed CFP and its external dimension. I particularly welcome the inclusion of a human rights clause as well as ILO provisions on fundamental principles and rights at work. Sectoral support will contribute to the development of the country’s fisheries infrastructure, to the capacity-building of the Liberian fisheries authorities, and encourage local employment. Although measures for the protection of the marine environment as well as observer coverage (15%) could be more ambitious, I fully support this very important SFPA.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the rapporteur, I voted in favour of parliament's draft resolution calling for the conclusion on behalf of the Union of a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. Through agreements with third countries, the EU provides financial and technical support for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries.  Against this background, I believe that the agreement is in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy and the sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities. It also strengthens cooperation with West Africa, which has important tuna fishing zones in general. Similar sectoral support measures may give hope to the growing role of local economies.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Recommendation convinced that the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia will clearly contribute to the achievement of the EU's objectives with regard to combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, as well as to propagate the objective of the common fisheries policy of sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities. The Protocol provides for a financial contribution from the EU amounting to EUR 715 000 for the first year, EUR 650 000 for the second, third and fourth years, and EUR 585 000 for the fifth year, which will have a positive effect on the local economy and coastal communities.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the fisheries partnership with Liberia as I believe this agreement is in the interests of both the European Union and Liberia. The agreement will provide Liberia with technical and financial support from the European Union while at the same time opening up Liberian fishing waters to a quota of EU vessels. I think that both of these aspects are important and in the European Union’s interest; on one hand to give our fishing industries additional waters to fish in, as well as helping Liberia to move towards stability and further progress and in doing so provide the opportunities for its inhabitants.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. In recent years, the European Union has signed a series of fisheries partnership agreements with third countries to provide financial and technical support, in exchange for fishing rights related to large fish stocks in the partner country area. I believe that these agreements are not only consistent with the common objectives of fisheries policy, but also provide a sustainable and economically viable management of the activity, which can bring many benefits for both parties, from a long-term perspective.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of a partnership agreement on sustainable fisheries between the EU and Liberia. Fishing grounds know no borders – the more important it is to coordinate and clarify the protection of maritime biodiversity and the implementation of sustainable fisheries beyond the EU borders.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The seas must be regulated uniformly. Only in this way can sustainable support for fisheries be maintained while respecting EU standards. The EU's fisheries partnership agreements with third countries promote the CFP and provide fishing rights in coastal regions outside the EU. As an alternate member of the Committee on Fisheries, I support the agreement.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement (SFPA, the first of its kind between the EU and Liberia). It contributes to greater cooperation between the EU, Liberia and the Western Saharan region without any increase in EU funding. Furthermore, it will help aid Liberia’s recovery following years of political and economic upheaval, as well as civil war and the recent Ebola crisis.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This agreement allows european fishing vessels to access Liberian waters. Signed on 5 June 2015 for a period of 5 years, this is the first fisheries agreement with Liberia. It concerns 28 seiner tuna (16 Spanish and 12 French) and 6 surface longliners (Spanish). In return, Liberia will receive 715,000 euros in the first year; 650,000 euros in the second, third and fourth years; EUR 585,000 in the fifth year, based on a reference tonnage of 6,500 tonnes. Support for the development of the fisheries sector policy (support for small-scale fishing, the fight against illegal fishing, surveillance, control) is half of this amount.  European financial participation will decrease from year to year, as shipowners will pay 55 euros per tonne in the first year of application, 60 euros per tonne in the second and third years, 65 euros per tonne in the fourth year of application and 70 euros per tonne in the fifth year of application.  After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, the Liberian economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement supports this development. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which is beneficial to both parties.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Liberia in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which is the first Sustainable Fisheries agreement between the EU and Liberia. It will reinforce cooperation, as well as enhance scientific cooperation and promote the development of its fishing sector.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The new Partnership Agreement is expected to contribute to Liberia’s recovery after the Ebola crisis and is a sign of the EU’s confidence in Liberia’s economy.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a serious achievement that the EU concludes a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia in West Africa. This is the first agreement of its kind between the two parties. The conservation of stocks of Atlantic tuna and other fish species opens a new chapter in the environmental protection of the country with an exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km2.  It is a positive change that the European Union is contributing significantly to the reduction of irregular, unreported fishing in Liberian waters and is familiar with liberians about the different techniques of sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Hungary, as a country with an active in freshwater fishing and aquaculture, can play a major role in boosting freshwater fish farming and aquaculture in Liberia.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Given that the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia is coherent with the aims of the Common Fisheries Policy, of a sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities and that it is of great mutual benefit to both parties, I have decided to support the report written by my colleague, Jarosław Wałęsa. The agreement will strengthen the cooperation between the Union and Liberia, and more generally with West Africa where important tuna fishing zones are located. It will promote a partnership framework in which to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Liberian fishing zone and also help the European Union in its fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The vote in favour was due to the benefit of both parties from this report. West Africa is a favourable area for fishing and I believe that the union would benefit a lot from a stronger partnership due to this. The Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Union and Liberia would aid the Union in its on-going battle against IUU fishing and also this would bring financial benefits to the Union, in particular to French and Spanish boats.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Liberia, which will benefit both partners. As a result, EU vessels will be able to access Liberian territorial waters while the EU will intervene financially in favour of the development of Liberia's sustainable fishing sector.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This is the first Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Liberia. It will reinforce cooperation in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Moreover, it will help the country to improve its fisheries monitoring and control, and the development of its fishing sector as well.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and the Implementation Protocol to that agreement, as this is in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy, thereby promoting sustainable fisheries and aquaculture management.  The agreement also contributes to the fight against undeclared, illegal and unregulated fishing, which is one of the Union's objectives, while supporting economically viable fisheries. In my view, this type of cooperation leads to mutual benefit, i.e. the Union provides technical and financial assistance to Liberia, improves fisheries management in West Africa, and the EU is entitled to fish stocks in Liberia's exclusive economic zone. Therefore, I support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement supports this development. This agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. It is of course that my voice was in favour of the text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement on Sustainable Fisheries with Liberia is certainly one of the instruments for maintaining good relations with the country, and it will also benefit the Union by enabling EU member states' vessels to fish in Liberian waters. The aim is both to strengthen EU-Liberia cooperation and to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and to jointly crack down on illegal fishing. The idea of responsible exploitation of fishery resources is an essential element of the EU's common fisheries policy, which is why I supported the proposal.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement which, for 5 years, will allow the European fleet to supervise tuna fishing activity in the Liberian fishing area in exchange for a financial consideration from the EU to promote sustainable fishing. This will have a positive impact on European fishing vessels, particularly in France.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. There is nothing to oppose a partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia on sustainable fisheries.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as its aim is to strengthen cooperation between the EU, Liberia and the Western Saharan region in general, especially as regards its tuna production. It also strengthens the partnership framework to further develop a sustainable fisheries policy in Liberia.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a serious achievement that the EU concludes a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia in West Africa. This is the first agreement of its kind between the two parties. The active protection of stocks of Atlantic tuna and other fish species opens a new chapter in the environmental protection of the country with an exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km2.  I am particularly pleased that the European Union is contributing significantly to the reduction of irregular, unreported fishing in Liberian waters and to make liberians aware of the different techniques of sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Hungary, as a country with an expert in freshwater fishing and aquaculture, can play a major role in boosting freshwater fish farming and aquaculture in Liberia. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Writing. \u2012 This Recommendation refers to the conclusion of a Partnership Agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries and its Implementing Protocol between the European Union and Liberia. It is obvious that such a partnership benefits both Liberia, which will receive financial and technical support, given the need to strengthen local society and combat illegal fishing, and the Union whose fishing rights will be guaranteed and the role in the region will be strengthened. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – An analogy to the well-established 'fair trade' is that european fishing vessels receive support from the European Union framework for activities in Liberian coastal waters in order to promote mutually beneficial objectives. This is a good recommendation, because the European population thus has access to high-quality marine fish, which are essential for a healthy diet, while fishing is regulated in order to make sustainable use of fish stocks

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the EU-Liberia Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and the Protocol on its implementation. It will strengthen eu-Liberia cooperation, but also more generally between the EU and West Africa. The years of civil war in Liberia had a negative impact on the economy and, accordingly, on fishing in the country, as instability allowed it to carry out illegal fishing activities with foreign vessels. This reduces the opportunities to increase national revenue from fishing activities and has a negative impact on fish stocks and marine ecosystems. I believe that, in the long term, EU financial support will have a positive impact on the local economy. The Protocol will help strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance, as well as contribute to better fisheries management in the region. The conclusion of this agreement will help the EU to achieve its objectives in terms of combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, as well as to implement one of the priorities of the Common Fisheries Policy – sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture. The Protocol will bring greater security and more rights for EU ships, strengthening its role in the region.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I would like to stress, once again, the importance of supporting the fisheries market at local level, at the same time as the international one. Having said that, however, it is essential to conclude international agreements to safeguard our fisheries. In the present case, the EU ratifies a 5-year agreement with Liberia in order to strengthen cooperation with liberia. Liberia, which overlooks the Atlantic Ocean coast, has important tuna fishing grounds. This agreement will make it possible, through improved monitoring, control and surveillance (MCS), the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of resources and support for the fight against illegal fishing. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the EU-Liberia Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Liberia Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement. This agreement will allow access for EU fishing vessels to Liberian waters. After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting, and this fisheries agreement supports this development. The agreement benefits both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because after periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting, and this fisheries agreement supports this development. This agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to fight illegal fishing alone.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This text relates to the partnership agreement between the European Union and the Liberal, signed on 5 June 2015. It opens Liberian waters to European fishermen for five years, with European subsidies in return. There are several advantages to this agreement. First of all, it allows, thanks to European aid, to revive the development of Liberia, which has been hit hard by the civil war and Ebola. In addition, European funding will gradually fall, from EUR 715,000 in the first year to EUR 650,000 in the second, third and fourth years, and 585,000 euros in the fifth year, on a benchmark basis of 6,500 tonnes. This agreement will benefit 28 seiner tuna (16 Spanish and 12 French) and six Spanish surface longliners. It will be under the control of a joint commission, which will monitor the implementation of the agreement. The whole text is positive, so I voted FOR.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this new agreement because it includes the possibility that EU vessels will be able to fish for 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year for a trade-off of EUR 3.25 million over five years. In addition, the financial contribution shall be divided equally between an amount for access to fishery resources and an amount intended to support Liberia's fisheries policy.  The agreement also includes other elements, such as the exclusivity clause, a human rights clause, and the principle that more favourable conditions should not apply to any country practicing deep-sea fishing than those applied to the EU. With regard to transparency, a key element for promoting sustainable fishing is included, a provision requiring the publication of any agreement (whether public or private) allowing access to foreign-flagged vessels into Liberian waters.  One noteworthy aspect of this agreement is that the financial contribution is also important for the development of artisanal fisheries and food security in Liberia. Although these development possibilities are limited by a lack of infrastructure.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the first fisheries agreement with Liberia by the European Union. Despite our strong commitment to a fisheries policy based on responsible management of local fisheries resources, we believe that a small share of exploitation responsible for certain fishery resources is possible to maintain the jobs in the sector. This agreement is the first to be made with that country, which implies that for the first time vessels fishing in those waters will be subject to and accountable to an agreement with the local authorities. The development of such agreements in such a way as to respect the full sovereignty of countries as well as to take into account the care of marine resources is fundamental to the sustainability of fisheries in general. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. I believe that we should adopt this recommendation, as fisheries cooperation agreements with third countries involve the exchange of fishing rights with third countries, while the EU grants them financial and technical assistance. With this agreement we seek to intensify cooperation with Liberia to combat illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. The main objective is to promote sustainable and economically viable managed fisheries. I support this report which will also provide fishing opportunities for Union vessels in the Liberian fishing area. For the reasons set out above and since the agreement and its protocol are in line with the objectives of the common fisheries policy and promote an partnership framework for the development of fishery resources in the Liberian area, I welcome its approval.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is to pay Liberia EUR 600,000 per year to fish 6.5 thousand tonnes of fish in 34 ships under the agreement. I do not agree with these neocolonial agreements, which, for the sum for dictatorial governments, take fishing rights away from ordinary people in poor countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia and the EU provides financial and technical support to the EU in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in Liberia's exclusive economic zone. European Union fleets have been hunting tropical tuna in the Gulf of Guinea since the 1950s, and currently this catch amounts to 10% of the world's tuna catches. This agreement could further expand the network of tuna fishing agreements in West Africa. The new Protocol improves cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Liberia to promote the development of sustainable fishing policies. The fisheries sector currently accounts for 3% of total GDP and has the potential to contribute significantly to liberia's development. Sectoral support to be made available under the Protocol will assist the Republic of Liberia in implementing its national fisheries strategy, scientific research, small-scale coastal fishing as well as fisheries monitoring, control and control and combating illegal fishing, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of this agreement because, in addition to a significant stabilising element in the fisheries sector between the EU and Liberia, it will help to eradicate illegal and unregulated fishing and destruction in the country's waters. The EU will reimburse Mauritania a total of EUR 3.25 million over five years, which will be apportioned equally to the amount for access to fishery resources and the amount to support Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementing protocol, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/5/2016 and because this recommendation is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement. The agreement, signed on 5 June 2015 for a five-year term, is the first signed by the European Union with Liberia. It allows access to Liberian waters by 28 tuna seiners and 6 longliners, with a degressive contribution from the European Union. Based on a reference tonnage of 6,500 tonnes, this contribution would increase from EUR 715,000 in the first year to EUR 585,000 in the fifth year. Over the same period, shipowners would see their contribution gradually increase from 55 euros to 70 euros per tonne. Another condition imposed under the agreement is the 20% threshold for seafarers on board made up of national fishermen from an African, Caribbean or Pacific (ACP) state, including at least three Liberian employees. Finally, the application of the agreement will be monitored by a joint committee throughout its validity period. We can only support this proposal for an agreement, which is balanced between the two parties. In addition, the agreement provides welcome support to Liberia, which has been hard hit by the civil war and, more recently, by the Ebola epidemic. The only false note is that we regret that the issue of incidental shark catches has not been addressed.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementing protocol. This is the first partnership agreement, concluded between the Republic of Liberia and the European Union, for sustainable fisheries with the aim of strengthening and consolidating cooperation between Liberia and the European Union in the global fight against un regulated fishing.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has a long history of fishing in the waters off the coast of Liberia. I support this agreement because it allows us to continue along this path, while also providing assistance to Liberia in order to support domestic consumption. I welcome the inclusion in the agreement of a human rights clause and the conditions of equal treatment with Liberia.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the proposal for the conclusion of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its Protocol of Implementation. From the European Parliament, we believe that this agreement is in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy, sustainable fisheries management and aquaculture activities, and is of great benefit to both sides. It also strengthens cooperation between the Union and Liberia, and more generally with West Africa, where important tuna fishing areas are located.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Union Fisheries Partnership Agreement (SSA) with Liberia is part of the Union's broader policy of providing financial and technical support to foreign states by taking fishing rights as consideration.  This Agreement will take place for the first time between the European Union and Liberia, whereas until now cooperation has only existed through the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.  The Union's objectives through this agreement are, inter alia, to combat illegal and uncontrolled fishing (MDGs) which has made a major contribution to reducing the national income for Liberian fishermen and to destroying the country's marine ecosystem. At the same time, fishing in Liberia also includes tuna, so the agreement could help to control and monitor the fisheries concerned and the other species with the ultimate aim of continuing their viability. With my vote, I support the conclusion of a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia, with the expectation that this agreement will be used properly to help combat illegal fishing, protect marine biodiversity and provide economic and social support to the country.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia and its Protocol for its implementation are in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy on the sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities and are of great benefit to both EU Member States and Liberia.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this protocol that will bolster cooperation between the European Union and Liberia. The protocol encourages a sustainable fisheries policy and will support the local economy in the long term.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. According to the agreement, the EU is allowed to fish in Liberian waters. The report aims to set up a joint commission to monitor the results. This first 5-year fishing agreement has a decreasing cost to our vessels year after year. This agreement benefits both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. Moreover, it is beneficial to its economy, which has suffered from the Ebola crisis and the civil war. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which has a coastline of 570 km along the Atlantic Ocean. The 246,152 km² EES is home to demersal and pelagic fishery resources, including tuna and related species. The main objective of the Implementation Protocol is to provide fishing opportunities for Union vessels in the Liberian fishing area, on the basis of the best available scientific advice, while respecting the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and, where possible, within the limits of the available surplus. The Protocol provides for fishing opportunities in the following categories: 28 tuna seiners and 6 surface longliners. The Protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 715 000 for the first year, EUR 650 000 for the second, third and fourth years, and EUR 585 000 for the fifth year.  Hence my assent.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement. The agreement strengthens the cooperation between the European Union, Liberia and the West African region as a whole, as well as facilitating further action to combat illegal, unreported and unregistered fishing.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement with Liberia. Liberia, like the EU, has sustainable and responsible resource management objectives in fisheries. I therefore welcome this new partnership and the positive consequences it should have, among other things, on the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. In this particular area, cooperation is essential. Good management of fisheries resources can only be done multilaterally. I therefore encourage the conclusion of such partnerships and the strengthening of their provisions on the transparency of fishing activities. I would also like to stress the importance of the EU's support for the development of the fisheries sector in the partner countries with which it concludes such agreements.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Union, through sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, provides financial and technical support to countries in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. The Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Union and Liberia will allow access to an area of more than 250 000 km², home to bottom and pelagic fish, including tuna and tuna-like species. The Liberian authorities shall cooperate closely with the Union in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The years of civil war have created a space for illegal fishing activities in which foreign vessels have fished fish stocks in Liberian waters, resulting in liberian fishermen and the state losing potential revenue and eroding the health of fish stocks and the marine ecosystem. I am convinced that the conclusion of such an agreement will contribute to the Union achieving its objectives of combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and will extend the objective of the Common Fisheries Policy of sustainably managing fishing and aquaculture activities. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between EU and Liberia, which is the first Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement (SFPA) between the EU and Liberia. This agreement will reinforce cooperation, in particular in the fight against IUU fishing, and help the country to improve its fisheries monitoring, control and surveillance capacity, as well as enhance scientific cooperation and promote the development of its fishing sector. It is also essential that this agreement is expected to contribute to Liberia's recovery after extremely difficult years of conflict and civil war, political and economic instability, and the recent Ebola crisis. The Agreement and Protocol are in line with the reformed CFP and ensure that the fishing activities of EU vessels in Liberian waters are carried out in respect of the principles of sustainability, good governance, transparency, non-discrimination and respect of human rights. This SFPA further expands the EU's network of tuna fisheries agreements in West Africa.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, the European Union has concluded a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with "third countries" to provide financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries.  On the basis of the mandate received from the Council on 20 June 2014, the Commission negotiated with the Government of Liberia the conclusion of the first Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and Implementation Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. On 5 June 2015, the Parties corked the Tuna Fisheries Agreement and Protocol, which is valid for 5 years and can be tacitly renewed. The Protocol provide for a Financial Contribution from the Union of EUR 715 000 for the first year, EUR 650 000 for the second, third and fourth years and EUR 585 000 for the fifth year.  The Council intends to adopt a decision on the ratification of the Agreement and the Protocol, for which it must obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries stresses that the Agreement and the Implementation Protocol are in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy and bring significant mutual benefits to both parties, and therefore recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the Agreement and the Protocol annexed therect. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this agreement is to allow EU fishing vessels to enter Liberian waters for a period of five years. After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, the Liberian economy is restarting and this fisheries agreement supports this development. This agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. So I voted for it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has signed Fisheries Partnership Agreements (OAAs) and Protocols with 'third countries', through which it provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide variety of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone (EES).  This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which has a coastal strip of 570 km along the Atlantic Ocean, with an EES of 246 152 km² housing demersal and pelagic fishery resources, including tuna and related species. I endorse the rapporteur's position, considering that the APPS with Liberia is consistent with the objectives of the common fisheries policy, sustainable management of fishing and aquaculture activities, and that the Agreement strengthens cooperation between the Union and Liberia, and generally West Africa, an important tuna fishing area. As set out in the report, I am in favour of the adoption of this Agreement.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. After periods of civil war and the Ebola epidemic, Liberia's economy is restarting, and this fisheries agreement supports this development. This agreement benefits both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. That's why I voted FOR.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the spread of environmentally harmful practices and wildlife in Atlantic tuna fishing, we sincerely welcome the Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries concluded between the European Union and Liberia.  The agreement will serve the dual purpose of promoting sustainable conditions and practices in fishing and ensuring good growth opportunities for European operators. The partnership, in fact, through cooperation between the agency responsible for monitoring the exploitation of marine resources and the European Commission, the reference to the conventions of the International Labour Organisation, and the imposition of rules to protect marine biodiversity, with particular reference to the populousness of tuna, will guarantee conditions of greater environmental and social sustainability. The text of the agreement obliges the Liberian authorities not to grant fishing permits that do not comply with the provisions of the agreement to fleets from third countries. The funded contribution will also support job creation and infrastructure construction for the fisheries sector, thus supporting measures to stimulate the growth of the economic system, which has been torn apart by years of civil war. During the conflict, the lack of control over fish stocks led to a serious exploitation by foreign fleets of the marine ecosystem and a decrease in the Atlantic population.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Fisheries Partnership Agreements represent an understanding where the EU offers financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights. I have voted for this report that will grant the European Union’s distant water fishing fleets access to the gulf of Guinea’s tropical tuna. This agreement will strengthen cooperation between the EU and Liberia as well as with other West African Countries where important tuna fishing zones are located.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Partnership Agreement between the EU and Liberia encourages closer economic cooperation between the two Parties in the fisheries industry and related activities. The Agreement lays down the principles, rules and procedures governing the conditions under which Union vessels may engage in fishing activities in the Liberian fisheries area, as well as economic, financial, technical and scientific cooperation in the fisheries sector. Actions taken shall be taken in the light of the promotion of sustainable fishing in Liberian fisheries and the development of Liberia's fisheries sector.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report concerned a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Liberia. Sinn Féin generally does not support Fisheries Partnership Agreements as here, when they are at the expense of developing countries and for the benefit of larger operators of the external fleets. For these reasons I abstained on the vote.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. I support the partnership agreement on sustainable fisheries between the EU and Liberia. Sustainable fishing is an important step for economic development.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU has an interest in the tuna fishing area there, but the agreement also aims to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fish stocks and to support the sustainable development of the economy of Liberia and the region.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and the Protocol for its implementation.  This agreement will renew the framework for a strategic fisheries partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, which promotes a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources. The EU has a great responsibility in ensuring the conservation and sustainable management of international fisheries resources. In the interests of both parties, it is necessary to further develop sustainable and responsible fishing and to increase the value of fishery products.  It should be noted that eu financial support will be granted for research, as well as for small-scale fishing, monitoring, control and surveillance of fisheries and the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of my colleague's proposal because I believe that the partnership agreement with the Republic of Liberia fits perfectly into the framework of the fisheries partnership agreements already concluded by the European Union. The current cooperation between the European Union and Liberia in the fight against illegal fishing, which has not been declared or regulated, would, in my view, be further strengthened by this agreement. Furthermore, given the EU's economic interests in tuna fishing, the conclusion of the agreement signed in June 2015 would ensure greater security of rights for EU vessels as well as ensuring the sustainable management of fishing and aquaculture activities. Convinced that the partnership agreement is of mutual benefit to the two contracting parties, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be concluded by the European Union with the Republic of Liberia, which has a 570km coastline along the Atlantic Ocean. Its exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km² is the habitat of adjective and pelagic species of fish, including tuna and tuna-like species. Given that the EU and Liberia have been cooperating with multilateral agreements for many years and that the Liberian authorities have been working intensively with the EU to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, I think the EU-Liberian Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement will be beneficial for both sides. EU vessels can fish 6 500 tonnes of tuna a year for which Liberia will receive EUR 3.25 million over five years, and with Liberia not providing any other country engaged in deep sea fishing with more favourable conditions than the EU. The financial contribution shall be divided equally into the amount for access to fishing resources and the amount to support Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy. I believe that the positive impact of sectoral support measures for the local economy and coastal community will be shown in the long term. Accompanying financial packages also contribute to combating illegal fishing, which is unfortunately present and we need to fight.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I take into account the recommendations and opinions of these committees and give consent for the conclusion of the agreement and its protocol. In recent years, the European Union has signed several sustainable fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with "third countries". The EU provides financial and technical support to fisheries agreements in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the exclusive economic zone of the partner country.
