Since 2014 and the common fisheries policy reforms, these agreements have been referred to as sustainable fisheries partnership agreements. This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be concluded by the European Union with the Republic of Liberia, which has a 570km coastline along the Atlantic Ocean. Its exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km² is the habitat of adjective and pelagic species of fish, including tuna and tuna-like species. I agree with rapporteur Jarosław Wałęsa's view and consider that the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia and its implementation protocol are in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy, sustainable fisheries management and aquaculture activities and are of great mutual benefit to both parties.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report refers to a legislative resolution establishing a new protocol of fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and the Republic of Liberia. The App provides for eu vessels to access liberia's exclusive area on the basis of the best available scientific advice and respecting iccat recommendations, where applicable, within the limits of the available surplus. The Protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 715 000 for the first year, EUR 650 000 for the second, third and fourth years and EUR 585 000 for the fifth year. This support fulfils the objectives of national fisheries policy and, in particular, the needs of the Republic of Liberia in relation to scientific research, artisanal fishing and monitoring, control and surveillance fishing and the fight against illegal fishing. It is noteworthy that the capacity development component of Liberia's autonomy is superior to that of the previous protocol, which deserves support. The establishment of this agreement can be a form of cooperation with mutual benefits and is therefore supported by its continuation.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Bearing in mind the reports we have supported on the functioning and organisation of fishing zones with African countries such as Cape Verde, Madagascar, Mauritania, and in particular Guinea-Bissau, which is geographically closest to Liberia, fishing zones and relations with Liberia should also be regulated. Among other things, the aim is to create a stronger institutional framework of those multilateral agreements that we have already implemented in part and through which we also cooperate with Liberia. This institutional framework helps, both EU fishermen and Liberian fishermen, but also empowers liberian authorities, which can ensure that fishing zones are treated against illegal and unreported fishing. As a result, Liberia can increase its national income and the number of employees in the fishing sector. Given that the objectives of the Liberian fisheries policy are consistent with the objectives of EU fisheries policy and that Liberia shows a clear will to comply with the recommendation of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna, I support Representative Wałęsa's recommendation that consent be given to the conclusion of the Agreement and its implementation protocol with the aforementioned Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Liberia.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia on a sustainable fisheries partnership and an implementing protocol. This agreement represents an important milestone in the relationship between Liberia and the EU. Until now, the EU and Liberia have only cooperated in fisheries through multilateral agreements. However, there is now a possibility that cooperation will move to a bilateral level, which will make it possible to better achieve the objectives set by the EU in the field of fisheries. I believe that this agreement could bring about a change, particularly in the area of illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, which in many cases has a negative impact on the health of fish stocks and the marine ecosystem. This illegal fishing method emerged mainly after the Civil War and has a negative impact not only from an environmental point of view, but also financially harms Liberian fishermen and the state budget. At the same time, this Agreement will strengthen cooperation between the Union and Liberia and, more generally, with the whole of West Africa, where large tuna fishing zones are located. The Commission's assessment also shows that the EU fisheries sector has a strong interest in catching this type of fish in the region. Therefore, if a sustainable fisheries partnership is concluded between Liberia and the Union, this agreement will present benefits for both parties.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Apps (Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries) with Liberia, and its implementation protocol, are consistent with the objectives of the common fisheries policy and with the principles of sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities. The agreement strengthens cooperation between the EU and Liberia, and more generally with West Africa, where important tuna fishing grounds are located. It also promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and for the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in liberia's fishing zone. I believe that this partnership can bring many mutual benefits for both sides. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this recommendation.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement, which is the first such agreement signed between the European Union and Liberia. As the country's exclusive economic zone is vast and rich, it will both open up fishing grounds to European vessels, especially French vessels, and strengthen controls to protect and conserve the area's resources.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the existing strategic line on sustainable fisheries, and following other partnership agreements concluded in recent years with third countries, the Commission has negotiated a new Agreement with Liberia.  Liberia already cooperates with the EU through various agreements on the conservation of marine species, voluntarily applying standards of good practice in responsible fishing and food. Similarly, Liberia extends its cooperation with the EU to the fight against illegal fishing and, in this case, serves this Agreement to strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance within liberia's exclusive economic zone.  The Implementing Protocol, in addition to quantifying the financial contribution to that third country,, in contrast guarantees access rights to EU vessels. This cooperation not only aims at the sustainability of fisheries policy, but also the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the maritime areas of partner countries.  Having said the above, I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. A first in the European Parliament this lunchtime with the adoption by 584 votes in support of a fisheries agreement between the EU and Liberia. It opens Liberian waters to 28 seiner tuna and six European surface longliners, in return for a contribution of 3.25 million euros over five years. This money will help Liberia better manage its fisheries resources and improve the implementation of its fisheries regulations. The country still suffers from a flawed surveillance system that handicaps it in its fight against illegal, unreported, and unregulated (INN) fishing. Efforts are important to cooperate with the international community in this area, modernize its fishing sector and develop local communities. Liberia has a strong interest in fostering these types of partnerships. The figures speak for themselves: more than half of its population lives on its 570 km of coastline, and the fishing sector accounted for 3% of its GDP in 2014. Its reserves of bonitos, albacores, and obese tuna are particularly attractive to European fleets that catch 10% of their tuna catches in the Atlantic and Gulf of Guinea.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. This is the first sustainable fisheries partnership agreement with Liberia, established for a period of 9 years since December 2015. The main objective is to establish fishing opportunities for EUROPEAN Union vessels in liberia's exclusive area, respecting the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna. The annual contribution will be 715,000 euros in the first year, 650,000 in the second, third and fourth, and 585,000 in the fifth, with a base reference of 6500 tonnes. Added to this is an additional amount for access to and development of Liberia's fisheries policy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The adoption of international fisheries agreements is always good news. They are a key element for the sector in many Member States. This agreement provides that EU vessels can fish for 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year in exchange for a financial contribution aimed in part at promoting sustainable fishing and improving food security in Liberia, and partly access to fishery resources by Community vessels. It also welcomes the incorporation of a new human rights clause in Liberia. It is vital for the future of the sector to renew the Fisheries Agreements and find new alternatives in other waters. Of course, in accordance with the sustainability of the activity within the framework of the principles of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy and its external dimension. For all this, I have cast my vote in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday gave its approval to the conclusion of the first sustainable fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. It adopted by a large majority this report which supports these arrangements which allow EU vessels to catch tuna in the waters of this third country whose coast stretches for 570 km along the Atlantic Ocean. The conclusion of a fisheries agreement with Liberia would undoubtedly help the European Union achieve its objectives on combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The new agreement was signed in June 2015 for a period of 5 years from the date of provisional application, i.e. the date of their signature. The protocol provides fishing opportunities in the following categories: 28 seiner tuna and 6 surface longliners. It provides for a financial consideration of 715,000 euros for the first year, 650,000 euros for the second, third and fourth years and 585,000 for the fifth year (with a reference tonnage of 6,500 tonnes).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. The Sustainable Fisheries Agreement is concluded with our important partner, Liberia.  Neither the form nor the content of the document call into question the need to accept it as a measure in the interest of both parties to the contract. Liberia has significant fish stocks for which the European Union has the necessary capacity to absorb it. I believe that the funds received by Liberia will contribute to the modernisation of this country. At the same time, I would like to point out that in this agreement both parties are committed to limiting their appetites by catching fish only to the extent that it does not undermine the natural balance. And that is good. Such wordings must be the cornerstone of all EU fisheries agreements.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Recently, the European Union (EU) has signed a series of Fisheries Partnership Agreements with third countries through which it provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights targeted at a wide range of fisheries resources in the partner country's exclusive economic zone (EES). This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement (APPS) is the first to be signed between the EU and the Republic of Liberia, with a coastline of 570 km and an EES of 246 152 km². The EU has cooperated with Liberia in various multilateral agreements and specifically in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU fishing). The conclusion of an Apps with Liberia will clearly support the EU in achieving its objectives in the fight against IUU fishing and to disseminate the objective of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which aims at sustainable management of fishing and aquaculture activities, which underpinted my vote in favour of this recommendation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament the approval of the EU-Liberia Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement and the Additional Implementation Protocol. It is a reminder that this agreement with Liberia is in the direction of sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities, as envisaged by the Common Fisheries Policy, but also that it has important mutual benefits for both parties. This agreement allows for responsible management of fisheries resources in Liberia's tuna-rich fishing area. Finally, I supported this agreement with Liberia because it will support improved surveillance and control of the Liberian fisheries sector and the exclusive economic zone.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this report, which presents a positive assessment of the EU-Liberia cooperation agreement in the field of sustainable fisheries in a territory with a large presence of resources. The aim of the agreement is to strengthen, together with commercial cooperation, the control and monitoring of the sustainable exploitation of resources.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Liberia in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Liberiasustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement, as the agreement not only takes into account guidelines for sustainable fisheries, but can also help Liberia in the long term by providing financial support to the local economy on the ground. In my view, this partnership will ensure the long-term survival of fish resources, particularly tuna, which is common in the region, through better monitoring and regulation. It also combats illegal overfishing.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against granting approval to the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. I oppose such agreements since they reproduce a colonial relationship of exploitation of the least developed countries by the most developed. In addition, in this case, there are serious indications that fishing opportunities allocated to European Union vessels may adversely affect small local fishermen and fishermen as more than half of the population lives in coastal areas in Liberia and depends on fishing for their livelihoods and fishery products make up about 65% of the animal proteins consumed in the country.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution approving the conclusion of the first Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries and its Implementation Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. For a total of EUR 3.25 million over five years, EU vessels will be able to fish for 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year in Liberian waters. Financial contributions should be shared equally between an amount earmarked for access to fisheries resources and an amount intended to support Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy. The exclusivity clause, a human rights clause and a principle where no other country fishing on the high seas can enjoy more favourable conditions than the EU have been included. I believe that this agreement can not only bring many economic benefits to both sides, but also help to strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance in order to prevent INTA fishing (illegal, unregulated and undeclared) and to ensure the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks in the region.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats for the fisheries agreement with Liberia, I was concerned to check aspects related to the transparency of the relationship established, respect for the Republic of Liberia and the values of the European Union, including human rights and workers' rights. I was also concerned about the adequacy of the funds involved and the respect for environmental standards generally established at international level. As it is the first fisheries agreement with this country, there are still little-mature environmental details that should be improved in future renewals.  Personally, at no time have I had any doubts about the support to be given to this agreement with Liberia. This is a country that is still fragile and with institutions in the process of being structured, so the stimulus of cross-border relations that strengthen ties with the international community is crucial. This agreement, in particular, is a good indicator of what Europe's role in the world can actually be. For all these reasons, I voted positively for this fisheries agreement between the European Union and Liberia.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which is the first Sustainable Fisheries agreement between the EU and Liberia. It will reinforce cooperation, in particular in the fight against IUU fishing, and help the country to improve its fisheries monitoring, control and surveillance capacity, as well as enhance scientific cooperation and promote the development of its fishing sector. It is expected to contribute to Liberia's recovery after extremely difficult years of conflict and civil war, political and economic instability, and the recent Ebola crisis. The Agreement and Protocol are in line with the reformed CFP and ensure that the fishing activities of EU vessels in Liberian waters are carried out in respect of the principles of sustainability, good governance, transparency, non-discrimination and respect of human rights. This SFPA further expands the EU's network of tuna fisheries agreements in West Africa.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to agree to the conclusion of the agreement. This agreement will help the EU to meet its objectives of combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and strengthen the objective of a common fisheries policy of sustainably managing fishing and aquaculture activities.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and the Implementation Protocol to that Agreement, as I consider the main objective of Liberia's fisheries policy to be in line with the objectives of the EU Common Fisheries Policy. Important items in Liberia's fisheries policy objectives are linked to restoring fish biomass capacity to produce the highest sustainable yield and promoting international cooperation on the management of common stocks. Given that the EU is highly interested in tuna fishing in Liberia's waters, a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia would contribute to strengthening monitoring, control and control and better fisheries management in the region. The Development Committee pays attention to the fact that during the preparation of the evaluation preceding the negotiations, no consultations were carried out with Liberian stakeholders, and notes that this needs to be corrected in the future. It also states that in Liberia, the contribution of small-scale fishing to food security is crucial but limited by the absence of infrastructure. The Committee on Budgets is of the opinion that the protocol improves cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Liberia to promote the development of sustainable fishing policies. In particular, it provides for the monitoring of vessels by a satellite vessel tracking system and the transmission of catch data electronically.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is commendable that the EU Commission intends to conclude a new Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia on the basis of the relevant directives. The new agreement is intended to take into account the priorities of the reformed COMMON FISHERIES POLICY for the purposes of the STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP between the EU and Liberia. Nearly 570 km is the long coastline of Liberia, where on an area of 250 thousand km2 of the Atlantic Ocean the largest fishery resources are also tuna and their related species. Fishing opportunities provide more than 50% of liberia's population with jobs and livelihoods. The Protocol provides EU vessels with fishing opportunities in the Liberian fishing zone for annual payments to Liberia. I add to the rapporteur's view that the EP has a limited role to play in approving and monitoring partnership agreements, and I am afraid that by protocol we should not create official opportunities for European fishing companies to take on liberia and its people's natural assets through controlled processes.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The EU has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries in recent years, providing financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights in the partner country's exclusive economic zone.  This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be signed by the EU and the Republic of Liberia.  The Agreement shall be consistent with the objectives of the common fisheries policy and the sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities and bring significant mutual benefits to both Parties.  It enables, inter alia, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources and helps to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. With regard to transparency, which is an essential element of promoting sustainable fisheries, a provision is included requiring the publication of all agreements, both public and private, on access by vessels flying the foreign flag to Liberian waters.  The transparency provision is particularly welcome, as the fisheries transparency initiative is only just beginning to be real. The report corresponds to my views on sustainable fisheries, which is why I supported it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. In recent years, the European Union has signed several sustainable fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries. Such agreements aim to provide financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the exclusive economic zone of the partner country. The Republic of Liberia along the Atlantic Ocean has a 570km coastline and an exclusive economic zone that is the habitat of bottom and pelagic fish species, including tuna and tuna-like species.  The EU and the Liberian authorities work intensively together to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Illegal fishing intensified during the civil war years when foreign vessels pumped fish stocks in Liberian waters, resulting in a reduction in potential national income that would have been economic to Liberian fishermen.  Consequently, I support this report, as the conclusion of a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia would, inter alia, help the EU achieve its objectives in the field of combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and to broaden the common fisheries policy objectives in the area of sustainable fisheries management and aquaculture activities.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement is the first to be concluded by the European Union with the Republic of Liberia, which has a 570km coastline along the Atlantic Ocean. Its exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km² is the habitat of adjective and pelagic species of fish, including tuna and tuna-like species. The EU and Liberia cooperate through multilateral agreements and through intergovernmental and regional fisheries organisations. The Liberian authorities work intensively with the EU to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.  This agreement stipulates that EU ships can fish 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year for €3.25 million over five years. The financial contribution shall be divided equally into the amount for access to fishing resources and the amount to support Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy. I support the draft resolution, as I consider the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia to be in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy, sustainable fisheries management and aquaculture activities and of great mutual benefit to both sides. I also believe that it strengthens cooperation between the Union and Liberia and, in general, the Union and West Africa, which are where important tuna fishing zones are located.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol. I support the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Liberia, which, like other agreements with third countries, will provide financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a large number of fish stocks in the Republic of Liberia's exclusive economic zone. In this case, it is 570 kilometres of coastline along the Atlantic Ocean, which is a source of fishing species such as tuna and tuna-like species.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Through this protocol signed with Liberia, the EU is entitled to access liberia's fishing zone, by exchanging a rent, specific quantities that European fisheries will be entitled to fish and support the development of sectoral fisheries policies for the country. Because of the above we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The intended Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol will result in strict control and supervision by the EU monitoring mechanisms of Liberia's exclusive economic zone, which marks a direct EU involvement in a major area of national sovereignty of a third country.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a serious achievement that the EU concludes a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia in West Africa. This is the first agreement of its kind between the two parties. The active protection of stocks of Atlantic tuna and other fish species opens a new chapter in the environmental protection of the country with an exclusive economic zone of 246 152 km2. I am particularly pleased that the European Union is contributing significantly to the reduction of irregular, unreported fishing in Liberian waters and to make liberians aware of the different techniques of sustainable fishing and aquaculture. Hungary, as a country with an expert in freshwater fishing and aquaculture, can play a major role in boosting freshwater fish farming and aquaculture in Liberia. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Ocean fishing is one of the important sources of food for the European Union. It may be carried out both in the territorial waters of the Member States and in the territorial waters of third States. In this respect, the Union shall conclude fisheries partnership agreements with those States which take account of the provisions of the common fisheries policy. At the end of last year, such an agreement was concluded with Liberia, the first such document signed with the country in western Africa. The agreement provides for the EU to allocate a total of EUR 3.25 million over the next five years to grant permission to capture 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year, subject to compliance with European standards of transparency, employment and full compliance with the standards of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) and the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). The agreement will be beneficial for both sides, allowing the Liberian side to develop port infrastructure, combat illegal fishing, develop sustainably the fishing sector and the economy affected by civil war and the Ebola epidemic, and strengthen scientific cooperation between the two parties. In conclusion, I support the adoption of this document.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Indeed, in recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements (APP) and protocols with "third countries". Through the APP, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone (EEZ). Since 2014, with the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, these agreements have been called "partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries". This sustainable fisheries partnership agreement is the first agreement to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia. It is regrettable, however, that the European Parliament plays only a limited role in the adoption of partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries, reduced to a simple approval procedure. The European Parliament should play a more active role and should be immediately and fully informed at the various stages of the APA procedures or their renewal, in order to increase the transparency and democratic accountability of the protocols!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a sustainable fisheries partnership agreement with Liberia, as it will bring both economic and political benefits to Liberia and the EU. In fact, this agreement will allow the EU to fish in the Liberian fishing zone, which is particularly important for the EU tuna fishing sector. In return, the EU provides financial and technical support to the Liberian fishing sector, which will benefit the local economy and the coastal communities. This will also be a big step forward in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing, which has grown significantly during the years of civil war, and for spreading the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) objective of a sustainable management of fisheries and aquaculture activities. Finally, this agreement will also be an opportunity to strengthen the political cooperation between the EU, Liberia, and West Africa more generally.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. EU fisheries agreements, the principles of which have recently been clarified by the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, must allow EU vessels to access the surplus of seafood available to a third state. The latter therefore sets a tonnage which is granted to the Europeans and the EU pays it, in exchange, a financial consideration. Europe will also contribute, under this agreement, to aid for the development of Liberia's fisheries sector, through a second financial envelope. In particular, it must enable the eradication of illegal and undeclared fishing on its coasts, by providing funding for port infrastructure and, of course, control. In view of the evidence on the effectiveness of surpluses in the EU fleet and in view of the apparent added value for the Liberian fishing sector, I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The coast of the Republic of Liberia along the Atlantic Ocean is 570 kilometres long and the 246 152 km economic zone is the habitat of demersal and pelagic fish species, including tuna and tuna-like species. I believe that the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of fishing resources in the Fishing Zone of Liberia. This is the first agreement the European Union will conclude with the Republic of Liberia, strengthening cooperation between the Union and Liberia and, in general, the Union and West Africa, which contain important tuna fishing zones. I believe that the conclusion of a Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia will help the European Union achieve its objectives of combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, but also broaden the common fisheries policy objectives for sustainable fisheries management and aquaculture activities.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol. The EU has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries in recent years.  Under these agreements, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a large number of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. The new EU-Liberia agreement deals only with tuna. EU vessels can catch 6,500 tonnes of tuna per year for a total of EUR 3.25 million over the next five years.  The amount of the financial contribution shall be equally divided between access to fisheries resources and support for Liberia's sectoral fisheries policy. Other elements of the reform are also included, such as the exclusivity clause and the human rights clause, as well as the principle that no other remote maritime country can have more favourable terms than the EU.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Liberia in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The aim of the agreement is to allow fishing vessels from EU member countries to access Liberian waters. This agreement was signed on 5 June 2015 for a period of 5 years. The agreement establishes a joint commission to monitor its results and implementation. This is the first fisheries agreement with Liberia. It concerns 28 seiner tuna (16 Spanish and 12 French) and 6 surface longliners (Spanish). This agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Liberia does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. I voted FOR.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Liberia in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement, the first to be signed between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia, because it will help strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance, and contribute to improved governance of the fisheries in the region.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – It strengthens the Union's cooperation with Liberia and, more generally, West Africa, which has important tuna fishing zones.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about the first collaboration agreement to be signed between the EU and Liberia, which helps to improve relations in this area in West Africa, where important tuna fishing areas are located. Through the agreement, the parties are committed to developing a sustainable and responsible fisheries policy, which will help improve the local economy in the area. We are therefore talking about an agreement which will benefit both sides so I think it is appropriate to vote in their favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this very first fisheries agreement between Liberia and our European Union. This agreement will, among other things, strengthen cooperation between the two partners in the field of fisheries and contribute to the fight against illegal fishing. It also provides for the further development of the fisheries sector in Liberia and better cooperation at the scientific level. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to the recovery of Liberia after extremely difficult years of conflict and civil war.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a new legislative resolution establishing a new Protocol of Fisheries Partnership Agreement (APP) between the European Community, of the one part, and the Republic of Liberia, on the other. The aforementioned APP provides for access of EU vessels to liberia's exclusive area, on the basis of the best available scientific advice and respecting the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), where applicable, within the limits of the available surplus. The Protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 715 000 for the first year, EUR 650 000 for the second, third and fourth years and EUR 585 000 for the fifth year. It is noteworthy that the capacity development component of Liberia's autonomy is superior to that of the previous protocol, which deserves support. The establishment of this agreement can be a form of cooperation with mutual benefits and is therefore supported by its continuation.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU-Liberia Partnership Agreement for Sustainable Fisheries. The main objective of this agreement is to provide fishing opportunities for European vessels in Liberia's fishing zone and to increase cooperation in the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated (INTA) fishing. In fact, the agreement will help Liberia to improve its fisheries monitoring operations and to promote the development of the entire sector. In addition, the agreement will contribute to the economic recovery and political stabilisation of the country, which has been weakened by years of civil war. Finally, the partnership is in line with the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) by ensuring that fishing activities in Liberian waters are conducted in accordance with the principles of sustainability, transparency, non-discrimination and human rights.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I abstained from voting on the European Parliament recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Partnership Agreement on Sustainable Fisheries between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementing protocol. In principle, I believe that the regulation of fisheries should be in the hands of the Member States.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I approved this agreement by giving my vote in favour. The EU and Liberia have been linked and cooperating under the UNCLOS and ICTAT conventions for decades. The resolution concerns only tuna fishing, mainly palms, yellowfin tuna and bigeye tuna, fished by EU fleets in the maritime area concerned. EU vessels can fish for 6,500 tonnes of tuna a year for a total of EUR 3.25 million over five years. The report notes, inter alia, that Liberia fulfils the FAO's requirements for responsible fishing.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and its implementation protocol. I agree with the rapporteur's statements that the Agreement strengthens cooperation between the Union and Liberia and promotes a partnership framework in which a sustainable fisheries policy can be developed and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Liberian fishing zone.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent The first fisheries agreement with Mauritania was concluded in general in 1989, and since then several subsequent agreements have been taken up. The primary objective of the new agreement will thus be to resolve existing problems, to continue quality cooperation, etc. It is regrettable that Mauritania has objected to landing the canary island at the port of Las Palmas, forcing our fleet to carry out all landings at the port of Nouadhibou on its territory. And while the logic of such a decision is understandable in principle, I share the rapporteur's position that the Commission should address this problem at the meetings of the Joint Committee. And since the infrastructure needed to be sufficiently developed in Mauritania itself at the moment, the need to land in the port of Nouadhibou would be rather illogical. And more than that, better conditions are also provided in The Ports of Gran Canaria. But I support it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is invited to give its recommendation to approve or reject the EU-Mauritania fisheries agreement. The Fisheries Partnership Agreement allows European vessels to fish in That country's waters for a further four years. The agreement covers a quota of almost 300 000 tonnes. The EU-Mauritania's financial contribution has substantially decreased and part of the contribution is earmarked for the sustainable development of the area. Conditions have improved significantly since the last agreement, so I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Agreement which will allow EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters. The Protocol, which has been provisionally implemented since 16 November 2015, provides for fishing opportunities for crustacean vessels, except lobster and crab; non-freezer trawlers and bottom longliners dedicated to black hake; demersal fishing vessels; tuna seers; tuna pipers and longliners; pelagic fishing freezer trawlers, and fresh pelagic fishing vessels. The highest weight category is pelagic freezer trawlers, for which a quota of 247,000 tonnes is expected, out of a total of 281,500 tonnes fixed for the entire fleet. This new protocol is a major step forward from the previous one and Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and access preference for the European fleet. However, I expressed in my speech the need to include the Galician cephalopod fleet as soon as the scientific data support the sustainability of stocks.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it goes beyond certain lines of international law which must be taken into account when justifying the fishing of other territories. There is a more than clear risk that territorial provisions will be violated with respect to the occupied territories of Western Sahara which as a nation should be represented in the negotiations on the exploitation of its natural resources. Such agreements include environmental and social provisions, so they are a preferable situation to unregulated exploitation. However, the fact that such treaties are treated in conflicting territories or with occupying forces, in accordance with international law, implies that the right of peoples to decide on their own resources is not being respected. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement to renew a partnership between the European Union and Mauritania in the fisheries sector, which is one of the largest fisheries agreements signed by the European Union.  This agreement will notably allow the movement of EU fishing vessels on Mauritanian waters, with a financial consideration that includes the support of the sectoral policy, to the tune of 4,125,000 euros per year. Even if, despite Parliament's request, the agreement excludes the cephalopods (the octopus) that Mauritania has granted to China (which poses a problem of monitoring Mauritanian waters by the European Union, as some Chinese vessels are suspected of illegal fishing), I support this agreement beneficial to both the Union and Mauritania, which does not have the means to combat illegal fishing , a fight that would be facilitated if vessels from third countries were not allowed to fish in the same waters.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This was a vote on a protocol for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. The money under this agreement to be allocated to the local fisheries sector is the bare minimum showing that the main aim in this agreement is to grant access to large external fisheries operators at the expense of the developing country in question. For this reason, I voted against this report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement which will allow European vessels to fish for shrimp, wild fish, tuna and small pelagic fish in Mauritania's exclusive economic zone. In return, the EU will pay Mauritania 59.125 million euros per year.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement: fishing opportunities and financial compensation, which refers to Mauritania, which is one of the poorest countries in the world, with 42% of its population living below the poverty line. EU support in the field of fisheries policy concerns support for scientific and technical cooperation, training, fisheries monitoring, environmental protection and infrastructure development.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to renew the access of European Union fishing vessels to Mauritanian waters.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement between the European Union and Mauritania on fisheries suffers from the same problems as many other such arrangements. It is exploitative and elitist at the expense of ordinary people in Liberia. Consequently, I voted against. I further note that the report itself acknowledges many of the shortcomings of the policy.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. This text aims to promote the development of local communities and to combat illegal fishing, a top priority of the European Union. In addition, this agreement with Mauritania improves both cooperation with local communities and support from the European fishing sector. The two texts also aim to promote the development of local communities and to combat illegal, undeclared and unreged fishing, a major priority of the European Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. Its aim is to adopt a new four-year EU-Mauritania fisheries protocol, which will enable EU vessels, including Lithuania, to fish for crustaceans, tuna or pelagic fish in Mauritanian waters. In its stretches, the EU has committed EUR 59 million to Mauritania each year. support and help the country's fishing sector. July 2015 The Protocol signed enables spanish, Italian, Portuguese, French, German, Latvian, Lithuanian, Netherlands, Polish, United Kingdom and Ireland vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters. The EU will be able to catch 247 500 tonnes of pelagic fish each year, of which 58 000 tonnes of them are affected. tonne quota allocated to Lithuanian vessels.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This agreement aims to allow EU fishing vessels access to Mauritanian waters for a period of 4 years: it is one of the largest fisheries agreements signed by the EU.  It should be noted that the total allowable catch increased from 300,000 tonnes in the previous agreement (which expired in December 2014) to 281,000 tonnes.  However, the agreement excludes cephalopods (mainly octopus) that Mauritania has reserved for China, which poses problems of monitoring Mauritanian waters for the EU, with some Chinese vessels suspected of illegal fishing. However, this agreement is beneficial for both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. So I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. At the end of a long period of negotiation, the European Union and Mauritania signed a new protocol on 10 July 2015 that will allow EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. In return, the EU will make a financial contribution to promote sustainable fisheries management on Mauritanian coasts. I approved this agreement.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Mauritania, a point of contact between black Africa and the Maghreb world, is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world. Its weak economy is based on the very low presence of land for agricultural use, mostly on the banks of the Senegal River, mining and fishing. Mauritania's waters are among the most fishy on the planet and although the fisheries sector represents about 10% of the country's GDP, it still appears to be under-exploited. From 1989 until 2014, the European Union and Mauritania concluded several fisheries agreements which were replaced, in 2015, by the new agreement already provisionally applied. I supported the Mato report on the EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership because I agree with its content. Thanks to it, in exchange for a financial contribution for access rights and support for the promotion of sustainable fishing, European vessels will have access for four years to the country's exclusive economic zone, being able to exploit the country's fish stocks, in particular shrimps, tuna, demersal and pelagic fish.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries.  There are timely improvements for Mauritania in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement should allow EU fishing vessels to enter Mauritanian waters. A four-year agreement was reached on 10 July 2015 with Mauritania, one of the largest fisheries agreements signed by the European Union. Mauritania will in fact receive 59,125,000 euros per year (including 4.1 million euros for sector policy) for a total of 281,500 tons in catch compared to 300,000 tons previously.  Unfortunately, the agreement excludes cephalopods (octopus) because Mauritania has granted them to China, and this may pose problems of monitoring Mauritanian waters by the European Union, as some Chinese vessels are suspected of illegal fishing. Nevertheless, the agreement is beneficial to both parties, so I voted in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Mato report on the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement is well structured and does not contain any problematic passages. I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the report. Like the previous fisheries agreement with Mauritania, some problems still remain, such as transparency, corruption and lack of consultation with stakeholders. Overfishing is a major problem, especially by foreign boats and the risk is that the agreement does not contribute to sustainable fishing despite its intention. Both labour law and the environment must be taken into account, and in this case the report does not meet the requirements. That is why I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The adoption of international fisheries agreements is good news. They are a key element for the sector in many Member States. However, they have been experiencing serious difficulties, as in the case of Mauritania, the union's most important fishing ground, which has been unable to access since August 2012. This particularly affects my region, Galicia. Similarly, the economic interest and use of the Community ports of La Luz and Las Palmas, where discharges continue to be refused, is affected. For this reason, I abstained.  It is vital for the future of the sector to renew outstanding fisheries agreements and find new alternatives in other waters; of course, in line with the sustainability of the activity within the framework of the principles of the reformed common fisheries policy and its external dimension.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation because, under the first fisheries agreement of 1989 with Mauritania and the various agreements concluded since then, EU vessels have been able to fish in the waters of that country. The current Partnership Agreement entered into force in 2006, extended for two years until the end of 2014.  Following lengthy negotiations, the European Union and Mauritania signed a new protocol on 10 July 2015 allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for four years. The European Parliament considers that the new protocol is much more advanced than the previous protocol, and mauritania's new commitment to transparency and priority access to the EU fleet is welcome in the light of the recent experience of previous years, when Mauritania allowed foreign fleets to fish with cephalopods and prevented the EU fleet from. Since the previous agreement did not include the cephalopod category, there have been very significant changes in the EU fleet and even the dismantling of vessels, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to monitor very closely the state of cephalopod stocks, as well as to strictly respect the priority given to the EU fleet to fish for surplus fish in that country. A positive factor is that the financial contribution is more balanced in view of the fishing opportunities granted. This basically ensures a better cost-benefit ratio of the agreement with Mauritania, which is also facilitated by technical changes.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft resolution on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Mauritania in the fisheries sector on fishing opportunities and financial contributions. After lengthy negotiations, the EU and Mauritania have reached an agreement for a period of four years. The agreement will allow European fishing vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters.  It is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world, where as many as 42% of its population lives below the poverty line. The fisheries sector is very poorly developed in Mauritania, but nevertheless represents 5-10% of its gross domestic product, so there is still a lot of potential for efficiency. I am convinced that the conclusion of this agreement will also contribute to this, as it represents a major step forward, both in the sustainable development of fisheries and in financial subsidies to the country. In addition to its financial obligations, the agreement also provides for the employment of 60% of locals on European fishing boats fishing for prawns and a deep catch trawl.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement between the European Union and Mauritania dates back to 1989 and was followed by a number of others, allowing the EU access to the country's fish stocks. The new protocol, which has been provisionally applied since last November, extends fishing opportunities in Mauritanian waters and the country's exclusive zone for a further four years and opens up new opportunities for European vessels. It also represents a considerable step forward compared with the previous agreement, which fills many gaps both in terms of guarantees of non-discrimination and preferential access for the European fleet and in terms of greater transparency, which Mauritania undertakes to ensure by making public all the agreements signed in this field with third countries. I am therefore in favour of approving this new, more balanced and transparent protocol, which also gives greater importance to environmental sustainability and the socio-economic dimension linked to the agreement, providing, for example, for the obligation to recruit a substantial proportion of the crews among Mauritanian fishermen, for the benefit of local employment.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement, which is much better than the previous one, especially from the specter of bitter experiences of the near past when Mauritania opened access to foreign fleets at the same time as it closed access to European fleets. The duration of the four-year agreement will also provide greater stability for fishing fleets in Mauritanian waters.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report provides for the possibility for EU fishing vessels to fish in Mauritania's territorial waters under a well-defined quota over four very advantageous years (281,500 tonnes) and with a financial consideration of EUR 59,125,000 per year, of which EUR 4,125,000 will be spent on policy and the fight against illegal fishing , which Mauritania cannot carry out on its own. For all these reasons and despite the presence of Chinese boats that are difficult to control in the area, I voted for this report.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This was a vote on a protocol for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. The money under this agreement to be allocated to the local fisheries sector is the bare minimum showing that the main aim in this agreement is to grant access to large external fisheries operators at the expense of the developing country in question. For this reason, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement represents an important step forward both for European fleets, whose access to Mauritanian fish resources is regulated more clearly and more favourably than previously provided for, and for local fishermen who are guaranteed a share of the fisheries that will enable them to live and develop in the future.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This agreement should allow EUROPEAN Fishing Vessels to access Mauritanian waters. In return for an annual financial contribution of EUR 59.125 million, European vessels will be able to fish up to 281,500 tonnes. It should be noted that this agreement excludes cephalopods from the fishery that Mauritania had already granted to China.  I voted for this agreement which is advantageous for both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to fight illegal fishing.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 1989 there have been a number of fisheries agreements with Mauritania, which have allowed European vessels to fish in the areas of that country. This new agreement comes with a number of improvements, which eliminate the gaps in the previous protocol. Thus, a number of fishing areas for the fleet were helped, including those targeting seafood, which increased fishing opportunities. The new Protocol also sought to clarify the methodology for applying the rule obliging European vessels to donate 2% of catches of pelagic species to disadvantaged persons. Moreover, there is a focus on increasing transparency, so Mauritania has committed itself to publishing all public and private contracts with third countries. I was in favour of this partnership agreement because I believe that Mauritania's new commitments lay the foundations for strengthening a partnership based on transparency, mutual trust and non-discrimination of the European fleet against other foreign fleets.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 10 July 2015, the European Union and Mauritania signed a new protocol, which will allow EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. The Protocol has already been provisionally applied since 16 November 2015. The financial compensation that the European Union will pay annually to Mauritania to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing zone amounts to EUR 55 million, as against eur 67 million under the previous protocol. In addition, a financial contribution of 16.5 million for the total period of the agreement (4.125 million per year, as against 3 million in the previous protocol) is intended to stimulate the sustainable development of the fisheries sector; the agreement would provide for equal treatment of EU fleets (sometimes penalised in the past compared to those of other states). Mauritania is a fishing zone of medium interest to Italian vessels, although it too is penalised by EU technical standards (which are then extended to its APPS agreements with third countries). Vote.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the sustainable fisheries agreement between Mauritania and the European Union. The agreement was signed after lengthy negotiations between the European Commission and Mauritania. The result is a balanced agreement that maintains the benefits of this agreement for European vessels and supports the development of local fishing in Mauritania in accordance with the surplus principle.  This agreement is very cost-effective: 98 vessels are fishing under this agreement, but fishing opportunities are reduced to the necessary quantities. Priority is given to the European fleet in case a surplus of certain species is identified.  This agreement allows for the establishment of a framework for the regular exchange of information on fishing capacities and fishing activities taking place in Mauritanian waters, both by domestic fleets and by external fleets or fleets fishing under Mauritanian flags depending on external economic interests. This provision allows for greater transparency of any fishing activity taking place in Mauritanian waters.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the new fisheries agreement with Mauritania. Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and preferential access for the European fleet are positive, especially when it relates to the bitter experience of previous years, when Mauritania opened up cephalopod fishing in its waters to foreign fleets while denying access to European fleets. The agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for the agreements that the European Union will now sign with other third countries. I therefore encourage the Commission to follow the same path of transparency for the other bilateral negotiations as well. The increased support offered to mauritanian local fisheries also demonstrates the European Union's strong commitment to the development of the fleets of the countries with which it has concluded agreements, as well as the EU's desire to export the environmental, economic and social sustainability model promoted under its fisheries policy.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a vote on a protocol for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. The money under this agreement to be allocated to the local fisheries sector is the bare minimum showing that the main aim in this agreement is to grant access to large external fisheries operators at the expense of the developing country in question. For this reason, I voted against the protocol.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol to the EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement. It will allow EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a further four years. The protocol also introduces improvements to the previous agreement such as priority access for the European fleet, better cost/benefit ratio and greater stability and transparency.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, which allows European vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters. In order to allow European vessels access to Mauritania's exclusive fishing zone, the European Union will pay Mauritania EUR 55 million annually, as against EUR 67 million under the previous protocol. In addition, a financial contribution of EUR 16.5 million for the total period of the agreement is intended to stimulate the sustainable development of the fisheries sector, as well as the protection of the environment, marine protected areas and coastal areas.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and agree with the rapporteur's position. The new protocol is an important step forward compared to the previous one and the new obligations undertaken by Mauritania with regard to transparency and preferential access for the European fleet are welcomed, bearing in mind the poor experience of previous years, in which Mauritania has made it possible to fish for cephalopods by foreign fleets while denying access to the European fleet.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement on fishing opportunities and financial contribution is an attempt to intensify fisheries cooperation between the EU and Mauritania, which will have positive results for both sides. The additional opportunities given to European fishermen to develop their activities, together with the important economic and labour rewards that Mauritania will receive, are a positive step forward and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, again on fisheries, because, like the previous one, it introduces a partnership agreement and in this particular case with Mauritania. I voted in favour because, when I looked at the report before me, I was able to see how this protection not only the economic resource that fishing represents but also how it presents itself as an important commercial engine in the environmentally friendly use of this resource. In addition, and this is very important, this report takes care to protect people in need in the territory by devoting part of the proceeds of the resource to them, in order to respond effectively to the serious food safety problem in Mauritania.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The first fisheries agreement with Mauritania dates from 1989, and a series of agreements have been signed since then enabling European vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters. The current Partnership Agreement came into force in 2006 and was renewed for a period of two years in 2012, expiring at the end of 2014. After lengthy negotiations, the European Union and Mauritania initialled a new protocol on 10 July 2015 that will enable EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the new agreement signed with Mauritania, which represents a shared interest and in particular an opportunity for Mauritania to develop its economy focused largely on fisheries. The agreement promotes considerable progress on the commitments made by the Mauritanian State to ensure greater transparency and preferential access for the European fleet in national waters. The agreement also has an exemplary function, paving the way for the signing of agreements between the European Union and other third countries. I therefore voted in favour of the partnership signed, a necessary instrument for the development of sustainable fisheries and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Mauritania.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The current Partnership Agreement came into force in 2006 and was renewed for a period of two years in 2012, expiring at the end of 2014. The Council’s decision to conclude a protocol for a period of four years will ensure that there will be better use of quotas and is designed to strengthen mutual trust and non-discrimination for the European vessels.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament is called upon to vote on the approval of the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Mauritania. The aim of the agreement is to provide European Union vessels with fishing opportunities in Mauritanian waters, taking into account the available scientific assessments and in particular those made by the Central and Eastern Atlantic Fisheries Committee (COPACE), in compliance with the scientific advice and recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) and within the limits of the surplus available. The aim is also to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania with a view to establishing a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the fishing zone of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, in the interests of both parties. The agreement also provides for a reduction in the financial contract to be paid annually by the EU to Mauritania in relation to the previous protocol, which will amount to EUR 55 million instead of EUR 67 million. It is very important that the EU respects its obligation to promote environmentally and socially sustainable fishing in developing countries, which is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, because it goes beyond certain lines of international law which must be taken into account when justifying the fishing of other territories. There is a more than clear risk that territorial provisions will be violated with respect to the occupied territories of Western Sahara which as a nation should be represented in the negotiations on the exploitation of its natural resources. Such agreements include environmental and social provisions, so they are a preferable situation to unregulated exploitation. However, the fact that such treaties are treated in conflicting territories or with occupying forces, in accordance with international law, implies that the right of peoples to decide on their own resources is not being respected. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 European vessels have been fishing in Mauritanian waters since 1989. The agreement with this country is an example of agreements concluded by the European Union with other third countries. I voted to increase the duration of the protocol to four years. This will lead to greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritania.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement was concluded with Mauritania in 1989, and since then a number of successive agreements have allowed European vessels to operate in the waters of that country. The current Partnership Agreement entered into force in 2006 and was renewed in 2012 for a two-year period until the end of 2014.  After lengthy negotiations, the European Union and Mauritania on 10 July 2015 corked a new protocol allowing EU fishing vessels to fish in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years. The Protocol shall apply provisionally from 16 November 2015. The new agreement rectifys some of the shortcomings of the previous Protocol and represents a significant step forward compared to the previous one, and the new commitments of Mauritania on transparency and priority access for the European fleet are to be welcomed. Today's adopted report, which I supported, underlines that the agreement with Mauritania should serve as a model for future agreements to be signed by the European Union with third countries, and therefore encourages the Commission to take the same transparency approach in all bilateral negotiations.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania launched a new 4-year protocol in 2015 that allows EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for around 300 000 tonnes per year of shrimp, bottom fish, tuna and small pelagic fish. In line with the EU's fisheries policy, the Protocol will contribute to responsible fishing and the sustainable management of fisheries resources, including greater transparency. It aims to minimise the impact of fisheries on marine ecosystems and to preserve Mauritanian small-scale coastal fishing. Taking all these aspects into account, I voted 'yes'.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative report focuses on the EU's new protocol, which will allow European fishermen to exploit fisheries resources in Mauritanian waters for four years. In return, the EU commits to pay 55 million euros per year (compared to 67 under the old protocol) to ensure the stability of Mauritania's fishing sector.  According to the rapporteur, this protocol is a great step forward from the previous one and encourages the European Commission to continue its bilateral negotiations in a transparent manner. For the author, this partnership should serve as an example for the EU's future agreements with third countries. Considering that this agreement will promote the European Union's cooperation with Mauritania on fisheries, I supported this report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The fisheries agreement between the European Union and Mauritania ensures a balance between access to surpluses off the Mauritanian coast for European fishermen and the protection of the marine environment and stock renewal. This compromise is in line with the CFP's new objectives for more sustainable fisheries and more responsible management of the sea's resources. The renewal of the 2014 agreement, which expired, will allow European fleets to catch various species of fish and shellfish in exchange for the payment of a consideration to Mauritania of 70 million euros per year, of which 3 million will be allocated for the development of local fisheries. This financial contribution will also contribute to the establishment of a Mauritanian fleet so that, when the protocol expires in two years, it can fully exercise its sovereignty and exploit the resources of its territorial waters.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Mauritania, fishing vessels from EU Member States can fish 281 500 tonnes per year off the Mauritanian coast, 12 500 tonnes less than the agreement that is now expiring. This significant reduction is justified as some fish stocks have been too low and therefore time should be allowed to strengthen them. Not only the current fisheries partnership agreements, but also other fisheries partnership agreements show the tendency of the European Union to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Europe's supply is therefore steadily and significantly reduced by the amount of marine fished. Therefore, the EU should pay more attention to freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. It is important that freshwater aquaculture is brought to the fore and receives as much EU support as possible. The budget for the common fisheries policy after 2020 will have to be reformed in line with this line. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted for a renewal of the fisheries agreement with Mauritania. The EU has concluded fisheries agreements with Mauritania since 1989, a key sector for Mauritania but also important in the framework of the "blue growth" promised by the EU, namely a policy of sustainable growth in the maritime sector.  Over the next four years, this agreement provides fishing quotas of around 280,000 tonnes to the European fleet, offset by an annual fee of 60 million euros, of which just over 4 million will be directly allocated to the development and protection of Mauritania's fishing sector. I would like to point out that quotas have been reduced compared to the previous agreement in the interests of preserving the environment.  In addition, the agreement ensures a real economic and development partnership with Mauritania, since 60% of the workforce employed on board will be Mauritanians.
