Finally, it seems important to highlight Mauritania's efforts towards transparency and has committed to publishing all similar agreements it would make with third countries.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text aims to allow european fishing vessels to access Mauritanian waters. A new agreement was reached on 10 July 2015 for a period of 4 years. The previous one had expired in December 2014.  This fisheries agreement is one of the most important signed by the European Union in this regard. The annual financial consideration is 59,125,000 euros per year, based on an eligible catch total of 281,500 tonnes and includes support from the sector policy, to the tune of 4,125,000 euros per year.  The agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. So I voted for this text.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation as well as with the conclusion of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, (a) granting the European fleet preferential access to Mauritania's surpluses and (b) reducing the annual financial contribution to be paid by the EU to it in order to allow European vessels access to the exclusive zone; fishing.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Mauritania, fishing vessels from EU Member States can fish 281 500 tonnes per year off the Mauritanian coast, 12 500 tonnes less than the agreement that is now expiring. This significant reduction is justified as some fish stocks have been too low and therefore time should be allowed to strengthen them. Not only the current fisheries partnership agreements, but also other fisheries partnership agreements show the tendency of the European Union to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Europe's supply is therefore steadily and significantly reduced by the amount of marine fished. Therefore, the EU should pay more attention to freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, I fight to bring freshwater aquaculture to the fore and to receive as much EU support as possible. The budget for the common fisheries policy after 2020 will have to be reformed in line with this line. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Access of Portuguese and other Union countries to Mauritanian waters is for a period of four years. This is the most important fishing protocol currently signed by the EU with a third country, with a financial contribution of EUR 59.125 million per year: EUR 55 million to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing area and EUR 4.125 million to foster sustainable development of the fisheries sector and the protection of the environment and marine protected areas and Mauritanian coastal areas. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: agreement advantageous for both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to fight illegal fishing.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement signed between the EU and Mauritania will allow Eu ropean Union vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years, for a total of 281,500 tonnes per year of different types of tuna and related species. I voted in favour of the new protocol because I consider it to be a favourable goal for the EU, which will contribute to responsible fishing and sustainable management of fisheries resources, including with enhanced transparency measures. The Protocol pays particular attention to reducing the impact of fishing activities on marine ecosystems, respecting the activities of Mauritania's coastal and artisanal fleets

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it provides a more realistic provision of catches.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The last fisheries cooperation agreement between the European Union and Mauritania was signed in 2012 and expired in 2014, so a new protocol is needed to allow European Union fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters in the coming years. The annual financial contribution to be paid by the European Union to Mauritania for allowing European vessels to enter its exclusive fishing zone amounts to EUR 55 million. This is a reduction in the contribution of EUR 12 million, which is due to the smaller amount of allowable fishing for European fishermen.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the agreement which in some way helps European fisheries.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation as with the conclusion of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, (a) granting the European fleet preferential access to Mauritania's surpluses and (B) reducing the annual financial contribution to be paid by the EU to it in order to allow European vessels access to the exclusive zone; fishing.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Mauritania is one of the poorest, least developed countries in the world, ranking 161 out of 187 on the Human Development Index 2014. 42% of the population is living below the poverty line (USAID). The economy remains weak. The economy is therefore centred on mining activity and fisheries. Support for the development of the sectorial fisheries policy of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania amounts to EUR 4 125 000 per year. This support meets the aims of national fishing policy and in particular the needs of Mauritania as regards supporting scientific and technical cooperation, training, fisheries monitoring, protecting the environment and development infrastructure. The increase in support for the local Mauritanian fishing sector demonstrates the European Union’s resolve to bolster the development of the fleets in countries with which it has signed agreements, and its desire to export the model of environmental, economic and social sustainability that it advocates in its fisheries policy. Some 30% of the population (42.9% of youths) remain unemployed. The protocol’s requirement to hire Mauritanian fishermen (60% of the crew for shrimp vessels and pelagic trawlers) is therefore welcomed. I welcome this agreement and protocol.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. Similarly, the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement strengthens fisheries cooperation with third countries. Through agreements with third countries, the EU provides financial and technical support for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries. I therefore support the call for the signature on behalf of the Union of the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and a financial contribution to Mauritania for a period of four years.  In agreement with the reporter, it should be noted that the new Protocol represents a significant step up from the previous one. In particular, Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and priority access for the European fleet are to be welcomed.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement that the Agreement will be very favourable to both parties. The new Protocol is a major step forward in Mauritania's commitments on transparency and access preference for the fleet. Similarly, the Union's sectoral support will be increased to improve European support for the implementation of the new sectoral strategy on the sustainable development of fishing activities in that country, as well as for improving the living conditions of Mauritanian citizens.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the basis that this new agreement is a substantial improvement from the last fishing agreement with Mauritania. This new agreement will keep the Mauritanian fishing waters open for a quota of EU vessels which is very important and it is better than the last agreement from a cost/benefit perspective. Another important aspect of this agreement is the support that the EU will provide to Mauritania and its fishery sector, including the employment of Mauritanian citizens on EU ships for increased employment and EU support to build an effective and sustainable fisheries sector, a major provider of food to Mauritania.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial compensation provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. The agreement with Mauritania must be an example for future agreements that the Eu ropean Union will sign with other third countries. The country's economy is weak and has to deal with a structural food deficit caused by the desertification of arable land and the scarcity of means of production. Economic activities are focused on fishing, benefiting from some of the richest waters in the world, but there are very few opportunities to develop the economy and not exploited. A strengthening of cooperation between the Union and Mauritania establishes a partnership framework for the development of a policy that makes responsible use of its resources in the fisheries sector.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Technical Council decision on fishing opportunities and financial compensation under the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement. In order to enforce sustainable fisheries policies across borders and to protect maritime biodiversity, clear rules and agreements are needed. These are being hit here.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Mauritania is also an important partner for the EU in fisheries policy. Eu financial aid gives it access to Mauritania's exclusive fishing zone. In return, the sustainable use of stocks and environmental protection in the coastal region will be ensured and promoted. I support the partnerships with third countries under the CFP.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which is balanced and has the approval of all parties, from civil society organisations and business to political groups. This new agreement marks a significant improvement on the previous one, and with no additional EU contribution. Particularly welcome are the commitments made by Mauritania to transparency and priority access for the European fleet.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This agreement allows european union fishing vessels to enter Mauritanian waters. Concluded on 10 July 2015 for a period of four years, it is one of the largest fisheries agreements signed by the European Union. In return, Mauritania will receive 59,125,000 euros per year, based on an eligible catch total of 281,500 tonnes. This financial consideration includes support for the sector policy (support for small-scale fishing, the fight against illegal fishing, surveillance, control) to the tune of 4,125,000 euros per year. In addition, the European Union will monitor Mauritanian waters, as some vessels in third countries are suspected of illegal fishing. This agreement is beneficial to both parties, which is why I voted in favour of its renewal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Mauritania in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it represents a major step forward by comparison with its predecessor. The new commitments given by Mauritania in relation to transparency and priority access for the European fleet are welcome. The agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements signed by the European Union with other third countries.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The new protocol confirms several decades of cooperation in the field of fisheries, a key sector for the development of Mauritania and one of the pillars of the European strategy for blue growth.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Mauritania, fishing vessels from EU Member States can fish 281 500 tonnes per year off the Mauritanian coast, 12 500 tonnes less than the agreement that is now expiring. This significant reduction is justified as some fish stocks have been overly reduced in size and therefore time should be allowed to strengthen them. Not only the current fisheries partnership agreements, but also other fisheries partnership agreements show the tendency of the European Union to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Europe's supply is therefore steadily and significantly reduced by the amount of marine fished. The EU needs to pay more attention to freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. In many cases, it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. The budget for the common fisheries policy after 2020 will have to be reformed in line with this line.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. This new agreement has remedied some of the shortcomings that undermined the usefulness of the previous protocol and represents a major step forward by comparison with the previous one. The new commitments given by Mauritania in relation to transparency and priority access for the European fleet are also welcome.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This is a massive step forward in the fisheries partnership EU-Mauritania. This protocol sees a decrease in the financial contribution from the Union, the cost/benefit ratio has improved greatly with this report. What is more, the financial contribution will be used in the form of support to promote the sustainable development of the fishing sector and also environmental protection in the protected marine and coastal areas. This report offers more transparency from Mauritania which will be a benefit for the European fleet.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the sustainable fisheries agreement between Mauritania and the European Union. This agreement will allow European vessels to fish in Mauritanian territorial waters while supporting the development of local fishing in Mauritania. In the event of a surplus, the European fleet will have priority. This agreement seems to me to be really balanced and that is why I welcome its adoption.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement is in line with the reformed CFP. We welcome the new commitments given by Mauritania in relation to transparency and priority access for the European fleet. I believe that the agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements signed by the European Union with other third countries.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the signature, on behalf of the European Union, the Protocol on the Identification of Fishing Opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years, as it represents an improvement compared to the previous one, and is based on a higher degree of transparency.  The financial contributions paid by the EU to Mauritania allow Union fleets access to the Mauritanian exclusive fishing zone with a solution to some shortcomings that challenged the implementation of the previous agreement. For example, the number of Mauritanian personnel that must be present on European ships has been changed and fleets destined for migratory species have been improved. I believe this has struck a better balance between the Union's financial contribution and fishing opportunities, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This is an agreement that benefits both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. It is true that this fight would be facilitated if vessels from third countries were not allowed to fish in the same waters. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 As with cooperation with Liberia, this is a very useful tool for cooperation and rapprochment between the EU and the African countries. At the same time, it is a means of achieving the long-term objectives of the EU's common fisheries policy, namely responsible use of resources, sustainable fishing and the fight against illegal or overfishing. Both agreements show a positive trend in extending similar Union partnerships to West African countries. Of course, rigorous monitoring of the implementation of agreed measures and adequate use of financial support will be essential to prevent any fraud.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement, which will allow European fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. The annual financial consideration that the EU will pay to the country to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing area amounts to 55 million euros per year. In addition, financial assistance of 16.5 million euros, for the duration of the agreement, to promote the sustainable development of fisheries and the protection of the environment.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. There is nothing to prevent a protocol establishing fishing opportunities and financial compensation under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this balanced agreement, where all sides agree with the outcome – from civil society organisations to companies to politicians. The key part of it was to push the Mauritanian state to be more transparent in terms of its deals with third countries. Although this has been achieved to a certain extent, more work needs to be done.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Mauritania, fishing vessels from EU Member States can fish 281 500 tonnes per year off the Mauritanian coast, 12 500 tonnes less than the agreement that is now expiring. This significant reduction is justified as some fish stocks have been too low and therefore time should be allowed to strengthen them. Not only the current fisheries partnership agreements, but also other fisheries partnership agreements show the tendency of the European Union to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Europe's supply is therefore steadily and significantly reduced by the amount of marine fished. Therefore, the EU should pay more attention to freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, I fight to bring freshwater aquaculture to the fore and to receive as much EU support as possible. The budget for the common fisheries policy after 2020 will have to be reformed in line with this line. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a review of the new Protocol concluded between the European Union and Mauritania concerning the operation of European fishing vessels in Mauritanian waters. The report gives a more realistic picture of the technical specifications of vessels and the management of resources. There is thus a better balance between the Union's financial contribution and fishing opportunities, due to Mauritania's commitments to transparency and preferential access for the European fleet. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement, as it provides for the possibility for EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. In order to adopt this European policy, the EU will have to pay Mauritania an annual contribution of EUR 55 million. For the rapporteur, Gabriel Mato, this agreement is an important step forward, as it is capable of guaranteeing stability for fishing in Mauritanian waters. He also says that this agreement should set an example for future agreements between the EU and third countries. That is why, on the basis of the above considerations, I am voting in favour of the agreement with Mauritania in order to guarantee financial support and to promote the sustainable development of both fisheries and the environment.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Mauritania partnership agreement in the fisheries sector.  This agreement allows access for EUROPEAN Union fishing vessels to Mauritanian waters. The agreement with Mauritania is one of the most important fisheries agreements signed by the European Union. The annual financial consideration is 59,125,000 euros per year, based on an eligible catch total of 281,500 tonnes. The financial consideration includes the support of the sector policy, to the tune of 4,125,000 euros per year. Despite the European Union's request, the agreement excludes cephalopods (the octopus), which Mauritania has granted to China. This poses problems in monitoring Mauritanian waters, as some Chinese vessels are suspected of illegal fishing. The agreement is beneficial to both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this fisheries agreement because it is fair to both parties. It also has the merit of helping Mauritania, which is a reliable partner in the fight against Islamist terrorism.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text aims to renew the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Mauritania. It endorses the four-year consensus signed on 10 July 2015, which benefits the two signatory entities. It is one of the largest fisheries agreements in the EU, which in return grants Mauritania more than 59 million euros a year. It therefore assists him in its development and its fight against illegal fishing.  Although the Mauritanian authorities have granted exclusive fishing for cephalopods (octopus) to China, which poses problems of illegal fishing (some Chinese vessels are suspected of illegal fishing), I think it is a good idea.  So I voted FOR.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement because it offers fishing opportunities in Mauritanian waters to vessels in the European Union taking into account available scientific assessments, in particular those of the Committee on Fisheries for the Central-Eastern Atlantic (CPACO), taking into account scientific opinions and recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna (ICCAT) within the limits of available surpluses. The objective of the agreement is also to intensify cooperation between the European Union and Mauritania in order to establish a collaborative framework to promote the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in that country's fishing area, for the benefit of both Parties.  Sectoral support has increased from the previous period to assist the Islamic Republic of Mauritania in implementing its new sectoral national strategy on sustainable development of fishing activities. The new protocol is a major step forward from the previous one and Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and access preference for the European fleet.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it goes beyond certain lines of international law which must be taken into account when justifying the fishing of other territories. There is a more than clear risk that territorial provisions will be violated with respect to the occupied territories of Western Sahara which as a nation should be represented in the negotiations on the exploitation of its natural resources. Such agreements include environmental and social provisions, so they are a preferable situation to unregulated exploitation. However, the fact that such treaties are treated in conflicting territories or with occupying forces, in accordance with international law, implies that the right of peoples to decide on their own resources is not being respected. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This agreement is a major step forward from the previous one, with new commitments to Mauritania that improve the European fleet's access to its waters.  It also represents an example of parence in bilateral negotiations and represents greater stability for our fleet. It is the necessary change to achieve a credible protocol to ensure that non-Community fleets will be subject to the same technical conditions in terms of conservation and resource management. The EU will contribute to a greater balance through a financial contribution. I accompany the rapporteur's claims and urge the European Commission to find a solution in the Joint Commission allowing downloads at The Canary Ports, which offer better conditions for catch control than Mauritanian ports. In these terms I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is to pay Mauritania EUR 55 million and an additional EUR 16.5 million per year to limit fishing rights for crustaceans in Mauritanian waters. I do not agree with these neocolonial agreements, which, for the sum for dictatorial governments, take fishing rights away from ordinary people in poor countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Protocol, provisionally applied from 16 November 2015, allows EU fishermen to fish in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years. In order to ensure greater transparency, Mauritania has committed itself to publicly disclosing all public or private agreements with third countries and to providing the European fleet with preferential access to available surpluses. The Aim of the Protocol is to offer fishing opportunities for European Union vessels in Mauritanian waters taking into account available scientific assessments, opinions and recommendations on the limits of the surplus available. A positive element of the new Protocol is to strike a greater balance between financial contribution and fishing opportunities. In this way, together with the amendments to the technical measures, the cost-benefit ratio of the Agreement with Mauritania has significantly improved. Extending the duration of the protocol to four years will ensure greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritania's waters. therefore, I supported this Report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement allows EU fishermen to fish temporarily in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years from 2015. The annual financial contribution that the European Union will pay this country to allow European vessels to enter its exclusive fishing zone will be EUR 55 million per year. Plus eur 16,5 million in financial assistance for the entire duration of the Agreement to promote sustainable development in the fisheries sector and environmental protection in marine and coastal protected areas. In addition to the economic, financial benefits for both sides, the agreement is of stabilising importance for the catching fleets, so the EU supports the enforcement of environmental and social sustainability.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/5/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement. This agreement, signed on 10 July 2015, renews for a period of four years the previous agreement, which expired in December 2014. With a financial contribution from the European Union of EUR 59,125,000 per year, it grants the Latter's vessels access to Mauritanian waters, for an permissible catch total of 281,500 tonnes. The exclusion of cephalopods from the agreement is regrettable, even though the fishing right of this species has been granted to China. Given the suspicion of illegal fishing, this exclusion will not facilitate the monitoring of Mauritanian waters. Apart from this reserve, we support this overall balanced agreement, which is one of the most important signed by the European Union in this sector.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the EU-Mauritanian Fisheries Partnership Agreement: fishing opportunities and financial compensation. The European Union and Mauritania have signed a new protocol, which will allow EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of about four years.  The European Union will pay Mauritania EUR 55 million annually to allow European vessels access to its fishing zone, with a further financial contribution of EUR 16.5 million to stimulate the sustainable development of the fisheries sector.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The renewal of the agreement with Mauritania strengthens an earlier agreement, which is already very beneficial for both. Both sides will be able to meet their domestic demand. In particular, Mauritania, as one of the poorest countries in the world, with a desperate food deficit and enormous food insecurity, absolutely must be best supported. That is why I am pleased that the agreement includes measures to deal with these problems.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The new Protocol signed between the EU and Mauritania in July 2015 has a validity of four years and concerns the right of European vessels to operate in Mauritanian waters. The new protocol provides an annual financial contribution from the EU of 55 million, as opposed to the 67 million of the previous agreement. Similarly, financial support of EUR 16.5 million is provided to promote sustainable development in the fisheries sector and to protect the environment in maritime areas in need of attention. The amount of financial aid has increased considerably since the previous agreement provided for EUR 3 million for the same purpose. I therefore share the rapporteur's opinion that the new protocol appears to have improved in many areas since, inter alia, it promotes the development of the region by maintaining the 60% rate for Mauritanian crew members of European vessels. This helps to give jobs to Mauritanian citizens while reducing the country's unemployment and poverty rate. This is very important, considering that Mauritania is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world with 42% of the population living below the poverty line.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's position that the new agreement is much more advanced than the previous one, and that the new mauritanian commitments will ensure transparency and give the EU fleet better access. Extending the period of validity of the Protocol, which is the most important document currently signed by the European Union with third countries to four years, will ensure greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritanian waters.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this protocol which will give EU fishing vessels priority access to Mauritanian fishing waters. The protocol also considers the sustainability of fish supplies.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The first fishing agreement with Mauritania was concluded in 1989 and since then several successive agreements have allowed European vessels to fish in Mauritania's waters. Mauritania's waters are among the most fishy in the world and, although the fishing sector contributes 10% of its GDP, the country under-exploits this natural resource.  In the proposed agreement, the authorized quota for freezer pelagic fishing trawlers has been reduced and Mauritania has been required to employ Mauritanian sailors on board for at least 60% of the crew in order to combat local unemployment (30%).  In addition, a rule requires European ships to donate 2% of pelagic catches to the poor.  In these conditions, which seem less leonine to me, I cannot oppose such an agreement, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. According to the agreement, the EU is allowed to fish in Mauritanian waters. The report aims to set up a joint commission to monitor the results. This first 4-year fishing agreement has a decreasing cost to our vessels year after year. This agreement benefits both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. That European vessels fish in no-go zones will help ensure that third countries' boats do not come. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement concluded with Mauritania dates back to 1989 and since then a number of agreements have been concluded which have allowed European vessels to fish in mauritania's waters. The fisheries agreement with Mauritania is one of the few EU fisheries agreements allowing access to mixed fisheries.  The new protocol, applied provisionally since 16 November 2015, provides for fishing opportunities for crustacean fishing vessels, with the exception of lobster and crab. Several countries including Portugal are allowed to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. For Portuguese vessels, the protocol provides for fishing opportunities of 250 tons of crustaceans, with the exception of lobster and crab.  The FINANCIAL contribution that the EU will pay to this African country is EUR 59.125 million per year: EUR 55 million to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing area and EUR 4.125 million to foster the sustainable development of the fisheries sector and the protection of the environment and marine protected areas and Mauritanian coastal areas.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this fisheries agreement, as it follows a succession of agreements between the European Union and Mauritania ensuring stability for the fishing industry and guaranteeing more durable conservation and management of resources.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the approval given by the European Parliament to the conclusion of this new fisheries agreement with Mauritania. I particularly welcome the strengthening of the Union's support, through sectoral support, for the sustainable development of fisheries in Mauritania. It is essential to develop the exploitation of this natural resource of which the country is rich.  With Mauritania and its other partners, it is essential that the Union continues to promote the principles of sustainability and responsible management of resources that it applies internally.  I would also like to underline and encourage the provisions of the agreement providing for the commitment of Mauritanian fishermen and the obligation to allocate 2% of the catches of pelagic trawlers to the poor.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The first fisheries agreement was concluded with Mauritania in 1989 and various other conventions allowed European vessels to fish in its waters. On 10 July 2015, Union negotiators initialled a new protocol allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for the next four years. The Protocol, which has been in place on a temporary basis since 16 November 2015, provides for fishing opportunities for crustacean vessels, with the exception of crawfish and crab; trawlers (not freezer) and deep-sea longliners; fishing vessels for deep-sea species; tuna seiners; pole-and-line tuna vessels and longliners; freezer vessels fishing for pelagic species and vessels (not freezer vessels) fishing for pelagic species. However, the quota allocated to the category, which amounted to up to 300 000 tonnes in the previous Protocol, has fallen significantly in order to take account of the rate of fleet utilisation, which directly affects the financial contribution that the European Union will pay to that country. However, despite the fewer fishing opportunities, I expect the fleet to make better use of the shares, thanks to significant changes in the technical conditions imposed by Mauritania, as well as the obligation to employ Mauritanian seamen on board. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal as it stands.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Agreement and Protocol as it is in line with the reformed CFP and ensures that the fishing activities of EU vessels in Mauritanian waters are carried out in respect of the principles of sustainability, good governance, transparency, non-discrimination and respect of human rights. The new protocol represents a major step forward by comparison with the previous one, and the new commitments given by Mauritania in relation to transparency and priority access for the European fleet are welcome, particularly bearing in mind the bitter experience of previous years, when Mauritania opened up to foreign fleets at the same time as it denied access for the European fleet. The agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements signed by the European Union with other third countries. It is the most significant protocol currently signed by the European Union with a third country. The duration has been increased to four years which will ensure greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritanian waters.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Community concluded the first fisheries agreement with Mauritania in 1989. The current Partnership Agreement entered into force in 2006 and was renewed in 2012 for a two-year period until the end of 2014. On 10 July 2015, the Parties corked a new Protocol, which will be applied provisionally from 16 November 2015, allowing EU fishing vessels to fish in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years. In exchange for European vessels' access to Mauritania's exclusive fishing zone, the financial compensation payable by the European Union shall be EUR 55 million per year, supplemented by a financial grant of EUR 16,5 million to be paid during the agreement to encourage the sustainable development of the fisheries sector and the protection of the environment in marine and coastal areas. The Council intends to take a decision to sign the Protocol on behalf of the EU, for which it must obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries stresses that the Protocol represents a significant step forward from the previous one and welcomes Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and priority access for the European fleet, and therefore recommends that Parliament agree with the signing of the Protocol. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this agreement is to allow European Union fishing vessels access to Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. The agreement seems to benefit both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The EU and Mauritania have already had an agreement in the fisheries field since 1989 and since then a number of agreements have been concluded that have allowed European vessels to fish in the waters of that country. The current Partnership Agreement ended at the end of 2014.  After lengthy negotiations on 10 July 2015, the European Union and Mauritania initialled a new Protocol that will allow EU fishermen to work in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years.  I endorse the rapporteur's position on the great progress of this new Protocol in relation to the previous One and mauritania's new commitments on transparency and preference for access to the European fleet. As set out in the report, I am in favour of concluding this Protocol.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This is an agreement that benefits both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. It is true that this fight would be facilitated if vessels from third countries were not allowed to fish in the same waters. So I voted FOR this text.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the social and economic circumstances of Mauritania, fishing practices harmful to the marine ecosystem and the historic presence of European fishing fleets in Mauritanian waters, we are voting in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Mauritania. The agreement will, in fact, guarantee European operators and fishermen the exploitation of an important fish stock while respecting the environment of coastal areas and protected areas, aimed at developing a sustainable and responsible fishing model. The text provides, in fact, for the European Union to pay the Mauritanian Government an annual contribution to measures to support the level of employment and the creation of greater production and processing capacity through infrastructure investments and strategic advice. Fishing is, after the mining sector, the second largest source of earnings for the country, which, in 2014, ranked 161st, out of 187, in the human development index and chronically suffers from a dramatic level of unemployment. To this end, we welcome the condition of the protocol which will require operators to include Mauritanian fishermen in their crews, 60% for shrimp trawlers and pelagic trawlers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Fisheries Partnership Agreements represent an understanding where the EU offers financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights. I have voted for this report that will grant the European Union’s fishing fleets access to Mauritanian waters for a period of four years through the newly installed protocol on 10 July 2015.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The new fisheries agreement between the EU and Mauritania eliminates certain shortcomings of the previous Protocol. With a view to increasing transparency, Mauritania undertakes to publish all public or private contracts with third countries and also to grant preferential access to the EU fleet for its surpluses. The annual financial contribution to be paid by the EU to this country to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing zone is EUR 55 million per year, compared to EUR 67 million in the previous Protocol. Added to this is financial assistance of 16.5 million over the entire duration of the agreement (EUR 4.125 million per year, instead of EUR 3 million under the previous Protocol) to promote the sustainable development of the fisheries sector and protect the environment in marine protected and coastal areas. Sectoral support has thus been increased to improve European assistance for the implementation of the new sectoral strategy on the sustainable development of fishing activities in that country. I voted for the agreement with Mauritania, which should be an example of the agreements concluded by the European Union with other third countries.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because it approves the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, which is a normal step. We have before us an agreement beneficial to both parties, an integral part of the new fisheries agreements between the EU and different third countries. Under this agreement, the EU will pay around EUR 55 million per year for four years for the possibility of fishing 287,500 tonnes of fish that will reach the European market. It is also important to note that EU funds will help Mauritanian fishing industry and support the authorities' fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and the obligation of EU vessels to employ 60% of Mauritanian staff will help local communities and support increased labour specialisation.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This was a vote on a protocol for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. The money under this agreement to be allocated to the local fisheries sector is the bare minimum showing that the main aim in this agreement is to grant access to large external fisheries operators at the expense of the developing country in question. For this reason, I voted against this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. Fishing is a fundamental part of Europe's food supply. The report contains sensible proposals, with which I can only agree.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to give EU vessels fishing opportunities in Mauritanian waters and to contribute to sustainable fisheries policy and more responsible exploitation of fish stocks. In addition, it seeks to alleviate Mauritania's 30 % unemployment with the obligation to employ local populations on EU vessels and to improve the methodology for the transfer of 2 % pelagic for the good of the needy.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of a new four-year EU-Mauritania fishing protocol. It is the most important document currently signed by the European Union with third countries, which ensures the sustainable use of fish, living aquatic resources, adequate protection of the marine environment, the smooth operation of the fleets of EU Member States and adequate consumer provision of quality food.  It should be noted that this Protocol will enable eu vessels, and therefore Lithuania, to fish for crustaceans, tuna or pelagic fish in Mauritanian waters. In addition, greater stability and protection of the interests of the European fishing industry will be ensured.  It should be noted that the EU will allocate EUR 59 million annually to Mauritania. support to the country's fishing sector. A partnership framework will also be established to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and to use fisheries resources responsibly, taking into account the interests of both parties.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On this proposal, I have chosen to vote in favour. In its wording, the new protocol would allow European vessels to fish, with a few exceptions, for crustaceans in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. This protocol revises the eligible fishing quotas, thereby reducing the economic compensation paid by the European Union to Mauritania. Given that the new protocol makes it possible to fill the gaps in the previous text, as well as to improve the fishing conditions of the fleet fishing for migratory species and to guarantee positive fishing conditions for European fleets, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the EU-Mauritania Fisheries Partnership Agreement on fishing opportunities and financial contribution. As we unfortunately know, Mauretania's economy faces economic challenges and focuses mainly on mining and fisheries, with fishing representing 5-10% of annual GDP. Mauritania is among the countries whose territorial waters are rich in fish, but the opportunity to develop an economy through this natural resource is not sufficiently exploited, and a very small amount of catches are landed in Mauritania's ports or processed locally. Taking these facts into account, I believe that this agreement will be mutually beneficial, both to the EU and to Mauritania. In addition to the EUR 55 million that Mauritania will earn through granting access to its fishing zone to the EU fishing fleet, this agreement also provides an additional EUR 16.5 million in the form of financial support to promote the sustainable development of the fisheries and environmental sectors in protected marine and coastal areas of Mauritania, in line with European policies for responsible environmental and nature behaviour and sustainable fisheries development.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I take into account the recommendations and opinions of these committees and give consent for the conclusion of the protocol. Mauritania is one of the poorest and least developed countries in the world and ranks 161st in the 2014 human development index rankings. According to USAID data, 42% of the country's population lives below the poverty line. The new Protocol introduces improvements to the highly migratory fishing fleet, which will allow these vessels to fish under conditions similar to those applied in other third countries, as control measures and access to the Protocol and other tuna fishing agreements are harmonised. Further significant improvements have also been made with a view to explaining the methodology for the application of the rule obliging European vessels to cede two per cent of pelagic catches for the benefit of persons in need. Mauritania undertakes, with a view to ensuring greater transparency, to publicly disclose all public or private agreements with third countries and to provide the European fleet with preferential access to available surpluses. I support the conclusion of this protocol, as I believe it will contribute to the export of the EU model in terms of environmental care, economic and social sustainable development promoted by the EU in its common fisheries policy.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a legislative resolution establishing a new protocol of fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. The APP provides access to EU vessels to a wide variety of fish and other non-fish species in mauritania's exclusive economic zone. The new protocol for the four-year period provides for an annual EU financial contribution of EUR 59.125 million, comprising: - EUR 55 million for access to mauritania's Exclusive Economic Zone; - EUR 4.125 million to support fisheries sectoral sustainability policies in Mauritania. These figures correspond to a reduction in the amounts transferred in the previous Protocol, which were EUR 70 million. However, this reduction reflects changes in most quotas, as well as, it is said, a more realistic forecast of catches. On the other hand, there is an improvement in the value used to strengthen the territorial capacity in Mauritania, its autonomy and the development of its potential in the fisheries sector. We also value the incorporation of a 60 % share of Mauritania's workers in European ships, implicitly with the same rights as Europeans. The signing of the protocol is supported.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission negotiated the renewal of the Protocol on identifying fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Mauritania. I supported Representative Mata's recommendation to sign the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and Mauritania, as this Protocol aims to offer fishing opportunities for EU vessels in Mauritanian waters, taking into account the available scientific assessments. Similarly, this decision aims to strengthen cooperation between the EU and Mauritania in order to establish a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries strategy and responsible use of fishing resources in the Mauritania fishing zone, in the interests of both parties. Sectoral support has been increased compared to the previous period to assist Mauritania in establishing a new national strategy in the area of sustainable development of fishing activities, in particular in the context of scientific and technical cooperation, training, fishing control, environmental protection and development infrastructure.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Council Decision concluding a Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and financial contribution for a period of four years under the Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania on a fisheries partnership. In view of the positive steps taken by Mauritania, which include the acceptance of commitments in the area of transparency and preferential access for the European fleet, as well as for reasons of long-term cooperation, an extension of this Protocol is appropriate. Positive changes include improvements in the fishing opportunities of European fishermen, who, for example, were restricted in cephalopod fishing in the original protocol. At the same time, a better balance has been achieved between the financial settlement and the agreed fishing opportunities. Despite some persistent shortcomings, I consider this agreement to be a possible model for other similar treaties with third countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement with Mauritania dates back to 1989 and, since then, a number of agreements have been signed with the aim of allowing European fishing vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters. Thanks to the new fisheries agreement with Mauritania, Community vessels will be able to fish - for a period of four years - shrimps, demersal fish, tuna and small pelagic fish in Mauritania's exclusive economic zone. In return, the EU will pay Mauritania EUR 59.125 million per year - EUR 55 million for total allowable catches and EUR 4.125 million to stimulate the sustainable development of mauritania's fisheries sector. The resolution on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy (CFP) states that the Community fisheries agreement with Mauritania will serve as a model of transparency and enforcement. I therefore voted in favour and I hope that the transparency provisions of the last protocol with Mauritania, which provides for the publication of all agreements with states or private entities granting foreign vessels access to their exclusive economic zone (EEZ), will be included in all future Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (EEAs).

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreement signed between the European Union and Mauritania, which follows the expiration of the 2012-2014 partnership agreement.  Signed for the next four years, the agreement will allow European vessels to catch shrimp, fish, tuna or small pelagic fish in Mauritania's exclusive economic zone.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The first agreement between the EU and Mauritania in the field of fisheries dates back to 1989 and since then several agreements have been concluded which have enabled European fishing vessels to enter the exclusive economic zone of that country.  This Protocol will extend the activity of EU fishermen in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. The agreement also negotiated a significant advance in Mauritania's commitments to transparency and preference for access to European fleets, thereby underpded by the bitter experience of the past years, during which the activity of European fleets was seconded to the benefit of other foreign fleets.  Noteworthy is also the substantial improvement in the cost-benefit ratio compared to previous agreements, based on a significant decrease of around EUR 12 million in the annual financial contribution.  On the other hand, the legislator adjusted an increase in funds to promote the sustainable development of the fishing sector and environmental protection in Mauritania, in order to promote the environmental sustainability model advocated by the European Union as well as in the areas of fisheries policy.  Because of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We oppose this agreement as Euro-colonial exploitation benefitting the political class at the expense of ordinary Africans.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. This vote validates a new fisheries agreement that regulates access to Mauritanian waters in exchange for compensation of nearly 60 million euros per year.  This agreement improves the precedent, which expired in 2014 and is rarely implemented in practice because of the restrictions imposed. It guarantees the EU fishing conditions similar to those granted to third countries, particularly in terms of royalties. The contribution to Mauritania is reduced from 67 million to 55 million euros per year. The other part of the compensation aimed at promoting the sustainable development of the fishing sector and the protection of maritime areas is increased from three million to just over four million euros per year. A Joint Committee is set up to review the quotas granted to the EU in the event of excess stocks. Imports of fish products (shrimp, tuna, wild fish) soared in 2015 to 45% of Mauritanian imports into the EU.  This agreement is the EU's most important fisheries protocol with a third country and should, for Parliament, serve as an example for future agreements.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The current partnership with Mauritania dates back to 2006, was renewed for two years in 2012 and expired at the end of 2014. The European Union and Mauritania established a new protocol on 10 July 2015 to allow EU vessels there for a period of 4 years. The protocol has been applied provisionally since November 2015. The annual financial contribution to the fishing permit of EU vessels in mauritania's exclusive area is 55 million. To this, 4,125 million are in addition to financial support to promote the sustainable development of the fishing sector and the environmental protection of marinas and coastal areas. It is worth remembering that 42.9% of mauritania's population is unemployed. It's one of the poorest countries in the world.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 The adoption of international fisheries agreements is good news. They are a key element for the sector in many Member States. However, they have been experiencing serious difficulties. In the case of Mauritania, the EU's largest fishing ground, where the European cephalopod fleet has still not been able to access since August 2012. This particularly affects my region, Galicia. The same is affected by the economic interest and use of the Community ports of La Luz and Las Palmas, where discharges continue to be refused. For this reason, I voted against this agreement. The financial counterparty and the status of the stock justify nothing else. It is vital for the future of the sector to renew the outstanding Fisheries Agreements and find new alternatives in other waters. For its part, in accordance with the sustainability of the activity within the framework of the principles of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy and its external dimension.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday gave its assent to the conclusion of the new fisheries agreement between the EU and Mauritania. After a long period of negotiation, the European Union and Mauritania signed a new protocol on 10 July 2015 that will allow EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. The protocol, which has been in effect on an interim basis since then, sets out fishing opportunities for shellfish fishing vessels, non-freezer trawlers, etc. The annual financial consideration that the EU will pay to the country to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing area amounts to 55 million euros per year. In addition, financial assistance of EUR 16.5 million over the duration of the agreement to promote the sustainable development of the fishing sector, as well as environmental protection in protected maritime and coastal areas.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fisheries Agreement is concluded with our important partner, Mauritania.  Neither the form or content of the document calls into question the need to accept it as a measure in the interest of both parties to the contract. Mauritania has large fish stocks for which the European Union has the capacity to absorb. I believe that the funds received by Mauritania will contribute to the modernisation of this country. At the same time, it is only necessary to encourage Member States, both governments and businesses, to make every effort to fully exploit the benefits of this agreement, while limiting their appetites, to catch fish only to the extent that the natural balance will not be undermined

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 After lengthy negotiations, the European Union (EU) and Mauritania signed a new protocol on 10 July last, allowing EU vessels to fish in Mauritania waters for a period of four years (which will give some stability to the European fishing fleet to Mauritania). In return for this Agreement, the EU will contribute €55 million. In addition, EUR 16.5 million will be paid in the form of financial support to promote the sustainable development of the environmental, fisheries and protected areas of the environment. In concluding this agreement with the EU, Mauritania has made new commitments on transparency and priority access for the European fleet, this being an Agreement which should serve as an example for future agreements signed by the EU with third countries. The balance that has been achieved between financial contribution and fishing opportunities is highly positive thanks to substantial cost-benefit improvements.  As I said earlier, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament the approval of the protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial consideration provided for by the eu-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement. The point is to clarify that the new fisheries agreement should address some of the shortcomings of the previous protocol, particularly in terms of transparency and preferential access for the European fleet. I supported this text because it also provides for a better balance in the financial counterparty for the fishing opportunities set, which translates into a more optimal cost-benefit ratio.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report gives a positive opinion to the EU-Mauritania agreement, which regulates relations with mauritania in the fisheries sector. The report welcomes the transparency of the agreement with regard to the definition of commercial and legal relations. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries.  There are timely improvements for Mauritania in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU fisheries agreement with Mauritania. It is balanced and promotes marine protection on the one hand, and it helps to develop coastal areas on the other. It also ensures sustainable management of fish stocks off Mauritania.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against granting approval to the Association Agreement in the fisheries sector between the Union and Mauritania. I oppose such agreements since they reproduce a colonial relationship of exploitation of the least developed countries by the most developed. There are still doubts about the sustainable management of fisheries and the marine environment, the management of the money contributed by the EU for the development of local fisheries. In addition, there are serious indications that fishing opportunities allocated to European Union vessels can adversely affect small local fishermen and fishermen when small pelagic fishing is opened to these vessels.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution approving the new four-year protocol that will allow EU vessels to fish in Mauritanian waters for prawns, demersal fish, tuna and small pelagic fish for a total of 281,500 tonnes per year. The European Union will pay an annual financial contribution of EUR 59.125 million, of which EUR 4.125 million will be used to support the development of Mauritania's sectoral fisheries policy. This is currently the most important economic agreement signed by the European Union with a third country. The new protocol is a good step forward compared with the previous one. Mauritania's new commitments on transparency and preferential access for European vessels will, in fact, allow a significant improvement in the cost-benefit ratio, ensuring a better balance between the financial compensation and the fishing opportunities granted and more stability for the EU fleet fishing in Mauritanian waters. I hope that this agreement will serve as an example for the agreements that the Union will now sign with other third countries and that the Commission will follow the same path of transparency in all bilateral negotiations.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is one of the most important fishing agreements in the European Union. This agreement allows for a great extension of fishing opportunities for eu fleets, it is ensured that only renewable biological marine resources that are not usable by the European Union are used, doors are opened to cooperation with local industry and increase food security in Europe.  I believe that European fleets have a role that goes beyond mere catch of fish. European fleets carry values and attitudes that are not negligible.  It therefore seems particularly important to me that this agreement lasts for four years, thereby enabling stability in operations and the establishment of perennial partnerships between companies and institutions of the European Union and Mauritania.  For all these reasons, I voted positively on this fisheries partnership agreement.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is a balanced agreement, where all sides agree with the outcome as well as civil society organisations who were involved. This is the most significant protocol currently signed by the European Union with a third country. The duration has been increased to four years which will ensure greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritanian waters. This new protocol represents a major step forward by comparison with its predecessor. The new commitments given by Mauritania in relation to transparency and priority access for the European fleet are welcome, particularly when you bear in mind the bitter experience of previous years, when Mauritania opened up to foreign fleets at the same time as it denied access for the European fleet. The agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements signed by the European Union with other third countries.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The new protocol of the EU agreement with the Islamic Republic of Mauritania is a major step forward compared to the previous protocol. Mauritania has taken on new commitments in the area of transparency and priority access for the European fleet. The EU is committed to supporting the development of the fleets of countries with which it has agreements and wants to export its model of environmental, economic and social sustainability, which it promotes in its fisheries policy, which in this case demonstrates by increasing aid for local fisheries in Mauritania. I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the signature, on behalf of the European Union, the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years, as I consider it to be in the interests of both parties. The new agreement addressed some of the shortcomings that harmed the usefulness of the previous protocol: the number of Mauritanian personnel required to be present on European vessels, the non-discrimination of the European fleet in relation to other foreign fleets, the public disclosure of all public or private agreements by Mauritania with third countries, and the provision of preferential access to available surpluses to the European fleet. The agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements between the European Union and other third countries, and the rapporteur therefore encourages the Commission to take a transparency-based approach in all bilateral negotiations. The strengthening of support for local Mauritanian fisheries demonstrates the European Union's determination to help develop the fleets of states with which it has concluded agreements and its desire to export the model of environmental, economic and social sustainability it advocates in its fisheries policy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement with Mauritania dates back to 1989 and, thanks to various other conventions that have since been concluded, European vessels have been able to fish in the waters of that country. In 2006, the current cooperation agreement entered into force, which was renewed in 2012 for two years until the end of 2014. On 10 June 2015, the European Union and Mauritania initialled a new protocol allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for four years. Fishing opportunities shall be fixed on the basis of this Protocol. The annual financial contribution that the EU will pay Mauritania to allow European vessels to enter its exclusive fishing zone amounts to EUR 55 million per year. A very important part of the agreement is also the change that has taken place in determining the number of Mauritanian personnel who must be compulsorily boarded on European ships. Although a 60 % share has been retained, it does not include jobs related to the operation of machinery, which will solve problems relating to the level of qualification of Mauritanian seafarers. The new agreement also contains other significant changes aimed at strengthening mutual trust and non-discrimination between the European fleet and other foreign fleets, which is why I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Since 1989, when the first fisheries agreement with Mauritania was concluded, successive agreements have allowed european vessels to fish in the waters of that country. The protracted negotiations between the EU and Mauritania ended on 10 July 2015 with the initialling of a new protocol allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years.  This Protocol represents a major step forward, as Mauritania has taken on new transparency and priority access obligations for the European fleet, which it has not made possible in the past. Compared to the previous agreement, this time the EU has committed itself to a smaller financial contribution to ensure access to the exclusive fishing zone for European vessels.  At the same time, sectoral support has increased in order to improve European support for the launch of a new sectoral strategy in the field of sustainable development of fishing activities in that country. The protocol also addressed the problem with the level of qualification of Mauritanian seamen to be present on European vessels.  Mauritania has also undertaken to publish all private and public agreements with third countries for reasons of transparency and to give the European fleet priority access to its surpluses. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ On 10 July 2015, the European Union and Mauritania signed a new Protocol allowing fishermen from EU territory to fish in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years. The annual financial contribution to be paid by the EU to Mauritania to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing zone is €55 million, and under the previous protocol this contribution amounted to €67 million.  It is important to highlight the change in the number of Mauritanian personnel that must be present on European vessels. Although this percentage remained at 60%, it no longer includes the staff operating the machines, thus addressing the difficulties associated with finding Mauritanian seafarers with suitable qualifications.  The Protocol also contains some radical amendments aimed at strengthening mutual trust and non-discrimination of the European fleet in relation to other foreign fleets, which should ensure that conservation conditions are imposed on the EU fleet and apply to other foreign fleets.  I support this agreement because, in addition to being a better version of the previous Agreement, I believe it will contribute to EU fisheries and serve as an example for future agreements between the EU and other third countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and Mauritania initialled on 10 July 2015 a new Protocol allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritania's waters for a period of four years. The annual financial contribution to be paid by the European Union to the country to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing zone is €55 million, compared to €67 million under the previous protocol. In particular, the change in the number of Mauritanian personnel required to be present on European vessels is highlighted. Although the percentage remained at 60%, it no longer includes the staff operating the machines, which addressed the difficulties associated with finding Mauritanian seafarers with suitable qualifications. The Protocol also contains some radical amendments designed to strengthen mutual trust and non-discrimination of the European fleet in relation to other foreign fleets, which should ensure that conservation conditions imposed on the EU fleet apply to other foreign fleets. I support this agreement because I think it is a step forward from the previous one. I also believe that the agreement with Mauritania should serve as an example for future agreements between the European Union and other third countries.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for four years.  The new protocol, which will be in force for four years and has already been initialled by the EU and Mauritania, will enable european Union fishermen to continue to fish in Mauritanian waters unmanavened. I welcome the transparency and priority access for the European fleet to which Mauritania has committed, as we have seen in recent years that Mauritania has prioritised foreign fleets for certain fish species, while the European government has given it up.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Protocol signed with Mauritania allows European fishing vessels to enter the country's fishing zone in exchange for a financial contribution, but also the obligation for 60% of fishing workers to be Mauritanian. In view of the exchange that Mauritania will have with regard to its workers and the financial support it will receive, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 With the conclusion of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, the economic exploitation of that country is sought by granting the European fleet preferential access to Mauritania's surpluses and by reducing the annual financial contribution to be paid by the EU to it in order to allow European vessels access to its exclusive fishing zone.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Mauritania, fishing vessels from EU Member States can fish 281 500 tonnes per year off the Mauritanian coast, 12 500 tonnes less than the agreement that is now expiring. This significant reduction is justified as some fish stocks have been too low and therefore time should be allowed to strengthen them.
