Not only the current fisheries partnership agreements, but also other fisheries partnership agreements show the tendency of the European Union to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Europe's supply is therefore steadily and significantly reduced by the amount of marine fished. Therefore, the EU should pay more attention to freshwater fish farming.  A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, I fight to bring freshwater aquaculture to the fore and to receive as much EU support as possible. The budget for the common fisheries policy after 2020 will have to be reformed in line with this line. In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The signing of fisheries partnership agreements between the EU and third countries has become a priority of the common fisheries policy in recent years. These agreements are intended, in addition to increasing the Union's marine food resources, to contribute to the sustainable development of this sector worldwide and to the economic assistance of developing countries. Mauritania is one of the poorest countries in the world, with an alarming unemployment rate (30%), especially among young people (43%), where fishing occupies a significant share of the economy (5-10%). The EU has concluded fisheries agreements with the country since 1989. A new four-year agreement was concluded in July 2015, which provides for access for EU member fishing vessels for catches of cephalopods, crustaceans, tuna and pelagic species, in exchange for the EU's EUR 55 million contribution, plus EUR 16.5 million for the sustainable development of the Mauritanian fisheries sector and environmental protection. The agreement is conditional on compliance with European standards of transparency and the involvement of a majority indigenous workforce (60%), which will lead to the development of the local economy. I therefore support the adoption of this document.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is regrettable that the European Parliament plays only a limited role in the adoption of partnership agreements in the field of sustainable fisheries, reduced to a simple approval procedure. The European Parliament should play a more active role and should be immediately and fully informed at the various stages of the APA procedures or their renewal, in order to increase the transparency and democratic accountability of the protocols. But on the content of the agreement, I voted in favour of the Mato report.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the new protocol renewing the EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement, which grants the EU certain fishing rights in Mauritanian waters in return for financial, technical and environmental support to the Mauritanian fishing economy. The new protocol, which renews the agreement for four years, will be a major step forward in comparison to the previous one, especially regarding transparency and priority access for the European fleet, as well as regarding the obligation of equal access conditions for non-EU fleets.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. EU fisheries agreements, the principles of which have recently been clarified by the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, must allow EU vessels to access the surplus of seafood available to a third state. The latter therefore sets a tonnage which is reserved for Europeans, the EU gives it in exchange a financial consideration. In previous discussions, Mauritania's proposed tonnage on cephalopods had sparked debate and led to the confrontation of various scientific opinions. That was what caused the agreement to fail. Today, the proposed "quotas" seem acceptable to the three parties: Europe, Mauritania and scientists.  The EU will also contribute, under this agreement, to aid for the development of Mauritania's fishing sector, through a second financial envelope. In particular, it must enable the fight against illegal and undeclared fishing, by enabling the financing of port infrastructure and control. So I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that the same principles and rules should apply in partnership agreements with third countries as apply to fleets in European waters. Equity and sustainability must also be translated into adequate support for local fisheries for sustainable development. I very much welcome the work done by the Commission to include the issue of human rights and the mutual responsibilities of Europe and third countries. The contributions made by the European Union in exchange for fishing rights really do reach the local populations.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years. This Protocol contains amendments aimed at strengthening mutual trust and non-discrimination of the European fleet in relation to other foreign fleets. I would highlight Mauritania's commitments to transparency and preferential access for the European fleet, given the experience of previous years when Mauritania allowed foreign fleets to fish for cephalopods in their waters, while at the same time defending access to the European fleet. In my view, changes to technical measures and a greater balance between financial contribution and fishing opportunities are another positive element that will significantly improve the cost-benefit ratio of this Agreement. The new Protocol represents a major step forward from the previous one and should serve as an example for future agreements between the European Union and third countries.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania on fisheries partnership for a time of four years was supported. The first fisheries agreement with Mauritania was concluded in 1989 and since then successive agreements have allowed European vessels to engage in fishing activity in the waters of that country.  In 2006, the current Partnership Agreement entered into force, which was extended for a period of two years in 2012 until the end of 2014. Following lengthy negotiations, the European Union and Mauritania initialled a new protocol on 10 July 2015 allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. Three-tenths of the population (42.9% of young people) are unemployed. It is therefore welcome that the Protocol requires the hiring of Mauritanian fishermen (at least 60 % of the crew).

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries. There are timely improvements for Mauritania in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The aim of this agreement is to allow EU fishing vessels access to Mauritanian waters. A new agreement was reached on 10 July 2015 for a period of 4 years. The previous agreement expired in December 2014. The agreement with Mauritania is one of the largest fisheries agreements signed by the European Union. Despite the European Union's request, the agreement excludes cephalopods (the octopus), which Mauritania has granted to China. This poses problems for the European Union to monitor Mauritanian waters, as some Chinese vessels are suspected of illegal fishing. This agreement is nevertheless advantageous for both sides, especially since Mauritania does not have the means to combat illegal fishing. I voted FOR this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted ABSTENTION since we consider these agreements not to be consistent with the type of sustainable fishing we are defending. While reports often indicate that they point to an improvement in fishing production in the EU and the country concerned with which the agreement is made, large fishing corporations, not small producers, or the local population, are often beneficiaries.  There are timely improvements for Mauritania in relation to previous Treaties, but there are not enough controls on the management of funds in the target country and to date there have been no improvements in the population as a product of these agreements, but poor management of them.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EU-Mauritania fisheries partnership agreement because it will help strengthen monitoring, control and surveillance, and contribute to improved governance of the fisheries in the region.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Extending the period of validity of the Protocol, which is the most important document currently signed by the European Union with third countries to four years, will ensure greater stability for the fleet fishing in Mauritanian waters.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an agreement for a period of 4 years that improves the previous ones, since on the one hand it commits Mauritania to improving transparency and prioritizing access to the European fleet and on the other hand improves the EU's contribution to promoting sustainable development of the fisheries sector and environmental protection on sea coasts. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this agreement because it is a balanced agreement that all parties do. This is the most important protocol that the European Union has concluded with a third country. The duration has been extended to 4 years, which will ensure greater stability of the fishing fleet in Mauritanian waters.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a new legislative resolution to establish a new protocol of fisheries partnership agreement (APP) between the European Community, of the one part, and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, on the other. The aforementioned APP provides access to EU vessels to a wide variety of fish and other non-fish species in mauritania's exclusive economic zone. The new protocol for the four-year period provides for an annual EU financial contribution of EUR 59.125 million. These figures correspond to a reduction in the amounts transferred in the previous Protocol, which were EUR 70 million. However, this reduction reflects changes in most quotas, as well as, it is said, a more realistic forecast of catches. On the other hand, there is an improvement in the value used to strengthen the territorial capacity in Mauritania, its autonomy and the development of its potential in the fisheries sector. We also value the incorporation of a 60 % share of Mauritania's workers in European ships, implicitly with the same rights as Europeans.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report is a new agreement aimed at remediing the shortcomings of the last protocol.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – In the vote on the European Parliament recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion – on behalf of the European Union – of the protocol establishing fishing opportunities and financial compensation under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period of four years, I abstained. In principle, I believe that the regulation of fisheries should be in the hands of the Member States.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 In 2015 the EU and Mauritania agreed on a new protocol allowing EU fishermen to operate in Mauritanian waters for four years and concerns in particular pelagic freezer trawlers. It should be noted that the four-year validity of the Protocol will ensure greater stability for the fleet operating in the waters of the region. I voted in favour of Mr Uto's report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2015 report on the new protocol between the European Union and Mauritania. Under this Protocol, the European Union will have the possibility to fish in Mauritania's waters in exchange for an annual financial contribution. I think that, in addition to the possibility of fishing in Mauritanian waters, there is also a very positive report that part of the financial contribution provided by the European Union will be used to support the local fishing community in Mauritania. In my opinion, this is a significant aid, as fishing provides a very important share of jobs in countries such as Mauritania or Liberia, and it is a source of subsuance for the often poorest sections of society. Another positive of the report was its overall direction towards the protection of marine ecosystems and the incitation of responsible and sustainable fishing.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of approving the EU-Mauritania agreement allowing EU fishermen to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years. Compared to previous agreements, it strikes a better balance in the financial contribution to the agreed fishing opportunities. In order to export the model of environmental, economic and social sustainability that it advocates in its fisheries policy, the EU in turn offers greater support to Mauritanian local fishing.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft Council Decision concerns the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Civil Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part. The committee responsible has already given a favourable opinion on this matter. In order to complete the procedure successfully, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that potential military use of satellite navigation technologies in this case cannot be excluded, especially when Korea is one of the areas where the offensive interests of Atlantic imperialism are concentrated.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is the confirmation of a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project.  GNSS (For Global Navigation Satellite System) is the generic acronym for any satellite positioning/geolocation system. Galileo, already operational, continues its development and will be commercialized in 2017. It should be noted that it is a partner but also a competitor of the U.S. GPS and that, unlike its competitors, it will be exclusively under civilian control.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ The colossal waste of taxpayers’ money which is provided to this programme every year amounts to EUR 6.3 billion – nothing more than outrageous when there are other sectors crying out for assistance. The report concerned the extension of the Galileo satellite system to various new sectors and a vote to allow Korea to upgrade their own differential GPS station to Galileo signals. Moreover, there were also concerns raised about the potential for the systems to be used for non-civil purposes. For example, the European Commission considers law enforcement to be a ‘civilian’ purpose, so that this and other such borderline purposes could be put to use under the project. This is completely unacceptable to my party and therefore I voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). Galileo, already operational through interoperability with GPS satellites, is continuing its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk, the Netherlands; it is expected to be commercialized by 2017.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this Agreement because I believe that the United Kingdom should leave the European Union; such matters should be determined at Westminster.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This proposal, in favour of which I have spoken, is simply to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project - where GNSS is the generic acronym for any satellite positioning and geolocation system - which is both a competitor and a partner of the US GPS system. Galileo is already operational thanks to interoperability with GPS satellites and is expected to be commercialised by 2017.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The Cooperation Agreement on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS) between the EU and the Republic of Korea is part of the Galileo system. The inclusion of a reliable partner and a technological power such as Korea will serve to give a boost to this system. I voted in favour because I believe that the Galileo system will reduce the current dependence on other systems such as GPS or GLONASS. In addition, Galileo will have an exclusively civilian use whose work will have an impact on a large number of applications and services.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. If we consider it important to develop a global civil satellite navigation system alternative to the system implemented by the U.S., we have reservations as to some commercial purposes of this cooperation agreement. In addition, the rapporteur of this recommendation belongs to the far-right ENF group, with which we do not share the same values.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text is a recommendation drafted by a colleague of the ENF group and member of the Northern League, Gianluca Buonanno, whose aim is to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both competitor and partner of the US GPS (Global Positioning System). GNSS is the global acronym for satellites, each has its name (GPS in the United States, GLONASS in Russia, etc.). After delays and extra costs, Galileo is in the process of being completed and is expected to be commercialized in 2017 as it continues to expand at ESTEC in the Netherlands. Galileo, on the other hand, will only be managed by the civilian sector, unlike its competitors. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is acceptable and does not present any critical issues. I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. By this Recommendation, Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Civil Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other. The Recommendation merely validates the change of 'European Community' to 'European Union' in the text of the Agreement after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, on the Civil Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). The Republic of Korea has space technology and their application capabilities. It actively uses satellite navigation services in a wide variety of sectors, including transport, fleet management, science and surveying. This Agreement was signed on 9 September 2006 in accordance with Article 1(1) of Regulation (B) of 2006/2006 of 1 September 2006. council decision on its signature. The Signatory Member States of the European Union and the Republic of Korea have completed their internal procedures relating to the entry into force of the Agreement. The agreement aims to encourage, facilitate and strengthen cooperation between the parties in the field of civil global satellite navigation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The global telecommunications network plays an important role among EU countries and their trading partners, so I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, in the field of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civil use.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. It was simply a matter of validating a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). I voted for it.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – The colossal waste of taxpayers’ money which is provided to this programme every year amounts to EUR 6.3 billion – nothing more than outrageous when there are other sectors crying out for assistance. The report concerned the extension of the Galileo satellite system to various new sectors and a vote to allow Korea to upgrade their own differential GPS station to Galileo signals. Moreover, there were also concerns raised about the potential for the systems to be used for non-civil purposes. For example, the European Commission considers law enforcement to be a ‘civilian’ purpose, so that this and other such borderline purposes could be put to use under the project. This is completely unacceptable to my party and therefore I voted against this report.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Satellite positioning has become essential for socio-economic prosperity and GNSS has already become the backbone of a growing industry worth billions of euros. The greater precision and reliability of the system, with its guaranteed and personalized services, will offer a quality of service of the highest level in the field of navigation, positioning and measurement of global time by satellite. Adopting a single standard for the Global Civil Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the EU and the Republic of Korea is a positive aspect that can improve the effectiveness of the movements of citizens and merchant ships, as requested many times by operators in the sector.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US GPS system.  It should be noted that Galileo is already operational thanks to interoperability with GPS satellites and is continuing its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in the Netherlands. It is expected to go on sale by 2017. I voted for this cooperation agreement.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Cooperation Agreement with Korea on the Global Civil Satellite Navigation System was based on negotiations between the European Community and the Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, the Agreement being signed on 9 September 2006. The Republic of Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors such as transport, fleet management, science, geodesy. Collaboration in this area can only bring about the development of complex civil satellite navigation systems based on information exchange and transparency. The Republic of Korea has distinguished itself over the years in the field of space technology and applications, investing substantially in this sector. A cooperation agreement on the global civil satellite navigation system brings significant benefits to both parties, strengthening their partnership, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 South Korea is associated with GNSS (Galileo) with this agreement. Identical agreements have already been adopted with other third countries. The Northern League has traditionally favoured Galileo, an EU satellite navigation system that can be interoperable with its US (GPS) and Russian (GloNaSS) counterparts.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because the Republic of Korea is certainly a country with important capabilities in the field of space technologies and applications. Korea is actively using satellite navigation services in a variety of areas, including transport, fleet management, scientific research and geodesy. I would like to remind you in this regard that the ultimate aim of the agreement between the EU and Korea is to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation between the parties in the field of global civil satellite navigation. Cooperation activities in this particular field include radio spectrum, scientific research and training, industrial cooperation, the development of trade and the market, standards, certification and, finally, measures including regulation, enhancement, safety, responsibility and cost recovery. The main ideas for collaboration come from joint research activities in the field of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), both through European and Korean programmes. Important examples are therefore provided by the European Community Framework Programme for Research and Development, the European Space Agency's research programmes and programmes organised by Korea's GNSS-related ministries and agencies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned the extension of the Galileo satellite system to various new sectors and a vote to allow Korea to upgrade their own differential GPS station to Galileo signals. I voted against this report for a number of reasons, first because of the massive amounts of taxpayers’ money that gets poured into the Galileo Programme every year (EUR 6.3 billion) and second because of the potential for the systems to be used for non-civil purposes. For example, the European Commission considers law enforcement to be a ‘civilian’ purpose, so that this and other such borderline purposes could be put to use under the project.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, we voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the GNSS Agreement with the Republic of Korea by voting in favour of this report. South Korea is our strategic partner and I am glad that this agreement will help us enhance our cooperation in the area that of civil global satellite navigation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the proposal for a Council decision concerning the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, on a civilian Global Navigation Satellite System, as we consider the Republic of Korea to be a country with considerable potential in the field of space technology and its applications.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States with the Republic of Korea on a Civilian Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) is an effort with positive and negative elements. It must be ensured that joint participation in space programmes is done with the right intentions, with the protection of important information and without it being at the expense of citizens' rights. As I therefore consider it necessary to consult further on the facts of the agreement, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report determines the conclusion of an agreement for cooperation on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part. I voted in favour because I believe that such an agreement can only benefit the European Union because the Republic of Korea is a particularly strong country in technology and this report aims precisely to facilitate and improve cooperation in this area. I therefore believe that we are in favour of using the strengths of the Member States, but also of third countries, in the best possible use.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Republic of Korea is a country with capabilities in the space technology and applications. It is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. Bulgaria, Croatia, and Romania are to become parties to the agreement by the conclusion of a protocol.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, we voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Buonanno Report which approves the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement on a civilian global satellite navigation system between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Korea.  The Agreement, signed on 9 September 2006, which was subject to its conclusion at a later date, aims to stimulate, promote and strengthen cooperation between the Parties within the framework of a global satellite navigation system for civilian use.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We recognise the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, we voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for the conclusion of a cooperation agreement under the new satellite navigation systems, as they represent innovative geolocation technologies that can be successfully used for civil purposes. This agreement is a major step towards the development of new technologies and also represents an important step forward in relations between the European Union and Korea.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. It is therefore important that agreed procedures are set in place so as to ensure that common requirements are fulfilled.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because I believe that potential military use of satellite navigation technologies cannot be excluded in this case, especially when Korea is one of the areas where the offensive interests of Atlantic imperialism are concentrated.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the agreement is to stimulate, facilitate and strengthen cooperation between the parties in the field of civilian global satellite navigation as part of the European and Korean involvement in the GNSS system. This is an initiative that I personally support, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative report deals with the process of ratifying the cooperation agreement for a global satellite navigation system for civilian use between the European Union and the Republic of Korea.  Considering that globalisation is pushing to open borders, and among them maritime areas, and that this cooperation agreement will make it possible to simplify the European Union's cooperation with the Republic of Korea, I supported this report.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, on the Civil Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). The purpose of concluding the Agreement is to support and improve cooperation between the Parties in the field of civil global satellite navigation.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution giving Parliament the approval of a cooperation agreement on a global satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civilian use between the European Community and its Member States on the one hand and the Republic of Korea on the other. The purpose of this agreement is to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation between the parties in the field of global satellite navigation for civilian use. Following the recommendations of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I thought it was appropriate to support it, as the Republic of Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services and has capabilities in the field of space technology and applications.  The sectors opened by this agreement to cooperation activities are: radio spectrum, scientific research and training, industrial cooperation, trade and market development, standardization, certification and regulatory measures, extensions, safety, liability and cost recovery. The parties will be able to adapt this list through a decision of the steering committee for the GNSS instituted under the agreement.  The agreement also includes provisions for information exchange, consultation and dispute resolution.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). Galileo is already operational thanks to interoperability with GPS satellites and continues its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk, the Netherlands. It is expected to be commercialized by 2017 and, unlike its competitors, Galileo will be under exclusively civilian control.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Korea on the Global Civil Navigation Satellite System, as I believe it is important for all citizens. The international nature of the Galileo programme has led several countries to apply for a cooperation agreement with the European Union. The European Commission formally expressed an interest in March 2005, on the basis of a Council authorisation, negotiated a cooperation agreement on the Global Civil Navigation Satellite System between the European Community (and its Member States) and the Republic of Korea, which was then signed in September 2006.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that the EU cooperate with the Republic of Korea, a country with considerable potential in the field of space technology and its applications. The aim is to encourage, facilitate and promote a civilian Global Navigation System (GNSS), independent of the US GPS System.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: it is to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the AGREEMENT between the EU and Korea which encourages, facilitates and strengthens cooperation between the parties in the field of global satellite navigation for civil use. The agreement will be implemented within the framework of European and Korean contributions to a global civil satellite navigation system. GNSS systems provide good accuracy and information integrity control for civil navigation uses, so I believe that there is a need for improvement in the exchange of information between the two parties.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. I do not have position on this issue.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the agreement allowing South Korea to be associated with the GNSS (Galileo), an EU satellite navigation system interoperable with GPS and GloNaSS..

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation as it proposes EU cooperation with the Republic of Korea, a country with considerable potential in the field of space technology and its applications. The aim is to encourage, facilitate and promote a civilian Global Navigation System (GNSS), independent of US GPS.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as UK businesses are heavily involved in the construction of the space infrastructure for the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). In addition to this, British universities have benefitted significantly by leading the uptake and utilisation of the new capabilities that the system offers.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the agreement on the civilian global satellite navigation system with Korea. In doing so, I authorise the Commission to adopt the decision to conclude the agreement on behalf of the EU.  The Republic of Korea has appropriate capabilities in the field of space technology and its applications, as well as active use of satellite navigation services in various sectors, including transport, fleet management and scientific and geodetic applications.  The EU can only benefit from the expertise available to Korea. Similar cooperation agreements can boost cooperation in the field of space exploration, facilitate the exchange of information and deepen bilateral relations with Korea in general.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Agreement convinced of the need to continue to make international progress on cooperation on a global satellite navigation system. There is no doubt about the great potential it poses for European industry and citizens, so the Union must continue to work with its international partners to achieve greater cooperation in this important area.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this cooperation agreement on GNSS with the Republic of Korea; the agreement is important and will enchant the EUs relations with the Republic of Korea in several key areas of satellite navigations. These areas include cooperation between EU and Korean industries, cooperation in the fields of science and research, as well as the development of the market of trade in satellite systems, all which could be of great benefit. Deeper international cooperation in satellite navigations could provide large advantages in the long term in sectors such as transportation and science where satellite navigation systems are widely used.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civilian Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) with Korea. With its galileo civil navigation system, Europe has a great opportunity to become the world leader in this field. For this to succeed, appropriate agreements with third countries are needed. Korea can be an important step in this.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Korea has relevant capabilities in the fields of space technology and applications. Satellite navigation services are currently actively used in various areas such as transport, fleet management and science. The Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the Union and the Republic of Korea promotes cooperation in the fields of research, progress and the development of new opportunities.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this report along with colleagues from the Socialists and Democrats group. This is the conclusion of an agreement already ratified by the EU and all Member States concerned. Our policy is never to cooperate with the far right ENF group, to which the rapporteur belongs.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Galileo is a satellite navigation system. It was developed by the Member States to compete with GPS from AMERICAN laboratories and to break out of the technological dependence our industry finds itself in on these subjects.  Galileo is therefore expected to be on the market by 2017. It will thus compete with the hegemony of American technology and enable European technologies to gain market share. To do this, it must be compatible with the technologies used by other countries, hence the need for cooperation agreements.  Many states have shown interest in this new technology and have already signed such agreements.  My fellow Italian Member of Parliament Gianlucca Buonanno proposed to support this agreement, so I logically voted in favour.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The GNSS is the European positioning and geolocation system, which is entirely civilian. It was initiated in 1999 to ensure the independence of Europe from the American GPS and this has always made me this project friendly.  It is a pity that the whims of the time, relying first on a fully private financing, then a public-private partnership, caused this project to fall behind, and that it took seven years, if I remember correctly, to finally realize that a public project of this magnitude, like so many others before it (nuclear, space, aeronautics, etc.), could only be based on public funding.  But the project is finally on track, seems to be meeting its deadlines, and is attracting more and more countries willing to cooperate. For once, despite the involvement of the European Union and the Commission, I can only rejoice. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. If we consider it important to develop a global civil satellite navigation system alternative to the system implemented by the U.S., we have reservations as to some commercial purposes of this cooperation agreement. In addition, the rapporteur of this recommendation belongs to the far-right ENF group, with which we do not share the same values.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ This is the conclusion of an agreement already ratified by the EU and all Member States concerned. I did not participate in this vote as my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, never cooperates with the far-right extremists, the ENF.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Republic of Korea is a country with capabilities in space technology and applications. It is currently an active user of GPS services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. Korean interlocutors have expressed a specific interest in extending the use of satellite navigation through Galileo to various sectors including transport and fisheries and the upgrading of their differential GPS station network to Galileo signals.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, on the Civil Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). The purpose of concluding the Agreement is to support and improve cooperation between the Parties in the field of civil global satellite navigation.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and the Republic of Korea. This cooperation agreement that lays down the principles, scope and forms of cooperation on satellite navigation was negotiated in 2005 and signed in 2006. However, the agreement is only now being concluded as only recently have all Member States completed their national procedure to approve it.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission negotiated a cooperation agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part. The Republic of Korea is a country with capabilities in space technology and applications and this is an agreement from which both parties can win.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other because it improves cooperation with Korea in the area concerned, and strengthens the Union's technological capabilities.  The exchange of information and experience, and the establishment of an efficient and advanced navigation satellite system can definitely strengthen certain activities of significant importance for the Union, such as rescue and border control operations. The Republic of Korea has achieved significant results in the field of satellite systems, and is an advanced state in the development of new technologies. I support this recommendation, although I consider it necessary to ensure that the Union's interests are protected in all aspects of the Agreement.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Galileo, already operational thanks to interoperability with GPS satellites, continues its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk, the Netherlands; it is expected to be commercialized by 2017. There was no reason for me to object. That is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We recognise the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, Diane James MEP voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation between South Korea and the EU in the field of global satellite navigation for civilian use.  Indeed, it is essential that the EU develops its own satellite navigation system (GALILEO) in order to compete with the US GPS system.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. This is an endorsement of the continuation of a protocol on data exchange with South Korea under the GNSS programme.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, on the Civil Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). The purpose of concluding the Agreement is to support and improve cooperation between the Parties in the field of civil global satellite navigation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Korea is a country with space technology capabilities. Korea has long expressed its willingness to expand the use of satellite navigation. The purpose of the report is to implement a satellite navigation agreement between Korea and the EU. I voted against this report because I have reservations about whether satellite navigation could be used for other reasons.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written. \u2012 Cooperation between the European Union and South Korea on the global GNSS civilian satellite navigation system is beneficial to both parties. This is particularly necessary now, as positioning services have become ever closer to consumers with smartphones in recent years. GNSS collaboration contributes to the global reach of digital services and products. The European Parliament must actively support measures that support innovation cooperation and enable European industry to enter the Korean market in a rapidly growing field of positioning applications.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The subject of today's vote concerns the agreement on cooperation with Korea on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS). Parliament approved the conclusion of the agreement negotiated between the EU, the European Space Agency and Eurocontrol, the European organisation for the safety of air navigation, on the European contribution to the development of a global satellite navigation system (GNSS). The aim of the agreement is to establish cooperation between the three parties in order to make a European contribution to the development of a GNSS. This effort would place Europe in a position to offer a satellite-assisted navigation system that would meet the requirements of civil users, regardless of other means of navigation and radio positioning. In view of the reasons given in this agreement, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the cooperation agreement with Korea on the Galileo Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). This system is both a competitor and a partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). Galileo, already operational thanks to interoperability with GPS satellites, continues its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk, the Netherlands. It is expected to go on sale by 2017. We can only hope that this deadline will finally be met.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it confirms a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the Galileo project, a competitor of the US GPS.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) allows for satellite geolocation and positioning. It is divided into several custom systems, named by a different sign as GPS for the United States.  For the European Union, the Galileo module is being developed by the European Space Agency. It is a partner and competitor of the GPS, but has the merit of being under exclusively civilian control.  The text put to the vote refers to the EU cooperation agreement with South Korea on Galileo. Having no reason to object, I voted FOR.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that potential military use of satellite navigation technologies in this case cannot be excluded, especially when Korea is one of the areas where the offensive interests of Euro-American imperialism are concentrated.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement foresees cooperation in the fields of trade, standardisation, research and radio spectrum, but does not include sensitive components of the European navigation system Galileo. I consider such an agreement to be harmless, but I do not agree with the overall approach with which the EU is building its own navigation system. That's why I got late.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors, including transport, science and geodesy. The aim of this agreement is to support, facilitate and enhance cooperation between the European Community and its Member States and the Republic of Korea in cooperation on the Civilian Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS).  I supported this report as this Agreement seeks to encourage, facilitate and enhance cooperation between partners in the civilian global satellite navigation system.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Republic of Korea is one of the world's most developed countries, especially in terms of the development of electronic technologies and systems, which clearly also applies to the systems of civilian global navigation satellites, which can be used in a wide range of tools and applications – cars, ships, mobile phones, aircraft, etc. In the production of all these things, the Republic of Korea is also among the world leaders. Given the real benefits that such cooperation could bring to both parties, at least in economic and social terms, it was absolutely logical to join my colleagues and support the entry into force of this highly important cooperation agreement.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, on a civilian Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement. The aim is to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the Galileo project. The European Galileo system is both a competitor and a partner of the American GPS, and is already functional thanks to interoperability with the latter's satellites. Unlike its competitors, Galileo is placed under exclusively civilian control. Currently being developed at the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk (Netherlands), Galileo is expected to go on sale in 2017. We can only support this partnership agreement, which is aimed at European technological innovation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the cooperation agreement with Korea on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS) is in my favour. These systems, aimed at providing a geospatial positioning service with global coverage, allow geolocation on any point of the Earth's surface or atmosphere with an error of a few meters. The aim of the report is to improve air cooperation with Korea.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of Korea have much to cooperate on in the field of civil technology. We are both at the forefront of civil space engineering. This agreement will lead us to work together more closely and allow us to improve our technological standards. I am in favour of cooperation and growth alongside the Republic of Korea, so I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the resolution in which we agree to the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Global Civil Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) with the Republic of Korea.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to promote and facilitate further cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Korea in the area of civil global satellite navigation, not including the Galileo programme.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. On 18 July 2005, the Council authorised the Commission to negotiate a cooperation agreement on a civil-use Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between Member States, the European Community and South Korea. A first agreement was signed on 9 September 2006 subject to its subsequent conclusion.  It is now a matter of approving such an agreement on behalf of the European Union. Since the agreement is limited to the civilian uses of this technology and that this satellite navigation project will counterbalance the current total control of these tools by the US via GPS, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is the validation of a cooperation report with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project. It is a competitor as well as a partner of the American GPS and would be under exclusively civilian control. It would allow us to distance ourselves from the GPS system.  As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This type of agreement is very important for the creation of bilateral partnerships that lead to the economic development of all parties. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the cooperation agreement with Korea as it strengthens the European Galileo-project and provides new opportunities in the field of scientific research and training as well as industrial cooperation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the approval of the European Parliament for the conclusion of a cooperation agreement with the Republic of Korea on a global satellite navigation system for civilian use. Cooperation with a country such as the Republic of Korea is particularly desirable as it is a leading country in space technology. The two partners will be able to increase their cooperation in this area with a variety of applications.  Satellite navigation for civilian use is a technology of the future whose potential benefits are far from negligible. I would like to stress the need to cooperate at the global level in order to make the most of the opportunities offered by this technology.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – I consider the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, to be very beneficial as Korea is one of the countries with qualifications in space technology and application. It actively uses satellite navigation services in the fields of transport, science and geodesy. The main areas where cooperation will take place are, in particular, scientific research and preparation, industrial cooperation, regulatory measures and safety. The agreement in question also regulates the exchange of important information concerning satellite navigation and Galileo, consultation and dispute resolution, and I therefore support the proposal.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important agreement. As one of the leading countries in the field of electronic devices, the Republic of Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. This agreement seeks to enhance cooperation activities between the European Community along with its Member States and the Republic of Korea in terms of satellite navigation and navigation timing. Moreover, the agreement ensures that South Korea gives full support in all key aspects of the Galileo programme such as standards, certification or frequency allocation.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The aim here is to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). Galileo is expected to go on sale in 2017 and is expected to be an expected alternative to the US system. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2006, the Cooperation Agreement on a civilian satellite navigation system (GNSS) was concluded between the then EEC, its Member States and the Republic of Korea. The Agreement aims to stimulate, promote and strengthen cooperation between the parties within the framework of a global satellite navigation system for civilian use. In view of the importance of this agreement for the parties involved, on the one hand, and taking into account the new framework of competence established by the Treaty of Lisbon with regard to the binding of the EU to international agreements, on the other hand, the Union's link to this agreement acquires extreme relevance.  In this regard, I am voting in favour of the draft decision, as the Union's link to this agreement is essential to ensure a stable and healthy global environment.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. It is simply a matter of validating a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). So I voted for it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that Korea will serve as a great partner in cooperation on civilian global satellite navigation systems. The quality of information technology and mobile communications is an important part of GNSS, and Korea is undoubtedly able to provide high standards in these areas. The conclusion of the agreement has been approved and I look forward to further deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Korea.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this report, part of the framework agreement between the European Union on the one part and the Republic of Korea on the other, following the evaluation made by my political group.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the Cooperation Agreement on the Global Civil Navigation System between the EU and the Republic of Korea is beneficial to both parties. Investments by the Republic of Korea and the EU in the research and development of civil satellite navigation systems have greatly improved our daily lives, so that the widespread use of these systems has been achieved in areas such as navigation, transport, science and geodesy. In my opinion, cooperation between the two parties to develop new systems and improve existing ones will have a direct positive effect on the lives of European citizens.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – The colossal waste of taxpayers’ money which is provided to this programme every year amounts to EUR 6.3 billion – nothing more than outrageous when there are other sectors crying out for assistance. The report concerned the extension of the Galileo satellite system to various new sectors and a vote to allow Korea to upgrade their own differential GPS station to Galileo signals. Moreover, there were also concerns raised about the potential for the systems to be used for non-civil purposes. For example, the European Commission considers law enforcement to be a ‘civilian’ purpose, so that this and other such borderline purposes could be put to use under the project. This is completely unacceptable to my party and therefore I voted against this report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a purely technical confirmation of the continuation of a protocol on the exchange of data with South Korea under the GNSS programme under Rule 50/51.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement encourages and enhances cooperation in the field of civil satellite navigation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of this cooperation agreement with Korea on a civil global satellite navigation system. It should be noted that this agreement will promote and strengthen cooperation between the parties in the field of civil global satellite navigation. In addition, it will facilitate the more efficient development of a global satellite navigation system for civil use and the development of a common global system. It should be noted that the agreement will promote joint research activities. It will also increase mutual cooperation between industry and help develop trade and stimulate investment.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We recognize the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, we voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's proposal, as I believe that the global satellite navigation system is of great importance and useful to ensure the accurate positioning of civil applications, as well as being an essential element for the socio-economic development of European industry. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Republic of Korea is a country with capabilities in space technology and applications. It is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement on a civil GNSS with Korea to allow for a more globalised and open partnership with the Republic of Korea.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Korea is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, maritime affairs, science and geodesy. This Agreement seeks to encourage, facilitate and enhance cooperation between Korea and the EU in the civilian application of global satellite navigation. Activities aimed at cooperation in satellite navigation are: use of radio spectrum, scientific research and education, industrial cooperation, trade and market development, standards and certification, regulatory measures, security and accountability and reimbursement. This Agreement is a continuation of the cooperation so far and the 2006 Agreement, which in today's form does not include important elements of the protection of sensitive technologies and components of Galileo that are prohibited by european union or Member States from exporting and proliferation. Also, the current agreement does not include the architecture of the Galileo security system (in space, on Earth and in the user segment) or the exchange of confidential information regarding satellite navigation and galileo. Due to the need to continue cooperation so far, improve the availability of services, but also protect sensitive European technologies at the same time, I support the proposal for an agreement and have supported the recommendation for its conclusion.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Although I support the adoption of the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other hand, unfortunately I cannot participate in the voting of the case led by the ENF parliamentary group. Regardless of the processing of ENF cases, I will not stand in the way of the adoption of this Treaty, which aims to strengthen EU cooperation in global civilian satellite navigation. Sectors where cooperation in the world's civil satellite navigation will be possible are: scientific research and education, industrial cooperation, trade and market development, security, etc.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this Agreement is to encourage, facilitate and increase cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Korea on a global civilian satellite navigation system (GNSS). This Agreement, among other things, involves activity in fields such as radio spectrum, scientific research and training, industrial cooperation, certification and regulatory measures, trade development and security.  The assumptions of this agreement, in the harmless appearance, conceal, in fact, what constitutes a step of destabilization in that region of the globe. If, on the one hand, there are positive aspects of scientific and economic development for both sides, on the other hand, it paves the way for a new chapter of interference in the ongoing conflict with North Korea, in which every day we see new developments. In the short term, the deepening of this agreement in the fields of encryption and information security (INFOSEC), security architecture systems (space, land and users), security control resources and confidential information exchange on satellite navigation (GALILEO) could be at stake. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. I welcome the continuation of cooperation with the Republic of Korea under the Galileo programme. Korea is a very important partner of the European Union in Asia and a country with enviable technological potential and infrastructure capabilities. Further development of cooperation in the field of civilian global positioning systems will increase the security of citizens, but more importantly, encourage the development of industries dependent on the rapid exchange of information primarily through monitoring the situation on the ground and transferring new knowledge. As part of horizon 2020, the EU has committed to developing an enviable technological capability, taking a leading role in the fields of industrial and scientific excellence. The future must therefore also be in greater interaction with all countries willing and able to act together with the EU in these programme orientations. I supported Mep Buonanno's recommendation to conclude a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) Cooperation Agreement with Korea, taking into account that Korea has adequate capabilities in the field of space technology and applications and actively uses satellites in various sectors, including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the cooperation agreement between South Korea and the European Union in the context of the use of the Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS). This programme is particularly illustrated by the Galileo satellite, which offers precise positioning, at the cutting edge of technology and guaranteed for all types of civil applications, such as car navigation systems, mobile phones or even maritime, road, rail and air transport.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. 'u2012's satellite navigation systems establish geospatial positioning using artificial satellites. This technique enables receivers on the earth's surface to determine their location compared to satellite signals. Since the global satellite navigation system (GNSS) is instrumental ly used for the political and military services of the Member States, as well as various civilian uses (in the fields of transport, fleet management, science and geodesy and cartography), this draft resolution serves to approve the conclusion of a cooperation agreement with the Republic of Korea. In this context, the report was in my favour, which approves the maximisation of the coverage capacity of the Member States, this time through the association with Korean space technology.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We recognise the capabilities in the space technology of the Republic of Korea. However, we voted against the conclusion of a cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of Korea as we believe that the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission, should be entitled to negotiate such an agreement.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Ten years after the signing of the cooperation agreement on a global satellite navigation system for civilian use between the then European Community, the Member States and the Republic of Korea, the Council has just approved this strategic agreement on 1 March 2016. South Korea joins the list of countries that, at different levels of cooperation, already participate in the Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS): China, India, Israel, Norway and Switzerland. It must be recognized that Korea is a country with capabilities in the field of space technology and applications. It is an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors, including transportation, fleet management, science and geodesy. And this allows the Commission, in line with what it has done since the beginning of the Galileo programme, in partnership with the European Space Agency, to strengthen this strategic area of radio navigation. Such cooperations have emerged as guarantors of the system's overall nature and, in particular, its interoperability with other existing or future systems, such as the US GPS or the Chinese Beidou.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. This cooperation agreement with Korea aims to encourage, facilitate and improve cooperation in the field of global satellite navigation for civilian use.  Moreover, the agreement does not undermine the institutional structure established by EU law for the implementation of the Galileo programme, nor the regulatory measures that implement non-proliferation and export control commitments, including the control of intangible technology transfers, or national security measures.  I therefore voted in favour of this text, as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. By this resolution, Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a global civil satellite navigation system (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other. The resolution merely validates the change of "European Community" to "European Union" in the text of the agreement following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, on the basis of the draft cooperation agreement on a global satellite navigation system for civilian use between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other, and in view of the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which gives its approval to the conclusion of the agreement and instructs the President to transmit the position of the Commission, as well as the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of Korea.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. The Cooperation Agreement on Satellite Navigation is concluded with our ally and partner, South Korea.  Neither the form or content of the document call into question the need to accept it as a measure which will increase the competitiveness of both parties to the contract. At the same time, it is only necessary to encourage Member States, both governments and businesses, to make every effort to fully exploit the benefits of this agreement.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Republic of Korea is a country with high technological and space application capacity. He is also an active user of satellite navigation services in various sectors, including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. The European Commission, on the basis of the Council's authorisation of 18 July 2005, has negotiated a cooperation agreement on a civilian global satellite navigation system (GNSS) between its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, on the other. Since the Agreement was signed in September 2006, the signatory Member States and the Republic of Korea have completed the procedures necessary for the entry into force of the Agreement. In accordance with Article 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Commission proposes to the Council a decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on behalf of the European Union after the consent of the European Parliament. We are therefore faced with a draft legislative resolution which formally takes on a mostly technical-legislative character and, to that extent, my vote was in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and in line with the opinion already expressed in the work of the committee responsible (Industry, Research and Energy), I voted in favour of this report. As part of the creation of the Global Satellite Navigation System, the report gives a favourable opinion on the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between the Member States of the European Union and South Korea, facilitating the progress of this important project for both parties.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. If we consider it important to develop a global civil satellite navigation system alternative to the system implemented by the U.S., we have reservations as to some commercial purposes of this cooperation agreement. In addition, the rapporteur of this recommendation belongs to the far-right ENF group, with which we do not share the same values.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that potential military use of satellite navigation technologies in this case cannot be excluded, especially when Korea is one of the areas where the offensive interests of Atlantic imperialism are concentrated.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I have refused to participate in this vote. This is the conclusion of an agreement which has already been ratified by the EU and the Member States concerned. I did not participate in this vote because, alongside my Socialist colleagues, I will never cooperate with nor legitimise far—right extremists like the ENF Group, of which the rapporteur Gianluca Buonanno is a member.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between the EU and the Republic of Korea on the civilian use of the GNSS satellite navigation system, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The Galileo programme, with its international nature, has fostered a cooperation agreement with the EU in a number of countries. In March 2005, the Republic of Korea, a country with significant capabilities in the field of space technology, also expressed its interest in the agreement.  Korea, which is an active user of GPS services in various sectors, including transport, science and geodesy, has expressed its desire to extend the use of satellite navigation through galileo to other areas. The approval of the cooperation agreement with Korea in the field of the global satellite navigation system will bring closer cooperation between the EU and Korea and will allow for the implementation of elements of the European satellite navigation programmes.
