At the same time, it will also open up the possibilities of EU cooperation with Korea in areas such as standardisation, radio spectrum, trade and market development for satellites. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Global navigation systems are useful global tools with worldwide coverage. GNSS also guarantees countries such as Slovakia cost-effective solutions in ensuring economic growth of current and future needs while maintaining environmental protection and with an emphasis on sustainable development.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament published a draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Korea and expressed its agreement to conclude that Agreement.  Taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I support this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament improving cooperation with the Republic of Korea.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This is the conclusion of an agreement already ratified by the EU and all Member States concerned. I did not participate in this vote as my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, never cooperates with the far-right extremists, the ENF.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament has published a draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Korea. Parliament has expressed its agreement to conclude this Agreement. I support this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament, as I believe that in this way we encourage, facilitate and enhance cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Korea.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, in the field of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civil use.  The Republic of Korea boasts high capabilities in the field of space technology and applications. It also regularly uses satellite navigation services in different sectors. I welcome the cooperation with Korea in the area of the global satellite navigation system, which will be most reflected in the areas of transport, fleet management, science and geodesy.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As a group, we are vertically opposed to the navigation systems developed by the EU. The reasons are because they are already used for military purposes despite the contrary declarations, but also because they do not meet the objectives they set (detoxification from the American GPS). On the contrary, the Americans have the right to block the EU's satellite navigation system.  For the above reasons we voted against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that the EU cooperate with the Republic of Korea, a country with considerable potential in the field of space technology and its applications. The aim is to encourage, facilitate and promote a civilian Global Navigation System (GNSS), independent of US GPS.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At a time when access to precise location and time information is extremely important, global satellite navigation systems need to be taken action. Already in the 1990s, the European Union began work on the largest industrial project under integrated European structures, the Galileo programme, which aims to ensure satellite independence from the US for the countries of the European Union. The EU's Galileo project has also become interesting for non-Community countries thanks to its innovative nature. In 2006, South Korea and the European Union concluded talks on Korea's participation in the programme. The Agreement provides for cooperation in research, training, market development and trade. It also assumes industrial cooperation and cooperation in the creation of legislation, standardization, certification and development of regional assistance systems.  The conclusion of the agreement with Korea once again confirms the European Union's desire to develop international cooperation. The growing interest of third countries in participating in the Galileo programme stimulates the market for GNSS-based services, with an estimated potential of 3 billion receivers and global revenues of €275 billion per year in 2020.  The European Parliament's agreement with Korea is a symbolic confirmation of the need to intensify international cooperation in the field of satellite navigation under the leadership of the European Union.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I have decided not to vote on the report in question. Together with my socialist and democratic colleagues, I find it regrettable that people whose racist comments are legion, represent Europe in spite of themselves through texts, even if they are non-legislative.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the EU and Korea, in order to encourage, ease and improve cooperation in the field of civil global satellite navigation, which Korea is an active user of. This agreement will allow for closer collaboration in the domains of radio-spectrum, scientific research, industry, security, standards and certification. I look forward to a fruitful cooperation.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, on a civil global satellite navigation system (GNSS). In the 21st century, the proper functioning of any navigation systems, including in particular air transport, requires cooperation between as many countries as possible. It is important that that cooperation be used for civil purposes, as the above-mentioned draft Council Decision points out. The Treaty with the Republic of Korea fills this legal gap.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Korea has adequate capabilities in the field of space technology and actively uses satellite navigation services in various sectors, including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania are to become parties to the Cooperation Agreement on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System by concluding a protocol in accordance with Article 6(2) of the EIA. acts on the conditions of accession of the Republic of Bulgaria, Romania and the Republic of Croatia and the adjustments to the treaties on which the European Union is based. Given that the Member States of the European Union are signatories to the agreement and the Republic of Korea have finalised their procedures for the entry into force of the Agreement, I supported the Recommendation on the draft decision of the Council on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on the Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, in the field of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civil use.   I have taken into account the Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part, in the field of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) for civil use (11516/2006).

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. If we consider it important to develop a global civil satellite navigation system alternative to the system implemented by the U.S., we have reservations as to some commercial purposes of this cooperation agreement. In addition, the rapporteur of this recommendation belongs to the far-right ENF group, with which we do not share the same values.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the EU's cooperation with reliable satellite navigation partners, which is essential for the success of the Galileo project. The Republic of Korea, as a democratic country, is important to us not only because of its geographical location, but also because of its market and research potential in the field of space technologies.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on Civil global Navigation System with Korea because it is very important that the EU includes South Korea in further technical cooperation and exchanges with us. This reinforces our position and South Korea with regards its neighbours.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This text is simply intended to validate a cooperation agreement with South Korea on the European GNSS Galileo project, both a competitor and partner of the US Global Positioning System (GPS). GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) is the generic acronym for any satellite positioning/geolocation system: GPS for the United States, GLONASS for Russia. Galileo, already operational through interoperability with GPS satellites, is continuing its development at ESTEC, the European Space Agency's technology centre in Noordwijk, the Netherlands; it is expected to be commercialized by 2017. It should be noted that, unlike its competitors, Galileo will be under exclusively civilian control. I voted FOR the text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. If we consider it important to develop a global civil satellite navigation system alternative to the system implemented by the U.S., we have reservations as to some commercial purposes of this cooperation agreement. In addition, the rapporteur of this recommendation belongs to the far-right ENF group, with which we do not share the same values.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this decision, Parliament approves the conclusion of the agreement with a country which has great potential in the field of technology and space applications and actively uses satellite navigation services in various sectors including transport, fleet management, science and geodesy. We are therefore talking about an agreement which will generate benefits in this area and so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this cooperation agreement on a civil global satellite navigation system between the European Union and South Korea. This cooperation will bring technological benefits to both partners.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The assumptions of this agreement, in the harmless appearance, conceal, in fact, what constitutes a step of destabilization in that region of the globe. If, on the one hand, there are positive aspects of scientific and economic development for both sides, on the other hand, it paves the way for a new chapter of interference in the ongoing conflict with North Korea, in which every day we see new developments. In the short term, this agreement could be deepened in the fields of encryption and information security (INFOSEC), security architecture systems (space, land and users), security control features and confidential information exchange on satellite navigation (GALILEO). By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. This report is a purely technical confirmation of the continuation of a protocol on the exchange of data with South Korea under the GNSS programme under Rule 50/51. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Cooperation Agreement on a Civil Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Korea, on the other. This is an overstepping of the EU's competences. Member States should decide for themselves on issues such as this.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The content of the report is not controversial, and reflects an agreement already ratified by the EU and all Member States concerned. However, the rapporteur of the report is a member of the far-right group ‘ENF’ (Europe of Nations and Freedom). I therefore did not participate in this vote as my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, never cooperates with the far-right extremists, the ENF.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, in turn endorsing the initiative of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which was adopted by an increased majority in this House, supported by most political groups.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The entry into force of the cooperation agreement on a civil global navigation satellite system between the EU and the Republic of South Korea is further evidence of the high level of interest, but also of the need to fully implement the EU's Galileo satellite navigation programme. This is a very important initiative that deserves support.  At present, 12 of the 30 planned satellites of the constellation Galileo are in orbit. By the end of this year, another 6 satellites are planned to be in orbit. The acceleration of work on the construction of this system comes from the pressing need to build an autonomous, alternative to GPS, but at the same time compatible with it, global positioning system. Galileo will be even more accurate than the competition and thus have great commercial potential, as most of its services will be open to a wide audience. International cooperation in implementing, but also exploiting, Galileo's potential is key to its success. We want EU partners to be aware of our capabilities and have access to the technologies we create. The agreement with the Republic of South Korea is proof that Galileo is and will be an added value and that our partners want to use the skills we offer.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (A8-0065/2016), I voted in favour of the conclusion of an agreement on cooperation with Korea in the field of global navigation satellite navigation system (GNSS) for civilian use.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The European Union regularly promises change with revolutionary policies formulated with such different wordfires, which is what I have seen here in the seven years I have been here. What they have in common is that it will never be any better for the people of Europe, and in particular not for the populations of the so-called new Member States, which are regarded as second-class.  The latest key word in cohesion policies is community-driven local development. The interesting thing is that this is precisely what the European Union is doing in the Member States, as it happens in Hungary. How can we talk about community-led local development when the lands were stolen, there is no Hungarian land on the ground, it has been taken into foreign hands. In addition, they need successful small business owners: they are not, because they have been destroyed by global multi-companies. There are no communities and no local leaders, because sensible, well-educated people have already left their home countries because of the European Union. Thank you very much!

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr As you know, in the 2014-2020 programming period, more emphasis is placed on an integrated and territorial approach under cohesion policy to promote economic and territorial cohesion. Two new instruments were introduced to achieve this objective: community-driven local development (CLM) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). In this context, I would like to stress in particular that CLMD can be used at sub-regional level to strengthen synergies between local actors in both the public and private sectors, while ITI helps to implement an integrated territorial strategy to combine financial resources from different priority areas. In total, these two instruments will receive 5% of total cohesion policy funding, or EUR 16 billion, in the current programming period, and it is good that 20 Member States will use ITI, while CLMD will only be used by 18. Thank you!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, the 2008 Treaty of Lisbon establishes territorial cohesion as one of the Union's main objectives. Territorial cohesion must be supported by cohesion policy and structural funds, in particular funds, in order to avoid territorial and demographic differences, with a view to integration and development in the Member States of the European Union.  The 2014-2020 programming period introduces the tools to strengthen cooperation between public and private actors, as well as policies for more sustainable urban development. In Europe, growth can be generated through networks between major agglomerations and, in the absence of European public intervention, countries tend to prioritise investment for connections to the heart of Europe, to the detriment of suburb. This is why policies aimed at greater territorial cohesion, especially in Romania, where 47% of the population lives in rural areas, are a form of funding so that peoples remain linked to the territory, encouraging income production, development and competitiveness.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, although we are having a serious debate in the Czech Republic about the extent to which cohesion policy and the Structural Funds always deliver only effective and meaningful projects. There are certainly projects that can be doubted. Even so, I believe that this policy makes sense and that the positives outweigh the negatives. This is also why I supported this material and why I welcome the fact that this material brings two new tools that will reach municipalities and cities and through which they will be able to apply for money from European funds for their projects. As I have already said, it is necessary to monitor the level of efficiency of the use of such money, because there are really projects whose effectiveness can be questioned, and secondly, everything must be done so that the administrative burden on the municipality and the city does not harm, destroy them and that only for formal reasons municipalities and towns may not receive money.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, I have just voted against this measure, as I do against all of the things on the Committee on Regional Development that I sit on – and when it comes here – for a very simple point of principle. The people of the UK pay their taxpayers money; it should be going to the UK.  It should be tax representation to the UK; not being distributed across the EU. I am terribly sorry if there are areas in the EU that are poor. I really am. But it should not be funded through British taxpayers’ money. We have our own issues and our own problems, and not least in the West Midlands where I come from, where people cannot get in to see a doctor; they cannot get into the schools they want; people are being thrown out of council houses, and here we are, with British taxpayers’ money being distributed across the EU. Well, I hope the projects go well for the people in the EU. I would rather you paid for them yourself rather than taking them from the British taxpayer.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Cohesion policy plays a central role in the development of European strategies and objectives. Finally implementing the partnership principle, in accordance with the 2014-2020 strategy, will undoubtedly improve the executive effectiveness of European programmes. To this end, two new instruments have been envisaged: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and participatory local development (CLLD). While ITI aims to bring together funds from different programmes to make them multidimensional, the CLLD aims to develop and implement bottom-up strategies for local development. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report, trusting in the need for a multi-level approach that is essential for the successful implementation of regional policies.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report because it is possible to identify some challenges at the present time, such as concerns about increased local influence in certain Member States, a limited budget and the integration of multiple funds.  The main problems identified in the report refer to the lack of trust between different levels of government. In addition, additional, often unnecessary, requirements and obstacles are created at the national and regional levels (so-called overregulation practices) that add additional complexity. To reduce this heavy burden and administrative complexity, the new High-Level Group of Independent Experts on Monitoring Simplification for Beneficiaries of the ESI Funds, recently established by the Commission, is high expectations.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted positively on this resolution because it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to provide greater funding and to share good practices when implementing the two new instruments with the Structural and Cohesion Funds for the period 2014-2020; participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). I am in favour of asking Member States to promote the use of these instruments to improve the management of funds, including in a complementary way, while increasing the upward approach, in order to address the problems of structural unemployment, the integrated development of the least developed regions, the fight against youth unemployment and to provide solutions to the lack of funding for small and medium-sized enterprises , main economic and stable job creation engines. These two tools will only be able to operate within the framework of a fairer cohesion policy, not subject to so-called macro-conditionality, and which enhances the economic diversification of the poorest areas, especially in the southern European Union.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on new territorial development tools as part of the Cohesion Policy 2014-2020: Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Local Development led by local actors (DLAL). These two new territorial development tools would aim to reduce regional disparities by addressing the financing and cash flow problems of SMEs as well as youth unemployment. However, through this approach, which would promote the autonomy of local and regional actors, the Union's powers would be strengthened at the expense of those of the Member States. In addition, it should be noted that with the implementation of these tools, local authorities and intercommunities will be obliged to mobilize substantial financial resources to manage their burden and administrative complexity. The creation of these two tools therefore represents yet another attempt by the EU to appropriate the exclusive competences of the Member States, by weakening their power to intervene in the field of urban development. I therefore strongly opposed this text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained a number of important provisions and in particular the focus on Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) was very welcome. The report was concerned with increasing the use of two new instruments for cohesion funding, namely Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment. ITIs allow for a strategic bundling of funding to meet the goals of priority programmes. These tools, if used more widely with a multi-fund approach, can increase flexible and more appropriate use of cohesion funds for local communities, regions and other sections of society. My party have been supportive and have encouraged the use of Community-Led Local Development as it is focused on a grassroots approach, empowering people from the ground up. As the shadow rapporteur on this file, I introduced a number of amendments to ensure that this bottom-up approach is paramount, as well as ensuring that cross-border regions are better taken into account in the use of this funding. Moreover, CLLD is based on the experience in Ireland of the LEADER approach to funding. My party have fought very hard on the issue of LEADER to ensure that funds are firstly received and secondly distributed evenly, equitably and effectively within the communities that need them.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which encourages Member States to use new instruments for projects to create quality jobs and opportunities for SMEs, stimulate investment, sustainable and inclusive growth and social investment, and contribute to poverty reduction and social inclusion, particularly in regions and sub-regions where this is most needed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which refers to the new territorial development tools within the framework of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy 2001-2020 places great emphasis on the bottom-up approach through the use of integrated and location-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the new tools mentioned in the report will probably be able to help the frequent phenomenon of the inability of local governments to develop and implement strategies for their territory.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report proposes new tools for territorial development aimed at directly addressing local needs and issues, which is a backdoor way for the European Union to expand its areas of intervention in urban policy when this should depend exclusively on The Member States.  I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Under the principle of subsidiarity I believe that cohesion policy is a matter which should be reserved for individual nations, not for the European Union. Consequently I felt that I had no option but to vote against this resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. This resolution introduces new tools for cohesion policy: local development led by local actors (DLAL) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). I believe that territorial cohesion is one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union. These new programmes focus on implementing integrated and territorialized approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Cohesion policy plays a crucial role in the development of the EU’s economy. I voted in favour of this proposal, as it makes it possible to develop and update the policy through introduction of two new mechanisms: Integrated Territorial Investment and Community-Led Local Development. ITI plays a role of a unique platform to combine investments from different funds under priority axes of one or more operational programmes. CLLD provides a bottom-up approach and guarantees that initiatives of local communities will be heard. Regional policy is highly important to unleash the growth potential of the EU and we should make the Cohesion Policy more efficient to strengthen our capacities.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this proposal for new territorial development measures in cohesion policy 2014-2020. The aim of the proposal is to measure the implementation of CLLD and ITI measures. Two new instruments have been introduced for the 2014-2020 programming period: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and community-led local development (CLLD). CLLD is a new tool for use at sub-regional level. It builds on community-led local development experience through the LEADER initiative and is based on a bottom-up approach: it aims to strengthen synergies between local actors, both public and private. Iti will contribute to the implementation of integrated territorial strategies, as this instrument enables funding to be combined from several priority axes of one or more operational programmes. ITI can be used to achieve the objective of sustainable urban development, but they may also be targeted at other territories. I agree with the need to address the problems associated with these programmes, such as the fact that young people are often excluded from the debate on public policy. It is essential to involve young people in territorial development measures, in particular CLLD. In addition, the multi-fund funding opportunities secured by the new regulations should be used as widely as possible to take a truly integrated or holistic approach to intervention under cohesion policy. It is also important that instruments such as ITI and CLLD play a more prominent role in future discussions on cohesion policy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is on two new territorial development instruments, Integrated Territorial Investment and Community-led local development, which are part of the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.  In its explanatory memorandum, the report recalls the need not only for greater flexibility and better integration of EU programmes, but also for generally validated national and regional policies. It also stresses that by guaranteeing a more general approach to governance reform, EU funds should not be directed to national and regional policies within a parallel system, but rather used to achieve sustainable economic outcomes embedded in a broader endeavour. The proposed two instruments already had reservations for the proposers. For example, the Committee on Regional Development has suggested that the idea is complex and that some Member States and regions consider the instrument unnecessary, as coordination with local actors is ongoing. In view of this, the proposed two new instruments do not bring added value and, as they are new instruments, local expertise is not available, which can lead to delays and implementation difficulties. In addition, the development of parallel administrative structures, lack of flexibility, lack of funding for the entire financial planning period and lack of coordination with other development strategies may cause problems in implementation. At the same time, strengthening subsidiarity can be seen as a positive element. Against this all, I abstained at the time of the vote.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report promotes the creation of new tools for territorial development through ITIs (integrated territorial investments) and DLAL (territorial development led by local actors) by developing investments in quality infrastructure, particularly in transport, at a time when public investment is stagnating.  These new investments could, in particular, solve the financing and cash flow problems of SMEs, but not make up for the competitiveness gap they are experiencing as a result of the savage globalization encouraged by the Eurocrats.  Finally, these new tools of territorial development, which bypass state services, are a backdoor way for the Commission to expand its scope of intervention and precisely to deal with local and regional entities over the national authorities of the Member States. So I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The report, which I approved, highlights two new territorial tools in the framework of cohesion policy. Local development led by local actors (DLAL) is a new instrument for sub-regional use. It is based on the experience of the Local Development Leader method conducted by the actors and is based on a bottom-up approach: it aims to strengthen synergies between local actors, both public and private. Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) will contribute to the implementation of integrated territorial strategies as it allows for the pooling of funds from several priority areas of one or more operational programmes. It can be used to achieve the goal of sustainable development in urban areas. Member States should indicate in their partnership agreements how they intend to use the ITI and DLAL, as well as the types of zones and challenges that these mechanisms will be working on.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which aims to give guidance to the new instruments of territorial development in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. These instruments are Participatory Local Development (DLP) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). Its main purpose is to increase the involvement of the social fabric in the development of rural areas, improve funding and give greater flexibility to it that allows for integrated use of funds and an increase in the participation of local actors.  Cohesion policy has been and is essential for the economic and social progress of Spain and Europe. The instruments adopted must improve this policy which is essential to achieve a sustainable economy and reduce territorial inequality as set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy. Communities such as Extremadura, Andalusia or Asturias have the possibility to develop their economies thanks to these funds. At the same time, these instruments require a high degree of transparency as well as good governance between different institutions and governments. A challenge which, if successfully addressed, will help to have a fairer and more cohesive Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, Eurostat reported that 63 regions in 7 EU Member States had unemployment rates of between 2.5 % and 4.9 % while at the same time 7 Member States had rates above 30 %. In a highly diverse context such as this, the key objective role attributed by the EU to the issue of territorial cohesion is becoming increasingly apparent. To achieve this, the European Union has, within the period 2014-2020, equipped itself with a set of innovative instruments aimed at promoting territorial governance and economic and social cohesion. These are specifically integrated territorial investments (ITIs) and participatory local development (CLLD). The Tomašić report, which I supported today with my vote, effectively describes the complexity of the challenges and opportunities offered by these new instruments, highlighting in particular the significant changes they make both in terms of combining funding flows and planning local initiatives. The European Union must make every effort to provide all possible support, training and guidance so that local development strategies have as their priority the fight against youth unemployment and the financing of SMEs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective in the EU Treaties. We voted In favour, since these two tools for territorial development, Participatory Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investment, are oriented in the right direction. We consider it necessary to have an upward, bottom-up approach to cohesion policies and to include the participation of both institutions at various levels and civil society. The report also includes problems such as youth unemployment in many regions, inequality, joint action in border regions, etc. On the other hand, we highlight the failures that occur both in their application and in the disrecognition of these tools, which together with their excessive bureaucracy would be problems to be tackled promptly. While these tools should be further delved into cohesion policies, we believe that the report welcomes the problem in question and proposes a line of citizen participation which we consider essential in cohesion policies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report because it faces two of the problems that explain the remoteness between European citizens and institutions the weakness of the integration of local actors in the upward phase of decision-making processes and the extreme bureaucratic complexity it has for any citizen and even for institutions, especially when they are small, to confront dialogue with European programmes. This is generally negative, but particularly serious in access to programmes that promote territorial balance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on new territorial development tools, namely Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and local development led by local actors (DLAL), should enable, through these tools, to invest in quality infrastructure, particularly in transport.  If we can think that these investments could reduce regional disparities especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and youth unemployment, we can see, for example, that in France the scope of intervention of ITIs corresponds about that of the current policy of the city. So, again subsidies with lost funds in our suburbs for a result that can be predicted in advance, even though medium-sized cities or rural areas will still be forgotten by European policies. Moreover, these tools will further weaken states as this is a bottom-up approach where local and regional actors gain autonomy, even though substantial financial resources will have to be mobilized for the administrative management of these tools. Finally, these tools allow the Union to intervene more and more in the competences of the States, so I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the approach of the two funds, which provide for starting from the needs of the territories to develop investment policies for local development. However, these financial instruments prove to be difficult to manage and overly burdensome for local authorities: they should be simplified to ensure greater and more effective access. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the resolution. The main reason is that the resolution expresses support for so-called structural reforms, which are merely a cover name for austerity policies. It is this devastating economic policy that has not only caused mass unemployment and poverty in Europe, it has also contributed to deepening regional disparities and countering cohesion. The policy has hit women particularly hard and discouraged gender equality. Furthermore, I am critical of the way in which the european cohesion and regional funds have been characterised by fraud and fraud throughout the ages. Despite much talk of action against this, the problem has continued, which puts the existence of the funds as such in question.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Territorial cohesion is one of the types of cohesion referred to in Article 174 TFEU. The 2014-2020 cohesion policy strategy aims to use integrated, local-based approaches to continue to cohesive the Union economically, socially and territorially in line with the 2020 Strategy. Participatory local development and integrated territorial investment are two of the new tools that provide cohesion policy and introduce fundamental changes in the capacity of local authorities to be able to properly guide their initiatives and sources of funding. The empowerment of local authorities is one of the central axes of this policy which aims to correct development imbalances between regions and to take integrated actions in favour of sustainable development.  I supported this report with my vote to continue to face the myriad challenges which, as the document points out, we still have to do on cohesion policy.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and community-led local development (CLLD). Territorial cohesion has been recognised as one of the main objectives of the European Union enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. The next generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period therefore focuses more on the application of integrated and location-based approaches in order to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion. Under the Framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, two new instruments have been introduced in the 2014-2020 programming period in order to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and community-led local development (CLLD). Community-led local development is a new tool for use at sub-regional level. It builds on community-led local development experience through the LEADER initiative and is based on a bottom-up approach: it aims to strengthen synergies between local actors, both public and private. Integrated territorial investment will contribute to the implementation of integrated territorial strategies, as this instrument enables funding to be combined from several priority axes of one or more operational programmes. ITI can be used to achieve the objective of sustainable urban development, but they may also be targeted at other territories.  In the Partnership Agreements, Member States had to specify how they would use ITI and CLLD and what types of areas and problems these mechanisms would be allocated to.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of new territorial development instruments for cohesion policy 2014-2020 requires the development of strategies in the early stages of the implementation process in cooperation with regional and local actors, in particular at the level of vocational training and specialised training and technical and financial support. This will facilitate effective partnership cooperation between regions, Member States and the EU.  I would like to draw attention to the fact that the actions implemented under these instruments must take into account the priorities of local actors and be consistent with the overall objectives of the operational programmes, as well as with other EU, national, regional and local development strategies and smart specialisation strategies. In addition, flexibility should be provided. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ u2012 My fellow Members and I supported the report on new tools for territorial development in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. The Treaty of Lisbon recognised territorial cohesion as a fundamental objective in the development of the European Union.  The Frameworks of the European Structural and Investment Fund (EFSI) constitute two new tools for achieving territorial cohesion, namely integrated territorial investment and the development of local communities. With the adoption of the report, we laid the groundwork for the realisation of the two new tools, both at the implementation level and in the early processes of implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion funds are often used inadequately and partially due to intricate tiered management that limits and slows down their use. Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective of the EU, enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, and its achievement must be supported by a clear division of responsibilities and an integrated approach on the ground. Two new instruments, participatory local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investments (ITIs), were introduced for the 2014-2020 programming period, in order to strengthen a bottom-up approach by consolidating synergies between local public and private actors and enabling priority funding programmes to be identified. However, there are still many challenges: from administrative burdens, management skills, implementation responsibilities to constraints on EU funding and poor alignment with other development strategies. We must ensure that funding measures are used to the greatest extent possible and that the bottom-up approach to managing funds is strengthened. That is why I support this report.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The aim here is to strengthen and facilitate direct dialogue between local or territorial authorities and the European Union, thereby marginalising the role of Member States in regional development. Even if these European funds are intended to tackle the financing and cash flow problems of SMEs, it is clear that this will not be a real answer to the central problem of the lack of competitiveness of these SMEs in the context of globalisation. The aim is therefore to deviously strengthen the EU's scope of intervention in urban policy in opposition to the sovereignty of the Member States. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that cohesion policy is one of the main growth instruments for the European economy and that its role can still be expanded to make it more effective and efficient. In particular, I believe that it is important to achieve greater coordination between national and local policies and european policies and that the short- to medium-term objectives to be pursued are to combat youth unemployment and support SMEs, the real backbone of the European economy.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is an essential instrument for improving the employment of European citizens, while reducing inequalities, poverty and promoting environmentally friendly and inclusive economic growth. From this point of view, I welcome the introduction, within the new 2014-2020 programming, within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, of new instruments such as participatory local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investments (ITIs). These are new capable arrangements, delegating greater responsibilities and management skills at local level, to encourage the development of a type of bottom-up approach that I believe is essential for the full achievement of the objectives of cohesion policy. However, we must work together to facilitate the use of these new mechanisms, in particular by simplifying the administrative burden required and by promoting the establishment of a greater climate of cooperation and trust between the various levels of government, which is essential to ensure that these instruments achieve real results. It is also necessary for national states and European institutions to take active action to support local actors, who often encounter difficulties in designing and implementing local development strategies, in their development and implementation.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report promotes the creation of integrated territorial development tools, which are supposed to compensate for the decline in public investment in Member States as a result of austerity policies imposed by the European Commission.  While these new investments can reduce regional disparities within the Union as part of cohesion policy, it must be admitted that they will not limit the competitiveness deficit that our SMEs suffer as a result of savage globalisation.  Moreover, the implementation of these new tools is based on a bottom-up approach that gives local actors greater autonomy, weakening the power of national authorities. They are indeed a backdoor way for the European Union to extend its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States.  Finally, local authorities will have to mobilise substantial financial resources to manage the administrative complexity of these tools, to the detriment of taxpayers who will once again be called upon to finance the European bureaucracy.  So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy, namely integrated territorial investment and community-led local development, have been developed in response to the many challenges facing Member States, seeking an integrated and territorial approach. The DLRC is a particularly important tool for local communities, as it pursues a bottom-up approach to place responsibility to the community through local action groups. ITI is also a valuable tool as it tracks the region's on-the-ground situation, making a direct contribution to improving the unexplored potential of the area. These tools can strengthen community capacity and foster innovation by encouraging entrepreneurship. I believe that both the DLRC and the ITI must play an even greater role in cohesion policy, requiring active involvement of both local authorities and civil society in the territorial development strategy. I have expressed myself in favour of the new instruments because I believe that, through them, Community development can be achieved, in the interests of citizens, with their active participation.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur, from the ECR Group, considers it difficult to assess the two financial instruments, which came into force under the current MFF. Although the approach of the two funds (bottom-up, i.e. starting from the needs of the territories) is positive, it is noted that the two instruments are complicated to manage for local authorities and costly in administrative terms. The report is critical, although it could have been more critical. On this basis, I am abstaining.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 EU cohesion policy plays a key role in promoting the development of the Union's regions, providing visible solutions that could not have been solved by investing only at national, regional or local level. In view of the challenges at regional level, a crucial role in the shift towards investment in smart, sustainable and inclusive growth is played by cohesion policy 2014-2020, providing solutions by supporting activities that combat climate change, promote more efficient use of energy and create new jobs for young people. At the same time, the new ITI and DLRC territorial development instruments will provide the prerequisites for sustainable and balanced growth of disadvantaged areas. I support this report because, while communities will be encouraged to work together to identify their own development needs and neutralised resources using the DLRC strategy, ITI offers Member States both flexibility in the development of operational programmes and efficiency in implementing integrated actions through simplified funding. These two new instruments can play an important role in adapting to demographic change and reversing development imbalances between regions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the new instruments for territorial development in cohesion policy 2014-2020, which calls on the Member States to make greater use of integrated territorial investment instruments (ITIs) and participatory local development (CLLD) for the implementation of the territorial approach of cohesion policies. The bottom-up approach and the participation of local actors are essential elements for the effectiveness of the Structural Funds and the effective achievement of its objectives. The CLLD also offers opportunities for urban and peri-urban areas and should form an integral part of broader urban development strategies. Its implementation through a single-fund approach, however, can lead to the loss of opportunities in the creation of more effective local development strategies. As far as ITIs are concerned, however, they should not be limited to urban areas alone, but could affect geographical areas such as metropolitan, urban and rural or cross-border areas. It is essential that local partners play their role as key players in the preparation of the territorial development strategy, since it is possible, through this instrument, to take account of specific territorial needs by determining their scope more flexibly.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns increasing the use of two new instruments for cohesion funding, namely Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD). These tools, if used more widely with a multi-fund approach, can increase flexible and more appropriate use of cohesion funds for local communities, regions and other sections of society. CLLD in particular is an important tool, as it rests firmly upon the idea of a ‘bottom-up’ approach, delegating competencies and resources to local actors, and is based on the experience in Ireland of the LEADER approach to funding. ITIs allow for a strategic bundling of funding to meet the goals of priority programmes.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) are two new tools in cohesion policy which aim to help better invest the funds available under EU cohesion policies. These are both of great importance as territorial cohesion is one of the objectives of the European Union and it aims to increase competitiveness and contribute to sustainable development. CLLD is particularly promising as it is based on a bottom-up approach and therefore strengthens the local actors. The report also rightly stresses the crucial role played by the local actors in EU cohesion policies and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses two new cohesion policy instruments: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and participatory local development (CLLD). The former represent a new method of allocation aimed at merting funds from different priority axes of one or more operational programmes. The CLLD, on the other hand, is a tool to be used at sub-regional level and aims to promote the implementation of bottom-up local development strategies. I voted in favour of this report. The text, in fact, on the one hand analyzes the effectiveness and added value of the two instruments, on the other hand it comprehensively outlines the challenges and possible critical issues. Moreover, thanks to the adoption of the amendments tabled by the 5-Star delegation, the report highlights the fundamental importance of minimising potential conflicts of interest in interactions between public and private actors, as well as a non-discriminatory and transparent approach in relations between European, national and regional levels.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Participatory local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investment (ITI) are the new instruments provided by cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 to promote integrated strategies for sustainable urban development. The report voted on today in plenary has highlighted the weaknesses of the two instruments, which are considered by local actors to be too complex and require specific competences that are often not present in administrations, especially if they are small. As far as Italy is concerned, these instruments concern the four regions of the South where, in addition to the objective difficulties encountered by other European regions, it is added that of planning by supplementing the financial resources provided for by the various Structural and Investment Funds.  While I share the view that ITI and CLLD can play an important role in addressing the many closely interrelated challenges facing urban areas (social, demographic, economic and environmental) and can therefore only be overcome through an integrated approach, I believe that action needs to be taken to simplify them also in order to reduce administrative costs.   I hope that the high-level group set up by the Commission will soon be able to identify useful pointers to facilitate accessibility by local authorities. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and underline that the bottom-up approach and the involvement of local actors are crucial to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the new territorial development tools under cohesion policy 2014-2020, on integrated territorial investment and local development at the initiative of local communities is an attempt to strengthen existing financial tools, but also to create new ones. As it aims to create additional job opportunities and improve economic conditions across Europe, I think it is a positive step and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims at a very important objective for the European Union, namely cohesion between the various territories. Indeed, I believe that, in order to achieve this objective, the report takes account of a fundamental element that I myself have learned over the years by working in politics: if we want to achieve strong cohesion, we need a bottom-up approach with the participation of local actors. Support is therefore needed at both national and European level with targeted funding. Having noted that this report takes account of all these elements, which I believe to be basic, I voted in favour, in the hope that we will achieve this important goal as soon as possible, for a united Europe not only on paper but also in practice.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Territorial cohesion was recognised as a fundamental objective of the EU and enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty. Against this backdrop, the new generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period puts greater emphasis on the use of integrated and place-based oriented approaches to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new ERDF regulations stipulate a ring-fenced budget of 5% of expenditure for sustainable urban development. Under the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds two new instruments have been introduced in the 2014-2020 programming period in order to achieve the territorial cohesion objective: Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investments (ITI). In terms of resources allocated to ITIs and CLLD, around 5% of the cohesion policy budget (approximately EUR 16 billion) is expected to be used for these tools. 20 Member States will use ITIs (EUR 13.6 billion), 17 Member States will use ITIs in order to deliver sustainable urban development actions (EUR 7 billion), as stated in Article 7 of the ERDF Regulation. When it comes to CLLD, a total of 18 Member States have expressed their intention to implement it. The take-up is based mostly on the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the existing LEADER programme.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion has been recognised as a fundamental objective of the European Union and enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. In order to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, two new tools have been created for the 2014-2020 programming period: Community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). In order to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy, a bottom-up approach and the participation of local actors is essential. It is essential to include youth in territorial development instruments, in particular in the CLLD. I support the Ruža Tomašić report because if we harness the full potential of cohesion policy, we will be contributing to improving employment opportunities, promoting sustainable and inclusive growth, poverty reduction and social inclusion.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that we have not yet fully exploited the possibilities offered by the two instruments Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and the local development measures (CLLD) carried out by the local population. The path taken is the right one: only with the support and active participation of local actors and the grassroots approach will we achieve a strengthening of territorial cohesion.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon.  By offering the opportunity to improve employment opportunities, promoting sustainable and inclusive growth and promoting poverty reduction and social inclusion, cohesion policy is an instrument of territorial development. In this regard, two new instruments were introduced under the European Structural and Investment Funds in the 2014-2020 programming period to achieve the territorial cohesion objective: participatory local development and integrated territorial investments. I voted in favour of this report, but also considering the considerable challenges that integrated territorial investment entails with regard to implementation by local authorities, which are often unprepared for managing funding. The EU should therefore encourage the use of integrated, land-based approaches aimed at fostering economic, social and territorial cohesion, while also promoting territorial governance.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ There is a learning curve that several Member States are going through based on the experience of implementing LEADER and EQUAL in particular, in previous funding periods. Progress has been registered on the LEADER approach which has led to an exponential increase in Local Action Groups, providing opportunities for community organisations within rural areas to improve the quality of life of the population. However, at the same time, a quicker pace of establishment of these Groups by the Member States is needed since there are several locality organisations which are seeking support. In this regard, it is important for procedures and conditions of implementation to be simplified, not least through the establishment of the High Level Group of Independent Experts on Monitoring Simplification for Beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds and the Commission’s efforts in the field of Better Regulation. This would maximise the potential of LAGs to reflect a bottom-up approach adopted in decision making.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Tomasic report looks at territorial development strategies and delegations of responsibilities and resources at decision-making levels in the Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 programme. The report states that stakeholder involvement can strengthen the integrated and local approach, especially where the use of CLLD (participatory local development) and ITIs (integrated territorial investments) is limited. Local actors require technical and financial support from regional, national and European levels, particularly in the early stages of the implementation process. The report also calls on the Member States to provide support to smaller local situations with limited capacities, stressing that the definition of appropriate and quality strategies is still a challenge today. The report appears to be well done and touches on issues of fundamental importance, which is why I am voting in favour of it.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted positively on this resolution because it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to provide greater funding and to share good practice when implementing the two new instruments with the Structural and Cohesion Funds for the period 2014-2020; participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). I am in favour of asking Member States to promote the use of these instruments to improve the management of funds, including in a complementary way, while increasing the upward approach, in order to address the problems of structural unemployment, the integrated development of the least developed regions, the fight against youth unemployment and to provide solutions to the lack of funding for small and medium-sized enterprises , main economic and stable job creation engines. These two tools will only be able to operate within the framework of a fairer cohesion policy, not subject to so-called macro-conditionality, and which enhances the economic diversification of the poorest areas, especially in the southern European Union.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Coordination between local and regional actors in territorial development strategies is an essential element for the success of territorial policies for the development of urban and rural areas. Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 identified two important tools to foster synergies between the various stakeholders: integrated territorial investments and participatory local development. My vote in favour of this resolution is intended to support integrated national and regional policies aimed at concrete and sustainable results that meet the objectives identified in the EU programmes. I believe that we must above all support the smaller and less developed local situations, where the lack of resources and competences not only aggravates general phenomena such as youth unemployment, but also makes it more difficult to implement the instruments of cohesion policy effectively. I am convinced, in fact, that territorial cohesion starts from the bottom up and that all realities, even the smallest and most peripheral ones, as well as rural ones, must be able to benefit from instruments for planning and implementing local development strategies, without being subject to the overlapping of administrative and financial burdens at national, regional and local level.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion has been recognised as a fundamental objective of the EU and enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. In this context, the new generation of cohesion policies for the period 2014-2020 further emphasises integrated and realities-based approaches in the territory in order to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion. Local actors often do not possess the capacity to develop and implement development strategies that concern their territory. They need support, both at national and Union level. This is particularly important for smaller towns and disadvantaged areas. I voted to make the most of the possibilities of multi-fund financing so that a truly integrated approach to cohesion policy measures can be reached.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is one of the union's fundamental objectives, as set out in the Treaty of Lisbon. Against this background, the new generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 financial engineering period places greater emphasis on approaches that take into account integrated and local needs. Two new instruments were introduced to achieve this objective during the 2014-2020 financial planning period: Community-led local development and Integrated Territorial Investment.  Community-led local development is a new tool that can be used at subregional level. Integrated Territorial Investment will help to implement integrated territorial strategies and can be used to achieve the sustainable urban development objective. I voted in favour of Parliament's own-initiative report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Within the Framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD), initiatives represent significant progress in developing the capacity of local actors to pool funding streams and well-targeted local initiative plans. I believe that the Commission's focus on results and results should also help local policies to move away from over-absorption of funds, towards actually identifying specific targets that will bring about concrete changes. Targeted actions are necessary to adapt these tools closer to local actors and build capacity so that they can participate effectively in strategies targeting their territory. I therefore voted 'yes'.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because ensuring that local people have more say over what happens in their local area is essential, with many people in the UK unsure over how and where EU funds are spent, through the numerous and often complicated EU funding schemes. Providing greater transparency over existing funds will give the public more information, whilst also helping communities have a bigger say over what happens in their local area. To do this, we need much less regulation and burdensome red tape. Whilst, this is one step forward in helping communities have a greater say over what happens in their local area, the EU can do much more to cut regulations, reduce the administrative burden and streamline its various funding processes.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. \u2012 The late adoption of many operational programmes 2014-2020, the complexity of the innovative instruments of cohesion policy, iti - integrated territorial investments and CLLD - participatory local development, implemented for the first time and only by some Member States, do not allow to analyse their effectiveness and added value. The bottom-up approach and the participation of local actors are essential to achieving the objectives, but it must be admitted that local actors often lack the capacity to implement development strategies that affect their territory and therefore need adequate support, both at national and European level. In my opinion, the Commission should present a roadmap indicating which states and operational programmes are most at risk of automatic decommitment of resources. We also need the late payment directive and the public procurement regulations to be properly applied, so that there is a real balance between simplification and measures to prevent errors and fraud, so as to prevent both the misuse of the many billions at our disposal and the infiltration of organised crime. I am, however, voting in favour of the resolution.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Youth unemployment is one of the most pressing problems facing a large number of Member States. In this context, I believe that local and territorial development strategies must include in their absolute priorities combating youth unemployment, taking into account local and regional specificities, as well as promoting public-private partnerships with the development of appropriate vocational training programmes to adapt to labour market developments.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to assess the utilization rate of projects under Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Local Development by Local Actors (DLAL) as part of the Cohesion Policy for the period 2014-2020.  The report advocates the active participation of local actors for effective implementation of cohesion policy and encourages the use of several European Structural Investment Funds (ESIs).  Considering that the European Cohesion Policy requires the development of synergies between local players in order to increase the efficiency of investments on the ground, I have supported these new tools of territorial development.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Since territorial cohesion is one of the main objectives of the European Union, in addition to existing developments, the instruments for the 2014-2020 financial planning period apply an integrated and local needs approach. Under the European Structural and Investment Funds, two new instruments will be introduced: Community-led local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). They are likely to be implemented with 5% of the cohesion policy budget. On the basis of preliminary feedback, ITI will be used in 20 Member States and CLLD in 18.  Clld's difficulties arise primarily from the prominence of actors at local level and the increase in their responsibilities. Member States where LEADER is already employed have a significant experientience advantage. The challenges of the ITI are related to the implementation of tasks of local bodies with limited expertise, the resulting delays and the lack of coordination of other development structures. The problem of both instruments is the increase in administrative burdens, the distrust of Member States influencing territorial development at local level, the limited budget of funds and the integration of several funds. Development strategies should prioritise pressing problems such as youth unemployment, a lack of resources for SMEs or adapting to the new demographic situation. An analysis of the use of the two instruments by the Commission is an important task for the future. On the basis of effectiveness, the need to allocate resources in the regulation of post-2020 cohesion policy will be established.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report promotes the creation of new territorial development tools through ITIs and DLAL. However, in France, the scope of intervention of ITIs is in keeping with the priority geography articulated with the city's policy. More funds will be poured into the suburbs and peri-urban territories.  In addition, local authorities and intercommunities will have to mobilize substantial financial resources to manage the administrative burden and complexity of these tools, despite the creation of a "high-level group of independent experts" to simplify the use of these funds and combat over-regulation.  As urban policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States, which does not have to be exploited by the EU, I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on new territorial development instruments under cohesion policy 2014-2020 because the new initiatives represent an opportunity for local stakeholders to benefit from funding flows and plan targeted local initiatives. The bottom-up approach adopted implies greater involvement of local actors, as well as coordination and better absorption of ESI Funds.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report as the use of ESI Funds creates additional and unnecessary requirements and obstacles at national and regional level. Moreover, high funding for the implementation and implementation of the TSTs and OCTs will in no way lead to the creation of quality jobs. On the contrary, it promotes the smooth integration of refugees and the right to set up their own businesses.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on territorial development in the plenary vote. The report focuses on two instruments, CLLD (Community-Led Local Development) and ITI (Integrated Territorial Investments). The reporter regrets that the two instruments are not fully used by the Member States and analyses the challenges that hinder the use of these instruments.  The bottom-up approach, the involvement of local actors in decision-making, is extremely important, but consultation with local levels should have real added value and should not result in a significant increase in the already complex and complex administrative burden.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: these new tools of territorial development are a backdoor way for the European Union to expand its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States.  In addition, local authorities and intercommunities will need to mobilize substantial financial resources to manage the administrative burden and complexity of these tools.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because, I believe that it is essential to encourage local actors to use the new instruments of territorial investment. This would ensure greater coordination and targeted use of the European Structural Funds and investment funds. It will therefore be important to provide for ad hoc activities aimed at bringing these instruments closer to the local actors so that they can validly participate in the development strategies of their territory.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as I believe it is hypocritical for the EU to preach on employment policies while its ECB arm continues to force Ireland to borrow and burn billions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Multi-fund integration remains a challenge for all stakeholders, in particular in community-led local development and ITI. Extensive simplification efforts are needed to create favourable conditions for the implementation of these instruments. I therefore welcome the establishment of an independent high-level expert group to monitor simplification for beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds and the European Commission's efforts in the field of better regulation. Integrated territorial investments should not be limited to urban areas, but could cover geographical areas such as urban areas, metropolitan areas, urban and rural areas, subregional or cross-border areas. ITI can best take into account specific territorial needs by being more flexible in their territorial scope and thus taking a truly locally oriented approach.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the instruments in question are complicated for local authorities to manage and this report is not critical enough.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as the use of ESI Funds creates additional and unnecessary requirements and obstacles at national and regional level. Moreover, high funding for the implementation and implementation of the TSTs and OCTs will in no way lead to the creation of quality jobs, on the contrary, it promotes the smooth integration of refugees and the right to set up their own businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Two tools – Community-Led Local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investments (ITI) – are the new instruments in the current cohesion policy for this purpose. It is expected that around 5% of the cohesion policy budget will be used for these tools.
