It is still too early to evaluate the effectiveness of these tools, however, some challenges can already be identified, such as fear for increase of local influence in certain Member States, limited budget and the integration of multiple funds. The main problems identified in the report concern the lack of trust between the different levels of government. Furthermore, the often weak capacity of local governments to develop and implement strategies for their territory needs to be mentioned. These tools should help the latter. The current cohesion policy allows for a multi-fund approach which seeks an integrated use of different cohesion policy funds, although this may add to the complexity of the usage. Furthermore, difficult administrative procedures and additional, (unnecessary) legal requirements imposed by Member States (‘gold plating’) may add further complexity to it. This is an issue which needs to be looked at, possibly by the High Level Group of Independent Experts on Monitoring Simplification for beneficiaries of the ESI Funds, recently established by the European Commission.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 As territorial cohesion is one of the union's core objectives, the 2014-2020 financial period places greater emphasis on integrated and local needs approaches in order to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. In this context, community-led local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) instruments can be a solution for better financing and for strengthening synergies between local and public actors. This approach will help to implement territorial strategies.  However, often local actors do not have the capacity to develop and implement development strategies in their area. These actors need support at both national and EU level in order to have these instruments have the desired effects. In order to achieve a holistic approach, multi-fund financing opportunities provided for in the new regulations should be used to the fullest extent possible. The report is heading in the right direction, so I welcome the efforts of the reporter and approve it with a positive vote.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that territorial cohesion must be a fundamental objective of the EU, as enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty. The new generation of cohesion policy programmes for the period 2014-2020 places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and locally based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. We must also work to ensure the participation of local actors, as it is essential to achieve the objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I support these new cohesion policy instruments as they will give new tools to the EU in order to provide local actors and governments with better funding for crucial development projects, part of the cohesion policy. This ‘bottom-up’ approach to development and financing is crucial if the EU is to achieve the objectives of the cohesion policy and we must face all the challenges that these instruments will face in the short term. I believe that the cohesion policy must be a constantly evolving programme to face our modern challenges and I hope that these new instruments can play their part in this. It is very important to overcome any lack of administrative capacity on the side of local actors and then proceed with addressing our changing realities; changing demographics and high unemployment, especially among youths.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on the new instruments for territorial development in cohesion policy 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment (ITI) and participatory local development (CLLD), as I believe that the active involvement of regional and local organisations is crucial to the full implementation of the economic, social and territorial cohesion policy, just as I am convinced that innovative approaches to local knowledge are needed to address local problems. to local solutions. In other words, we need more than ever the policy of economic, social and territorial cohesion in order to address the territorial imbalances that still exist between the various European regions and to give the poorest and most disadvantaged regions the opportunity to converge towards higher levels of growth and income and towards those of the richest regions. I believe that it is in the interests of the European single market to have regions that do not have too many differences between them, because competition in the global economy with the strongest countries can only hold up if Europe has fewer inequalities within it. At the same time, we need an increasing involvement of local actors in the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. Regional development is one of the EU's core concerns , where Europe is also directly felt by citizens and can be experienced in the neighbourhood. This support policy must be constantly developed and improved. I therefore voted in favour of the report 'New instruments for territorial development under cohesion policy 2014-2020' and I hope to see strong impetus for further de-bureaucratisation of procedures.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the promotion and cooperation between the Union's regional actors. To this end, the EU must draw up an appropriate plan on targeted actions and future investments for local actors. The link with young people must not be overlooked either.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The Tomasic report focuses on two new European tools of the Brussels "regional policy" that are supposed to facilitate the territories' access to European funds. As usual, the names are barbaric: DLAL (local development led by local actors) and ITI (integrated territorial investment). Although these are new forms of tools that existed before 2014, the LEADER and PUI programmes, the aim is to further strengthen the financial and other links between the European Union and sub-regional local authorities, to involve them in the consideration and implementation of European policies at their decision-making level, and to justify a European role in national urban policies. The French authorities have of course encouraged these tools, seeing them as a way to compensate, somewhat, for the territorial and financial disengagement of the state. But it must be remembered that these funds, presented as a windfall and a benefit from Brussels, are in fact only a very small return of the French taxpayer's money, since France is a net contributor to the European budget to the tune of 9 billion euros. In addition, they can only complement (capped) other public funding, and their complex implementation has a significant administrative cost. I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective in the EU Treaties. We voted In favour, since these two tools for territorial development, Participatory Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investment, are oriented in the right direction. We consider it necessary to have an upward, bottom-up approach to cohesion policies and to include the participation of both institutions at various levels and civil society. The report also includes problems such as youth unemployment in many regions, inequality, joint action in border regions, etc. On the other hand, we highlight the failures that occur both in their application and in the disrecognition of these tools, which together with their excessive bureaucracy would be problems to be tackled promptly. While these tools should be further delved into cohesion policies, we believe that the report welcomes the problem in question and proposes a line of citizen participation which we consider essential in cohesion policies.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report because territorial cohesion, enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, is a fundamental objective of the EU. The new generation of cohesion policies for the 2014-2020 programming period further emphasises the use of integrated and realities-based approaches in the territory in order to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion. Two new instruments were introduced under the European Structural and Investment Funds in the 2014-2020 programming period to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: Community-led local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investment (ITI).  The contributions of local authorities are essential to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy, but unfortunately in many Member States there can be a lack of trust between the different levels of governance when it comes to the implementation of the CLLD and the ITI, and this can be a serious problem, which can seriously affect the implementation of the territorial approach.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it puts emphasis on the need for integrated and place-based approaches to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion, with an emphasis on bottom-up governance. The report seeks to combat some current issues, such as fear of an increase of local influence in certain Member States, a limited budget for local government and difficulties integrating multiple funds.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. It is not only EU programmes that need to be more flexible and better integrated, but also mainstream national and regional policies. Ensuring a more general spirit of governance reform will help to ensure that EU funds are not delivered in a ‘parallel’ framework to national and regional policies, but rather are embedded in a broader drive to produce sustainable economic outcomes.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Territorial Development Report focuses on two instruments: CLLD (Community-Led Local Development) and ITI (Integrated Territorial Investments). The reporter underlines that the two instruments are not fully used by the Member States and analyses the challenges that hinder the use of these instruments. The bottom-up approach, the involvement of local actors in decision-making, is extremely important, but consultation with local levels should have real added value and should not result in a significant increase in the already complex and complex administrative burden.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that highlights the importance of the new tools available within cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 on Community Led Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investments. I fully support and welcome the creation of the new CLLD instrument, which has gone beyond the LEADER initiative to empower local communities and provide specific local solutions, not only via EAFRD, but also via the other ESI Funds. CLLD offers possibilities for urban areas and should be an integral part of wider urban development strategies, including through cross-border cooperation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The favourable vote is because territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective of the EU, since the Lisbon Treaty. I agree with the bottom-up approach that is outlined in this report. Enhancing territorial cohesion is an aim of the Union and this report outlines an active way of doing so, hence the vote in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it considers youth unemployment to be the most pressing issue for the Member States, together with SMEs’ lack of financing, and stresses that local and territorial development strategies have to address these issues as one of their priorities. The report points out to the Commission that more attention needs to be paid, in the review of that strategy and of the MFF, to regional and local contexts, and to the specific circumstances of the areas concerned. Moreover, improved coordination between the Commission, the Member States and the regions with regard to guidance for these tools is a must.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020: Integrated Territorial Investments (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) as I participated as shadow rapporteur in the preparation of this document and support the application of these two new tools in cohesion policy.  Member States should be encouraged to prepare strategies to strengthen the application of CLLD and ITI through a multi-fund approach to create more effective regional and local development strategies. It is necessary for the Commission and the Member States to develop targeted training activities for regional and local stakeholders for CLLD and ITI. In implementing the ITI, it is essential that local partners play a key role in preparing the ITI territorial development strategy and are fully involved in responsibilities related to governance, supervision and auditing.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. These new territorial development tools aimed at directly addressing local needs and issues are a backdoor way for the European Union to expand its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States. So I decided to vote against the text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to assess the utilization rate of projects related to territorial investment and local development led by local actors, as part of the cohesion policy 2014-2020.  The report supports the bottom-up approach and the participation of local actors by emphasizing the need to strengthen administrative capacity. It also encourages the use of a multi-fund approach and the development of synergies to increase the efficiency of investments.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this report because, regrettably, it offers little substantial added value and, at the same time, does not help to eliminate the still insufficient convergence between Member States.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament resolution on new territorial development instruments under cohesion policy 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment and community-led local development, I supported them because it notes that the tangible involvement of regional and local actors from the outset, their involvement in territorial development strategies, the adoption of these strategies and the appropriate transfer of powers and resources to lower decision-making levels are key to the success of the bottom-up approach , and considers that the involvement of partners can also strengthen an integrated and locally conditional approach. I was happy to encourage the Commission and the Member States to provide additional support, training and advice to small and less developed sites, which have only more modest resources and capacities and which may find it difficult to cope with the administrative burden and complexity associated with the implementation of these instruments during planning and implementation, and recalled that territorial cohesion must be based on the bottom up and must also include small administrative bodies which must not be eliminated or discriminated against in any way. I believe that the possibilities of investment in territorial development are not yet sufficiently known in the Czech Republic and we are losing the possibilities for development because of this.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on territorial development in the plenary vote. The report focuses on two instruments, CLLD (Community-Led Local Development) and ITI (Integrated Territorial Investments). The reporter regrets that the two instruments are not fully used by the Member States and analyses the challenges that hinder the use of these instruments.  The bottom-up approach, the involvement of local actors in decision-making, is extremely important, but consultation with local levels should have real added value and should not result in a significant increase in the already complex and complex administrative burden.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Two new tools were created for the "Cohesion Policy" for the period 2014-2020 in order to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: the Community leadership for Local Development "Community-Led Local Development" (CLLD) and integrated territorial investments "Integrated Territorial Investments" (ITI). I voted in favour of the report because it promotes better political cohesion in the Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the report providing for the establishment of new instruments for territorial development in cohesion policy 2014-2020. Territorial cohesion is one of the EU's key objectives, supported through integrated approaches that improve the efficiency of public intervention in the territory. In this respect, the Framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) has introduced two new measures to achieve the objectives of territorial cohesion. These new instruments include participatory local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). The report we are voting on today aims at an analysis of the programming and implementation of clld and IT, identifying the main problems affecting it and the possible recommendations for better implementation of these tools. By putting these measures into practice, we want to allow greater participation by local members and, therefore, promote an approach that starts from our communities and subsequently leads to the achievement of our common objectives.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on new territorial development tools as part of the Cohesion Policy 2014-2020.  New investments could help reduce regional disparities in cohesion policy, including addressing SME financing and cash flow problems and youth unemployment.  Nevertheless, the increase in budgetary transfers in the European Union will not limit the competitiveness deficit experienced by our SMEs because of the savage globalisation. Moreover, the implementation of these new tools is essentially based on an approach by which local and regional actors gain autonomy, further weakening the power of national authorities. These initiatives should be solely the responsibility of the Member States. In addition, local authorities and intercommunities will need to mobilize substantial financial resources to manage the administrative burden and complexity of these tools. Finally, these new tools of territorial development, whose aim is to respond directly to local needs and issues, are a backdoor way for the European Union to extend its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Indeed, under the pretext of facilitating the release of European funds for territories with low administrative capacity, integrated territorial investments (ITIs) strengthen the prerogatives of local authorities and intercommunities to the detriment of states.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. In the context of the development of territories and local authorities, the report proposes to create new tools, the ITI (integrated territorial investment) and the DLAL (local development led by local actors).  However, the scope of these tools in France focuses on priority geography, thus suburbs and peri-urban territories. These investments favour local actors, which weakens the role and legitimacy of the sovereign state.  It is clear that the EU aims to extend its scope of action on the prerogatives of the Member States. I am firmly opposed to this policy and vote AGAINST.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because although it is too early to assess the effectiveness of the new tools, the report identifies some of the current challenges, such as concerns about increased local influence in certain Member States, a limited budget and the integration of multiple funds.  The report, in addition to reflecting all of the above, also refers to the lack of trust between the different levels of government that create additional, often unnecessary, requirements and obstacles at the national and regional levels (so-called overregulation practices) that add more complexity.  The report also states that in order to reduce the heavy burden and administrative complexity, a new high-level group of independent experts will monitor simplification for beneficiaries of the ESI Funds, recently established by the Commission.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted positively on this resolution because it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to provide greater funding and to share good practices when implementing the two new instruments with the Structural and Cohesion Funds for the period 2014-2020; participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). I am in favour of asking Member States to promote the use of these instruments to improve the management of funds, including in a complementary way, while increasing the upward approach, in order to address the problems of structural unemployment, the integrated development of the least developed regions, the fight against youth unemployment and to provide solutions to the lack of funding for small and medium-sized enterprises , main economic and stable job creation engines. These two tools will only be able to operate within the framework of a fairer cohesion policy, not subject to so-called macro-conditionality, and which enhances the economic diversification of the poorest areas, especially in the southern European Union.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. •u2012 Territorial cohesion in the EU is recognised in the Lisbon Treaty as a fundamental objective. On this basis, we must identify the challenges and promote new instruments in order to achieve the social, economic and territorial cohesion goals set for the coming years. I believe that political governance is essential to achieving the desired effects. In this way, the new tools we propose in this report support both at national and European level the management of funds by responsible actors, as they often lack the capacity to develop and implement the development strategies that concern their territories. I would like to emphasize that it is vital to include young people in all these instruments of territorial development, to combat youth unemployment and to help strengthen the link between generations within these communities.  For the reasons set out above, and while I believe that we can still make further progress in reducing complexity and administrative burden, I welcome its approval.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 It is an unnecessary report full of corny phrases and calls for activist subsidy and tax policy. According to the report, 'youth unemployment is the most pressing problem in the Member States, together with the lack of funding for SMEs'. The report "underlines that the local and territorial development strategy must address these challenges as one of its priorities; calls on local and regional authorities to introduce tax and other incentives to promote employment and interregional mobility of young people and to put training at the forefront in partnership with training institutions". I don't think the EU should be talking about national economic policy. Rather than introducing special incentives and programmes for SMEs, I think it is better to have generally low taxes and limited bureaucracy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The report refers to new, innovative cohesion policy instruments that can make a significant contribution to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality local jobs, sustainable development and achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Two new INITIATIVES under ITI and CLLD can play an important role in adapting to demographic change and correcting imbalances in regional development.  Community-led local development (CLLD) has a bottom-up approach, strengthens local communities and provides specific local solutions under the ESI Funds. When implementing integrated territorial investments (ITIs), it is essential that local partners play a key role in preparing the territorial development strategy and are involved in governance, supervision and auditing. Member States should use these instruments on projects to create quality jobs and new opportunities for SMEs, to boost investment, sustainable and inclusive development and social investment. To this end, it is important to combine financial instruments, in particular the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund. Strengthening regional and local structures is essential for the full implementation of economic, social and territorial cohesion policy, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Structural and Investment Funds are introducing two instruments for achieving the territorial cohesion objective in the 2014-2020 programming period. The first is community-led local development, based on LEADER knowledge and based on a bottom-up approach. The second instrument is integrated territorial investments, which allow the financing of integrated territorial strategies by pooling funding from several priority areas of one or more operational programmes. Effective cooperation between the two instruments is needed for the correct and efficient use of these instruments. Local communities must use their immediate knowledge and experience from local locations, the cooperation of public and private actors. This will allow them to develop a more comprehensive and realistic local development strategy. Integrated territorial investments must be the professional guarantor of the projects. In doing so, we must place emphasis on effective assistance, flexibility and the removal of unnecessary administrative obstacles.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the new territorial development tools under cohesion policy 2014-2020: Integrated Spatial Investment (OCT) and local development at the initiative of local communities, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/5/2016 and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report concerns the creation of new financing tools, within the framework of integrated territorial investment and local development programmes led by local actors. The scope of these new financing tools is broad, from youth unemployment to the financing needs of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The areas affected by these funding tools correspond to the priority areas defined in France under the city's policy. We oppose this report for the following reasons: - the introduction of new European financial transfers to areas that already receive national subsidies does not appear to us to be an appropriate solution to the economic and social difficulties of those areas; The management of these funds relies on local authorities. This method of organisation is part of the European regionalisation strategy, to the detriment of the competences of the Member States; We are concerned about the operating costs that will result from the management of these funds by local authorities.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new instruments for territorial development in cohesion policy 2014 - 2020. Cohesion policy and territorial cohesion are among the European Union's priority objectives enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon.  In fact, two new instruments have been introduced under the European Structural and Investment Funds for the 2014-2020 programming period to achieve the territorial cohesion objective: participatory local development (CLLD), a new instrument to be used at sub-regional level, and integrated territorial investments (ITIs), used to achieve the sustainable urban development objective, as well as being used for other types of territory.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The bottom-up approach to territorial development requires more support from the UNION level, as well as from regional and national governments. As expressed in the report, local actors need better funding and better technology to be more effective in their action. The EU should encourage the exchange of good practice between European regions. In the end, creating jobs is the most important issue together with support for SMEs in underdeveloped regions. In too many of these regions, young people and women are hampered by a lack of education and opportunities, so this should be our first priority when working on these regions. I voted in favour of this report because all the issues mentioned are addressed.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the report on the new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which includes integrated territorial investment and the promotion of participatory local development. Collaborative strategies with regional and local actors need to be established in the early stages of the implementation process, in particular in the area of specific and special training and technical and economic support, in the context of an effective partnership between regions, Member States and the EU.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon defines territorial cohesion in Article 174 as one of the union's main and fundamental objectives. Therefore, programming for the years 2014-2020 could not be without focusing on territorial development and social and economic cohesion. The programming sets out two new tools that will contribute to territorial development and these are the Local Development initiative of the Local Communities (TPTK) and the Integrated Spatial Investment (OCT). The TACP will operate, as the report says, at subregional level and will be based on the initiative of local communities, which will be able to cooperate with private and public bodies. On the other hand, the OCT will contribute to sustainable urban development by pooling funds from the various operational programmes. For both territorial development tools there are challenges, such as the complexity of their implementation, their acceptance by local actors, the lack of expertise, the possible lack of flexibility and satisfactory guidance by the Commission and finally the increase in administrative burden. Nevertheless, I would like to vote in favour of the report in the belief that with a careful strategy these tools will be able to make a significant contribution to achieving the objective of territorial development within the framework of cohesion policy.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the EP's report on new cohesion policy instruments- integrated territorial investment (ITI) and community-led local development (CLLD), because I believe that these measures will contribute to economic, social and territorial cohesion and to the creation of quality local jobs.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report which evaluates the EU’s cohesion policy, particularly Integrated Territorial Investments (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development projects. The report offers recommendations that will help the effectiveness of these initiatives.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report stresses the rapid implementation of two new tools of cohesion policy: Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Local Development led by local actors (DLAL).  Behind this bureaucratic gibberish, one objective: to increase the voice of private actors in territorial projects. Under the guise of "good governance" is the promotion of public-private partnerships. Companies with the means and expertise win the market delegated by the public or the dominant voice in the local project. Not the associations. And it is in the process the loss of state expertise and resources to plan coherent projects between territories.  The report pushes ignominy to the point of supporting "provisions establishing that neither government nor any interest group can hold more than 49% of voting rights in LAGs", local action groups that supposedly mix these different actors equally to promote "integrated and multi-sector innovative strategies".  In this context, the desire to help small communities or tax incentives for the employment of young people or seniors will remain wishful thinking. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report would like to launch new investments through European programmes (DLAL and ITI) in order to achieve the Europe 2020 social cohesion targets. The use of these programmes will not solve the competitiveness deficit of SMEs in the face of the ultraliberalism advocated by Brussels. These measures will weaken local authorities. I do not forget that these instruments are a major means for the EU to expand. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective of the European Union, enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. The 2014-2020 generation of cohesion policy provides for and encourages the use of integrated and local-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion as well as territorial governance. Integrated and local-based approaches are to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of public intervention, responding to the specific needs of the territories and promoting their attractiveness. It is therefore necessary to define strategies at the first stages of the implementation process, in collaboration with regional and local actors, in particular at the level of specific and specialised training, technical and financial support, in the context of an effective partnership between regions, Member States and the EU. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which provides expertise concerning the tools applied in the EU’s cohesion policy, allowing us to implement this policy more effectively and successfully.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Innovation is not just a matter of bringing new products to market or introducing new production processes. Policy also needs innovation, and sometimes the innovative nature of a new approach lies in the introduction of obvious elements and actors in the decision-making process.  This report rightly makes a strong case for a bottom-up approach to cohesion policy. Prioritizing local knowledge to address local problems with local solutions can help improve the efficiency and effectiveness of government action. That way, you can better anticipate the specific needs of the people in an area. Tackling youth unemployment and caring for the ageing population are current challenges in which the knowledge of local actors can contribute significantly to the realisation of sustainable local employment and social cohesion. Local development driven by the local community, with technical and financial guidance and support from the regional, national and European levels, increases the chances of a successful cohesion policy.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – One of the fundamental objectives enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon is to maintain territorial cohesion. The next generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places greater emphasis on using integrated and locally oriented approaches to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new regulations on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) provide for a fixed budget of 5% of expenditure on sustainable urban development. For the 2014-2020 programming period, two new instruments are envisaged. The first is community-led local development, which is used at sub-regional level and aims to strengthen synergies between local actors, both public and private. Integrated territorial investments, as a second instrument, will contribute to the implementation of integrated territorial strategies, as they make it possible to pool funding from several priority areas of one or more operational programmes. 5% of the cohesion policy budget (around EUR 16 billion) is planned to be allocated to these instruments. These instruments will help local actors develop their capacities so that they can successfully participate in strategies aimed at their territory. Personally, I very much welcome the bottom-up approach and the active involvement of local actors, and the proposal has my full support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the new territorial development tools in cohesion policy 2014-2020 because I am in agreement with the report as it makes reference to small cities and the need to take into account the territorial dimension and specific needs. The reference to small cities is important since this reflects the Riga Declaration which requires that cities are not generalised but categorised by their size and context. For this reason, I have supported the report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is one of the union's fundamental objectives. In order to achieve this, two new instruments were introduced under the European Structural and Investment Funds during the 2014-2020 financial planning period: Community-led local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). CLLD is a new tool that can be used at subregional level, based on LEADER's community-led local development experience and a bottom-up approach. The ITI will assist in the implementation of integrated territorial strategies by allowing funding from several priority axes of one or more operational programmes to be linked. The Report of the Committee on Regional Development considers the challenges faced so far with regard to the application of the two new instruments and makes recommendations for responses to these challenges. I voted in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. These new investments could help reduce regional disparities in cohesion policy, including addressing SME financing and cash flow problems and youth unemployment.  But in France, their scope of intervention intersects with the city's policy. As a result, more money will be poured into the suburbs. Moreover, the increase in budgetary transfers in the European Union will not limit the competitiveness deficit experienced by our SMEs because of the savage globalisation. These new tools of territorial development further weaken the power of national authorities, local authorities and intercommunities will have to mobilize substantial financial resources to manage the burden and administrative complexity of these tools. Vote against it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is one of the objectives promoted by the Union, in line with Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The EU cohesion policy framework for the period 2014-2020 provides for and encourages the use of integrated and local-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion as well as territorial governance. In this context, community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) initiatives are innovative cohesion policy tools and can contribute significantly to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality local jobs, sustainable urban development and achieving the europe 2020 objectives. I therefore vote in the favourable direction, because I believe that the strengthening of regional and local structures is essential for the full implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The implementation of these new tools for territorial development is essentially based on a bottom-up approach where local and regional actors gain autonomy, further weakening the power of national authorities. These new territorial development tools aimed at directly addressing local needs and issues are a backdoor way for the European Union to expand its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The harmonious development of the Union, through the strengthening of its economic, social and territorial integration, is a central objective of the EU's cohesion policy. It goes in the desired direction, and i therefore voted in favour, for the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to allocate a budget of 5% of expenditure (EUR 16 billion) for the introduction of two new instruments in the 2014-2020 programming period. On the one hand, participatory local development (CLLD) with the aim of strengthening synergies between local actors, both public and private, and integrated territorial investments (ITIs) that can be used to achieve the sustainable urban development objective, as well as being used for other types of territory. Two important initiatives towards ever closer cooperation between local actors and an incentive for a bottom-up approach to cohesion policies. Our commitment at European level to implementing these instruments together with local actors and to strengthening their capacities, while respecting the national constraints to which they are subject, cannot be strained. I therefore hope that these instruments will become increasingly important in the practice of cohesion policy in the future.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion has always been very important for the European Union. I am pleased that this subject of particular importance remains one of the main objectives and that the European Parliament is constantly looking for tools that can make the cohesion process even more effective. The report intends to create two new instruments within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds, which it calls Community-led local development and Integrated Territorial Investment.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ One of the fundamental objectives of the European Union is territorial cohesion. I have voted for this report that will bring a new tool to be used at sub-regional level based on the Leader experience of community-led local development. The new tools can also be used for delivering the sustainable urban development objective.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment and community-led local development. Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-led Local Development (DLRC) are innovative instruments in cohesion policy, which some Member States will implement in this form for the first time and which can contribute significantly to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality jobs at local level, sustainable development and achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. We call for the development of strategies in the early stages of the implementation process with regional and local actors, in particular with regard to specific and specialist training, technical and financial support, as a result of a genuine partnership between regions, Member States and the EU. While measures adopted under these instruments must take into account the priorities of local actors, they must be aligned with the overall objectives of the operational programmes, as well as with other national, regional and local development strategies and smart specialisation strategies, allowing for margins of flexibility.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ Decentralisation of decision-making to regional and local actors is central to strengthening the objectives of the cohesion policy. I support this resolution and the creation of the Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) tools as they will allow local stakeholders, well informed about the specific regional or local needs of their communities, to participate for example in making decisions on how best to use funds to create high-quality jobs to spur growth and ensure a more even economic and social development across EU regions in line with the objectives of the cohesion policy for 2014-2020.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on two new cohesion policy instruments aimed at promoting the development of rural and urban areas. I see their contribution as placing emphasis on integrated investments that should help sustainable development. I consider it important that both instruments are built on a bottom-up approach, i.e. to strengthen the cooperation of local (rural or urban) public and private actors. This is an opportunity for our cities and municipalities and it will depend on them to take advantage of it by being able to put forward quality projects in the area of sustainable rural and urban development.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report itself has not changed. For me, this report is indefensible, as it mainly contains propagandistic added value.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Community-led local development and ITI should become increasingly important, and Member States could make more use of them. The report addresses the various problems that have arisen, starting with the complex approach of resources to the Member States, who fear their potential impact. New opportunities must be exploited, young people must also be involved, additional and unnecessary requirements and obstacles must also be waived at national and regional level, and solutions must also be found to simplify.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  In particular, cohesion policy 2014-2020 must pay particular attention to new territorial development measures. Integrated territorial investment and community-led local development will allow for a more efficient uptake of cohesion policy budgets and help reduce socio-economic disparities. It is therefore important to facilitate the use of these measures in order to promote the active participation of local and regional actors.  Given the importance of technical and financial support, it is necessary to establish strategies for the initial stages of the implementation process and strategies for technical and financial support. In addition, it should be possible to use a multi-source funding approach to help develop more effective regional and local development strategies.  In order to improve employment and sustainable and inclusive growth, to promote poverty reduction and social inclusion, tax and other incentives should be considered. Regions should be able to benefit more effectively from the benefits of the social investment package. A specific investment programme should be drawn up for this purpose.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The new development of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and location-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. To achieve this objective, two new instruments have been introduced for the 2014-2020 programming period: Local Development at the Initiative of Local Communities (CAPC) and Integrated Spatial Investment (OCT). I voted in favour of this report, which emphasises the importance of the bottom-up approach, since the involvement of local actors is crucial to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Mrs Tomašić's proposal, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour, as I believe that the adoption of an integrated territorial approach is a particularly good instrument for the development of European cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Indeed, I am convinced that these approaches make it possible to pay particular attention to territorial specificities and attract more investment. In the same way, I believe that focusing on bottom-up local development can be particularly beneficial in enhancing the role of local and regional actors. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Every person on our planet is affected by their surroundings and environment. Working together and developing new tools to tackle problems linked to territorial development is key to developing solid partnerships across Europe and beyond. The integrated territorial instruments provide a flexible mechanism for formulating integrated responses to diverse territorial needs, without losing the thematic focus through which cohesion policy is linked to the Europe 2020 Strategy. Therefore, I vote in favour of the new territorial development tools in cohesion policy 2014-2020.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Community-led local development and integrated territorial investments are innovative tools that will be put into use by some Member States for the first time in the proposed form, which can make a significant contribution to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality local jobs, sustainable development and achieving the objectives of European strategies, all of which I warmly welcome.  The new initiatives under these instruments represent significant changes in the ability of local stakeholders to combine forms of funding and plan well-targeted local initiatives. As the European Union policy for the period 2014-2020 enables and encourages the application of those approaches that focus on specific areas, which aim to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion while promoting territorial governance, I support the Report and supported the proposed Resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the need to imagine new strategies involving local and regional actors who need to be provided technical and financial support in the context of an effective partnership between the regions, the Member States and the EU. The interest in an integrated approach on a territorial basis is supported by the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period, and is important for greater flexibility of EU programmes and better use of European funds provided in line with local specificities, in order to achieve sustainable economic results and to act on structural problems, first of which youth unemployment. The Commission and the Member States must provide additional support, training and guidance to smaller and less developed local realities, which have more limited resources and capacities and for which the administrative burden and complexity associated with the implementation of these instruments could be difficult to manage in the programming and implementation phases.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. I agree with the rapporteur that youth unemployment is one of the problems for Member States that needs to be addressed most urgently, together with the lack of funding for SMEs. I underline that local and territorial development strategies need to address these issues as one of the priorities. I also call on local and regional authorities to provide tax and other incentives to encourage youth employment and interregional mobility of young people and, in partnership with training facilities, to prioritise vocational training. I welcome the creation of a new Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) tool that offers more than LEADER, strengthens local communities and provides specific local solutions not only within the EAFRD but also through other European Structural and Investment Funds. I note that different approaches to governance can be applied in the implementation of 'Integrated Territorial Investment' (ITI), but nevertheless I think it is essential that local partners play a key role in preparing the ITI territorial development strategy and are fully involved in the responsibilities related to governance, oversight and auditing, ensuring that local stakeholders are really responsible for ITI interventions.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This report focuses on the role of local and regional authorities as enhancers of regional development and, consequently, promoting territorial and social cohesion and potentially absorbing structures of the various EU funds and funding that aim to promote such cohesion and development. Today, more than 75% of EU citizens live in an urban context, with growing needs in terms of their political, social, economic and cultural organisation. In the European context, there are cities that alone have more population and infrastructure than certain countries or regions of the Union. The city context is thus increasingly decisive in the management of the public thing. The eu-wide response pursues the federalist logic through direct communication between the European Commission and "cities", without the intermediation of Member States, ignoring their prioritisation for their regions, a view we reject. A logic is put to cohesion policies that link the cohesion funds themselves to the entire financing strategy associated with the so-called Juncker Plan - which aims to directly finance private individuals and make cohesion policy subject to macroeconomic reforms. Even considering these fundamental caveats, it is understood to be important to support policies that effectively aim at promoting territorial cohesion.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support MP Tomašić's report stressing the importance of a bottom-up approach in territorial cohesion policy-making through an assessment of past successes, achieved primarily through tools from integrated territorial investment (ITI) initiatives and community-led local development initiatives (CLLD). Successful local and regional development strategies must take into account a number of factors, such as satisfactory EU financial support, how to tackle unemployment, finance small and medium-sized enterprises, strengthen technological capabilities and social infrastructure. The report recalls that easier access to less developed regions through iti and CLLD tools also entails greater EU engagement, primarily by providing access to finance for those regions and local communities in need. Such an approach also calls for the reduction of unnecessary regulation in relations between European institutional mechanisms with local, regional and national levels, which should ultimately result in the achievement of the objectives set in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020.  I welcome the need to analyse the shortcomings of ITI and CLLD tools so far in order to correct them and to make the tools effective in combating some of the pressing problems of EU member states, such as unemployment.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on integrated territorial investment and community-led local development, as European economic, social and territorial cohesion policy requires strong regional and local authorities that are directly confronted and have an overview of local problems. It is essential that these authorities establish their strategic advantages in a committed way, on the basis of which their development strategy can be compiled to improve the quality of life of citizens. Although the measures taken must be aligned with the general objectives of the operational programmes and other eu or national development strategies, we must not forget that they must be based in particular on the priorities of local actors. I voted in favour of greater flexibility in the European Union's programmes, but also in national and regional development programmes. It is not possible for beneficiaries to create unnecessary obstacles and administrative requirements, thus creating nonsensical barriers to the necessary development. I also supported the partnership between the private and public sectors, which should facilitate investment activities at local level. At the same time, However, I voted in favour of a transparent and non-discriminatory approach to avoid possible conflicts of interest between private sector representatives and the public. In order to successfully implement, simplify and solve territorial development policy, the European Commission, the Member States of the European Union and their regions need to communicate better with each other. I therefore also supported the need to increase coordination between these entities.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which evaluates the newly created financial instruments under cohesion policy. The two instruments, community-led local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI), were developed to achieve the objectives set out in the framework of territorial cohesion. The main objectives that these instruments help to achieve are improving youth employment and improving the financing of SMEs. Thanks to CLLD and ITI, these problems should be addressed within the framework of the territorial and local development strategy. The main approach of both programmes is a bottom-up approach. While CLLD strives for synergies between local and public actors, ITI can be used to achieve urban development or to develop other types of territory. However, in order for this system to work, regional and local actors need to be permanently involved in the setting up of these instruments, while providing technical and financial support.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and needs-based approaches of territories to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new ERDF Regulation provides for the allocation of 5% of its budget for sustainable urban development. Two new instruments have been introduced under the European Structural and Investment Funds to achieve this objective: participatory local development (CLLD). As mentioned earlier, around 5% of the cohesion policy budget (around EUR 16 billion) is expected to be used for these instruments. If the objectives of cohesion policy are to have the desired effect, there is a need for adequate economic support at European level, to be allocated, above all, to the most peripheral and disadvantaged areas such as islands and mountain areas. I voted in favour of this report and I hope that instruments such as ITIs and CLLDs will play an increasingly central role.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Within the Framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD), initiatives represent significant progress in developing the capacity of local actors to pool funding streams and well-targeted local initiative plans. The Commission's focus on results and results should also help local policy to move away from over-absorption of funds towards actually identifying specific targets that will bring about concrete changes for local businesses and residents.  Member States were required to indicate in their partnership agreements how ITI and CLLD would be applied by Member States and to identify the types of areas and challenges they cover. A bottom-up approach is of paramount importance, as is the participation of local actors in the use of new instruments that will contribute to improving coordination and more targeted use of ESI Funds. Targeted actions are necessary to adapt these tools closer to local actors and build capacity so that they can participate effectively in strategies targeting their territory. It is also important to make use of the multi-fund opportunities achieved with the new rules, which should be applied in order to achieve a truly integrated/holistic approach to cohesion policy interventions. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Cohesion between European territories is one of the foundations of the European Union. To achieve this, some tools are being implemented, such as the European Structural and Investment Funds (ISFs) aimed at promoting integrated territorial investment (ITI) as well as local development led by local actors (DLAL).  I voted in favour of this report, which assesses the utilization rate of projects under these two objectives and mentions the importance of including more local actors in project management. It is these actors, at the local level, who are the driving force behind European cohesion policy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We voted against this because this scheme is yet more EU corporate nonsense intended to spread misleading pro-EU propaganda using British taxpayers’ money to fund it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Effective use of public funds, the fight against waste and mismanagement are golden rules that no public policy should deviate from.  For example, the adoption of the Tomasic report on new territorial development tools in the framework of the 2014-2020 cohesion policy must be evaluated favourably.  Local development led by local actors (DLAL), which aims to strengthen synergies between local actors, both public and private, and integrated territorial investment (ITI), which allows the pooling of funds from several priority areas to achieve sustainable development goals, are the two new tools for territorial cohesion. Clear strategic choices have been made, with at least 5% of the ERDF's resources now being invested in urban areas.  The continued support of the Dutch Presidency of the Council for the future European urban agenda through the drafting of the Amsterdam Pact is a step in the right direction. It is also a sign of the Union's new desire to resolutely embark on a more innovative and economical cohesion policy serving cities and urban areas.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which focuses on two new instruments to support the territories under the 2014-2020 Cohesion Policy: the Instruments "Integrated Territorial Investment" (ITI) and "Local Development led by Local Actors" (DLAL). Cohesion policy is, let us remember, the Main Investment Policy of the Union and must, in particular, contribute to the fight against unemployment and meet the financing needs of SMEs. Local actors should the appropriateness of these new instruments and provide technical and financial support.  The participation of local actors in cohesion policy, through a bottom-up approach, contributes to the creation of a necessary link between the Union and its territories.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The new generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and local-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. In this sense, two new tools were created in the 2014-2020 programming period in order to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: Community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). As a member of the REGI Commission designated by the Group of European Socialists to monitor the report, I managed to get 36 amendments included in the final text put to the vote. I ensured that the regional and local dimension of this funding was not misrepresented in the document, ensuring: the necessary technical support at the level of specialised training to address the difficulties in implementing these instruments; the importance of local and regional authorities not taking such a dominant position in local action groups that conditions initiatives from other social entities; the adaptation of regional and local projects to demographic change in order to try to reverse the resulting imbalances; avoiding duplication of coordination structures; dissemination of these instruments to local government and an efficient evaluation at process and results level.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Territorial cohesion is one of the types of cohesion referred to in Article 174 TFEU. The 2014-2020 cohesion policy strategy aims to use integrated, local-based approaches to continue to cohesive economically, socially and territorially the EU in line with the 2020 Strategy. Participatory Local Development (DLP) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) are two of the new tools that the Cohesion Policy is equipped with and that introduce fundamental changes in the capacity of local authorities to be able to correctly guide their initiatives and sources of funding. The empowerment of local authorities is one of the central axes of this policy that aims to correct development imbalances between regions and to take integrated actions in favour of development that is also sustainable.  I supported this report with my vote to continue to face the myriad challenges which, as highlighted in the document, we still have to do on cohesion policy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The text adopted yesterday urges Member States to put an end to their distrust of local authorities and to better integrate them into the use of these two new instruments of cohesion policy. Recalling the lack of financial and human resources suffered by several local and regional authorities, the European Parliament called on the Commission and the Member States to support localities and regions also through training and advisory services for smaller entities in particular, in order to limit territorial discrimination. The text also calls on the Commission to draw up a European picture of practices and to break them down as widely as possible, including through online platforms, and also encourages small administrative entities to come together to streamline resources in order to make the most of the possibilities of these instruments. As a reminder, urban policy is one of the highest priorities of the Dutch Presidency of the Council of the European Union, which is expected to adopt the Amsterdam Pact on 30 May, a pact that enshrines the urban agenda.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 As a politician who has worked for two decades in the field of regional development, I can only welcome the provisions of the report, which propose to increase the role of the integrated territorial development and community-initiated local development methodologies established in the previous financial period. I am pleased that the rapporteur has accepted our proposals on standards for the activities of local action groups, and has also paid due attention to the issues of public engagement, local administrative capacity, ownership of EU-funded activities.  At the same time, I would like to stress that the cornerstone of stable growth is a stable legal environment. I am therefore pleased that the report focuses on strengthening the territorial development instruments already tested. The results of the previous financial period confirm the effectiveness of local development mechanisms based on the involvement of local communities and the bottom-up approach. It is now only the task that remains for us to ensure that communities and other beneficiaries of European Union aid can fully exploit the potential of existing territorial development instruments.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective of the European Union, enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty. Cohesion policy 2014-2020 therefore focuses on an integrated and territorialised approach to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. Two new tools have been put in place to achieve this goal: local development led by local actors (DLAL) and integrated territorial investment (ITI), which will account for about 5% of the cohesion policy budget (16 billion euros).  Although it is still too early to make a real assessment, the report by Rua Toma-i, provides an initial assessment of the problems, challenges and perspectives associated with these tools. The lack of trust between different levels of government or the weak capacity of local governments to develop comprehensive strategies for their territories are thus identified.  These tools must be able to remedy these problems, by promoting a rationalised use of European funds, without creating an administrative complexity that is still far too present. The approach proposed by the DLAL and the ITI should be part of future debates on cohesion policy.  I voted for this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion has been recognised as a fundamental objective of the European Union, enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon - a new dimension that has been in addition to the objectives of social cohesion and economic cohesion previously considered (since 1986). In this context, the new generation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and local-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new ERDF Regulation also establishes a budget limited to specific purposes of 5% of expenditure for sustainable urban development. Under the European Structural and Investment Funds, two new tools were created in the 2014-2020 programming period to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: Community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). This report aims to assess the implementation of iti and CLLD initiatives under Cohesion Policy 2014-2020. I consider this to be an extremely important exercise for identifying the main challenges encountered and for making recommendations to address these challenges, facilitating a more effective implementation of these initiatives on the ground, with the aim of fostering territorial cohesion in particular, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which points out that the new tools for territorial development are innovative instruments in terms of cohesion policy and that they represent a qualitative leap in the ability of local actors to better coordinate grants and to plan more limited local initiatives. These two new tools are Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI), which better combines the flow of funds from several programmes, and local development led by local actors (DLAL), which aims to strengthen synergies between local players in order to better target actions to be taken. The ITI and the DLAL are therefore vectors of better territorial governance within the framework of cohesion policy. I supported this text because it reminds us of the need to define strategies and to wisely delegate responsibilities and resources to local decision-making levels. In order to become more effective, the participation of regional and local actors, from the very beginning, is essential to ensure effective local action, particularly in the fight against youth unemployment and the financing of SMEs.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the evaluation of two instruments available to the Union's territorial cohesion policies. The report hopes that the involvement of local authorities (not only metropolitan but also rural) will take place from the earliest stages of resource allocation and investment planning, in accordance with a bottom-up, bottom-up logic.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective in the EU Treaties. We voted In favour, since these two tools for territorial development, Participatory Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investment, are oriented in the right direction. We consider it necessary to have an upward, bottom-up approach to cohesion policies and to include the participation of both institutions at various levels and civil society. The report also includes problems such as youth unemployment in many regions, inequality, joint action in border regions, etc. On the other hand, we highlight the failures that occur both in their application and in the disrecognition of these tools, which together with their excessive bureaucracy would be problems to be tackled promptly. While these tools should be further delved into cohesion policies, we believe that the report welcomes the problem in question and proposes a line of citizen participation which we consider essential in cohesion policies.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of improved integrated territorial investment (ITI) and local development (CLLD) measures under European cohesion policy, as it can encourage cooperation between different local groups such as associations, private individuals or local businesses and local authorities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted positively on this resolution because it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to provide greater funding and to share good practices when implementing the two new instruments with the Structural and Cohesion Funds for the period 2014-2020; participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). I am in favour of asking Member States to promote the use of these instruments to improve the management of funds, including in a complementary way, while increasing the upward approach, in order to address the problems of structural unemployment, the integrated development of the least developed regions and countries, the fight against youth unemployment and to provide solutions to the lack of funding for small and medium-sized enterprises , main economic and stable job creation engines.  These two tools will only be able to operate within the framework of a fairer cohesion policy, not subject to so-called macro-conditionality, and which enhances the economic diversification of the poorest areas, especially in the southern European Union.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the 2014-2020 programming, it is important to promote the full and efficient use of new instruments for territorial development that can help improve coordination and ensure the more targeted use of The European Structural and Investment Funds. I therefore hope that the debate on the future of cohesion policy will devote more space to integrated territorial investment (ITI) and participatory local development (CLLD) in order to effectively combine funding flows and plan targeted local initiatives. I voted in favour of the report, which makes recommendations on the future of the CLLD and ITI instruments. We should not underestimate the administrative burden and complexity associated with the implementation of these instruments, which are often difficult to manage, especially by smaller local realities. I therefore hope that the Commission and the Member States will work to make these instruments as visible and comprehensible to their users as possible, while avoiding unnecessary red tape and making further efforts to simplify rules and procedures.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. One of the values of the European Union is respect for diversity. For this, several mechanisms have been defined and, one of them, geographically based, is crucial for the autonomous regions of Portugal. This is the status of the Outermost Region. Community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) are innovative cohesion policy tools that some Member States will use in this way for the first time and which can contribute significantly to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality local employment, sustainable urban development and achieving the europe 2020 objectives. It seems to me, however, that these tools will have to be put in place by the appropriate legal and financial tools and that their implementation must be done in a participatory and in harmony and inter-help between all partners, but mainly the European Union and the Member States. For the above and also because some of the recommendations are consistent with information and reports from the Committee of the Regions, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it identifies the lack of trust between the different levels of government. While it is still too early to evaluate the effectiveness of the tools that the report refers, but it does highlight that there are some issues that can already be identified: fear for increase of local influence in certain Member States, a limited budget for local government and difficulties integrating multiple funds.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the use of new tools in projects to create high-quality jobs and opportunities for SMEs, to promote investment, sustainable and inclusive growth and social investment, and to contribute to poverty reduction and social inclusion, especially in regions and sub-regions where it is most needed. I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. - 2020: Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Community-Led Local Development (CLLD), as ITI and CLLD, as innovative tools in cohesion policy, can make a significant contribution to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, sustainable development, local job creation, and achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The report considers that CLLD opens up various opportunities for urban and suburban areas and should be an integral part of urban development strategies, including cross-border cooperation. I also believe that it strengthens the local community and provides specific local solutions within all ESI Funds. In addition, he stresses that ITI should not only be limited to urban areas, but should also apply to geographical areas such as urban districts, metropolitan areas, urban-rural, sub-regional or cross-border areas. Candidates for financing activities through the ITU mechanism in the Republic of Croatia, which was introduced with the aim of strengthening cities as a driver of economic activities, are the seven cities with the highest concentration of population, namely - Zagreb, Split, Rijeka, Osijek, Slavonski Brod, Zadar and Pula. The four cities are expected to be granted funding through ITU mechanisms, depending on their urban development strategies.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
