text: Writing. \u2012 Although the European Union is increasingly strengthening its economic, social and territorial cohesion in order to promote its overall harmonious development, we continue to see major differences between the levels of development of individual regions. I therefore welcome all eu action aimed at reducing these disparities. I supported the resolution because I believe that, thanks to the new territorial development instruments under cohesion policy 2014-2020, the EU can help these regions in the area of development. I agree that territorial cohesion, in terms of access to integrated territorial investment and community-led local development, must start from the bottom up and must also include small administrative actors, but I believe that without sufficient support, both at national and EU level, the new instruments will not have the desired effect. In this context, I expect the Commission and the Member States to provide specific assistance, in particular, to smaller and less developed areas, which often have limited resources and capacities and for which the use of these instruments in planning and implementation due to administrative burdens and complexity can be difficult.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy in the period 2014-2020. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I have followed in particular measures to combat unemployment. Integrated territorial investment (ITI) and in particular community-led local development (CLLD) are very important instruments of local development and cohesion. In the Czech Republic, there are very good experiences with their predecessor, LEADER. At local level, the actors greatly appreciated this programme, in particular the relatively less demanding administration and participatory nature within the so-called local action groups. I very much appreciate that these instruments exist and work because they clearly can have positive consequences for employment as well. That is why we have also asked the Member States to make the CLLD method available to the European Social Fund, if they have not already done so.  However, these tools are quite new and not very well known. There may also be problems in their implementation. That is why the European Parliament has called on the Commission and the Member States to work to resolve the problems of the mid-term revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework and to promote these instruments as best as possible. Of course, I will continue to monitor their effectiveness and fulfil expectations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Territorial cohesion is considered a fundamental objective of the European Union and is enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. Accordingly, the new generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places more emphasis on using comprehensive and local approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion, including the introduction of two new instruments: community-led local development and integrated territorial investment. Community-led local development follows a bottom-up approach, which means that the objectives and funded projects are set on the basis of local needs of the community, not forced at national level. It is crucial that local partners take on the role of the main player in the preparation of the territorial development strategy in integrated territorial investments and are fully involved in its management, monitoring and auditing. However, integrated territorial investments constitute an instrument enabling a more flexible determination of the territorial scope and thus the application of a genuine local approach. The report calls for these instruments to be strengthened and for their possible mandatory use in the post-2020 period. The Greens' efforts to demand high standards by local actors have also been taken into account, and the report highlights the importance of local ownership, tackling youth unemployment and demographic challenges. In view of the above, I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 establishes and promotes the use of integrated and locally oriented approaches to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion, while promoting territorial governance. Innovative instruments in the field of cohesion policy can make a significant contribution to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating jobs and contributing to sustainable development towards the europe 2020 objectives.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Territorial cohesion is one of the main objectives of the European Union, and cohesion policy for 2014-2020 enables and encourages the application of integrated approaches that focus on specific areas, all with the aim of fostering economic, social and territorial cohesion and promoting territorial governance. Integrated approaches are therefore important as means of focusing on specific areas and improving the effectiveness and effectiveness of public intervention by responding to and contributing to the specific needs of the area. In order for economic, social and territorial cohesion policy to be complete, it is important that regional and local structures are strengthened. Likewise, innovative approaches prioritise local knowledge in solving local problems through local solutions. However, it should be borne in mind that local stakeholders need technical and financial assistance at regional, national and European Union level. I support this report because, in addition, I believe that community-led local development (CLLD) and integrated territorial investments (ITI) should play an even more important role in future cohesion policy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒Territorial cohesion is one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union. Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 enables and encourages the application of integrated approaches focusing on specific areas aimed at fostering economic, social and territorial cohesion while promoting territorial governance. Integrated approaches focusing on specific areas are intended to improve the effectiveness and effectiveness of public intervention by responding to and contributing to the specific needs of the area. Parliament underlines the need to combat over-regulation practices that create additional requirements and barriers at national, regional and local level. In order to make visible progress towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, the revision of this strategy and the multiannual financial framework should pay more attention to regional and local contexts and to the specific circumstances in the areas concerned. I support this motion for a resolution, as I believe that these approaches will play an even more important role in the future cohesion policy of the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment and community-led local development. At the level of regional and local actors, we need commitment to territorial development strategies, a sense of responsibility for them and an appropriate transfer of powers and resources to lower levels. I support the call to define strategies, in cooperation with regional and local actors, at the beginning of the implementation process, in particular at the level of specific and specialised training and technical and financial support, in the context of an effective partnership between regions, Member States and the EU.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. New EU regional policy tools have the potential to give communities a bigger say in what happens in their local area and in how EU regional development funds are spent. However, if they are to succeed, then clearer guidance and less red tape are a must, I therefore welcome calls for further clarity, guidance and support in relation to territorial development tools and for simplification across ESI funds.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The use of ESI Funds creates additional and unnecessary requirements and obstacles at both national and regional level. High funding for the implementation and implementation of the TSTs and OCTs does not in any way lead to the creation of quality jobs;

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on territorial development in the plenary vote. The report focuses on two instruments, CLLD (Community-Led Local Development) and ITI (Integrated Territorial Investments). The reporter regrets that the two instruments are not fully used by the Member States and analyses the challenges that hinder the use of these instruments.  The bottom-up approach, the involvement of local actors in decision-making, is extremely important, but consultation with local levels should have real added value and should not result in a significant increase in the already complex and complex administrative burden.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the new territorial development instruments of cohesion policy make a significant contribution to increasing economic, social and territorial cohesion and reducing social inequalities. Territorial cohesion, as one of the UNION's core objectives, has given greater emphasis to integrated and local needs during the 2014-2020 financial planning period. In this context, two new instruments have been introduced: Community-led local development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI). In my opinion, for the Member States that joined in 2004, the implementation of the leader programme at the time required a massive learning process. We should be at the fore when, in addition to community development, job creation and economic development play an increasingly important role. However, I regret that in many cases these resources are allocated in Hungary purely through partisan political interests and not in accordance with the real needs of local actors. Another problem, in my opinion, is that the implementation of the system of local development is often complex, lacking coherence and centrally managed. I am confident that it can move away from Hungary from the top. I agree with the rapporteur that a bottom-up approach and the involvement of local actors are essential to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy and that the different levels of governance can in many cases seriously hinder the implementation of the territorial approach.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it deals with the introduction of integrated regional investment and local community development projects in member states' 'Investments for growth and jobs' programmes. In particular, the challenges of introducing them have been well presented.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 places particular emphasis on the economic and social dimension. It will use two new tools for this purpose: Community-led local development (DLRC) and integrated territorial investment (ITI). In this context, it is worth mentioning the poor capacity of local governments to develop and implement strategies for their territory.  These instruments are intended to improve the situation, in particular by facilitating the process of integrated use of more funds within cohesion policy. For this reason, the proposal receives support from me.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Concrete participation of regional and local actors, from the earliest stages, their commitment and ownership of territorial development strategies and the judicious delegation of responsibilities and resources to lower decision-making levels are essential to the success of the bottom-up approach. I believe that the participation of partners can also strengthen the integrated and territorialised approach, particularly in the event of low adherence to the ITI and DLAL instruments. However, local actors need technical and financial support at regional, national and European level, particularly in the early stages of the implementation process. It is within this framework that the European Parliament's desire to issue this text is in place.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the new territorial development tools in cohesion policy 2014-2020, at I believe that they will render local initiatives more successful. In fact, these tools will allow for local actors and communities to be attributed more responsibility and ownership over their projects, as well as more control over their resources, while receiving technical and financial support from the regional, national and EU levels. I do believe that challenges such as youth unemployment, the lack of SME funding, ageing populations, social inclusion, adapting infrastructures to demographic changes and migration flows, as well as using digital connection to better link citizens and administrative authorities, can best be addressed at the local level.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion, as enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, is recognised as a fundamental objective of the European Union. I think it is essential that we increase the number of actions aimed at making known the possibilities it offers local authorities. In fact, unfortunately, local realities underestimate the potential of these programmes and do not implement development strategies that would allow territories to develop and grow. And that's despite the financial possibilities. If we want to ensure that these instruments have the desired effect, support must be provided at both national and European level through targeted information activities. I believe that the bottom-up approach and the participation of all the actors are essential for achieving the objectives of cohesion policy, and there is ample room for improvement in our action on this point.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported the report by The European Parliament, Mrs Tomašić, for several important reasons. The report promotes a new generation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which focuses more on economic and social cohesion, which is essential for new Member States, including Lithuania. It is also important that the report assumes that local actors receive support enabling the development and implementation of development strategies in their area of action. And most importantly, young people are involved in social and territorial development. This will lead to the creation of new jobs in the future by reducing unemployment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment and community-led local development. Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective of the EU, as set out in the Treaty of Lisbon.  Community-led local development and integrated territorial investment are innovative instruments of cohesion policy that some Member States will implement for the first time in this form and which can make a significant contribution to achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion, creating quality local jobs, sustainable development and achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective in the EU Treaties. We voted In favour, since these two tools for territorial development, Participatory Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investment, are oriented in the right direction. We consider it necessary to have an upward, bottom-up approach to cohesion policies and to include the participation of both institutions at various levels and civil society. The report also includes problems such as youth unemployment in many regions, inequality, joint action in border regions, etc. On the other hand, we highlight the failures that occur both in their application and in the disrecognition of these tools, which together with their excessive bureaucracy would be problems to be tackled promptly. While these tools should be further delved into cohesion policies, we believe that the report welcomes the problem in question and proposes a line of citizen participation which we consider essential in cohesion policies.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as all tools should be promoted in order to reinforce and improve cohesion policy within the EU. The different aids should be subject in my view to cost benefit economic analysis to avoid waste and make the most efficient use of funds.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. These new investments could help reduce regional disparities in cohesion policy, including addressing SME financing and cash flow problems and youth unemployment. In France, the scope of the ITI's intervention is in keeping with the priority geography articulated with the city's policy. More funds will be poured into the suburbs and peri-urban territories. Nevertheless, it must be admitted that the increase in budgetary transfers in the European Union will not limit the competitiveness deficit experienced by our SMEs because of savage globalisation. Moreover, the implementation of these new tools of territorial development is essentially based on a bottom-up approach where local and regional actors gain autonomy and further weaken the power of national authorities. These new territorial development tools, aimed at responding directly to local needs and issues, are a backdoor way for the European Union to expand its scope of intervention in urban policy, the exclusive competence of the Member States. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion is one of the union's fundamental objectives, as set out in the Treaty of Lisbon. Against this background, the new generation of cohesion policy for the financial planning period 2014-2020 places greater emphasis on approaches that take into account integrated and local needs in order to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. With my vote, I supported S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 Territorial cohesion is a fundamental objective in the EU Treaties. We voted In favour, since these two tools for territorial development, Participatory Local Development and Integrated Territorial Investment, are oriented in the right direction. We consider it necessary to have an upward, bottom-up approach to cohesion policies and to include the participation of both institutions at various levels and civil society. The report also includes problems such as youth unemployment in many regions, inequality, joint action in border regions, etc. On the other hand, we highlight the failures that occur both in their application and in the disrecognition of these tools, which together with their excessive bureaucracy would be problems to be tackled promptly. While these tools should be further delved into cohesion policies, we believe that the report welcomes the problem in question and proposes a line of citizen participation which we consider essential in cohesion policies.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it advocates a more important role for the new territorial development tools and asks for incentives to increase their take-up. It also confirms the importance of bottom-up and place based approaches where local stakeholders including from civil society have to be involved, thus increasing transparency and ownership of cohesion policy action on the ground.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's focus on results, as this should help local policymakers move from over-spending and the isation of implementation processes to setting real and meaningful targets that would bring tangible changes to local businesses and citizens.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report evaluates the Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and Participatory Local Development (DLP) tools, highlighting its importance in order to be able to involve the maximum number of actors and thus detect the specific needs of each community (DLP) and the possibility of facilitating synergies and effective use of funds when combining them through the ITI tool. We are talking about a report which aims to encourage THEMs and regional and local authorities to increase the use of these tools in cohesion policy for this period so I consider it necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because we as politicians must ensure the most efficient use of public resources and combat administrative ignorance and mismanagement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Territorial cohesion has been recognised as a fundamental objective of the European Union and enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. In this context, the new generation of cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period places greater emphasis on the use of integrated and local-based approaches to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new ERDF Regulation establishes a budget limited to specific purposes of 5% of expenditure for sustainable urban development. Under the European Structural and Investment Funds, two new tools were set up in the 2014-2020 programming period to achieve the objective of territorial cohesion: Community-based Local Development (CLLD) and Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI).  We follow the appreciation of this perspective of local development, while calling attention to the need to avoid any short-circuit between the European institutions and local government bodies that may mislead a necessary policy link with the central and regional governments of the Member States.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's report on new instruments for territorial development under cohesion policy 2014-2020: Integrated Territorial Investment (ITI) and local development measures (CLLD) carried out by the local population. I am opposed to cohesion policy as a whole. It is not possible to align regions and Member States with centrally allocated funding. Europe should live and celebrate its regional and national differences, rather than wanting to make them equal through the EU.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The current cohesion policy (2014-2020) puts greater emphasis on a bottom-up approach and that is why the EU put in place new tools such as community-led local development and integrated territorial investments. All these new tools are very much welcomed, on the condition that they are used to their full potential in Member States and regions. It is therefore crucial to ensure that local and regional governments are provided with the necessary capacity support to be able to plan and deliver such programmes.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. I voted in favour of this European Parliament motion for a resolution for the following reasons. Although territorial cohesion is an important objective of the EU, we have not yet achieved all our objectives in this respect. This is especially true with regard to two instruments: the CLLD (Community-Led Local Development) and the ITI (Integrated Territorial Investments), which play a major role in this policy.  With regard to the CLLD, we have come to the conclusion that it is a very complex concept, that it is considered unnecessary by some Member States and that a downward vertical movement of power in some of them is also very difficult. In addition, many Member States fear the administrative burden associated with the implementation of these mechanisms. These problems are also experienced with regard to the ITI.  It is therefore obvious that I support a resolution that points to these problems and gives clear suggestions on how they can be resolved. It is stressed that the initiatives should take a bottom-up approach and therefore aim for sufficient participation by local actors. Moreover, such an approach must be holistic and inclusive. Specific attention to youth unemployment in the EU is needed.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on the new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. I welcome the rapporteur's approach, which believes that the bottom-up approach and the participation of local actors are essential to achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. It notes that, in a number of Member States, there can be a lack of trust between the different levels of governance when it comes to the implementation of the community-led local development instrument and the integrated territorial investment instrument. This is an important issue that needs to be addressed, as it can seriously affect the implementation of the territorial approach.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Any initiative that enhances local communities' access to funding and supports local development is our immediate priority. This resolution calls on national, regional and local authorities to establish flexible and effective frameworks for the absorption of funds, while underlining the ECB's specific investment priority for local development and strengthening local initiative. The possibilities offered by the new regulations should be used more to achieve an integrated bottom-up cohesion policy.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The objective of cohesion policy is to develop the economic aspect of the most disadvantaged regions of the EU territory, as there are clear differences between the infrastructure and quality of services in the different Member States. These differences are precisely what need to be reduced, so that everyone can be in conditions of competitiveness in the economy that are as similar as possible. I am in favour of this report because it not only favours the least-favoured regions but is also positive for all Europeans, as this cohesion policy in turn pursues a more eu economic development

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the cohesion fund report was favourable. First of all, I welcome the request to the European Commission to publicise and simplify access to the financial resources made available to local authorities, starting with the Integrated Territorial Investment Funds (ITIs) and Participatory Local Development (CLLD). In this respect, we must address the lack of competent actors in European policies at local level. To this end, it is proposed to evaluate the design of concrete incentives to stimulate Member States to implement CLLD and ITIs, together with potential tools to ensure greater coherence between operational programmes, CLLD and ITI. In particular, I welcome the attention paid to the new generations in the report: it is essential to include young people among the recipients of territorial development instruments. An impressive number of young people (14 million) are not employed and are not engaged in education or training (NEETs), while youth unemployment rates have exceeded 50% in some Member States. Clld with a particular emphasis on young people can be a factor of cohesion between community generations and can allow the development of new employment pathways.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report because I am convinced of the positives that regional and local actors are involved in. At the same time, however, I am of the opinion that local actors need technical and financial support from regional, national and EU levels. Personally, I am concerned about the high unemployment rates in a number of EU Member States and regions. Member States should therefore, in my opinion, use all available instruments in projects that will lead to the creation of high-quality jobs and opportunities for SMEs. These projects will also contribute to promoting investment, sustainable and inclusive growth and contribute to poverty reduction and social inclusion.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Tomasić's report on new territorial development instruments under cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. In particular, the report addressed the promotion of a bottom-up approach, the strengthening of integrated and locally oriented approaches and, overall, support for the delegation of powers from higher levels to below. I support this principle, as I believe that strengthening the powers of the very regional and local organisations that are best aware of the needs of the region will help us to bring the benefits that cohesion policy provides directly to the addressees, and we will be able to address them better and more effectively to local and regional communities in accordance with their needs. At the same time, I am of the opinion that by supporting lower levels of governance, we will achieve better growth, job creation and support innovation at local level. A very welcome element in the resolution was also the call to simplify the administrative complexity of the funds, as, in my opinion, it is precisely the complex processes that often discourage applicants from trying to obtain funding under cohesion policy.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tomasic report on cohesion policy, because I believe that the proposals presented have the potential to generate a solidarity development of the EU territory. I highlight two tools included in this report: integrated territorial investment and community-based local development, for which about 5% of the cohesion policy budget will be used. I would stress that, having been designed to combat asymmetries and esteach the gap between access to opportunities for European citizens, and the volume of resources it mobilises (more than EUR 350 billion by 2020), cohesion policy is a key tool for reversing the cycle of stagnation in which the EU plunged after the financial crisis started in 2008. I regret that, given its importance, the process of implementing cohesion policy does not deserve particular attention from the EU. Delays in their implementation and the difficulty in combining them with other tools to support development, growth, employment and investment are missed opportunities when the EU is experiencing difficulties requiring the mobilisation of all available resources.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on new territorial development tools in cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020: integrated territorial investment and community-led local development. I believe that the new tools of territorial development can make a significant contribution to the creation of quality local jobs, sustainable development and the achievement of the europe 2020 objectives.  The measures taken under these tools should pay particular attention to the provision of tax and other incentives to promote youth employment and their interregional mobility and give priority to vocational training in partnership with training institutions.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation covers Community balance of payments statistics in the light of the new TFEU Treaty with the aim of empowering the European Commission. All the amendments that promote transparency and cooperation have become part of the final compromises, but have been removed in trilogues, making the regulation in fact not in line with current open government requirements. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour as this is a technical dossier to update the methodology for the development of balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. In addition, the text has almost unanimous support, following the conclusion of the trilogue with the Council.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because despite consistently improving the content of the initial proposal for a Regulation, it assumes the authority of international institutions with zero democratic control. This report contains numerous proposals that will allow the production of such statistics, for example it raises the distinction between foreign direct investment in the real economy and speculative investment, which may allow differences in both flows in the balance of the Member States; it also includes greater demands in the area of regional breakdown of statistics which can be very useful for the development of a true cohesion policy. However, the report makes it crystal clear that the provisions taken by IMF and OECD in this area must be introduced into european policy and I have not finally been able to vote in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted abstention on the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 184/2005 on EU balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. Although a number of measures are aimed at strengthening reporting and publishing obligations as part of an improvement in the transparency and detail of statistics, this text aims to entrust the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. In addition, the purpose of studying these statistics is to contribute to the economic governance imposed on Member States. Finally, they aim to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the general guidelines of the Union, which is unacceptable to us.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the four votes on this file including the ECON Committee’s amendments, the Commission’s proposal and the legislative resolution. This was a technical file amending existing regulations on how statistics are collected in the European Community on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, reviewing the regulation to remove references to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. While I am opposed to the general attempt to regulate all aspects of the economies of Member States, this file related only to statistics and may improve the quality and transparency of economic statistics, so I did not believe a vote against was justified and abstained.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Although this report proposes to improve the fineness of statistics related to financial flows in and out of the EU, it is a matter of entrusting the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific. Their primary value is that of economic governance imposed on Member States. They help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the eu's general guidelines, as well as with legal obligations derived from the EU's economic governance framework. I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. I vote against all resolutions designed to give the Commission greater power to pass delegated acts.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. These statistics are part of the EU's overall framework to monitor economic developments in each Member State and in the EU as a whole. I believe that, in a world where international capital flows have multiplied and become more complex, the production of reliable statistics, in the areas of balance of payments, international trade in foreign services and direct investment, is essential to the monitoring exercise of macroeconomic imbalances. These tools will ensure better traceability of these flows and serve the fight against tax evasion. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on balance of payments, statistics on international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The Regulation on balance of payments, international trade in services and statistics on foreign direct investment is part of a common EU framework to monitor economic development in each Member State and throughout the Union. The development of reliable statistics in such areas is very useful for monitoring key characteristics such as current reports and developments in financial flows within and outside the EU. Since the adoption of the original regulation and subsequent updates, international capital flows have become more intense and complex, making it more difficult to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. The revision of the Regulation is an opportunity to increase the transparency and completeness of statistics relating to the IPA, the IPA and FDI and to make the latest legal innovations more reliable in making decisions on economic policy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is an amendment to the previous Regulation on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment in order to ensure that the Commission can modernise the Regulation on the basis of delegated law. In particular, the forthcoming statistics make it possible to distinguish greenfield foreign direct investment from foreign direct investment leading to acquisitions, which do not increase gross capital formation in the Member State or the working capital of the entity affected by the change of ownership during a given period. I supported the adoption of this report because the amendment of the regulation serves to improve the traceability of capital flows. At the same time, it should be noted that this is necessary because the earlier liberalisation of capital flows and the deregulation of the financial sector have resulted in an omnisque situation, which is a hotbed of tax fraud and speculation carried out by a wide variety of methods.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report follows on from inter-institutional negotiations on the amendment of regulation (EC) 184/2005 on statistics on financial flows in and out of the EU. The aim is to strengthen reporting and publication obligations to improve transparency and the level of detail of statistics, incorporating recent regulatory innovations related to the fight against money laundering and tax evasion into statements, such as the public registers of effective beneficiaries put in place by the Anti-Money Laundering Directive.  However, this report effectively entrusts the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows, especially since these statistics are not only for a scientific purpose: they also serve to strengthen the economic governance imposed on Member States. I was therefore unable to vote in favour of this report, despite its original plan, which was not lacking in relevance.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The balance of payments records all economic transactions between resident and non-resident entities over a period of time.  Since the adoption of the original regulation and its successive amendments, international capital flows have both multiplied and become more complex. Specifically, the increased use of special purpose entities and legal arrangements for the transfer of capital inflows and outflows have exacerbated the difficulties of controlling these capital flows in order to ensure their traceability and avoid double or multiple accounting, thus a more difficult fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. The purpose of this report is to update the existing legislation in relation to this phenomenon.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of reliable statistics is a key element in ensuring the coherence of the economic policies of eu Member States with the EU legal framework and economic governance system. Monitoring of economic developments within the Union is carried out through a general framework based on Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments statistics (BdPs), international trade in services (SIS) and foreign direct investment (IDE). The Giegold report, which I supported today, has effectively addressed the issue of the revision of Regulation 184/2005, linking it to the growing complexity of international financial flows. The text adopted sets out two priorities in particular: 1) aligning the regulation with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon and 2) increasing the transparency and granularity of statistics with regard to BdP, SIS and IDE. The Commission's overall priority must be to strengthen cooperation with other international organisations providing economic statistics, such as the IMF and the OECD, in order to achieve an overall system that allows for increasingly reliable statistics to monitor macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained from this vote on a procedural dossier, in which, as has been done with other legislative acts, any reference to regulatory procedures with control is removed, as this procedure has been removed from the legislative process since 2009. Theoretically all these references should have been removed by the end of the previous legislature.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. U2012 The progressive technicality of operators and the new governance and supervisory rules that articulate imbalance control processes in member states and the need for the best data to plan and evaluate policies and prevent practices such as tax fraud or so-called "aggressive fiscal planning" require improving our balance-of-payments statistical apparatus , international trade in foreign direct services and investment. For these reasons I have supported this report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment statistics aims to strengthen reporting and publication requirements to improve transparency and the level of detail of statistics. It is proposed to add various points on recent innovations in the fight against money laundering and tax evasion. For example, the international identifier for legal entities, which is part of the OECD's proposals to improve reporting on financial account information or the EuroGroups directory or the international identifier for legal entities.  The report also aligns the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty for delegated acts and enforcement measures by redefining the essential elements that the Commission could amend and by increasing Parliament's delay in objection to these amendments. Unfortunately, I note that this report actually proposes to entrust a lot of strategic information about financial flows even though it is a question of improving the finesse of statistics, but it is well known that this will allow above all the economic governance imposed on states.  So I abstained overall.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is said in the Giegold report, which updates the legislation on delegated and implementing acts assigned to the European Commission.  I believe it is necessary to completely rethink EU legislation on the collection of macroeconomic data, an area that is often manipulated by statistics, in line with the EU institutions. I consider the Commission, an institution outside democratic and citizens' control, unsuitable for ensuring the transparency of statistical processing. I therefore voted against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour, following the conclusion of the tripartite dialogue with the Council, of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, as regards the commission's allocation of delegated and implementing powers to adopt certain measures. It is a technical report updating the methodology for conducting statistics on balance of payments, foreign direct investment and international trade in services.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The Regulation on balance of payments, international trade in services and statistics on foreign direct investment is part of a common European Union framework to monitor economic development in each Member State and across the EU. The development of reliable statistics in such areas is very useful for monitoring key characteristics such as current reports and developments in financial flows within and outside the EU. These statistics therefore contribute to ensuring consistency between Member States' economic policies and broad EU guidelines and their compliance with legal requirements under the EU's economic governance framework. More specifically, reliable statistics are a crucial basis for the monitoring process identified under macroeconomic imbalance procedures. Since the adoption of the original Regulation and subsequent updates, international capital flows have become more intense and complex. More specifically, the increased use of special purpose measures and legal structures to divert capital flows has led to an increase in the monitoring of these capital flows, their sufficient traceability and the difficulties associated with avoiding double or multiple accounting, thus making it more difficult to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 European statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment (FDI) are key to ensuring sound economic policy-making and accurate forecasting of economic prospects. This is of paramount importance at the level of both the European Union and individual Member States, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a report by my colleague Sven Giegold on EU statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  The proposed amendments aim to provide common information on foreign direct investment output and inputs and income streams from related investments, both between individual EU Member States and other countries in the world. The regulation also aims to enrich statistics of incoming and outgoing foreign direct investment. This information will complement current statistics on foreign direct investment collected on the basis of the approach of the direct host country or applicant.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today aims at the revision of Regulation 184/2005 and has a dual objective: to improve quality and to standardise Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. This harmonisation is of fundamental importance in order to make correct and effective economic forecasts and, consequently, to enable better management of macroeconomic imbalances and possible future crises. I welcome the fact that, in promoting increasingly reliable and comparable data collection, the report supports greater coordination between Eurostat and the other international organisations that provide most of the statistics in this area, such as the OECD and the International Monetary Fund, as well as further differentiations with regard to foreign direct investment in particular. In this respect, the distinction between "greenfield" investment flows, which give rise to real gross investments and generate new opportunities, and mere acquisitions, which only achieve a change of ownership for pre-existing economic activities, is certainly positive. The revised text will therefore make it possible to have more valuable data, allowing better traceability and understanding of flows, and therefore economic and commercial trends in an increasingly globalised reality.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report on reconciliation of statistics related to balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The aim of this harmonisation is to better predict the future crisis. Poor quality statistics played a major role in the 2008 financial crisis, so it is essential to further harmonise the EU statistical collection and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The main aim of this report is to provide the European Commission with statistics on financial flows in and out of the EU, which one can legitimately ask what they will be used for. These are, in fact, of a sufficiently precise and detailed level that I think are more a matter of the strategic governance of each State rather than the competence of an international organisation, even if it is European. I fear that this information is in fact merely used to affirm the Commission's supremacy over the Member States in terms of economic management. Therefore I voted AGAINST.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on the four votes on this file including the ECON Committee’s amendments, the Commission’s proposal and the legislative resolution. This was a technical file amending existing regulations on how statistics are collected in the European Community on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, reviewing the regulation to remove references to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. While I am opposed to the general attempt to regulate all aspects of the economies of Member States, this file related only to statistics and may improve the quality and transparency of economic statistics, so I did not believe a vote against was justified and abstained.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important for the Union to equip itself with more modern and accurate statistics that will enable it to devise and implement its policies in the manner that is as fluid and multifaceted as possible.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen reporting and reporting obligations to improve transparency and the fine balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad. It is therefore proposed to include, among other things, the international identifier of legal entities, the public registers of beneficiaries set up by the directive to combat money laundering.  I have abstained on this report which will entrust the European Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. Moreover, these statistics will help to certify the adequacy between the economic policies carried out by national governments and the general guidelines of the Union.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal on the statistics of the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment aims to amend Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 184/2005, with a view to aligning it with the new institutional context. The aim is, in particular, to identify the powers conferred on the Commission and to implement the related procedures for the adoption of measures on the basis of those powers. The powers envisaged shall be those for the adoption of delegated acts in situations where, for reasons relating to economic and technical changes, it is necessary to update the data requirements. It is also proposed to confer powers on the Commission with a view to adopting common quality standards and harmonising the content and periodicity of quality reports. As regards the European statistical system, the Commission has concrete proposals to improve the partnership under this system, in order to make its activities more efficient. I was in favour of this report because I believe that it is necessary to confer powers on the Commission to update data requirements, but also to ensure adaptation to the new institutional context.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation in question, as can be seen from the title, relates to EU statistics on certain performance of Member States. In itself, this would be something for granted, almost a text to be expected without paying too much attention. The all-political problem, however, lies in the fact that our delegation is sceptical about the powers delegated to the EC, the real European institution far from democratic and citizen control. Not only that, we can very well add that we are also not interested in the clash between the EP and the Council over the use of delegated acts (normally preferred by Parliament) or implementing acts (more in the interests of the Council). The basic problem for the League is the lack of confidence in the work of the EC and in the fact that, in such a sensitive area as the collection of macroeconomic data, politically fraudulent or interested use of the interpretation of number and data flows is very frequent. The issue of 'manipulation' of statistics is, in our view, central. The Council has managed to include a few more guarantees of transparency in the final agreement, but on the whole it is always a measure to which I voted against.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because the revision of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 represents a real opportunity to increase the transparency and granularity of statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad. I believe that an update should also be made in order to ensure compliance with the rules laid down in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEI). It is therefore necessary to take full advantage of recent legal innovations and, therefore, to make these statistics an increasingly reliable instrument for decision-making support in the field of economic policy. My vote in favour also stems from the usefulness of strengthening reporting and publication requirements, which provide a better overview of gross capital flows. Not of secondary importance is the advantage that can be gained from recent innovations, such as, for example, the international legal entity identifier (LEI), part of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) framework for improving the transmission of financial information for tax purposes.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a technical file amending existing regulations on how statistics are collected in the European Community on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, reviewing the regulation to remove references to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. While I am opposed to the general attempt to regulate all aspects of the economies of Member States, this file related only to statistics and may improve the quality and transparency of economic statistics, so I did not believe a vote against was justified. For these reasons I abstained on the four votes which included the ECON Committee’s amendments, the Commission’s proposal and the legislative resolution.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the regulation on Community statistics should be updated to take into account the recent developments. It is particularly important that the new proposal aims to further strengthen transparency and to increase inter-institutional cooperation. It also promises improved accessibility of the Eurostat website and user-friendliness is crucial for all European Union websites to ensure proximity to the EU citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the measure is to amend the Regulation on Community balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and direct investment abroad in the light of the new provisions of the TFEU. Therefore, the main objective is to give the European Commission greater powers in the enactment of delegated and implementing acts. I abstained from the vote because, despite the fact that the final text of the ECON Committee accepted all our amendments, the latter was completely distorted in the trialogues. Furthermore, the final text provides for the creation of a new Commission executive agency and, therefore, a further waste of public money by the citizens of the European Union.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Statistics are a key instrument for economic policy decisions, and their reliability depends on their ability to anticipate the emergence of new financial crises in the future. Indeed, it has been shown that in 2008 poor quality statistics underestimated the scale of the crisis that would have severely affected our economies.   The update of the current regulation on the EU statistical framework on balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment, approved in plenary, is essential above all to monitor and monitor developments in current accounts and financial flows inside and outside the Union, which have intensified in recent years and have become more complex and difficult to analyse.  Eurostat's cooperation with international organisations such as the OECD and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) must also be strengthened and the assessment of the quality of national contributions to statistics publicly disseminated. I therefore voted in favour of amending the regulation because measures are being introduced to improve and make statistics more transparent at European level, which will also make it possible to better understand the impacts on employment of direct investment.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. It is part of the eu framework aimed at monitoring economic developments in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. The production of reliable statistics in these fields plays a specific organic role in monitoring vital data, such as developments in current accounts and financial flows within and beyond the EU.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment on the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. This report is a positive step towards improving the existing rules and I believe it contributes to the imposition of a more sound regulatory framework. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The statistics in the report speak for themselves: this amendment should, in my view, be seen as a positive opportunity to increase transparency and to take advantage of recent legal innovations and to make these statistics a more reliable instrument for economic policy decisions. It is in line with these objectives, to which the report itself aims, that I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ This is part of the overall EU framework aiming at monitoring the economic developments in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. The production of reliable statistics in such fields is in particular instrumental for monitoring key features such as the developments regarding current accounts and financial flows within and beyond the EU. Thus, these statistics help ensure the consistency of Member States’ economic policies with broad EU guidelines as well as with legal requirements derived from the EU economic governance framework. More specifically, reliable statistics are a crucial basis for the monitoring process established in the context of the macroeconomic imbalances procedures.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the development of reliable statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad is essential in order to monitor developments in current accounts and financial flows within and outside the EU. Statistics in these areas contribute to ensuring the coherence of Member States' economic policies with the broad union guidelines, as well as with the legal obligations arising from the Community economic governance framework. International financial flows have intensified and become more complex, and in particular the increased use of vehicle companies and legal construction for the transfer of both inbound and outbound capital flows has made it more difficult to monitor these flows to ensure their adequate traceability and avoid double or multiple accounting, thus making the fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning more complicated. I therefore voted in favour of the regulation harmonizing Community statistics in the field of taxation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Foreign direct investment statistics are part of the overall EU framework aimed at monitoring the economic developments in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. The production of reliable statistics is instrumental for monitoring key features such as the developments regarding current accounts and financial flows within and beyond the EU. Given that so far this information is only required on a net basis (investment in the country minus investment abroad), which hampers the analytical value of the reported information, it is a concern that some statistics may not adequately reflect the comparative state of play amongst the countries and hence provide a distorted picture of FDI in Europe. The report seeks to build on the current situation by compiling the main headings, by following the ‘ultimate host/investor country’ approach to identify the host country of the direct investment enterprise for outward FDI and the home country of the direct investor for inward FDI as defined in the OECD Benchmark Definition of FDI.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because despite consistently improving the content of the initial proposal for a Regulation, it assumes the authority of international institutions with zero democratic control. This report contains numerous proposals that will allow the production of such statistics, for example it raises the distinction between foreign direct investment in the real economy and speculative investment, which may allow differences in both flows in the balance of the Member States; it also includes greater demands in the area of regional breakdown of statistics which can be very useful for the development of a true cohesion policy. However, the report makes it crystal clear that the provisions taken by IMF and OECD in this area must be introduced into european policy and I have not finally been able to vote in favour.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation on Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of the general EU framework which allows monitoring of the evolution of the economic situation in each Member State, but also throughout the Union. The development of reliable statistics in these areas is particularly necessary to monitor certain key elements, such as those of financial flows within the EU, but also those outside its borders. Thus, these statistics are useful to ensure that Member States' economic policies are consistent with the EU's general guidelines. I voted for better transparency of this data, as well as for turning these statistics into a tool for making economic policy decisions.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to amend the balance-of-payments statistics regulation, international trade in services and foreign direct investment to adapt it to the new institutional framework. This proposal aims, in particular, to clarify the Commission's powers within its powers to harmonize the content of quality reports. Considering that the reliability of the EUROPEAN Union's foreign trade statistics is essential to the definition of an effective export strategy, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed revision of the regulation (EC) No. 184/2005. The revision of this regulation enhances the transparency and detail of balance-of-payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. In addition, it aligns the regulation with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty which give the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts and acts of enforcement.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report covers statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The aim is to improve the transparency and detail of statistics by strengthening reporting and publication obligations through recent regulatory innovations related to the fight against money laundering and tax evasion.  The report aligns the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty for delegated acts and enforcement measures by redefining the essential elements that the Commission could amend and increasing Parliament's delay in objection to these amendments.  The text aims to entrust the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows.  It appears that these statistics are mainly aimed at ensuring that Member States' economic policies are adequacy with the Union's guidelines, particularly economic ones.  So I decided to abstain.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support any report that leads to more transparency. This is about foreign direct investment and how to distinguish them from mergers and/or takeovers of existing companies. We have such a case in our country in 2015, which counts as the largest foreign investment of this year, and in fact it is not. Something needs to change so that there are no differences in statistics and from there in the future plans of the Community countries, because this can affect the economic growth of a country and therefore the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report proposes to strengthen Eurostat (Commission) cooperation with other international organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) with a view to full control of Member States' trade and investment

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The production of reliable statistics is essential, in particular, to monitor key economic aspects, such as current account and financial flow developments, within and outside the EU. Reliable statistics provide an essential basis for carrying out the monitoring process established under macroeconomic imbalance procedures. I therefore agree with the revision of the provisions of the Regulation to increase the transparency and granularity of statistics relating to balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: the Commission is given a great deal of strategic information about financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific and help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the general guidelines of the Union.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the development of reliable statistics, in areas such as balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad, is essential above all to monitor the development of current accounts and financial flows inside and outside the EU. Therefore, the availability of reliable statistics becomes important for the process of monitoring macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. Not in total agreement.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Accurate and reliable statistics are essential for the monitoring process under macroeconomic equilibrium procedures. Several years have passed since the last regulation was adopted in this area and international capital flows have intensified. Greater use of special purpose vehicle and legal structures to channel outflows and capital inflows has made it difficult to track these flows, ensure their reasonable traceability and avoid double or multiple accounting, thereby making it more difficult to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against report that does not consider the risk of "manipulation" of statistics.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as it proposes to strengthen the Commission's (Eurostat) cooperation with other international organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) with a view to fully controlling Member States' trade and investment.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this, as the text agreed with the Council includes pilot studies which are a good way of ascertaining the feasibility of improving foreign direct investment (FDI) statistics whilst also analysing costs and benefits.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call on the Commission to improve the quality of the data (Article 4) and for a delegated act on enhanced foreign direct investment statistics, with improved granularity and transparency: this will allow for more detailed analysis of flows that are essential to a better understanding of the functioning of globalised economies. The revised text will allow us to better understand whether a foreign direct investment is leading to real job creation and greenfield investments or is just a complex legal construction for channelling funds in an opaque way (Recitals 6, 16, 17, Article 1) and to start compiling FDI data based on an ‘ultimate ownership concept’ (Article 5(2)-(3)). This is also topical in view of the ongoing tax evasion scandals. Eurostat has also agreed to step up efforts to enhance its website for a more user-friendly presentation of the data (Recital 1). Bad quality statistics played an important role in 2008 financial crisis. Therefore, it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of the overall EU framework for monitoring economic developments in each Member State and throughout the Union. These statistics help to ensure consistency between member states' economic policies and the overall EU guidelines and the legal requirements arising from the EU's economic governance framework.  Parliament's report points to the revision of the Regulation as a real opportunity to improve the transparency and detail of statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. Furthermore, to take advantage of the latest legal innovations that make these statistics more reliable tools for economic policy decisions.  Secondly, Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 should be updated to ensure its coordination with the rules in the TMS which confer on the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts and implementing acts.  The Regulation should be brought into line with the Treaty of Lisbon, because it distinguishes between powers which may be conferred on the Commission according to whether, as laid down in Article 290(1) of the TMS, they relate to the adoption of non-legislative acts (delegated acts) with general effect supplementing or amending certain non-essential provisions of legislative acts or to the adoption of uniform conditions for the implementation of binding Union acts (implementing acts) provided for in Article 291(2) of the TMS. I voted in favour of this report as shadow chancellor.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need for reliable statistics in these areas, as it is particularly useful for controlling key aspects such as current account developments and financial flows within and outside the EU, which contributes to ensuring the coherence of Member States' economic policies with the more general EU guidelines. The revision of the Regulation represents an opportunity to increase the transparency and granularity of statistics, as well as to take advantage of recent legal innovations to make these statistics a more reliable tool in economic policy decisions.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on economic statistics on the basis that statistics is of huge importance in a large number of areas. The results of this resolution would give a more accurate and detailed view in regard to economic developments and financial flows in the Member States. Very importantly this would in turn indirectly lead to a more accurate view for policy makers of what decisions need to be addressed in the economy. I also support the report’s proposal that Eurostat should deepen its cooperation with other financial institutions that produce statistics, such as the IMF.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement with the Council on the proposal for a regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad. I believe, in fact, that high-quality and comparable statistics relating to the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment (IDE) are crucial for public policy-makers in the Union, researchers and all European citizens. I therefore supported the need to give the Commission (Eurostat) the power to take all necessary measures to allow easy and easily accessible online access to data sets and to provide users with an intuitive presentation of the data. This type of statistic, in this case, is of fundamental importance in ensuring that economic policies are developed in an informed manner and that economic forecasts are correctly formulated. I shared the EP's position of updating levels of geographical unbundling, levels of unbundling by institutional sector and levels of unbundling by economic activity provided that such updates do not affect the communication burden or change the applicable underlying conceptual framework. I also agree with the need to give the ECB greater consultative powers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the technical report 'Balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and direct investment', as it outlines important milestones of a deeper and simplified internal market and facilitates procedures.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. International financial flows are becoming increasingly intense and complex. Therefore, it is difficult to monitor them closely. The statistics serve as an important, reliable basis for the monitoring process and are part of the overall EU framework for monitoring economic developments in the individual Member States and throughout the Union. They help to ensure consistency of Member States' economic policies through rough EU guidelines and legal requirements.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment as regards conferring of delegated and implementing powers upon the Commission for the adoption of certain measures (COM(2014)0379 – C8-0038/2014 – 2014/0194(COD)) as bad quality statistics played an important role in 2008 financial crisis. Therefore, it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. In principle, this text aims to strengthen the reporting and publication obligations of information in order to improve the transparency and level of detail of the various economic statistics. In addition to regulatory innovations related to anti-money laundering and tax evasion, methods are proposed to improve financial account reporting. However, all these mechanisms entrust the Commission with a great deal of information, including strategic data on financial flows. This governance of the Commission in the economic field is imposed on the Member States. So I voted against this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained from this vote on a procedural dossier, in which, as has been done with other legislative acts, any reference to regulatory procedures with control is removed, as this procedure has been removed from the legislative process since 2009. Theoretically all these references should have been removed by the end of the previous legislature.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council which amends Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 because I do not want to see a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis which was, in part, caused by poor quality statistics. Labour MEPs support the further harmonisation of statistics collection in the EU and the improvement of the quality of data collected.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment as regards conferring of delegated and implementing powers upon the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because the methodology on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment needs to be updated. Having high quality economic statistics is very important for the development of European public policies and also for academic research. In this sense, European statistical information is a public good which must be adequately supplied, and whose importance for deepening the internal market, the completion of economic and monetary union, and for the political construction of Europe, cannot be underestimated.
