name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Reliable statistics in the field of balance of payments international trade in services (ITS) and foreign direct investment (FDI) are crucial for the monitoring of the economic development in the EU and in individual Member States. I voted in favour of this revision that will make those statistics more transparent and efficient for EU economic policy decisions as well as enhance the cooperation between international organisations with an aim to increase the quality of the data and promote exchange of best practices. Furthermore, I welcome the new inclusion of pilot projects related to FDI statistics on the ultimate beneficiary ownership concept in order to assess a concrete and efficient methodology in reporting and aggregating the data. These pilot studies will be carried out by Member States 24 months after the regulation comes into force followed by a report from the Commission 12 months later.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The need to align this proposal with the new institutional context and the recently revised statistical system by amending the regulation is aim of this report. Moreover, I voted in favour as the need to strengthen the transparency and level of detail in statistics is something which is needed. An element which I find very favourable is that the user friendliness of the Eurostat data based interface shall be improved.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Bad quality statistics played an important role in the financial crisis. We should have a harmonised statistics collection in the EU and an improvement of the quality of the data collected.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Community Statistics Regulation on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment in terms of granting delegated and implementing powers to the Commission to adopt certain measures, as this revises the provisions of the regulation in question in order to reach two objectives. First, the revision of the regulation improves the level of transparency of balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, and these statistics, with the help of legal advances, become a more reliable tool for economic policy decisions. On the other hand, it is necessary to align the Regulation with the rules of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which allows the Commission to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts. Therefore, I support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Although this report proposes to improve the fineness of statistics related to financial flows in and out of the EU, it is a matter of entrusting the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific. Their primary value is that of economic governance imposed on Member States. They help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the eu's general guidelines, as well as with legal obligations derived from the EU's economic governance framework. I therefore abstained from voting on this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The report proposes to increase the transparency and detail of COMMUNITY statistics. In particular, it calls for strengthening publication obligations in order to take advantage of recent innovations. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although the content of the report can be generally accepted, certain critical points remain with negative consequences for Europe as a financial location. For example, the idea of transparency is reflected in a public database, which should contain fine data that would also allow conclusions to be drawn about sensitive trade secrets. For these reasons, I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of the report is to remove all provisions relating to the regulatory procedure from all legislative acts by the end of the parliamentary term. The Commission undertook to examine legislative acts containing references to the regulatory procedure. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that these legal innovations will make statistics more reliable and make them a tool for decision-making on economic policy.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – In the 11 years since the adoption of the original Regulation, the volume and complexity of international capital flows have increased considerably and it is indeed timely to modernise it. In support of this report, the primary objective of the report is to make statistics possible to distinguish greenfield foreign direct investment from foreign direct investment leading to acquisitions. The fight against tax fraud and aggressive tax planning is a hit topic today, which can also be served by a review of regulation to ensure better traceability of capital flows. I note that all this would not have been necessary if excessive liberalisation had not taken place earlier.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – With regard to balance of payments (BdP), international trade in services (SIS) and direct investment abroad (IDE), EU intervention is aimed at monitoring economic developments in individual Member States but also in the European Union as a whole. The aim of this proposal is to amend the Regulation to bring it into line with the new institutional context. The problem arises with regard to the growing contrast between the ECB and the Commission in terms of statistics. In fact, under the previous system, the ECB was consulted on matters relating to its competence, whereas with this proposal the Commission tends to exclude the ECB from the possibility of obtaining relevant statistics. I therefore believe that the revision of this regulation represents an opportunity to increase the transparency and flow of statistics with regard to BdP, SIS and EDI, and therefore to enable us to benefit from these instruments, through clearer and more reliable methods.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment statistics report. Although this report proposes to improve the fineness of statistics related to financial flows in and out of the EU, it is a matter of entrusting the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific. Their primary value is that of economic governance imposed on Member States. They help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the eu's general guidelines, as well as with legal obligations derived from the EU's economic governance framework.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because while it changes the calculation of balance-of-payments statistics, it also gives a lot of information to the Commission.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text proposes to improve the finesse of these statistics and their transparency. To do this, it lists a number of proposals. In an anti-laundering and tax evasion framework, he wants to add the national, international ID to the mandatory declarations... However, under the guise of scientific improvement, the report tends to give the Commission strategic information for the control of financial flows. It aggravates the economic governance suffered by the Member States.  I am strongly opposed to this text and I voted AGAINST IT.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the methodology on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment needs to be updated. Having high quality economic statistics is very important for the development of European public policies and also for academic research. In this sense, European statistical information is a public good which must be adequately supplied, and whose importance for deepening the internal market, the completion of economic and monetary union, and for the political construction of Europe, cannot be underestimated.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because despite consistently improving the content of the initial proposal for a Regulation, it assumes the authority of international institutions with zero democratic control. This report contains numerous proposals that will allow the production of such statistics, for example it raises the distinction between foreign direct investment in the real economy and speculative investment, which may allow differences in both flows in the balance of the Member States; it also includes greater demands in the area of regional breakdown of statistics which can be very useful for the development of a true cohesion policy. However, the report makes it crystal clear that the provisions taken by IMF and OECD in this area must be introduced into european policy and I have not finally been able to vote in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. Community statistics are part of the overall EU framework for monitoring the economic developments of each Member State and the Union as a whole. That is why I believe that the development of reliable statistics helps to control key aspects of our economy, such as the evolution of current accounts or flows within or outside the Union. These are essential in the same way in the monitoring process.   I support the amendment of the Regulation on them, because I consider that given the complexity that capital flows have acquired in recent years, we must ensure the transparency and granularity of statistics and thus ensure that they are a valid political decision-making tool.  With this review we also give the Commission powers, through thin acts and implementation, to ensure the updating and adaptation of the Regulation in certain non-essential elements.   For the reasons set out above, and because of the importance of the financial market in the European economy, I vote in favour of its approval.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is intended to increase transparency and improve statistics on economic indicators in the EU, but overall I consider these statistics to be redundant. Balance of payments can be more easily collected using existing bank statements, and there is no need to conduct expensive sample interviews that annoy companies.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment are important for accurate economic forecasting and economic policy-making. Also, reliable statistics are a key instrument of the monitoring process in the context of macroeconomic imbalances procedures.  The report underlines the necessity of updating Regulation No 1001/2013. 184/2005 in order to improve transparency and detail on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment by improving reporting and disclosure requirements, in order to take advantage of recent innovations such as the global identifier of legal entities and end-of-property registers. This should result in an increase in the analytical value of union statistics on foreign direct investment and contribute to the transparency and traceability of financial flows related to direct investment operations. Improvement can be achieved through better and more regular reporting. Statistics should allow for the distinction between new foreign investment and foreign direct investment resulting in acquisitions and not increasing gross investment in a Member State in a given period or increasing the working capital of an economic entity affected by a change of ownership. I supported the report because such international cooperation would facilitate the development of an appropriate conceptual framework for end-user ownership and the distinction between new FDI and those resulting in takeovers.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments (MB), international trade in services (SPT) and foreign direct investment (FDI) is part of the general EU rules aimed at monitoring economic developments in all Member States and in the Union as a whole. As can be understood, qualitative collection of such information and subsequent regular dissemination through various sources (e.g. Eurostat) are of fundamental importance, both for policy-makers, ordinary citizens, entrepreneurs and foreign partners. The amendment of this Regulation seeks to raise two main points. Firstly, to increase the degree of transparency and detail of statistical data, particularly in the case of MB, SPT, and TDI. Secondly, to align the regulation itself with the Treaty of Lisbon that has long entered into force. Given the frequent discussion of the shortcomings in the availability of different data and information, the current amendments are very important and hopefully they will achieve their primary objectives as soon as possible.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Thorough and exact statistics are the basis for monitoring and evaluating macroeconomic procedures. The proposal for a regulation presented aims at increasing transparency and detail of statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment and at aligning the present Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, where competences between the Commission and other co-legislators, the EP and the Council are more precisely separated. I supported this proposal because the thorough use of these statistics can also help to detect money laundering practices that damage the economy and the economy of the EU and the Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained when the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 was adopted. In the case of community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment as regards the delegation of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures, it is not sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. This report amends and complements EC Regulation 184/2005 on EU balance of payments statistics, international trade, services and foreign direct investment. It strengthens transparency obligations for trade and financial flows in and out of the European Union. In particular, it establishes an international identifier for legal entities (in accordance with an OECD proposal). The coordinated foreign direct investment survey, established annually by the International Monetary Fund, could thus be presented with a state-by-state allocation. The original intention of this agreement is to increase the transparency of financial and trade flows to and from the European Union. If this intention is laudable, we cannot support its underlying objective of strengthening the economic governance of the European Union at the expense of the prerogatives of the Member States. In particular, we denounce the exorbitant powers that this text confers on the European Commission.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment with regard to the conferring of delegated and implementing powers on the Commission for the implementation of certain measures. This regulation is intended to monitor economic developments in each Member State and in the Union. The revision of the regulation is therefore an opportunity to increase transparency and statistics with regard to BdP, SIS and IDE.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 As the world economy grows, the EU needs to increase its data collection capabilities to monitor developments. In the wake of the Panama Papers, we need to learn more about tax evasion and fraud. In particular, I support the mention of the relationship of transparency and traceability, which are fundamental to our liberal democracies. We must also strengthen Eurostat's role in monitoring cooperation with international organisations such as the OECD and the IMF. Eurostat is the instrument through which the European Union monitors these developments, so we should provide the necessary tools for its proper functioning.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The development of reliable statistics in areas such as balance of payments, international trade in foreign services and investment is essential to control key aspects such as current account developments and financial flows within and outside the EU. These statistics help to ensure the coherence of Member States' economic policies with the eu's more general guidelines, as well as with the legal constraints arising from the EU's economic governance framework. They are also the fundamental basis of the monitoring process that establishes the context of macroeconomic imbalance procedures. For this reason, we must support an improvement in the development and use of these instruments as we ask, with my support, in the report on the proposal for a Regulation on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted by a very large majority the Giegold report on balance of payments statistics. It calls for greater transparency in international capital flows. It is essential that balance-of-payments data cease to be manipulated by trusts or some opaque financial companies in tax havens. From now on, it will be possible to see the starting and arrival points of investment flows. Eurostat and Member States will now have to publish data on capital flows in a clear and accessible manner. Eurostat and Member States will also include data from future registers on the final beneficiaries of trusts in capital flow statistics. These changes will shed light if necessary on the murky world of investment flows. Transparency on direct investment flows is also needed to improve. Coordination between Member States and the European Commission must now aim to improve statistics in order to better understand whether direct investment leads to job creation or is only used for a takeover. I naturally voted in favour of this text.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Regulation 184/2005/EU, concerning balance of payments statistics (IP), international trade in services (JHA) and foreign direct investment (FDS), aims to monitor the economic situation of the Member States and the Union itself in general. The monitoring of financial flows plays a key role in all supervision, so as to ensure the consistency of Member States' economic policies and the Union's monitoring of the implementation of the guidelines and, ultimately, to ensure broader macroeconomic policy. Increasing capital flows and increasing complexity have now led to the need for a revision of the Regulation with a view to increasing the transparency and degree of detail of statistics, adding flexibility to exploit modern innovations that can make statistics related to balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment more reliable. The regulation also needs amendments in order to comply with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon. I am in favour of this resolution because I believe that transparency, as well as the degree of detail of statistics, are vital tools for the Union so that there is proper monitoring and monitoring of economic developments in the Member States.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the amendments tabled by the EP to the regulation, as they will increase the transparency and completeness of statistics, make the latest innovations available, and make these statistics a more reliable tool for economic policy decision-making.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which highlights the importance of transparency through publications on new innovations.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The production of statistics in the areas of balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is used to monitor developments in current accounts and financial flows within the Union and beyond. The increased use of special purpose entities and legal arrangements for the transfer of capital inflows and outflows have exacerbated the difficulties of controlling these capital flows, making it more difficult to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. To remedy this, the report proposes to increase the transparency and detail of these relative statistics. And while these statistics are also used to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the Union's general guidelines, particularly in the context of monitoring procedures on macroeconomic imbalances, I am voting for this transparency effort.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. By making the disclosure obligations of those concerned more rigorous, the text aims to refine the statistics related to financial flows, in a process of transparency. This is commendable if it was not agreed that a great deal of strategic information should be entrusted to the European Commission. If it does not have the power to change the rules of the acts, these statistics will still serve as an instrument of economic governance towards the Member States by the EU. Indeed, the statistics will be largely significant of the good discipline of states with regard to its economic orientations. As a result, I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 in order to align it with the new institutional context. In particular, the objective is to identify the powers conferred on the Commission and to establish the appropriate procedure for the adoption of measures based on those powers. It is proposed to give the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts, where, for reasons of economic and technical developments, data requirements should be updated, including deadlines for submission, as well as reviews, extensions and eliminations of data flows listed in Annex I, and where it is necessary to update the definitions set out in Annex II. It is therefore proposed to grant implementing powers to the Commission in accordance with the examination procedure provided for in Article 5 of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011, with a view to the adoption of common quality standards and the harmonisation of the content and frequency of quality reports. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this amendment to the regulation concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment statistics. The production of reliable statistics is of major importance in monitoring economic developments. Furthermore it improves transparency, and aligns this regulation with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Lisbon Treaty has led to a series of changes in the functioning of the European Union and the competences of the various institutions. It gives the Commission the power to establish delegated acts and acts of enforcement. Some complement some non-essential elements of a legislative act, while others are an available tool when uniform conditions for the implementation of legally binding acts are necessary. The report aims to give the Commission these two powers in specific areas relating to EU balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The aim here is to implement the Lisbon Treaty within the framework of international trade.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The aim of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment to be in line with the new institutional context and the recently revised European statistical system. In particular, the production of reliable statistics in the areas concerned serves as a tool for monitoring key aspects such as developments in current accounts and financial flows inside and outside the EU. Therefore, these statistics help to ensure that Member States' economic policies are aligned with the EU's general guidelines, as well as with legal requirements derived from the EU's economic governance framework. I consider reliable statistics to be an essential basis for the monitoring process under macroeconomic imbalance procedures. The revision of the regulation will help to increase transparency and contribute to more detailed statistics. It will also be possible to distinguish foreign direct investment on the greenfield from foreign direct investment resulting in takeovers which, in terms of the annual reference period, do not increase gross capital formation in a Member State nor increase the working capital of the economic unit concerned by the change of ownership. I support the proposal in its original version.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, since bad quality statistics played an important role in the 2008 financial crisis and therefore it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The amendment concerns implementing powers and would give the Commission a mandate to adopt certain measures. It aims to increase the transparency and detail of statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment and to bring Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 into line with the Treaty of Lisbon. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that parliament adopt the proposal with 28 amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment contains references to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny and should be re-examined taking into account the criteria set out in the Treaty. In order for statistical data to be produced in a timely, appropriate, transparent manner and with the quality and accuracy required in this area, it is important that, on the one hand, the Commission has the necessary powers to collect information and ensure common quality standards, and, on the other hand, that Member States provide the necessary statistical data.  I am voting in favour of this resolution, because I believe that access to statistical data is central to having a clearer and more realistic understanding of economic data.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Although this report proposes to improve the fineness of statistics related to financial flows in and out of the EU, it is a matter of entrusting the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific. Their primary value is that of economic governance imposed on Member States. They help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the eu's general guidelines, as well as with legal obligations derived from the EU's economic governance framework. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome Regulation No 184/2005 on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and direct investment abroad is part of the EU's general framework for monitoring economic developments in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. The development of reliable statistics in these areas is essential above all to verify key aspects, such as developments in current accounts and financial flows within and outside the EU. They therefore contribute to ensuring the coherence of Member States' economic policies with the broad union guidelines, as well as with the legal obligations arising from the EU Economic Governance Framework. More specifically, the availability of reliable statistics is essential for the monitoring process set up under the MIP. The revision of the regulation is a real opportunity to increase the transparency and granularity of statistics and to take advantage of recent legal innovations and to make these statistics a more reliable instrument for economic policy decisions. Secondly, the Regulation must be updated to ensure that it alignment with the rules contained in the TFEI, giving the Commission the necessary powers to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcome to the report. With the adoption of the proposal, statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment will finally become more transparent and detailed. The report also states that the Commission should strengthen its relations with international organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and the International Monetary Fund. More effective cooperation would improve the quality of balance of payments statistics, which the European Union has long sought.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s framework that monitors the economic development in each Member State also consists of European Commission Regulation No 184/2005 concerning statistics for balance of payments (BOP), international trade in services (ITS) and foreign direct investment (FDI). I have voted for this report that amongst others, will increase transparency.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 Quality statistical information is a fundamental public good for academic research and informed public policy development. Community balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment are essential for the development of sound economic forecasts and informed formulation of economic policies. Member States should provide the data necessary to produce Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, on time, in an appropriate form and at the required quality. The purpose of this proposal is to harmonise Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. This is important to better anticipate future crises.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it makes the necessary amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 184/2005 on Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in foreign services and services, instruments enabling monitoring of the economic situation in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. These amendments were necessary to ensure that this regulation was aligned with the provisions of the TFEU, while providing the possibility of reviewing the data collection methods necessary for good transparency. It is very important that these statistics are adapted to the reality and needs of the Member States and the EU, in order to be able to provide a fair perspective on the economic situation with a view to taking economic policy decisions.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I abstained on the four votes on this file including the ECON Committee’s amendments, the Commission’s proposal and the legislative resolution. This was a technical file amending existing regulations on how statistics are collected in the European Community on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, reviewing the regulation to remove references to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. While I am opposed to the general attempt to regulate all aspects of the economies of Member States, this file related only to statistics and may improve the quality and transparency of economic statistics, so I did not believe a vote against was justified and abstained.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because I can only partially support this report. The idea of transparency in a public database, which can often include trade secrets, is, in my opinion, unsupported. Statistics regulation is also used here to make political statements, which, in my opinion, is not a good way of improving the quality of the data.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the Regulation is to improve the collection of statistics and to increase its transparency and reliability. In addition, it is necessary to update the Regulation in order to comply with the provisions of the EU Treaty.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft regulation.  It should be noted that it is essential to identify measures to produce high-quality European statistics, as these measures contribute to ensuring the coherence of Member States' economic policies with broad EU guidelines and the requirements of the economic governance framework.  The new rules will strengthen reporting and publication requirements that will ensure transparency and completeness of data. In addition, the possibility will be created for the production and publication of internationally comparable statistics, which will allow a proper assessment of the overall capital flows and the use of the latest innovations.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 for monitoring the economic developments and financial flows of the Member States of the Union and given that there has been an increase in financial flows within and outside the EU since the adoption of the Regulation and that this situation makes it more difficult to monitor the same flows, I believe that an amendment to this Regulation in the direction of greater adaptation to the current situation and greater transparency is necessary. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – In our globalised and digital world, information plays a key role in understanding the successes and failures of past events. The gathering of such information and the evaluation of statistics, especially concerning economic issues, is key to creating an innovative and successful market economy of the 21st century. I vote for the gathering of statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and FDI to enable a better and more transparent analysis of the European economy. I am certain this will lead to a faster recognition of problems concerning global economic issues and a faster and more profitable decision making processes by investors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I am always in favour of improving transparency and therefore support the proposal to strengthen the reporting obligation and public disclosure of statistics. The global identifier of legal entities, end-beneficial ownership registers, the European Collective Register and the Coordinated Direct Investment Survey are useful innovations that will contribute to strengthening the disclosure obligation. In my view, it is important to allow for the distinction between new (greenfield) FDI and FDI resulting in takeovers so that we can have a realistic picture of the economic situation in individual Member States. We need new foreign direct investment for economic growth and employment gains, and I hope there will be more and more in Europe and Croatia. Cooperation with the IMF and the OECD can be better and more productive and the quality of national statistics should be raised to a higher level to avoid doubts about the inaccuracy of information. Implementation reports will show whether there is a need for further amendments to the regulation. The proposals put forward in the report are of high quality and the proposal for a regulation will improve the production of statistics and I have therefore supported this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I accept the proposal because I think it will contribute to harmonising EU balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, all of which are necessary to better anticipate future crises.  In my view, the new procedure for keeping statistics is more suited to the new legal regime created after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.  I also believe that a new way of keeping statistics will result in better quality of different EU statistics. Given that poor quality statistics contributed to the financial crisis in 2008, I believe that it is crucial to further harmonise the collection of statistics in the EU and to improve the quality and reliability of the data collected.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. The aim of this proposal is to amend the Regulation, which discusses the setting of rules and general principles of Member States' control mechanisms for the exercise of the Commission's implementing powers, in the context of the harmonisation of the EU Regulation on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, with the new rules of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The implementing powers currently conferred on the Commission under this Regulation should be ensured by granting the Commission the power to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts. This proposal empowers the Commission to adopt delegated acts where economic and technical changes require updating data requirements, including deadlines for submitted and audited, extensions and cancellations of data streams, and where definitions need to be updated. I support MeP Giegold's report setting out in particular the Powers of the Commission in order to establish an appropriate procedure for adopting measures based on its powers.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of reliable statistics on balance of payments (BdP), international trade in services (SIS) and foreign direct investment (IDE) is essential to monitor developments in current accounts and financial flows within and outside the EU. The revision of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 is therefore a real opportunity to increase the transparency and effectiveness of statistics with regard to BdP, SIS and EDI, as well as to take advantage of recent legal innovations. I believe that making these statistics a more reliable instrument is of fundamental importance in order to enable public authorities to take the most appropriate decisions on economic policy. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which mentions technical changes to bring European balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment statistics into line with the new rules of the European statistical system.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The production of reliable statistics ensures consistency and equal treatment in the analysis of economic data from the different Member States (MS) and is therefore essential for the full achievement of the European Union's objectives in economic governance frameworks. Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments (BOP) statistics, international trade in services (CIS) and foreign direct investment (EDE) is a decisive component of the EU's overall framework and is intended to monitor economic developments in each Member State and the Union as a whole. However, the increase in intensity and complexity of international capital flows has disrupted their control and tracking. This conjecture makes it difficult to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning, and therefore requires a legislative review of the dossier. In this context, the increased transparency and granularity of bop, CIS and RHE statistics could contribute to an improvement in the statistical indicators available at the time. In the future, the updating of the Regulation, which I adopted with my vote, will enable a more reliable instrument for economic policy decision-making.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – This proposed Directive extends the power of the Commission to issue Delegated Acts, accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Statistics in these areas contribute to ensuring the coherence of Member States' economic policies with the General Guidelines of the European Union, as well as their compliance with the legal requirements resulting from the EU's economic governance frameworks. Reliable statistics provide an essential basis for carrying out the monitoring process established under macroeconomic imbalance procedures. The revision of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 provides an opportunity to increase the transparency and granularity of balance of payments (BOP) statistics, international trade in services (CIS) and foreign direct investment (EI), as well as to take advantage of the latest legal innovations aimed at making these statistics a more reliable instrument for economic policy decision-making purposes.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour, following the conclusion of the trilogue with the Council, of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, as regards the commission's attribution of delegated and implementing powers to adopt certain measures. This is a Technical Report updating the methodology for the conduct of statistics on balance of payments, foreign direct investment and international trade in services.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, in view of the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and the Council (COM(2014)0379), the opinion of the European Central Bank of 5 December 2014 and the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (A8-0227/2015), the President is tasked with conveying Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the national parliaments.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I call for the support of my colleague Sven's comprehensive report on the regulation of balance of payments statistics. Objective and comprehensive statistics are at the heart of any more complex system and it is therefore in the European Union's fundamental interest to achieve the highest possible quality and coverage of the statistical system used.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to harmonize EU balance-of-payments statistics, international trade in services and direct investment abroad.  The revision of the European framework in this area is important because it must enable us to better anticipate economic disruptions and therefore crises. In 2008, poor macroeconomic statistics prevented us from identifying the extent of the phenomenon affecting Europe and the world. The harmonization of this data is therefore essential.  The Socialist and Democratic Group succeeded in strengthening the Commission's proposal in order to improve the quality of the data collected. This should allow us to better understand the interconnectedness of our economies or the role that investments play in job creation, for example.  I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this regulation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament concerns the need to amend the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005, which is an integral part of the general EU framework as regards economic developments in each Member State and in the European Union as a whole.  This is the need to produce reliable statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, taking into account developments in key economic aspects, current accounts and financial flows, both inside and outside the EU. As a whole, we are contributing to greater coherence of member states' economic policies within the framework of EU economic governance. I stress the importance of providing greater transparency, detail and reliability to these statistical data and stress the urgent need to update the Regulation in the light of the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular as regards the possibility for the Commission to adopt delegated acts. For the reasons given, my vote was in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the regulation on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. Reliable statistics provide better control of changes in financial flows and are useful in setting up Member States' economic policies and the Union's general guidelines. Since the adoption of the 2005 Regulation on the Calculation of These Statistics, the context has changed and international capital flows have multiplied. It was therefore necessary to revise this regulation in order to increase the transparency and detail of the statistics and to bring it in line with the Lisbon Treaty and its provisions. This revision will improve the quality of the data and strengthen the calculation of statistics.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the vote of the committee responsible, and in line with the ppe group's approach, I voted in favour of this report. It intervenes on the subject of monitoring three important parameters of the Union's economic development (balance of payments, international trade in services, and direct investment abroad). In this respect, the report takes the opportunity to redefine the regulation on these statistical parameters in order to insist on the obligations of publication and transparency, as well as on the legal guarantees necessary to ensure their reliable and correct use.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained from this vote on a procedural dossier, in which, as has been done with other legislative acts, any reference to regulatory procedures with control is removed, as this procedure has been removed from the legislative process since 2009. Theoretically all these references should have been removed by the end of the previous legislature

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment, as this is a further step towards transparency of investment and statistics.  From now on, therefore, there will be more concrete commitments to compile and publish statistics. It is important for us to be able to assess correctly whether investments, e..B from abroad, are really conducive and have a long-term effect.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because despite consistently improving the content of the initial proposal for a Regulation, it assumes the authority of international institutions with zero democratic control. This report contains numerous proposals that will allow the production of such statistics, for example it raises the distinction between foreign direct investment in the real economy and speculative investment, which may allow differences in both flows in the balance of the Member States; it also includes greater demands in the area of regional breakdown of statistics which can be very useful for the development of a true cohesion policy. However, the report makes it crystal clear that the provisions taken by IMF and OECD in this area must be introduced into european policy and I have not finally been able to vote in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ It is crucial that Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investments are up to date and accurate, historically. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council which amends Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 because I do not want to see a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis which was, in part, caused by poor quality statistics. We are still coming out the other side of the crisis eight years on, and while the Tories are doing their best to punish the poorest and most vulnerable in the UK for a problem primarily caused by financial mismanagement at the top, it is important that we do not ignore the details. Therefore it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 184/2005 on Community balance of payments statistics (BOP), international trade in services (ITS) and foreign direct investment (FDI) with regard to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission to adopt certain measures, as reliable statistics are a key basis for the process of monitoring macroeconomic imbalances. Since the adoption of the original regulation involving compensation changes, international capital flows have become more frequent and complex. This is why the following key points need to be addressed: increasing the transparency and granularity of BOP, ITS and FDI statistics, and aligning Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty.  In order to increase the quality of balance of payments statistics, the Commission (Eurostat) needs to strengthen cooperation with other international organisations that are the main providers of statistical services covered by this Regulation, such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The Commission points out that Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 184/2005 Needs to be updated to ensure its compliance with the rules on the functioning of the European Union which empower the Commission to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment are very important and are part of an overall EU framework aimed at monitoring economic developments in individual Member States and in the Union as a whole. In particular, reliable statistics in these areas serve as a tool for monitoring key aspects such as developments in current accounts and financial flows inside and outside the EU. Therefore, these statistics help to ensure that Member States' economic policies are aligned with the EU's general guidelines, as well as with legal requirements derived from the EU's economic governance framework. More specifically, reliable statistics are an essential basis for monitoring under macroeconomic equilibrium procedures. Transparency and detail on balance of payments, international trade and foreign direct investment should be significantly improved by tightening reporting and disclosure requirements in order to gain a better overview of gross capital flows and to improve financial account reporting. For this reason, the Commission should strengthen its cooperation with other international organisations which are important providers of statistics.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The production of reliable statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is important for monitoring the main features of economic development, such as changes in current accounts and financial flows both inside and outside the EU.  These statistics contribute to ensuring that Member States' economic policies are in line with the eu's broad guidelines and with legal requirements, and also provides an important basis for monitoring macroeconomic imbalances procedures.  The report includes additional legal requirements to increase transparency and disastement of balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, as well as to exploit legal innovations, such as the newly created register of final beneficiaries. Statistics should also make it possible to distinguish between direct investment of new projects and direct investments in acquisitions that do not increase gross investment in the Member States.  The report also foresees that the European Commission will have to carry out pilot studies if it is to develop a methodology for collecting these statistics within a 3-year period. To sum up briefly, the report contributes to improving the transparency of EU statistics in the areas of balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, which is why I supported it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 European statistics in these areas are essential in ensuring informed economic policy-making and exact economic forecasts. The financial and economic crisis has underlined the importance of compiling such statistics. At a time of economic crisis, more accessible data on the real and financial economy of the world would help policymakers and analysts, and, for example, more internationally comparable information on financial transactions and the impact of certain assets and liabilities would be available.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ International capital flows have intensified and become more complex, which means that it is increasingly difficult to monitor such flows and ensure their traceability, as well as to fight tax avoidance. Therefore, the European Commission's Regulation on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is an important part of the overall Framework of the European Union, which aims to monitor economic developments in each Member State and throughout the European Union. Reliable statistics in these areas are essential for monitoring essential features, such as financial flows inside and outside the European Union. Such statistics help to ensure consistency of Member States' economic policies with European Union directives, as well as legal requirements that are part of the European economic governance framework.  Consequently, I support this report and believe that reliable statistics are the necessary basis for creating a quality monitoring process in the context of macroeconomic imbalance procedures.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment as regards conferring of delegated and implementing powers upon the Commission for the adoption of certain measures (COM(2014)0379 – C8-0038/2014 – 2014/0194(COD)), as bad quality statistics played an important role in the 2008 financial crisis. Therefore, it is crucial to further harmonise statistics collection in the EU and improve the quality of the data collected

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No. 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of the overall framework that oversees economic development in each Member State but also in the European Union as a whole. Reliable statistics help ensure the consistency of Member States in implementing their economic policies with clear Union guidelines. More specifically, reliable statistics are a key base for the surveillance process established in the context of macroeconomic imbalance procedures. Since the adoption of the original Regulation, the international flow of capital has intensified and become complicated. More specifically, it has become more difficult to control the flow of capital, which has opened up scope for tax avoidance and similar illegal activities.  I support this proposal to amend the Regulation, as I believe it will strengthen the monitoring of the flow of money and reduce the number of illegal activities. I also believe that these amendments will be better able to monitor member states' consistency in implementing their economic policies.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment concerning the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  The amendments are going in the right direction. I welcome the new added recital, in which we define Community statistics as crucial to correct economic forecasts and informed economic policy decisions.  I also welcome the amendment under which the Commission should consult the European Central Bank on legislative acts in its area of competence.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report was more technical in nature, but we could not vote for it as even more responsibilities are being established centrally in Brussels, since the main issue of the report was to change the structure of a specific EU statistical office, and integrate it into the central statistical office. We have no opposition to statistics being compiled, which is why we have observed an abstention attitude in this report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report proposes to strengthen Cooperation between Eurostat (Commission) and other international organisations such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) with a view to fully controlling Member States' trade and investment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The Regulation is part of a comprehensive EU framework for monitoring economic developments in individual Member States and throughout the Union. Reliable statistics are particularly important in these areas, as this is the only way to monitor current account developments or cash flows inside and outside the EU. As both the volume and complexity of international capital flows have increased since the original regulation and subsequent amendments were adopted, it has become more difficult to monitor them and thus to combat tax fraud and aggressive tax planning. This is why it was necessary to update the Regulation, thereby providing more reliable statistics for economic policy decisions. In particular, I endorse the amendment calling on the Member States to provide the data necessary for the production of Community statistics in a timely manner, in form and in the prescribed quality. Furthermore, I agree with the use of innovative methods such as global entity ID.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The outbreak of the global financial crisis of 2008 putthe European Union in the face of the need to identify new approaches to ensure that such phenomena are not avoidable in the future. Such instruments include the adoption of a new way of developing economic statistics in an integrated manner at European level. These statistics must be carried out in a higher quality manner, in particular with regard to foreign direct investment (FDI), balance of payments and flows of trade in services at international level. In particular, account should be taken of how FDI translates into sustainable job creation and real economic growth. Improving these statistics will also indirectly contribute to combating tax evasion that currently affects Member States. In this way, Eurostat will be able to provide statistics as consistent as possible with the reality on the ground, which will allow for the adoption of appropriate policies in the areas concerned. I believe that this initiative will help to improve the lives of European citizens, which is why I am expressing my support for this document.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The Eu-balance-of-payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment regulation is part of the EU's overall framework to monitor economic developments in each Member State and in the EU as a whole. The production of reliable statistics in these areas is used in particular to monitor key aspects such as developments in current accounts and financial flows within the Union and beyond. Thus, these statistics help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the general guidelines of the Union, as well as with the legal obligations derived from the Eu's economic governance framework. Specifically, the reliability of statistics is essential to the monitoring exercise put in place in the context of procedures for macroeconomic imbalances. Since the adoption of the original regulation and its successive amendments, international capital flows have both multiplied and become more complex. A review was therefore necessary.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment, as I believe that it will strengthen transparency and the level of detail of statistics. This proposal aims at aligning the existing rules and delegation of responsibilities regarding statistics with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty to ensure common quality standards and harmonisation, and strengthen reporting and publication requirements. Reliable statistics are a crucial tool for the EU and Member States to monitor the soundness and legal compliance of economic policies. Moreover, as international capital flows have both intensified and gained in complexity in the era of globalisation, statistics are even more important to ensure traceability and avoid fraudulent financial behaviours.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade and foreign direct investment are essential for accurate economic forecasting and sound economic policy-making. I therefore support giving the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts in order to complement or amend certain elements that are not essential in certain legislative acts, and to take into account economic, social and technical developments. I believe that quality statistics constitute a public service relevant to academic research and informed public policy decision-making, and that Member States should provide the necessary data for the timely production of European Union statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment in the appropriate form. As the aim of this proposal is to harmonise existing legislation in a new institutional context, I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment in relation to the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures I supported.  Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of a common EU framework for monitoring economic developments in individual Member States and in the Union as a whole.  The production of reliable statistics in these areas is particularly important for monitoring the main features, such as changes in current accounts and financial flows both inside and outside the EU. These statistics help to ensure the consistency of Member States' economic policies with the eu broad guidelines and with the legal requirements arising from the EU economic governance framework.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained from this vote on a procedural dossier, in which, as has been done with other legislative acts, any reference to regulatory procedures with control is removed, as this procedure has been removed from the legislative process since 2009. Theoretically all these references should have been removed by the end of the previous legislature.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Although this report proposes to improve the fineness of statistics related to financial flows in and out of the EU, it is a matter of entrusting the Commission with a great deal of strategic information on these financial flows. Moreover, these statistics are not only scientific. Their primary value is that of economic governance imposed on Member States. They help to certify the adequacy of Member States' economic policies with the eu's general guidelines, as well as with legal obligations derived from the EU's economic governance framework. I choose the ABSTENTION.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of the overall EU framework for monitoring economic developments in each Member State and throughout the Union. In these areas, it is particularly important to generate reliable statistics to monitor developments in key features such as current account and cash flows inside and outside the EU. With my vote, I supported S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained from this vote on a procedural dossier, in which, as has been done with other legislative acts, any reference to regulatory procedures with control is removed, as this procedure has been removed from the legislative process since 2009. Theoretically all these references should have been removed by the end of the previous legislature.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on Statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment as it improves the transparency of EU statistics and will lead to more clarity and better traceability of foreign direct investments (FDI) within and from the EU to the rest of the world.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Reliable statistics are a crucial basis for the monitoring process identified under macroeconomic imbalance procedures.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal that aims to strengthen transparency and the level of detail in statistics and which is the result of consensus and which is why I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the methodology on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment needs to be updated. Having high quality economic statistics is very important for the development of European public policies and also for academic research. In this sense, European statistical information is a public good which must be adequately supplied, and whose importance for deepening the internal market, the completion of economic and monetary union, and for the political construction of Europe, cannot be underestimated.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'It is crucial that the balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment statistics are up-to-date and accurate. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The overall objective is to remove all provisions referring to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny from all legislative instruments by the end of Parliament’s seventh term (June 2014). In the context of the alignment of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 January 2005 on Community statistics concerning balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment to the new rules of the TFEU, implementing powers currently conferred upon the Commission by that Regulation should be provided for by conferring powers on the Commission to adopt delegated and/or implementing acts. In addition, the revision of Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 represents an occasion for increasing the transparency and the granularity of the BOP, ITS and FDI related statistics as well as for taking advantage of recent legal innovations to make these statistics a more reliable tool for economic policy decisions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In my opinion, the report has some worthy proposals. However, the idea of transparency is reflected in a public database, which could often include trade secrets. In addition, statistical regulation is also used here in order to make political statements, which is not a good way of increasing the quality of the data.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment. The low quality of economic indicators was one of the causes of the 2008 financial crisis. It is therefore important to harmonise statistical indicators more closely at European level and to improve data collection. The aim of this proposal is to harmonise statistical indices relating to balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad. I am convinced that this is an important step towards better anticipating future crises.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment concerning the delegation of delegated powers and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures. The aim is to generate higher-quality statistical information on Community statistics on the balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment, on the basis of which economic policy decisions will be taken. However, I am opposed to economic governance of the economy. Economic policy should be limited to setting framework conditions. Collecting statistical data is the first step towards micro-controlling the economy, differing from ordoliberal principles.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – Before taking any action and knowing whether it should take action at all, it is necessary for the EU to collect and analyse the right information. An important part of this is monitoring economic developments in the Member States according to specific reference frameworks, such as the Balance Of Payments (BOP), the International Trade in Services (ITS) and the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI). However, the current Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 should be updated in good time. Firstly, I agree that the above Regulation should be in accordance with Articles 290 (1) and 291(2) of TFEU. I therefore agree that these are essential elements which can only be amaned and complemented through the co-legislative procedure.  Secondly, this is a good opportunity to strengthen the requirements for the statistical information used by putting higher transparency and more detail first. This is a progress I can only stand behind.  In addition to the above-mentioned benefits, this motion also calls on the Commission and Eurostat to strengthen cooperation with international organisations such as the OECD and the IMF. This will only improve the quality of the information.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation 184/2005 on balance of payments statistics, international trade in services and foreign direct investment is part of the general EU framework which allows monitoring of the development of the economic situation in each Member State and in the Union as a whole. I voted for the EP report on this regulation because the development of reliable statistics in these areas is particularly necessary to monitor certain key elements, such as the evolution of current accounts and financial flows within the EU and beyond.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which was adopted by a large majority of its members. The text recognises the revision of the Regulation as a possibility that enhances the transparency and reliability of statistics, and therefore strengthens economic policy decisions. Finally, it should be noted that its updating is necessary in order to bring it into line with the rules of the SLEA.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text we voted on is nothing more than an update of a regulation on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and direct investment abroad in the light of the new TFEU Treaty with the aim of conferring greater powers of delegated acts and implementing acts on the European Commission. In the Committee on Economic and Social Affairs, the text received amendments for improvement, which involved greater control and transparency. However, the progress made by the European Parliament has been eliminated in the trialogues, since the Council has succeeded in eliminating almost all the innovations that had been introduced into the text. In order to assist the Commission, provision has also been made for the creation of a further agency (Balance of Payments Committee) which, in my opinion, represents a further waste of EU public money. For this reason and because of the disappointing results of the negotiations with the Council, I preferred to abstain during the vote in plenary.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 184/2005 on Community statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment concerning the granting of delegated and implementing powers to the Commission for the adoption of certain measures.  I agree that high-quality and comparable statistics on balance of payments, international trade in services and foreign direct investment are key to ensuring informed economic policy-making and correct economic forecasts.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, this report is an extremely ambiguous report. Although it has positive aspects for the mountains and recognises the need to support agriculture in the mountains, it has other aspects, in my view, which are extremely negative related to the exploitation of mountain resources and public services. I think that if we do not protect, in these areas, public quality public management services, it will not be possible to keep the population in the mountain areas. This report opens the door to support the replacement of the hiring of teachers and teachers and staff for public health services by distance education programmes and electronic health services. I think that is simply to pave the way for the mountains to continue to lose population and for large energy companies to be above the interests of people, the environment and biodiversity, with the excuse, that is, of meeting the European Union's renewable energy objectives. The same would happen to mining companies. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I fully agree that underdeveloped, poor areas in the European Union should be closed down, with some kind of conscious, well-thought-out strategy. This is what should be done – now more than 10 years ago – with those countries, not only mountainous areas, but also countries whose underdevelopedness and underdevelopedness have not, to put it this way, diminished anything compared to western countries.  Much more could have been reduced if we were not members of the European Union and we had to assess exactly what these specially underdeveloped areas are, and it should also be recognised that, for example, the ruin of the countryside is organically linked, it is not a random event that has occurred as a result of some kind of natural disaster, but rather that the ruin of the countryside should be seen. , how the depopulation and impoverishment of villages systematically and rationally follows from the European Union's neoliberal policies, economies and global free trade. Thank you.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The share of mountain ous regions in the european Union's total area is only 30%, but cohesion policy efforts often do not pay particular attention to them. In view of the potential contribution that a specialised community-wide approach can bring, I unequivocally support the adoption of these reports. I join in calling on the Commission to start developing a definition of mountain regions that could be used within cohesion policy, and the primary emphasis must, of course, be placed on populated regions.  A logical example is the problem of the existence of snow cover in recent years due to global greenhouses, which have a direct impact on European nature, animals and on the area that can be inhabited at the moment. And, especially in view of the effectiveness of the Strategy for the Alpine Region, it is clear that this strategy can also be successful. Thank you!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, I voted for this report because it is in Romania's interest for the Union to invest in the mountain regions and the Carpathian Mountains, which are in Romania, and that is because we also want to finance these regions and European money for their development and also for the protection of the environment.
