At the moment, the European Commission does not have an agenda for these mountain areas, including the Carpathian Mountains and therefore no strategy. That is why I ask them to make such a strategy as soon as possible, precisely in order to be able to access these funds and develop the mountain regions.  It is also very important to link this to jobs, because we talk about jobs all the time. We cannot create jobs if we do not develop and invest in such regions, where, even if there is less population, tourism can be done or projects or industries can be done differently.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, of course I voted for this report because it is about looking after remote and mountainous regions. I think there is a big debate across all Member States at the moment about balanced regional development, both across the European Union and within our own Member States and that, as Monica Macovei has just said, requires services to be available to those who live in these regions, including broadband, medical services, education and health. So I think this is a very timely report. On unemployment, yes we have real problems in our remote regions around youth unemployment. How do we maintain and encourage young people to live and work in these regions? If they do not have jobs, they will not stay. It is a real challenge for the European Union and for the Member States. As a last word on this report, linking it to the previous debate on unemployment, particularly focusing on youth, there is an issue in Ireland about the fact that people with disabilities are excluded from the Youth Guarantee Scheme. I think this has got to be addressed for the issue of equality and fairness. I hope our new Minister with responsibility for disabilities will take this on.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the development of cohesion policies, particular attention deserves the issue of mountain regions. This is, in fact, a large percentage of European territories, whose opportunities for growth and sustainable development are greatly reduced due to undeniable structural difficulties. The motion for a resolution seeks to draw up an action plan to combat phenomena such as: ageing of the population, lower quality of life, depopulation and, finally, social exclusion. While the reference to the key role of SMEs in the process of sustainable development and economic growth is admirable, the same cannot be said of the reference to financial instruments. Considering, on the one hand, the specific characteristics of these territories and, on the other hand, that the effectiveness of the EFSI has not yet been demonstrated, I have decided to abstain from voting, trusting in a future improvement in the proposed strategies.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it emphasizes how the EU's mountainous regions could contribute to their objectives, such as Europe 2020.  The natural resources of these areas can boost job creation in the EU, in particular through "green jobs" that support the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy could contribute to the fulfilment of the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion could be reduced within less developed mountainous regions with the help of Union funds. Mountainous regions can also become the engine of sustainable growth in the EU, as "green growth" centres.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The resolution concerns the consequences and challenges faced by mountainous regions in relation to European cohesion policy. Thus, the report calls for a clear definition of mountainous regions under an "Agenda for EU mountain regions" on a proposal from the European Commission. Alongside this agenda, the objectives of developing mountainous areas should be integrated into the various funds. In addition, the text contains some positive elements such as the request for greater use of participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI) instruments, or priority being given to the territorial dimension of cohesion policy. It also declares the need for the European Commission to encourage pilot programmes for the recovery of traditional economic activities. However, the development of areas cannot be stimulated through public-private partnerships; it also does not help to request a higher level of volunteering for the provision of public services. In short, this resolution seeks to detract from public management, which in practice is a serious threat to the territorial cohesion objectives set out by the Treaties. Consequently, I have decided to vote abstention to the report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I objected to this report on cohesion policy in mountainous regions. Indeed, in the face of the fact that Europe's mountainous regions suffer from a lack of administrative capacity, particularly in terms of transport, which isolates local populations and promotes unemployment, this text suggests the creation of macro-regional strategies to strengthen synergies and complementarity between European structural funds, with the support of local authorities. To the detriment of the national authorities of the Member States (which are not mentioned at any time in the text), the implementation of this new strategy represents yet another attempt by the EU to appropriate the exclusive powers of the Member States, by weakening their power of intervention.  It should also be noted that this text is part of the new territorial architecture sought by the European Commission, which in the short term may threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for a definition for mountain regions, which make up 30% of EU territory, and the creation of a single strategic approach towards these regions. This sustainable, strategic approach is much needed and is a matter which affects certain areas of rural Ireland, especially along the west coast and the northern part of our country. The report calls for steps to be taken to overcome issues of accessibility and a lack of infrastructure and public services, and to create employment and combat depopulation, while also taking into consideration cross-border issues. The challenges caused by youth exodus from these regions are also referred to. The Irish Government has treated rural Ireland shamefully – services have been stripped, our island communities have been attacked, young people have fled in their thousands and the poverty rate in rural Ireland has increased. The neglect of rural Ireland including mountainous regions has starved our communities of investment, funding and services and has contributed to depopulation and isolation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted by a large majority a report on cohesion policy in mountain areas. In this report, we call on the European Commission to better coordinate policies and put in place an ambitious policy for mountainous regions. To date, it is clear that there is no real European strategy for the mountain. Mountain regions today face many problems, such as difficult access, low number of job opportunities, an ageing population, lack of connectivity, not to mention the impacts of climate change. These are fundamental challenges that require strong government action. In particular, we call for better access to European funding for mountain areas, in order to maintain the diversification and complementarity of economic activities in these very fragile regions. Maintaining agricultural production in mountainous areas is a key issue in terms of employment and the environment.  Through the CAP but also through its cohesion policy, the European Union must invest more in these specific areas to simply keep them alive.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions because it refers to the importance of these regions and how they can contribute to development strategies, such as Europe 2020. The rich variety of renewable energy sources in the regions concerned, as well as their natural resources, can make an important contribution both to the achievement of the Union's energy objectives and to the fight against unemployment, particularly through green forms of employment, which are also aimed at the fight against climate change.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I am, in principle, opposed to the implementation of macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of action of national governments. As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. The macro-regional strategy in the Alpine region, the Carpathians or the Ionian region is simply aimed at strengthening the project of a new territorial architecture wanted by the European Commission, which in the short term may threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation based on legitimate relations between nation states. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that cohesion policy should be a matter for individual nation states, not for the European Union, and therefore I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to reduce the difficulties of investing in the mountains due to the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs of isolation. It is important to highlight the abundant natural resources and assets of mountain regions that contribute to better social, economic and territorial cohesion by ensuring sustainable economic development in the mountains.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountainous regions account for a large part of the EU's territory, as much as about 30%. Extreme conditions and remoteness cause structural difficulties in many mountainous regions, thus facing the phenomenon of depopulation and ageing, which can disrupt the natural cycle of generations and lead to a deterioration in social standards and quality of life. This often leads to an increase in unemployment, social exclusion and migration to cities. I support the calls for the Commission to start developing a working definition of mountaineer regions in the area of cohesion policy in order to improve coordination of relevant policies and measures. I agree that eu policies should respect a special concept in relation to mountainous regions, as these regions face obvious structural difficulties. Additional support is needed for these regions to meet the challenges of climate change, to provide employment opportunities at all times, rather than just in the off-season, to develop the economy, to prevent and manage natural disasters.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report provides a niche highlight of the huge resources that mountainous and sparsely populated areas can be for the EU as a whole in developing a sustainable future through their ecological potential. At the same time, the population of around 70 million people is struggling in their daily lives, resulting in the depopulation of these areas as a whole. Simple economic thinking results in a lack of economies of scale, which makes all kinds of services (transport, health, etc.) more expensive here, which people living in relative poverty cannot use to the appropriate extent. The report sees a possible way out of solving these problems with the cooperation of Member States and the EU, which must be brought together by a specific and specific cohesion policy. It considers it necessary to establish a holistic agenda that could go along different policies towards a mature mountain development strategy. As the report calls for real solutions to real problems, I supported its adoption.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report recommends paying special attention to mountainous regions that suffer from a lack of investment, and therefore infrastructure, causing unemployment, poverty and rural exodus. It is the request to define a European policy specific to mountainous regions in order to strengthen synergies and complementarity between European structural funds. To achieve this, however, the report recommends that macro-regional strategies be put in place with the support of local authorities at the expense of member states' sovereignty.  And while the report points to the difficulties faced by SMEs and farmers in mountainous regions, particularly in terms of financing and cash flow, it does not call into question the decisions of the European Commission, which is often responsible for these difficulties: end of milk quotas, Russian embargo, environmental standards, administrative overload, etc.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The mountain regions of the Union rarely receive specific attention in cohesion policy. However, these regions represent a significant part of the territory of the European Union (about 30%), and the whole of the Union depends on their ecosystem services. This report, which I have approved, therefore calls on the Committee: - to draw up a 'programme for the European mountain regions', which should form the basis of a European strategy to develop these regions in the long term and to present a white paper on the subject; - to encourage the use of financial instruments in mountain regions in order to achieve concrete results; - to regularly assess the state of mountain regions in the Union and to analyse the results of the implementation of the operational programmes of cohesion policy.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the Union. Its main objective is to enhance community mountain regions.  These regions account for a large percentage of European territory. To ensure the success of cohesion policy in mountainous areas, it is necessary to adopt a differentiated strategy that addresses its special characteristics and the unique socio-economic context in which they are developed. In this regard, I consider the future development of an "Agenda for EU mountain regions" as well as a long-term strategy to be a very important point in the resolution. All policies addressed in this area should be aimed at protecting the environment, boosting local economies, and improving collaboration between Member States.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountain regions are a key area for the economic, social and sustainable development of many Member States and are generally a source of ecosystem services that are fundamental to the union as a whole. The Iotova report, which I supported today with my vote, places at the centre of the reflection the need to define carefully the terms 'mountain region' and 'regional policy', in order to proceed effectively towards the implementation of a concrete political proposal from the same upright regions. Although they occupy 30% of EU territory, they are rarely considered today within cohesion policy and national policies, often also due to the additional costs arising from chronic infrastructure deficiencies and their peripherality. We need a change of perspective, starting with the establishment of an agenda for the EU's mountain regions and an increase in EIS funds for underdeveloped mountain regions. Increased connectivity and accessibility, combined with substantial investment in renewable energy, can make Europe's mountains real centres of green growth. Only by creating these new catalysts for sustainable development within the EU can we stop the depopulation of our mountains, promoting their size as places of life and work.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The EU has so far not had a coherent strategic approach to mountainous regions. Although there are some elements with this specific orientation (e.g. in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) there is no definition or guidelines for a regional policy in mountain areas and interventions are usually timely, linked to specific results.  We voted IN FAVOUR because, although not perfect, the overall content of the text is constructive and balanced: it highlights the specificities of mountain regions and advocates a comprehensive approach, including the convening of a European agenda, to guide EU investments and actions and facilitate greater coordination between Member States in cross-border mountains.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I note with satisfaction in this report that for once the mountain regions are the subject of specific attention from the European institutions and cohesion policies. Indeed, the mountainous regions have been incorporated into the last political reform of the CAP, which I consider to be a great step forward for a sector where farmers often face significant natural and economic handicaps. Yes, we need to help farmers maintain their agricultural production in mountain areas. Yes, they must be given specific aid when necessity or urgency is required. Yes, we must pay particular attention to small farms and family farms for which the administrative and tax burdens are too heavy to survive. The mountainous regions, and in France we have many, have abundant natural resources, assets linked to the diversity of energy sources and are centres of green growth. Let us not exclude them from European policies and allow them to be pillars of sustainable growth and employment.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. U2012 I support this initiative report because there is a huge opportunity for improvement in development policies, combating depopulation and generating new activities that can take place in European mountain areas. The characteristics of the environment and its communities and the new activities they can lead to fully fit with the keys to the 2020 strategy that needs (smart) knowledge, should lead to sustainable activities and generate opportunities for integration and social cohesion.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the European Union indicates that they would be structurally disadvantaged due to a lack of infrastructure, including transport. These regions would also face a greater rise in unemployment and poverty, thereby reinforcing social exclusion, rural exodus and an ageing population. The report proposes to remedy the problem by defining a European policy specific to mountainous regions by increasing and channelling the union's funding opportunities. This would require macro-regional strategies with the support of local authorities at the expense of Member States' sovereignty. The report also makes a series of fair findings on the difficulties of SMEs or farmers without questioning the Commission's policies. I therefore voted against this report because I do not want the Union to extend its prerogatives even further to the detriment of the nation-states.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text being voted on is acceptable and without criticality, includes an exhaustive list of policies and actions in support of mountain communities and territories. Our mountains absolutely need more attention from the EU, in order to protect and enhance the immense human, cultural and economic heritage that these particular territories represent. I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The mountainous regions of the EU have been the subject of cohesion policy in a rare frequency. This report emphasizes how mountainous regions of the EU could contribute to their objectives, such as Europe 2020.  The natural resources of these areas can boost job creation in the EU, in particular through 'green jobs' that promote the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy could contribute to the fulfilment of the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion could be reduced within less developed mountainous regions with the help of Union funds. Mountainous regions can also become the engine of sustainable growth in the EU as 'green growth' centres.  On the other hand, the report calls for the adoption of an agenda of the EU's mountainous regions and the mainstreaming of the mountainous region dimension into future EU programmes and policies, in particular within the framework of the EIE Funds.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the European Union (EU). The EU's mountainous regions are rarely targeted in cohesion policy. The territorial dimension is being discussed, but the mountains themselves fall under the second plan and it is expected that the Member States will pay attention to the mountains themselves and the challenges associated with them. However, EU funds are often mobilised to achieve concrete results. As the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs of remoteness make it difficult to invest in mountains, mountainous regions are not taken into account. This report focuses on how the EU's mountains can contribute to achieving the EU's objectives, such as the Europe 2020 strategy. The abundant natural resources and wealth of mountainous regions can provide jobs to increase employment in the European Union, especially green jobs to help combat climate change. The wide variety and abundance of renewable energy sources can contribute to achieving the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, in the less developed mountainous regions of the EU, EU funds can reduce poverty and social exclusion. The development of many resources in mountainous regions can also improve social, economic and territorial cohesion by ensuring sustainable economic development for mountain areas. As the mountains themselves are centres of environmentally sustainable growth, they can be the driving force behind the sustainable growth of the EU economy.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the economic, social and cultural development of mountainous areas is complicated by the additional costs associated with climatic and topographical conditions, remoteness and difficult accessibility.  As the lack of adequate infrastructure, including broadband coverage and investment, in mountainous areas contributes to the growing gap between mountainous areas and other regions, emphasis should be placed on physical and digital accessibility, infrastructure and access of the population of these regions to public services and services of general interest such as education, while maintaining agricultural production. , social and health benefits, transport and postal services.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I also supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions, in which I also actively participated as shadow rapporteur for the EPP Political Group. Mountain areas cover as much as 30% of all areas in Europe and cover around 70 million Jews, so a comprehensive strategy and design of the development of these areas needs to be set.  It is also important to eliminate the backlog of the start of cohesion policy 2014-2020, as this is the only way for Member States to be able to help themselves through the various funds. New jobs ensure the settlement of these areas. Synergy between agriculture, the economy, tourism and crafts, on the one hand, and the preservation of natural heritage, unspoiiled nature and the insurance of water resources, on the other, are key points for the development of the EU's mountainous regions and the preservation of jobs.  We must also remember the provision of good transport and modern telecommunications infrastructure, which is a prerequisite for carrying out activities and working remotely in these areas.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The wealth of natural resources and the priceless agricultural and manufacturing heritage of mountain areas are a huge resource for the European Union, both in environmental and employment terms. Think, for example, of the abundance of renewable energy sources or the opportunities to develop quality green jobs, offering sustainable economic development to mountain areas. Unfortunately, to date, the lack of infrastructure and the high costs attributable to their peripherality make it difficult to invest in these areas. It is therefore necessary to include these areas in a 'regional' strategy that includes surrounding areas and urban areas within the framework of cohesion policy, so that the next programming period for EU funding is managed in a more integrated and efficient way than at present. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which aims to provide better conditions, compensatory measures and support for farmers, producers, farms and the inhabitants of these areas.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the Cohesion Policy Report in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountain regions have rarely been the focus of cohesion policy, and the natural resources and assets of these areas can contribute to and provide jobs to improve intra-EU employment, especially in the area of green jobs that contribute to the fight against climate change. Likewise, poverty and social exclusion in mountainous areas can be reduced with the help of EU funds.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. If I can share the observation that mountainous regions are disadvantaged in terms of transport, but also in terms of unemployment and poverty, I would have preferred this report to highlight the causes of this poverty: it is clear that the European Commission's policy on milk quotas, environmental standards and administrative overload has played a major role in the worsening of this poverty. Instead, the report calls for macro-regional strategies that would only weaken the States concerned and jeopardize the current successful cross-border cooperation of these border states. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This report calls for a definition for mountain regions, which make up 30% of EU territory, and the creation of a single strategic approach towards these regions. This sustainable, strategic approach is much needed and is a matter which affects certain areas of rural Ireland, especially along the west coast and the northern part of our country. The report calls for steps to be taken to overcome issues of accessibility and a lack of infrastructure and public services, and to create employment and combat depopulation, while also taking into consideration cross-border issues. The challenges caused by youth exodus from these regions are also referred to. The Irish Government has treated rural Ireland shamefully– services have been stripped, our island communities have been attacked, young people have fled in their thousands and the poverty rate in rural Ireland has increased. The neglect of rural Ireland including mountainous regions has starved our communities of investment, funding and services and has contributed to depopulation and isolation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is important for the Eu ropean Union to adopt a targeted strategy for the EU's mountain regions, which account for 30% of the EU's territory and one of its main biodiversity basins, in order to safeguard and develop it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 An important part of Europe (about 30%) it consists of mountain regions. These are extremely sensitive territories, characterized by unique and contrasting specificities, which require special attention: while they suffer from the problems related to peripherality, depopulation, the ageing of the population and a particular territorial conformation that give rise to important limitations for many economic and productive activities, on the other hand they make a fundamental contribution, through their thriving ecosystems, to the fight against climate change and to the protection of biodiversity; not only that, precisely in response to these problems and to the management of them, mountain territories can become - and in part already are - privileged laboratories to promote the development of new practices capable of combining economic well-being and ecological sustainability. In this sense, in accordance with Article 174.3 TFEU, I believe that all EU policies should provide for a new specific approach that takes account of their particularities. On the other hand, in order to respond adequately to the needs of mountain regions, the coordination of the various policies and programmes (CAP, Natura 2000, Horizon 2020, etc.) that have an impact on these territories, increasing the funds at their disposal, as well as promoting the creation of macro-regional strategies, must be strengthened.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. To the extent that cohesion policy aims to reduce regional disparities within the European Union, this report proposes to pay particular attention to mountainous regions that suffer from a lack of investment. To remedy this, it is called upon to define a European policy specific to mountainous regions by increasing and channelling the union's funding possibilities. The rapporteur also recommends strengthening synergies between European structural funds. In addition, this report calls for macro-regional strategies to be put in place with the support of local authorities, which we strongly condemn as these strategies limit the sovereignty of Member States.  As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, the macro-regional strategy carried out in the Alps and the Carpathians is simply aimed at strengthening the project of the new territorial architecture desired by the Commission, which in the short term threatens the sustainability of cross-border cooperation based on healthy relations between Member States.  So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy in mountain regions is a subject that has always been in my concern, given the importance of these areas for both Romania and all Member States. These regions comprise more than 30% of the EU's territory, contributing to the economic development of states, in particular through their specific characteristics, namely the diversity of renewable energy sources. These mountain areas have a positive impact in terms of combating climate change, preserving and protecting the ecosystems of these territories. However, we cannot fail to note that these mountain areas have been neglected, in particular because of the infrastructure and the additional costs involved in the isolation of these regions. As a result, in the absence of investment, many mountain regions face depopulation and ageing of the population due to extreme conditions and their peripheral character, which affects the natural cycle of generations and leads to a reduction in social standards and quality of life. This leads to increased unemployment, social exclusion and population migration. As a result, I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I am confident that better social-economic and territorial cohesion will be achieved through this policy on the cohesion of mountain areas, ensuring the sustainable economic development of the mountains.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report is a long and comprehensive list of policies and actions in favour of mountain populations and mountain territories in general. There is no major problem in the report, and we also find positive references to the Alpine macro-region. I am voting in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased with the interest in EU mountain areas, as 30% of the Union's territory is represented by these regions. The policy in support of disadvantaged regions must remain the foundation of cohesion policy and, in this respect, I support the development of an 'Agenda for the EU's mountain regions' on areas of interest in this area. I propose to achieve an integrated and flexible approach to the development and creation of jobs in the green economy, also taking into account new activities in areas such as mountain agriculture, sustainable tourism, handicrafts, sustainable forestry activities and renewable energy technologies. At the same time, for this area of interest, I believe that the attention paid to the development of technology (e.g. the Internet) must be balanced with the maintenance of investment in traditional development policies, the lack of access to these services being an additional reason for the depopulation of that area. I also consider increasing investment in infrastructure as a priority. Each region of the Member States must make the most of a new Europe, ready to meet the expectations of European citizens. For sustainable growth we need strong and growing regions.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The mountainous regions face specific problems that need to be addressed through targeted policies. These regions do have enormous potential for growth and job creation despite their geographical handicap. It is also important to stress the importance of agricultural production in its regions. It is therefore necessary to match the objectives of cohesion policy with these geographical specificities in order to enable the proper use of structural funds and to strengthen the synergies of relevant European policies. I voted in favour of this balanced report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy, which also calls for an integrated and coordinated approach to the exploitation of the funds available to the 'mountain regions', in the wake of what has already been done for the macro-regions and the Alpine region. The report calls, first and all, for a definition of a 'mountain region' to be drawn up. The current definition of 'mountain' has been conceived essentially in the context of agricultural policy, so it takes into account only a few aspects. We need a definition that allows for a global approach. Secondly, it calls for an agenda to be set for the EU's mountain regions. Many policies have been developed that indirectly affect mountain regions, but only a specific agenda could represent an even more targeted framework for cohesion policy and would lay the foundations for a territorial approach for the next programming period. Finally, great emphasis has also been placed on the issues of connectivity and accessibility of mountain regions, which are often isolated, which can only become more attractive for living or setting up SMEs if we can envisage and achieve growth that is both intelligent, sustainable and inclusive.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the sustainable development of mountain regions in the EU, including recognising the crucial connections between these regions and their surrounding and urban areas. The report in particular calls for a definition for mountain regions, which make up 30% of EU territory, and the creation of a single strategic approach towards these regions. It calls for steps to be taken to overcome issues of accessibility and a lack of infrastructure and public services, and to foster employment and combat depopulation, while also taking into consideration ecological impacts and cross-border issues. The challenges caused by youth exodus from these regions are also referred to. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the issue of cohesion for the mountain regions of the European Union by claiming the specific challenges and opportunities of these territories. There are several aspects of the text that we support, such as the call for the Commission to present an agenda for mountain regions in the wake of what happened with the urban agenda. It also calls for a definition of the term "mountainous regions", which is still absent and often the basis for the programming choices of the funds. Finally, the reference to the fundamental role of small and medium-sized enterprises for the development of mountain regions, the role of social enterprise and alternative business models for inclusive development and environmental protection should also be appreciated. Despite the multiplicity of positive aspects, However, I have chosen to abstain from voting on the report, as I have found some important shortcomings. I am referring, among other things, to the fact that there are far too positive references to financial instruments or forms of public-private partnership, since the lack of economies of scale would make the provision of these services unattre interesting from a commercial point of view.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Because of the typical characteristics of their geographical location, mountain regions face difficulties and challenges that are not fully covered by Union policies and in particular cohesion policies, which should, on the other hand, contribute more than others to limiting and bridging territorial disadvantages. There are no specific objectives and instruments that respond more to particular territorial needs.  The call for the European Commission to draw up an Agenda for the EU's mountain regions stems from the need to have a specific framework on which to develop a cohesion policy, and consequently to adapt the European Structural and Investment Funds in the next programming period. It is undeniable that these areas face serious difficulties due mainly to a lack of accessibility, infrastructure, connectivity and human resources. Moreover, the development needs of SMEs in mountain areas are not compatible with those set out in European programmes, such as Horizon 2020 or COSME, in which they are unlikely to be able to participate. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to proceed as soon as possible with the identification of a specific strategy that takes account of the mountain dimension in future European programmes and policies. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the Commission to draw up the 'EU Mountain Agenda' which should be the framework for transnational, cross-border and interregional policies.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions concerns important environmental and economic issues. Cohesion policy can and should be associated with corresponding policies relating to the urban environment, as they are inextricably linked. In this light, this report is a positive step for these regions and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to respond to a clear territorial problem, namely to water down the difficulties faced by Europe's mountain areas, both because of the lack of infrastructure and because of its peripherality. The answer is to improve cohesion between the various mountain regions in Europe through targeted investments to protect, on the one hand, the great natural wealth that mountains represent and, on the other, jobs throughout the Union. In fact, mountain areas have so much to offer, including in terms of employment! I therefore voted in favour of this report, which I believe lays a solid foundation for better social, economic and territorial cohesion, offering sustainable economic development to mountain areas.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Mountainous regions in the EU are rarely in the focus of cohesion policy. The territorial dimension is the subject of debate, yet mountains themselves are often left by the wayside and there is a reliance on Member States themselves to pay attention to mountains and their associated challenges. Yet the EU funds often focus on achieving specific results. The difficulty of investment in mountains, caused by a lack of infrastructure and additional costs due to remoteness, leads to the disregard of mountainous regions.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the large share of the European Union's territory that mountain regions represent, they receive insufficient attention because of the difficulties in investing in mountain areas due to the lack of infrastructure and additional costs attributable to peripherality. Given that mountain regions offer a number of opportunities to achieve the EU's employment, cohesion and environmental protection objectives through the sustainable use of their natural resources, I believe it is necessary to give priority to the territorial dimension of cohesion policy, through targeted initiatives for territorial development and additional support for territorial cooperation at European level. In addition, due to the abundance and variety of renewable energy sources and their dependence on resource and energy efficiency, mountain regions can contribute to the development of new technologies and innovation more generally. I voted in favour also in view of the special nature of mountain areas for their ecosystems and it is therefore necessary to promote measures to protect representative high mountain species. A coordinated approach is crucial in whatever form it is implemented, in order to ensure an adequate strategic orientation of EU funding towards achieving sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Considering that part of my constituency is Gozo, an island within an island nation – Malta – which is however not mountainous, I deem fit to underline common challenges which are mentioned in the report. I attribute importance to year-round sustainable tourism, which can create jobs and diversified content in those areas while helping tackle the problem of depopulation and the lack of generational renewal in those regions. Taking account of the call made by the report supporting the Commission in proposing a European Year of Islands and Mountains, I would like to emphasise that not all island regions in the EU are mountainous, therefore due consideration should be attributed nonetheless to their specificities, too. Due to diseconomies of scale, which frequently affect prosperity in such regions, I agree that it is important to develop policies for broadband access and therefore support the call for the Commission to develop specific policies for overcoming the digital divide in these regions.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The resolution concerns the consequences and challenges faced by mountainous regions in relation to European cohesion policy. Thus, the report calls for a clear definition of mountainous regions under an "Agenda for EU mountain regions" on a proposal from the European Commission. Alongside this agenda, the objectives of developing mountainous areas should be integrated into the various funds. In addition, the text contains some positive elements such as the request for greater use of participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI) instruments, or priority being given to the territorial dimension of cohesion policy. It also declares the need for the European Commission to encourage pilot programmes for the recovery of traditional economic activities. However, the development of areas cannot be stimulated through public-private partnerships; it also does not help to request a higher level of volunteering for the provision of public services. In short, this resolution seeks to detract from public management, which in practice is a serious threat to the territorial cohesion objectives set out by the Treaties. Consequently, I have decided to vote abstention to the report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountain regions play an essential role in the economic, social and sustainable development of Member States: they can contribute to the development of new technologies and enhance the use of renewable energies; manage ecosystems with specificities in terms of biodiversity; their activities have a crucial impact on many economic sectors. This wealth exposes mountain areas to specific needs and major challenges, including poor availability of usable land, climate change, non-seasonal employment and environmental protection. Therefore, with my vote in favour, I support the vision of this resolution for the development of a specific European policy for the EU's mountain regions, taking account of their structural disadvantages and proposing transnational and interregional strategies to turn these disadvantages into opportunities and development of territories. In particular, I hope that the new European agenda for the development of mountain regions will take into account the shortcomings of local SMEs in terms of infrastructure, connectivity and human resources, providing effective tools to encourage multiple agricultural production linked to the development of tourism and environmental protection activities, and to strengthen sectors such as forestry which can create new employment opportunities , as well as the protection of forest resources.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountain regions in EU Member States do not have special attention in cohesion policies. The difficulty of investing in the mountains due to the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs involved in the isolation of these regions makes these areas forgotten. The rich and diversified natural resources enjoyed by mountain areas can lead to job creation in order to improve the employment situation within the EU. I voted for better social, economic and territorial cohesion by harnessing the advantages of mountain regions.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountain regions in the EU rarely come to the fore of cohesion policy. The difficulty of investment in mountainous regions is due to a lack of infrastructure and additional costs due to remoteness. This report focuses on how the EU's mountainous areas can contribute to the UNION's objectives, such as the Europe 2020 strategy. The development of resources in mountainous regions can also lead to better social, economic and territorial cohesion by providing sustainable economic development for mountainous regions. This report points out that it is crucial to link mountainous regions with surrounding areas and urban areas, which is why this approach to the sustainable development of mountain areas needs to be transposed into cohesion policy. This report calls for the introduction of a timetable for mountainous regions in the EU. The agenda would serve the important purpose of creating the foundations for the territorial perspective of the next programming period.  The report calls for an increase in the resources allocated from the European Structural and Investment Funds to mountainous regions that are lagging behind development and to focus on three types of growth: smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 This document focuses on the development needs of mountainous regions in the European Union and on their potential to create jobs and sustainable growth. calls for the definition of mountainous regions from a regional policy perspective; The document proposes an 'EU MountainOus Agenda', which would provide an additional cohesion policy framework focusing on these regions, and calls for coordination of EU policies that have an impact on these areas. I supported several amendments concerning the Carpathians region. However, an amendment calling for a separate strategy for the Carpathians and rejecting the idea of extending the region to a macro-regional strategy for the Danube region was rejected. I abstained because of the rejection of the amendments I supported.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome that this report does not call for new EU structures, new legislation, or outright new funding. This calls for a joined up approach, to tackle specific challenges faced by mountainous regions, which may help support better economic decision making, potentially leading to more private sector growth.  As a result, I can support this file.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that, in mountain areas, agricultural holdings have not benefited and are not benefiting from an agricultural vocational training system adapted to mountain specificity, I consider it necessary to initiate an analysis process at European level with a view to adopting such an agricultural vocational training system adapted to mountain specificity within the framework of the macro-regional strategy for alpine areas.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 In my experience as president of the Florentine mountain community I was able to see first-hand the difficulties that mountain areas have to attract investments, due to the lack of infrastructure and due to significant additional costs attributable to their geographical peculiarity. The Union should define a clearer and more coordinated approach, within its cohesion policy, in order to guide the funding that is available more efficiently: I am thinking in particular of Horizon 2020, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and the EU's broadband strategy. These funding programmes should focus more on the needs of the less developed mountain regions and should be directed towards supporting SMEs, in particular agricultural SMEs, operating in those areas. For this reason, a 'European agenda for mountain regions' must be drawn up as soon as possible, defining an integrated and comprehensive strategic framework for the sustainable economic development of these areas and put mountain regions back at the centre of our political agenda. I supported this report, precisely because it provides an effective summary of the measures to be implemented by the European Union in the coming years to revitalisation mountain regions and to increase their ability to attract investment.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the contribution of European cohesion policies to economic development, particularly agricultural, and social development in mountainous regions. The report highlights opportunities for development in terms of growth and jobs, strengthening crafts, tourism and renewable energy production, and highlights the need to combat poverty and social exclusion in mountainous regions.  I was particularly involved in this report as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Indeed, agricultural activity plays an essential role in these regions, particularly in terms of economic development and social cohesion. In this regard, the CAP has developed a range of tools to fix agricultural production in mountainous areas and to help its development and diversification. It is regrettable, however, that despite numerous sectoral measures within the framework of European policies, there is currently no European mountain policy. Moreover, the lack of an operational definition of mountainous regions in cohesion policy (only in the context of rural development policy) is an additional difficulty. As the final report is of excellent quality, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the European Union. In mountain regions, SMEs are experiencing serious difficulties due to lack of access, infrastructure and connectivity. It is therefore essential that the Commission pays particular attention to the development of these SMEs.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the European Union because these regions have many advantages that must be exploited through agricultural production, but also sustainable tourism and the exploitation of renewable energy sources. In supporting this report, I would like to send a strong signal to combat the isolation and poverty that affect mountainous regions. European territorial cooperation must take into account the natural and geographical specificities of these regions so that they are no longer handicaps but assets. I would like to stress that mountainous regions can be pools of employment and growth, which is why it is in everyone's interest that they are really taken into account in European policies.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. The mountain regions face serious difficulties and must be better supported according to the principle of solidarity between the territories of the European Union. There is a need to ensure both a certain level of economic and social development and to address the difficulties generated by transport accessibility and declining demographics. It is therefore essential to establish the appropriate links with urban and lowland areas, and to guarantee access to digital services. Mountain areas, with their preserved ecosystems, can serve as the basis for many economic activities. Mountainous regions have preserved living conditions, maintain traditional know-how, and offer considerable potential for conversion to quality agricultural systems at the heart of a well-thought-out cohesion policy.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In order to reduce regional disparities within the European Union, this report recommends paying special attention to mountainous regions that suffer from a lack of investment, particularly in transport, but also unemployment and poverty, which contribute to social exclusion, rural exodus and the ageing of the local population. To remedy this, it is proposed to put in place macro-regional strategies with the support of local authorities at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States. As the latter are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project, I have not been keen to support a macro-regional strategy encouraged by the EU. So I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on cohesion policy in mountainous regions of the EU because it focuses on the development needs of mountainous areas in the European Union, as well as their potential to become sources of jobs and sustainable growth. Mountain areas are crucial to achieving the EU's employment, cohesion and environmental objectives through the sustainable use of their natural resources. Mountain areas are generally disadvantaged because of their remoteness or extreme conditions, which can lead to lower social standards and an increase in unemployment, which requires the coordination of the policies of these EU areas and, as stated in the report, the creation of a working definition of functional mountain areas in the context of cohesion policy in order to facilitate policy coordination and measures on these regions , as well as creating a specific approach for them due to their structural shortcomings.  I believe that it is essential for better policy coordination and better strategic cooperation to remain in the Carpathians under the Danube Macro-Regional Strategy, because this ensures participation in enhanced cooperation that generates new projects and cooperation networks.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the social, economic and territorial cohesion of the EU's mountains and aims to create an agenda that will provide the framework for transnational, cross-border and interregional policies; We are voting against the report as a whole, although it presents many positive elements for the development of mountain areas, as it uses programmes such as Horizon 2020, the ESI Funds and the EFSI, which support the employment and smooth settlement of migrants in these mountain regions.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May, I voted in favour of the report on mountainous regions. The report calls for support for underdeveloped mountain regions, outlining the problems that these regions have to deal with.  Mountain regions have set a target of smart, sustainable, inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, but they have a serious problem with their difficult accessibility, which could be remedied by improving their infrastructure. Here, I would like to underline in particular the importance of digital connectivity, which can contribute to preventing the depopulation of mountainous regions.  The rich natural resources and renewable energy sources of mountainous regions can also help other EU Member States to grow sustainably. A similar approach should be taken with regard to the priority support for other areas with natural disadvantages, of which, unfortunately, there are also some in Hungary.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: we are absolutely opposed to the implementation of macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the development of mountain regions can promote an improvement in social, economic and territorial cohesion, promoting employment and sustainable growth. The report stresses the need for a more integrated approach to the different policies and funding at EU level. The creation of a genuine European agenda for mountain regions would promote an even more targeted framework within cohesion policy, and could also serve as a basis for a broader strategy for the development of mountain regions, and a progressive reduction of poverty and social exclusion. Finally, the report has the merit of highlighting the fundamental issue of linking mountain regions to surrounding areas and urban areas.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report raises the point that the crucial connection of mountainous regions with their surroundings and urban areas needs to be taken into account. I agree and voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountains and mountainous regions in the European Union can create a large number of jobs in the future, and we should therefore not continue to ignore investing in these remote areas through European Union funds. Until now, the European Union has reprehensially forgotten mountainous regions and their potential to increase employment through so-called green jobs, which help combat negative climate change. European Union funds can alleviate poverty and social exclusion in less developed mountainous regions. Developing the numerous advantages of mountainous regions can also lead to greater social, economic and territorial cohesion. The European Union has many policies that relate in some way to mountainous areas, but so far there is no clear, single political approach to the mountains, so we should consider setting up a European Union programme for mountainous regions in the future.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which, through a series of policies, helps mountain populations and mountain territories in general.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as a whole, although it presents many positive elements for the development of mountain areas, as it uses programmes such as Horizon 2020, the ESI Funds and the EFSI, which support the employment and smooth settlement of migrants in these mountain areas.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Mountainous regions in the EU were rarely in the focus of cohesion policy. This report emphasizes how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to its targets, such as Europe 2020. The natural resources and assets of these areas can provide jobs to improve employment within the EU, especially green jobs which contribute to the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy sources could contribute to the EU’s renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion within less developed mountainous regions can be reduced with the help of EU funds. Mountainous regions can also be a leading force in sustainable growth within the EU, as centres of green growth. On the other hand, this report calls for an agenda for EU Mountainous Regions and the consideration of the mountain dimension within future programmes and policies of the EU, especially within the ESIF. I voted in favour.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of this report as it focuses on the opportunities that mountainous regions of the EU provide to achieve the Europe 2020 objectives. It highlights the opportunities that mountainous regions provide for job creation, sustainable tourism development and the use of renewable energy sources. I welcome the call made in the report establishing an EU programme for mountainous areas. Taking into account the mountain dimension in future EU programmes and policies, especially under the European Structural and Investment Funds, is key to ensuring the sustainable economic development of the mountains. I believe that coordinating EU policies for mountainous areas ensures that EU funding has a clear strategic orientation towards sustainable and inclusive growth. At the same time, I believe that incorporating the specific dimension for mountains into European territorial cooperation would provide a good guide to mountain policy in the EU by extending the best practice platform in these areas. Finally, I support a coordinated approach to sustainable development of mountainous areas in order to make the most of their enormous potential.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report, which points to the importance of mountainous regions in the EU from the horizon of cohesion policy. It is often up to the Member States to pay attention to mountainous regions and the challenges associated with them. In particular, I support the report's efforts to highlight how the EU's mountainous areas can contribute to the Union's objectives, such as the Europe 2020 strategy.  The rich natural resources and values of mountainous regions can provide jobs to improve employment in the EU, especially environmentally friendly jobs that contribute to the fight against climate change. In addition, it is crucial to link mountainous regions with surrounding areas and urban areas, and the approach to the sustainable development of these regions should also be transposed into cohesion policy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conviction that it is very important to distinguish the mountainous regions of the EU when defining and implementing Community cohesion policy. It's not just about talking about infrastructure or combating remoteness. It is undoubtedly a question of combating poverty, the social exclusion of the least developed mountain areas of the Union. And not only — which would already be reason enough — to improve the lives of people living in these regions, but also — which is very important — to ensure that these regions continue to be inhabited, they continue to provide their inhabitants with economic resources, because in this way we will be ensuring social, economic and territorial cohesion and, in turn, the sustainability of our territories and the achievement of the european Union's environmental objectives.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the report that mountainous regions have unfortunately been somewhat neglected in the EU’s cohesion policy. Residing and doing business and other activities in mountainous regions in many cases involve several difficulties and additional costs where local actors could use EU support. These additional costs come from many things, one example being additional transport costs due to lack of infrastructure and the natural remoteness of mountainous regions. In the effort to keep our mountainous regions vibrant and alive we must work towards promoting businesses and employment in those areas and for this goal the EU’s cohesion policy should play its part.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions, because so far cohesion policy, while focusing on the territorial dimension, has neglected the mountains as such and left it to the Member States to pay attention to the mountains and the challenges associated with them. This has fuelled the difficulty of investing in mountain areas due to a lack of infrastructure and the additional costs attributable to peripherality, and as a result mountain regions have so far received insufficient attention. I strongly supported the need to arrive at a definition of 'mountain regions' within regional policy, in the sign of a holistic European approach to the problem. So far, such a definition appears in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and is designed for agriculture, since it takes account of a shorter vegetative cycle and the impossibility of using machinery because of the slope of the soil.  I also supported the need to draw up a concrete policy proposal for mountain regions, through the introduction of an AGENDA for the EU's mountain regions. It could also serve as a basis for a broader strategy for the development of mountain regions by promoting a coordinated approach.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I ended up voting against the report on cohesion policy in mountain areas of the EU, as it sets the wrong incentives on too many points and outlines a scenario that does not meet the specific requirements of the different 'mountain worlds' in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy rarely focuses on the EU's mountainous regions, which often marginalises them. The difficulties in investing in these areas are mainly due to a lack of adequate infrastructure and therefore entail additional costs resulting from distances from larger conglomerations.  I welcome the outcome of today's vote, which reflects the need to define mountainous regions precisely, to draw up a concrete policy proposal for these areas within future EU programmes and policies, especially within the framework of the European Structural and Investment Funds.  Mountain areas are attractive for tourism, but also often rich in natural resources, the use of which can improve employment by creating new jobs, especially "green" ones, supporting sustainable development. A wide variety of renewable energy sources can contribute to the EU's energy policy objectives. The development of many of the assets, combined with EU funds, will lead to greater social, economic and territorial cohesion in mountainous areas. Only a coordinated, holistic approach to these regions can be essential to ensure that EU funding is properly targeted towards sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Mountain regions in the Union often fall into the background of cohesion policy. Up to now, the Member States should take care of these themselves. As a result, no concrete, consistent results could be achieved. However, I see potential in these areas in terms of new jobs and technical innovation, given the rich natural resources. I therefore support the promotion of these areas.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Mountainous regions of the EU have been neglected when it came to cohesion policy. This report highlights the potential for mountainous regions to contribute to Europe 2020 targets, but also how the resources of these areas can create jobs, including many in the green energy sector. In addition, the report underlines how EU funds can help tackle poverty in these areas.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. On the face of it, the Iotova report is sympathetic: to define a particular approach to European regional policies for mountain regions, in order to take account of their specific difficulties. Except that the resulting European programme should be, I quote, a 'framework contributing to international, cross-border and inter-regional policies'. We are here on the other side of national deconstruction by what Brussels calls cohesion policy. The RecentLy Voted Tomasic Report dealt with sub-regional communities (urban and periurban areas, coastlines, priority neighbourhoods) without worrying too much about their administrative limitations. The Iotova report falls into the category encouraging "macroregions". These are cross-border cooperations, including with areas of countries outside the European Union, which intensify the blurring of the Union's not only internal but also external borders. That is why I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The EU has so far not had a coherent strategic approach to mountainous regions. Although there are some elements with this specific orientation (e.g. in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) there is no definition or guidelines for a regional policy in mountain areas and interventions are usually timely, linked to specific results.  We voted IN FAVOUR because, although not perfect, the overall content of the text is constructive and balanced: it highlights the specificities of mountain regions and advocates a comprehensive approach, including the convening of a European agenda, to guide EU investments and actions and facilitate greater coordination between Member States in cross-border mountains.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy in mountain regions must be a specific one, given the special conditions in these areas. In Romania and other Member States there are many mountain regions with ecosystems that need to be protected. At the same time, mountain regions face relief-specific hardships, such as difficult access to resources, difficult and cost-effective transport, frequent climate change, no professionally trained human resources, no infrastructure for community service. The isolation of mountain areas makes them unattractive to investors, and this affects economic development. That is why the Commission must find special programmes. It is necessary to harmonise agricultural policies with those of tourism, craft and handicraft production.  I support the proposal in this report and stress the need for the Member States and the Commission to make regular assessments in order to direct a policy for financing these areas. SMEs, the development of services, tourism and manufacturing must be supported in mountain regions. Attracting young people to mountain areas is a priority and the Commission must prepare measures to stimulate young people.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which emphasises how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to important targets, such as Europe 2020. In particular, mountainous regions have high potential to provide green jobs which contribute to the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy sources could contribute to the EU renewable energy targets. EU cohesion funds have a fundamental role to play in reducing poverty and social exclusion within less developed mountainous regions.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Mountainous regions are too often neglected territories. The South-East constituency is particularly concerned by this problem: mountainous areas cover 75% of the territory in the Rhône-Alpes, 50% in PACA and almost all in Corsica. However, these regions do not benefit from a specific policy that takes into account their natural, social and economic peculiarities. That is why I voted for this resolution because it is time to create a European agenda for mountainous regions. It is necessary to clearly define what a mountain area is at European level in order to put in place a comprehensive European strategy for these regions. They need additional support to face their own challenges. These areas are affected by many geographical handicaps, on the one hand, and structural handicaps on the other. But they also have specificities that can prove to be assets, whether in terms of agriculture, biodiversity, resources and cultural heritage. The resolution that has just been adopted could serve as the basis for a European strategy investing, among other things, in green jobs, SMEs and agriculture. By giving them the right resources, mountain areas will be able to face their own challenges.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. An EU framework for development strategies in mountain areas would make it possible to take into account the specific challenges and importance of mountain farming, the high levels of biodiversity and the specific exposure of mountain areas to climate change. Cohesion policy could use such a framework to better address the demographic challenges of many mountain areas and to promote their economic and social development more efficiently with an enhanced sustainable development perspective.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The report draws attention to support for underdeveloped mountain regions, outlining the problems that these regions are experiencing. Mountain regions have set a target of smart, sustainable, inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, but they have a serious problem with their physical accessibility.  Only infrastructure development would solve this problem. In particular, I would like to highlight the importance of digital connectivity, which can contribute to preventing the depopulation of mountainous regions. The rich natural resources and renewable energy sources of mountainous regions can also help other EU Member States to grow sustainably.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for both the inception of an Agenda for EU Mountainous Regions and the consideration of the mountain dimension within future programmes and policies of the EU, especially within the ESIF. Overall, I was pleased with the four main areas the report focused on: definition of mountainous regions within the regional policy, a concrete proposal for an EU mountainous policy agenda, coordination of existing EU policies for mountainous regions and a focus on the three types of growth: smarter, sustainable and inclusive growth. The difficulty of investment in these regions, caused by a lack of infrastructure and additional costs due to remoteness, often leads to the disregard of mountainous regions. However, we must remember that as centres of green growth, mountains themselves can be a leading force in sustainable growth within the EU. I believe it is important that we foster and cultivate our mountainous regions in order to achieve better social, economic and territorial cohesion.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The aim of the report is to outline the potential of these regions to contribute to Europe 2020 strategy; therefore I believe that the vote in favour is intrinsic to achieving this. This report highlights that mountainous regions face difficulties due to the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs. However, by developing these regions there will undoubtedly be an increase in jobs and sustainable tourism. Also, as outlined in the report the need to increase synergies between EU policies and to develop public-private partnerships in various sectors is crucial for this report to be successful.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to draw up an agenda for the EU's mountain areas, as the Commission has not yet pursued a separate policy for mountain areas. Two points are important in this respect: on the one hand, projects and programmes under EU cohesion policy account for around 33 per cent of the EU budget, i.e. around EUR 50 billion per year. ALFA basically asks why structural support for individual regions must be implemented to such an extent through Brussels. Instead, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, this task should be increasingly carried out by the regions and nation states themselves. On the other hand, mountain areas can already benefit fully from EU cohesion policy. A separate policy for this is redundant. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. As an elected official from Auvergne, I am particularly attentive to dealing with the issue of mountainous regions and that is why I am pleased that the European Parliament has adopted a report on this important subject.  Mountainous regions are in a special situation because of their permanent natural and geographical handicaps. However, these handicaps can be exploited because these characteristics also make them their charm and their asset. For example, the European Union should encourage initiatives to strengthen agricultural production and develop sustainable tourism, but it should also pay particular attention to all the difficulties associated with the lack of infrastructure, such as access to broadband, as well as isolation, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: in writing. – I voted against the initiative report on cohesion policy in mountainous regions of the EU (2015/2279(INI)). While I am certainly committed to development in the EU, be it in mountainous areas or in urban areas, the report overlooked the fact that growth is the result of a combination of an innovation-friendly business environment and functioning social policies. No EU-funded programme, agenda or strategy can make up for the lack of competitiveness – a principle which is equally true for mountainous areas as it is true for cities, regions and countries.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. As centres of green growth, the mountainous regions should be a leading force in sustainable growth in the European Union. This report states that we need an agenda for Mountainous Regions and consideration of the mountain dimension in future programmes of the EU and within the ESIF.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament Resolution on Cohesion Policy in the EU's mountainous regions, as I have participated as shadow rapporteur in the preparation of this document and support the proposed text.
