The European Union needs uniform development, it should allow for the survival of living conditions in areas that do not provide the population with the same conditions as urban areas. I believe that this should also be given more attention and the EU should have special access to mountainous regions as part of its policies, as they have obvious structural and other shortcomings.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are opposed to macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments. As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, there is almost no mention of the Member States, even though they are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project. The macro-regional strategy in the Alpine region, the Carpathians or the Ionian region is simply aimed at strengthening the project of a new territorial architecture wanted by the European Commission, which in the short term can threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation based on healthy relations between nation states. As a result, my vote was against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the report on the new territorial development instruments to be very good, which is why I supported it with my vote. It still considers the assistance of people living in mountainous regions and the development of local EU communities to be very essential. The aim is to improve the quality of life in these areas, increase employment and thus reduce the need for migration for job offers. Moreover, new tools can build on proven methods from before – cooperation in so-called local action groups. At the same time, this report shows once again the importance of the principle of subsidiarity, where it is often best to help at local level and with the support of the Union to involve precisely those people who know the locality and are interested in working to improve their surroundings.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the development potential of mountainous regions, particularly through tourism and renewable energy, even though these mountainous regions are in a particular situation because of their natural and geographical handicaps. This report therefore aims to enable mountain regions to make the most of the possibilities of cohesion policy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with the report on cohesion policy in mountain areas, as it brings positive benefits for mountain regions in the EU Member States and is also important for a mountain country such as Austria.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it emphasizes how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to EU targets, such as Europe 2020.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to draw up an agenda for the EU's mountain areas, as the Commission has not yet pursued a separate policy for mountain areas. Two points are important in this respect: on the one hand, projects and programmes under EU cohesion policy account for around 33 per cent of the EU budget, i.e. around EUR 50 billion per year. ALFA basically asks why structural support for individual regions must be implemented to such an extent through Brussels. Instead, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, this task should be increasingly carried out by the regions and nation states themselves. On the other hand, mountain areas can already benefit fully from EU cohesion policy. A separate policy for this is redundant.  I therefore reject this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution of 10 May 2016 on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions on the grounds that mountainous areas have a positive contribution to sustainable development, the fight against climate change and the preservation and protection of ecosystems and biodiversity of regional ecosystems. Moreover, the resolution stresses the need to protect at European level typical alpine species capable of living in cross-border mountain ranges, such as kamzci, ioculars, large predators, bears, wolves or features, and calls on the Commission and the Member States to develop plans to protect and re-plant typical alpine species in native areas. This is important because mountainous regions are particularly vulnerable to climate change, hydrogeological risks that have particularly significant impacts in these areas, inter alia as a result of the increasing number of natural disasters that can have an impact on surrounding areas and negative consequences for economic development and tourism. In addition, SMEs in mountainous regions are facing serious difficulties due to the lack of accessibility, infrastructure, interconnection and human resources, and it was therefore necessary to call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the development of SMEs in mountainous areas, in particular those affected by natural and climate change disasters.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May, I voted in favour of the report on mountainous regions. The report calls for support for underdeveloped mountain regions, outlining the problems that these regions have to deal with.  Mountain regions have set a target of smart, sustainable, inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, but they have a serious problem with their difficult accessibility, which could be remedied by improving their infrastructure. Here, I would like to underline in particular the importance of digital connectivity, which can contribute to preventing the depopulation of mountainous regions. The rich natural resources and renewable energy sources of mountainous regions can also help other EU Member States to grow sustainably.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The present report calls for a holistic and coordinated European approach to mountains as well as for the establishment of a framework in the form of an Agenda for EU mountainous regions within the context of the cohesion policy. The aforementioned proposals are crucial in order to address the infrastructural, economic and environmental challenge that these regions are facing. I strongly believe that the improvement of living conditions in mountainous regions, as well as in other disadvantaged regions like outermost and volcanic areas, can lead to a better social, territorial and economic cohesion by providing new green jobs and renewable energy sources. Consequently, I voted in favour.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The concept of sustainable survival also makes sense, not only in relation to its sustainable development and precisely in the context of sparsely populated regions. These areas have enormous ecological potential, as the report rightly points out, in order to create a sustainable future. We cannot, for the u utnist time, once again fall into the trap of a one-plane economic approach, which would result in the depopulation of these regions. The report should be supported, which sees a possible way out of solving problems with the cooperation of Member States and the Commission, along the lines of a specific and specific cohesion policy. The question is, of course, if significant results have not yet been achieved, then it will succeed.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on cohesion policy in mountainous areas in the EU, as I believe that it is imperative that EU policies have a specific approach to mountainous areas due to their structural shortcomings. These areas need additional support to be able to provide long-term, not just seasonal employment, economic development, prevention and management of natural disasters, as well as environmental protection. Mountain areas should be included in all aspects of EU policies, including cohesion policy, by introducing a territorial impact assessment. It is key for many regions to set out solutions for access to quality education. In order to overcome the negative demographic trends in them, especially in the Balkans, equal access to education and the provision of childcare facilities, as well as the training and retraining of adults, would facilitate active integration into the labour market.  Last but not least, youth employment initiatives are important as a good opportunity to stop the tide of young people in response to the demographic crisis and the problem of an ageing population in mountainous regions.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This issue deals with exemptions for negotiators on their own behalf of goods. The Commission has proposed a single review both for negotiators on their own account for goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms. This review procedure is very complex, to the point where it cannot be completed by the end of the year, and therefore it seems unlikely that any legislation will result from this procedure in a short time. Given that such a delay would have some negative effects, an extension of the exemptions provided for by the CRR to 2017 was considered appropriate in order to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms. Looking at the supported proposal in detail, I think I am voting in favour.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on cohesion policy in the mountainous regions of the European Union. This report rightly recommends paying particular attention to mountainous regions that suffer from a lack of investment. That said, the report recommends that macro-regional strategies be put in place with the support of local authorities, to the detriment of the sovereignty of the Member States. I am opposed to macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments.  As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, there is almost no mention of the Member States, even though they are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it purports to allow the Union to manage the mountainous areas, and in particular the animal species that live there, when I believe that this should remain a competence of the States. He wants to put in place "macro-regional strategies" that tend to replace the regions with the states, which I absolutely refuse.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I opposed this text by voting AGAINST it. Although the rapporteur gives a realistic assessment of the difficulties of mountainous regions, he is leaning towards solutions aimed at strengthening EUROPEAN Union interference. It is true that these areas suffer from unemployment, poverty, ageing and social exclusion, reinforced by the rural exodus. However, it is not by implementing macro-regional strategies, which place local elected officials as interlocutors and direct leaders for the development of these territories, that the EU is responding to the problems. In fact, it goes against the sovereignty of the Member States and jeopardizes the good understanding of the nations. Through this text, the EU simply aims to extend its influence by appropriating the right to carry out regional policies involving several countries.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this report emphasises how the EU's mountainous regions could contribute to their objectives, such as Europe 2020.  Given that the natural resources of these areas can boost job creation in the EU, in particular through "green jobs" that support the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy could contribute to the fulfilment of the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion could be reduced within less developed mountainous regions with the help of Union funds.  I believe that mountainous regions can also become the engine of sustainable growth in the EU, as "green growth" centres.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The resolution concerns the consequences and challenges faced by mountainous regions in relation to European cohesion policy. Thus, the report calls for a clear definition of mountainous regions under an "Agenda for EU mountain regions" on a proposal from the European Commission. Alongside this agenda, the objectives of developing mountainous areas should be integrated into the various funds. In addition, the text contains some positive elements such as the request for greater use of participatory local development (DLP) and integrated territorial investment (ITI) instruments, or priority being given to the territorial dimension of cohesion policy. It also declares the need for the European Commission to encourage pilot programmes for the recovery of traditional economic activities. However, the development of areas cannot be stimulated through public-private partnerships; it also does not help to request a higher level of volunteering for the provision of public services. In short, this resolution seeks to detract from public management, which in practice is a serious threat to the territorial cohesion objectives set out by the Treaties. Consequently, I have decided to vote abstention to the report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. Because the mountain regions of the union have rarely been at the heart of cohesion policy, I think it is time for Member States to pay attention to these isolated regions.  The lack of infrastructure and the additional costs arising from its geographical conditions, make these areas need a concrete proposal like the one presented in this report. I consider it extremely important to conserve these natural landscapes, with a great wealth of resources and which also generate green jobs and contribute to the fight against climate change, one of the Union's top priorities in recent years.  For the reasons set out above, and because I am sure that a specific mountain political agenda will help to achieve the much-pursued intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth we are looking for and because this report also calls for support for the use of renewable energy and for overcoming the common challenges that exist in these regions and thus curbing their depopulation, I welcome its adoption.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to draw up an agenda for the EU's mountain areas, as the Commission has not yet pursued a separate policy for mountain areas. Two points are important in this respect: on the one hand, projects and programmes under EU cohesion policy account for around 33 per cent of the EU budget, i.e. around EUR 50 billion per year. ALFA basically asks why structural support for individual regions must be implemented to such an extent through Brussels. Instead, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, this task should be increasingly carried out by the regions and nation states themselves. On the other hand, mountain areas can already benefit fully from EU cohesion policy. A separate policy for this is redundant.  I therefore reject this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 It's just another social engineering to direct subsidies for young mountain farmers. According to the report, "creating new jobs in the green economy is to be one of the investment priorities of the ESI Funds", which are intended to "promote training in areas such as mountain farming and renewable energy technologies". Instead of creating these funds, the EU would do better to leave the money in the pockets of citizens who would rather buy organic products. And farmers would certainly be able to grow their products without EU training.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The report highlights the importance of mountainous regions representing a significant part of the EU territory. Many mountainous regions face problems of depopulation and an ageing population, leading to lowering social standards, rising unemployment, social exclusion and migration to cities. This report focuses on how mountainous regions can help achieve europe 2020 targets. Mountain regions offer an opportunity to achieve the EU's objectives, in the areas of employment, cohesion and environmental protection through sustainable management of natural resources. The natural resources of mountainous areas can help create new jobs and increase employment in the EU, in particular green jobs, which can contribute to the fight against climate change. Better policy coordination is necessary, as there are large differences between individual mountainous regions. Mountain regions can receive great support through various EU funds, which need to be complementary, deliver synergistic impact and achieve better and inclusive development. I supported this report as it aims to improve access and use of EU funds and policies through territorial development initiatives and cooperation at European level, with a view to improving socio-economic living conditions in mountainous areas.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 42% of the settlements in the mountainous regions of Bulgaria have less than 100 inhabitants, and in 25% of them there are no children under the age of 14. Approximately the same levels of marginalization of mountainous regions in social and economic terms we register in both the Carpathians and the mountains on the territory of Greece.  Today, my Colleagues in the European Parliament adopted by a large majority a resolution on cohesion policy in mountainous areas of the EU, which aims to secure additional targeted investments. As a result of the depopulation of these areas, real opportunities for their development are wasted.  The demographic collapse affecting the whole of Europe is particularly pronounced there. Providing better infrastructure in mountainous areas is key to attracting new investment. The resolution treats the aforementioned problems and draws attention not only to agriculture and tourism as areas of investment, but also to the potential for the development of renewable energy based on water resources, wind, sun and biomasi. Creating employment by subsidising small and medium-sized enterprises is also central to increasing the attractiveness of mountainous areas. I supported the adoption of the resolution because it is a step towards providing more favourable conditions for investment in the current and next programming periods.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountain areas have their specifics in terms of availability, climate, environment, infrastructure and population density. It is important that EU policy comprehensively take these specificities into account and that it sets and promotes conditions that promote the creation of green jobs and make effective use of the potential of mountainous areas. I therefore support the creation of a separate EU programme for mountainous regions, which will be the basis for their development strategy. With support from the European Structural and Investment Funds, we can create areas of economic growth from mountainous regions, with a view to protecting the environment and natural values.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 First of all I refer to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/5/2016. I note that I abstained in the vote on the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions because this report is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. We pass on the rosary of common places seeded by this report: the mountainous areas would, because of their isolation, be more prone to the evils associated with social exclusion (poverty, unemployment, ageing of the population). The report's proposals to remedy this situation are, once again, an interference with the prerogatives of the Member States. By proposing the management of the structural funds in partnership with the competent local authorities, the European Union is taking into account its desire to dilute the nation state through the regionalisation of the European territory. Firmly opposed to this vision of our territory, we can only reject this report.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions. Mountain regions do not receive sufficient attention to the problem of lack of infrastructure and their peripheral location (i.e. additional costs). However, the EU mountains would contribute to achieving objectives such as the 2020 Strategy (on renewable energy) so they are of considerable importance. The heritage and wealth of natural resources in these areas would offer green jobs, which can improve employment in the EU and combat climate change. With the sustainable economic development of mountain areas, an improvement in territorial, economic and social cohesion can be achieved. Sustainable growth within the EU can be given by the mountains themselves as they are centres of green growth.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The issues in mountain regions mentioned in the report are also specific to the mountainous regions of Italy, particularly those in the south, where development and inequality problems are most serious. People in these regions do not receive enough support and are at risk of losing their habits, even if they form the backbone of Italy (also geographically). I welcome the report's focus on SMEs and the gender equality situation in mountainous regions. The mountain environment poses specific challenges for SMEs and we must therefore find solutions to support these businesses and share best practices. Above all, I supported the resolution in its support for the next generation. We cannot let this thousand-year-old tradition and culture die; In order to keep them alive, we must support education, training, and job creation in these regions.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the cohesion policy report in the mountainous regions of the EU, territories that often suffer many difficulties because of their geographical situation, lack of infrastructure and additional costs arising from remoteness. This makes the lives of the inhabitants of these areas more complicated, who are discriminated against against residents in other territories. That is why we must work to help these territories in a special way and to harness their potential also in many respects, which can contribute to EU growth. To be sure, the development of many of the assets of mountain regions can also lead to better social, economic and territorial cohesion by facilitating the sustainable economic development of the mountains. As centres of ecological growth, mountains can be a driving force in sustainable growth in the Union.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The neglect of the Union's mountain areas is a fact, since the vast majority of development policies concern lowland areas. However, I believe that the difficulties that exist, such as the lack of specific infrastructure and the need for more expenditure due to the isolation of these areas, must be overcome in order to make methodical and proper exploitation of mountain areas based on their specificities. The natural wealth of the mountains leading to an abundance of renewable energy sources can help the Union's policies aimed at protecting the environment. This will create new jobs, the so-called 'green' positions in the report that contribute to the fight against climate change. Cohesion policy in mountain regions will also be able to contribute to combating the poverty and social exclusion experienced by the inhabitants of these regions, with the ultimate aim of sustainable economic development of the mountains. I would therefore like to vote in favour of the resolution since I am in favour of the need for an agenda to develop a policy for the mountain regions of the Union, combining the individual indirect policies relating to the mountains, with the ultimate aim of achieving a more comprehensive strategy for the development of mountain regions.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the provisions set out in the EP resolution to strengthen cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions and thus exploit the potential of the natural resources contained therein. I believe that creating green jobs in these regions would help to combat climate change and contribute to reducing poverty and social exclusion.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report proposes to work on a common definition of mountainous regions that would better recognize the structural difficulties of these territories: remoteness, depopulation, additional transport and access costs, and lack of investment. Such a definition would allow for a better focus on cohesion policy funds. And these territories also have underestimated challenges and assets, especially in terms of renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, the fight against climate change, especially through their glaciers, etc.  Despite disagreements, such as the promotion of projects as questionable as the current Lyon-Turin TGV or public-private partnerships, I vote for this text which takes into account the outermost regions and their volcanic islands living in the fragile and permanent balance of threat of natural disaster and unique biodiversity.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The European Union's macro-regional strategic enterprise is a problem in serving national governments. The EU follows its logic of evacuating intermediaries, obstacles to its power, in order to be directly and increasingly connected to local authorities. This is highlighted by the lack of mention of Member States in a matter that concerns them primarily. I fear for the good cooperation of the peoples in these regions if a third power comes to impose it on all. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountainous regions represent a significant share (about 30%) territory of the EU and the whole EU depends on its ecosystem services. These regions are structurally disadvantaged due to their extreme conditions and their outermost character, to the point that many mountainous regions face problems of depopulation and ageing of populations, which can disrupt the natural generational cycle and lead to a degradation of social standards and quality of life, considering that this situation is often associated with increased unemployment , social exclusion and migration to urban centres. Mountainous regions offer numerous opportunities to achieve the EU's employment, cohesion and environmental protection objectives through the sustainable use of their natural resources. It is therefore necessary to find appropriate cohesion policies for these less favoured regions so that they can develop their full potential. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution that draws attention to an important component of the Union’s cohesion policy. By providing a more generally applicable definition of mountainous regions we can more easily contribute to a holistic approach to mountains, properly take into account the characteristics of these regions and sustainably further develop these parts of the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The EU's mountain areas have hitherto been treated stepmotherly. The EU does not have a specific policy for the mountain areas and their adjacent zones, perhaps because it was assumed that mountain areas, due to the strength of their tourism assets and a locally anchored economic fabric, are self-sustaining, need little care and that member states do not take the challenges of these areas to heart.  In recent years, the understanding of the strengths and problems of these mountain areas has increased to such an extent that their potential contribution to meeting the European objectives of energy, climate control and employment must be translated into policy. These unexplored areas, with their high biodiversity, their natural resources and their multiness of renewable energy sources, deserve their place in the European approach to climate change and the development of green jobs. However, it is necessary to make investments that ensure the opening up of these areas and that economic and environmental interests are reconciled.  Parliament is right to ask the Commission to draw up an agenda for mountain areas. It is logical that the development of mountain areas and adjacent zones should be included in eu policies and programmes.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Mountainous regions are rarely at the heart of cohesion policy. Underdeveloped infrastructure and the need to incur additional costs due to their remoteness are hampering the development of mountainous regions and the influx of investment, resulting in poverty and social exclusion, which must be addressed through the European Structural and Investment Funds and in cooperation with other European Union instruments. Abundant natural resources and the abundance of renewable energy sources can provide employment opportunities, thus contributing to improving employment within the Union and to the Union's renewable energy objectives. I believe that increasing the importance of agricultural production and the subsequent promotion and labelling of agricultural products from mountainous regions will contribute to their development. I also agree on the need to increase synergies between European Union policies and to develop partnerships in both the public and private sectors in the areas of transport, communication and energy infrastructure. I express my support for the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that emphasises how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to its targets, such as Europe 2020. The natural resources and assets of these areas can provide jobs to improve employment within the EU, especially green jobs which contribute to the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy sources could contribute to the EU renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion within less developed mountainous regions can be reduced with the help of EU funds. Mountainous regions can also be a leading force in sustainable growth within the EU, as centres of green growth. On the other hand, this report calls for an agenda for EU mountainous regions and the consideration of the mountain dimension within future programmes and policies of the EU, especially within the ESIF.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Regional Development proposes a resolution to be adopted by the European Parliament on how the EU's mountainous regions can contribute to the Union's objectives, such as the Europe 2020 strategy. The report points out that, in addition to the agricultural definition of mountainous areas used today, there is also a need for a regional policy definition that takes into account the crucial importance of linking mountainous regions with surrounding areas and urban areas.  It urges the introduction of a road map for mountainous regions in the EU, based on policies such as Horizon 2020, COSME, LIFE, Natura 2000, the EU Broadband Strategy, the EU Climate Change Adaptation Strategy, the EU Environment Action Plan, the European Network Finance Facility, European Territorial Cooperation, the European Structural and Investment Funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI).  It calls for support for the use of sustainable energy sources in mountainous areas, taking into account their potential ecological impact. It also calls for bridging the digital divide, which could be an important step towards halting the depopulation of some mountainous regions. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. We are absolutely opposed to macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments. As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, there is almost no mention of the Member States, even though they are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project. The macro-regional strategy in the Alpine region, the Carpathians or the Ionian region is simply aimed at strengthening the project of a new territorial architecture wanted by the European Commission, which in the short term can threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation based on healthy relations between nation states. Vote against it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Although mountainous regions account for about 28.8 % of the territory, there lies 16.9% of the EU population. These regions face a number of common and at the same time problems specific to each region due to the specificities of their economy, climate characteristics and the diversity of existing natural resources. While Union policies have a major impact in these regions, in particular on environment and climate change, transport and connectivity, as well as on aerial entrepreneurship, these policies do not cover a specific dimension relating to their condition, and there is no specific EU policy for mountainous regions. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I consider it essential to create and coordinate specific Union policies for mountainous regions in order to cope with the disadvantageous constraints they face and thereby promote their sustained development.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. We are absolutely opposed to the implementation of macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments. The European Union wants, as usual, to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, there is almost no mention of the Member States, even though they are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project. The macro-regional strategy in the Alpine region, in the Carpathians or in the Ionian region, is simply aimed at strengthening the project of a new territorial architecture wanted by the European Commission, which in the short term can threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation, the basis of healthy relations between nation states. So I voted against it.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountain regions have rarely been at the heart of cohesion policies in the European Union. By focusing solely on the territorial dimension, cohesion policies have often underestimated the specificities of mountain areas, defined solely for their rural dimension and without distinguishing between developed and underdeveloped areas. The specificity of mountain areas makes it all the more necessary to develop targeted cohesion policies, in the full conviction that such an investment can contribute to the achievement of the objectives set, moreover, by the Europe 2020 strategy. The wealth of these areas, which until now has only been partially exploited, can become an opportunity for new, quality and sustainable jobs that value local traditions and knowledge, and help mitigate climate change. The mountain regions, Europe's green lungs, can therefore become the catalyst for new intelligent, sustainable and inclusive economic development projects. I therefore strongly support the EU's mountain regions agenda as an indispensable tool for a coordinated and strategic approach. The agenda is a coordinated framework for EU policies, starting with the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on cohesion policy in the mountain regions of the European Union. Territorial cohesion is one of the important components of the TFET but, although it represents a great opportunity, it still lacks full application. In this context, mountain areas need to return to the centre of cohesion policies. They can be one of the preferred ways of achieving the objectives that the European Union has set itself with the Europe 2020 strategy. In addition, cohesion policy takes on even more important features when it comes to the potential impact it could have on increased employment in mountain areas, especially in the green economy sector, thus contributing to the fight against climate change. Sustainable development must start again, first and for all, from mountain areas, which represent environments that are still protected, which must be able to adapt to a global market while maintaining the characteristics and specificities of the territory. Mountainous areas are often rich in renewable energy sources that are not fully exploited. Cohesion policies in mountain regions must be able to allow the development of alternative energy sources by financing the construction and maintenance of these structures.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report underlines that mountainous regions face serious challenges, with unemployment and a steady decline in living standards a constant problem, leading first to an exodus of the population and then to the total depopulation of such regions.  In this context, I think it is important not to emphasise the sea level standard in the geographical definition in the first place, and not to forget to support other regions that are geographically secluded and easily built, in addition to supporting mountainous regions.  They are very significantly disadvantaged in my country, in southern and eastern Slovakia, and, contrary to the report, are much lagging behind the industrially or touristically developed mountainous regions of Slovakia.  The exploitation of the potential of mountainous regions should be supported, but the exploitation of common social resources must be kept in line with the potential of natural resources, which can be achieved primarily by developing a rational policy. A good example is the design of motorway routes in Hungary, where the construction of expensive valley bridges and tunnels on difficult mountainous sections was prioritised instead of obvious routes on the plains.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The current cohesion policy rarely targets mountainous regions. I have voted for this report that will bring a coordinated EU policy and an Agenda for EU Mountainous Regions. It also establishes a definition of mountainous regions.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Mountain regions are very important because of the opportunities and potential they have in solving local, national and global problems. However, worrying trends, such as depopulation and population ageing, are particularly exacerbated in them. I therefore believe that ways and instruments should be sought through European cohesion funds in order to stop and even reverse these trends. Investments in a closed production cycle are an opportunity to do so. They ensure that the added value of the whole process remains in the region concerned. Farmers in the mountains are more difficult to achieve the economic performance of their competitors than other regions because of transport, natural and other constraints. For this reason, I believe that they should look for ways of merging, and in addition to being able to offer more production and reduce the costs of each producer individually, this would also help them in negotiations with the purchasers. I also support the call to streamline administrative procedures for these mountain producer organisations. The ambiguity and lack of sufficient mechanisms to promote the designation "mountain product" at European level are still a fact. For this reason, it has not reached the desired effect and recognition. Taking this into account, I strongly believe that the EC should offer financial instruments for its promotion.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions. Although mountain regions are an important part of the EU' territory, they are structurally disadvantaged due to extreme conditions and their peripheral character. As S&D ITRE coordinator, I stress the importance of achieving the EU's renewable energy targets and the development of energy and communications infrastructure. The Commission should develop specific policies to reduce the digital divide in these regions, including through the necessary public investment. New information and communication technologies offer varied opportunities for work, social inclusion and empowerment in the developing digital economy, and ESI Funds could be used for such opportunities. Easier access to new information technologies can lead to the development of distance educational programmes as well as eHealth services in mountain areas. I encourage the proposal and exchange of examples of good practice, thereby contributing to the economic diversification of mountain areas.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ Mountainous regions in the EU face distinct social, environmental, technical and economic challenges such as depopulation, poor infrastructure and few employment opportunities.  However, as this resolution rightly points out, the natural environment of mountainous regions also offers untapped resources that could be used to create green, environmentally friendly jobs. I voted to adopt this resolution because it addresses concrete ways for the EU to respond to these issues through, amongst others, the development of an Agenda for EU Mountainous Regions. Such an agenda should earmark funds from, in particular, the European Structural and Investment Funds and set out a plan for how to best tap into the natural resources of mountainous regions to ensure more inclusive, cohesive and sustainable development and growth.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report calls for a definition for mountain regions, which make up 30% of EU territory, and the creation of a single strategic approach towards these regions. This sustainable, strategic approach is much needed and is a matter which affects certain areas of rural Ireland, especially along the West Coast and the Northern part of our country. The report calls for steps to be taken to overcome issues of accessibility and a lack of infrastructure and public services, and to create employment and combat depopulation, while also taking into consideration cross-border issues. The challenges caused by youth exodus from these regions are also referred to. The Irish Government has treated rural Ireland shamefully – services have been stripped, our island communities have been attacked, young people have fled in their thousands and the poverty rate in rural Ireland has increased. The neglect of rural Ireland including mountainous regions has starved our communities of investment, funding and services and has contributed to depopulation and isolation. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Mountainous regions could contribute to the EU's objectives, for example by providing green jobs as well as renewable energy sources. At the same time, the EU's mountainous regions are rarely at the heart of cohesion policy, due to a lack of infrastructure and additional costs. A call is made for an EU mountainous region action plan to contribute to their economic and social development in the light of sustainable development.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Cohesion policy is the EU's main investment instrument, reducing the disparities in development between EU regions. Given the difficult situation of mountainous regions, they should be included not only in cohesion but also in all EU policies. A common definition of mountain regions should be established and applied. In addition, specific EU policy measures for mountainous regions should be established and appropriate coordination, monitoring and control should be ensured. In addition, on the basis of the progress of the Alpine macro-regional strategy, an EU agenda for mountain regions should be established. In order to promote the use of renewable energy sources and to reduce the digital divide, to increase the employment of young people and women, various types of incentives and other support measures should be applied.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which adopts more targeted and coordinated policies for eu mountain regions which are rarely at the heart of cohesion policy. This report calls for the development of an agenda for the EU's mountain regions and the inclusion of the mountain dimension in future EU programmes and policies, in particular in the European Structural and Investment Funds. The EU's mountain regions can contribute to its objectives, such as Europe 2020. Rich natural resources and the advantages of mountain regions can create jobs by improving employment within the EU, in particular green jobs that contribute to the fight against climate change. It is also important to develop synergies between the various funds and measures (including rural development) to take account of the specificities of mountain areas in the preparation and examination of operational programmes.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to my colleague's proposal, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour. It seems clear to me and fully acceptable that mountain regions should be included in the Union's cohesion policy in order to promote sustainable development and social inclusion in the regions themselves. Therefore; On the basis of the considerations expressed, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The EU is built on a solid foundation of solidarity, trust and the idea that together we can achieve more than we could ever achieve alone. I vote for the cohesion policy in mountainous regions of the EU, to enable a more effective and productive environment for SMEs and other local businesses affected by environmental issues in mountainous regions.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Mountainous areas are rarely the focus of the Union's cohesion policy, although they cover as much as 30% of European territory, a significant figure. They are important because the whole of the European area depends on the services of these areas.  I support this Report as it focuses on how mountainous areas can contribute to achieving the objectives of the European Union. I welcome the Report for its expressed aspiration to foster employment and economic progress in mountainous regions by stimulating the eco-product market, labelling the mountainous origin of products and preserving small, family producers and farmers, and the policy set out for sustainable development, which I consider positive, as it aims to keep young people, encourage milk production and use renewable energy sources. I hope that the goals outlined in it will indeed be revived soon.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that issues relating to mountain areas should be more relevant in EU policies, becoming aware of their enormous potential. The Union must therefore support access to these areas, develop a focus on environmental protection and an approach to overcoming common challenges, in particular on connectivity and accessibility. We also need to look at the mountain regions with resources to be used to improve a number of crucial areas such as employment, renewable energies, social, economic and territorial cohesion. As centres of green growth, the mountains themselves can act as catalysts for sustainable growth within the EU. In order to achieve objectives for the defence, development and use of mountain areas, however, the Union needs to establish an agenda for mountain regions and to include these issues in the future guidelines of the Union's environmental and territorial policies.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of a European Parliament resolution on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. I call on the Commission to work on an 'EU Mountain Region Programme' which should be a framework contributing to international, cross-border and interregional policies, and I believe that this future programme should set out priorities for the development of these regions in order to better align sectoral policies, to manage their funding opportunities through EU funds and to deliver long-term sustainable policies in the area of inclusion. I emphasise the importance of achieving synergies between policies, instruments and sectors, for which an integrated approach needs to be applied, and highlight the valuable experience gained in implementing the Alpine Convention, which aligns economic, social and environmental interests. I note that SMEs in mountainous regions face serious difficulties stemming from poor accessibility, infrastructure and connectivity and a shortage of human resources, and I call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the development of SMEs in mountainous regions, especially in areas affected by natural and climate disasters, and therefore call on Member States to prioritise investment in infrastructure and in services in mountainous regions.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This report focuses on mountainous regions, regions with low demographic rate, aged, without economic dynamism and justifying specific approaches to promoting their development and cohesion with other REGIONS OF THE EU. Some development strategies may contribute to the reversal of this situation include: agricultural and craft development, sustainable tourism practices, physical and digital accessibility, the development of renewable energies and ecosystem protection, policies to attract young people, improved health and education services, promotion of transnational and cross-border dialogue, considering that mountainous regions are not necessarily confined to just one Member State. These are correct positions, if carried out in a logic of public and strategic promotion of territorial cohesion. However, the tendency to involve eu cohesion policies and funds with the logic of structural reforms and macroeconomic conditions, in the hat of greater link between Juncker Plan funds and cohesion and investment funds, the tendency to take importance from Member States and their role in strategic management by shifting funding and policy actions to macro-regions , or the response of digitization as a means of promoting depersonalized and precarious working relationships, deserve our reference and will count on our full opposition.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support Iotova's report and the eu's newer, tougher approach in ensuring compliance when developing regions, as provided for in Article 174 TB. treaty on the functioning of the EU. A coordinated approach in the territories of these regions also means greater interdethasure between Member States, which really justifies cohesion policy's purpose, but it goes beyond the Union, making this policy truly significant for the entire geographical area of the European continent. Although they are left behind in technological terms and inaccessible, such regions must by no means be neglected because they offer an alternative approach to agricultural goods and environmental issues, economic development and social dimensions of life. Mountainous and mountainous areas are areas to live in, but more efforts need to be made to focus funds, primarily from the European Structural and Investment Funds, on the development of technologies and the creation of circumstances conducive to the dynamics of social and economic conditions maintenance, which in turn would contribute to greater employment opportunities and the progress of these regions.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and its Member States have considerable natural resources, exemplifying mountain areas. It is therefore surprising that the attention for these territories within the framework of EU policies, and in particular the Europe 2020 strategy, has so far been minimal. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in mountainous regions, because we should start making optimal use of the opportunities offered by these regions. This is not only a more sparing energy policy, for example, but also the creation of so-called green jobs that are in line with sustainable economic development and which can help the social inclusion of the population. It is the employment problem of the population living in these areas that is one of the problems that my own country, the Czech Republic, is also facing. I believe that the problems of mountainous regions deserve more attention at both national and European political level. In particular, the European Commission should therefore develop a definition of mountainous regions, present a comprehensive strategy and encourage the use of financial instruments for these territories to help them overcome their specific problems.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountain regions are often neglected within the framework of EU policies, making it perhaps the most challenging environment for life. Despite difficult living conditions, interest in living in mountainous areas is increasing and the EU approach needs to adapt to this trend. I support the proposal to create a definition of mountain areas within the framework of regional policy, as the only existing definition in agricultural policy is insufficient because of its unilateral focus. If this definition is created, a single policy approach can be created at the level of all Member States. It will also be important to create an agenda that serves as the basis for a more comprehensive strategy. A good and effective example of focusing on mountain areas is the EU Strategy for the Alps, which links mountainous regions and urban areas. I think it is important to maintain the population in these areas while providing jobs for people living there, especially in the environment. The mountains have a lot of potential and therefore opportunities for new jobs that would improve EU employment while contributing to the fight against climate change.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's mountain regions are rarely the focus of cohesion policy, due to the difficulty of investing in its areas, due to a lack of infrastructure and additional costs attributable to peripherality. On the other hand, the wealth of natural resources and cultural heritage of mountain areas can offer important job opportunities that can increase employment within the EU. Furthermore, the development of the many strengths of mountain regions could lead to an improvement in the social, economic and territorial cohesion of the whole continent. This report calls for the adoption of an agenda for the EU's mountain regions and specifies the aspects that should be taken into account. It focuses on three types of growth to which the Union is aiming: smart growth, sustainable growth and inclusive growth. In mountain regions, these types of growth are interconnected. Mountain areas are already a desirable living space and, with increased EU support for connectivity and accessibility, could become more attractive places to live or to set up SMEs there. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur that EU policy should present a specific approach to mountainous regions. Similarly, as regards the potential and importance of macro-regional strategies for the sustainable development of the EU mountainous regions with a strong dimension of cross-border cooperation.  However, it is difficult to accept that the Carpathians are a danube sub-region. In view of the large economic and social disparities, it is virtually impossible to reconcile the interests of the Carpathian area with the Danube region. Of course, cooperation must continue in areas such as flood protection and nature conservation, but in many other areas it is much more difficult to cooperate. The Carpathians region is an extremely important geopolitical area today, where the strategic political interests of the eu as a whole intersecte. The Carpathians as an area meet the criteria of macro-regional strategies described by the European Commission. It is therefore far premature to say at this stage that the European Parliament "welcomes the current initiatives for the Carpathians region as part of the EU Strategy for the Danube Region". I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Union's cohesion policy is fundamental in the constant search for solidarity and harmonisation of European territories. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the potential of Europe's mountainous regions, which face geographical and natural handicaps. For example, I want to talk about the Languedoc or the Pyrenees massifs in my region. Despite these difficulties, the European Union and the Member States must be aware of the opportunities for growth and jobs in these areas, particularly in the fields of agriculture, tourism, sport and renewable energy. Finally, the European Commission is invited to adopt an action plan to ensure that mountainous territories are taken into account in a comprehensive way in the various policies decided at European level.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The geographical composition of the mountainous regions represents a challenge for the citizens who populate them, as a result of the difficulties arising from the topology of these territories and the peripheral context in which they find themselves. Moreover, the treatment of economic policy and territorial cohesion does not include the specific nature of mountainous regions, bringing them to the exclusive responsibility of the Member States. At the same time, and because of these structural disadvantages (see Article 174 TFEU), it is necessary to consider a specific agenda for the "mountains" that favours the objectives of cohesion policy, in accordance with the principles of solidarity. In this area, and in my view, only concerted action by The Member States can deal with the scourge of poverty and social exclusion that are currently raging in mountainous regions. As regards the exploitation of ecosystem services, only the joint effort of the Member States will ensure the use of available resources. I therefore voted in favour of setting up a specific agenda for mountainous regions and including its own "mountains" dimension in future programmes. In this respect, I particularly welcome the proposal to increase ESI Funds as a par excellence instrument for triggering the true potential of the regions.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers' money to fund it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In adopting the Iotova report this afternoon, MEPs reiterated that not all regions of the Union enjoy the same conditions in terms of infrastructure and development, as is clearly the case in mountainous regions. Let's start with a common definition of 'mountain regions'.  And precisely there is a definition of mountains in the European Fund for Rural Development, although specific to agriculture, but which could be easily transposed into regional policy. Another area of concern for MEPs is that the EU's mountainous European regions rarely receive specific attention in cohesion policy. And too often European decision-makers prefer to let the Member States take care of the mountains themselves and their issues. However, of the EUR 351.8 billion allocated to cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, or almost a third of the total EU budget, it is still possible to make a small part of it available to mountain regions to meet their specific needs: climate change, seasonal jobs, tourism development and environmental protection. The territorial, economic and social cohesion of the Union is at this price!

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. This text focuses on cohesion policy, focusing on its implementation in mountainous regions. As a reminder, the mountainous regions make up about 30% of the territory of the European Union, and a significant part of my constituency.  We are making various proposals to support the mountain regions in the face of the challenges they face, which is why I have supported this text. Our proposals focus on issues of employment and growth in these regions, environmental protection against climate change, and accessibility and connectivity.  Cohesion policy must accompany mountainous regions so that they are forward-looking while ensuring that these territories preserve their identity and history.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Few times mountainous regions in the European Union are at the focus of cohesion policy. The difficulty of investment in mountainous regions, often related to the scarcity of infrastructure and the additional costs arising from the remoteness, often leads to them being forgotten. This report shows that the link between mountainous regions and surrounding areas is crucial. It also wants to show how the EU's mountainous regions can contribute to their objectives (such as those in Europe 2020). The natural resources of mountainous areas can be used to create jobs and thereby reduce unemployment in the EU, especially in the area of green employment, helping to combat climate change. The variety and abundance of renewable energy sources can contribute to the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion in the EU's less developed mountainous regions can be reduced with the help of EU funds. A concrete proposal is needed in the European fund strategy for these regions (a smart, sustainable and inclusive strategy).

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 The mountainous regions of the EU have been the subject of cohesion policy in a rare frequency. This report emphasizes how mountainous regions of the EU could contribute to their objectives, such as Europe 2020. The natural resources of these areas can boost job creation in the EU, in particular through "green jobs" that support the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy could contribute to the fulfilment of the EU's renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion could be reduced within less developed mountainous regions with the help of Union funds. Mountainous regions can also become the engine of sustainable growth in the EU, as "green growth" centres. On the other hand, the report calls for the adoption of an agenda of the EU's mountainous regions and the mainstreaming of the mountainous region dimension into future EU programmes and policies, in particular within the framework of the ESI Funds. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. By voting by a very large majority on this report, the European Parliament wanted to appeal to the European Commission to draw up a programme for the EU's mountain regions for the next financial programming period (after 2020). The text thus asks the EU executive to publish a communication including a programme for the mountain regions of the European Union, and then a White Paper dedicated exclusively to the development of mountain regions, based on good practice and integrating all decision-making levels. The adopted text also calls for the Commission to initiate a territorial impact study and undertake a regular and in-depth assessment of the state of mountain regions in the European Union, incorporating indicators on changes in quality of life and demographics, always with a view to optimising the arrowing of investments.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountain regions have relatively specific conditions which also have a significant impact on the efforts of the European Union and the Member States to ensure territorial cohesion. I agree with the idea that, for these reasons, mountain regions need to be given extra attention.  On the other hand, it is difficult to support a report which does not contain important provisions on the fact that, even for mountain regions, cohesion aid should be differentiated, in particular, according to the overall level of development that has already been achieved.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The mountainous regions of the European Union (EU) are rarely in the crosshairs of cohesion policy, with related issues and challenges being referred to member states. The difficulty of investment in the mountains, due to the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs dictated by their relative ultra-perpericity, usually leads to the lack of their needs. This report focuses on how mountainous regions can contribute to achieving the EU's objectives, such as the Europe 2020 strategy. The endogenous potential of these regions, especially those linked to their natural resources, can generate durable and quality jobs. The huge diversity and abundance of renewable energy sources can also contribute to achieving the EU's objectives in this area. At the same time, the situations of poverty and social exclusion in these regions can be reduced using cohesion policy. The development of many of the endogenous resources of these regions can result in improved social, economic and territorial cohesion, stimulating sustainable economic development. I also believe that a coordinated approach is needed covering mountainous regions and ensuring that the financial appropriations granted by the EU have an appropriate strategic orientation to sustainable and inclusive growth, additional reasons which led me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us of the importance of the mountainous regions of the Union. These regions rarely receive specific attention in cohesion policy, even though they contribute decisively to European objectives in a multitude of areas. This text calls on the Commission to take into account the specificities and strengths of mountainous regions, as well as to draw up a programme for European mountain regions. There is a need to strengthen the coordination of EU policies, strategies and programmes which have a direct impact on mountainous areas. Greater coherence will be made to benefit employment and economic growth in mountainous regions, but also to the sustainable growth, environment and accessibility of these mountainous areas. I have indeed supported this text which calls for special attention to the development of SMEs, to improve the marketing of agricultural products, to promote better access to public services but also to concentrate European efforts on the use of renewable energies in these mountainous areas. It is urgent and necessary that European policy towards mountainous regions be more coherent and better coordinated in order to exploit its full potential.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the particular situation of mountain regions within the Union, where infrastructural, economic and social handicaps are accompanied by the potential for agricultural and tourism development. The report proposes that, net of these handicaps, development for mountain regions should be seen as a contribution to achieving the Union's strategic development objectives, through the mobilisation of the European Investment Structural Funds and the public-private partnership incentive. In accordance with the general thrust of the report, I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The EU has so far not had a coherent strategic approach to mountainous regions. Although there are some elements with this specific orientation (e.g. in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) there is no definition or guidelines for a regional policy in mountain areas and interventions are usually timely, linked to specific results. We voted IN FAVOUR because, although not perfect, the overall content of the text is constructive and balanced: it highlights the specificities of mountain regions and advocates a comprehensive approach, including the convening of a European agenda, to guide EU investments and actions and facilitate greater coordination between Member States in cross-border mountains.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in mountain areas of the EU, as these areas are often disadvantaged because of their geographical location and therefore need special support. In particular, it is a question of creating sustainable jobs and developing local infrastructure. Poverty and social exclusion often predominate there, which we want to combat through projects specifically tailored to these regions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it has the merit of bringing attention back to the EU's mountain regions, analysing the critical elements of their development and their potential from the point of view of employment, economic growth, the social dimension and environmental issues and the fight against climate change. Unfortunately, there is currently no genuine European approach to mountain regions: in order to address the common challenges affecting these areas, it is first necessary to provide for greater coordination of the strategies and measures in question, strengthening synergies between existing instruments and taking into account the mountain dimension in the formulation and evaluation of EU policies. Only in this way will it be possible to guide and concentrate funds and interventions more effectively and to establish a framework for identifying the development priorities of these regions, within the framework of the 2014-2020 programming.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proper and thoughtful interpenetration of the common agricultural and cohesion policies can bring great benefits to rural and mountainous regions in the EU, contribute to food security, real equalisation of living conditions, the fight against negative demographic phenomena and bring numerous benefits. Cohesion policy alone, on the other hand, can address many unfavourable social and demographic trends by better targeting measures and actions.  Mountain areas in the EU account for around 17% of EU citizens, and this is therefore a very important area from an economic and social point of view. Mountainous regions require a specific approach due to difficult farming conditions in the case of agriculture, increased investment in the construction and maintenance of transport infrastructure, or greater dependence on weather and climate change. At the same time, they are also a treasure trove of culture, tradition and numerous world-famous food products, which are an important part of European identity. These areas also face demographic problems caused by the outflow of young people into cities, underinvestment and difficulties in broadband access and the availability of modern services. At the same time, these areas have specific potential for renewable energy sources such as wind, hydro and biomass. In this context, however, it should be borne in mind that the necessary modernisation measures do not seriously affect the local way of life, which is an invaluable asset.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which puts focus on mountainous regions, an area which is all too often forgotten about. The report emphasises how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to its target, such as Europe 2020. The natural resources and assets of these areas can provide jobs to improve employment within the EU, especially green jobs which contribute to the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy sources could contribute to the EU renewable energy targets. At the same time, poverty and social exclusion within less developed mountainous regions can be reduced with the help of EU funding.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy rarely targets mountainous regions in the EU. I therefore welcome the call for the creation of an EU programme for mountainous regions, which can only be used indirectly as a basis for already existing EU policies relating to mountainous regions. E.g. Horizon 2020, COSME, LIFE, Natura 2000, the EU broadband strategy, the EU climate change adaptation strategy, etc. However, I abstained in the final vote because I would have welcomed the current initiatives relating to the Carpathians no longer included in the EU strategy for the Danube region, but would have been in a separate, separate EU strategy for the Carpathians.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Cohesion Policy Report in eu mountainous regions because mountain regions represent around 30% of the Territory of the European Union and contribute to sustainable development, the fight against climate change, the preservation and protection of regional ecosystems and biodiversity, and also offer a large number of opportunities to achieve the objectives of the European Union – employment, cohesion and environmental protection – through the sustainable use of their natural resources. Cohesion policy often overlooks the importance of mountainous regions due to the difficulty of investing in them in terms of lack of infrastructure and transport costs. The report places great emphasis on reducing poverty and social exclusion in EU mountainous areas, but at the same time states that mountainous areas can contribute to the European Union's objectives, such as Europe 2020. Mountainous areas are underused sources of generating new, green, jobs that contribute not only to the employment of EU residents, but also to the fight against climate change. The report calls for the use of renewable energy sources in mountainous areas, but taking into account the environmental impact they may have. It also cites the importance of reducing the digital divide in these areas, and stresses the need to allocate more resources to underdeveloped mountainous areas.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although mountainous areas account for a significant part of the EU's territory (around 30 %) currently face very serious problems. The situation in mountainous areas is particularly concerning because extreme conditions and their remoteness lead to depopulation and an ageing population, which can disrupt the natural cycle of a generation and lead to a reduction in social standards and quality of life. The EU is honoured that the fate of mountainous areas is not indifferent to it and, in the interests of their social and economic development, it comes up with proposals and measures that can help them create new opportunities. I supported the resolution because I believe that cohesion policy will also help to stem population migration to cities, improve employment and thus quality of life in mountainous regions. Although there are major differences between mountainous regions, I believe that the EU and the Member States will help these areas in all aspects of EU policy, including cohesion policy, in order to overcome the existing problems.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union defines goratost as a serious and permanent natural barrier, which is now widely accepted as an outdated conception. Mountain regions do bring certain challenges, but also development opportunities.  The report takes the view that cohesion policy should treat mountain ing regions as specific areas offering specific economic activities, job opportunities, are ecologically vulnerable and pose certain challenges for forestry and agriculture.  With regard to tourism development and environmental protection activities, the report highlights the importance of ensuring diversified agricultural production and structuring the food chain in mountain areas, thus giving farmers greater bargaining power. At the same time, it also includes a requirement for spatial regulation in mountainous regions, including public participation and strengthening the link with the existing Alpine Convention.  It also underlines the need to protect iconic high-altitude species at European level and to set up an agenda for THE EU's mountainous regions and to take into account the mountain dimensions in future EU programmes and policies, in particular in the context of the European Structural and Investment Funds.  As the requirement to include the water sector link with public-private partnerships was rejected in the report and the gender dimension and the environmental dimension, including climate challenges, were strengthened, I also supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The rapporteur calls on the Commission to draw up an agenda for the EU's mountain areas, as the Commission has not yet pursued a separate policy for mountain areas. Two points are important in this respect: on the one hand, projects and programmes under EU cohesion policy account for around 33 per cent of the EU budget, i.e. around EUR 50 billion per year. ALFA basically asks why structural support for individual regions must be implemented to such an extent through Brussels. Instead, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, this task should be increasingly carried out by the regions and nation states themselves. On the other hand, mountain areas can already benefit fully from EU cohesion policy. A separate policy for this is redundant.  I therefore reject this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the basis for european Union solidarity. Due to remoteness, mountainous areas are mostly structurally disadvantaged, which can disrupt the natural cycle of generations and lead to a reduction in social standards and quality of life. Mountain cross-border cooperation is a sustainable way to promote the economic and social development of Europe's regions and cities.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Mountain regions occupy about 30% of the territory of the European Union. The EU area depends on services related to the ecosystems of mountainous regions that offer a range of opportunities to achieve Europe's employment, cohesion and environmental objectives through the sustainable use of their natural resources. Despite the importance of mountainous regions, there is no clear definition of mountainous areas in EU regional policy, and that definition used under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) is not adequate for cohesion policy and cannot be used as such to effectively manage this policy.
