Furthermore, significant differences are emerging between mountainous regions, which is why there is a need for coherent policy and sector action between different as well as within individual mountainous areas.  I support this report because I believe that mountainous regions should be given special attention to help them overcome problems such as climate change, off-season unemployment, economic development and the prevention of natural disasters. In order to improve the coordination of the policies and measures concerned under EU policies, mountainous regions with obvious structural weaknesses should be addressed in a unique way. It is also important to establish a working definition of functioning mountain regions in the context of cohesion policy, which will complement the definition of mountain regions used in the context of the EAFRD.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Mountain regions occupy about 30% of the total territory of the European Union. There is no clear definition of mountain regions in EU regional policy and the definition used under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development is not suitable for cohesion policy and cannot be used as such to effectively manage this policy. Due to extreme conditions and distance, these areas have structural disadvantages, to the point where many mountainous areas face the phenomena of depopulation and population ageing, thereby disrupting the natural cycle of generations. Significant differences are emerging between mountainous regions, which is why there is a need for concerted action between policies and sectors, both between different mountainous areas and within individual mountainous areas. Due to their specifics, in particular the numerous and diversified renewable energy sources and dependence on resource efficiency and energy efficiency, mountainous regions can contribute to the development of new technologies and innovation in general. I support this proposal for a resolution because I believe that eu policies should provide special access to mountainous regions. I believe these regions need help to overcome challenges such as climate change, economic development, employment, environmental protection and other similar challenges.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountain regions, which make up a significant proportion of the EU's territory, are around 30% of them and are at a disadvantage as a result of extreme conditions and remoteness than other regions.  I support the call on the Commission to supplement the definition of mountain areas used under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. This will improve coordination between relevant policies and measures. The definition must be broad-based and take into account various factors such as altitude, accessibility and inclination. The definition must also be so broad that it will also cover volcanic regions on islands and outermost regions.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support this report. I welcome genuine efforts to join up EU policy making, to make it more effective and to reveal the economic potential of regions with special characteristics.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because we are in favour of social and economic cohesion in the EU. Especially when it comes to mountain areas, which are difficult to access. In addition, the report deals with the creation of a definition of a specific group of mountain areas, an effort that can help create targeted policies for those regions. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the social, economic and territorial cohesion of the EU's mountains and aims to create an agenda that will provide the framework for transnational, cross-border and interregional policies and the implementation of an approach to address the challenges facing mountain regions in Europe. Although the report ostensibly presents positive elements for the development of mountain areas, its approach nevertheless follows the logic of previous already failed strategies.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 During the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May, I voted in favour of the report on mountainous regions. The report calls for support for underdeveloped mountain regions, outlining the problems that these regions have to deal with.  Mountain regions have set a target of smart, sustainable, inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, but they have a serious problem with their difficult accessibility, which could be remedied by improving their infrastructure.  Here, I would like to underline in particular the importance of digital connectivity, which can contribute to preventing the depopulation of mountainous regions. The rich natural resources and renewable energy sources of mountainous regions can also help other EU Member States to grow sustainably.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of cohesion policy, which makes important findings and recommendations on the development of mountainous regions. I believe that, despite the steps taken to create consistency, there are still contradictions in the combination of different funds. The mere politically motivated and lacking professional funds of double or multiple financing do not help the use of development resources. The territorial dimension is debated, yet mountainous areas are often forgotten, so it is up to the Member States to pay attention to mountainous regions and the challenges associated with them. Unfortunately, the Hungarian Government has completely forgotten about the most disadvantaged settlements with similarly common characteristics. I believe that, in addition to job creation, economic growth, renewable energy and the environmental aspect should be given greater prominence in these areas. Nevertheless, I agree with the reporter on the need to further strengthen infrastructure, education and vocational training. I welcome the fact that the report also takes into account in detail what the agenda and a specific policy for mountainous regions should take into account. I agree that, regardless of its form, a coordinated approach is crucial in ensuring that EU funding is strategically appropriate to achieve sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because of the importance of better coordination of cohesion funds and improvement of living conditions in mountain regions. However, I would like to make it clear that any funding for mountain regions should be based on existing national fund shares, because not all Member States, such as Finland, have mountainous regions.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The mountain regions of the European Union have rarely been in the spotlight of cohesion policy. This report highlights how such regions can contribute to the EU's objectives, particularly in the area of renewable energy. Natural resources and the particularities of these areas can also stimulate employment opportunities, in particular by creating new green jobs. On the other hand, this report calls for an 'Agenda for Mountain Regions' and to take this dimension into account in the framework of EU programmes and policies in the future. I express my support for this initiative.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I agree with my colleague Iotova and join her in calling on the Commission to begin the process of creating an operational definition of mountain regions within the framework of cohesion policy, completing the definition of mountain areas used in the context of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, with a view to improving the coordination of the policies and measures concerned. Such a definition must be broad and inclusive, taking into account various factors such as altitude, accessibility and slope. The Commission must develop a comprehensive definition covering also volcanic regions in islands and outermost regions, as well as areas that, while not mountainous, are largely integrated into mountainous areas. In this context, the idea, taken up in the European Union's strategy for the Alpine region, of including non-mountain areas in the strategy is a good initiative

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Mountainous regions represent 30% of EU territory. Yet, these regions have been disregarded and have not developed to their full potential. We need to make more out of our mountainous areas, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal. It aims to reformulate a broad and inclusive definition of mountain areas in the context of the EU cohesion policy and equip us with instruments to address the challenges which these areas present. These instruments will encourage community-led local development and territorial investments, the promotion of jobs, economic growth, and accessibility, especially for young people. Promoting the green economy as well as the digital economy could prove to be areas of particular interest, and useful to overcome the challenges of attractiveness, connectivity and accessibility in mountainous regions.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is a very important investment instrument in the European Union, because it offers opportunities for citizens, businesses and local and regional authorities to invest in development and certainly contributes to the revival of growth after the economic crisis. As the report states, this policy must pay specific attention to mountain regions, in order to exploit their peculiarities and to enable them through targeted investments, to increase the services available, promoting development and limiting depopulation. Full involvement of local realities in mountain regions also needs greater European integration.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported this report because, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture, I understand very well the problems that have been reported many times and which concern the EU's mountainous regions. Mountainous regions are often overlooked and repelled in terms of economic policy and development. EU funds are often targeted at concrete results and are difficult to achieve in disadvantaged mountainous areas. It is therefore very good that the report stresses the need to extend cohesion policy with particular attention to those areas. This will contribute to sustainable economic growth across the EU.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Cohesion Policy Report in the mountainous regions of the European Union focuses on the development needs of mountainous regions, as they are structurally disadvantaged and very often lead to depopulation and ageing of the population, which is causally linked to the reduction of standards and quality of life. I believe that the European Union needs to have a specific approach towards mountainous regions and develop a programme that will be a framework for the Union strategy with a view to achieving the long-term development of mountainous areas. However, due to the specificity of the case of the Carpathian mountain range, I believe that this chain cannot be included in the macro-regional strategy for the Danube region. I voted abstained because the call for a separate strategy for the Carpathian region was not accepted.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions.  Mountain regions account for a significant proportion of EU territory (around 30%). The whole EU depends on the services of mountain ecosystems. Due to extreme conditions and remoteness, these regions are structurally disadvantaged in such an extent that many mountain regions are facing a decline and ageing population, which can disrupt the natural generation cycle and lead to a decline in social standards and quality of life.  This often leads to higher unemployment rates, social exclusion and migration to cities. Mountain regions offer numerous opportunities to achieve the EU's objectives of employment, cohesion and environmental protection through the sustainable use of their natural resources.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The EU has so far not had a coherent strategic approach to mountainous regions. Although there are some elements with this specific orientation (e.g. in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) there is no definition or guidelines for a regional policy in mountain areas and interventions are usually timely, linked to specific results. We voted IN FAVOUR because, although not perfect, the overall content of the text is constructive and balanced: it highlights the specificities of mountain regions and advocates a comprehensive approach, including the convening of a European agenda, to guide EU investments and actions and facilitate greater coordination between Member States in cross-border mountains.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as all tools should be promoted in order to reinforce and improve cohesion policy of the mountainous region. I come from the Catalan Pyrenees and I am aware of the difficulties that mountainous regions face. The different aids should always be subject in my view to cost benefit economic analysis to avoid waste and make the most efficient use of available funds.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I am opposed to macro-regional strategies that limit the scope of national governments.  As usual, the European Union wants to expand its area of influence by intensifying its relations with local authorities. As such, there is almost no mention of the Member States, while they are the key interlocutors for the success of any cross-border cooperation project. The macro-regional strategy in the Alpine region, in the Carpathians or in the Ionian region is simply aimed at strengthening the project of a new territorial architecture wanted by the European Commission, which in the short term can threaten the sustainability of cross-border cooperation based on healthy relations between nation states. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Mountain regions account for around 30%, a significant part of the territory of the European Union (EU). These regions are structurally disadvantaged because of extreme conditions and their peripheral nature, so many mountain regions face depopulation and ageing of the population, which can affect the natural cycle of generations, leading to a reduction in social standards and quality of life. Through the abundance and diversity of renewable energy sources and their dependence on energy efficiency and resource use, mountain regions can contribute to the development of new technologies and innovation in general. Mountain farming is important for the identity and culture of mountain regions and continues to contribute to employment and to certain economic sectors in these regions, such as mountain agriculture, forest resources and tourism. The European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) should provide additional support to create synergies that will lead to better development.  I support the report, as it calls for the integration of the mountain dimension into future EU programmes and policies, in particular the ESI Funds.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mountain regions in the EU rarely come to the fore of cohesion policy. The territorial dimension is debated, yet mountainous areas are often forgotten, so it is up to the Member States to pay attention to mountainous regions and the challenges associated with them. However, EU funds often focus on achieving specific results. The difficulty of investment in mountainous regions is due to a lack of infrastructure and additional costs due to remoteness, resulting in these areas being ignored. With my vote, I supported S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The EU has so far not had a coherent strategic approach to mountainous regions. Although there are some elements with this specific orientation (e.g. in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) there is no definition or guidelines for a regional policy in mountain areas and interventions are usually timely, linked to specific results.  We voted IN FAVOUR because, although not perfect, the overall content of the text is constructive and balanced: it highlights the specificities of mountain regions and advocates a comprehensive approach, including the convening of a European agenda, to guide EU investments and actions and facilitate greater coordination between Member States in cross-border mountains.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the specific potentials and opportunities of mountain areas need to be considered as much as their challenges. Mountain areas are too diverse to elaborate an integrated European strategy. However, a framework for development strategies in mountain areas can be developed, taking into account the specific challenges and importance of mountain farming, the high levels of biodiversity in mountain areas, and their specific exposure to climate change.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I welcome the resolution on cohesion policy in mountainous areas of the EU, which calls for a pan-European agenda for mountainous areas as the basis for a future European strategy for their long-term development. The mountains cover a significant part of the EU territory (about 30%) and are at the heart of protecting biodiversity and combating climate change. Taking into account their cultural and natural heritage, mountainous regions can become a driver of green and sustainable growth through the development of a bioeconomy based on agriculture, forestry, renewable energy, tourism and crafts. Realising this potential requires a coordinated approach between the different EU policies and programmes for mountainous areas in order to provide infrastructure for physical and digital accessibility, access to education, social services, health and the development of multifunctional agriculture.  In this regard, I express my satisfaction that the resolution covered agri committee proposals for the 'revival' of mountainous areas through CAP support for the development of mountain farming and livestock farming, including mountain dairy production. The validation of the term "mountain product", the support of agrotourism and craft projects, as well as specialized training in these areas, will contribute to the preservation of identity and cultural heritage in mountainous areas.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that farming in mountainous areas plays an important role in mitigating climate change, as pastures and forests absorb carbon dioxide; I recall that farming, sustainable land management and sustainable forestry in mountain areas are essential for preserving biodiversity and avoiding environmental and landscape impacts, including on wildlife habitats, as this causes significant damage to livestock farms; I recall the importance of water resources in mountainous areas and the risk of natural hazards.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report highlights the potential of mountainous regions to contribute to the Europe 2020 strategy and to create jobs, sustainable tourism or develop renewable energy. It also stresses the importance of agriculture and appellations of origin in these areas in order to continue to grow and the need to promote tools such as improving communications and energy infrastructure by increasing synergies and through the use not only of public investment but of private investment and public-private partnership. It also stresses the need to continue to use regional development funds to combat poverty and social exclusion in less developed mountainous regions. In short, we are talking about a full and consensual report. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, which highlights how mountain ous areas in the European Union can contribute to achieving the EU's objectives, such as Europe 2020.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the mountainous regions of the EU are rarely in the crosshairs of cohesion policy. Although the territorial dimension is a topic of debate, the mountains themselves are marginalised and the issues and challenges related to them are referred to the Member States. The difficulty of investment in the mountains, due to the lack of infrastructure and the additional costs dictated by ultra-perpericity, leads to the lack of infrastructure. We follow this report on how the EU's mountains can contribute to sustainable development. The wealth of natural goods and resources in mountainous regions can create jobs and improve the employment situation in the EU, especially with regard to green employment, which contributes to combating climate change. However, this requires clearly targeted public development policies for the setting of endogenous-based companies that can counter the spontaneous market logic that tends to concentrate economic activity in cities, promoting the desertification of large portions of the territory.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report aims to improve the competitiveness of mountain regions and to support their inhabitants in economic terms. It also includes, for example, common approaches to the protection and development of nature reserves. The report calls for the development of an agenda for mountain areas. In addition, the report could well have added value, particularly for Austria, through measures such as the push for internet expansion, better support for regional agriculture and, in particular, for the dairy industry. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountain regions. This report highlights how mountain regions, which have rarely been the subject of cohesion policies, can contribute to achieving the objectives of these policies. The natural resources of these regions can provide many jobs, particularly in the renewable energy sector, helping to combat climate change. The wide variety of renewable energy sources can help Europe achieve the EU renewable energy targets. In addition, EU funds can help to reduce poverty and social exclusion in less developed regions. The report calls for an agenda for mountain regions and their consideration in future EU programmes.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on cohesion policy in mountain areas of the EU. I am opposed to cohesion policy as a whole. It is not possible to align regions and Member States with centrally allocated funding. Europe should live and celebrate its regional and national differences, rather than wanting to make them equal through the EU. It is really superfluous for the EU to put in place programmes for the protection of the chamois and eagles. There is nothing to prevent this from being regulated at Member State level and therefore on a subsidiary basis.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Mountainous regions in the EU were rarely in the focus of cohesion policy. This report emphasizes how the mountainous regions of the EU can contribute to its targets, such as Europe 2020. The natural resources and assets of these areas can provide jobs to improve employment within the EU, especially green jobs which contribute to the fight against climate change. The rich variety of renewable energy sources could contribute to the EU renewable energy targets. At the same time, proper support is needed, through the use of structural funds, for initiatives that improve the social and cultural cohesion of mountainous communities and help to overcome physical isolation and lack of cultural diversity, in particular through access to and direct participation in arts and cultural life. I represent a beautiful rural, isolated, mountainous area in the north-west of England – Cumbria – and I know first-hand the impact that the EU cohesion policy can bring to sustainable economic, social and cultural development of the regions.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The text tabled is an important tool for the support and development of the EU's mountainous and difficult regions. The report recommends the necessary conditions for job creation and economic development in the mountains, highlights the issue of the interconnection of difficult areas and their accessibility, taking into account the preservation and protection of their environmental wealth as well as their social and economic dimension and specificity. Of course I supported it, voting in favour.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on mountain communities proves to be quite good in most of its paragraphs, but contains some critical issues that have led me to abstain. It has the merit of inviting the Commission to present a concrete proposal for policy for mountain regions, stressing that mountain regions are at a structural disadvantage, to the extent that many are facing depopulation and ageing of the population, a reduction in the quality of life, the relative increase in unemployment, social exclusion and migration to cities.  The reference to the fundamental role of SMEs for the development of mountain regions is positive, and how good practices such as teleworking and e-commerce can contribute to economic diversification. On the other hand, the call for States to create incentives for a more active development of public-private partnerships in the field of transport, communication and energy infrastructure is particularly problematic, since the lack of economies of scale would make the provision of such services unattractive from a commercial point of view. I also find it problematic to call on national authorities to facilitate the implementation of transport connectivity projects in these regions with major cross-border corridors and roads using European funds and financial instruments.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the attention of cohesion policies on mountain areas of the European continent to be strengthened. In fact, although they represent more than 28% of our territory and are home to about 17% of the population, they have not so far been sufficiently taken into account by the various growth and development programmes promoted by the European institutions. At present, some mountain areas have problems such as depopulation, changes in the ecosystem and the consequent hydrogeological disasters to which it is a priority to find an answer. I particularly welcome the paragraphs in the resolution which highlight the great opportunity represented by mountain regions for the whole of Europe: they play a fundamental role both for the development of the third sector and for the agricultural sector. They are also a major source of renewable energy and raw materials. That is why creating new jobs in the green economy should be one of the investment priorities of policies. An eco-sustainable approach could be applied to both mountain agriculture, sustainable tourism, crafts, forestry and renewable energy technologies, generating new jobs.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the report presented because cohesion policy rarely targets mountainous regions in the EU, although I personally consider these areas to be very important. Mountainous areas suffer from under-built infrastructure and remoteness, leading to a lack of investment and indifference to mountainous regions. I believe that the rich natural resources and advantages of mountainous areas can create jobs that will improve employment in the EU, especially with regard to green jobs that can contribute to the fight against climate change. Mountain areas as centres of green growth can in themselves be the driving force behind sustainable development in the EU. I consider it crucial that these areas receive sufficient support to ensure year-round and not only seasonal employment and economic growth.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Iotova's report on cohesion policy in mountainous regions was supported. The mountainous regions of the European Union are specific areas that have beautiful nature, form a significant part of our territory, but on the other hand also encounter specific problems. These include, in particular, unemployment problems and related brain drain problems to areas where they are better able to be applied on the labour market, infrastructure problems, but also environmental problems related, for example, to climate change, melting glaciers or human threats to exceptional mountain ecosystems. The report focuses in particular on the development needs of these areas and on their potential to become a source of growth and jobs in the European Union. In order to achieve these objectives, we have therefore called on the Commission to focus more on the specific needs of mountainous regions within the framework of cohesion policy, to define them properly and to coordinate individual policies more. We have also supported initiatives relating to the Carpathian Region in this resolution in the European Parliament.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 An important measure that we are discussing, bringing our Parliament even closer to the territories, especially the less developed ones, which absolutely need specific management policies. Mountainous regions, in particular, can and must become a wealth of our Europe; we must avoid depopulation, especially in rural areas. More generally, we must continue to support cohesion policies, which, precisely because of their importance, must continue to be central to our financing choices.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Iotova report because I believe that the proposed approach will give greater emphasis to the role of these regions in cohesion policy. I would stress that, despite the contribution they can make to the European objectives, in particular with regard to the 2020 Strategy, mountainous regions have so far not been an integral part of cohesion policy. I would remind you that, given its structural disadvantages and its outermost character, it is essential to provide additional support to mountainous regions in their economic development, the prevention and management of natural disasters and the protection of the environment, and to contribute to the achievement of the EU renewable energy objectives. In this respect, I would like to point out that mountainous regions have the capacity to offer numerous opportunities for achieving the EU's green jobs and environmental protection objectives through the sustainable use of their natural resources.  Finally, I would like to point out the proposal of this report to call on the European Union to develop a specific policy for these regions through an 'EU Mountain Regions Agenda', which will form the basis of a European strategy to ensure the long-term development of mountainous regions and areas that depend on them.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. Mountain regions, because of their unique shape, are faced with structural disadvantages. The increase in unemployment in these areas is conducive to migration to cities and, as a result, mountain regions are experiencing severe depopulation. In order to deal with these phenomena, this report calls on the Commission to define what is meant by 'mountain regions' and to review on this basis the programming of funds that is all too often unbalanced in favour of large urban centres.  Thanks to an amendment by the M5S, small and medium-sized enterprises are given a central role in the development of mountain regions. Good practices such as e-commerce and the use of digital marketing channels can, in fact, contribute to the economic diversification of these regions by bringing prosperity and employment. However, I note the critical issues in the report and, in particular, where financial instruments and forms of public-private partnership are understood, which are mainly necessary for the revival of mountain economies. I am not convinced by the interest shown in these instruments, which seem more attentive to purely economic aspects than to real socio-environmental development of the territory. These critical issues led to my abstention vote.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountain regions, which make up a significant proportion of the EU's territory (around 30 %), play an important role in the economic, social and sustainable development of the Member States and provide a wide range of ecosystem services.  I therefore believe that EU policies should develop a specific approach for mountain regions, as they are characterised by obvious structural constraints; recalls that these regions need additional support in overcoming the challenges posed by climate change, in providing employment throughout the year and not just during the season, in economic development, prevention and management of natural disasters and environmental protection, and in efforts to achieve the EU's renewable energy objectives.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on ongoing negotiations on the first review of the economic adjustment programme for Greece (2016/0697(RSP)).

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I look forward to being with you today to discuss the latest developments on Greece's adjustment programme following yesterday's Eurogroup, a Eurogroup which was - I can say - a very good meeting, probably one of the best we have had on this subject which is really of major importance to the euro area. The last time I spoke to you about Greece, I stressed the achievements that had already taken place, including the recapitalization of four Greek banks that are systemic banks, the reform of the VAT system, the implementation of a strategy to solve the heavy issue of non-performing loans, and an agreement on the parameters for establishing the privatisation fund. This was already a series of substantial progress. I also told you that many challenges remained, including structural reforms that needed to be taken before concluding the first review of the programme. A first step was taken on Sunday with the adoption of important laws to reform and unify the pension system, as well as to reform income tax. These two measures alone - these two reforms - taken together will have a considerable permanent budgetary impact, which represents about 2% of Greek GDP. They will make the system stronger, more durable and unified. Finally, through this reform, all pension funds, for all retirees, will give access to the same building. All of this will be fairer because it is the most modest who are favoured or spared, so that, finally, all will pay their share to secure the state's income. These reforms are the result of several months of intense discussions and efforts by greece, by the Greek authorities, in close collaboration with the Commission. I would like to greet here the heads of mission of the various institutions, the European Central Bank, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), the International Monetary Fund - all those men and women who do not spare their time and are really, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, on the ground, in Athens, in sometimes difficult conditions. The institutions have worked well together. These two reforms are part of a very important package of measures that also includes the creation of an independent revenue agency, a mechanism - rather than a strategy - to manage non-performing loans and, finally, the establishment - not the parameters - of the new privatisation and investment fund with the passage of all this as priorities, priority actions of the necessary legislation. That is what we were actually asking for. Overall, these measures will make a very important contribution to the recovery of the Greek economy, and that is what we ultimately want. For the past six years we have been making these adjustments with the aim that the Greek economy will be healthier, its public finances to be stronger, competitiveness can return, growth to restart and investors to regain confidence in Greece. It is an open economy, which needs foreign investment. I would remind you that the latest forecasts, which I presented last week, indicated that economic growth in Greece would be positive again in the second half of this year and that the public deficit should fall below 3% in 2017. These forecasts are in the order of 2.7%, which is by no means negligible for Greece in 2017 provided, of course, that these reforms can be adopted. That is why it was crucial that these important reforms be concluded. The great achievement of yesterday's Eurogroup is that these negotiations on reform are finally complete, that we have reached an agreement - there are still some details to be settled and, above all, votes to be taken - and that the Greek economy in this way will be able to get back on the right foot and return to growth. There was a second block in our discussions yesterday and in previous weeks, which was the need to reach agreement on a contingency mechanism, the final details of which will be settled in the coming days, by what is called the eurozone working group, the Euro Working Group. This mechanism meets the criteria set by the Eurogroup in Amsterdam two weeks ago, namely that it will be objective, legislated upstream, credible and automatic. What is it about? The aim is to look at how to meet the target set by last summer's MoU, to generate a primary surplus of 3.5% in 2018. The Commission believes that the measures already approved will be sufficient to achieve this primary surplus target, but this is not the view all partners. The Commission has therefore agreed with all members of the Eurogroup that it is useful for a mechanism to exist, in a way, to ensure or reassure all partners about the credibility of the commitments made. In other words, what is important is that, if, if this primary surplus were not to be reached, then there would be the mechanisms to ensure that, in any event, steps would be taken to achieve it. Basically, on that second block, we also reached an agreement yesterday. It must therefore be remembered that, 1) on the package of reforms necessary for the conclusion of the first review, we have succeeded and that, 2) on this contingency mechanism, with a few details, we have also succeeded. Today's message - mine - is therefore very clear: Greece has already travelled, with the help of its partners, a very significant part of the path charted together last August, but we have not yet crossed the finish line. How do we do that? First, it is important that the measures I have presented quickly be voted on in the coming weeks. It is a prerequisite for the conclusion of the first review of the program and the disbursement that must accompany it. It is envisaged that the European Stability Mechanism will pay a large sum for the rapid payment of the State's arrears to its creditors, which will also have a positive impact on the economic recovery and will mitigate the effect of tax measures which may have - it is true - a partial recessive effect. As Klaus Regling, the director of the ESM, said yesterday, it is true that the liquidity situation is becoming more tense and this solution must be found. Finally, with regard to the third package, the debt issue, it is first and foremost a question for the Member States and for the European Stability Mechanism. But I want to say here that the Commission is quite satisfied with the statement approved yesterday. The President of the Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, proposed that we deal successively with the short-term problems - how to manage the debt well until 2018 - without a change in the programme and without a haircut, because these are two red lines that are very clearly drawn, then, that we see in the medium term - after 2018 - if and at that time what additional measures would be needed and and, finally, in the long term, for several decades, the technical measures that we might have to take to develop the debt still without a haircut. I would simply say that the sustainability of Greece's debt is a fundamental element of the agreement reached last summer and, as such, I am pleased that we have had, for the first time, in the Eurogroup an open and constructive debate on this point. The Commission is ready to contribute, technically, to these discussions in the future. As agreed yesterday, the institutional teams and the Greek authorities will now work intensively in the coming days to finalize the agreement. I am confident that we will be able to take favourable decisions at the next Eurogroup meeting on 24 May. What decisions? They can be of two kinds: first, there are the first two blocks together that could pave the way for disbursement under the program and then the design for a debt approach. It is, of course, desirable that these three issues be dealt with together and that the agreement be comprehensive. But with Jeroen Dijsselbloem, we said last night, at the end of the meeting, that there were also two tracks that were being taken. It was desirable that they not be followed in parallel, but they were distinct. We will work with the other institutions and all the partners to help the Greek authorities finalise their commitments, so that they can benefit shortly from the first disbursement. And I am giving you an appointment after 24 May to - I hope - this comprehensive agreement which will make the path of reforms that will allow for a return to growth, the return of confidence and the growth of investment. Here, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, are the few introductory words I wanted to share with you at the opening of our debates. I am, of course, at your disposal to discuss the path we will take together in the coming months, but I want to reiterate here my very deep and very sincere conviction that after much collective work, the path taken is the right one and that the path to success is mapped out. This exceptional Eurogroup meeting on 9 May will, I am sure, remain a strong date in this history of the success we wish for from the Greek programme. This is good because 9 May, as you know, is Europe Day. Yesterday we contributed a little to this party. It is not always a festive atmosphere at the Eurogroup, but we have nevertheless contributed to the progress of Europe.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When we discuss the situation in Greece today and the overview of the programme, the focus is first of all on the people – the people of Greece, who are suffering a great deal, who have suffered a great deal. What is the expectation there? What is the expectation of the people of Greece, but also of other countries in Europe, when we talk about the reform agenda? On the one hand, there is the expectation that people will want to be allowed to live in a state that is functional, that deals efficiently with the tax money it receives, that it works well in the state. The need to reform the state apparatus is not just a Greek issue, it is an issue throughout Europe. Above all, the justice system must function better in Europe. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, the citizens' desire that they have social security, that social security – the buzzword pension – also be guaranteed in a sustainable, long-term and lasting way. And it is even the case that Prime Minister Tsipras is now openly standing in Greece and saying that there is no alternative to pension reforms, that we need to reform pensions structurally so that they remain stable in times of demographic development. There is a desire throughout Europe that we will not continue with debt. Unfortunately, all those countries that have high debt burdens are also the countries that have poor prospects for the future. In other words, stable budgets – that the state does not live beyond its means – is a wish that I believe exists throughout Europe. And last but not least, there is a desire for growth. The basis, as Commissioner Moscovici has made clear, is the question of growth in the European Union. We have now got the Juncker plan up and running with EUR 80 billion that has already been paid out, and I am pleased that, in the Juncker Plan, we have now financed the first Greek project to receive this investment money. These are the wishes that are on the table and which have a lot to do with reforms, with change. I would like to emphasise that I recognise that the Greek Government is now also ready for these reforms. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she What I have now described in terms of wishes is precisely the wish list that the PPE-DE also has. That is our reform agenda for Europe. The five countries that have received aid from Europe, from the ESM, in recent years, have been governed by EPP governments in recent years and have made precisely these changes – and they have succeeded. Ireland, for example, had a higher growth rate than China in 2015 – let's face it: Ireland was better at growth than China! Thanks also to Enda Kenny for that. Ladies and gentlemen, the question arises as to why of the five countries that have received aid, four are now out of the programme, leaving only one country, namely Greece. Why? Unfortunately, I now have to become more political about God. In 2014, at Samarasˊ times, we had a 0.7% increase in growth in Greece, and last year– in 2015, when the Tsipras government took office, Greece had a minus of 0.2%. That is, growth the year before and last year again a slump in the economy. Ladies and gentlemen, Tsiprasˊ policy has harmed Greece. The last Samaras programme, launched a year ago today, when we were on the verge of completing the programme, would have meant that Greece would have to save another EUR 1 billion – a year ago today – and that would have meant that Greece would get out of the programme – save a billion! Now we are discussing the question of the need to save EUR 5.4 billion – that is the current programme. And that is why it must be said quite clearly that last year was a lost year for Greece, and that the Tsipras government has even caused massive damage to the Greek economy. Tsipras himself recently admitted that he was somewhat naive about the task of prime minister. All I can say is that Europe and Greece cannot afford to behave naively. And I would also like to say explicitly that Tsipras has now had to abandon many of his election promises and has not been able to deliver much of what he actually promised the people. And regardless of Greece, we can tell the electorate across Europe: please do not believe the populists who are pretending to deviate from the reform programme! In the end, unfortunately, it will be paid dearly by God. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she What is to be done now? The compromise is on the table. I believe that if everyone reaches out to each other, we can still achieve a great deal. And for Greece, I would like to refer to what the opposition leader Mitsotakis said in his speech. With an honest, strong leadership, he has described alternatives to Tsipras's wrong policies in Greece, a clear course for reform, for a stable budget, for a modern Greece. The people of Greece can continue to rely on Europe and also my group, the European People's Party, to stand by their side when it comes to solidarity.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one year after the outbreak of the first Greek crisis, we are once again here discussing Greece. Meanwhile, the world has changed: in just over a month' s time, on 23 June, there will be a major referendum in the United Kingdom. Europe is shocked by the worst crisis since the war. But we're here, still here, in a kind of remake of a bad movie that's already been seen. Something is wrong, ladies and gentlemen, and I want to make it clear that this has only one name: it is called therapeutic relentlessness against the Greek people. The Greeks honoured the commitments made in the memorandum. Eurostat, as Commissioner Moscovici reminded us, told us a few weeks ago that Greece's public accounts are even better than expected. Many reforms have been made. Of course, we must remain vigilant and ensure that everything is done, in particular the reform of public administration and the judiciary.  I disagree with Mr Weber on one point: for me, the problem today is not Athens, the problem is called the International Monetary Fund. The problem is the extremists, who, in the name of a vindictive vision, want to punish Greece and invent the concept of preventive austerity, that is, the idea that the Greeks three years in advance must approve measures which, as the International Monetary Fund itself has acknowledged, would kill any economy. In the conditions in which Europe finds itself today, provoking a new crisis would be irresponsible. After yesterday's Eurogroup, thanks to the work of Commissioner Moscovici and the European Commission, all the conditions are in place to successfully close the review of the Greek programme and open the chapter on debt relief – I am not saying cut, but relief – on which we committed ourselves a year ago. That is a source of pride for our group. From the outset, we Socialists and Democrats were convinced that an agreement could be reached between the parties, a fair compromise calling on Athens to reform intelligently in exchange for Europe's support and debt relief. After yesterday's Eurogroup, alibis have fallen and it is now up to everyone to assume their responsibilities, and I would like to conclude, here too clearly, that if the International Monetary Fund wants to sabotage this agreement once again, then the Union as a whole must have the strength to move forward on its own.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Moscovici and Mr Weber, it has been six years since Greece entered the Memorandums. Six stone years in which Greece's GDP fell by 25%. 40% of the Greek population lives below the poverty line. Wages and pensions have fallen. Unemployment exceeded 1.5 million people. Thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises have closed. The tax evasion of Greek property hit a ceiling and the debt, from 125% of GDP in 2010, reaches 200% of GDP in 2016. Yet the troika, and in particular the IMF, continues the "business as usual" and has imposed, with a view to completing the first evaluation, additional measures of EUR 5.4 billion, voted for by the neo-monumental parliamentary majority SYRIZA - ANEL. The troika also imposes additional "cava measures" of EUR 3.6 billion plus a budget cutter. So yesterday's Eurogroup, Mr Moscovici, continued the well-known failed memorial policy - also served by the Samaras government, Mr Weber - of violent fiscal adjustment, merch austerity, middle-class tax evasion, the sell-off of public property and red loans. Yesterday's decision by the Eurogroup is therefore a new social Armageddon, a monument to the cynicism of the troika and the lenders towards the poor Greek people. As for the so-called debt settlement, we have a repetition of the same task: refusal to immediately return the profits of the ECB and central banks from Greek bonds, which only for the period 2014 - 2016 reaches 5.1 billion euros, which could go for growth. So again promises uncertain, vague, about a supposed future settlement of Greek debt "when, if and when", of a debt that has been proven, Mr Weber, to be shameful since of the EUR 220 billion given as loans to Greece in the memorandum years, only EUR 9 billion has been granted to Greece. The remaining EUR 211 billion went into the pockets of the lenders, rescuing the German and other banks. That is enough, Mr Moscovici and Mr Weber! The Greek people can no longer stand poverty and do not tolerate exploitation and humiliation and will soon throw the troika out of our country to take Greece back.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for being with us. I am happy to hear what you are telling us about the fact that the discussions at the Eurogroup have been more constructive, that the horizon is clear. We are aware of that. I am always a little embarrassed because it seems that our discussions here are discussions of insiders, of people who see things from the inside in a rather technical way.  The truth for everyone else, for all European citizens, Greek or not, is that it has been six years - as previous speakers have said - that we have summits on Greece, exactly six years, since it was the weekend of 9 and 10 May 2010. It is also six years ago, for example, that Mario Monti's report on the single market was handed over, and it is clear that the lack of growth and the lack of investment that the Juncker plan is trying to compensate for are also due to this considerable slowdown in the Union at twenty-eight. It is always said that the eurozone is going badly, but I do not see any considerable progress or glimmers of genius in the 28-member Union.  These discussions, always the same, on the substance really give a feeling of trampling. As far as the procedure is concerned, we realize that there has not been much progress on the legitimacy of the institutions that make these decisions either. I say this with a certain sense of responsibility. Of course, it's not easy, of course we did what we could. It is one thing to do what we can as a matter of urgency; but the fact that we continue and do not see the colour of the implementation, nor the report of the five presidents, nor the previous report of the four presidents, nor the Blueprint of the Commission is another, and we have at the moment the feeling of a euro area that we do not understand. Brexit was a fantastic missed opportunity to look at the future of the eurozone. There was a way to conclude a completely different settlement than the one that was concluded outside the treaties in a rather foolish way. But what worries me the most about what you said is the number of things that are postponed until 2018.  Commissioner, are they being postponed until 2018 because it is in Greece's interest or is it because there are elections in France and Germany?

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Weber, in the five minutes of your speech you attacked the Greek Prime Minister, Mr. Tsipras, five times to help your political friend, Mr Mitsotakis, but unfortunately the truth does not help you, because your Friends of the New Democracy left Greece with a public deficit of 15.5%, with a public debt of 125% of GDP and, by the end of 2014, together with PASOK, had reached 180% of GDP. You may see Mr Weber, Perhaps even in your sleep, but I can assure you that just as you have not been able to help Mr Samaras, you cannot help Mr Mitsotakis. You will see Mr. Tsipras for many years as prime minister because that is what the Greek people want. Yesterday was a good time, both for Greece and for Europe, in the Eurogroup after six years of savage, cruel one-sided austerity, a huge recession, a tripling of unemployment, great poverty! We have finally had some positive news that can help Greece and the Greek people to finally ensure greater stability, political and economic, a faster return to growth based on the optimistic forecasts made by the Commission and Mr Moscovici and to ensure debt sustainability without any burden on the European taxpayer. But it is also a decision that also helps Europe avoid an unnecessary new crisis and destabilisation in its south-east, as it has tried with the blackmailing, irrational, irresponsible things demanded by the International Monetary Fund. Yesterday the Eurogroup rejected the excessive and unreasonable demands for new additional recessionary austerity measures demanded by the International Monetary Fund and yesterday the Eurogroup laid out a clear road map for substantial debt relief by cancelling the plans of those who wanted this commitment to be broken. We have two challenges ahead of us: Greece will honour the agreement it has signed to return to growth as soon as possible by making all the necessary reforms, but Europe, the United Europe, must honour its commitment to substantial debt relief and make it concrete and substantial.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, at the dawn of his mandate, Jean-Claude Juncker declared here, in essence, that in his view social justice was as important as the soundness of public finances. Colleagues, since the beginning of the crisis and despite three aid plans for Greece, or perhaps because of them, the three million Greek citizens who were exposed to poverty and social exclusion in 2009 have been joined by another 900,000, the combined population of Luxembourg and Malta. Some say this is the price to be paid by Greece for the mistakes of the past. I think that those who have benefited from the country's over-indebtedness - I am thinking of the financial sector, the shipowners, the arms sector, but also a clientelistic political class - are not those who are paying the price today for this irresponsibility. You will therefore understand, ladies and gentlemen, that I do not share the optimism that seems to prevail in the wake of yesterday's Eurogroup. The so-called step forward is the potential opportunity to discuss debt relief arrangements. But the price to be paid, even to start these discussions, is so exorbitant that it makes the real possibilities for debt relief completely derisory. While it was necessary to restructure as early as 2010 to make private creditors pay the price for their share of irresponsibility, six years later, the creditors who have become public are limited to waving the carrot of hypothetical relief, on the condition that Greece drinks the chalice of austerity to the dregs. This austerity, precisely, the creditors persist in accentuating it, while the IMF itself considers it socially unsustainable and economically counterproductive, the same IMF that advocates debt relief. I see that those who absolutely insist on having the IMF on board — because the IMF knows how to deal with such a crisis — persist in not listening to what the IMF is saying when it says, "Let's reduce austerity and restructure the debt." Of course, this would force the creditors, and all those who insist on austerity, to recognize that so far they have gone the wrong way. They obviously cannot admit it, especially when the government they have opposite is not precisely their political color. Secondly, of course, there is everything that is missing from the conclusions of the Council and the Eurogroup yesterday, such as the question of investment. Investment in Greece has fallen by 70% since the beginning of the crisis. Everyone knows that the investment capacity in Greece is zero, but we are told that there will be a few crumbs of the Juncker plan to celebrate. You'll understand that it won't be enough. There is also the issue of setting up a proper tax system. It is clear that successive Greek governments have not shown much enthusiasm to finally collect taxes and fight tax evasion and evasion. The Member States of the euro area could have provided them with expertise by delegating civil servants to them, but since they carried out 58,000 redundancies in the civil service, the "finance" sector, they may no longer have many people to send reinforcements to Greece. Ladies and gentlemen, I would say that without a radical change of course, the suffering of a largely abandoned Greece alone in the face of the refugee challenge will only increase without the State or its economy being able to rebuild itself. Is that all that the Last Chance Commission has to offer?

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, in 2001 on the eve of joining the euro, the Greek Prime Minister said: ‘Thankfully Greece will finally be at the heart of Europe. We will finally have greater prosperity. We will finally have greater stability. We will finally have greater ability to live our lives in prosperity’. Well face that with what the Greeks are facing today: Greek unemployment at nearly 25%; youth unemployment at 52%; the numbers of Greek young people who have left their country at 200 000; suicides since the crash at 6 000 people; the money spent on austerity – over EUR 40 billion – and every month over the next few months Greeks will have to find five billion to pay for those people who are controlling their country: the ECB and the Troika.  Is that the prosperity, the growth and the great future for Greece that was pronounced in 2001? No. But what you did have during the times of the crash was a man here in this Chamber placing his arm around the Greek Prime Minister at the time, when the people of Greece had said do not give us the chance of austerity, and I am reminded of the line from Caesar to Brutus: ‘Tu quoque, mi fili’ – ‘And also you , my friend’.  Because at the moment when that arm was placed around the Greek Prime Minister at the time of the new government and after a referendum that said we did not want that austerity, what you allowed was the arm to embrace you and the slow knife and dagger of the EU’s austerity programme slice itself into the heart of the Greek people.  And whilst there are Members here from Greece from the EPP and the Socialists who spout solidarity, who believe that they want care for those Greek people. Well yes, it is fine for you with your champagne lifestyles, but bear in mind the families who have to suffer the deaths of the 6 000 members of their families who have committed suicide.  Greece is not getting any better, because we have already seen after five years the economy shrink by 27%. But there is hope for the Greek people. As Mr Pittella said, yes, in the United Kingdom we are hosting our referendum to leave the European Union. Our growth has been better, our job opportunities better, because we are not tied to the euro. We do not have the ECB telling us what to do. We do not have control by the IMF, but believe me, to those Socialists who vote to stay in the EU, that will happen to you, too.  To the Greek people, they say the bankers will leave, the businesses will leave, the money will leave your country. I am telling you, the people of Europe will come to your country with freedom, prosperity and arms open wide when you set yourselves free by leaving the European Union too, like Britain will do on 23 June.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Greece is bankrupt. The country is a patient who has to go on the financial drip every six months. Eur 215 billion has already cost and what has happened to this money? Some 10 billion ended up in the Greek budget. Almost 140 billion has been used to pay French and German bank loans, to save these banks. European citizens must bleed for the mistakes of europe's elite. In the case of the Netherlands, it is already about EUR 25 billion. Money we'll never get back. Money coughed up by hard-working Dutch people. Consider what we could have done with those billions, for the care, for our elderly, for pensions, for strengthening our borders, for our security. The President of the Council of Ministers, Mr Rutte, promised during the elections: 'not a penny more to Greece'. What a perverted liar. The Netherlands, like so many European countries, such as Greece, faced a policy of austerity and austerity. All to keep the bankrupt EU and the bankrupt euro alive artificially. We need to shut this money tap. Not another billions to Greece, not more rummaging into the pensions of European citizens. The euro must be abolished. Greece must go back to the drachma. Enough is enough.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Madam President, the guillotine law passed by the SYRIZA-ANEL government demolishes the people's insurance rights, while at the same time generalising their savage tax avoidance. Approval by the House you have, but legitimize the people for all this you never got! Despite your competition, you all agree - the European Union, the International Monetary Fund and the government - that the criterion for evaluation is cheap work and challenging privileges in big capital. This is the strategy of monopolies that you serve with the people permanently victimized, both in the crisis and in any recovery that comes. The permanent mechanisms of successive unpopular measures, automatic cuts in wages, pensions and entitlements are the memorandums of duration of the European Union, not only in Greece but also in all its Member States. These can be put to an end if the capitalist economy itself, which is profit-based, is targeted. A determined people can overthrow it and become the same owner of the wealth it produces.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Madam President, in the end Winston Churchill was right when he said 'if you want to get rid of the Left once and for all, I would add populism, you have to let them govern for three or four months'. In the case of Greece, utopia and delusions - as the Prime Minister himself admitted in Parliament - cost the Greek people more. Indeed, the European institutions have identified the objectives of fiscal adjustment, for the Samaras government in December 2014 at EUR 1 billion, and for the Tsipras government now at EUR 5.5 billion and to add EUR 3.5 billion in preventive austerity measures. To solve the Greek problem, the Tsipras government chose the easy way, the path of raising taxes. However, an excessive increase in taxation leads to a reduction in public revenue to zero. The programme is in danger of not coming out and in October we need new measures. Debt needs to be regulated, it needs relief. Europe has shown solidarity. Debt fell by 100 billion euros in 2012, its service needs 4 billion euros a year from the 16 it previously needed. The Tsipras government cannot use the debt as the last fig leaf of a failed negotiation. Greece needs giant public and private investment, it needs to unleash all the productive forces of the country, it needs to get back on track for growth to go through this great and prolonged crisis at the lowest possible cost.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Madam President, I think it is difficult to deny that the Greek memorandum of last summer is very ambitious in its attempt to find a balanced approach between stability, growth, competitiveness and social fairness, but it is also very demanding because it is fully front—loaded in its method and extremely broad in its scope. At the same time, I think it is equally very difficult to deny that this Greek Government is delivering and is seriously committed in making reforms and implementing what has been agreed.  For these reasons it is positive that an agreement has finally been achieved on the policy package of the fiscal and structural measures which are necessary to conclude the first review of the programme. I also consider it a good result that the contingency mechanism will be based on the Greek proposal and will not impose on the Greek people additional preventive austerity measures that would have been politically and economically destabilising. I note that the institution that has strongly advocated this option produced an economic forecast on the 2015 primary balance that has proved to be totally wrong. This would have called for more prudence, which hopefully in the end is materialising.  Finally, I strongly welcome that the discussion on additional debt relief has taken place and that now there is guidance and a clear mandate to identify specific measures like maturity extensions, grace periods and this, the interest deferral, on the basis of a three-stage approach that – and this is another positive element – does not exclude further measures in the long term.  So yes, 9 May has been a good day for Europe and I would like to thank the Commission – and Commissioner Moscovici in particular – for its crucial role. Now we strongly encourage finalising of the Eurogroup guidance by 24 May in order to put Greece on the path of stability, growth and jobs and in order to give a clear signal that Europe is able to address and solve difficult crises and can do whatever it takes to preserve its stability and integrity.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen! It is astonishing to hear these speeches here, which distort the facts and paint the fact that things are no longer going on. I would like to remind you that it is six years since the European treaties were broken – by the fact that the large bailouts have been erected. Six years ago it was said that Greece would get money for three years. 2013 is said to be the end of Greece's support, and then Greece will stand on its own two feet. Six years have passed today and Greece is not on its own feet! There is talk about 2016, 2017, 2018; and Commissioner Moscovici has said that for decades to come, Greece will still have to be helped with debt servicing. Ladies and gentlemen, this policy has failed! And that the Commissioner is now saying that Greece will be better off, we have been hearing for years and days. Each time, the Commission's forecasts were several percentage points higher than the reality that was later established.  When Mr Pittella of the Socialists says that it is the IMF that is to blame for the crisis, he simply distorts the facts. Greece is not saving, as Mr Pittella said, but Greece still has to save, even though six years have now passed since Greece should have been ready for three years. Ladies and gentlemen, this policy has failed. Greece must leave the euro and should receive debt relief in connection with the exit. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, thank you for allowing me to ask a question for the third time. We couldn't have your colleagues, we probably can't at the EPP ask questions. Dear Colleague, I have listened to your point of view and I would like to understand, because it resembles that of my fellow speakers on the part of the EPP: how do you understand solidarity? Greece is a full member of the European Union. The Treaty is about cohesion. How do you understand solidarity? What would be, in your understanding, solidarity and rights in the case of a Member State with problems and difficulties?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Grapini, I would like to thank Mrs Grapini for her work I fully agree with you that we should show solidarity in the European Union with those who are poor, who have inadequate infrastructure, where the social institutions cannot guarantee the social support that we want. But I do not believe that we should show solidarity with those who are uneconomical. I do not believe that we need to show solidarity with those who are over-indebted. I do not believe that we need to show solidarity with those who do not implement the agreed measures in the programmes for years and days. We simply have to take the principle of conditionality seriously and say that if we do not deliver, we will not pay.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Madam President, the negotiations between the European institutions and Greece have given us, for six years now, the most sinister of the shows: that of the financial cavalry and the inability to decide.  If Greece has gone to the brink of bankruptcy, it is as much its responsibility, by the falsification of its public accounts, as that of the creditors, by their culpable blindness. As early as 2009, they should have seen their losses to bring Greece's debt down to a sustainable level and leave it to national authorities to find democratically the appropriate answers to win the trust of lenders they needed. Instead, incomprehensible and untenable patterns were constructed. How can a country with a public debt of twice its gross domestic product be left?  Today, the eurozone is in danger, Commissioner. The Stability and Growth Pact is no longer respected and its governance is evanescent. Cynical attitude than that of making loans to pay off previous debts maturing. We are prolonging an illusory situation that can only lead to tragedy.  Diplomatic discussions behind the scenes of power must give way to political arbitration and realism.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Commissioner, yesterday's decision by the Eurogroup is a monument to economic subserviness and the imposition of economic power on Greece. Yesterday you, the eurozone ministers, once again promised the neo-monumental government a future settlement of a debt that is not settled and so you have achieved new unpopular measures. Yesterday, Commissioner, and you know this very well, the Greek Finance Minister handed over the keys to the Ministry of Finance, handed over the keys to the Greek Parliament and from now on the lenders will decide by legislating and formally by presidential decrees what should be done in Greece. From now on, for the surplus, for the taxes that will be put into the grass roots, for the taxes from which multinational companies will be exempt, the lenders will decide. Mr Moscovici, the euro area of austerity, unemployment, inequality and memoranda, the adjustment programmes you say, have done, with the responsibility of course of the Greek governments that sign and implement memoranda, the Greek Parliament to have only a decorative role. The answer, Mr Moscovici, will be received by the Greek people, but also by the French people and youth who have taken to the streets and squares in European cities.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President, and also for you, Congressman, to take my question. I think that honest speech really belongs here in this Parliament. What do you think would be the solution? We have heard many times what is not the solution. What would be the solution you think? Thank you very much!

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". I too would like to thank my colleague for the question he asked me. Mr President, we know the solution, the Commission knows it, and the Eurogroup knows it, everyone knows it. The Greek debt problem is a political lever to impose austerity policies. When Greece found itself in a borrowing problem, the Treaties could be circumvented and not the troika's bandit mechanisms fixed and the Treaty amended, Article 136 if you have not followed it, in order to impose legal memoranda calling for unpopular measures. So there were solutions to address the problem. However, they did not want it and now, as evidenced by the data provided by my colleague, data published by a German institute, of all this EUR 220 billion loan that Greece has taken over the years, the EUR 210 billion went to the German and French banks and, because I am an old MEP, Mr Colleague, I also remember the confession of Mr Moscovici's primate, Mr Olli Rehn, who admitted that all these aid programmes were supposed to be made to Greece to save the euro area and the German banks ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, I cannot help but smile when I hear the people's bench give lessons to the Greek Government after it has sunk the country's economy and trucated national accounting to enter the euro area. I think it's a little daring. In any case, I would like to say that I believe that Greece is in recent days facing a kind of impossible sandwich, between the irrationality of its European creditors not wanting to restructure the debt, when everyone knows that it must be done, and the recessionive suicide measures that the International Monetary Fund wants to impose. Yesterday we went a small step, but I think it's frankly insufficient. Commissioner, I would like to ask you for two things: debt restructuring must be more ambitious and we must speed it up now. We know since 2010 that this is not sustainable and we need that to be done as quickly as possible. And the second thing, and with this I conclude: to a country that is currently one more point of primary surplus than the program marked—one more point of primary surplus than the program marked—and is beginning to emerge from recession, asking for more recessionous action is suicide. So it seems to me that contingent measures go far beyond what we should; it seems to me that we are asking for a kind of preventive austerity that is misused, but in any case, let the Greek economy breathe and do not impose any more recessive measures on it. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, our colleague mentioned something about the situation with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund. In fact Greece has made some progress in fiscal terms I would say, and in the end – and this is my question to you – do you not think that the European Union and the International Monetary Fund should find a common, maybe political, and of course financial, solution?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: blue-card answer. – I think that would be the ideal situation, but it would require having rational terms, in the sense that we need debt restructuring that and the Europeans do not want to accept that we need that, and we need to avoid more recessionary measures. But we need both of those things. If on those two grounds we could find a common agreement, of course that would be ideal. But those two things are necessary and, until now, both the IMF and some of the European creditors have been blocking them.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday you played the ode to joy on EU day, but to see the state of affairs, it seemed more like a funeral march.  The Greek Parliament has approved yet another austerity package. All the rescue programs, if we can call them that, have failed. A few days ago Handelsblatt's study found that only EUR 9.7 billion out of 216 of the first two rescue packages went to the Greek people, while the rest went to financial institutions. And the third programme insists on the same mistakes: primary surplus of 3.5 % and no nominal debt cuts.
