It is an economic folly, but above all a social one, a crime against the Greeks, crushed by a failed EU. Skyrocketing tax burden, savage privatisation, destruction of all social rights and as many as 12 reforms of the pension system. But that is not enough, the Eurogroup has requested and obtained a contingency mechanism with further cuts, should the targets not be met. Greece will capitulate humiliated once again. There are no prospects for the country and never before, until the euro noose is released.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. How many times have we heard in this House that the current bailout package for Greece will work, bring stability, and usher in a U-turn in Greece. And how many times have we heard in all 28 parliaments of the Member States that the current bailout billions for Greece will help this time and that it is not lost money that has been burned in the Peloponnese.  Today, we know that every aid package has only made the situation worse. The debt mountain in Greece is now 183% of economic output. And any economist will tell you that this can no longer be refinanced. If you look at a really shabby side of this whole aid policy, this week a very interesting article was published in the Mirror, according to which, according to the European Institute for Management and Technology, it was proved that 95% of the aid did not go to the people of Greece, and that they were not handed over to the small and medium-sized enterprises there in order to slowly get the economy's wheel going. Ninety-five percent have gone into the throats of the banks, and the banks have made a shabby policy from the start. They bought bonds from the European Central Bank with cheap money without interest from Greece, raised 15 to 20% in interest and, in reality, did not have to be liable for them.  The only way out of this crisis can be to pull Greece out of the eurozone so that Greece can become competitive again, and to give both areas – those that are not overly affected by the bailout policy, and Greece, on the other – a way to find a good future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, once again we are spectators in the same theatre of the absurd. The situations we are experiencing in the European Union are incredible, and such political analgesia and misery have never been experienced before. European leaders, tied behind Germany's chariot and with their stubborn instrument the SYRIZA-ANEL government, also demolished Greece's last strongholds. They have broken all their promises to the people, betraying their country and destroying the land by handing it over with future generations to the IMF's genocidal lenders and especially to our allies and partners, povertying the people, breaking up all social classes, trade, public health and everything else about the functioning and existence of a state. The memorandum loans did not save Greece but european banks by transferring their losses to the Member States which in turn transferred them to Greek taxpayers. The Greek budget resulted in less than 5% of loans amounting to EUR 220 billion. Euros were given to save Greece in the first five years of the memorandums, while the rest went to rescue European banks, according to a survey published in the German financial newspaper Handelsblatt. In all the countries that isaw the so-called memorial salvation, their debt, as a percentage of GDP, at least doubled. In fact, the Commission does not make statements on the state of negotiations on the Greek support programme, it simply draws up the chronicle of a pre-announced death.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Madam President, we are, it seems, on the right track. It took a long time for the reforms to begin to be adopted in Greece since the arrival of Alexis Tsipras. It is a shame to have wasted so much time since we remember that during the time of the Samaras government, we saw growth pick up in Greece.  However, we must rejoice today in some concrete progress and say that the main architect of this progress is the Greek people. You have to give him a lot of courage. Greek citizens have had to make many efforts without seeing the direct benefits. They are going through an extremely difficult period. They, too, are on the front lines, who have had to bear the consequences of wait-and-see policies and systematic opposition to each embryo of reform. There are still too many disparities in Greek society, there are still too many privileges for some and too much misery for others.  Let us therefore be clear: the Eurogroup has not given Greece its white-seing. The Greek government must be very aware that European flexibility is conditional on the real progress of reforms. I am pleased that the Eurogroup has been able to start discussing a possible debt adjustment, Greece's debt which still stands at 180% of GDP. Such a development can only be understood and accepted by European public opinion if it is of course the counterpart of real efforts to solidify and sanitize the country's economy. But finally, today, we must recognize that without European solidarity, even if it is criticised by some, Greece would be plunged into an even more serious crisis. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), a question with a "blue card". Thank you, Madam Colleague, for taking my speech. You mentioned earlier the progress that Greece had made with the governance of the country by Mr Samaras. Are you aware that he too is responsible for the sad economic situation in which our country is located? He also signed a memorandum which was a harbinger of the current memorandum and, in addition, there was also the man who in unacceptable violation of democratic rights, democratic customs and customs, illegally sending the leader and deputies of the third party to prison. Is this Mr Samaras whom you admire and whose actions you applaud?

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: "blue card" answer. The only observation I can make is that in Mr Samaras's time, there was already a resumption of growth in Greece. I remember talking about it myself because, unfortunately, I found that in France we didn't even have that growth. That's what I remember. In addition, reforms were being undertaken.  Of course, there are certainly shared responsibilities, but nevertheless, this beginning of growth was a positive thing, and it is a pity that we have wasted time since then.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which With regard to the Eurogroup, I think that, very slowly, reason is returning to the discussions of the finance ministers and, I would like to thank you personally, Commissioner Moscovici and your staff, for your contribution to this. This work must continue, we need results on 24 May! Unemployment - screaming; Investment rate - down. Huge slump since the 2009/2010 global financial crisis. We need growth and jobs for the people of Greece.  Ladies and gentlemen of the European People's Party, I have now heard three prominent speakers, each of which has said that your governments in southern Europe always do everything right and everyone else always gets it wrong. I don't think you believe it yourself. If you come back to plenary with this, I will ask you to present the list of reforms that Mr Samaras has completed. Please let us know, otherwise the argument will kill you.  I believe that we need an economic perspective not only for Greece, but for the whole of southern Europe. We need to talk about how the talents of the people of the South can be made fruitful again, how they can contribute to an economic division of labour in the European Union, and I hope that we can slowly enter this debate and stop talking about managing debt.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Pittella has just said that he feels like he is in a movie. Yes, that also applies to me. But I feel like we're in the middle of a movie and the same scenes are being shown again and again. That is exactly the impression I have. I have heard this so many times in this Parliament, this incantation of what needs to be done. I say to them that when Mr Moscovici says what Greece must do, it is a programme of incapacitation! And then he says: now comes growth, now comes investment, now comes competitiveness. No, none of this is coming! The Economist has noted that "The Greek economy is hopelessly uncompetitive". Have a look at the statistics! Why has the number of unemployed in Germany fallen from ten percent to five percent, why has unemployment in the south of the eurozone risen from ten percent to fifteen percent or more? Because the euro is a false relative price. That's it! You have to start with that! But this Parliament is not dealing with the problems, but is dancing around the Golden Calf of the euro without wanting to get to grips with the problems.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: –  Madam President, I think we should take a slightly broader view of these problems. If you look back in history you can see that in the 1950s and 1960s, the general trend in Europe was that everybody was going 5% to 6% into the future, coming close to the bigger picture. That changed in the mid-1970s and even more so after the enlargement in the 1990s. What we need now is a new cohesion policy. But in order to have a new cohesion policy, we need a budget which is appropriate to those challenges. It is not much use to speak in this Chamber about who got what wrong; there is not a single politician in this House or in any other parliament who can say that he did everything right. Almost every politician has something on his back, so we should stop blaming each other; we should work for a new budget and try to fix the problems of those countries in Europe that are really in dangerous waters.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, I am pleased that most of you here today recognise that, in fact, a crime has been committed against the Greek people. But, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday's political developments also show once again that in Europe today there is a dominant force that will be indifferent to democracy for rights and human lives. It imposes cutters, memoranda and anguish. There is also a willing prime minister in Greece who implements this policy by stating that the radical alternative path is an illusion. But there is also a force in Europe, also recorded here, which has no illusions about the memoranda and defends the path of democracy and social justice. There is also a people in Europe who, without illusions, did not succumb to the blackmail of the European directory and said 'no' to saving the banks by choosing their own bailout. So there are two kinds of evaluations. The one that counts the subjugation and collapse of Greek society as the profit of the banks, and the one that counts the resistance of the Greek people as the profit of European society. Ladies and gentlemen, in this conflicting European reality each of us is assessed by who it defends and what Europe it is fighting for.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the Handelsblatt newspaper recently claimed that 95% of the aid to Greece went to its creditors, to the European banks. Greece is paying a high price for access to the remaining 5%. The austerity measures that the Tsipras government voted on were supposed to be a review of Greece's debt. Yesterday, the Eurogroup timidly opened the discussion as if to delay better. Possible debt-restructuring measures are being postponed at the end of the current program in 2018. But how can an economy project itself and invest in the future under these conditions? The absence of decisions brings economic and social agony.  In 2018, when the Greek economy has suffered the effects of this new austerity plan, the re-profiling will be nothing more than a memory. A haircut all the more important as we will have persisted in the error will be necessary. The Greek people will be at their worst and the creditors will not be reimbursed. Commissioner, why persist in this direction?

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: Madam President, last Wednesday, the Handelsblatt, a major German newspaper, finally admitted what serious experts have been saying for a very long time: the so-called aid to Greece went absolutely not to the Greeks but to the banks. In fact, less than 5% of the sums paid by all of us have actually been injected into the Greek economy. The price of this tiny share has been for the Greek people a total denial of democracy and absolutely considerable social violence.  As early as 2010, when the IMF was considering a Greek default, you, the European Commission, in particular, set up a real Ponzi scheme: you chose to save the banks rather than save the people. To repay its debt, the Greek state has been borrowing more. Moreover, you decided to punish the Greeks with a relentless, unprecedented and historic violence when they tried to choose another democratic path by electing Mr Tsipras and then voting no, a little less than a year ago, in the referendum on the aid plan. You have subdued Mr Tsipras, who did not have the courage to resist you and who did not have the courage to choose the path of the end of the euro for his country. Today, the European Central Bank continues its daily search for liquidity. You have put all the responsibility for this situation on the Greek people when, of course, it is the choice that has been made that is at issue.  Yesterday you were celebrating your so-called founding fathers of the European project. I hope that this Europeanist masquerade will not celebrate an additional anniversary and that we can finally listen to the peoples, move towards this cooperation between free nations, sovereign nations, the only one that works.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the situation in which Greece finds itself now is the result of political actions undertaken by this government since it took office. Greece was on its way out of crisis in the second half of 2014. It had projected economic growth of more than 2% for 2015 and the primary budgetary surplus, but this was all jeopardised by the current government last year. Keeping banks closed for three weeks would harm any economy. But what is the way forward now? The way forward, in my view, is reforms.  What Greece now needs is reforms. Greece needs a functional and efficient public administration; this would be to the benefit of the people. Greece needs more competitive and flexible labour markets; this would help people find a job, especially young people. The government should make it easy for young people to start their own business. Education needs to respond to the needs of the labour market; enterprises need to be privatised and well-managed. All this will make Greece competitive and it will lead to investments and new jobs. These measures work. We have seen it in Portugal, in Ireland, in Cyprus, in Spain. Only if applied completely will this package help Greece. Unless the economy is competitive, strong and reformed, everything else is just a quick fix. Even debt relief alone will not help. Reprofiling debt alone will not regain the trust of investors and new debt will accumulate unless the budget is brought into order and the economy is reformed.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in the variation in the ranges we produce on the situation in Greece, it seems to me that three lessons can be learned from yesterday's Eurogroup meeting. The first is that the Hellenic government's massive efforts in reforms and fiscal seriousness must be particularly welcomed. It should be remembered that the laws passed by Athens on Sunday on the pension system and on income tax represent more than three billion annual savings. Thus, the commitments made by Alexis Tsipras in the framework of the agreement made last summer are kept and his political credibility with the institutions not only cannot be questioned, but it must be, once again, welcomed and encouraged. The second lesson is that on the greek debt issue, common sense is beginning to prevail, but here too we must move forward in the face of a promise that we made to the Greek people in the summer of 2012 and which we renewed last summer. The third lesson is that, despite the progress, the reasons for the renewed optimism must be quickly justified by lucid acts, and on this point we are measuring the stakes of the meeting set for 24 May so that Measures to manage Greek debt can be made and that investors and insurance markets return to the long-term path.  This is what Greece needs most and, together with Greece, the entire eurozone.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, despite your great European agreement reached in August 2015, nothing is resolved in Greece. As denounced by the National Front, the Euro-austerity that the troika imposes on the Greeks only weakens their nation and makes it impossible to repay their public debt.  You do not want to admit that the entire eurozone is in agony and that Greece is just a symptom of the cancer of the single currency. For patriots, a debt is a debt. Therefore, a partial cancellation of the public debt, a haircut, would be irresponsible because it would amount to a partial default that would set fire to the powders of European public finances. On the other hand, we, the reasonable creditors, must accept a moratorium on Greek debt with a rescheduling of duration and interest to allow a fresh start for Greece. But in order to meet its financial commitments, Greece must benefit from three fundamental conditions: its monetary sovereignty by leaving the euro zone in order to partially monetize its debt through its national bank; secondly, the settlement of the 162 billion euros of the Greek historical debt by Germany in financial reparation for war and, thirdly, the cessation of your European migration plans which the Greeks suffer. Thus, we will collectively avoid a humanitarian crisis and an economic crime in the cradle of democracy.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: PPE). Madam President, in Greece we have good news, but we also have bad economic news. The good news is that the Tsipras government had abandoned its strategy of confrontation with the eurozone and is making the necessary adjustment effort, so we will not have a repeat of the 2015 crisis. Unfortunately, there is also bad news. First, we are obliged to pay dearly the bill of the failed radical experiment Tsipras – Varoufakis of 2015. Secondly, the economic policy mix implemented by the SYRIZA government emphasises the exterminating taxation of private sector enterprises and households, thus creating new problems in the functioning of the economy. Thirdly, at the request of the International Monetary Fund, the Tsipras government has accepted the creation of an intervention mechanism and the preparation of so-called preventive measures for 2018. Thus, it sends the message that the Greek programme is not particularly reliable and removes the forward character of the third programme and the relevant memorandum. In this way it makes them less effective and less developmental. This demonstrates the enormous cost of left-wing populism. SYRIZA triggered early elections in late 2014, blocking Greece's exit from the memorandum by implementing the latest 1.2 billion euros ($1.2 billion) bailout. Euro. But the Tsipras government has already implemented, announced or planned measures ten times the height. That says it all about left-wing populism. We hope that the passion of the Greek people has also become a lesson for the Peoples of Europe.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while the greek drama culminates in new desperate austerity measures, new pension cuts and the most savage tax raid on the poorest, by the most callous nationalist government of the post-civilization era, some celebrate this convenient and helpful policy, as a blank cheque to the troika and to every demand for it. Sometimes there is more hypocrisy among us, but today the alibi for our IMF dragon is over, as the European Union has accepted an agreement that avenges the weakest citizens, without real progressive reforms. It is the Schaeuble policy that is absolutely served and shifts any easing of the 2018 targets and we see. And while some late friends turn a blind start even to the absolute sell-off of Greek property to foreign funds and speculators from the SYRIZA–ANEL co-government, let's leave the flag of solidarity for when we really decide to care about the citizens and not the numbers and flags of left-wingness.

name: Paul TANG
text: – When Wolfgang Schäuble arrived at the eurogroup yesterday, he said that Greece had made the wrong decisions and therefore had to pay. This reminds me of a tantalus torment: the moment the goal gets closer, the goal is moved. Greece has made a huge budgetary adjustment. It was necessary, but also second to none. And yet the target has been moved. A surplus of three and a half% was agreed last year. So in addition to Greece's wrong decisions, we can also talk about the unrealistic demands of eu countries. Christine Lagarde has called the three-and-a-half percent target unrealistic and the IMF has acknowledged that the issue of debt relief should have been on the agenda as early as 2010.  It is therefore time for EU countries to take a critical look at their own actions and demands. Not because I believe in Schäuble's guilt and penance, but because I think you can learn from mistakes. From 24 May, it must be clear that Greece will receive debt relief in such a way that Greece can stand on its own two feet again.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Madam President, yesterday's Eurogroup has shown us that the European institutions and the Greek governments are cooperating undisturbed. Six years of crisis, three memoranda, twelve positive assessments and there is always a government that, triumphantly, tells us that the numbers will prosper tomorrow, but all people see are new direct and indirect taxes. Why is this happening? It is because the European institutions, forgetting growth, only plan budgetary targets that are collapsing, because we do not have growth. And governments deny the reforms, precisely because they may have threatened the deep Greek client state. However, twelve positive assessments have shown us that there is no way out unless major reforms are made that do not have budgetary costs, such as the renewal of the public sector and subsidised agriculture, the reduction of pharmaceutical expenditure, the reduction of the time for the administration of justice, the cessing of fuel smuggling, the cessing of corruption in public spending. Exactly what two governments have not touched in five years and fifteen months the current government has not even begun.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Moscovici for the work he has been doing for more than a year now, after we saw that call for a referendum last minute last spring when we were about to reach an agreement. We have probably lost a year and it is true that we have now reached an agreement that I think is reasonable; even though people in this Parliament , like my colleague, Meps Eva Kaili - rightly question the trust we may have in the Syriza Government, it is true that we have reached a reasonable agreement. I would like to recommend in some way that reforms focus on a few areas that really release growth capacity, for example in the export sector, taking into account Rodrik's idea of major reforms, of reforms that actually release growth. On the other hand, as Mr Paul Tang said, we need to address the debt issue now. There is that issue in the compromise, but we cannot wait any longer, because Greek citizens cannot continue to suffer cuts and adjustments without a hopeful future that will allow them to regain growth and enthusiasm for Europe.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Madam President, Mr Moscovici, today too much has been said about the past and less about the present and the future. The question is very simple. A roadmap has been agreed which, albeit belatedly, is moving in the right direction of development. The second thing we have before us is that, despite all the mistakes that have been made, serious reforms have also been made. So the question is simple for all of us. Will we help the Greek people, who are suffering and making sacrifices as a member of this family? Will we help the Greek people who are opening their arms to the persecuted at the same time as many Member States are setting up fences? As for debt, I answer it as simply as I can: without debt relief to the extent that it becomes sustainable, growth through rational investment will not occur. Investments in an economy with out-of-control debt are not made. As for the International Monetary Fund, which calls for less austerity but demands preventive austerity measures, I fail to understand their logic.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, yesterday the Eurogroup reiterated the decision on the debt going back to November 2012, but with added and increased measures and an automatic financial correction mechanism. It is a promise that has been pending for four years and since January 2015 alone, 9 billion euros have gone out of the pockets of Greeks. At the same time, you too have a responsibility as lenders, since you allow a policy mix based on more taxation, more increases in insurance contributions, which favour both tax evasion and tax evasion. To break this vicious circle, Greece does not need any more programmes, it needs another policy with fewer taxes, with less spending, it needs another government that will move quickly to structural reforms, so that we do not discuss the Greek problem here again, for Greece to be the protagonist at the heart of the euro zone and, of course, first of all, you to keep your promises that have been pending for four years.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Madam President, I think it is absolutely urgent to move away from the exclusive or strictly accounting approach and finally give prospects to Greece and, even more, to the Greek people.  It seems to me that we need to act in two directions at the same time. Yes, of course, we need substantive reforms - and we all know this - of the state, of administration, of justice, of health. But I would add that if the substantive reforms had been made before, Mr Tsipras would not have to do them today. That's the first point.  Second, yes, of course, we need to redevelop the debt. We need to reorient it. We basically need to provide financial aid and devote it to constructive development projects. Greece needs to rebuild an industry, rebuild agriculture, build and open new avenues, especially with regard to renewable energy. Finally, in conclusion, let us stop spending our time pointing the finger at Greece and the Greeks, thinking that they are not doing enough and that this is not going well, and let us be by their side. Let's help them act, help them move forward and build a future.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, white smoke from the Eurogroup is a good sign, but a heavy price to pay for the Greek economy. More taxes and insurance contributions to the productive forces do not pre-promote the reduction of unemployment which is the most important social issue in Greece. In-general injustice, as young people - at least those who work in Greece - will pay higher contributions for smaller pensions. The responsibility lies with the lenders and the Greek government. The strategy deficit for better days highlights the absence of vision. That is why more and more Europeans are failing to identify in today's Europe the principles and values we celebrated just yesterday. Finally, if some people really believe here that the IMF is an obstacle to a fair solution to the Greek debt, but also to a fairer austerity policy for the Greek programme and we want the withdrawal, then let us vote, in the European Parliament, for the IMF to leave the Greek programme, unless of course you use it only as an alibi.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, coming from Ireland I have the greatest empathy with the Greek people, and indeed the Greek Government right now, because what they are suffering, we have suffered. We heard the same arguments. We were told at the time that the debt was too big, that we would default, that we would be better off out of the eurozone, that all the money was going to the banks and that it would lead to zero growth in the economy.  Well, a few years down the line, thanks to good government and the sacrifices of the Irish people, we are now the fastest growing economy in Europe, and hopefully we can say the same about Greece in a few years’ time. I think in fairness to Greece, and to the Prime Minister, the last time I spoke here I was very critical of him. I told him it was time to show a bit of leadership and stop running around Europe, giving interviews to all the media outlets and, in fairness, he has changed. It takes a big man to change tack and admit the folly of his ways, and especially the grandstanding of his then Finance Minister, the blustering Mr Varoufakis. So now I think that they are making the readjustments. We should do everything we can to be as flexible as possible with the Greek Government so that they can make the necessary recovery and enjoy the growth that we are enjoying in Ireland today.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, perhaps we should admit that the European Union made some mistakes in persevering with its austerity policy, and perhaps it should be said that the compensation demanded of the Greek people was excessive and that the measures taken were not sufficient to ensure the recovery of the Greek economy.  Yet, from what we learn, the Eurogroup does not seem to want to change its strategy. On the one hand, stringent measures such as the contingency plan, a kind of automatic compensation mechanism, are still being proposed, ready to start with new spending cuts and new taxes in the event that Athens fails to meet the budgetary targets set out in the programme, and in particular a primary surplus of 3.5 % of GDP in 2018. On the other hand, greece's demand for interest relief on its public debt is still being ignored, with an extension of repayment deadlines, without affecting its nominal value. Athens has made important reforms such as the very recent ones on pensions and taxation. The Eurogroup must acknowledge these efforts and make Greek debt sustainable by expiring payments, taking into account more the volume of annual maturities than the total amount, and extending the period during which Athens will not have to pay interest.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, Greece is Greece – that is not going to change. As early as 2010, my own party, the Finns Party, opposed the granting of aid packages to Greece, or rather to the French and German big banks, to which the subsidies ended up through Greece, a recent study confirms. However, the majority makes decisions in the democratic system, and in 2010 we Finns Party remained in the minority in the Finnish Parliament. Common rules and agreements are concluded to ensure that they are all respected. It is now reported that some reforms are being carried out there in Greece, some are not being carried out. You should go and check the right things to do, since you can't trust the word. Greece must follow its adjustment programme before any extension of the loan period or a revision of interest rates can even be discussed. Or it would be better if Greece were to get out of the euro and solve problems and also improve the position of its poor citizens.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, at yesterday's Eurogroup meeting it was accepted that the sustainability of Greek public debt presupposes measures in the short, medium and long term. All this is positive, as long as it is transformed into concrete and effective actions. It must be understood by all that neither Greece nor any other state, outside or within Europe, can achieve primary budget surpluses of 3.5% of Gross National Product per year over decades. Greece must ensure that it does not return to primary deficits, but other eurozone member states must find a way to reduce the burden of Greek debt to such levels that it can be refinanced by the capital markets. A realistic and brave restructuring will ultimately benefit both Greece and its lenders.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all those who have spoken in this debate, which I believe will have been fruitful and useful.  Of course, it is more than difficult to answer as the views that have been expressed are diverse. I want to see that, of course, mistakes have been made and, of course, responsibilities have to be established. You don't go through six years of crisis without seeing these inadequacies of all kinds. As it happens, I have a bit of a step back on these cases, not only the setback of the year and a half that I have just passed to the Commission in charge of this file, in the College of Commissioners, but also before since I was already a member of the Eurogroup as Minister of Economy and Finance of my home country, which is still my country. France. Therefore, I have been involved in these discussions for four years now. And I can assure you that, in reality, responsibilities are shared. Mistakes have been made at all times, basically, by all Greek governments. I think that the moment in which we find ourselves is a very decisive moment which should nevertheless encourage us to express a consensus on the need to continue solidarity with Greece, which everyone recognises. Let's start with common sense thinking. It is not for this or that here to say in the place of the Greek people whether or not they wish to remain in the euro area. The evidence is that it is. The choices that are made today, above all beyond any partisan consideration, bear witness to this long-term ambition. My conviction, that of all the members of the Eurogroup - and by definition, it is men and women from all groups who are present here or almost and therefore have different political sensitivities - is that we took an important step yesterday, after much work. This step is that of a solid reform programme that is now underway, that is accepted by all and which must be the basis for a return of confidence and growth in Greece with the following investment. This is what the Greek people, who have suffered greatly from this crisis, need. We owe this consensus to the Greek people. I am not talking about this or that political formation, I am not talking about the authorities, although I want to say how well we have worked in recent months with the authorities to pass these reforms, which are still difficult reforms.  I think your debate also provides us with some interesting ideas for the Eurogroup meeting on 24 May. We have carefully taken note of the members' comments and the points that have been raised today. Of course, if we put ourselves in the shoes of a particular government, of a particular institution, we could wish to go in that direction or in the opposite direction, but as a last point, I would point out to you that this is the first time that all the issues have been taken together. First, the issue of structural reforms. There is an ambitious package that is there, then a contingency mechanism that protects itself from the vagaries which, once again, the Commission thinks can be ruled out. Finally, it is the first time, since November 2012 , and not least because there is now a package of reforms on the table that is solid and credible - that we are able to deal with the Greek debt issue. We are going to do it and we want to do it. Therefore, I think that yesterday an important step has been taken. I repeat, I hope that on 24 May we will be able to reach agreement as broadly as possible, at least on the first two blocks and, if possible, on all the issues.  I have heard speakers from various countries who have had programs or who want Greece to do so. That's my wish, too. For the past four years, I have had to attend sixty, seventy or even eighty Eurogroup meetings and my wish is that one day at a Eurogroup meeting, we can say: "That's it, Greece is out of the programme". After all, it is a normal country, a country that has succeeded in the reforms that have enabled it to return to growth.  I think that beyond the different political sensitivities that may inhabit us, it is a wish that we can all share. I believe that all the same is the one that drives you all and that I feel the same way as you do.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Despite all the flowery rhetoric we are subjected to, about European solidarity and what have you, the so-called economic adjustment programmes for Greece have become a hypocritical sham. The truth is that the process is driven by casuistic calculation based on the application of self-serving economic and financial positivism. The process remains detached from the hardship and suffering that millions are having to endure. It is true that those who over-borrow have to pay for their mistakes, but there comes a time when a line must be drawn under their liabilities. For it is also true that those who over-lend should also have to pay for their mistake: that is the logic of the free market. In the case of Greece, those who over-lent have been let off almost scot-free. We are now having to support a policy in which a people that has been subjected to years of austerity is being forced to accept the prospect of having to carry further burdens. The way forward can only be substantial debt relief. Most actors in this miserable scenario subscribe to the dogma that eurozone membership is irreversible. They should be prepared to pay in order to safeguard that dogma.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. At this Eurogroup meeting, the Eurocrats expressed their satisfaction with the absurd and unpopular austerity measures accepted once again by the Greek Parliament, showing their ruthless indifference to the economic and social suffering of a country massacred by years of austerity. Yet another loan package has therefore been unblocked, which will certainly not lift the economy and help the Greek people, as would be normal if cooperation and peace reigned in Europe, rather than abuses of power and greed. The German newspaper Handelsblatt puts it in black and white, according to which 95% of the money lent to Greece since the beginning of the financial crisis has been absorbed by banks. The public purse went 5%: €86.9 billion was used to repay the old loans, €52.3 billion to pay interest to creditors and €37.3 billion to recapitalise banks. The citizens, who have been living in economic, social and humanitarian emergency conditions for years, have been owed EUR 9.7 billion. This is intolerable. I am close to the Greek people, who continue to suffer, in the name of the holding of the euro, the imposition of devastating neoliberal reforms and humiliating austerity conditions dictated by banks, markets and Eurocrats.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the preparation of the World Humanitarian Summit (2016/2585 (RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by saying that, in my view, the summit is an opportunity the global community cannot afford to miss. On Thursday, conclusions on the World Humanitarian Summit are expected to be adopted by the Council. The Presidency has been at the forefront of preparing a strong common position of the EU and its Member States, obviously in very close cooperation with the Commission and the European External Action Service.  Let me be clear. The Council wants the World Humanitarian Summit to be a success. From July last year, the Netherlands has put in place an envoy for the World Humanitarian Summit and this has enabled us to link up early with all key players: the United Nations, humanitarian organisations, EU institutions, the Member States and other UN member states and stakeholders.  Let me mention some of the most important things the Member States would like to come out of this summit. We would like the global community to recommit to the humanitarian principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence. World leaders must also commit to addressing the root causes of humanitarian crises by stepping up their efforts to resolve conflicts peacefully and to prevent new conflicts from emerging.  We want all actors, including those who have influence over parties to a conflict – all of them – to respect international humanitarian law. Let me repeat what I said during our debate in Brussels two weeks ago. Violations, such as attacks on medical facilities and schools, are unacceptable. It will be crucial to keep international humanitarian law high on the international agenda, to hold perpetrators accountable and speak out clearly and publicly against serious violations. Upholding international humanitarian law is also linked to a central theme of the summit: placing people at the centre of humanitarian action. So we must move away from drawing boards in capitals and truly listen to the affected population. And yes, we must also work towards eradicating sexual and gender-based violence and emergencies. At the same time, I would like to say that women and girls should not only be seen as victims, but as key partners who should be involved in all phases of the humanitarian response cycle.  The Presidency also believes that more efficiency in humanitarian assistance can be achieved by promoting innovation – innovation in financing humanitarian action, innovation in promoting the technologies and innovation in new partnerships. As an example of the latter, the Netherlands is one of the founding partners of the Global Alliance for Humanitarian Innovation, which is foreseen to be officially launched in Istanbul. Let me also say a few words on humanitarian financing. The Netherlands and other EU Member States are among the top 15 global humanitarian donors. Together with Turkey, these donors were invited by the High—Level Panel on Humanitarian Financing to negotiate the Grand Bargain on aid efficiency with the 15 biggest humanitarian implementing organisations. We have lent our full support to the Grand Bargain negotiations. We hosted the first of the four Sherpa meetings in Amsterdam on 29 February and, in the course of the negotiations, we led, together with the World Bank, the discussions on aid transparency.  Let me again thank the Commission and the United Kingdom for hosting the second and third Sherpa meetings. The fourth, and last, Sherpa meeting, hosted by Sweden, is, as you most probably know, currently ongoing in New York. Let us hope for a swift and successful conclusion of the meeting. As the Presidency of the Council, we would like to see as many donors and humanitarian organisations as possible sign up to the Grand Bargain and to its suggested commitments.  In closing, I would like to thank Parliament for your interest, your guidance and your advice. The summit participation of this House is a clear demonstration of your dedication and commitment. I am obviously looking forward to hearing a bit more about your views and expectations ahead of the Istanbul Summit.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we are only twelve days away from the World Humanitarian Summit, a Summit which is a unique – maybe a once in a generation – opportunity for us to make a lasting difference. To make history by sending a clear signal around the world that global humanitarian needs and suffering require urgent and collective action. The Summit could not be more timely. The challenges we face are enormous. Last year, humanitarians assisted over one hundred million people. Displacement is at its highest since the World War II. Millions flee conflicts or leave their homes behind to escape disasters or climate change, and people are displaced for longer periods than ever before.  The way in which we have been responding to growing needs is not sustainable any more. People affected by crisis need to live with dignity, rather than just receiving assistance. Business cannot continue as usual. Humanitarians continue their tasks under challenging circumstances, but other actors must step in as well: to make the humanitarian system more effective and efficient but also to prevent conflicts, reduce disaster risk and empower communities. It is no secret that we had higher expectations for bold political outcomes from the Summit. Nevertheless, I hope that we can ultimately deliver a strong vision for the future in Istanbul. The UN Secretary-General’s ‘Agenda for Humanity’ is a very good basis for action. The European Union remains committed to doing its part, in line with the call that was put forward in the resolution on the World Humanitarian Summit that Parliament adopted in December. I also recognise your contribution to the formulation of our priorities. This is why I am particularly pleased that Members of the European Parliament will attend the Summit. Your participation is very important to us and we advocated with the UN at the highest level to ensure your representation. As the European Union, we go to the Summit with a clear set of three key objectives. I would like to thank very much the Dutch Presidency for this and of course the previous Presidency, the Luxembourg Presidency, and others.  Firstly, the lack of respect for international humanitarian law that we are witnessing today is simply unacceptable. Civilians are targeted, medical facilities and schools are destroyed, medical and teaching personnel and humanitarian workers become casualties. We must stop it. Therefore, we want the basic norms and values of humanity to be upheld and reconfirmed. We strongly advocate for the respect of international humanitarian law (IHL) and we want the Summit to reaffirm its centrality. I particularly welcome the recent ‘resolution of the European Parliament on attacks on hospitals and schools as violations of IHL’, which echoes this priority. We also want more efficient and effective humanitarian action: cooperation rather than competition in the UN system and among implementing organisations, and more flexibility and predictability of financing, involving of course also the private sector. To this end, we are engaged in the discussions to follow up on the report of the High—Level Panel on Humanitarian Financing.  Finally, we want to strengthen the humanitarian and development link and engage more strategically with partners. In particular, situations of protracted displacement call for a novel approach in order to ensure that affected people move from aid-dependence to self-reliance. This is the ultimate objective of a key piece of our commitment at the Summit: our Communication on Forced Displacement and Development that we adopted on 26 April. We will address these key issues and we intend to deliver strong commitments. We expect other actors to do the same. For the success of the Summit, political commitments at the highest level will be essential. These should pave the way for an effective follow—up, because the Summit will not only be a culmination of months of consultations and preparations, but also the beginning of the transformation of the international humanitarian system, through, definitely, the implementation of our commitments.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I would first like to point out that this summit comes at a time of great organizational difficulties and the presence of actors, such as this Parliament, which has difficulty in being at the appropriate level at the Istanbul summit. , at the most appropriate time. Because there is now the largest accumulation of top-level humanitarian crises in the world, from Iraq to Syria, South Sudan, Central African Republic, but also in Ukraine or also in Yemen, also in Libya and also in other parts of the world. Because we currently have the highest number of people displaced from their homes— around 120 million, from thirty-seven different countries—almost half of them children. Because right now there is the biggest gap between the need to serve people and the funding we have; we have about 40% funding gap. And because at the moment, too, there are growing violations of the principles of humanitarian action and attacks on facilities and actors. So it's time to address a strong call, a serious drive to address humanitarian crises around the world. There has been a lot of consensus in the various global dialogues and in the various regional dialogues, and I believe that the position expressed by the Commissioner and the representative of the Council also reflects this consensus on what needs to be done. However, there is less determination in the commitments to be made. The Commission presented its proposals with its priorities; Parliament supported it; Parliament, in turn, developed a report calling for a comprehensive consensus of humanitarian action, in which we also called for a need to better protect in connection with development cooperation policies; we also called for a greater role for local actors and women; to talk to the displaced, to which the Minister referred, and we also called for consistent funding. So what I are asking the Commission and the Council to do now is for Istanbul to be the first step, and for Istanbul to be followed by serious commitments from the Commission by the Member States towards a comprehensive consensus of humanitarian action, towards a new initiative that will pool development policy and humanitarian policy , and towards commitments to denounce violations of humanitarian principles, attacks on various humanitarian actors. I conclude, Madam President, by saying that Istanbul must be a first step for dignity to regain an adequate level in this world.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – War, environmental disasters and food insecurity are and remain causes of much suffering and death and grief. Millions of people around the world are begging for help. In Syria, Ecuador, Yemen, Ukraine, Burundi, but also in Turkey. Turkey which - o irony - is the host country of this world summit. The southeast of the country is bleeding. Erdogan's repressive practices against the Kurds are abhorrent. And I ask the EU and its Member States: take it up for these people at the summit. We all agree that we can do better and do better. The current context and crisis require more resources, but first and foremost greater efficiency. We must learn from the mistakes of the past. I would like to mention a few points. Coordination is fundamental. Local NGOs and the private sector can offer added value. In addition, complementarity is important. Humanitarian and development aid needs to be better coordinated. Proactive measures are also essential. There is too little attention for emergency prevention, which means that aid and reconstruction cost much more afterwards.  And finally, we need to talk about conditional aid: aid that is linked to political or security considerations. The summit must not be yet another talking bar. Promises and commitments must be put into concrete implementation plans. And on this point, I agree with the previous speaker. We cannot come together within this and a year without interim, tangible changes on the ground. If not, the Istanbul summit is a failure in advance.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, anyone who attends major UN summits regularly attends ceremonies of self-satisfaction. The international community is right to welcome the success of alleviating suffering in either crisis and to recall that disasters have been averted through humanitarian action. However, we should not hide our faces in the face of three dramatic aspects that will undermine the world humanitarian summit on 23 and 24 May in Istanbul: first, the increasingly threatened security of medical missions; second, the proliferation of crisis outbreaks accepted as inevitable; thirdly, the gulf between the commitment of states, particularly the European Union, and the actual funding results. On the first point - the increasingly threatened security of medical missions - is it the result of human stupidity, the bad faith of the warlords or both? Failure to respect the impartiality of humanitarian action is unacceptable. The states represented in Istanbul would do well to put an end to these practices. As for the proliferation of crisis outbreaks, military intervention is generally not the answer. That is why diplomacy must mobilize in time. Not just any diplomacy, but the best possible. The states represented in Istanbul would do well to remember that. The commitments made by the European Union are generous, of course, so they are regularly renewed for the simple reason that they have not been kept. For the Member States of the European Union, it is a question of credibility. The Member States would do well to remember that. It is not enough to see that others - almost all others - are doing worse than the European Union and its Member States. For the Twenty-Eight, this is no reason to let their guard down in the face of the scale of the challenge. Our hopes rest on the commitment of the Presidency and our Commissioner. Good luck, Christos!

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately humanitarian crises are becoming more frequent. The causes are not only climate change or natural disasters, but often armed conflicts resulting from economic interests; political decisions, such as closing borders in the face of the arrival of thousands of refugees, which has created a humanitarian crisis in our own territory. That is why we are extremely skeptical of the real possibilities of this Summit.  What good are vague humanitarian aid commitments if their policies are aggravating humanitarian crises themselves? Unless the real objective of the Istanbul Summit is to make up the policies of the European Union and, above all, those of our new Turkish partner.  Ladies and gentlemen, there is no point in giving Away Band-Aids with your left hand while with your right you are handed out axes to human rights and international law. If they want to provide solutions, they can do so tomorrow: open safe roads and enable a humanitarian corridor for the arrival of refugees; other hand will still be stained with blood.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the World Humanitarian Summit – the first ever – could be an opportunity to reaffirm the centrality of international humanitarian law and it could improve ways of strengthening compliance with it. But look at what is happening. There have been concerns about the summit’s level of ambition, and I really hope that the European Union will do everything to ensure that the level will not be lowered. It is a good idea to have all stakeholders around the table, but certainly it is states which have to commit themselves in a binding way to improving the situation. Médecins Sans Frontières gives cause for alarm in that it has informed us, with disappointment, that it is pulling out of the summit because the summit is neglecting to reinforce the obligations of states to uphold and implement the humanitarian and refugee laws to which they have signed up. Seventy-five of the hospitals that MSF manages and supports have been attacked in the past year. This is a scandal. The rising number of attacks on schools and hospitals is a horrifying example of growing indifference to international humanitarian law. The deliberate targeting of civilians and civilian infrastructure amounts to a war crime. Reinforcing the role of independent and impartial humanitarian aid and the need to improve emergency response both have to be addressed properly at the World Humanitarian Summit. Improving the situation of women, girls and other vulnerable groups during conflicts should be at the core of these talks.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you for the floor, Madam President. For the first time ever, there is now to be a World Humanitarian Summit, and the aim is good, but the place for this is Turkey – to show to some extent, I suppose, the ties between the EU and Turkey. Turkey that does not uphold democracy. Turkey that does not uphold human rights. Turkey that does not uphold freedom of expression. Turkey, which is not even in Europe, but in Asia. Turkey forcing Angela Merkel to prosecute a comedian. Turkey, which imprisoned a Dutch journalist a few weeks ago when it returned home after completing his holiday. The crime was that this journalist wrote critically about President Erdogan on Twitter a few years ago. I think it is quite wrong that the European Union should in any way participate in Turkey, as this country actually stands for exactly everything that the EUROPEAN Union does not stand for. Thanks!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask the Commissioner, who is here and whom I thank: how much does this summit cost to help poor countries? Because we talk here every time and no one explains that, 100, 80 % of what is obtained goes only for representation expenses, to pay bureaucrats, to fix things, while to help the people in need there is very little left of the ciccia that is collected. How much does this summit cost, Commissioner – I am asking you again – where does the whole world go? And where does the whole world go? In Turkey. And Turkey all know how democratic it is with Erdoğan, who would better retire, because I think he is a done and finished dictator. That would be some kind of Hitler from 2000. I would like to ask: is Turkey, as if one were going to take drug addicts and then, in order to improve the situation of drug addicts, as a supervisor, take Pablo Escobar, who was the great head of drugs in Colombia and around the world. You do the same thing: if there is one country where you should not have held the summit, it is Turkey. What are you guys doing? Talk, in quotes, about drugs and call Pablo Escobar. Congratulations, do a really nice service! And explain to the people and to those who are also here where you throw all this money! Why don't you give them to people! You all eat them!

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Madam President, we have heard that there are different levels, different views on what the level of ambition of this summit is, but if there is consensus on one thing towards this summit in Istanbul, it is the fact that the world humanitarian system is overburdened, that there is a chronic shortage of funds to meet all humanitarian needs. We've heard from colleague Guerer how many millions of people around the world need some kind of humanitarian aid. We know that today we have more refugees in the world than we did in the immediate aftermath of World War II. Unfortunately, we are witnessing a dramatic rise in humanitarian crises, and the particular challenge is that these are protracted crises. Long-term displacement takes on average more than 25 years for refugees and more than 10 years for 90% of internally displaced persons. It is in this regard that I think it is important to put emphasis on crisis education and I know that the Commissioner is doing just that. In these protracted crises, only the humanitarian aid system cannot meet all needs. Forced displacement is not only a humanitarian challenge, it is also a political, development and economic challenge for human rights. Of course, there is also the phenomenon of irregular migration – we must also take into account the security dimension. Finally, I welcome the Commission's communication from April this year, which aims to gradually end dependence on humanitarian aid in existing situations of forced displacement, fostering autonomy and enabling displaced people to live with dignity and contribute to societies where they live.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that at the first World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul, Europe will find itself again, showing that it wants to be the protagonist of humanitarian action and solidarity, especially in the face of the crisis of refugees and forced migrants, starting with the most vulnerable, children and young people. That is why, as the S&D Group, we have launched the 'Educate' campaign to double the resources for access to education and education for children in emergency conditions, which account for only 2 % of humanitarian aid. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Stylianides for responding to our November report, investing an increase of EUR 52 million for 2016, and for being with us next Saturday in Rome, at the launch of our campaign in Italy.  In the new global humanitarian strategy, education is not a second step, but an essential part of reception and protection policies, the prevention of violence, as well as investment in the resilience of children in the project of their lives and their families. But we have also proposed humanitarian corridors – educational corridors, as we have called them – for the reception of refugee students by European universities. It is important that the Italian Government, Germany and now perhaps Spain will already accept refugee students in their training courses in universities.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, in thirteen days' time, the United Nations World Humanitarian Summit begins in Istanbul, and the EU is expected to play a leading role in this. I would like us in Turkey to speak openly about what humanity means in dealing with citizens and their rights. What we must certainly not accept is that someone like Mr Erdogan is uncommenting lyricised in the light of such a summit. Let us talk about the regression of human rights, which is mentioned in the recent EU progress report, we talk about limited freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the press, we talk about inhumane genocides and about taking responsibility for them. With regard to the summit, we Europeans must remind ourselves and the world that the best objectives will not work if there are no concrete instruments. That is precisely what this summit must be judged on. Preventing conflicts, respecting human dignity, fighting suffering and hunger, giving everyone their chance and investing in humanity – all this is only possible in concrete terms. I want a summit of practiced humanity.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President; thank you very much, Commissioner, for being here today. Attacks on humanitarian aid structures and organizations have multiplied in recent years. In 2015 alone, Doctors Without Borders has already reported at least seventy-five attacks on its facilities. Last week, in Syria's Sarmanda refugee camp, thirty people were killed in an attack that can hardly be considered an accident. There's a pattern of behavior. As the French Foreign Minister called it, we are talking about a war crime, a crime against humanity. The World Humanitarian Summit, the first in history, must provide an urgent and joint response against impunity. Compliance with international humanitarian law and the protection of humanitarian workers must be at the heart of European humanitarian aid policy. The safety and survival of those who suffer the most, who are precisely those we want to help, depend on this premise. As the European Union, it is up to us to strengthen the crucial role of the International Criminal Court. We must use all our European influence to put an end to this abominable and unacceptable situation.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we voted on Mr Guerrero Salom's report on the World Humanitarian Summit, we recognised that it still represents a good position to ensure that the European Union plays a leading and leading role for all the other participants. For the 5-star Movement, the wishes of the summit are to put an end to inconsistency and start acting together with intellectually honest governments, which will have the opportunity to make mea culpa and put an end to actions that precisely create humanitarian crises. We must remember that 80 % of crises are caused by conflicts generated by the same actors who say they want to solve the problem. The world humanitarian summit will also be attended by states such as Saudi Arabia, which is promptly armed with European aircraft and bombs and is now the main cause of the humanitarian emergency in Yemen. We remember not only the attacks on hospitals, but also those on rescuers and the media, hit with the criminal technique of double or triple attack. I wanted to ask Commissioner Stylianides to promise the citizens of Europe that at the summit we will make a real commitment in this direction to participating states such as Saudi Arabia.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab World Bank figures say that 250 million people are affected or exposed to humanitarian crises. Social and economic instability, protracted conflicts and natural disasters are exaceing these crises. The May Summit in Istanbul aims to highlight the importance of this problem and to find effective solutions to support.  A very important UN initiative was to organise a number of humanitarian consultations within the regions. It should be borne in mind that international aid should be the last measure that we activate when local aid systems are overloaded. Therefore, the local potential to build resilient and independent societies must be substantially supported.  As the current crises are long-term, it is crucial to bridge the gap between ad hoc humanitarian aid and long-term development aid. I also hope that the summit will not overlook the aspect of adapting all humanitarian actions to the diverse needs of the affected communities, especially women, children and people with disabilities. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank Mr Wenta because, of course, the key question for all of us is: how can we become more efficient? My question is this: what can we do in the area of self-employment and, above all, in the area of family farms in developing countries? How can we help people to help themselves? What could development policy do in the future to make it easier for families to produce what is needed on the ground?

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I would like to thank you for the question, Mr Rübig. Because, as you know, we have worked together in this report on small and medium-sized enterprises, which are so important for building in developing countries. In this respect, we can really help to build our society if we continue to make good use of the development instruments – including the 0.7% share of the Member States' GDP. Then we can help even better in this area. Otherwise we will really get into trouble. But I hope that we can prepare this even better in this direction, especially in our DEVE Committee.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, the Commissioner said that we will continue to put our grain of sand in. It is not a grain of sand that is needed, Commissioner, it is much more. It's political commitment, it's resources—40% of what's needed—it's intelligence, it's determination about everything we need. Istanbul will only be useful if it flips, if it changes course what humanitarian aid is currently being and the almost daily contempt for international humanitarian law and the defence of human rights. That would have to be Istanbul for Istanbul to be a success. And in this case we talk about the difference between life and death for many people and, in the case of the European Union, for their credibility as a decisive player in the world. And on this I would like to tell you, Commissioner, knowing full well that it is not your responsibility, that the European Parliament has been completely sidelined at this marginalised summit, and we have only obtained accreditation for this whole House in order to participate in the debates, which I regret and for which I require urgent intervention from you.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the world has not faced such a large number of displaced persons since World War II, so it is indeed the right time to hold a World Humanitarian Summit. There is currently no better place to hold a meeting like this than Istanbul, as Turkey is at the centre of migrant routes and represents a major partner for the European Union in tackling the migrant crisis. Europe and the world must help the crisis hotspots be taken out and refugees adequately taken care of, and this meeting, I believe, will contribute to this. But I can't help noticing that some sides use the tragic fates of people for political blackmail. This is not responsible or humane behavior, so I hope that the world leaders at this meeting will deal with it. I will take the opportunity to reiterate my position on visa waiver for Turkey. Without meeting all technical criteria, such a decision would be terribly irresponsible and would jeopardise the safety of our citizens.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, I visited Lebanon a few weeks ago where I also met with Syrian refugees. None of them expressed a wish to move to Europe, but wanted to return to their homes in Syria. In order for them to be able to wait in the neighbouring country for a time when it would be safe for them to do that, they must have access to elementary things like schools for the children, the possibility to work and access to medical care. This is something that other countries, including the European Union, can support through financial means. The World Humanitarian Summit must deliver a clear commitment to increasing humanitarian aid to help refugees close to their homes.  Another problem is promises made by different countries to help during crises but which have not been delivered. Look at the actual money given to Haiti and Nepal after the earthquakes and also the refugee crises at hand. There are promises to give money, but these promises must also actually be upheld. This first ever World Humanitarian Summit must really deliver and not become a disappointment.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, in September 2015, the European Commission had already set seven priorities for the field of humanitarian action. The question now for this global humanitarian summit is: can we move from the assertion of good intentions to very concrete things? I believe that, as Commissioner Stylianides says, we must act courageously and give clear answers, at least to the funding gap in humanitarian aid and, secondly, to the effectiveness of that aid.  My second point is about the link between humanitarian aid and political solutions to crises. On this point, I disagree with Mr Corrao. I do not believe that humanitarian aid can be a substitute for political solutions to crises. I do not think it is necessary, on the other hand, to make a kind of self-stigmatization of Europe. We must be proud of the fact that Europe is truly the largest donor in the world.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent This World Humanitarian Summit must send out a signal. We live in a world where 250 million people are affected by humanitarian crises. A total of 60 million people are currently forced out of their homes by wars, conflicts and disasters. Half of these refugees are children. The EU and its Member States will only show real solidarity and responsibility if they finally set an example at this summit and fulfil their financial obligations. A good example of the possibility of doing something different here is my group's so-called EdUKaid initiative – instead of spending four per cent of humanitarian aid on education in the future. The Commissioner intends to include this demand in the forthcoming draft budget. I would like to thank him very much for that.  As rapporteur in the Committee on Development on the 2016 budget, I have pushed for 26 million more to be spent on education in refugee camps. The World Summit will call on all participating states to include the EdUKaid initiative in humanitarian budgets as well.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, the Global Humanitarian Summit must outline a sustainable humanitarian aid framework for over 120 million people in need of the world. I hope that the results will surpass all previous donor conferences of this nature. One of the main issues to be raised at the meeting is that of the financing of humanitarian aid. As shadow EPP rapporteur for the opinion of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and as a permanent rapporteur for the recommendations to the UN General Assembly, I stressed the priorities I will set at the meeting, namely: for more effective cooperation in the UN system for the crossing of networks for recruiting and financing fighters for terrorist groups, on the importance of interreligious and intercultural dialogue to reduce refugee flows , and to allocate financial and human resources for permanent education into fundamental values such as human dignity, freedom of speech, equality and compliance with laws.  Turkey, as host of the meeting, must also abide by basic democratic rules and not use this household for political propaganda purposes, but for the future of the millions in need around the world.  Turkey was designated as the host of this meeting before the migration wave had still flooded the country and Europe. There is something symbolic about the fact that the world is gathering for the first time right in Istanbul to come up with concrete solutions that strengthen Europe's role not only as a major donor of humanitarian aid, but also as an active factor determining the development of the world.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I truly hope the World Humanitarian Summit will take important steps forward in order to identify solutions to fully reshape the humanitarian system.  I would say to the Commissioner that in the end it is a matter of the European Union’s level of ambition. We, the European Union, Commissioner, have to come forward with real proposals for a new, real humanitarian system in this world in order to take full responsibility for the European Union countries and to seize every opportunity to make humanitarian assistance more effective and humanitarian work less dangerous.  In order to achieve all these goals, it is fundamental to develop a common understanding among stakeholders of key concepts, such as accountability and transparency and to create a new business model to anticipate risks that makes greater use of joint planning.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul comes at a very important time. The question faced by the participants – how best to use humanitarian aid – feels more urgent than in a very long time. In 2016, it is estimated that 125 million people in 37 countries are in need of humanitarian aid. Christian Yazidis and other ethno-religious groups in Iraq and Syria are among the most vulnerable. On the ground in the region, I recently saw the significant efforts being made, but there is no doubt that more can, and more, needs to be done. In this context, it is important to point out that EU aid must be more clearly linked to human rights. A cautionary tale is EU aid to Eritrea, which was extended at the end of last year, with no real demands on democratic reforms. Here's a homework to do. My view is that the Commission must continue to give priority to European coordination of aid, and always give priority to human rights in this context. Thanks!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, at a time when the world is facing so many humanitarian tragedies, not only the tragedy of refugees, but more than 125 million people in need of assistance, what should be under construction today was a great mobilization of wills and resources to make the next humanitarian summit in Istanbul a concrete response of the international community to the point of view. Unfortunately, preparatory work guarantees everything but that, which is why we need an attitude of responsibility and leadership of the European Union at this summit and leadership must be based on exemplary commitments. Commissioner, we know your commitment, we hope you will defend a clear roadmap for strengthening humanitarian assistance, which implies a substantial extension of the humanitarian funding base.  There is no other way to honor the value of the dignity of the human person.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The history of charitable and humanitarian aid is as long as the history of humanity is. However, times are changing, circumstances are changing and methods and instruments for helping others should also change. Today, humanitarian aid is expected by millions of people in almost forty countries around the world, as many as sixty million of these people are displaced by conflicts. This is a very dangerous phenomenon of the 21st century. The world therefore needs a new humanitarian law today, among other things. It also seems that we need reform of the outdated and rather ineffective UN response system today. I therefore expect that the Global Summit will contribute to addressing such important challenges today as the lack of funding, the lack of coordination between organisations and agencies, including United Nations agencies, and the inclusion of donors not representing the West in the system.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the World Humanitarian Summit aims to reshape the global approach to humanitarian aid and as the world’s biggest donor of aid, the EU will be there at the top table. From a UK perspective, with a referendum on the horizon, we need to consider our position in the world, and I firmly believe that together with our European partners we can reshape the global agenda for the better.
