If we want to lead the international community towards a more compassionate and humane world, Britain must remain and work to make the EU stronger.  However, with great power comes great responsibility. The EU must also hold true to its principles in all of its foreign policy, even when it is under pressure. As we deliver humanitarian aid to victims of war crimes we cannot then turn round and make quick-fix deals with regimes that commit such crimes. All of the EU’s agreements, including, for example, the Khartoum Process, must be consistent with our human rights values and humanitarian and development goals.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – It is certainly a humanitarian summit at the right time, because, as we have heard, there have never been so many people in need, so many people displaced around the world since The Second World War.  The solution we are looking for in this case is very much linked to what the Council spokeswoman said in the introduction: we must eradicate the reasons for what is happening around the world. In an objective, honest politics, a policy that will put human and conflict resolution at the forefront in a peaceful way, not through new conflicts and deepening discord around the world.  It is therefore necessary for the European Union, in this way, to show to a large extent what its values are in this world, to enable people to live well and to live decently where they were born, and in this way to help the people of Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and thus to help Europe, which is the highest destination for these refugees.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, although the European Union is the main donor of humanitarian aid, it is presenting itself at this world summit, ironically organised in Turkey, with the image disgraced by the way it has not been able to respond to the greatest humanitarian crisis since World War II, which results from war and terrorism in its neighbourhood — in Syria, Iraq, Libya — and oppression and misery in other countries in Asia and Africa. The EU-Turkey deal, in violation of the UN Convention on Refugees and therefore in violation of European treaties and the most basic humanitarian principles, is shameful. On his account today in Europe and in the hotspots in Greece, there are refugees detained and attacked, including women and children and many unaccompanied minors. And in Indomeni, a real sin city, what's going on is intolerable. The European Union's action at the summit will be another exercise in hypocrisy if it pursues austerity policies that project unemployment and poverty throughout the Mediterranean region and beyond, and if it remains blocked, unable to act to resolve conflicts, to prevent conflicts and to help other peoples to end autocratic and oppressive regimes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, it is the first world humanitarian summit to take place in Istanbul, a city where the demonstrations of 1 May were drowned in blood. It is the biggest event on this year's UN agenda to be hosted in a state in Turkey that blatantly violates social rights, fuels bloody wars, oppresses minorities and political beliefs. In the context of the conference, the European Union must give concrete answers to the major humanitarian crisis that the Syrian people are currently experiencing, under the responsibility of Turkey. A humanitarian crisis that is being carried over to Europe and especially Greece and will continue to exist as long as the European Union tolerates and lets Daesh and its supporters continue their criminal work. But the humanitarian crisis is not only affecting refugees, it is also affecting the Greek people who, having been impoverished by the memoranda and the troika, can no longer accommodate other refugees. There must finally be an international response to this problem and rich countries, not just in Europe, must make a decisive contribution to tackling it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – The fact that the number of people affected by violent conflicts or natural disasters has increased enormously today, that there has never been such a large number of displaced persons since World War II, i.e. the number of refugees, alone justifies the necessity of organising a humanitarian summit. Astonishing figures reveal the number of people in need of humanitarian aid, which show that the world is increasingly divided into two parts: those who need help and those who can help because of their situation. The EU is the world's largest aider, but because of the magnitude of the problem, this is no longer enough: global cooperation is needed to reduce the devastating effects of climate change, terrorism and violent conflicts. The explosive population growth of developing areas could pose new challenges for humanitarian aid in the coming decades.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are witnessing the greatest displacement of men, women and children since the Second World War: two hundred and fifty million people on the move, almost 60 million refugees in the world. We are witnessing a real humanitarian crisis on a global scale. People are fleeing, but fleeing war, conflict, poverty, climate change.  So this summit is welcome, because it allows us to focus on some important points, such as rethinking the use of humanitarian aid to move towards development policies that must move towards medium and long-term projects, intervening on the real causes that move people: policies therefore prevention, policies that must concern above all also the urgency of the , the humanitarian corridors, so that we can no longer see what we are seeing at the moment, for example in Lebanon, Syria, but also on European soil.  We must go further in order to get out of that emergency vision and arrive at a policy of prevention and give concrete answers.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all allow me to thank you for these very constructive and fruitful discussions. I always appreciate the views and position of Parliament and this is particularly true as we are getting ready for such a unique multi-stakeholder event as the World Humanitarian Summit. This is why I insisted on increasing the number of places for the European Parliament at this big event. My services and I did our best so that this Parliament has a strong presence there and I am pleased to announce today that we secured two additional places in the EU delegation for the European Parliament. We have common priorities: more efficiency; more effectiveness in the humanitarian system; respect for international humanitarian law and, of course, humanitarian principles also; more support for education, emergencies, and many more in the humanitarian field. This is why we have this very strong collaboration because we are in the same boat. This Summit will complete a cycle of events – the SDG Summit with Agenda 2030, Sendai, Addis Ababa and COP21 – that have provided a vision for the future. Their outcomes provide a solid framework for the future, but real progress can only be achieved if we now turn to the poorest and most vulnerable and look at how we can help them thrive. This is the mission of the World Humanitarian Summit.  I hope that when we look back in 2030, we will be able to say that this event was a true game changer. Through the long consultation process it lent a voice to everyone: from leaders to members of affected communities, from academics to the private sector. It involved thousands of people across the world. It introduced a new way of discussing some of the toughest problems we face at a truly global forum and it generated momentum to bring about systemic changes in how we could prevent, respond to and recover from crises. It delivered on the ultimate goal: that by 2030, fewer people require life-saving emergency assistance. This is our common goal. On Thursday, I hope that the Council will adopt a second set of Conclusions on the Summit. We have worked with the Presidency and Member States on a strong position. This will guide us in making commitments at the Summit but also beyond that. I count as always on your continued support and cooperation during the follow-up so that we can show leadership and deliver on our commitments. Thank you very much for your collaboration.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the World Humanitarian Summit is not an end point, but is in a way a starting point for a global community to restore humanity, as the Secretary—General of the United Nations has said several times. We hope to see many, many meaningful and sincere commitments by all stakeholders at the highest possible level. Yes, we have to make sure that the summit is not perceived as a western—dominated event. So outreach was, and is, being coordinated in particular by many states outside the Union.  I also agree with Mr Guerrero Salom that, from the very first day after the summit, we will have to show that we are serious about our commitments. As the Presidency of the Council, we are ready to play our full part in this endeavour, and we very much count on our cooperation in the coming weeks.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written Declarations (Article 162)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The istanbul summit on 23-24 May 2016 is a response to the unprecedented increase in the number of people affected by armed conflict and natural disasters. It is a unique opportunity to establish global consensus to reaffirm the principles of humanitarian aid and strengthen humanitarian action. It is necessary to identify new ways of financing the humanitarian sector in a predictable and appropriate manner. Greater attention must be paid to the dimension of disaster prevention and preparedness and to reducing vulnerabilities, by involving local people as much as possible in humanitarian actions and ensuring the security of people in conflict zones, with a focus on the safety of people and protection against violence of all kinds. The objective of the summit must be to improve humanitarian action at global level by drawing up a final document based on the reaffirmation of the universality and relevance of the fundamental principles of humanitarian action, which must include a set of joint commitments to make the international humanitarian response more efficient, as well as a plan to implement the recommendations.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The forthcoming World Humanitarian Summit is the main objective of improving the response to the increasingly frequent, increasingly difficult and protracted humanitarian crises affecting a record number of lives. After a long period of international discussions on the humanitarian framework, it is time today to engage in dialogue, develop commitments and an action plan that will adapt the humanitarian architecture to new challenges and realities, give it a new form and contribute to good change throughout the humanitarian aid system.  I am pleased that the consultation before the World Humanitarian Summit raised important issues that should be discussed and then included in the post-2016 action plan. I am thinking here of increasing the involvement of new donors in the humanitarian system, of coordinating the work of UN agencies in order to avoid conflicts of competence and at the same time to improve cooperation between them, and of developing new ways of facilitating access to conflict areas and, finally, of increasing the interest of local NGOs in assessing needs and providing assistance.  I hope that at the forthcoming Istanbul Summit we will be able to agree on and develop common priorities for international humanitarian aid that take into account the interests of individual EU Member States.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – We are facing unprecedented humanitarian crises in scale and nature. Today, more than 400 million people worldwide are affected by military conflicts, natural disasters, climate change and socio-economic instability. These people need effective and secure humanitarian assistance. Unfortunately, securing and delivering such aid under the current system is a rather difficult undertaking due to insufficient funding and lack of funds. I therefore believe that the world needs a new humanitarian system based on fundamental principles of humanity, solidarity, the protection of human life and respect for the norms of international humanitarian law. It must rely on coordinated, timely and flexible funding, with the support of a new public-private partnership. As the world's leading humanitarian donor, the EU has the potential and capacity to establish and develop such a humanitarian aid system. At the upcoming global humanitarian summit in Istanbul, the Union must take the lead in delivering the millions of people suffering. This is not only our moral duty, but also a commitment that the European Union has continued to fulfil for decades.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I fully agree that the World Humanitarian Summit should take place, and I would even welcome the organisation of humanitarian summits on regular cycles so that a rich world, a rich Europe, helps countries and their peoples caught up in natural disasters, earthquakes, landslides, floods... This should be the main objective of humanity, but after six years of 'watching' war crimes in Syria and other countries, with support for the supply of weapons to countries where fighting is being fought, organising the World Humanitarian Summit is a weak patch for people fleeing their homes to save their lives. It is necessary to talk first about the causes of humanitarian crises, how to prevent them, how to combat them. The EU is a strong economy within the world, is a strong leader within the world's superpowers and should take the helm in cooperation with the UN as a peacemaker and mediator in resolving war conflicts in the world. Only then will the World Humanitarian Summit make sense and encourage even greater solidarity between the people of Europe and those suffering around the world.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the oral issue to the Commission on the EU-Mercosur: the way forward in the trade negotiations of the Association Agreement, by Bernd Lange and Pablo Zalba Bidegain, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O—000046/2016 - B8—0366/2016) (2016/2596 (RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Indeed, on 15 March, the Committee on Trade decided to put this question for an oral answer. You know, Commissioner, my co-author Pablo Zalba Bidegain and I have also written you a letter on the issue in order to get the negotiations with Mercosur back on track, which are a bit murmured, because we do indeed believe that the political changes in some Mercosur countries have changed the situation. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Some people may not have this in mind any more, but we have been negotiating with the Mercosur countries since 1999 – that is, for a very long time – without any real action being made. We started the concrete trade negotiations on 17 May 2010 – which is six years ago, after all – and this, despite the fact that Mercosur is a central element on the world map for the European Union, both politically and economically. We discuss a lot about TTIP and many other things and sometimes forget about the economic importance of the Mercosur area. We have shown a bit of flag in the region with Colombia, Peru and now by adding Ecuador, but not with the core countries. That is why it is so important that we really get back on our way here. Parliament has always made it clear that we want a fair agreement. We want the negotiations to be concluded successfully. Hence the questions that we have put on the table, Commissioner. However, on 15 March, we were not so optimistic that market offers would be put on the table tomorrow. In this respect, I would perhaps also modify the question somewhat and ask not so much when the market offer will be put on the table, but rather what will be put on the table on 11 May. Perhaps we should discuss a little more the substantive moments. It is quite clear that we on the European side will certainly have to look again at the issue of agriculture – and I also see Mr Dess on the other side – particularly with regard to the issue of beef and citrus fruit. On the Mercosur side, it will certainly also be particularly concerned with mechanical engineering and corresponding equipment. So maybe you'll get a few more answers. Then, Commissioner, of course, the question: what are the next steps, and what about the sustainability impact assessment? This is a crucial issue for a trade agreement. Perhaps you could also say something about what the Member States think. A large country in the Mercosur Council seems to have some political difficulties at the moment – perhaps you can also give us some thoughts on the current political situation. Thank you very much for your attention – I look forward to your answer.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am not sure I can solve the political crisis in Brazil during this short time but I want to thank Mr Lange and the plenary for putting this question because it is indeed a very topical issue and we are, of course, aware of the huge political importance of reconnecting with Mercosur but it also has, as you said Mr Lange , great potential economic use.  We have long historical and cultural ties with Mercosur, many shared interests and, of course, we have, on both sides, economic interests. So in terms of trade Mercosur countries offer EU exporters and investors a very attractive market and this is still subject to significant tariffs and barriers. EU exporters pay annually more than EUR 4 billion in tariff duties alone, so the potential gains of a free trade agreement are of course evident.  We are committed to those negotiations and we are encouraged by the interest that has been seen lately in the four Mercosur countries in moving forward, and a very large majority of EU Member States also welcome this movement and the work towards an exchange of offers. This exchange has been carefully prepared on both sides, given the importance of moving the negotiation process forward, because there has been a long history to this and now we need to look forward. We have kept you and Member States informed about this. The timing of the exchange of offers: I had a meeting with Mr Nin Novoa, who is the Foreign Minister of Uruguay and the current President of Mercosur, and we agreed to exchange offers in this week of May, so we are fine tuning the very last formulas here, and making the final checks with Member States, of course. We are looking forward to studying the Mercosur offer when it comes. We will study it very carefully and of course share the results and our analysis with Member States and with Members of the European Parliament. The exchange will be a first step in this new phase and Mercosur has already indicated that it is a first phase and that they are ready to improve offers during the negotiations, and we will set a timing for negotiations when we have analysed each other’s offers. We have set out with the Uruguayan Minister a very ambitious agenda for the rest of this year, so we are both aiming to advance the negotiations quite rapidly. We hope to make progress on all areas with the aim of obtaining a balanced, comprehensive and ambitious agreement with Mercosur. The EU is aware and the Commission is aware that we have strong offensive interests with Mercosur but there are also some specific defensive interests in the agricultural sector. Following the various impact assessments conducted during the course of the last negotiations, we will conduct a new impact assessment and a new sustainability impact assessment for the trade part. That will of course also cover key issues such as human rights and economic impacts of the agreement. With regard to the impact on the agricultural sector we have already conducted two studies in 2011 on the impact of a potential deal between ourselves and Mercosur which examines a range of scenarios and we take account of those conclusions in the calibration of our offer. In addition, as has been announced by Commissioner Hogan, the Commission is also conducting now a general study of the cumulative aspects and impacts of the different free trade agreements on our European agricultural sector and we expect conclusions later this autumn and will of course share them. Investment protection was one of the parts in the question as well. The mandate for this negotiation dates from 1999, which was well before the Lisbon Treaty; there is therefore no chapter on investment protection foreseen in the mandate. There will be some parts of investment covered in the services and establishment chapter, but no specific chapter on this. I hope that with this that I have answered the questions and I am looking forward to the debate.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, we are now at a key moment to move forward in the negotiations for an Association Agreement with Mercosur and I am glad that this debate is finally taking place. We must take advantage of the political change that took place in Argentina, as President Macri has been totally in favour of starting the negotiation, negotiations that have been going on for more than ten years, thus missing great opportunities for both markets. The European Union and Mercosur have important political and economic ties and the signing of an agreement would bring enormous benefits. We must take this opportunity to make decisive progress in strengthening economic and trade ties, but also cultural and human ties between the Mercosur countries and the European Union. Either week, as the Commissioner said, there will be a first exchange of offers, which is nothing more than the submission of proposals from both sides. It is a first step towards the negotiation and I thank the Police Station, the whole Commission and the negotiating team for the proactive attitude they have shown in channelling the beginnings of the negotiation, and even more taking into account some known reluctance in recent weeks. There are some discrepancies, but they account for only 10% of the total of what is being negotiated. It is unreasonable to reach 90% of the Agreement because of the reluctance of some. When there is a will, understanding is always found. I would like to remind you that, as with any other partnership agreement, an impact measurement study will be carried out. These studies are carried out in parallel with the negotiation. The exchange of negotiating offers cannot be postponed at the end of the impact study, simply because it is inefficient and serves only as a blocking mechanism for those who oppose the signing of trade agreements with other States. We mustn't waste any more time. Work must be done to make the Agreement on European Union and Mercosur a reality as soon as possible.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner, who spoke earlier. Mercosur has always been an important reference point for Europe, not only in political and cultural terms, but also in economic and commercial terms. It is enough to quote one fact: the European Union is Mercosur's main trading partner and Mercosur is the sixth most important export market for the Union. Despite this, Mercosur remains the only bloc of the countries of the Americas – if we exclude the United States and Canada – with which the European Union has not yet signed a trade agreement. Moreover, in recent years the distance between the two sides of the Atlantic has seemed to be increasing, due to a strategic shift of Latin American countries towards Asia, and in particular towards China, as demonstrated by the conclusion of plurilateral treaties such as the TPP and some bilateral agreements such as China-Chile and China-Peru. Today, however, the Mercosur bloc's partners are showing us a new willingness, and relaunching the negotiations for an association agreement is a significant opportunity to strengthen existing links with this area within the broader framework of a transatlantic EU strategy. The exchange of offers to be held in these days will be a fundamental stage in this renewed commitment. The agreement would provide not only for a reduction in tariffs, but also for the reduction of non-tariff barriers and greater cooperation on controls and compliance with each other's standards. As is the case with all agreements, however, here too we are calling for trade to be a new opportunity and not just a source of imbalances.  We call on the Commission to be ambitious in the negotiations but also to be cautious, taking into account the needs of the most sensitive sectors of our productive fabric. I hope that today's debate will demonstrate the European Parliament's political support for relaunching the negotiations, so that a balanced agreement can be reached which will be a real factor in economic development for our continent.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, producers across Europe are not anti-trade; they see the value of fair and free trade. In my constituency in Northern Ireland, for example, we are large exporters in the agri-food market. However, while the principle of these trade deals being pursued by the Commission may be sound in practice, many feel that agriculture is being used as a bargaining chip and kept to the end of the negotiations – and I refer to the TTIP aspect of that as well, even though that may have gone on the back burner a bit until after the Presidential election. The possible conclusion of the Mercosur trade deal is what is now giving many in the agricultural community a great deal of worry. In particular, there is grave concern about the Commission offering a quota of 78 000 tonnes of beef, of which 39 000 tonnes is high-quality beef at a tariff rate of 7.5%. Commissioner, can you confirm what Commissioner Hogan has said today in Wales – that it is off the table? It would be useful for many of us to know if that is a fact. A majority of Member States, I understand, have made their position about this very clear to the Council. If that is the case, it is certainly welcome that Mercosur countries are already a major agri exporter to the European Union – 86% of our beef imports and 70% of our poultry meat imports, and I do not think that the market can absorb much more. I understand that we are looking at the moment at how much more we can absorb within Europe from other Member States. I think that we should wait for that report to come from the Commission, to see how much more the European Union can actually absorb as far as the extra exports would be. Commissioner, you cannot expect us to stand by and allow our beef, poultry and pig industries to be destroyed on these negotiations.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, Commissioner, as you know, it was in 1999 that the Council adopted a mandate to negotiate a trade deal with the Mercosur bloc. 17 years have passed, and we have still not reached an agreement. In the meantime, some of these countries have even been taking protectionist steps against exports from the European Union. So let me come back to the reason for opening these negotiations. Mercosur has a population of 286 million, it is the fourth largest trading bloc in the world and it represents an important economic bloc both in the region and globally. For me it is unbelievable that the European Union does not have trade agreements with these important economies, such as Argentina or Brazil, especially as we have advanced in negotiations and upgraded our trade agreements with many other countries in the region. Can you imagine that back in 2000 the  then Trade Commissioner Lamy was predicting rapid progress on negotiations with Mercosur? But after years of inaction we can feel now a fresh wind blowing. We finally have the political momentum on both sides to move forward in these talks. We must take full advantage of it. There are many real economic benefits to be gained for European businesses in the Mercosur members’ markets, which encompass our major trading partners in the region. The Commission and the Member States must be fully committed to securing an ambitious deal with Mercosur, but we must also deliver within a realistic time-frame. I look forward to hearing positive news on the exchange of offers so that we may continue to use this chance to move forward in achieving a final agreement. You have our full support, Commissioner, to negotiate this deal, but we cannot be negotiating with a 17-year-old mandate for ever. If we miss the current political momentum, I call on the Commission to come back to this House and begin a discussion on a new strategy to advance our trade relations with the Mercosur countries, even if that were to mean bilateral negotiations with those countries individually.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Many questions, Commissioner: do you remember 1999? This is the old mandate on which Mercosur is being negotiated – from the last millennium. At that time, there was not even the euro and this old piece of paper has not even been published to this day. And also to the Council: in view of the growing criticism in the Member States, do you really consider it democratically legitimate not to define a new mandate? Our farmers are now alarmed – yet another free trade agreement. So new quotas again? Again the deal, market access for services and industrial goods from the EU against market access for agricultural goods from Brazil and Argentina?  I have repeatedly asked the Commission to publish a calculation of the sum of the burden on Europe's farmers when we add up the entire ongoing negotiations. Are you finally able to respond? Give us all a respite in which we in Europe, but also our friends in Mercosur – including Venezuela – can democratically define what kind of fair trade relations we can build together. This also gives you time, Commissioner, to read my report on trade relations with Latin America once again.

name: José BOVÉ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, I am still very annoyed. Today, there is a sense that all of these free trade agreements that are being put in place one after the other — Canada, then tomorrow perhaps the United States, and then Mercosur — are being done permanently with agriculture as a bargaining chip when there is nothing else to offer. Earlier, we were talking about the balance sheet: today, we can say, already, that more than 100,000 jobs would disappear in agriculture and in related trades if these import agreements were to pass. Today, we have a problem with Mercosur because we can see that a number of ministers are telling us "we don't want sensitive products" - at least for now, until the negotiations have advanced. But are you able to tell me today that we will not bring a kilo more beef or poultry meat within the European Union? Because the question is there: today we have a crisis on production, poultry, beef and pork. Today, we are experiencing a dramatic situation within Europe and we still want to open the borders. That is something that is not possible. In terms of standards, I have a real question: a year ago, we voted in this chamber to ban the use of meat from clones or cloned animals. You know as well as I do that, in Mercosur and especially in Argentina, clones are already used. What measures have you implemented today at the Commission level to ensure that there is no import from clones? There is no such as that. As far as GMOs are concerned, there will also be a problem with the implementation of the standards. It is the same debate as with Canada and the United States. That is why, today, I am simply asking you to stop these free trade agreements and return to the multilateral table of the World Trade Organization.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there has been talk of a trade agreement with Mercosur (the Common Market of South America) for almost twenty years, but now the change at the top in Argentina seems to have given new impetus to the negotiations. Commissioner, we are not a priori opposed to this agreement, but rather we believe that there is much to be gained for European industry and european Union companies to access the public procurement market in South America, but we must not trade some advantage in market access for our agriculture, as unfortunately happens all too often. If the agreement is successful, we run the risk of a 70 % increase in beef imports and 25 % in poultry imports, at a time when the European livestock sector is not sailing bleeds. What is more, there is less agricultural regulation in South America, which raises the same problems as other agreements, which are now sadly known and have already been mentioned by other Members. An agreement with Mercosur can also be a counterweight to treaties such as TTIP and CETA. As trade relations increasingly become a north-north flow, it is important not to exclude the south of the world from the global value chain. So 'yes' to a mutually beneficial agreement, which reduces bureaucracy for small and medium-sized enterprises and facilitates mutual access to the market, but 'no' and still 'no' to any agreement that threatens our agriculture.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, free trade can create prosperity. But the question is always at what price. I am therefore very critical of this agreement, precisely because the negotiations on ttip are still in our bones. I think I can also talk about you, Commissioner. There are several factors that we should question here in this free trade agreement. Firstly, there is the factor in the fact that these negotiations are to be resumed after a six-year hiatus. On the other hand, the circumstances in Europe, but also in South America, have changed completely since this agreement was reached in the 1990s. Do you therefore think it is so easy to start where 2010 ended? I do not think so, because the conditions are different, and of course particularly in the agricultural sector. We are experiencing very difficult times in Europe, particularly in small-scale agriculture in Austria, and in particular in the pig, milk and beef markets. Accordingly, the opinion of agriculture throughout Europe, and especially in Austria, on this agreement with the Mercosur countries is also critical. This is about existences for our producers, and it is precisely these that should be at the heart of our interest here. I am particularly critical of the market crisis in Europe. I have little positive in this respect.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We have an almost unique opportunity to finally put our trade relations with South America on a better footing. We have had good political relations for years, we have very intensive trade relations, we have many companies from Europe operating in the Mercosur countries today. And if we manage to give our companies better legal certainty through these negotiations on a possible agreement, if we manage to put these trade relations on a broad, legal basis, to open up the market, to create economic growth there – here and there – then that will certainly help.  It is clear to us that there are sensitive areas. The previous speaker referred to a few, as mr Fisas did. We will look very well at creating market access on the one hand, but on the other hand protecting our interests in areas where we have particular sensitivities. And I am very grateful that I have understood you, Commissioner, in exactly this direction.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the association agreement between the European Union and Mercosur has a political significance that far transcends its economic and trade benefits. Europe needs new allies to counter the risk of loss of geopolitical and geoeconomic relevance. At this stage, Mercosur is still favouring negotiations with Europe, but this situation may not last much longer and, if we return to a deadlock, we risk losing the opportunity to other powers such as the United States and China. We must therefore ask whether it is advantageous for the future of Europe for these two powers to control trade in Latin America, a region where peace and democracy have consolidated, unlike other regions of the world. We must therefore make a choice: either we give in to some European sectoral interests, however legitimate they may be, and to geoprotectionist trends that have failed to analyse the dynamics of the global economy, or we perceive once and for all the importance of this agreement for economic political relations between the European Union in South America. The indecision and fears of some Europe in this area may lead to a weakening of trade and cooperation in the Atlantic, which is historically our area of influence. This would be a very serious mistake.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, there are many voices who from this House are calling for the negotiations on this agreement to be accelerated, even letters have been sent to the Commissioner hem in this regard. A haste-signed agreement can be counterproductive to the parties, especially smaller ones. We do not want the shift to a neoliberal government in Argentina or the non-institutional legitimacy that is taking place in Brazil to be exploited by those who saw social conquests in Latin America as an obstacle to mere profit. In view of the negative consequences that similar treaties are having on the region, we believe it is necessary, first of all, to study the possible effects of this Agreement on the different pre-negotiation territories, as well as a more transparent and cooperative negotiation of civil society and trade unions, especially agricultural ones; and, secondly, binding mechanisms for safeguarding sustainable development and human rights. This will run counter to the interest of accelerating it, but I hope that no one in this room wants an agreement that jeopardizes the just and equal relationship between countries and peoples. I wish.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has just restarted negotiations with Mercosur. I am concerned about these negotiations. I will take the only example of agriculture where the standards in the Mercosur countries are far from ensuring the minimum level of security as we practice it here in Europe, including the massive use of antibiotics and hormones.  I would like to welcome the French beef industry which, together with Interbev, may be able to withdraw cattle farming from the negotiations with Mercosur. But let's be vigilant. In any case, let us not take for cash this proposal made by the President of the European Commission. Above all, I would like to tell you that this EU-Mercosur agreement is an agreement which unfortunately reminds us of TTIP. We will therefore have to be very careful because, as much as we have been vigilant with the transatlantic treaty, as much with this agreement with Mercosur, it is the whole European agricultural sector that is under threat.  Colleagues, at one point we voluntarily renounced the agreement with Mercosur. Today we are resuming this agreement but let us be very vigilant because our European culture is in very bad shape, and it is now appropriate, at a time when our sectors are in great difficulty, not to unfortunately put in place this treaty which could be the total end of our European agriculture.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Trade negotiations and trade policy are a bit like astrology. When the stars are right, things happen that were otherwise thought impossible, and a little so I feel that it has been with the negotiations precisely with Mercosur. Because all of a sudden we have gained new momentum in the negotiations, something that I thought was almost impossible. Almost after the idea of a free trade agreement has begun to be given up. And now I think it's important to take advantage of it. I would therefore like to know when the Commission intends to respond to Mercosur's customs offer, so that we can maintain this momentum. But the moment we start to get the negotiations going, so are the critics, and we have them here. It is above all agriculture that is concerned about. But it is not the case that we are particularly looking to damage agriculture. On the contrary, agriculture is the sector in Europe that is most protected by customs duties, and therefore the one that is to be negotiated at all. If any other sector could come close to getting the protection of customs duties that agriculture has, then they would be overjoyed. They couldn't even dream of it. But the costs of these duties, they are not borne by Brazilian farmers, they are borne by families with children who buy food, and we should also think about them. Thanks!

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, thank you for being here with us today in this debate. You know that I am deeply defending the strengthening of economic, trade and political relations between the European Union and Latin America and I am told of the efforts it is making. I believe that it is essential to seize the opportunity to conclude an agreement with Mercosur – we are its second export market and they are our sixth market – that is ambitious, balanced, that protects the interests of both sides and, of course, takes into account asymmetry. I believe that this agreement will take place within the framework of the Commission's new trade policy strategy and it is essential that this new trade policy serves as a reference for transparency, the participation of economic and social actors and, of course, to help harness the development potential of Mercosur countries , because our trade agreement model has nothing to do with China's, and we do want to help these countries achieve sustainable development and demand social responsibility from our companies. I was very pleased to know that you are going to do a new environmental impact study and I would like to know: is it possible to improve the mandate, which has been out of date, and to update it to adapt it to the current situation?

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the Americas is our natural ally because of the depth and breadth of our links with that continent, and the European Union's trade relations with Mercosur are very important. It is a market of about 290 million inhabitants, the sixth for exports from the European Union, but Chinese penetration is increasing in the region. That is why we need a Trade Partnership Agreement with Mercosur, which is also important for Mercosur, so that it does not be isolated from the large spaces of free trade that are being set up in today's world. Argentina's change opens a favourable outlook in the relaunch of these negotiations, which live a crucial week. We need to take advantage of this new dynamic; we need a balanced, comprehensive, ambitious agreement; As you said, Commissioner, to watch over our legitimate interests and also to introduce the relevant limitations and safeguards, paying particular attention to our sensitive products such as agriculture. But I'm done; I would also like to stress the geopolitical importance of the European Union-Mercosur Agreement. It will strengthen ties with a region from which Europeans cannot do without it, because as Spanish and as a Galician, I dare say that Mercosur countries are sister countries, part of our own being.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, I wanted to say that we have many very important agreements with many Latin American countries: with Chile, with Mexico, with Central America, Colombia, Peru. These agreements are good, by the way, they favor peoples, they favor the humblest people of these peoples. And if you look at Latin America and look at the map, you discover that there is a huge, huge hole in what mercosur is, and the first agreement that could have that great political, economic and social space with the world is with the European Union, because it has no Mercosur agreement, with anyone. He doesn't have it with anyone, not with the United States or with China. If Europe does not, others will do it, and I think it is important to say that Europe has to be there, at the front line of that possible agreement because the time has come, because this is just the time. And that agreement will be good, it will be good for the peoples, it will have problems but they will negotiate. Who can refuse to start a negotiation that has been standing for almost twenty years? Let's get started, we're going to defend the issues well, but let's get started, which is about time.

name: Albert DESS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done In 2010, together with 76 colleagues, I tabled a motion here in connection with the Mercosur negotiations, which were relaunched at that time, which was aimed at ensuring that trade agreements can only be concluded if our standards for consumer protection, animal protection and environmental protection are respected in terms of minimum social standards. This decision was taken at that time by 535 votes; the vast majority of Parliament has agreed. If you follow this decision, we can live with the trade agreement. I was the chairman of the german-Brazilian parliamentary group in the German Bundestag for ten years, And I know the country very well. When I look at our standards, we penalise the farmer if a cow lacks an ear tag. In Brazil I have seen whole herds of cattle without ear tags. How do you intend to establish traceability in beef when cattle have no ear tags at all? We must therefore ensure that our agriculture is not sacrificed on the altar of the world market in these negotiations.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in the deregulated globalisation we live in today, what gives strength to the European matrix, to our identity, to our concern for the planet are factors that harm us in competitive terms. But the way is not to retreat from good practice, the way is to disseminate good practice so through a fundamental instrument that are trade agreements.  Trade agreements are now more important than they have been in the past, requiring a geopolitical and geostrategic approach. The predominance or irrelevance of the European Union is played in the new global business cycle. Tomorrow, with the exchange of proposals, a new window of opportunity opens.  Commissioner, the negotiating process cannot be determined so only for geostrategic reasons, nor be limited by parcel and localist interests. So I ask you: is the Commission prepared for smart and holistic negotiation? What signal will the Commission give to the world with its attitude towards negotiations with Mercosur? Weakness and fear, or, on the contrary, determination and ambition?

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, for many years this agreement was halted by a lack of political will, for a political environment which was not prone to move forward, to launch the negotiations, because of a negative political environment in Latin America. Political changes, especially in Argentina, have changed that climate and it is now important that we here in the European Union indicate our political will to move forward. I think that's exactly what we should do on this occasion, in this compound.  Obviously there are areas that are more sensitive, such as agro, and that will be taken into account, and surely our negotiators will do so during the negotiations, but this opportunity must be seized. Since we are talking about Argentina, brazil, countries that are powers in football, I will make an allusion: when you miss an opportunity, a great chance, what happens to you is that you score a goal. We have to put that goal in and win that game.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the interest of the European Union and Mercosur, two continental blocs, is of course to talk to each other, to exchange and to work together. Nevertheless, we have learned with a little astonishment, the resumption of negotiations with Mercosur and I wonder: what is the legitimacy of a mandate that dates back to the last century, in a world that did not know the globalization of today and where the last exchanges of offers had provoked a real outcry on our continent leading to the end of the negotiations?  When you look at the trade balance, it is very clear: we are exporting 19.9 billion more industrial products than we import. On the other hand, the agricultural product deficit is $19 billion. There are therefore serious risks to agriculture as the bargaining chip of this negotiation, even though European agriculture is in crisis, even though with Commissioner Hogan we are unable to resolve this crisis in Europe because we no longer have enough tools.  I therefore call for your utmost vigilance on this matter.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, no one can deny that the European Union-Mercosur Association Agreement is a pending subject. For the first time since the talks began in 2000, circumstances have changed and there is now political will to celebrate it. Mercosur is ready to submit its offer and, despite the difficulties involved in this Agreement, the European Union must seize this moment by showing its determined and seamless willingness to move forward in these negotiations. The aim is to achieve a balanced, ambitious and comprehensive agreement, which will undoubtedly generate significant benefits of all kinds for both regions, for their citizens and for their small and medium-sized enterprises. At a time of crisis the European Union needs to find new resources to generate growth, to generate jobs for its citizens. The European Union cannot pass up the opportunity to reach an agreement with its sixth trading partner and with one of the regions with the greatest growth potential in the world. Let us hope that the negotiations that begin the day after tomorrow will come to fruition and we can finally conclude a historic agreement that will improve the quality of life of the citizens of both sides.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the strengthening of relations between the European Union and Mercosur is undoubtedly an imperative for both regions. We cannot be suspended with this agreement and its negotiations.  The European Union, as has already been said here, is Mercosur's main trading partner, accounts for about 20% of total trade and has reached EUR 110 billion in recent years. On the European side, forecasts point to positive economic impacts and benefits in terms of productivity as well as employment.  However, we need to ensure that this agreement does not question rules on agriculture, in particular in some essential goods, such as Madeira bananas, dairy products from the Azores, or Portuguese meat. We need measures to ensure the sustainability of our agriculture and its future development.  Commissioner, this agreement can have important geostrategic contours for Europe. Portugal and the Azores and Madeira Archipelagos, in the centre of the Atlantic, can assume a fundamental centrality that will greatly contribute to the economic and social development of Europe as well.  Let us move forward without fears and we are here to support it also in this agreement which will bring important benefits to Europe.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you would have received letters from me on this issue, and you have heard the word ‘agriculture’ mentioned more than once. Indeed you yourself raised it. So, on point 4 of the question I would like you to give more detail about how you intend to take into account the potential threat to the agricultural sector.  I think what worries us is that the initial offer was to come forward with a very – we believe – generous concession to the Mercosur countries on agriculture, and if that was a potential opening offer my fear is what would come afterwards. Maybe you would explain the rationale in the Commission that caused such outrage across the European Union?  You know, timing is everything, and it is so in trade agreements. The reality, as Michel Dantin has pointed out, is that agriculture is on its knees. Across many sectors there are real problems, and you eluded very well to the realities of so many deals happening and the need for an overall view of their impact. I would rather that we waited for that impact before we sign any deals.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I must admit that I am rather concerned about the resumption of these negotiations. First of all, how do you justify us being able to resume negotiations on the basis of a mandate that is more than 17 years old? Our offensive interests have evolved, the economic situation is not the same and the agricultural sector is currently in a serious crisis. Appropriate specific measures must be applied to sensitive agricultural products. They should not be used as a bargaining chip, let alone traded now. I have noted, Commissioner, that the Commission will finally carry out an impact assessment of the accumulation of quotas already granted in other free trade agreements. It is both a question of economic efficiency and political credibility for the Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, as a Member of the Committee on International Trade (INTA) I am normally in favour of free trade agreements and in favour of waiting for the final document before making up my mind, but I think with regard to Mercosur I have a different opinion.  Firstly, I think the timing is all wrong, especially from the point of view of the struggling agricultural sector. At a time when prices are dropping, consumption of meat is dropping, when the Russian ban is impacting hugely, when the cumulative effect of other FTAs is beginning to affect us and when there is no equivalence of standards – we want to make it worse. I think that this is not good enough and we have to cry ‘stop’.  As has been pointed out, there is already an imbalance of almost 20 billion between what we take in and what we export. It is very good for Mercosur. No wonder they want to push the door open further without equivalence of standards. I think it is time to say we must mind our own agricultural sector first and then think about Mercosur when the time is right.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are at a right time to discuss this question, because we are in a political moment and at an unbeatable economic moment for this exchange of offers. From a political point of view, we see Argentina politically turning to a government much more prone to agreement with the European Union. In Brazil, despite political difficulties, they have realized the importance of prioritizing trade openness as well and not just prioritizing regional integration. And Paraguay and Uruguay are also very willing at the start of these negotiations.  But it is also a good economic time to start these negotiations. A good economic moment because the European Union needs growth and job creation and, without a doubt, free trade agreements are an important tool for boosting growth and job creation; moreover with a trade and political ally such as Mercosur, area and region with which we share values and with which we share principles.  Moreover, not only does the European Union need to boost growth and job creation. As I said, Brazil is also going through economic difficulties, and other countries also need to boost growth and job creation. Moreover, in a context where the European Union has agreements with Colombia and Peru, has agreements with Mexico, which, by the way, is modernizing, has agreements with Chile, and is negotiating the important agreement with the United States, Mercosur needs these negotiations more than ever to have an additional instrument to boost growth and not be isolated from the rest of the world.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I would like to refer to this agreement with Mercosur by saying that it is very important, also for me, politically, that this Agreement be concluded between Latin America and the European Union, certainly not only because of the trade aspects, but also because of our relations with Latin America. I am Spanish and therefore I believe that a rapprochement must be promoted and a good method may be to promote an agreement. I'm not so clear that it's a good idea to probably do it with a mandate from seventeen years ago. And, Commissioner, I also have to tell you that I am a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I am in constant contact with the sector, we are going through a brutal, brutal agricultural crisis. The Commission and the Member States, the Governments of the Member States, are unable to resolve it. I don't know if it's the right time to start negotiations. I don't know. I have some doubts, but it would be good if you had the impact assessment as soon as possible, to see what effect this Agreement can have on European agriculture.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union–Mercosur agreement paves the way for the free trade agreement between the European Union and Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, which will have disastrous consequences for the European Union's agricultural sector, according to the agro-union organisation COPA-COGECA. In particular, the Mercosur countries are already exporters of agri-food products to the Member States of the European Union, with 86% of European imports corresponding to beef and 70% to poultrymeat. Therefore, according to the representatives of COPA-COGECA, the abolition of duties is unnecessary to increase trade with the European Union, since the European Union exports very little of the beef it produces. Furthermore, imports from the Mercosur countries are not in line with the high quality and environmental standards of the European Union and there is concern about food safety as cloned meat is circulating in Argentina. Finally, the agricultural sector will lose EUR 7 billion.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, in addressing the Commissioner, I want to concentrate on the threat to agriculture, in particular the European beef industry, and I want to ask: what about equivalence of standards? EU farmers are surely entitled to know that they operate on a level playing field when it comes to environmental, food safety, food traceability, consumer protection and animal welfare standards.  We quite rightly insist on those standards in the EU. Those standards mean significant extra costs for EU farmers. It has been estimated that it could be in excess of EUR 200 per head. Whatever the figure is, it is hugely significant and we know from previous experience, when the IFA and the Irish Farmers’ Journal went to Brazil, that EU implementation of equivalence of standards leaves a lot to be desired. I am not saying no to trade, Commissioner, but I am saying we need a level playing field, otherwise how can we expect European beef farmers to survive? Finally, Commissioner, can you confirm what Commissioner Hogan said: that beef will not be included in market access offers which will be presented to Mercosur this week, and can you guarantee that there will be no ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, Europe is facing a structural crisis that stems from its commitment to a production-based agricultural model.  The European Commission remains convinced that the salvation of our European agriculture is openness to the world market. In this context, it now intends to reopen a dossier that has been paralyzed practically since 1999, intends to open the process even further by negotiating tariff exemptions with mercosur partners, creating, in practice, another free trade agreement with this Latin American bloc.  The terms of this negotiation include the possibility of exempting a wide range of agricultural goods, even the most sensitive ones, such as red meat, white meat, dairy products, fruit and vegetables. It should only be clarified that Argentina is only the largest producer of beef.  The European Commission cannot deny the current crisis. This escape forward is unqualified and reveals a complete disregard for the importance of European farmers and their role in preserving the rural world, biodiversity and food security.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The importance of external circumstances in terms of the common agricultural policy is growing. What is happening in Europe depends on what we do, what we negotiate on the world market, on the global market. We have some analysis when it comes to TTIP. We have signed an agreement with Canada, there are further agreements, including with Mercosur. Does the Commission have such a consolidated, aggregated analysis of the impact they can have on European agriculture? Of course, I know that trade is taking place both ways, that some compromises must also be made – but will we not go too far in these concessions, so that it will have negative consequences for European agriculture, that we will actually have to say goodbye to the European agricultural model and move towards concentration, increased production and, consequently, greater industrialisation in order to be competitive on the world market?

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a trade agreement with Mercosur has been awaited for 17 years. The general conditions now seem favourable, but this must not and cannot be at the expense of European agriculture. 50 % of European imports from Mercosur are agricultural products, as many as 86 % of our beef imports and 70 % of poultrymeat imports come from these countries. The European Union is close to a trade deficit of EUR 20 billion in the agricultural sector, without a free trade agreement with Mercosur. It therefore seems logical to express concerns about the agricultural negotiations with Mercosur, as 20 Member States have done by calling for an impact assessment that takes due account of the potential impact on the European agricultural sector. The Commission, in relaunching the reopening of negotiations with Mercosur, will have to carefully assess the repercussions in agriculture, also in view of the serious crisis facing the sector and given the impact assessment on the potential effects that this agreement could have on the European agricultural sector.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, the President of Uruguay has said that the reason why we do not want a trade agreement is because we are afraid of competition. Now competition would be fine if it were fair competition. The type of competition they are referring to is one where one of us runs a race with a pile of bricks on our back and the other one gets to run with a fan at their back. They are not, it is not fair. Different standards, which cost us more. Inevitably this is not going to work. But the problem that we have is that it is really hard to believe where the European Union is going with these trade negotiations. It is really hard to believe whether we are being told the truth on what are the red lines. We have now been told by Commissioner Hogan that beef is off the menu. Can the Commissioner tell us definitively whether that is true or not, because it will cost us EUR 500 million in Ireland if it is not? Also, where is the joined—up thinking within the European Union? Where does climate change fit into all of this? And can you also answer this question: who do you represent, Commissioner? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I think all of you agreed that these negotiations with Mercosur have dragged on for quite some time, and I fully agree with that. But something has happened that opened a new unique window of opportunity. The change of government in Argentina with its President saying that it is his priority, his government’s priority, to reach out to Europe and to work with us has created a new momentum. We are now facing the possibility that we can finally take those negotiations forward after so many years, engaging with countries with whom we share so much history, so much culture and so much friendship. It is important for cultural, political, geopolitical reasons, and also for economic reasons.  This is a fantastic export market. There are more than 250 million people, opportunities for European businesses such as the car sector, machinery, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, luxury goods, wines, spirits and also in the agricultural sector, for instance fruits, vegetables, dairy, processed food, etc. Our exports, as I said, pay more than four billion annually in tariff duties and these can basically all be eliminated through an ambitious free-trade agreement (FTA). It will also open up new possibilities for our service sectors and for our public procurement.  As regards the agriculture sector, we are of course very aware of the crisis in the agriculture sector in the European Union, but I think we need to be correct on the figures: 60% of our agricultural imports from Mercosur are soya and feedstock for our own cows and pigs, and the FTA would eliminate taxes, tariffs, on this issue, making it less expensive for farmers. We actually have a trade surplus when it comes to pigmeat and dairy with Mercosur, and more could be exported through FTA. Our laws and our standards and our SPS regulations would of course have to be respected, as in all free trade agreements but having said that, we are very vigilant of the agricultural sectors. I will not confirm today what is in, and what is not, because we are finalising the final offers that will be exchanged later this week. Once it is there and once we have received the Mercosur offer we will share it with you and we are also working on this general analysis. Because of the crisis of the agriculture sector we will follow this very closely, and it is also because of that we are trying to open more markets in order to give more possibilities to our agriculture.  The mandate is old – yes – that is in the hands of the Council. I hope the Council will make the mandate public because that is the line of the Commission, as you know: that all mandates should be public. Once negotiations have started – because it is only an exchange of offers that we doing this week – and are up and running, we will, as always, work in very close collaboration with the Council, of course, but also with the Committee on International Trade and other interested members.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The EU is the second trading partner for Mercosur, and Mercosur is the sixth for the EU. It stresses that the economic and political opportunity to achieve this Agreement must be seized, that it must be ambitious, balanced and take into account asymmetry between regions, and that it will be negotiated on the basis of new criteria such as transparency, participation and corporate responsibility. The EU has partnership and trade agreements with many Latin American countries such as Mexico, Chile, Peru or Colombia that have been good for the peoples, because they have brought them wealth. In the case of Mercosur we have a shortcoming that we must rush to fill as soon as possible, because otherwise others like China or the US will. If we seize the opportunity we will have the advantage of being the first region to sign an Agreement with Mercosur. The exchange of offers is only the beginning of the negotiation, the result of which must not be prejudgeed: We Europeans will work to defend our interests and reach a fair agreement.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. It is a major step forward that trade negotiations between the European Union and the South American Free Trade Association, MERCOSUR, can resume with the return of Argentina. The EU needs to conclude a balanced, profitable free trade agreement with the South American block. However, the preliminary impact assessment that will be used to start negotiations is outdated, since since 2004 the world, including trade, has changed considerably. A new impact assessment reflecting the current situation is needed. It is very irresponsible to resume negotiations until this is born, there are so many uncertainties. I am therefore shocked to learn of the European Commission's tariff offer for sensitive agricultural products, which contains figures that are completely out of touch with reality. It's not time for that. If the aim is to conclude a well-prepared, truly balanced free trade agreement, then we must not rush, but take the time to achieve a good result. I regret that the oral question tabled by the Committee on International Trade does not at all deal with these priority issues.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: in writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, opening up new markets is necessary to promote agricultural growth and help to solve crisis situations like the one we are currently living in. But bilateral and multilateral trade agreements should ensure a level playing field between the parties and maintain the restrictions that are most appropriate for the most sensitive sectors to avoid that rather than creating opportunities we are causing disadvantages. The European Union should in no way use the European primary exchange currency sector. Mercosur is an opportunity for some European sectors, but in specific cases, such as beef or poultry, the necessary safeguards must be introduced, taking into account the cumulation effect with concessions that could be made under other trade agreements. In both Mercosur and any other trade agreement, impact studies are needed, the results of which should be discussed by the various European institutions before any offer is made by the European Commission. Finally, stress the need for maximum reciprocity in environmental and food security to ensure a level playing field.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. Considering that the European Union and the Mercosur partner countries launched negotiations for the creation of a free trade area (SAS) more than fifteen years ago and having seen political changes in the region, in the hope of an ambitious resumption and acceleration of negotiations, we believe that the issue addressed to the Commission is particularly timely. In view of the growing volume of trade flows, which make Mercosur the EU's sixth trading partner, and its closeness to global issues, an ESA between the two regional areas is the natural step forward in friendly relations between the two partners. In full support of the reinvigorated negotiating ambition, we take this opportunity to ask the European Commission for assurances regarding the dismantling of duties on agri-food products. The large imbalance in the trade balance, which has seen the EU import agricultural goods totalling EUR 21 billion as against only EUR 2 billion in exports, and the concern expressed by about half of the Member States raise important questions about the possible effects that the agreement will have on the economy of rural areas and their impact on employment. Has there also been any progress on Mercosur's offer in the area of public procurement and the automotive sector?

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the monitoring and current state of the agenda for the period up to 2030 and the SDGs (2016/2696(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted last September is a major achievement. This Agenda will be the focus of global development cooperation in the years to come.  But let me be clear, the adoption was just a very first step in addressing this global challenge and as agreement on the implementation and review mechanism of the Agenda is still to be secured, we have important and significant work ahead of us, and yes, further preparation of the EU position before the July session of the High-level Political Forum in New York is crucial to ensure an optimal and action-oriented outcome that will be in line with EU priorities. As most of you know, the Council is of the view that the follow-up and review process should accelerate progress on implementation of the comprehensive 2030 Agenda. It should also foster broad ownership and accountability. Without any doubt, the Council remains committed to a full and active, constructive role of the EU and its Member States in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, obviously in close cooperation with all partners and stakeholders. Now in our capacity as the EU Presidency, the Netherlands organised on 19 April a meeting for Member States to exchange best practices with respect to national implementation of the global goals. The Netherlands will also organise a meeting at the end of this month about multi-stakeholder participation, and yes, we consider it of the greatest importance to maintain the indivisible nature of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development with the Addis Ababa Action Agenda as an integral part of the 2030 Agenda. The EU has started its work for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. The Commission will present a new approach to ensuring economic growth as well as social and environmental sustainability beyond the 2020 timeframe, taking into account the Europe 2020 review as well as the internal and external aspects of the implementation of the UN sustainable development goals. A roadmap is expected to form the basis for further discussions. Within this context I am happy to note that revision of the European Consensus on Development in light of the 2030 Agenda will feature on the agenda of the Development Council on Thursday. It will be a very first and general debate but I do expect Council to focus on how to address the comprehensive nature of the 2030 Agenda, how to ensure the best possible contribution, what means of implementation and financing instruments can be used best, as well as how to improve coherence, complementarity and coordination between the EU and the Member States.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the EU was instrumental in shaping the global 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, and I see several of the key players before me here today. But New York was only the start; and Europe has a duty – to itself, and to the international community – to lead in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The Commission is committed to delivering its part in an integrated way, and we have made our response to the SDGs one of the priorities of the 2016 work programme. We will present to you an initiative in the course of this year on ‘next steps for a sustainable European future’ to map out the EU contribution.  Delivering on the SDGs is deeply entwined with our objectives under the 10 priorities of the Juncker Commission. Vice-President Katainen and I are coordinating this, while working closely with High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini for the external side. This work builds on a solid basis. Through the Europe 2020 Strategy, and through a wide range of EU policies, from climate change to skills and innovation, the EU is already delivering on many SDGs. One of the challenges in our institutions, in our Member States, will be to prevent dividing up implementation between an international, a national and a European strand. What we do at home needs to be consistent with what we do in Europe and internationally. If we are serious about the SDGs, we need to understand the philosophy behind them; namely that it is an integrated and universal agenda, and no longer the ‘developed world’ telling the rest of the world what they need to do. It is also us telling ourselves what we need to do. Externally, the SDGs are already playing a big role in shaping our development cooperation but also more broadly. The Commission will present later this year a proposal to revise the European Consensus on Development in the light of the SDGs and changing global trends. We need to address all three dimensions of sustainable development – economic, social and environmental. Eradicating poverty, eliminating inequalities and combating climate change are not competing objectives; they go hand in hand. This means change in Europe too. And 2030 is the day after tomorrow, if not already tomorrow. I strongly believe that if we take a hard look at our prospects as European society in a business-as-usual scenario, if we do not step up our efforts over the next generation, what we can hope to achieve in terms of structural economic growth is not encouraging – an annual average of perhaps 1 to 1.5% if we are lucky. With our demographic realities, that is simply not sufficient to sustain our social model, our European way of life. It is a very uncomfortable truth, but it is nonetheless true. If we want to be in a position to provide for our parents, our children, for everyone in need, if we really want a sustainable, social model for our societies, we need to move much more quickly to a sustainable economy, to a low-carbon, resource-efficient, circular economy. We need to make sure we enable people to fully participate in society. This is not about something that is ‘nice to have’; it something that is urgent and something we need to have. This is about competitiveness in the widest sense of the word. This is about the future of the European way of life. It will not happen all by itself. I am deeply convinced that new forms of governance and smart regulation are increasingly going to play an important part in that respect. To make this transition from where we are now to where we need to be tomorrow and the day after tomorrow, you need governance; you need broad alliances with businesses, NGOs and society at large. This is what we need to create in Europe, and I count on working with you hand in hand. The European Parliament will lead on this.
