If we fall in the trap of only defending the past, all we will find ourselves able to do, is to slow down decline. This is about shaping the future. A prosperous future for all Europeans. So the Commission sees the global 2030 Agenda as a tremendous opportunity – for Europe, for the international community at large. An opportunity also for us all to overcome our own silos, whether they are in the services or between countries and between institutions. Our intention is to make the implementation of the SDGs, like the circular economy, a team effort. We encourage you to do the same, and I look forward to work closely with this House on this Agenda over the months and years to come, and with the Council of course.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, Mr. Vice-President, Madam High Commissioner, Madam Minister, indeed without false modesty, the adoption of agenda 2030 has been a great success for the European Union. It was the culmination of a truly inclusive negotiation process where, in addition to the United Nations Member States, civil society and the private sector also participated, but it was essential that the EU had a unified position.  That is why this agenda includes concepts such as good governance, the rule of law, inclusive institutions that were not part of the development agenda before. And you, Mr. Vice President, Madam High Representative, were in New York when that agenda was adopted, and now comes the hard part, which is the implementation of that agenda, that program, these development goals. And before us is actually the first act in implementing where this will be measured, which is a meeting of high-level political forums in the 7th month in New York.  The aim of this debate and the resolution we will adopt is to demand that we once again have one unified position of the European Union there and not be presented exclusively at the level of different EU Member States. We may have already expected communication from the European Commission, but we understand the complexity of the process, so we will probably have this communication in the second half of this year. But what we need is to establish, together with the Council, a common position that we could be successful in July. And that is really the objective of this debate and this resolution and what we are asking both the Council and the Commission.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank both the Vice-Presidents for being here tonight, and also the Council. I think it is a very important statement of intent that you are all here tonight to embrace the concept of the universal agenda of the SDGs. When you talk around the capitals of Europe, and indeed in this Parliament, to be honest, we get the impression that we are still talking of SDGs as a replacement for the MDGs. It is something about development policy, exactly what you said, Commissioner Timmermans, and we need to move away from that, we need to get this comprehensive agenda.  I was pleased with what the Presidency said about bringing the Member States together and their coordination. It would be useful to set it out for Parliament so that we know what the Member States and Council are going to do: that will be very important. I have just got few specific questions for the Commission stemming from New York. We have seen progress and statisticians have done their job: they produced these statistics, these indicators. Is the Commission looking at those statistics now? Are you thinking how we can implement them and set some baselines across the Commission? How are we preparing for the first meeting of the high-level political forum which takes place in less than 2 months’ time? How will the Commission be represented? How will the Member States be represented? Will we speak with one voice in that forum? It would be useful for us to understand that. We know that the development aspects will be covered by a new consensus on development. I am very pleased that Commissioner Timmermans has said that we will look at the 2020 strategy for the internal aspects. We must have a universal agenda and we must be coherent. We must not lose sight of important things such as financing for development, and the major conference this week in London about corruption.  We all know that there is money there if we can harness it for governments to invest in the interest of society and not to have it stashed away in bank accounts in places like Panama. So there are some very important coherent issues and I very much welcome what has been said tonight and the concept of agenda that the Commissioners have spoken about.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The new development goals are ambitious and can be historic in their impact. It is now up to the world community to show that it is in the right and also with the European Union. What was negotiated in New York should use the Union as a momentum to modernise its own development strategy. I have three suggestions.  Firstly, it is essential to involve the private sector because it is an indispensable player in the creation of prosperity It is a utopia to think that substantial progress can be made by relying solely on the financial transfers of the rich countries. Point two: with goals alone you achieve nothing. It is essential to focus on policies and reforms that create prosperity and encourage economic growth, such as integrating poor countries into world trade, good governance, fighting corruption. And finally, it is important that progress is measurable. Indicators should be sufficiently clear and specific, and it is crucial that they are tailored to the specific circumstances of each state.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Sustainable Development Goals adopted last September in New York show what mankind should achieve over the next 15 years: to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger and to create economically, socially and environmentally sustainable development around the world. In order to achieve the 17 SDGs by 2030, it is of paramount importance to draw up a plan on how the objectives will be implemented in practice and how their progress will be monitored. Implementation shall be measured by appropriate indicators. The EU must show leadership in achieving sustainable development. It plays an important role in this as the world's largest trading power, the largest donor of development aid and a leading force in environmental policy. The 2030 Agenda aims to achieve comprehensive action to promote sustainable development. In the EU, it must be implemented in both internal and external policies. Action must be consistent at both Member State and Union level. The fact that both Vice-President Timmermans and Mr Mogherini are involved in this debate shows that the Commission has understood the comprehensiveness and universality of the SDG. We in this House are going to closely monitor the Commission's efforts to implement the Sustainable Development Agenda. Parliament is ready to give all its support to this work.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the SDGs are often referred to, or vilified, as utopian. However, I believe that this is not the case. Consider, for example, the requirement to eradicate poverty in all its forms everywhere by 2030. I understand that this may sound unrealistic, but if we consider that the cost of eliminating poverty in the world for a full year is equal to the cost of arms in eight days, we will realise how little is enough. The hard truth is that poverty can be eradicated, but there is a lack of will, especially from the political and economic elites who have been so drastically involved in the status quo. Cutting poverty in half sounds more realistic than the requirement to eradicate poverty everywhere and in all its forms, but we must not forget that poverty kills more people every year than it did during World War II. If we want to go to the root of the problem, then we will get to the failing political and economic elites and the uneven way in which wealth is distributed in the world. But we don't talk about that anymore.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The sustainable development agenda is universal, as has been said. From their point of view, we are all – indeed all – developing countries, and not a single country in Europe has the luxury of reforming nothing and not reviewing its policies. And now the 2030 Agenda will be on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council on 12 May. But is this the right body? Commissioner, you said that there is a philosophy behind it. This philosophy is actually world internal politics. It takes up sectors that were previously considered to be classically intra-European. In order to prove that we did not make empty promises at the UN in September, the Heads of State or Government should, instead of discussing them at foreign minister level, make a statement together with the Presidents of the Council, the Commission and Parliament. The next step should be a clear plan for what exactly Europe will do, when and by what means, so that all sustainability targets can really be achieved on time, including the climate target. After all, it is simply logical that the strategies of COP 21 should be intertwined with the sustainable development goals and be meaningfully intertwined. In order for this link to take place, we greens will still be tabling amendments here, and I would ask everyone to support these amendments.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in 1992, in Rio de Janeiro, 178 governments adopted Agenda 21, which established sustainability principles and criteria with the aim of guiding the development policies of the twenty-first century. Ten years later, in 2002, Johannesburg was noted that tangible results had not been achieved and the lack of culture and awareness of sustainable development was recognised. Today we are following a new agenda with 17 objectives and 169 targets to be achieved by 2030. We believe it is essential and urgent to demonstrate that the word sustainability is no longer a mirage for the European Union.  How can we make coherent and sustainable policies of European interests that determine land grabbing, the exploitation of non-renewable resources, arms sales, deforestation, corruption and, in most cases, odious social and economic inequality? Objectives and declarations of intent are not enough. The European Union must undertake a thorough review of development policies, ensure regular monitoring and accountability, ensure adequate funding and initiate a new process of citizen participation in the planning, design and implementation of these policies.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, two political values are important for democracy: legitimacy, that is, to tell the truth and to share this truth through credibility, to live the truth. However, on sustainable development, the European Union should question its legitimacy and credibility.  Of the seventeen objectives on the sustainable development agenda, I remember the first four: poverty, hunger, health and education. What is the legitimacy of sustainable development when EU policy results in a 47% increase in child mortality in Greece through its policy to the banks against the Greek people? What credibility does the Union have in supporting free trade and relocating its pollution while perceanting the UN's ecological objectives? China pollutes for us more than for it, and that is the eighth objective.  If we remain in our hypocrisy, nothing will change. At home, man works for the economy and the economy works for finance, whereas with the Copernican revolution - if our priorities were human - of this new humanism that the Holy Father asks us to listen to wisdom, in short to avoid the desolation and suicide of Western Europe, we should want finance to work for the economy and the economy for man and his needs.  This revolution, I propose: it would be to use the capabilities of the Central Bank, the current 1 trillion monetary creation to invest them in a human project of sustainable development that would then be truly economic, social and environmental. 500 billion invested in the countries of southern Europe and 500 billion in co-development with the South. This project is within our reach. (The Chair withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I would first like to say that the PPE Group was one of the initiators of today's discussion on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. For us, today's debate is important in the run-up to the High-Level Political Forum to be held in July, bearing in mind that the effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda is something that we need to stick to.  As a permanent rapporteur on the coherence of development policies, I would like to draw attention to recital J and paragraphs 11, 12 and 13 of the text that we will be voting on Thursday. If we want the implementation of the 2030 Agenda to be a success, I believe that this coherence of development policies is needed. We need clarity from the Commission on how the coherence of development policies and the 2030 Agenda will be articulated.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – It is very important that what we bring in on the one hand - either in Paris or in New York - should also be implemented in our own European Union. There is a very important challenge there.  Let me give you two examples. In Paris where it was about climate, strongly linked to the 2030 targets and the SDGs, we have committed to keeping the temperature rise below 2 degrees. This has an effect on the objectives we set when it comes to ETS and also non-ETS, and the Commission is fully working on that. I can only give them a heart to be very ambitious in that.  The second example concerns, perhaps somewhat unexpectedly, biodiversity. Three SDGs deal with biodiversity and the Commission launched a "fitness check" of the Habitats Directive and the Birds Directive 15 months ago. It is extremely important that we convert it as well. We should not revise these directives but implement them. And that is an encouragement to the Commission.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Vice-President Timmermans on an excellent speech, where he asked us to be comprehensive in dealing with sustainable development and ending poverty. A comprehensive approach to this up to 2030 requires us to recognise that global poverty has still got a billion people in need, but we also have a huge humanitarian crisis in the Middle East and we need to understand that in its totality if we are going to make any progress.  The 17 sustainable development goals are a great – and very important – comprehensive, sustainable and enjoined effort. But it requires money – it requires USD 2.5 trillion. My report, which was passed in Parliament last month, points out how to raise these sort of funds – by leverage, which we have done, and the Commission has committed itself to that – and we can actually involve the private sector, in public—private partnership, to act comprehensively, reduce poverty and also sustainably help the EU in that problem. But I am already told that the UN is now six months behind creating the 230 indicators that we need. We must not allow the United Nations to use its bureaucracy to slow down this process. The global humanitarian crisis which I mentioned a few minutes ago also requires that the new Secretary—General of the United Nations, who we are going to look towards to implement our programme, has some humanitarian experience. It should not really be just someone who can run government, but someone who has got hands—on experience of development and humanitarian work. In that regard, I think Parliament should also have a further role in scrutinising the work of the UN and in the sustainable development goals up to 2030 in the programme that we have devised because it is our European taxpayers’ money that will be used.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President, High Representative, Commissioner, gender equality is the truly universally cross-cutting applicable component of the 2030 Agenda. It is where every country needs to step up and make this aspiration the reality of our time. I think we all can agree on a crucial fact – all SDGs must deliver for gender equality and women’s empowerment, the stand-alone goal No 5. Let me cite Mrs Puri, UN Women Deputy Executive Director: ‘As a comprehensive, inclusive and universal development framework for action the 2030 Agenda must be our inspiration, and civil society is called to harvest the gender equality compact across sustainable development, human rights, peace and security and the humanitarian commitments to advance its critical work’. This is for me the paramount perspective. We are experiencing for the first time ever that so much emphasis has been placed on acceleration and creating change within one generation. This emphasis is a clear signal that the 2030 Agenda is the ultimate challenge. It is time for our world to fast-forward and that is why we men and women in politics are expected to press that button and use our strongest determination.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Working together to achieve the 17 SDGs is in the global interest, you are right. In order to preserve our European way of life, we need to reshape our relations with other parts of the world. It cannot be a matter of continuing the existing forms of development cooperation. The results after more than half a century are not satisfactory. A comprehensive approach that brings together public, private and civil society engagement will be much more effective.  Above all, good governance on the ground is a prerequisite. Here we can offer a lot of expertise. However, it must also be wanted by the partners. As long as for every euro that flows south, up to ten euros illegally flow from the south to the tax havens, this is a futile struggle. The return of such funds to the use of the countries of origin is central. Perhaps the Panama Papers will help. But the Member States that have constructed such dependent territories, and, by the way, thank you to Nirj for implicitly supporting Mrs Georgieva's candidature for Secretary-General of the United Nations, must also contribute.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr President-in-Commissioner, I would like to thank the Dear High Representative! With regard to the objectives of the 2030 Agenda, I consider two key points of outstanding importance that still need to be considered for a successful agenda process. Firstly, the lack of policy coherence between the various EU policies. Secondly, we still need a coordinated strategy of the national states with their objectives and timelines.  An example of this is the Commission's current important initiative on supply chains in the textile sector. I am working very this issue and i spoke about it two weeks ago at the Commission's high-level conference as a representative of Parliament. The basic coordination between the various Areas of the Commission alone has taken several months, and I hope that the Commission will soon present the overview analysis announced on this subject, including on the national textile analyses to date. In addition, a European observatory is needed to follow the implementation of the set indicators on the 2030 Agenda by all Member States, but also to make them transparent. We started this process together in New York a few months ago, and I hope that we will bring it to a successful end.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: " Madam President, Mr. Timmermans said well that these goals speak of shaping the future, that we should understand the philosophy of these goals. Thus, these are the 17 SDGs and agenda 2030 builds on the development goals adopted in 2000. There is certainly talk of cooperation that is within the international community, and in terms of moral obligation to create a different future. While the MDGs focused on developing countries, the 2030 Agenda is the first global agreement setting out a universal, comprehensive action programme that will affect all countries. Also, all countries must participate in the implementation of the new programme. That's the difference, that's the different philosophy. In any case, 17 ambitious objectives that speak to environmental, social and economic objectives, the most important of which is implementation. Implementation is at issue here and I hope that we will be capable enough and wise enough to know how to implement the goals we have set for us. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – You mentioned that the Millennium Goals are the basis for this 2030 strategy. But since then, it's happened in the world, and I'm referring specifically to the refugee crisis. Do you not think that we should devote the European Union's assistance much more, much more intensively and specifically to the starting focuses of the refugee crisis?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you for asking. It is evident that the European Union is allocating big money, and we remember that in 2014 it allocated €58 billion. So, the biggest donor of development aid is the European Union and in any case we will focus on these countries as well, but there are global goals that we agreed on in New York and I hope that we will push for their implementation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, do you not think that it might be very important for the European Union’s credibility and leadership that this important organisation is going to develop a common European Union position on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda? Do you not think that we ought to call on the High Representative, the First Vice-President and the Commission as a whole to do their best possible to develop a common position on this implementation which is so important?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Frunzulica, that's what this is all about. It is not about individual countries, but it is a common approach of all 28 EU countries. Likewise, this is the first time that each country does not decide for itself, but we act together. So I think your question is out of context.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Correct answer, obviously matched the question.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Madam President, High Representative, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has With the 2030 Sustainability Agenda, the international community has launched a global rethink. There is no question that affluent societies such as the EU must go ahead and honour the commitments, both at home and in terms of aid to other partners in the world. To be brief, we need this comprehensive sustainability strategy in the EU. Secondly, we need legislation that wants to achieve these 17 objectives and does not counteract them. And thirdly, we need progress to keep the whole thing under constant review. I hope that the report by the Commission's sustainability officer will make very concrete proposals in a few weeks' time. I would also like to ask the Commission and the Council: what can the cross-policy and institutional coordination look like? It is a Herculean task to bring these three sustainability goals together. That is what the Commission is called upon to do, but also the Member States, Madam President-in-Office of the Council.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, 2015 was certainly very important in sfining the sustainable development agenda, but in 2016 and then, in the course of implementation, the credibility of the commitments made will be played out.  The European Union and the Member States have a dual responsibility: first, to fulfil the commitment to achieve 0.7% of gross national income in development aid and, secondly, to develop concrete plans for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda with quantitative targets, deadlines and appropriate monitoring.  And I ask the Commissioner that coordination efforts between the Commission and the Member States are underway to implement the sustainable development goals and what more we can do to ensure proper monitoring, the involvement of this European Parliament, because this is the time of truth, the time when it is decided whether or not we are up to the political commitments that have been made.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Madam President, development policy is key in achieving a more inclusive and peaceful world by uniting global efforts to improve people’s lives worldwide and eradicate poverty. The EU is the world’s largest provider of development and humanitarian assistance, and with the adoption of Agenda 2030 last September in New York we all committed to the implementation of the new sustainable development goals. But how is this assistance being utilised?  As the situation in Europe has deteriorated dramatically, I think that the new sustainable development goals should take a step further and adopt strong objectives to reflect the enormity of the crisis, while addressing the root causes of migration in the countries of origin. We want to make sure that the funds achieve their purpose: to build sustainable economies, health services and educational facilities, create jobs and give a future to people in their own countries. We need to ensure that the new approach to migration is a top priority in the Agenda 2030 and sustainable development goals.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the aim of the 2030 agenda is to help the Member States of the European Union fight poverty and achieve sustainable development. In particular, according to the 2030 Agenda, issues such as poverty, climate change, health, education and gender equality should be addressed in order to achieve the sustainable development objective. Of course, the European Union, with its mercely austerity, is far from helping its Member States achieve these objectives. With the policies of the Memorandum imposed by the European Union on Greece, what it ultimately achieves is to create armies of the unemployed as well as to increase the rates of poverty and social exclusion. If the European Union really wants to achieve the objectives of the 2030 agenda, it must abandon austerity, take decisive measures against poverty and help solve the problem of public debt, both in the European region and in developing countries.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to draw Vice President Mogherini’s attention to goal 16 on promoting just, peaceful and inclusive societies. I have just returned from Egypt, where the situation is anything but. Over 40 000 political prisoners, 544 forced disappearances since August 2015, human rights organisations and their families living in fear of arbitrary arrest and detention, a free press that is virtually non-existent, and political opposition crushed. I have repeatedly asked the Vice-President to meet to discuss the case of Ibrahim Helawa, who will spend his 1000th day in prison on Friday, arrested as a juvenile for attending a pro-democracy rally in 2013. A European Parliament resolution, a letter from 50 MEPs and a meeting request from almost every Irish MEP has not persuaded you to meet, so could I please reassert the urgency to meet with the Vice-President to discuss Ibrahim Helawa, but also the wider situation in Egypt.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: My fellow Members were not active here in the catch the eye procedure, I was only able to speak to two Members.  The catch the eye procedure is over.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone here for their ideas and suggestions, which I believe are extremely useful in this phase, in which we are trying to take all the lessons learnt from the responsibility we showed last year in shaping the consensus on the Agenda 2030 and translate this into respective responsibility with regard to starting the implementation phase at an early stage. I think there is one lesson we learned very clearly from the previous experience of the Millennium Development Goals, which is that we cannot wait and see years go by before we start working seriously on the implementation. I remember very well being in New York together with a number of you – with Linda, with Vice-President Timmermans and Commissioner Mimica – celebrating the achievements of the SDGs last September together, in this team approach that underlines that we have understood that this is an Agenda that implies our work on our internal policies as much as it does on our external policies, and that we are starting to work on the changes, the efforts, that are needed to shift the mentality we have in our daily work and put together the different parts of our policies that are connected with the implementation of the Agenda. This will require, as Frans Timmermans mentioned, internal-external coordination, interinstitutional coordination and also a similar kind of work inside all the different institutions, including Parliament. That is why I was particularly glad to see that this debate has involved many of you – coming from different backgrounds and active on different committees – to feed in the work of Parliament also on different aspects. Let me also say that – as many of you have mentioned, and as Frans Timmermans also mentioned at the start – the agreement was just the beginning, and now the real part – the implementation – starts. We have started to work with this comprehensive approach on the different elements of our implementation work: from the issue of climate change to the sustainable development part, but also migration. We often focus in this House and in this plenary on the different parts of our policies on migration and refugees, but I believe that if we managed to implement fully the SDGs, 95% of the work we need to do to tackle the migratory and refugee phenomenon would be done, because this is the root cause. What we need to respond to global challenges is integrated solutions, and this poses a serious challenge to our traditional way of doing things and of working. But I believe this is going to be an extraordinary opportunity for us to understand how we have to deal with the world of today, with this internal and external coherence that is going to be essential, and also to push not only the Member States to coordinate more – I would say one word on this for which I should jump to the other side of the Hemicycle – but also to, let us say, encourage the UN system to adapt to these challenges. The UN system also needs to reflect on its own working methods if it wants to implement the Agenda in a proper way. On the external side: we are working on how best to adapt our external action and our development policy to fulfil the Agenda, contributing also to the commitments we have undertaken on climate change at COP 21 in Paris and aspects of our EU global strategy that we debated in this Hemicycle just last night. Many of you referred to the fact that next Thursday we have a Development Ministers Council, or rather a Foreign Affairs Council, in its development ministers formation, and – once again I should jump to the other side of the Hemicycle to say so, but the Presidency will forgive me if I play my double hat in a flexible way – we will have a discussion on the review of the European Consensus for Development, including its adaptation to the Agenda 2030, and we will reflect on some new elements of the Consensus. Here I will need your help and our coordination – our common work – to be courageous enough to bring us to the next stage, because my impression is that we will need to work on including in our Consensus elements that we have not had so far. By way of example, I am speaking of our work on peace and security, which are consistent parts of our implementation of Agenda 2030; the important role of the private sector; our more and more differentiated partnerships with increasingly diverse partners, including middle-income countries, which will be a complicated debate, but we need to have it; on working together with Member States through joint programming and joint implementation, which I believe could be the key for us to mobilise resources in a more strategic way, coordinating more what we are already doing towards a common objective. We also need to look into the more traditional ones, coordinating all of this effort also with our reflection on the post-Cotonou reflections and proposals. I will continue to work on the external sides of this with Commissioner Mimica, with Parliament, with Linda and with the Development Committee, so that we can carry out this joint work in liaison with the work that Frans Timmermans, Vice-President Katainen and the others are developing on the internal side. We also have our public consultation process, which is of course also going to feed our work in this. I know that we can count on your very active support and also your contribution to this work, because we are in a field that was not there before, and this is a huge occasion for us not only to understand the complexity of the world much better, but also to interact with it in a more effective way. For sure, after Thursday we will have more in terms of what the Council will have.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, after the beautiful statement by Federica Mogherini, our High Representative, what can I say? There is little I can add, but allow me to underline that the Council is devoted to continuing our exchange of views in the coming months, among Member States and also among institutions. It is important. The work on the implementation of the 2030 commitments and towards the adoption of the new European consensus will continue. There is – I have said this before, but I will repeat it again – still important work and significant work ahead of us. Obviously, as stated by Federica Mogherini, your active support is highly appreciated, and I look forward to continuing our close cooperation.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 11 May 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The Sustainable Development Goals are essential to the objectives that the European Union has fixed for its Agenda 2030. They represent targets that the Member States have to achieve in terms of internal development and assistance for the development of the poorest countries in the world. The European Commission has to motorise the steps that are taken to achieve them but also to support the Member States all the way. On paper the goals and Agenda 2030 look good, but we have to make sure they are happening. It is in the best interests of the European citizens to push for their achievement and in order to do that we need to allocate financial resources and the expertise to make them possible. I really hope we will not remember the Sustainable Development Goals only at the next UN Summit where we will have to think about other goals. For that we need to communicate more about them, involve people and civil society, and generate a common cohesive strategy across Europe for their achievement.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU assistance to Lebanon and Jordan to face the effects of the Syrian crisis (2016/2698(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by saying that I was just in Lebanon and Jordan – actually, physically, I was in Jordan coming from Lebanon – on the day of the terrorist attack in Brussels and I felt, I experienced myself, very directly, the support and the sympathy that these countries gave us Europeans on one of the most dramatic days of our recent history. And I believe that that was a reflection of our partnership, our friendship, which is strong, as we work with each other, but basically we support each other – which is sometimes more important than that – but that was also a reflection of the fact that those countries are facing that kind of challenge every single day that goes by. Because when we mention the effects of the Syrian crisis, we tend normally to focus on the refugee crisis – which is indeed the case, I will come to that in a moment – but we should not underestimate the risks in terms of security, the threats, the challenges that these two countries are facing due to the crisis in Syria and the spread of Daesh in their own region. So I think we should always keep this in mind: that they are exposed to different levels of threats and pressures, and the way in which they are resisting this storm, which is actually a perfect storm, is quite remarkable. And let me also mention that we discuss these two countries together very often. Our work with them is always highlighted together. They are very different one from the other – I know you all know that as regards their political situation, social situation and obviously this very same composition of the countries – but indeed they have some elements in common. First of all, they are giving shelter and hope to millions of people fleeing Syria. They show a great example of peaceful coexistence among different faiths and nationalities, which is an example for the Middle East, an example for Europe and also an example for the whole world. And they can play an important role in the solution of so many crises, starting with Syria, obviously – we sit together in the International Support Group for Syria. But let me mention, for instance, the key role that Jordan plays when it comes to the Middle East peace process. I believe we all agree across the different political families on this: that our support for Jordan and Lebanon is an investment, is in the best interests of the countries, of the countries’ citizens, of Syrian refugees, of the whole region in terms of stability and security, and it is also in the best interests of European citizens. There are over one million registered refugees in Lebanon. The real figure is likely to be higher – perhaps around 1.5 million – as the UNHCR, as we know, is no longer allowed to register new arrivals, which is something that should be fixed as quickly as possible. This means that one quarter of the Lebanese population are Syrian refugees – one quarter. Lebanon is just a bit bigger than Strasbourg’s region, Alsace; but Lebanon alone hosts almost as many Syrians as the entire European Union. I would like us to keep this in mind, very clearly, when we speak about these two countries, facing at the same time a neighbouring country that is torn by war and the threat of Daesh. So those who believe that refugees might destroy our Union should look at these figures and – allow me to be blunt – feel ashamed. There are over 630 000 registered refugees in Jordan. The recent census shows that 1.2 million Syrians are in the country. So these are the figures; these are the numbers; and these are issues that are not debatable. These are there, they are facts. But let us also keep in mind that we are talking about real people behind the numbers, with names, faces, stories to tell, hopes for the future, and that we have to support these countries also for the sake of the humanity that is behind these numbers. I visited refugee camps in Jordan and Lebanon several times, and the last time was on the very day of the terrorist attacks in Brussels. If I can share with you on a personal note, it was very difficult for me in those hours to decide to keep the agenda of our meetings going with what was happening just a few metres away from our European institutions. For me it was important to hold the meetings inside the refugee camps in Jordan that day, as I did in Lebanon on the previous day, because in the camps, but also in the local communities that are hosting them outside of the camps, you very often meet people who are fleeing from the same atrocities that we sometimes experience in Europe. These are in most cases people fleeing from the atrocities of Daesh and who can tell you stories that you would never ever want to hear. Obviously, we had held other meetings and visits before that – myself, Commissioner Hahn, Commissioner Stylianides – on several occasions, and what I saw in those days, what my colleagues and friends have seen every time we go there, is people that even if they have experienced the worst atrocities in their lives, still have a smile on their face, still find a reason to hope and still believe that it can be possible to go back to their homes. When you ask them – sometimes 10-year-old boys and girls in the school, sometimes 17-year-old boys and girls, hoping to go to university – if you ask them: what is your dream, if you can express one wish, what would it be? It is not to come to Europe, it is to go back to Syria. All of them! So I think that we have a collective responsibility towards those hopes that are still alive in their minds and in their hearts. We have obviously a duty to work on a solution to the Syrian crisis. This is something that we are constantly doing. I was just in Paris for one of the meetings with the Syrian opposition and some of our partners in the region in Europe and the United States. To continue working on that, we will have another meeting of the Support Group for Syria next week, so our work on that side does not stop: it is tireless. But we have a duty to feed this hope with concrete measures every single day. In those camps and in the local communities that are hosting so many refugees, both in Lebanon and Jordan, we have almost always also seen the European Union in action. We have seen schools paid for with European support, food and clothes, both thanks to our help, babies born in hospitals that we finance. We are literally giving life in those places, and it made me proud of our European Union. It showed me that our work can have a direct impact on every single life that we invest in, and this makes the figures for our money, our support, our investments in the region, real when you see the baby that was born the previous day, when you see the children in school, when you see the food and water coming. The European Union is the first donor in the region. This means that we have been helping Syrian refugees with almost EUR 6 billion mobilised so far by institutions and Member States together – EUR 6 billion! And this is something of which I remind our partners around the world every time I meet them, from Washington to Tokyo. Because I believe that we have to reach a point where this is felt as a global responsibility – not just a regional one, not just a European one, but a global one – and I believe that we are slowly managing somehow to broaden the spectrum of actions that are taken also by other actors in order either to welcome refugees or support financially other countries that are welcoming them there. The pledges of the International Donors Conference in London last February are already materialising, building in many cases on long—standing efforts that, as you know, we have undertaken since the beginning. You know that more than half of the money pledged in London and which is coming in concrete projects comes from the EU budget, and if you look at the EU budget and Member States’ budgets combined, this makes up two thirds of the pledges in London. We are trying to address the refugees’ immediate needs but also, as I said, to keep hope alive. In concrete terms, hope is the possibility to go to school for the children, to learn a job, to imagine your own life after exile, and for this very reason we are very much focusing especially on two main issues – the support we give to children and young people and the support we give to women – because we know very well that these are the two engines for keeping hope alive in the families that flee Syria. This is important for Syria and its future. This is important for the Syrian people. This is important for the host countries, but this is also important for Europe because it is quite clear that hope can succeed where the fear of fences and border police can only fail. So this is also a very pragmatic approach that we can take. Investing in schools, education, job creation for the young people of Syria in Jordan and Lebanon is also a way of investing in their future close to home. At the same time, we also need to support the host communities and their resilience. So we are working on the compacts of mutual commitments with Lebanon and Jordan, which will come on top of the commitments agreed in London and will be annexed to our new bilateral partnership priorities. If an agreement is reached, and I am quite positive about that, the European Union could provide overall over EUR 1 billion in 2016 and 2017 for these initiatives, both in Jordan and Lebanon. And this is not only about aid, because when Europe acts as a union, as we managed to do in London, we can mobilise a unique and quite impressive number of different assets ranging from trade to policy dialogues. For Jordan, for instance, we are looking into a temporary relaxation of rules of origin to announce trade investments and job opportunities for Syrian refugees also. That would create job opportunities for the Syrians and for the Jordanians in the host communities that are more exposed. I called the compacts a win—win—win proposal. They would benefit the refugees, the host communities and us. In fact the compacts are being designed to build on mutual commitments, and let me stress how proud I was that we managed to shape these compacts in the London Conference out of a mainly UK idea, using mainly EU tools for the benefit of us all. And I believe this is something that our friends in the UK should consider when we talk about the added value of our common instruments. On our mutual commitments: for instance, while we provide financial support to schools for attendance for refugee children in Lebanon, we also need the local authorities to create a protective environment around the children, so the parents can feel confident about sending their children to school. In our relationship with Jordan and Lebanon we can learn a great deal; we can learn a lot from each other, and perhaps Europe has more to learn than we would want to admit. I agree with the wise words of the King of Jordan, His Majesty King Abdullah, when he says that countries that are hosting a relatively small number of refugees should maybe act more and preach less. But let me also take a moment to remember the tens of thousands of Syrian refugees stranded at Jordan’s north-eastern border, the ‘Berm’. The vast majority of them are women and children and they need urgent humanitarian assistance, which is difficult to deliver in such a remote area. I am aware that the issue is very sensitive and there are a number of aspects, so I am very grateful to the Jordanian Government for its decision to allow 20 000 people from the area to be hosted at the Azraq camp. This is a very important move, and I hope that relief and protection for refugees at the Berm can be found quickly. I know that this House, this Hemicycle, this Parliament supports the work we are doing with both Jordan and Lebanon, and let me tell you that your contribution will be important and will be welcome in continuing this important work. On my side you know that I will guarantee that I will always work to strengthen our ties with these two countries at all levels, especially because –I know we normally focus on the fact that they are hosting the refugees, but let me stress once more – their resilience is strategic to our security. This is not one region out of many; it is our region and it is the most troubled region in the world. So their resilience is somehow a very strategic element of our internal security as well. King Abdullah is a very respected and inspiring figure in the Muslim world. and I remember that we listened to his words here in this Hemicycle last year. And I have had the pleasure of meeting him and Queen Rania on several occasions. Let me say that obviously we are also focusing very closely on the political situation in Lebanon, especially on ending the political crisis. That is crucial to realising the full potential of our partnership, and maybe we will have another occasion to come back to this proper discussion on the future of Lebanon’s political and institutional situation another time in this Hemicycle. But let me close by quoting the words of King Abdullah of Jordan speaking in this Hemicycle, from that podium, one year ago, who said: ‘Our victory now depends on our unity. Europe’s role is vital ... It is essential that our regions renew the source of our great strength: the mutual respect that binds and sustains us.’ I believe that we have a responsibility to each other, and that responsibility is our duty to tell our friends and partners: Europe is with you as you are with Europe. We will not leave you alone because our common victory depends on our unity. I thank you very much. I look forward to listening to your views on that. (Applause)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her Colleagues! I am impressed by the speech. Because this speech, Mrs Mogherini, which you have given, shows us Europeans the mirror. We complain and hear some shouting from the outer sides of the House about the overburdening of Europe. When I consider what is being done in other parts of the world – and especially in the region – it is downright ridiculous what we have had in terms of pressures so far.  I have been to Lebanon on various occasions over the last two years. When I see that a country of four million people, which is just as divided by the Saudis and the Iranians and has 300 000 Palestinian refugees in camps for 60 years, has now taken in well over a million from Syria, that is an incredible effort and moral achievement. When I see that the King of Jordan, because of the Palestinian refugees who have been there for decades, no longer has a majority of his own in his country and this very poor country has now taken on this number of refugees once again, I would invite us all to extrapolate and look at the population of the city in which one lives. what there are in terms of loads. Incidentally, we must also include Turkey, which has also taken over these high burdens to a large extent. That is why I think it is important – and I believe it will be – that we give them our full support in terms of funding and also in terms of political support. This is a question of Christian charity, it is a question of humanity. And every single human life has to be counted here and not always the general bills are drawn up.  This is a matter of our security. If this region explodes, it will have dramatic negative consequences for us, and that is why we should finally realise that this is not a question of how we can be better off here – by keeping ourselves out of it – but that we fight for our interests when we help the people there – the states, such as the refugees. That is why I can only give you full support from my group for us to do more here, both the Member States and the European Union. We also need to talk about this when we talk about the midterm review, about the budget, where new priorities are being set here.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank High Representative Mogherini for her passionate plea for solidarity and action. This is the message we need, and it is a clear invitation to Member States to take action to show that our moral standards are equally practised and not only spoken – that they are not only good teachings for others.  The situation today in Lebanon and Jordan is not sustainable. There are more than two million refugees in two small countries, in which they represent between 10 and 30% of the population. The UN’s humanitarian appeal for 2015 shows that 61% of the needs have been financed. A lot was promised in February at the London Conference on Syria, but we know very well that funding shortages means that most of the vulnerable Syrian refugees in Lebanon and Jordan live well below the UN poverty line. The generosity of the communities in the two countries is high, but it might not be enough. If we fail to help the two countries, then they could become the refugees of tomorrow. I quote you, Madam High Representative: ‘Jordan and Lebanon are rocks in the Middle Eastern storm’, and therefore I believe we have to support them by all means.  Jordan sets an example through its important efforts towards democracy and Lebanon is a stable but fragile state surrounded by so many threats. It is imperative to support their economic and social resilience in these difficult times. The EU has been a leading donor in the region, but we have to feel the sense of urgency and take difficult decisions. We also have to understand that if we want a comprehensive strategy to tackle the migration crisis, cooperation with Turkey is of equally huge importance.  On behalf of my S&D Group, I urge the Commission for the pledges to be disbursed and for the EU compacts to be finalised as soon as possible in order to immediately strengthen our assistance and cooperation with them using the full range of EU policies. Finally, I will also encourage the Commission and the European Parliament to respond immediately and effectively to the Jordanian request to grant the special arrangement on rules of origin, which we hope can help to provide new jobs for the Jordanians and Syrian refugees alike.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – At the beginning of February this year, Jordanian Prince Abdullah warned that his country had reached a boiling point, a boiling point, because of the influx of hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees. The facts speak for themselves. Syrian refugees now make up 20% of the total Jordanian population. As a result, the Hashemite Kingdom is forced to spend as much as 25% of its national budget on them. The budgetary stretch in Amman is therefore completely out of the way. EU aid in this dire situation in the form of the creation of necessary jobs – such as stimulating the tourism sector and improving the market access of Jordanian products to the European market – is more than welcome. I wholeheartedly agree with the requests of the Jordanian authorities in this. The situation in Lebanon is even more dramatic. Syrian refugees already make up 25% of the total population. Moreover, 90% of these Syrian refugees are Sunni, with all the consequences for the delicate religious balance between Sunnis, Shiites and Christians in the country. New Lebanese visa measures for Syrians have now led to large-scale illegal Syrian immigration into the country. The sad consequence is that 70% of Syrian refugees in Lebanon are currently in deep poverty. Just last month, a research report revealed that 70 percent of Syrian refugee children in Lebanon are being ruthlessly exploited in the labour market. An insider told me that there is widespread slavery and human trafficking, not to mention the abhorrent sexual slavery under which Syrian women suffer physically and psychologically in Lebanon.  High Representative, I urge the Lebanese authorities to address child and women abuses among Syrian refugees at home and to ensure the ultimate protection of their human dignity.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the High Representative on her speech, which was full of passion and compassion for the people that are in need of our support. During the last few months we have had a debate in Europe on the unprecedented arrivals and migrants on our shores. Heads of State have stated that Europe, the richest continent on the planet, can no longer cope with the numbers of refugees arriving. Let us be clear: we are facing a challenging situation. This is true, but this is mainly because we have completely failed to find a sustainable common European solution. If you were to spread the 1.5 million asylum seekers evenly throughout the Member States of the Union, it would imply that every city of 10 000 persons would receive 30 asylum seekers. Does this merit the crisis narrative? The amount of asylum seekers making their way to Europe over the past few years corresponds to not even 0.3% of our population. How about comparing that with the Lebanese situation where I, together with some ALDE colleagues, studied the situation a few weeks ago? Lebanon, a country approximately one-third of the size of Belgium with 4 million citizens, has received somewhere between 1.2 and 1.8 million refugees from Syria, which means that one in every four persons in Lebanon is a Syrian refugee.  This does not merit the crisis rhetoric. We in Europe are complaining over and over again that refugees should stay in the neighbouring countries as we sit back. Colleagues, mainly on the right wing of this House, are stating over and over again that it is not the same because the UNHCR and other NGOs will take care of the responsibility for them, but the truth is that the UNHCR only has the capacity to help about 15% of the refugees in Lebanon. In my view, while we must assist Lebanon and Jordan, we must first of all sort out our own failed asylum system rather than trying to close immoral deals or statements with increasingly authoritarian governments such as the Turkish one.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Madam Mogherini, I would like to begin by sincerely thanking you for your commitment to the political solution to the situation in Syria. It's not the numbers we're talking about, actually: it's people and lives we're talking about. And to account is not only to account for the money that is invested in countries like Lebanon or Jordan: it is also to account for the political choices of the European Union, because not all the money in the world together can help to wash away consciences.  We obviously have to support Lebanon, Syria and Jordan, both in the political process in Syria and on the issue of refugees in Lebanon and Jordan, because they are countries that give shelter and hope, as I have said, and well, to millions of people. But that's not enough. We cannot think that through an outsourcing process we have solved the problem by placing refugees in border countries. We need political solutions too and a non-shamed response from the European Union. I believe that the agreement with Turkey is part of the problem and not the solution in this regard. It is indeed a shame: we are talking about poorer countries and the European Union has an obligation to do much more to welcome these refugees and in a political response to the fundamental problem of conflict.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Mogherini, thank you very much for your excellent statement. There is no political solution in sight in Syria. Half of Syria's population is on the run, and one in four Syrians have since left their country seeking refuge in another country. There are more than 4.5 million refugees living in the four neighbouring countries of Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq alone, and there is no doubt that the region will remain dependent on international aid for years to come. At the Syria donor conference in London at the beginning of February, EUR 5 billion was pledged for this year and a similar amount for the coming years. However, the sums required are much higher. I visited Lebanon last year and had intensive discussions with Syrian refugees. Most refugees are aware that they will not return to their homeland for years to come. It is therefore important that international and local aid measures go beyond basic services and open up prospects. Adequate schooling and access to the labour market are of central importance for refugees. Keeping perspectives open also means that Syrian refugees have a realistic chance of moving to the EU with their closest relatives. Unfortunately, I am regularly told of major difficulties in approving applications for family reunification, for example in German embassies and consulates. In addition to financial and operational support, it must be an essential part of European aid that Syrian refugees can continue to seek protection with us.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, thank you for your speech and for your commitment. I believe that there is substantial and strong unity of opinion on this issue among most Members of this House. Who would say today that we do not want to help two heroic countries such as Jordan and Lebanon?  In spite of myself, however, I find myself having to make an analysis and to reckon with what I regret to do in a certain way. If we look, for example, at the Trust fund "Madad", which is really concerned with helping Syrian refugees, and we go and compare what we do in Jordan and Lebanon, on the one hand, and in Turkey, on the other, there is a considerable discrepancy. We have reckoned before, we have said important figures: there are about 1 300 000 refugees in Lebanon, and at least 650 000 – but probably one million – in Jordan. We will therefore have some 2.5 million refugees who, in return, receive aid of 1.8 billion between the two countries. For Turkey, counting what comes from the Trust fund, the 3 billion refugee facility and another 3 billion from the March 2016 agreement, we get to over 6.3 billion, and I obviously do not want to count pre-accession funds.  In Jordan and Lebanon there have been refugees since the first Israeli-Palestinian wars, hundreds of thousands. There are incredible efforts to live together, while in Turkey we see an ambiguous attitude towards Daesh and an attitude that has yet to be condemned with regard to a not enough fight against oil trafficking, for example. In essence, I have to say: why do we use this positive discrimination for a country that, however, shows much less commitment? Is it because Turkey is blackmailing us, am I thinking? Can we accept that we are strong with the weak and weak with the strong? In the face of the efforts of these countries, I say no.  We must continue along the path of London, if we are to make a positive discrimination, it must be towards Jordan and Lebanon, greatly increasing efforts and not giving in to the blackmail of authoritarian figures who would rather bow to their wishes. Helping Lebanon and Jordan also frees them from the blackmail of other regional powers such as Saudi Arabia, which is far from sympathetic to refugees, but very interested in exacerbating, for example, the clashes between Sunnis and Shiites in Lebanon itself and proxy wars. Their stability is ours, their prosperity is ours. We honour the European Union's Nobel Peace Prize every day on the ground.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her European support to Lebanon now amounts to just over EUR 860 million per year. I welcome this, as the small country with over a million official refugees is bearing the brunt of the refugee reception in the region. However, we need a greater earmarking of these funds. Lebanon has been a model for the integration of different religions for years. This is massively threatened by the advance of extremist Islamic forces. In particular, the situation of Christians threatens to deteriorate in the long term. However, it is precisely the increasing aggression against Christians in refugee camps that must be stopped, not only here in Europe, but already in the Middle East. The Union must therefore also make its financial assistance to deal with the refugee crisis conditional. Religious minorities are also protected in refugee camps, if necessary also through sectarian camps.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank Mrs Mogherini for her I, too, came back from Syria and Lebanon last week, and I noticed there that the refugee camps directly on the border are now empty. In other words, the pressure on refugees is eased. I do not understand why you are always talking about the whereabouts of the refugees, without at the same time taking into account the fact that the situation in Syria has completely changed: 62 towns, villages and communities have been recaptured by the Syrian Arab army in the last six weeks.  I have been to Maalula and seen 1500 of the 7000 inhabitants come back there. 5500 apartments are empty there, and this is what it looks like in other villages and towns. There is a lot that could be done by taking care, instead of funding schools, to encourage the return of refugees to safe areas. I think there is a lot that is possible there. I also miss the fact that you include in your questions those who are the main cause of the refugee crisis, namely the United States of America. How many refugees do they take in?

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to join what you have said and express respect for the efforts of Jordan and Lebanon to reduce the human suffering of millions in the region.  The European Union is the largest financial donor to the Syrian crisis, which has so far contributed more than 5 billion euros. eur 1.5 billion from its budget and member states' budgets in the form of humanitarian aid and support for economic development and stabilisation. Very often, we stress that Turkey has hosted over 2 million people. refugees, but we forget the small countries of Lebanon and Jordan that have accepted a total of 1.7 million refugees on their territory. more than 20% of their total population. In other words, the pressure on Lebanon and Jordan is immense. We must not forget that hundreds of thousands of Palestinians and Iraqis live in both countries because of other conflicts in the Middle East.  It is in our interest not only in terms of values, humanity and compassion, but also in our interest in reducing the refugee wave to Europe to help both Syria and Jordan.  Following the agreement with the European Union, Europe must also help solve the refugee problem in others in other countries, but we must also turn to solutions within us. With the changing world around us, with the crises in our European neighbourhood, we need to be much more united and truly of a so-called "soft power" to become a "hard power" – to have a common defence capacity, to have a common protection of the outside border, general intelligence.  In foreign policy, Europe needs to be much more united and consolidated.  I very much want, Mrs Mogherini, to have a unified voice before the world and for that voice to be your voice to be heard, for Europe to be respected and to participate not only in humanitarian and development aid, but also in finding political solutions to the crises around us.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President; I must congratulate you, Mrs Mogherini, on congratulating you and also thank you on behalf of all those of us who continue to believe in a strong Europe, but also in a europe of solidarity. And listening to you is a balm, the truth, in this European political geography which unfortunately has neither your energy nor your commitment, Madam High Representative. So thank you and congratulations on everything you're doing.  Indeed, as we have all said, Lebanon and Jordan, together with Turkey, are the countries that have taken in the most refugees from the Syrian war. Many of these countries already had a very high number of palestinian refugees— this is the case in Jordan and Lebanon—and are countries that have many domestic difficulties. The High Representative mentioned security issues; they have many social problems, they have social structures that do not bear the amount of needs that arise, so their effort is twofold and the example should serve the Member States of the European Union that are behaving with this selfishness when dealing with the refugee crisis. We Europeans really like to give lessons, but perhaps we should set an example rather than lessons and, in this case, take an example of countries that have made a huge effort of generosity with much greater difficulties. I wish the Europeans and, above all, the European governments would have been up to it.  I believe that in this Parliament you will find, Mrs Mogherini, mostly strong support to sustain the effort towards Lebanon and Jordan, because it is a smart decision, because it is a fair decision, because it appeals directly to the values we stand for and also appeals to our own interests in terms of security and for the European Union to continue to have a strong voice in the world. The voice you, Mrs. Mogherini, is representing today.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Thank you very much mrs Mogherini for her personal contribution to the region and her personal interest in it. I think this is a very clear signal to our partners in Lebanon and Jordan that we particularly appreciate what they are doing for refugees from neighbouring countries. I think we should, firstly, politically learn from the mistakes that we, as the West, have made in this region. Because we have made mistakes, there is nothing to discuss on this issue. Secondly, we should very strongly support these two countries in a political, economic and humanitarian sense so that they can deal with refugee issues, because that is in our basic political, social, economic interest. Once again, I would like to express my personal thanks to Commissioner Mogherini.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the High Representative for her heartfelt remarks today on a very tough situation in which too many people find themselves. The risk, danger and additional human suffering of a destabilised Lebanon – and that is what I will focus on – must not be underestimated, because the vast majority of the approximately 1.2 refugees in Lebanon are young and female. With a population of 4 million people in total, no other country is sheltering so many – until recently, with open borders. The Lebanese people are five times as poor as the average European, and 25% of the population are refugees. Let those who claim that we are the first to suffer the consequences of the ongoing terrible war in Syria, think again and look to Lebanon. It should humble and shame all of us. Let the situation in Lebanon we are discussing today be a reality check for those who still preach shelter in the region as a mantra that will be a self-fulfilling prophecy, or who see the outsourcing of our problems to Turkey as the only credible solution. Do we plan to do as comprehensive a deal with Lebanon, or only when people reach our shores? This would be too cynical, but we do have to look at what is spent per capita, also in Lebanon, and make sure that we look at the bigger picture, including stability, infrastructure, countering terrorism and countering radicalisation.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I would also like to thank you for your intervention. We have been in refugee camps on the Turkish-Syrian border, and I know the meaning of the smiles of Syrian children and the sobs of the parents. You will agree with me that this situation - this humanitarian aid absolutely necessary for Jordan and Lebanon - also reveals our indignity, not that of the European Union, but that of Europe, a Europe which is not able to take in one-tenth of the refugees welcomed in Lebanon and Jordan, or about 1.7 million people. I will be in Jordan and Lebanon this Sunday with the Committee on Budgets, and it will be very difficult for me, in these circumstances, to lecture both in Lebanon and in the Jordanian State. This situation also reveals our immorality, because ultimately what we do is relocate our bad conscience as well as our fears.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Madam President, let me thank Ms Mogherini not just for her words today, but also for her tireless efforts and the tireless efforts of all around her to make this world a better place to live in, especially for refugees in Jordan and in Lebanon. I myself had the chance last week to represent President Schulz at the first Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region of the Women in Parliaments Global Forum, and there I had also a chance to visit the Azraq camp, which is funded to a large extent by EU money. There was a big EU flag there which, they told us, had not been there for long – so now it is there! But the most touching thing was seeing kids in school: the education there. The young ones – like elementary school kids – were really eager to learn, so many of them, and saying what they wanted to become when they get older, also wanting to return. But then, the older they get, the fewer are attending school. We saw some preparing for graduation, and we heard that the reason why there are fewer of them as they get older is, in part, because there is no prospect for them to get scholarships to universities, for example. So my colleague Beatriz Becerra and I decided that we will start a small Parliament initiative, with – hopefully – other parliamentarians, to support those young people – mostly the young women, but also some of those young men – to get some scholarships to be able to do what Ms Mogherini said: to keep hope alive for them to have a prospect in life. That will, hopefully, be one of our small contributions, to also work on that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Are you aware that in Syria all training is financed by the state until the end of your studies? If people could return to their homeland, they could be trained there free of charge.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, but you know for yourself that it is currently not possible to study in Syria. That means they could study in Jordan. But there they have to pay for it. And I think it would make sense to support that. Of course, we hope that the war in Syria will soon be over. But this requires joint efforts, and Mrs Mogherini and many others are doing the same.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, we must pay tribute to Jordan and Lebanon, whose hospitality has helped ease the pressures facing EU countries by people traversing the dangerous migration routes into Europe, exacerbated by Chancellor Merkel’s earlier unwise comments. Concerns have already been raised by the Archbishop of Canterbury, highlighting the continued threats facing Christians and other minorities seeking equal sanctuary, and I would like to hear what actions are being taken to protect such groups, who face real threats within refugee camps from radical Islamists. As a grandson of both an Ashkenazi refugee and also of a lady who opened her own house to a family of refugees fleeing the 1956 Hungarian Revolution, I well understand the human suffering endured during a refugee crisis.  However, I am concerned by the wider political motives being played out as we hear continued commentary of how the EU has supposedly delivered peace since the Second World War, when in fact it has actually been achieved by the United Nations and NATO. So rather than channelling Member States’ money through EU institutions – which, at best, have a mixed record – let us instead work through the institutions that have a track record in not just bringing opposing sides to the negotiating table, but are best able to deliver results, rather than the aspirational aims of an EU desperately seeking a wider role on the international stage.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support EU support for Lebanon and Jordan is justified in order to help fewer migrants arrive in Europe. Because this immigration has serious consequences. We also know the financials in numerical order: this is EUR 250 000 for five years, a huge amount, on the basis of which the penalties of the Member States which rejected the quota were calculated.  But there are more serious consequences. I mention a symbolic example: in Hamburg, a little-used evangelical church has been converted into a mosque, where it is not only used on Fridays. Well, it can be said that we should be glad that the function has not changed, the house of God remains a house of God, but let me quote Turkish President Erdogan. In 1997, as mayor of Istanbul, he proudly proclaimed in a speech: "Mosques are our barracks, domes are our helmets, mynarets are our bayonets, the faithful are our soldiers." Everyone should think about that.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, High Commissioners, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has We can indeed be proud of what we have done in the area of humanitarian aid to Lebanon and Jordan. However, I am equally convinced that we are not sufficiently involved in this. I expect us to be much more active in resolving the Syrian issue in the field of foreign policy, because we should not leave it to the United States and Russia to decide what is happening there. Because if something goes wrong, we will feel the consequences. The refugees, in particular, do not go to Russia or the United States. Hence the call to do more. Because we see that we have a situation in Jordan where the generosity is remarkable. They share their education system, they share their scarce resources such as water, energy and housing. This is also driving up prices. In Jordan, it has to be said that groups like the Muslim Brotherhood are in sentiment against the king's policies. That worries me.
