I would therefore ask that we also check whether we can still increase aid, especially for Jordan. We must also note that ISIS is already inthecising in the north-east of the country. Perhaps we also need to provide assistance in Jordan in a different way in order to fight against it. Overall, I hope that we will maintain the commitment to stabilise these two countries.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We should have this important debate much more often. Indeed, the situation in the countries of origin is the most important challenge for resolving the refugee crisis. Not everything is rosy, it must also be admitted that we have also made mistakes, that we have also failed. For example, the cuts to the World Food Program were instrumental in the rapid increase in the number of refugees last summer.  However, support measures in the countries of origin are not only important out of self-interest: they help countries such as Lebanon and Jordan. Anyone who has ever been to these countries and visited these camps will agree with me: it is great what is being done in these countries, how the people are prepared to share the little with the refugees. When a country like Jordan, which is suffering from water shortages, hosts more than 600 000 additional people. We must support these efforts, with money, with more money and with the establishment of self-government structures, such as in Zaatari. We need these structures, where people can take matters into their own hands, educate their children in schools and become economically active. However, we should also go a step further and consider whether we should not continue systematically, as the Americans in Europe did with the Marshall Plan, for example, after 1945. We should consider whether we should not develop a Schuman plan for these countries.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – Exactly one year ago I started measuring the situation myself in the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan. It must be said that the establishment and management of that camp by the UN refugee agency UNHCR deserves praise. Where does it look now that these camps are deflating? Why are these families getting to Europe in rickety boats? The answer is that there are not enough resources and that makes itself felt very concrete. For example, food rations have been very low for some time. What does a starving family do that can't get a work permit there? Flee, or marry off their daughters at a young age and send their sons out to beg.  Europe must not wave the moral finger and keep its borders open. Europe must contribute to the reception in the region with adequate resources for the refugee camps. The fact that we still have to repeat this years after the outbreak of the war in Syria makes me despondent. The fact that private organisations have to provide assistance to people and children with disabilities with their own resources is angering me.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Madam President, the money that the EU granted to Lebanon and Jordan was simply a bribe to stop more people coming to the EU as Brussels tried to deal with a migrant crisis which is bringing this place to its knees. Over the winter, refugees in camps in Lebanon had to burn toxic plastic because they had no firewood, yet give the EU a big stage to announce its benevolence and it finds billions to give away. The real reason it is so generous to these countries taking in refugees is because if they follow the other millions crossing the border into Greece, the project would collapse. The Commission has decided it is better instead to use taxpayers’ money to keep these people in camps, some of which are run by Daesh, whilst economic migrants flood the EU’s external borders – most making their way to richer countries like Germany, Sweden and the UK. The EU is taking control of our immigration and asylum policy and is fining countries a quarter of a million pounds per refugee they refuse to take in, and the people have had enough. We can see that in the polls ahead of the UK referendum and in the increasingly desperate stories being pumped out by Project Fear, including disgraceful claims that if we leave this political union we will be plunged into a third world war. It is British lives which brought Europe out of tyranny and NATO which kept the peace, not the EU – just as the EU will have no impact in dealing with the Syrian war.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, Lebanon and Jordan are two of the Countries of the Middle East which in total host 1.7 million refugees from Syria, alongside the refugees they host from Palestine and Iraq. The aid to be given to these countries by the European Union must be important in order to be able to deal with a humanitarian crisis that has arisen as a result of the civil war in Syria. But the problem is not only economic; it focuses mainly on the possibility of destabilising these two countries because of the side effects of having large numbers of migrants in them. For this reason, the aid to be given there must be given on a pragmatic basis in order to avoid the mistakes made in the case of Greece. Because, as you all know, the wrong way in which the European Union has handled the issue of refugees and migrants in Greece has already created many problems and risks turning that country into a concentration camp for unhappy human beings. That is why, in the aid given to Lebanon and Jordan, mistakes must be avoided because today, in the case of Greece, we depend on Turkey's goodwill - whether it blackmails us or not - and on the goodwill of some Member States, whether they will ultimately agree with the percentage of migrants they have to accept or whether they will close their borders.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Madam Vice-President, first of all, I thank High Representative Mogherini for her very substanual presentation on EU assistance to Lebanon and Jordan in dealing with the consequences of the Syrian crisis. Europe and other countries neighbouring Syria are facing their biggest refugee crisis since the end of World War II. Our response to this challenge must be a European and holistic approach based on the principle of solidarity towards people fleeing war threat, but also thanks and support to countries such as Lebanon and Jordan that have borne the greatest burden in caring for refugees in this war-ravaged part of the world. I welcome the EU's efforts, especially those carried out to protect and protect civilians, especially children, as we have had the opportunity to hear. Commitments at the London Conference are important, as well as the preparation of compacts for Lebanon and Jordan that should provide employment and economic opportunities for the benefit of host countries and Syrian refugees. This is an additional value on the already allocated financial support of EUR 1 billion for Jordan and more than EUR 770 million for Lebanon. It is important that we strive to support international efforts to address the causes of migration, including the implementation of the Security Council resolution on Syria, the Agreement in Munich on the Cessation of Hostilities, the humanitarian approach and the resumption of talks on the political transition, as well as the efforts of Special Representative Staffan de Mistura.  The EU's visibility in tackling the Syrian crisis is essential, especially in the context of the impending conquest of our new global strategy on foreign and security policy.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, I would like to stress one aspect in particular, thanking you for the speech you have made here and for the passion and intelligence with which you wanted, through your speech, to take up the general appeal of this Parliament. I believe that we must place particular emphasis on one aspect: the Syrian tragedy has a huge impact in economic terms and in social and civil terms both in Lebanon and in Jordan.  The latest figures from some international institutes tell us, for example, that the youth unemployment rate in Jordan has risen from 19 % to 35-39 %. In Lebanon, the collapse in GDP growth – Lebanon is a country that has grown at a very high rate over the last ten years – and the increase in demand for primary public services could generate an estimated loss of around $7.5 billion. So this is not only a dramatic crisis from the point of view of reception, but we are facing a dramatic crisis which calls into question the very existence of the two individual States, from an economic and social point of view. That is why two guidelines are fundamental: on the one hand, to have coordination on resources, to have clarity and transparency on the impact of our policies, our choices. Those suggestions that have come from other Members go in the right direction, if not even imagine a real extraordinary plan of Europe towards what you have called our region. And secondly, what I insist on most is this extraordinary plan for education and training. 1 700 000 children and adolescents aged between 5 and 17 live in refugee camps or are victims of the Syrian tragedy. We owe them an extraordinary plan of training, education and opportunities to approach new work. Well, I think these are the choices that stand before us.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, Lebanon and Jordan are home to more than 1.7 million refugees from Syria, or about 20% of the population of the two countries combined. We must recognise this effort and continue to support it. We have already contributed more than EUR 1 billion in financial assistance and this money is vital for Lebanon and Jordan to be able to manage the refugee crisis. The two countries can provide Syrian refugees with a secure life close to their home country. It also decreases the desire to embark on risky trips at sea.  I support the Union's initiative to provide EUR 350 million for the education of refugee Syrian children. This money helped Lebanon and Jordan enroll about 140,000 Syrian children in public schools. It saves some of the generation of Syrian children, of course, not all.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, Jordan and Lebanon have been humane and responsible in their approach to the refugee crisis. In total, the two countries have taken in more than four million refugees, more than a third of their total population. Let us also recall the lands of the Visegrad Four. It is a group of countries that often remembers its Judeo-Christian civilization and the principles of humanism and has its experience with the emigration of people from the communist totalitarian era. The Visegrad Four countries also have several times higher gross national product than Lebanon and Jordan. Together, we have more than sixty million inhabitants. Yet the Visegrad Four has so far accepted only about 1,000 refugees.  Mr Kaczynski recently said he would not accept a single refugee for security reasons. The European Commission recently came up with a proposal that makes a significant effort to ensure proper protection of the European Union's external borders and thus security within an area without internal borders. The proposal to set up a European Border Guard is now being debated here in the European Parliament. I hope that the Faction of the European Conservatives and Reformists, of which members of the Law and Justice party are part, will support this proposal in order to ensure the security they argue. Jordan and Lebanon deserve not only our recognition, but also continued financial support under the European Union Regional Fund. The least we can do is make it easier for those who save lives instead of us.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the High Representative for all she is doing. Syrian refugees now make up almost 20% of the combined population of Lebanon and Jordan. To put things in perspective, this is equivalent to the EU taking in over 100 million refugees. The EU has significantly stepped up assistance, becoming the leading donor with over EUR 4.7 billion spent. However, no amount of aid is going to help Lebanon and Jordan accommodate the immense number of Syrian refugees. We must end the Syrian conflict so that refugees can eventually return home. Otherwise, the EU will have to engage in greater burden sharing – financially, but also in taking in more Syrian refugees. Meanwhile, we must work with these countries to address legal frameworks pertaining to their treatment of refugees. Madam High Representative, are you planning to raise the question of employment laws for refugees, given that there is strong evidence that many Syrian refugees – including women and children – are exploited in the workplace?

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today's debate is proof that when we are really talking about war exile, we can talk calmly. We know that Lebanon and Jordan are countries that have been experiencing mass exile for many months, for more than a year, who have simply crossed the border from war-torn Syria and Iraq. If we were then to react from the outset to what is happening there, instead of making declarations such as President Juncker's declarations on the future legalisation of illegal immigration, firstly we would send out a signal that aid can be provided where we are actually dealing with war exile. Secondly, we would not create an impulse that encouraged hundreds of thousands of people to make bad life decisions. It is worth thinking about this example. Of course, it is indisputable that those countries that bear such a heavy burden must be helped, but let us not mix these issues with attacks on countries that simply soberly think about organised illegal immigration.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I agree with Mrs Mogherini that we should see this Middle East region as our region, all in the context of the EU. In any case, Jordan and Lebanon should also be commended, but also your efforts, Mrs Mogherini, which you have made to keep humanitarian aid at an enviable level. We appreciate everything you do: €6 billion is not small money invested by the EU as the largest donor, but I also agree with you that every refugee in this area has their first and last name and that we really need to look at them all that way. Likewise, when we compare the numbers, namely Turkey, which has taken in 2 million refugees and Lebanon and Jordan who have received 5 million of them, then we really need to imagine ourselves, with all those Iraqis and Palestinians that these countries have received so far.  In any case we need to have a unified approach, strengthen defence capabilities and I agree with those who say that we cannot only act humanitarianly - we must also seek a political solution. I'm sure you look at it the same way. In any case, the EU needs to be at the forefront and we cannot leave it to the US and Russia to address this issue, which is difficult and I know that there is no easy answer to it, but that is what we all need to work on together.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, at a time when the Member States of the European Union are unable to reach an agreement on the relocation of some thousands of refugees to their countries by not showing the necessary solidarity, and at the same time as Erdogan is blackmailing Europe in the worst possible way, Lebanon and Jordan have turned into tanks of millions of refugees ready to explode. For example, around one million Syrians have taken refuge in Lebanon, making up a quarter of the population. Lebanon and Jordan are two countries with a refugee culture. Lebanon is already home to 500,000 Palestinians and another one million to Jordan, all victims of the Israeli-Palestinian conflicts of the past, and now they have to manage but 2.5 million Syrians. But can they afford such a burden without being financially destabilised and for how long? Lebanon's prime minister said his country has so far spent a third of its GDP on refugees, while Jordan's king said that in order for his country, which implements an IMF austerity programme, to meet the needs of refugees it needs 2.5 billion euros. The amount of the aid was EUR 1 million per The need for European aid to Lebanon and Jordan is urgent and urgent. Apart from the humanitarian side, however, aid must aim to prevent the destabilisation of these countries by eliminating the root causes of the refugee waves.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, as my colleague Afzal Khan said and the previous speaker just said, Jordan and Lebanon’s handling of the refugee crisis should put us in Europe to shame. Our inability to cope with one million refugees really should make us worry and be humbled compared to what the Lebanese and the Jordanians have been able to do. I do not know Lebanon very well, but I know Jordan quite well. Jordan has, over the years, taken in Palestinian refugees and refugees from the Iraqi war. They have not, by and large, put these people in camps, but have welcomed them and integrated them into their society and made them part of the Jordanian economy. The Syrian crisis, however, has put an almost unmanageable strain on that country. I applaud the Commission’s response to the crisis in both these countries. I hope that, when more resources become available, we will be able to put more money into the area, but we also need to look at our trade policy and other policies to see how we can help Jordan. They are not blessed with the natural resources of their neighbours, so we should be looking at how we can, for example, change our rules of origin to help them trade more with us to create jobs inside the country and tackle the very severe unemployment they face.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Mogherini, thank you very much for your dedicated opening statement and, in particular, your reference to the importance of Jordan for the outstanding solution to the Middle East conflict. Lebanon and Jordan are among our most important and reliable partners in the reception of Syrian war refugees. Lebanon alone has taken in a total of 1.5 million refugees, representing about 30% of its population, compared with 10% in Jordan. Compared to the EU, which has a population of 500 million, it can really be said that Europeans are shying themselves from their responsibilities, which is a disgrace. Lebanon and Jordan urgently need our continued support. At the end of 2015, I looked at the situation on the ground in Lebanon and spoke to many refugees. If we want to ensure stability in these countries and throughout the Middle East region, we must become more united. If Europe does not support these countries with refugee quotas and relieves them in doing so, we must give them maximum support in trade, through humanitarian aid, but also through economic development. Many thanks to the High Representative and her team for their hard work towards a diplomatic solution so that peace can return to Syria. We must work more closely together on the dream of refugees that you have described, that they can return home and rebuild their country with our help.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative Mogherini, first of all, I would like to congratulate you on your action in this area. You show compassion, humanitarian empathy and political courage. Yes, political courage when we hear speeches of shame, hatred and fear on the benches of the far right of our Chamber, when, as was pointed out in this debate, we welcome only less than a tenth of the refugees who are welcomed in Lebanon and Jordan, as you also pointed out earlier. High Representative.  You show empathy and compassion. I was in a camp in lebanon's Bekaa Valley a few weeks ago, and I could see that school children were welcomed and smiled in a particularly difficult context. You are right, we are right: that the European Union should finance refugees who are welcomed with difficulty but, at the same time, courageously in Lebanon or Jordan.  Therefore, it is our duty to support you in your action at the head of European diplomacy on behalf of refugees who are in these countries. To support them is to defend ourselves, we Europeans. Thank you again for your action. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8 of the regulation)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. " What does it have to do with empathy to say ritually over the years that there will be no talks with the Syrian government about peace in a situation where we see houses being demolished, how tens of thousands of people have to flee from there over the years, how people die of starvation in besieged cities? Is it empathy to look at all of this? Really, let's weigh the words.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: "blue card" answer. In 1995, when François Mitterrand, President of the French Republic, last appeared before the European Parliament, he said - and he was right - that "nationalism is war". In the face of these nationalists, in the face of the nationalist discourse we are hearing, we must ensure, together with the European Union and in the case of European diplomacy, that humanitarian solutions are possible that effectively enable the children welcomed in these refugee camps, in Lebanon, Jordan or elsewhere, to find, through our funding, a source of hope. This is what is most important in the action we are taking. What we are doing with Mrs Mogherini is not only courageous, but also humanitarian empathy, and this humanitarian empathy, which nationalists will never be able to develop.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I have just come back from a visit to Jordan, where I attended the recent Women in Parliaments Conference. As the EU has very rightfully provided the lion’s share of humanitarian aid to Jordan and Lebanon, we must be sure that the funding goes to empower women and girls in these communities so that they can take a lead in building up lives in harsh conditions and lay the ground for post—conflict peace building.  The No Lost Generation programme, aiming to provide education to more than half a million Syrian refugee children, is incredibly important. Education must aim to empower young women and girls socially, economically and politically, and address specific gender-based needs such as violence against women and girls.  Jordan has suffered economic losses because of the wars going on around it, with factories closed in the border region and many jobs being lost, yet still it has managed to welcome and house millions of Syrian and Iraqi refugees. The European Union and its national governments bear a grave moral responsibility to provide these refugees with shelter and protection. We must take an example from Jordan and Lebanon and follow suit.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, according to the most recent figures from the UNHCR, the number of Syrian refugees in Jordan and Lebanon exceeds 1.5 million souls. Lebanon in particular, which is a small country with 4.5 million inhabitants, is currently home to more than one million refugees. It is the country with the highest refugee-permanent population ratio in the world. As we all understand, this situation cannot continue for a long time without a major humanitarian crisis. Sooner or later these refugees will find themselves back on the road to escape and many of them will be heading to Greece. The European Union must take all necessary preventive measures to deal with the coming crisis. I have personally long proposed the creation of hot spots in the first host countries for refugees and the organisation of their immediate resettlement in the countries of the European Union. This, of course, requires resources. So instead of spending EUR 6 billion on the project, the European Union is not going to be able to do that. In addition, we must give some of this money to the organisation of refugee camps and hot spots in Jordan and Lebanon.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Dear Mrs Mogherini, you have brought something new into this function. You have shown that you are not ashamed to show emotion and sensitivity and compassion. Indeed, nations in the Middle East show more compassion when it comes to refugees coming from neighboring nations. However, I must say that it would also be right to remember that Europe also knew more solidarity when it came to refugees from Spain, from Germany, from the Czech Republic, bosnia and Herzegovina, from different countries. In short, we were accepting those who were like us.  However, we have a problem when it comes to recognising diversity, multiculturalism, different religions, different values. We know this world only as a place of exoduation of our values, our democracy and so on.  Mrs Mogherini, I would ask you – even when it comes to problem solving, political problems – to show the same sensitivity and equal will and the same energy. I'm sure you will get support in this House, and it's all the more important to point out at a moment when we are being suggested – let's see the American elections – leaders who can enter the world more unrest than constructiveness.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, the European policy of providing support to Jordan and Lebanon on the one hand, and Turkey on the other, is completely wrong. Refugee numbers have already been reported in Lebanon, Jordan and, respectively, Turkey. Financial aid, of course, to Lebanon and Jordan and Iraq together amounts to EUR 350 million, as opposed to aid to Turkey amounting to EUR 6 billion. In Lebanon, refugees go through thorough checks and are given a residence card or deported if they do not meet the criteria. To renew the card they pay $100 or must guarantee a Lebanese citizen. In Jordan, refugees have access to the labour market, but if the work is claimed by a Jordanian and a refugee at the same time, the job is taken over by the country's national. In the Europe of diversity and open borders, all this seems racist. But it is democratic for the European Union to pay these sums to Turkey, which, along with Saudi Arabia and Qatar, created ISIS, drowns innocent souls in the Aegean, trades in oil and stolen ancients with the Daesh. For Greeks, in the evil he hears in the name "Turkey of Erdogan and Muslim Sunni extremism" there is a solution. Imposing an embargo, stopping all funding and ending its accession process to the European Union.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank you all for what seems to me to be an uncontroversial – or almost uncontroversial – field of support, reminding ourselves that the debate we had tonight was on the EU assistance to two countries to face the effects of the Syrian crisis. We have had – and I am sure we will have at other times – a debate on our political work on solving the Syrian crisis, which is a different debate – obviously linked, but a different one. I would love to discuss the recent developments with you. Some of you mentioned this in two different ways, some saying that a political solution is not on the horizon and others saying that it is already solved. As very often happens, probably the truth is somewhere in between. I am not completely negative about the fact that we might come to some sort of political transition in Syria in the coming months. We are working hard on this and believe me when I tell you again – we were together with John Kerry and others yesterday – the European Union is not only helping to assist in managing the effects of the Syrian crisis, but also playing a major role in the political work to find a solution to the Syrian crisis, but this is not the debate we are having tonight. Again, I would welcome another debate specifically on this in one of the next sessions. Let me come to some of the issues you raised during the debate. One: some of you mentioned something that I believe is critical and crucial. This debate is about us supporting Jordan and Lebanon, not only because of their hosting of Syrian refugees, but also because of their crucial importance and the importance that we attach to their economic, social and security resilience. Let me also be frank – as, you will know by now, I always am – I find it unacceptably cynical whenever we discuss our support for these countries just because we do not want refugees to come to Europe. To me this is completely unacceptable from a moral point of view. Let me also add that it is somehow striking that sometimes the same narrative of those who want to protect our identity – including the purity of our background, be it on a religious or cultural basis – do not listen to the words of Pope Francis, which tell us that this is what we have to do: protect people’s lives, make sure that our European approach to asylum is up to the values that we have in our foundations. I am not a Catholic myself, but being an Italian and a Roman, I can tell you that I have learnt in in my years of life something very basic. If you are a Catholic, if you are a Christian, you cannot pick and choose the words of the Pope that you like the most and ignore the others. This is not sustainable. Sorry, that came from my heart, because last week in the Vatican we had a very moving – and also very politically relevant – event where the Charlemagne Prize was presented to Pope Francis, and I think we had some lessons for Europe there as well. Coming to politics, I will quickly answer some of the questions you have mentioned. Regarding special arrangements for Jordan on the rules of origin, I told you in the beginning, in my opening remarks, that we are working on that. We will need all your support to make sure that this happens in a coherent way, which means that it would be good, when we come to the decisions, to be supported in translating our political will into concrete acts. I believe this can be a real game—changer for the Jordanian economy and the hosting communities because, in this way, we could create jobs both for Syrian refugees and for Jordanians, thus preventing a major social problem in the country and also an economic one.  The same goes for the budget. I took note of what Elmar Brok mentioned at the beginning of our debate – and I will remember it when we come to a debate on our budget – namely that we might work together on increasing the level of the budget we have for our external action in general and, in particular, for some of these aspects. We have now, as I mentioned, invested EUR 6 billion so far. This also means that, for instance, the World Food Programme, which I met just a few weeks ago, is now financed until the end of the year, which is something that has never happened before. This is thanks to European Union support. But I would like to mention not only the money we spend, but also the effects that we bring with this money. I understand that you all visited the camps, so you have seen some of the projects we fund, some of the children that go to school thanks to our funding, and some of the health and education facilities we support. I would like to mention some figures because, again, these translate into concrete action. With our funds, we support the enrolment in public schools of more than 112 000 Syrian child refugees. We have rehabilitated 35 public schools – and I visited one of them. Every school obviously hosts many children, allowing education, because we also need to focus on preventing radicalisation in the future, and we risk having a lost generation there, which is also an investment in our security and the stability of the region. We are guaranteeing psychosocial support for 8 000 children and you can imagine how key this is for the future of the region and the country. We are supporting immunisation for 310 000 Syrian and vulnerable Lebanese children. I could continue. I understand very well, as I am a politician myself, that you do not need only to tell your constituencies how much money was spent but what it brings, and this is what it brings, which again is a moral duty. In my opinion, it is a humanitarian duty but also an investment in our own security and stability. Here again, when it comes to the budget, I count on your support to translate our common position in words into something concrete. Let me close on one last point that also concerns money, namely the London pledges. Some of you mentioned the fact that we pledged a lot in London and that the money is not there. It is there. There is one thing on which you can always be sure: when the European Union pledges money, this translates immediately into projects funded. This is true for Lebanon and Jordan and is true for other projects on the humanitarian, and also on the development, level. This is true for instance – and this reflects a link with one of the debates to follow, because I love night sessions in Parliament and I never finish before midnight so we have another two! – on the pledges we made in Cairo for Gaza, where you can be sure the European Union pledges all translated into financing. So when we pledge, the money is there and the projects we have started to finance out of those pledges are already there. I and my team are ready to provide you with all the details about all the projects that are already in place. This allows us also to say to our partners in the region and in the world that we are doing our part, please do yours. Here I would call for you to help me in reaching out to parliaments all over the world and asking them also to do their part in what is a humanitarian duty that we all collectively share. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Lebanon and Jordan are an example for Europe and for the entire international community of peaceful coexistence between various nationalities and religions in a conflicted region, such as the Middle East. I therefore support the close collaboration between the EU and these two states - Europe's strategic partners in resolving the crisis in Syria, as well as in the Middle East peace process. The EU must strengthen its relations with Lebanon and Jordan, in particular by providing financial aid for the effective management of the Syrian refugee crisis it faces, with these two countries providing asylum to around 1.7 million refugees in Syria. I welcome the aid already granted to Lebanon and Jordan, with the EU being the main donor to the Middle East, with around EUR 6 billion mobilised so far by the European institutions and the Member States.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I fully agree with the speech by The High Representative Federica Mogherini: the European Union's financial support to Lebanon and Jordan, in order to manage the Syrian refugee crisis, is an important and necessary investment, I would say indispensable, not only to help these two countries to deal with a humanitarian emergency of unprecedented proportions, but also to ensure a certain security and stability in Europe. Recently I had the opportunity to meet the Maronite Bishop of Lebanon, Patriarch Béchara Boutros Rai who, in an interesting speech, told how the two religions, Muslim and Christian, live peacefully in Lebanon and how it is important that in Europe we realize the need to help Syrian refugees regain their dignity, a home and a decent life , not only by hosting them within Europe's borders, but also by helping them to return home, in a situation of peace and well-being. Let us remember that Lebanon is taking in one million refugees, out of a population of 4 million, and in the meantime, together with Jordan, it must also face up to its own fight against Daesh terrorism, which is trying in every way to destabilise an already fragile situation.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – What is happening in Lebanon and Jordan borders on a humanitarian catastrophe. It does not surprise me that 65% of registered Syrian refugees are under the age of 25.  At the same time, Lebanon and Jordan have maximized the ability of Syrian refugees to study and work legally, forcing them to rely solely on humanitarian aid and black work. It is for this reason that the lives of Syrian refugees in Lebanon and Jordan are a real disaster and only with the delivery of humanitarian aid will it not improve.  I am of the opinion that the European Union must stop being only a donor of humanitarian aid and cooperate with refugee countries to find ways to improve their lives. If this does not happen, I fear that a large number of people who have fled to Lebanon and Jordan will be looking for ways to move to Western Europe.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: in writing. – The highest burden in coping with the wave of refugees falls upon the neighbouring countries of the conflict areas. Among these countries, the most difficult situation is faced by Lebanon and Jordan. Turkey is not the only country that is in difficulty. If we consider the population of Lebanon, of just 5.8 million people, the 1.2 million refugees it is hosting is a bigger burden than any other similar situation in the world. This means six times more refugees than Turkey and 15 times more than Germany. I must remind European leaders of the clear and very concrete proposals regarding the support EU can offer to Lebanon which we received from Mr Nabih Berri, the Speaker of the Parliament of Lebanon, during his recent visit to the European Parliament. Similar proposals were also forwarded to the EU by the Jordanian authorities. The European Union has a clear and direct interest in helping Lebanon and Jordan deal with this situation. It is in no one’s interests to just sit and watch how these countries are bowing under the pressure of the wave of refugees. Such a possible grim future is also a threat to Europe’s security, and it must be addressed before it is too late.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – It should be borne in mind that refugees in Lebanon and Jordan are, above all, war refugees. People who want to return to their homeland and build their lives there, not move on to live in Europe. In order to be able to wait in neighbouring Syria until the war is over and to go home again, they must be provided with basic life conditions such as the possibility for children to attend school, the possibility of working for adults and medical care. Here, the EU can make a significant contribution, both financially and directly, through various UN aid organisations and with human resources.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2016/2699(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the political and economic situation in Venezuela is becoming more difficult by the day. Two months ago we were discussing this and other issues relating to Latin America together in the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and I agreed at that time with many of you that only dialogue and cooperation among institutions could end the crisis and serve the real interests of the citizens of Venezuela. Since then, only two months, we have seen how badly the current political situation is impacting on the social and economic picture of the country.  Venezuela is a country with rich human and natural resources. It has the potential to be among the leading nations in Latin America and in spite of that, the people of Venezuela are suffering from violence, a world record in daily murders and random kidnappings. They are suffering permanent shortages of food, basic goods, most medicines and medical care. Water is scarce and no longer guarantees the former sanitary standards. Even electricity is subject to frequent rationing while Venezuela is, as we all know, the fifth largest exporter of petroleum in the world. Inflation rates are among the highest in the world. The economy is contracting at an impressive pace. Beyond the economic situation we are all aware, and I know how important this is for this Chamber, of the restrictions on civil liberties, the media situation, the situation of many of the opposition leaders, some of them in prison awaiting trial. Our institutions, and I personally, have regularly highlighted the violations of fundamental freedoms and urged respect for due process of law.  A country faced with so many challenges needs first and foremost functioning institutions at the service of their people. As you know, the clash between the government and the parliament is blocking any serious attempt to tackle the crisis and address the citizens’ needs; and the stalemates cannot curb violence or slow down the inflation. These are the solutions the voters asked for, and these are the solutions that the people of Venezuela need. The European Union is obviously distant geographically, but not politically. We are not a distant observer. On the contrary, hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans hold a European passport as dual nationals. Many European companies which have invested in the country, generating jobs and growth, although they struggle to hold on in the current situation are there. Many are owed large debts by the States. I also want to add that we have an interest in avoiding a spillover of tensions into neighbouring countries and here I immediately think of Colombia, which could soon come out of a long painful conflict; it really does not need a destabilised country on its border.  So the question is how can we help Venezuela and its citizens? Parliament’s three resolutions adopted since spring 2014 emphasised that the crisis can only be overcome by peaceful and constructive dialogue in full respect of human rights and the Venezuelan Constitution. This is not about interfering in Venezuela’s domestic affairs, but we have a duty to offer our Venezuelan friends all the help they might need and want towards a peaceful solution of the crisis. We do so as friends. We want to see Venezuela thrive again. I really hope that the country’s leaders will accept a helping, friendly hand, because in extraordinary times like these, it would be only natural and normal to do so. We have been discussing the situation in the country with many international and regional partners, from the UN to the Organization of American States to UNASUR, with neighbouring countries, with Vatican diplomacy, and the message we are all passing on is that both the government and the parliament should move towards a more cooperative attitude. Whatever the solution to the crisis will be, the people of Venezuela need their institutions to address the security situation and to put the economy back on track.  This goes beyond ideologies and political systems. This is about serving the people of Venezuela, the only source of legitimacy of all elected institutions in the country. With no dialogue at all among different forces, the situation can only get worse. This is something that no one can afford either inside or outside of the country. Neither the majority, nor the opposition government nor parliament. The people of Venezuela are calling for action, all of them, regardless of their political views. They deserve a country that can guarantee them a normal life. And political leaders, all of them, have a duty to answer their call. We, at the level of the European Union, are always ready to support, and I am sure that this Parliament will support our efforts in this respect. And on this particular issue let me tell you that I look forward to listening to your comments and views because this is one of the issues where parliaments can help the most.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, in December, when I was an observer in the elections in Venezuela, the Government threatened to expel me because I said I found a country on the brink of the humanitarian crisis. Since then, the food crisis, the medical crisis and the energy crisis have added to the political crisis and the economic crisis. Today a Venezuelan worker needs eighteen times the minimum wage to make the purchase for a week. In supermarkets it is impossible to find the essentials, such as milk powder, such as PAN flour, as diapers. Venezuela's citizens have to endure six-, seven- or eight-hour queues in order to get to a place where they sell something, with the question of whether there will be anything left to sell or whether they will have enough money to buy it. 80% of medicines and 50% of doctors are missing from hospitals. Because half of the doctors have left Venezuela and those who are still practicing there are doing so in conditions of war, without having the necessary to be able to care for patients. And this in a country that was rich. This in a country that had a phone before Spain had it, which had electricity before it was held by Spain, which had heating and air conditioning before Spain had them, which had cars before Spain had them. Other times, in this House, we have asked them for freedom, dignity, human rights for some country, even for Venezuela. Today we come here to ask for something different: in addition to freedom and freedom for political prisoners, bread and medicine. Even the Catholic Church is not allowed to distribute food in Venezuela today. We are on the brink of a social crisis and we have to do everything we can to prevent it. Venezuela inevitably walks towards disaster and in our hands it is that it does not happen. Every year 25,000 people die as a result of street violence and the narcogenerals have taken over the situation. It's up to us, Mrs. Mogherini. He has our support for playing a role in Venezuela. (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I add to your prudence, Mrs Mogherini. I believe that, indeed, in Venezuela we are in a very delicate and very serious time. Everything you have described I share, but we have two institutions, both with a legitimate source of power: Parliament, on the one hand — last year's December elections - and the Government with its President, which also comes from a legitimate election by the Venezuelan people. And the two institutions don't collaborate. Here's the problem.  Unfortunately, political war is taking time. Both of you. I don't know if I'm the one to judge who has the responsibility. My view is that it is true that Venezuela lacks freedoms and it is true that the powers of the House under the sovereign mandate given to it by the people last December are probably not being respected. This is very likely to be the case, but the political question is what does Europe do? What do we do to help the Venezuelan people who cannot continue in this situation? And my answer is, like yours, to help ensure that there is a political agreement between Government and Parliament, between Presidency and Assembly, so that they can solve the problems of Venezuelans, and they must understand each other, respect the powers and agree on emergency economic solutions. That's my proposal. If not, they're doomed to an election that no one wants right now. That's my opinion, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, following nearly two decades of reform, a programme of investment and infrastructure, the establishment of a sustainable social security system and the development of a sovereign wealth fund, the economy continues to grow. This is the story that Venezuela should have been able to boast about, but unfortunately the reality today is dramatically different. As supermarket shelves lie empty, a two-day week for the public sector workers has been imposed to conserve energy and government hand-outs grind to a halt, the situation in Venezuela is dire. In this respect, Venezuela has become a poster child for the populist, corrupt, crony, socialist ideology of Mr Chávez. Hugo Chávez’s mix of government giveaways and bloating of the public sector in a bid to cling to power for nearly two decades, whilst enriching himself and those around him, has clearly been an unmitigated disaster for that South American country.  Today, we catch on as a successor Maduro seeks to build on that legacy, only this time lacking both the oil market high prices and the charisma. As is only inevitable, economic crises are leading to political crisis, and with increasing calls now for Maduro to go, the country appears to be heading in a disastrous direction. Only this week, we saw the assassination of the opposition UNT leader German Mavare. As this all unfolds, it is difficult not to look at neighbouring Colombia and reflect on the economic and security achievements of that democracy, seen there without the high oil price advantages afforded to Venezuela. It is now time for a new democratic model for Venezuela and a new approach. Venezuela deserves better than the ghastly Chávez legacy.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, every day that passes there are more political prisoners in Venezuela's prisons, there are more violent deaths on the streets, more shortages in pharmacies and supermarkets, more shortages of water and electricity. Mrs Mogherini, Venezuela is in a multiorgan ruling. And President Maduro's response to this crisis cannot be for officials to work only two days a week or for women not to use hair dryers. By vetoing the Amnesty and National Reconciliation Act and trying to prevent the revoking referendum called by the opposition, the Government of Venezuela is preventing an orderly exit to a comprehensive crisis. And Venezuela can't wait any longer. Certainly, from Europe we must continue to demand the release of all political prisoners, respect for constitutional order and the will for democratic change expressed by Venezuelans. But above all, Mrs Mogherini, it is imperative that the Government of Venezuela request international humanitarian aid that it is reluctant to ask for: basic supplies, food, medicines. I ask you from here that the European Union intercede to give Venezuelans a chance.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this is the eighth action against Venezuela. Look, I came to Parliament during the terrible bombings against Gaza: five hundred minors killed; there was no resolution. Nor were there in coups or dozens of journalists killed in Latin America, because many who are here only accept democracy when they win their own. I checked in December, Mr. Pons. In a second, Venezuela's electoral power went from fraudulent to reliable when they won their own. The legislature was sought to be above an elected presidency with the same legitimacy. And now they're trying to violate the legal deadlines of the possible revocation. I am ashamed of the role of the European Union with a country which today chairs Unasur, which is a member of the Security Council and which in July will preside over Mercosur. The European Union prefers to take on obscure destabilizing agendas rather than defending the democratic institutionality threatened today in Brazil and Venezuela. Leave Venezuela alone, stop grafting on Venezuela's affairs.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, Venezuela, who are a sister people, it is true that you are living in a difficult situation, a climate of violence, a crisis and a high polarisation. Following the opposition's election victory in a free election held a few months ago, the climate of tension does not cease, and it is true and we must recognize that situation. But I believe that what is very important is that we join our voices, and my group joins yours, with calls from both UNASUR and CELAC, including the Pope, to give a boost to dialogue, recognition and reconciliation of the parties so that a certain institutional and constitutional normality can be resumed. And the European Union must work together on that, Madam High Representative. I do not believe that we, as has been done and have done many countries of the European Union many times, have to interfere, supporting certain political options in the country, but play a constructive partner role, because the most important thing, Madam High Representative, is that we help Venezuelans and Venezuelans to decide their own future.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, I believe that the dramatic situation in which Venezuelans find themselves is evidence of an absolute failure of the Chavist experience. I'm sorry about the far left but, unfortunately, that's the way it is. We see all the signs of this absolute disaster with widespread corruption, compounded by the explosion of crime and the decline in freedoms, as our liberal colleague mentioned, and, of course, Maduro's conspiracy delusions.  In this context, I do not understand how our Socialist colleague can aspire to a dialogue between the opposition and the President. Could we establish a dialogue with someone who sees only the conspiracies that stand in his way? Our position must be very clear: we must put pressure on the president. There are two million Venezuelans who have called for a referendum, I think we need to be very clear on this subject. I also regret the fact that last year, when our political group, the EPP Group, proposed the support, by the Sakharov Prize, of the Venezuelan opposition, precisely because of this brotherhood of the extreme left and friends of the extreme left, we continued to support someone very similar to the most troublesome autocrats.  In my view, the position must be very clear so as not to cast doubt on our democratic commitment.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, Ms Mogherini, Venezuela is living in a truly tragic situation from a political point of view, from an economic and social point of view. It is true that the changes in the international economy, in particular the fall in the price of oil and some natural tragedies, some natural disasters, have contributed somewhat to this.  But we cannot fail to see that all this results from the failure of a particular model of political organisation and a certain model of economic and social development. In fact, Venezuela is faced with the failure of the options that have been made over the past few years. And, here, of course, we must clearly see all that has been going on there in terms of disrespect for fundamental freedoms and of being trampled on by the democratic rule of law.  It is not enough to hold elections to ensure the prevalence of a democratic rule of law, as we know. Democracy is not reduced to that. Now, here, the truth is that there is now a conflict between two powers: a presidential power and a legislative power. And while there is no absolute balance in terms of the allocation of responsibilities — it would be wrong, in my view, to do so — the truth is that the call to dialogue that has already been made here, and which in a way was part of the intervention that Mrs Mogherini made at the opening, seems to me to be a sensible appeal. There will be no solution - given the state of polarization that has reached Venezuelan society - there will be no peaceful solution if there is no investment in this same dialogue and, from this perspective, this appeal makes perfect sense.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, after two Resolutions of the European Parliament in the last two years, the situation in Venezuela has not only not improved but worsened. Solutions can only be found to emerge from the crisis that Venezuela is in today through dialogue. Therefore, there cannot be a single political prisoner. The first step in initiating this crucial dialogue is to pass the Amnesty Act.  I am very concerned about the situation of the Venezuelan people. There is a serious humanitarian crisis and people are suffering. I again ask the High Representative to promote more action by the European Union to deal with this crisis and, above all, to help the Venezuelan people.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the most reactionary and factional forces recover the lie and the worst mechanisms to disrupt Latin America, remembering Chile and Pinochet — unacceptable and criminal interference practices that we reject. American imperialism, European neocolonial stigma, and monopolistic oligarchies do not forgive the Venezuelan people, who for 18 years have affirmed a willingness to break with a past of exploitation, impoverishment, and neoliberal policies.  The will to build a future based on economic development that privileges the people and not the submission to the interests of foreign capital, a future based on social policies that are now unquestionable, public control of strategic sectors, free access to health and education, the fight against poverty and the valorization of workers' rights and wages : arguments that hurt the ears of those who advocate policies of austerity, impoverishment and neocolonial exploitation of third countries.  Be deceived those who already rub their hands: the sovereign will of the peoples and the struggle for righteous ideals will win. This will be the case in Venezuela.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Mr President; thank you for your presence and for your words, Mrs. Mogherini. Look, Mrs Mogherini, the last time I spoke in this House about the situation in Venezuela, I advocated an amnesty law and then for the dialogue and reconciliation between an opposition that won the Assembly outright and a Presidency of the Republic that barricades itself in Miraflores. What's happened since then? For, in the face of the call to dialogue, the Bolivarian regime sends thugs to beat the Secretary-General of the MUD, Mr. Torrealba, in a cowardly manner; that political prisoners are still in the dungeons and new cases are opened up against them and against the students, who are wanted to be criminalized; that the amnesty law is rejected by a judiciary that lacks all independence and equanimity; and that the Venezuelan people see their calamities increase and that their shortcomings are bordering on a humanitarian emergency. And in this situation, what to do? The opposition has initiated a collection of signatures for a revocation referendum process to remove President Maduro from the presidency. The process is constitutional and, although citizens know that verification of their signatures will serve, as was the case in the day, to draw up a blacklist in the totalitarian way of Cuban political commissioners, people are coming to the tables to sign, and in a few days 1,500,000 people have done so. To all this, the claims of freedom for political prisoners, the demands of democracy, President Maduro will call it "interference", deny us legitimacy and insult the President of the Government of Spain again, with the communist applause and complicit silence of his podemite partners.  But this is not the case: Venezuela has all our respect for its sovereignty and the Venezuelan people, our affection, which is not incompatible with us speaking up in defense of the freedoms and human rights that are trampled with impunity. Today I repeat that this Parliament cannot and should not be silent in the face of a limit situation with totalitarian behaviour. Today Venezuela also deserves political criticism of a regime that we cannot endorse because it needs our help. Congratulations, Mrs Mogherini, for your words, for your courage and for your respect.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, in a country that is one of the largest oil producers in the world, many essential services are closed due to a lack of energy. This paradox shows well how there is a strong relationship between democracy, respect for civic and political rights and economic and social sustainability. Venezuela has been the victim of a clear disregard for democratic legitimacy. And this virus, as has been the case elsewhere in the Latin American continent and the world, has contaminated the economy and society and caused scarcity and suffering to the Venezuelan people.  We must therefore reiterate our call for the elected powers in Venezuela to dialogue, respect each other and know how to have the best interests of their people as a priority of action. I greet you, Mrs Mogherini, for the effort you have made in this regard. Political legitimacy in Venezuela must be re-softened, because this is the way to prevent social explosion and political and economic implosion.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam High Representative, after the elections on 6 December, in which I was present as an unofficial observer, we all hoped that Venezuela could regain its place within the democratic nations.  Unfortunately, reality has been in charge of killing that hope.  Venezuelans are now experiencing an unbearable situation from a political, social and economic point of view. From the humanitarian crisis in the food sector, from the health crisis to the energy crisis, there are dark rates of crime and multiple human rights attacks, with the arbitrary detention of political prisoners, many of them in sub-human conditions. Madam High Representative, at this crucial moment in your history, when we are witnessing the beginning of the revocation process and at the very moment when the National Assembly is discussing the rupture of the constitutional order that has taken place in the country, Venezuela needs the firm support of the European Union. Claiming freedom, democracy and respect for human rights in Venezuela is not interference in its internal affairs, as the extreme radical left of this Parliament understands. It is, therefore, our obligation as Democrats. Thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini, for your efforts for the Venezuelan people.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The High Representative was right to say that the situation in Venezuela is very worrying. Rising prices and an unprecedented economic slowdown, and now additional water shortages and power outages, are leading this country into an ever deeper recession – people are suffering. The government in Caracas, which in principle does not seem to be responsible in the many trouble spots in the country, continues to work on blocking parliament, rather than seriously trying to resolve the problems.  Given the miserable, incompetent, and ultimately destructive policy outcomes of socialist governments in recent years, President Maduro and his cabinet are unlikely to be able to overcome the crisis. Once hailed as the hope of the global left, chavism turns out to be a great nightmare for the people of Venezuela.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, we have been bringing to this Parliament for years a 'Enough now! on behalf of millions of Venezuelans. Years in which we have demanded — without success, by the way — that the European Union make more than just statements in protest at Nicolas Maduro's anti-democratic attitude.  Today we say here that we can no longer. Venezuelans who are going hungry and in need in a rich country can no longer, but to which their leaders and corruption are causing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis. Opposition leaders, the one who has clearly won the last election and suffers almost daily intolerable aggression, can no longer be seen. Relatives of political prisoners who remain in prison can no longer, while real criminals, many of them in leading positions, continue to commit their stumbles with complete impunity. And we can no longer democrats in Europe and around the world, who see with horror how the international community continues to do nothing. Mrs Mogherini, we need something done at once and we need it done now. If not, we may have to recognise that we have failed in the objective of making the European Union an internationally important player.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: – Mr President, the political, social and economic situation in Venezuela must concern us all, not only as citizens, but mainly as European politicians. And in fact, Madam High Representative, in Venezuela you live in a real powder keg, which a slightly stronger fuse will blow up.  A councillor from the Portuguese Communities from Venezuela even said two weeks ago in Lisbon, and I quote, "that the situation is unsustainable and our greatest fear at the moment is that we are moving towards civil war. The situation is serious."  In addition to the strong rationing of basic products, civil servants will also work only two days a week, because the Government has decided to ration the power supply — a measure that today has been extended at least until the next day 27. Also concerned about this very serious situation, Pope Francis wrote to Nicolás Maduro last week. The time has therefore come for the European Union to act to ensure the protection of the large expatriate community of European citizens living and working in Venezuela, which includes close to 200,000 registered Portuguese. To finish, Madam High Representative, I ask you to do everything in your power to restore confidence in this country.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini; the people of Venezuela, oppressed, violent, extorted, kidnapped, desisted, frightened, went through one of the biggest crises in their Republican history. Political prisoners, hopeless; democracy, in the hands of dictators; violence, uncontainable; Caracas, the violent city of the world; impunity by 97%; institutional destruction; increased private responses to security and justice; hospitals, unsastrate; basic, limited and scarce foods; the two-day work week; the country of light, without light; currency, worthless; inflation at 700%; free, gagged or fleeing media; justice, biased; legislative legislation, in the hands of the court; flowers and fields abducted by the Federal Court of Manhattan for doing charity work; opposition, manized; neither rules nor laws before the arbitrariness of power: this is the current portrait of my dear Venezuela. May your suffering soon be over. Long live Venezuela free!

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Venezuela’s democracy and economy have reached a perilous state. Recently, about 2 million citizens expressed their will for a referendum to be able to decide the fate of the current president. I think this is a sign of deep dissatisfaction with the political regime, which has deeply divided the country in dire need of reform. After the victory of the united opposition last year, Mr Maduro has used all his powers to block practically every initiative by the new parliament, including the release of political prisoners. It is obvious that President Maduro has no constructive ideas on how to heal the deepening crisis, so the country has reached an explosive impasse. His last recipe was to impose a two-day working week for public servants to save energy. I think he should follow this original solution by a personal example: establish a zero-hour working week for himself, thereby saving the energy of his countrymen and clearing the way for national reconciliation and reforms.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, the situation in Venezuela is really alarming. We have heard the data: inflation of 700%, desupply of basic inputs, the worst energy crisis in the history of Venezuela, in an oil-producing country. But the problem is not only energetic or economic, the problem is fundamentally political; it is erosion, I would say almost the destruction of democratic institutions by the regime of Nicolás Maduro. And obviously the solution is in respect of the rule of law; obviously, in fostering dialogue, but a dialogue that will be productive only if it has a clear objective, and that clear objective may be only one, and it is the reconstruction of a free and democratic Venezuela.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, a few weeks ago we discussed in this House the changes in relations with Cuba; a few moments ago we discussed the unblocking of negotiations with Mercosur, but in Venezuela things are not changing. Maduro's regime continues to ignore what the Venezuelan people asked for at the ballot box and hinders the legal and political channels of opposition expression, and now the National Assembly. That is the rejection of the Amnesty and National Reconciliation Act or the growing obstacles to the revocation process, while the Venezuelan people are living in a very serious economic and social situation already described. The situation is very worrying. In a few hours a debate begins at the National Assembly in Caracas on the breakdown of the constitutional order and the systematic and repeated violation of the Constitution, to the detriment of the interests of the Venezuelan people. This, Mrs Mogherini, is, as you will know, the title of this afternoon's debate. It shows the very tense political climate that Venezuela is living, the result of an authoritarian drift that we have been denouncing for some time from this Parliament. I'm done, President; we must all strive, Mrs. Mogherini. (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Mr President, Venezuela is currently experiencing serious economic and social difficulties. Together with the Venezuelan population, they are going through the same european emigrants, many of them Portuguese and Madeiran.  More than a year ago, Nicolás Maduro adopted severe measures that led to a lack of food in supermarkets. It recently decided to cut back on 4 hours of electricity supply and, extraordinary fact, that civil servants only work on Mondays and Tuesdays, with the argument of saving electricity and water.  In addition to disrespect for the human condition, Venezuela disrespects democracy. Venezuela disrespects foreign direct investment and calls into question trade, free trade. We are also jeopardising the trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur.  We can't be indifferent, Mrs Mogherini, we shouldn't be indifferent. It's a country with which we have enormous affinities. They connect to Venezuela in the bonds of blood and deep friendship. Let us not lower our arms, Europe has to act quickly to... (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, one minute is enough to say loud and clear that the Venezuelan people are abducted by a nefarious ruler who has managed to make a rich country live in poverty; a President who does not recognize that cry of freedom and dignity that spreads throughout Venezuela. Venezuelan society is being mistreated by Maduro, or is it not mistreatment to live without light, without medicine, without food, and, more seriously, without hope, after seeing all the attempts of this brave people to regain their dignity fail?  Today I want to be one more Venezuelan, a mother, a wife, a daughter of any of the political prisoners who beg Europe not to forget them and who continue to demand the release of all those prisoners who are simply for wanting a free Venezuela.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the collapse of Venezuela is imminent, accelerated by falling oil prices and the 'corruptcracy' climbing at all levels. Essential products such as food and medicine, medical care and even energy for civil servants to work are lacking. As the richest country in Latin America, Venezuela is on its way to becoming the poorest, with inflation at 600% and three-quarters of the population living below the poverty line, subject to total violence and insecurity. The European Union and this Parliament, especially with so many binationals among Venezuelans, cannot fail to condemn the sectarian, populist and delusional action of President Maduro, who does not govern, disgoverns Venezuela. Ms Mogherini, let us not waste any more time: it is important that you give the President and the Government of Venezuela the message that, if you have a common sense of a way, you immediately put an end to the persecution and censorship of the media, human rights defenders and opponents of the regime, and to start working on a patriotic understanding with Parliament to save the country and the people from catastrophe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). – The rapid fall in the price of oil has been a cause for Venezuela's fragile economy over the past two years and has brought about a major political crisis. Whatever the outcome of a possible referendum on The Eve of Maduro, the European Union must accept it but also show restraint and objectivity in its judgment. The period of Chavism may be coming to an end, but that does not mean that all those policies that allowed the economic recovery of venezuela's poor inhabitants, which solved the housing problem to millions of people, who gave access to the land to the coastal farmers who nationalized the oil revenues, should be overturned. Policies confronted by domestic mobsters as well as international powers. Unfortunately, the European Union's attitude towards Venezuela has been unilateral all this time. Today, the European Union must let the Venezuelan people set their own independent course in the difficult period ahead.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Today, the impression of Venezuela as a country in poverty, in staruzing, in fact a country facing a humanitarian crisis, a country that is almost in a state of war, is being created here. But the information we're getting is also different. We would therefore also like to hear here in Parliament the representatives of Venezuela, who should therefore say what is really going on there. Why are socialist countries getting so nervous? Maybe it's because there's no such differentiation between the poor and the rich, because education, health care is not yet privatized. They used to be so thundery about socialist Yugoslavia, but the truth was completely different. Maybe that's why she had to be taken down. But Venezuela is a sovereign country that is no longer a colony. I think we need to let the Venezuelan people decide what country they want to live in. That's why he's got an election. It is for us, of course, to monitor – may – whether this election is fair and fair.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will be very brief because I believe that our debate has touched on all the aspects of the work that needs to be done. I will, however, concentrate on one key element for which I will need your help: to try to guarantee that the country can go towards a normal institutional setting, as one of you said.  Many of you mentioned the need to encourage dialogue in the framework of the respect of the will of the people, which is the source of legitimacy for any of the institutions of the country. This will mean encouraging and continuously calling on all actors to engage in a constructive dialogue among institutions and, on our side, standing ready to support in any possible useful way. I believe this is – and I see this as a common situation, a common analysis among us – as the best possible way, in connection and in coordination with regional and international actors, to address the difficult internal situation of the country, both from the political perspective and from an economic and security situation. Again, I would stress that the only way forward is overcoming institutional confrontation and finding ways to serve the citizens of Venezuela, which have expressed themselves clearly and deserve a normal situation and a normal life. Let me finish by saying that I will need your help in this, because the parliamentary contacts that you have developed over the years can be crucial to pass on this message alongside my own and that of our diplomatic services. I hope that we can work together in this respect to encourage institutions to come together and face what is a very serious political, institutional, economic and, potentially, security situation in the country for the benefit of all. I would like to thank you very much for the good debate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during a plenary session in June. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – Venezuela is in a very difficult time and in Europe we are concerned: the economic situation, of insecurity and desupply of medicines and commodities, as well as the political and institutional tension put the country in a serious situation. We are joined by very strong ties with the country and we want to help make the situation better. To this end, the European Union must recommend dialogue to the Government and the National Assembly, two institutions of different political signs but both born of the democratic legitimacy commanded by the people through the polls. A sincere, constructive, loyal dialogue within the margins of the Constitution between the two institutions is crucial so that, thanks to constructive cohabitation, the Venezuelan authorities can solve the problems of the country, for the sake of the Venezuelan people. The search for agreements is the way to avoid further deterioration of the situation, as well as the holding of a new election, which neither side wants today.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. – The tragic crisis situation in all aspects of Venezuela is unsustainable. Food shortages, hospital shortages, inflation, lack of press freedom... in short, everything we have been denouncing for a long time continues to increase and leads the country adrift. Maduro's government once again betrays democracy, ignoring what the people decided at the ballot box and constantly blocking the opposition with their full control of the judiciary. There are already several resolutions that this Parliament has adopted in relation to the situation in Venezuela, but we still do not see any real changes. We must continue to support the Venezuelan people and take a stronger stance on the Government, which has plunged Venezuela into a deep social, economic and political crisis that is difficult to remedy.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – Venezuela is in a very difficult time and in Europe we are concerned: the economic situation, of insecurity and desupply of medicines and commodities, as well as the political and institutional tension put the country in a serious situation. We are joined by very strong ties with the country and we want to help make the situation better. To this end, the European Union must recommend dialogue to the Government and the National Assembly, two institutions of different political signs but both born of the democratic legitimacy commanded by the people through the polls. A sincere, constructive, loyal dialogue within the margins of the Constitution between the two institutions is crucial so that, thanks to constructive cohabitation, the Venezuelan authorities can solve the problems of the country, for the sake of the Venezuelan people.
