The search for agreements is the way to avoid further deterioration of the situation, as well as the holding of a new election, which neither side wants today.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. – I stood here some months ago with an appeal to Venezuelan politicians to discuss how respect for democracy, rule of law and civil liberties needs to be at the forefront of political development in the country. We stated that cooperation between political actors in Venezuela was the most important element of the way forward from the political crisis and that the independence of judiciary must be key.  Unfortunately, we continue to see a serious political crisis coupled with a severe economic downturn. The socioeconomic situation in the country is degrading, and we are concerned about a new wave of violent protests. People lack basic food and medicine. The violations of fundamental freedoms, including the April decision not to grant amnesty to political prisoners, remain highly alarming. Yet again, I would like to underline that Leopoldo López, one of the great figures of the Venezuelan opposition movement, and my friend, should be liberated.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item in the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the expulsion and demolition of buildings in the West Bank, including projects financed from EU funds (2016/2712(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by thanking Parliament for keeping the situation in Palestine and Israel in the spotlight at the top of our political agenda. Once again, I wonder if there is a specific reason why these strategic debates always take place in the night sessions. I hope this is not a political sign.  We all know that the lack of progress towards peace, especially in the Holy Land, is always a prelude to a new escalation, and this is why we need to keep focusing on the two-state solution, even when Israel and Palestine do not make the headlines. This is a consistent, constant EU effort to work in that direction because we all know that, on the ground, the viability of a two—state solution is challenged on a daily basis and it is our key interest and also it is our political duty to keep it alive and possible in concrete terms. The expansion of settlements challenges the two-state solution. So does the growing trend of demolitions and confiscations of Palestinian structures, including those funded by the European Union and Member States. The same goes for the worsening living conditions of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.  Let me be very clear from the outset. Demolitions and Israel’s settlement policy are not the only challenges to the two-state solution. Unfortunately, we see many different challenges taking place on the ground. Terrorist attacks and hate speech challenge the two states and the possibility of people living side by side. The lack of Palestinian unity challenges the two states and their political perspective. A growing sense of disillusionment and despair on both sides among the people is a powerful enemy of peace.  So we always need to keep in mind the bigger picture, even when we focus – as we do tonight, because this is the issue on which you decided to focus our debate tonight – on one specific element of this bigger picture that is not encouraging for many different reasons and on many different aspects. But that still does not prevent us from continuing to work every single day for the two-state solution. Today, your focus is on settlements and on the issue of demolitions. Israel’s decisions to declare more parts of Area C as state land pave the way for further settlement activity and, as you know, settlements are illegal under international law, and the European Union always refers to them in this way and restates this position.  The European Council has stated several times that our Union opposes Israel’s settlement policy. We oppose a separation barrier built beyond the 1967 line. We oppose demolitions and confiscations, evictions, forced transfers, including of Bedouins, illegal outposts, settler violence and – let me remind all of us – we oppose all forms of violence on all sides, as I mentioned before, and we oppose the restrictions of movement and access.  This is not simply because we care about international law (which we do) and respect for it (which we do), but also because these actions directly reduce the Palestinians’ ability to use the land in Area C, something which is vital to development and growth in the West Bank and to the viability of the Palestinian economy. Israel, as an occupying power, has a duty to protect the Palestinian population and to facilitate its socioeconomic well-being.  You all know that the European Union is doing a lot to promote development and improve humanitarian conditions in Palestine. However, as a result of planning policies applied by Israel, projects funded by the European Union and Member States in Area C are often deemed illegal under Israeli law and are therefore demolished or threatened with demolition by the Israeli authorities.  EU humanitarian aid always respects the principles of neutrality and impartiality. We follow the humanitarian imperative of giving support to the most vulnerable, whenever and wherever this is needed, so where humanitarian projects are concerned, it is not conceivable for us to ask for prior authorisation from the Israeli authorities. It is our humanitarian duty. In the first quarter of this year, some 500 houses and other structures were demolished, and 650 people displaced. Approximately 20% of those structures were EU-funded. We are raising the issue with Israel in our regular dialogue, and we have established a specific consultation mechanism with Israel to discuss obstacles to the two-state solution and to the socioeconomic development of the Palestinians, including the issue of settlements and the issue of demolitions in Area C.  These mechanisms were used most recently last month on this particular matter of demolitions and dislocations and the issue was also highlighted in the Council conclusions we adopted last January. Tangible results have so far been very limited. Member States have agreed to continue the dialogue for six more months while pushing for an immediate moratorium on adverse developments in Area C, especially demolitions and confiscations. We are also engaging with Member States to agree common messages on this issue, including on the possible restitution or compensation for the confiscated or demolished EU assets. Demolition of a house or a humanitarian project has of course a very strong economic impact on those involved, and also on us, but this is not just about money and we know this very well: this is about the present for the people and the future of the political settlements.  We also know very well that only a serious and meaningful peace process can lead us out of the current downward spiral. There is an urgent need to improve the situation on the ground, and at the same time we have to keep an eye on the goal. Again, let me conclude on the bigger picture, because we are focusing tonight on one aspect which is important, relevant and serious, but we have to keep focused on the bigger picture. This is something you normally ask of me, but tonight I will be asking this of you.  We continue to work on a daily basis on two states living side by side, in peace and in security, to end the conflict and all claims. You know that we are working on the report of the Quartet together with the United States, Russia and the United Nations. The Quartet report will address these issues and will also include some substantial recommendations for the way forward, and I will be very glad to discuss the report with you in the coming weeks in one of the next part-sessions, because we know very well that what is key is working at the concrete perspective of the two states and how to put that in place in the near future.  I know this sounds like a daydream today, but we need to keep that daydream alive and to turn it into reality. We know very well, as Europeans at least, that this is the only way out of the cycle that we are seeing today, and we are stubbornly working in that direction.  I know that I can count on you and on your support to do this as we focus on the parts of the problem we are seeing, but let me ask you, at one of the next part-sessions, to come back to the process itself and the European Union’s contribution, through the Quartet report, to other initiatives that are also in place and being coordinated , such as the French initiative to hold an international conference, in coordination with the work we are doing in the Quartet, on our contribution to solve the crisis in the Middle East and to revitalise the political peace process to get to a two-state solution.  Again, I know very well that we are all on the same page on this, but we need not only to make a slogan out of it, but also to translate it from a parliamentary point of view into an active, constant daily work.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, thank you for this presentation of the issue before us this evening: demolitions in the West Bank. The reality is that the problem is complicated. Indeed, under the interim Oslo agreements to which Europe is a party, Area C, where these demolitions were carried out, remains under Israel's administrative military responsibility. The Israeli authorities point out that these are illegal constructions. On the other hand, as you probably know, as you have pointed out, Israel has repeatedly criticised the European Union, saying that it is financing constructions that are illegal and which aim to create de facto realities in violation of the Oslo agreements. In any case, they insist that projects funded in Area C must be coordinated with Israel. Since I understand, from the various press reports I have seen, that the Council is preparing a strategy on the issue of demolitions that may include the idea of compensation, perhaps we should first of all think about this necessary coordination with the Israelis? This coordination already exists at the bilateral level between the State of Israel and some Member States, but it might be a good thing to expand it. With regard to the broader perspective, I find that, of course, in order to restart the peace process, trust is an indispensable element. However, I believe that the Israelis in recent months feel that it is the lack of trust that is being put forward, they are told: "We do not want to work with you." This is really unfortunate because Israel is still the only democracy in the region, we must not forget it. I know that the far left does not agree with that at all and wants to support terrorists. I find that trust without democracy is impossible.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Madam High Representative, distinguished colleagues, everything we are discussing today is not new. The demolitions of projects financed by the European Union – or also by the European Union – are recurring and the time has come to do something to prevent this, because every demolition practically demolishes the bricks of an edifice called 'peace and two-state solution'. It is important, not only because it is a waste of European citizens' money, but also to avoid the continued displacement of Palestinian families living in these areas and to ensure that European assistance goes effectively to those in need.  In the absence of a political agreement, humanitarian assistance remains imperative, but has limited potential. That is why the Union's main objective remains to bring the peace process back on the agenda, as you pointed out a few moments ago. It is necessary to support the viability of two-state solution as the only solution to end the longest conflict in the region.  That said, Israel has an obligation to comply with the rules of international humanitarian law and to halt the expansion of the colonization of these areas. Israel is our partner, one of the most important, one of the few countries with which we have complex cooperation, but Israel, as a sovereign and democratic state, also has a duty to take responsibility for its actions, by ensuring both respect for its international commitments and respect for the democratic principles that define and govern it as a state.  The European Union has done much in this region. Today it is imperative, on the one hand, to continue humanitarian aid and invest in future Palestinian state.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – By financing illegal construction projects in Area C of the West Bank, the EU is violating the 1995 Oslo Agreements it co-signed. This unilateral action by the EU, still under the cover of humanitarian aid, is a failure to recognise Israel's military and administrative powers in Area C. Not to mention the misuse of European taxpayers' money, as perceived by my electorate. That is why I urge the High Representative to immediately stop all European support for illegal construction projects in Area C. Not a word about Hamas' terror tunnels. There is also talk of the two-state solution, but then you have to tell me when Mahmoud Abbas has recognised Israel as a Jewish state, let alone Hamas. I do not hear any clarity on this from the EU side. And then talk about a two-state solution! It's more than hypocritical: it's irresponsible. It is European self-disqualification in Israel and also in the region. It is high time for political self-reflection in the midst of all the crises that plague Brussels today.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam High Representative, you yourself have outlined the framework. We are, of course, only talking about one fact today, and these are the destruction of projects financed by the European Union. We could indeed talk about many other things, but let us stick to the subject.  The European Union is an ally of Israel and we all know that. But while we are talking about stopping the destruction, there have never been so many projects destroyed. According to UN figures, 75 buildings and structures financed by Europe and EU Member States were destroyed in the first quarter of this year, which is probably only a fraction of what was actually destroyed. Everything seems - and I am very careful now - that it is a systematic policy against the Palestinians. In this way, of course, we will never achieve the two-state solution that we all so firmly support. Schools, playgrounds, wells, solar panels, everything is destroyed. It doesn't go in with me. Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain, we, the European Union, we have all given our support. But this is being destroyed with military arrogance. In the meantime, we are talking about hundreds of thousands of euros. For Belgium alone, we are talking about almost 150 000 euros. We know people are being bullied away. We know that 400 children have become homeless since this year. And yet here it remains quiet again in Europe.  Mrs Mogherini, Europe must ask that international humanitarian law be respected by both sides – let us be clear. Both sides must therefore respect it. And I would very much like to get the exact figures: what has been destroyed that we paid for and how do we deal with it? I haven't heard that here. Are we going to ask for funding or are we going to put it on the table as a condition?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in the occupied West Bank, you can almost taste the dust from demolished homes in the air. Since January this year, more than 500 Palestinian homes and other structures have been bulldozed by Israeli authorities – more than in all of 2015. These demolitions are a clear human rights violation, affecting thousands of Palestinians, and are an obstacle to peace. They are part of a deliberate strategy to displace Palestinians out of the West Bank and make way for illegal Israeli settlements. In 2014, the EU initiated a ‘structured dialogue’ with Israel, to end the demolitions within six months. In 2016, two such meetings have taken place, and Israel shows nothing but contempt for the EU and the aid given to Palestine –Israel has increased its demolitions, especially of EU-funded structures. It breaks up solar panels, flattens water tanks and bulldozes classrooms, playgrounds and basic shelter. You can almost see them sneer at you. You can almost hear them shout at you: ‘and what are you going to do about it?’ Unfortunately, they know that the answer is nothing, and it is going to be nothing in six months’ time. This outrage must stop. We have to prevent Israel from acting with impunity. It is wrong. The Palestinian people need your help, Ms Mogherini, they need more than words: they need action, and they need it now.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! Mrs Mogherini. Israeli bulldozers have smashed buildings, tents, wells, schools, playgrounds, latrines, electricity supplies, and up the ruins often waving an EU flag. Hundreds of Palestinian homes and infrastructure in the occupied West Bank have been destroyed in recent months, even on an unprecedented scale but completely unally punishable. Worse still, the forcibly displaced Palestinians are replaced by Israeli settlers.  Mrs Mogherini, the EU's response to these systematic breaches of international law and direct attacks on EU-paid projects are in fact non-existent, just words as you heard just before. The so-called 'structured dialogue' is a farce which only serves to conceal the lack of political will on the part of the European Union to do anything about the core of the problem, the occupation and the growth of settlements.  Mrs Mogherini, it is high time to end the European Union's support, political as well as economic, for Israel's occupation of Palestine. I must ask you now, at last, as others have said, to publish the whole truth about the destruction of EU projects and to demand compensation, possibly by cutting the corresponding amount of EU support for Israel's participation in Horizon 2020.  Finally, I would urge parliament to send an immediate fact-finding mission to the West Bank to assess the situation on the ground.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, are we talking about Palestine? We will have two supporters in this House: for and against Israel. Is the European Parliament a democratic body and a staunch defender of human rights? Then it must be united in demanding respect for international law, which must be applied without exception.  The UN Security Council, the International Court of Justice in The Hague and the European Union call the demolitions a clear violation of international law and call it illegal. Although the European Union has publicly called on the Israeli Government to protect the projects it supports, international cooperation projects have still been demolished or seized by Israel. The demolitions not only violate the Fourth Geneva Convention, but also seriously undermine the two-state solution, which was de facto jeopardised by the Israeli Government.  It is time for the High Representative and the European institutions to demand that damages and violations be repared. In Palestine I have seen the despair of the civilian population. But I met Breaking the Silence, an NGO of Veterans of the Israeli Army. These, with fantastic work of communication and protection of local communities, show that only with a common path of Palestinian and Israeli civil society can peace be achieved.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the High representative! Your dream, you said, is the two-state solution in Israel. And what has the European Union done in the past? It has contributed to this by mandatory labelling of products from Judea and Samaria, and has contributed to this by financing illegal buildings in Zone C. You know that Israel is still responsible for security in Zone C.  Under the current conditions, a two-state solution would be an Israeli suicide. This is due to the topography in the region, and you know that! As long as the European Union finances illegal structures in zone C in Judea and Samaria, Israeli bulldozers will roll – and they will rightly roll, Mrs Auken. And they will roll for Israel's security, and that should also be in the interests of all of us in this Parliament!

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his What is happening today in the West Bank is completely unacceptable. People's homes, children's schools and vital infrastructure are being razed to the ground. Several speakers have mentioned this. Since January this year, in just four months, more buildings in the area have been destroyed than in the whole of 2015. I would urge you to declare that the Association Council of the European Union of Israel will not be convened until Israel has ceased this massive destruction. I would urge you to demand compensation. The EU cannot watch israeli authorities pursue policies aimed at driving people out of the area, tearing down, smashing, destroying all that the EU and its Member States have helped to build through aid funds. And as Mrs Vautmans demanded: give us the facts, how much money is involved, so we know the dimension of it all. Condemning only with words is not enough when international humanitarian law is violated, then it must also have political and economic consequences. Thanks!

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians is a tragedy for over many decades. Now we debate the West Bank displacement and demolitions, including projects founded by the EU.  Nowadays, we mainly hear concerns about the Palestinians. I acknowledge that their situation is serious, but let me remind you that if two sides are fighting, both must be examined.  Hardly mentioned are the 278 attacks by Palestinians on Israelis in the last months, but the Israeli response is covered globally. Why is this? The demolitions are mainly taking place in Area C. According to the 1995 agreement, this area is under full Israeli military and administrative responsibility, which means that projects must be coordinated with the Israeli authorities. I stress that this agreement was co-signed by the European Union.  I would like to ask the High Representative: why is the EU frustrating this agreement and the peace process by promoting illegal constructions there? This sends the wrong message to both the Israeli and Palestinian people.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini, for the brilliant introduction you have given today, and of course there is nothing to add to it. I just add that it's probably not a coincidence that we're running this debate so late at night. This points to the ignorance of this house to this difficult problem.  I'm not going to talk about statistics, my colleagues have already said. I would just like to say that, of course, the home-being destroyers of Palestinian families have a reason for any violent intervention in foreign property, but from the point of view of normal, international and international humanitarian law, it is completely unacceptable.  We must condemn this practice of quasi-legal state terrorism and collective punishment. Demolishing homes is a cynical mockery of human rights and a flagrant violation of the law that cannot end well - not for Israel, not for the Palestinians, not for the region as a whole, and not for us in the neighbourhood, which we want peace and recognition for Israel and justice for Palestine.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, in the name of reason and law, the European institutions cannot allow these hundreds of houses and public facilities to be destroyed in Palestine. On the one hand, they must not accept what is illegal, that is, territorial annexation and colonization, and, on the other hand, humanitarian law prohibits depriving thousands of Palestinians, including thousands of children, of their homes. Finally, by allowing the destruction of infrastructure financed by the European Union, we agree to allow ourselves to be humiliated and despised.  Even in Israel, in society and even in the military, there is now open concern about the government's abominable abuses. So we have to take responsibility and make the Israeli state pay for the destruction. The permanent violation of international law, democracy and Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement must lead us to suspend this agreement until the State of Israel respects international common law. We must now take urgent action.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, I was last July with a delegation of MEPs in the village of Al Hadidiya, in Palestine, in Zone C. It was a village, that's what's left of it.  (The speaker shows a photo at the meeting) This is what remains of this village today: ruins, nothing, everything has been destroyed. According to the United Nations, more than 600 buildings, schools and houses have been destroyed since the beginning of the year. Much of this construction had been financed by European funds.  The European Union must stop these demolitions. It must protect the most vulnerable populations living in Area C. Israel is not a state out of time, Israel is not a state outside the law. Human rights, as the name suggests, must be respected for all civilian populations, regardless of their origin, regardless of nationality.  The European Union must act to stop these demolitions. We must be accountable and ensure that Israel repays.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, as I recalled in an op-ed co-signed with Alon Ben-Meir, a professor at New York University who specialises in the peace process, in a major evening newspaper in France, rarely has the Israeli-Palestinian conflict appeared so far from a resolution. Rarely has the despair of two peoples had such a despairing face, with this daily life of violence. Rarely has the attention of the international community been so far removed from the Palestinian issue. Yet every week, as has been said, 50 Palestinian homes are destroyed by the Israeli authorities. However, 104 European-funded facilities have been destroyed since the beginning of the year.  Madam High Representative, a majority of Israelis and Palestinians want only one thing: peace. On 30 May, you will participate in this international summit in Paris as part of the French initiative to revive the peace process and reach a two-state solution. This means ending the hate speech propagated by some of the two sides, ending colonization and destruction, changing textbooks.  That is the roadmap we need to adopt for this solution. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work High representative! Realities must be repeated! It concerns the demolition of some EU-funded tents, huts and cattle sheds for Bedouins in area C and E1 of the West Bank. All the buildings that were built there, despite being financed by the EU, on public land, without prior information from the Israeli authorities – illegally and illegally. Let us assume that this would have happened in Germany. These buildings would be demolished immediately, the funds would be reclaimed and those responsible would be brought to justice, perhaps even to prison.  That is why My question, Mrs Mogherini, is this: does the EU officially accept the breach of treaties and illegal construction in order to create facts against our close partner Israel? Does ECHO use this support to provoke the legally water-resistant Israeli response? Will the EU continue to accept that illegal buildings will be built here with subsidies, with taxpayers' money from our citizens? And provocatively asked: why is Israel so harshly criticized by the EU, despite the violence of other countries, which here takes over the unjustified judgment of the UN authorities unchecked?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, until when will the European Union remain apathetic by observing fish silence. Instead of Israel working together to find a solution, it continues the settlements, displacements of populations and destroys targeted even the roadblocks set up with European Union sponsorships. They flatten every accommodation housing Palestinians trying to survive in inhumane conditions. They are turning Palestinians into refugees again in their own homeland. Israel, through its criminal activities, demonstrates that it is turning against any attempt by the Union to support the Palestinians and that it opposes any peace effort. Let us therefore finally understand that declarations and verbal complaints of empty content are not enough. If the European Union respects its principles and declarations, it must suspend the Association Agreement until Israel ceases to violate Article 2, which clearly states the obligation to respect human rights. It is outrageous, at a time when there are so many debates about tackling the refugee crisis, that the European Union is indifferent to the Palestinians.... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: – Mr President, the increasing demolition by the Israeli authorities in Area C of Palestinian homes, schools and factories has been well documented by the EU Heads of Mission. In fact, in the first few months of 2016, more Palestinian homes have been demolished than in the whole of 2015, thus making families homeless and undermining the two-state solution. With the failure of the so-called structured dialogue clear for all to see, I believe it is time to increase the pressure for action from the Israeli Government. So will Ms Mogherini make the holding of the EU—Israel Association Council and the proposed visit of Prime Minister Netanyahu conditional on a total freeze of demolitions? Will she also publish the number and value of demolished EU projects and support Parliament’s... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, we have seen waves of demolitions and the continued cruelty of forcible transfers in the West Bank, and let us not forget Gaza. Targeting Palestinian homes and EU—maintained projects has surged to an unprecedented degree in the last few months, and this during a period of EU—Israeli dialogue aimed at halting the demolitions. These practices are banned under international law and the Israeli authorities are fully aware of this. By allowing this to carry on, we are failing the Palestinians, as well as our own citizens, who contributed to the EU-funded projects. Even more, repeated failure has brought us to the brink of risking the viability of a two—state solution. Israel must comply with international law if it wishes the EU to upgrade its relationship with it. Madam High Representative, will you make the costs of the destruction of EU-funded projects publicly available and demand financial compensation from the Israelis for the damage?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). – Mrs Mogherini, developments in the occupied territories confirm, I would say, the complete failure of European policy in the region. Zaire's criminal policy continues with settlements and demolitions in the occupied West Bank growing despair and population gridlock. This year alone it has expropriated 7.5 thousand acres in the West Bank for settlement and Europe is watching as a spectator. Mr Netanyahu clearly tells you that he is destroying European Union-funded humanitarian structures because they were built, he says, illegally and you behave as if you don't care. And you're telling us that you're in favor of a two-state solution? Really, tell me, on what territory will the Palestinian state be created? You realize, I guess, there won't be anything left in a while. You started a structured dialogue and set a deadline of six months. It's been a month since the deadline and you haven't achieved anything. And I wonder, what else does Israel have to do to sanction it and activate the human rights clauses, which you have an obligation to defend in accordance with the treaties of the European Union and which, it seems, you have as decorative association agreements?

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Mr President, if I had not experienced it with my own eyes, I probably would not have believed it: in March of this year, I visited the West Bank with some fellow MEPs. Whoever we talked to, frustration and desperation was everywhere – frustration over the stalled peace process and desperation as the situation of the Palestinians had worsened over the years. But what really angered us was the random destruction of community structures that were built, or at least financed, by the European Union. I will leave out the numbers because they have been mentioned here before. The Bedouins we talked to showed us the remnants of their tents with even the EU symbols almost beyond recognition. Madam High Representative, I would like to know how vigorously you will demand from the Israeli Government compensation to the European Union and an end to that policy.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, it is clear that the expulsions and systematic demolition of basic homes and structures in the occupied West Bank are part of a comprehensive Israeli strategy against the Palestinian people and their viability as a state. EU-funded projects were already massively bombed in Gaza and member states' reaction was ridiculous. This incapable attitude also leads to the European Union remaining silent in the face of the daily deaths of the Israeli blockade against Gaza. Mrs Mogherini, your words reflect that the Commission is aware that what has been done and said so far has done no good, and you yourself have just stressed that it is not enough to proclaim slogans, that concrete action is needed. Well, Mr Anderson and Auken, and a few more have already said this: it is time to end Israeli impunity.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, first of all, I wanted to thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your commitment to the Middle East and the energy you put into it, particularly in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I fully share your objective of trying, by all means, to facilitate the peace process and to reach a two-state solution. What we are dealing with today, as you said, is part of the various challenges we have in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, namely the destruction of these infrastructures - basic infrastructure - financed by the European Union in The Palestinian territories. It is strange to hear some of our colleagues here who are struggling to come to terms with the fact that it is not these infrastructures that are illegal, it is the settlements that are illegal and which must be stopped. And so I find it illegal to have the humanitarian infrastructure paid by us to meet the needs of the Palestinians, I find that totally indecent. So all we are asking you to do , and we support you in this direction - is to re-establish dialogue and take sanctions if necessary, or even to obtain financial compensation.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, last month I was in the West Bank, Jerusalem and Hebron. I have been alarmed by the explosive environment and the despair of the Palestinian people, disbelieving of the Peace Process, the leadership itself, the two-state solution — which everyone considers already unfeasible in the face of the policy of settlements, forced displacement, demolitions, military repression and humiliation pursued, cruelly stupidly, by Israel — not to mention Gaza, prison in the open. There is nothing better to promote the radicalisation of Palestinian youth and children. In the Bedouin community of Al Hadidiya, in the Jordan Valley, and elsewhere, I have seen Projects funded by the European Union systematically destroyed by Israel. Ms Mogherini, how do you assess the outcome of the structured EU-Israel dialogue, which should freeze demolitions when they have increased? Have you ever asked Israel for compensation for the damage that the demolitions and confiscation of STRUCTURES financed by the European Union entail to European taxpayers? Will the cost of this destruction go public? We will pay dearly, in our own safety, these and other costs of the European Union not acting and letting the Peace Process die.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we have had a surreal debate in this House today: instead of talking about the 34 Israelis who have been killed by violence throughout this period, we have been discussing something else. Instead of talking about the cement that is systematically stolen by Hamas to finance the construction of the terror tunnel, we have dealt with something else. Instead of talking about those terrible images shown on television, about Palestinian children being trained to use the knife to hit the Israelis, we dealt with something else.  It is clear that when there is anti-Semitism there is terrorism, and the European Union must be aware that whenever anti-Semitism develops and is fuelled, terrorism develops. So let us deal with serious matters: let us take care of what the Israeli people are experiencing at this time, let us deal with the 34 Israelis who have been killed in recent weeks.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, in a few days’ time Israelis will mark their annual National Memorial Day for victims of the conflict and their 68th Independence Day, so it is a good time to reflect on the state of play. The Israeli Government has demolished hundreds of Palestinian homes, schools and clinics in recent months, leaving thousands of Palestinians homeless and under pressure to relocate. Israeli NGOs who report on human rights abuses oppose the occupation and advocate peace. They find themselves under pressure from the government and right-wing groups. In the meantime, the Israeli Government plans to expand settlements in strategic areas like E1 outside Jerusalem and E2 near Bethlehem, which will block off Palestinian communities and threaten the viability of the two-state solution, putting both Palestine and Israel at risk. So the EU must make clear that the two-state solution is a red line, demand a stop to these demolitions and request full compensation for the damage caused to EU infrastructures.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, given the daily and growing violation of human rights that we are seeing in the West Bank, it is necessary to find an immediate solution to the Palestinian issue. This year alone, the Israeli army has completely destroyed some four hundred houses and other buildings built with European Union funds in the West Bank, and recently demolished a school in the region, which means that twenty-three children will no longer go to school. In addition, the Israeli army is proceeding with the seizure of Palestinian territory and restricting the movements of those living in the occupied territories. At the same time, population displacements in the region are persistent, while the Palestinian population in the West Bank faces severe water shortages because most of this water is used by Israel and Israeli settlers. It is therefore necessary to resolve the Palestinian problem immediately so that we have a viable solution in the Middle East as well. The European Union should increase funds to combat poverty in the region, create jobs and defend human rights in the region.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European civil society has long demanded that the institutions be accountable and establish a concrete action plan with the aim of ending the occupation and achieving a just and lasting solution to the apartheid situation suffered by the Palestinian people. We call on the High Representative to demand that the Government of Israel immediately stop evictions and forced transfers, the indiscriminate destruction of Palestinian property, as well as the expansion of Israeli settler settlements in the West Bank.  Finally, we call for the clear positioning of the Member States and the European Commission in all cases where the Israeli authorities are demolishing humanitarian structures, built within the framework of money-financed projects by European taxpayers. Constant violations of human rights and international law cannot continue to be received with the complicit silence of the European institutions. Apply sanctions, do...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President; Mrs Mogherini, you told us two years ago that your top priority was the Israel-Palestine conflict. He said it right here after the first visit he made there. The results seem to be more than clear: more territorial annexations, more violence, more misery and the European Union made a fool of itself. EU-funded projects are destroyed at a pace like never before. What is illegal is not schools built by the European Union; what is illegal are the weapons and bulldozers that destroy them. But with your statement here today, it seems to me that what you are doing is to raise minutes of failure, not your staff, yes to the European Union. I was there too, in the Bedouin camps. I am not surprised at General Dov Sedaka's recent statement, when he said that the solution for Bedouins is not to regularize their status, but to demolish their camps and move them to Palestinian-controlled Zones A and B. Today, the European Union silently allows the continued deployment of new settlements, openly at odds with international law. What are we going to do? Endorse apartheid impunity or act...? (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, High Representative, for coming and listening to us. I was in Palestine last year and I must say I was shocked. Not only because entire houses, entire infrastructures have been arbitrarily destroyed by the Israeli military – no, the prisons in Israel are full of children and young people – I repeat: children and young people. When I was there, a teenager was shot from behind on the run for allegedly throwing a stone at a vehicle, presumably an armored vehicle. This is an extrajudicial execution. The shooter was celebrated like a hero in the Knesset. I would like to ask you, ladies and gentlemen: we cannot conclude privileged agreements with a state that does such things, we cannot supply military materials as EU states. We must be consistent if any values are still sacred to our House.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me say that, on one side, I am honoured that some of you in this room think that, in a year and a half in office, I would have been able to solve the oldest and most complicated conflict in the Middle East, and maybe in the entire world. I wish that could have been possible. I do not put limits on what could happen in the next three and a half years of my mandate – hopefully we will manage to move forward – but this tells us a lot about the fact that we have to keep focused and consistent in what we are doing. The European Union has a special role to play in the Middle East, not only because we are the first donor to the Palestinians and not only because we are the first trading partner to the Israelis, but because we are, I would be tempted to say, the only political actor that is constantly and so passionately focusing on this conflict – let us say that we are among the few in the world doing that – and because we have a special role that comes from our history and our geography. That is why I am a little saddened every time that we have a debate on Israel and Palestine in this Hemicycle, when I see that we easily divide ourselves between those who take one side and those who take the other side. I will be very clear on our principles, our firm positions and our firm actions. I believe that they are not negotiable and they are our strengths, but I also believe that we have to keep clear in our minds what our role is. Our role is that of trying to build bridges, trying to encourage those who still, inside Palestine and inside Israel and inside their societies, inside their political camps – and there are fewer and fewer by the day unfortunately – believe that peace can only result from Israelis and Palestinians working together and living together. This was self-evident in the time of the Oslo Agreement. I am of the generation that grew up politically with the Oslo narrative. I see very clearly that today we are facing the risk of generations of Israelis and Palestinians growing up – not only politically but in their own societies – considering this not to be normal, the idea of Israelis and Palestinians working together for peace.  I think that, as Europeans and as Europeans in institutions, we have a special responsibility in trying to help and in trying to facilitate. That is why I would like to thank those of you who took part in the Parliamentarians for Peace initiative, bringing together MEPs and members of the Israeli and Palestinian Parliaments to try and encourage them to bring forward an agenda for peace together because we are – and I remember that we have already discussed this, exactly in these terms, on another occasion in recent months – those who do not see problems but, on the contrary, see it as natural to say that we can – and we must – be friends of the Palestinian people and friends of the Israeli people. There is no contradiction in that because, as friends, we can advise, we can encourage and we can push – sometimes with more diplomatic words, sometimes with a tougher insistences – them to come together on the way towards peace. Indeed, some of you said that we have to preserve the confidence of the parties in the role of the European Union. I want to share with you – especially as a colleague mentioned the lack of confidence on the Israeli side – something that happened yesterday that to me was very important. The President of Israel, President Rivlin, came to the Europe Day celebration in the delegation of the European Union in Israel and passed on extremely positive and encouraging messages about the fact that, even on the things on which we do not see eye to eye, we can work hand in hand to move forward. I think that we have to pay attention to these kinds of messages and try to work on building bridges. Having said that – which is our political responsibility – our policy is crystal clear and evident to both the Israelis and the Palestinians. Time and again, we have demonstrated that there is a European unity on this position so that any attempt to divide Member States or institutions of the European Union does not work. I mentioned a few of the issues that are clear and firm for us: clearly, the fact that we oppose any kind of violence and hate speech, clearly, the fact that we oppose the settlement policy and, clearly, the fact that we consider our projects, funded by the European Union budget and by the Member States budget, as taking place under the humanitarian imperative. Our aid always respects the principles of neutrality and impartiality. As I mentioned, we follow the humanitarian imperative of giving support to the most vulnerable, whenever, whatever and wherever this is needed, and this is something we will not give up. This is our firm principle and our firm practice. We are also – as I mentioned in the beginning, but I noticed that many of you raised this so I will mention it again – working with the Member States on the steps forward, including on the possible restitution or compensation for confiscated or demolished EU assets. I stress that fact that we need to work, in this respect, together with all the Member States, building and keeping the unity of our Union because this is the point of strength that we have in every single step we take. Let me finish by saying that I really believe that the way forward for us is investing in the mechanisms and structures that we have in order to work together in a constant dialogue, both with the Palestinian Authority and with the Israeli authorities. That is why when some of you asked me for an assessment of the mechanisms we have put in place, I was very glad that we managed to put in place these mechanisms because, especially when you have difficult problems to discuss, you need institutional frameworks to do so in transparency, in clarity, in respect and with firm positions which sometimes we do not share with our Israeli friends. As many of you mentioned, the real point will be our capacity to bring forward the agenda for peace, which means the agenda for the two states. That might not mean the creation of two states in the next year and a half – I cannot promise that – but what I can tell you is that the work we are doing with the Quartet – which, I would like to remind you, a year and a half ago when we took office was basically not operative – is up and running , with the production and the work on the report that I also mentioned which will include substantial references to this issue in accordance with the work that we are doing with the US, the UN and Russia and in connection with some of the Arab countries, our partners, especially on the Arab peace initiative elements and including some elements of recommendation that , at that stage, the international community could put forward to the parties. Again, there is no magic wand and there is no magic solution that from one day to the next can create the two states but, when I see the trend of work that we have revitalised, re-energised, restarted in the last year and a half, together with our partners in the international community, I am confident of the fact that this could lead us , together with the parties, to some positive developments. I know that saying this today can seem very, very optimistic, but I think that if we are not guided by the hope of changing things, we will never manage to change things for real. So again I ask you to come together, as much as you can, in your efforts to facilitate this work, knowing that we have a special responsibility to the Palestinians and to the Israelis.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. – Last June I saw at first hand the impact of demolitions and demolition orders in the West Bank. With colleagues from the EFA Group I met people in Silwan in East Jerusalem who are being forced out of their home-district. Displacements and demolitions are on the increase. The EU has provided humanitarian aid and funding to threatened communities in the West Bank, only to see projects destroyed by the occupying forces. Compensation should be paid for this destruction. EU humanitarian activities and assistance are carried out in full compliance with international humanitarian law and humanitarian principles. Many of my constituents in Wales have raised this issue with me to demand action.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The humanitarian situation in Area C of the West Bank, which is under israeli civilian and military control, has deteriorated significantly. This year only, 522 houses and other basic structures such as pens, wells and cisterns have been destroyed or confiscated. Humanitarian partners report numerous cases where deliveries of necessities are requisitioned. Since the resumption of the eu-Israel structured dialogue in March 2016, 170 Palestinian structures have been prevented, including 49 projects funded by the EU, among others. Demolition orders issued threaten another 2,000 structures in Area C funded by European taxpayers. I would like to stress that EU humanitarian action is carried out in accordance with international humanitarian law. They aim to deliver humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable people. Further damage should be stopped and losses to be compensated. The population living in these areas must be provided with stable and decent living conditions. I hope that the JUNE EU-Israel meeting in the framework of the structured dialogue will be a new opening and will contribute to a solution to this difficult humanitarian situation in line with international standards.
